div1.head: A

div2.entryFree:
alphabetical letter A A A^ A_ |
The first letter of the alphabet [according to the order in which the letters are now commonly disposed; and also according to the original order, which see in art. Abjd]: called A^alifN. [This name, like most of the other names of Arabic letters, is traceable to the Phœnician language, in which it signifies “an ox;” the ancient Phœnician form of the letter thus called being a rude representation of an ox's head.] It is, of all the letters, that which is most frequent in speech: and some say that, in A=l=m=, in the Kur [ch. ii. &c.], it is a name of God. (TA.) Its name is properly fem., as is also that of every other letter; [and hence its pl. is A^alifaAtN;] but it may be made masc.: so says Ks: Sb says that all the letters of the alphabet are masc. and fem., like as Al~isaAnN is masc. and fem. (M.) As a letter of the alphabet, it is abbreviated, [or short, and is written A, as it also is generally when occurring in a word, except at the end, when, in certain cases, it is written Y,] and is pronounced with a pause after it: and it is also prolonged: (S, K, * TA:) [in the latter case, it is written A='N; and] this is the case when it is made a subst.: and when it is not called a letter, [i. e. when one does not prefix to it the word Harof,] it is [properly] fem. (S.) Its dim. is A^uyay~apN, meaning an A' written small, or obscure, (S, IB,) according to those who make it fem. and who say, zay~ayatu zaAyFA and *ay~alotu *aAlFA; but A^uway~apN according to those who say, zaw~ayotu zaAyFA. (IB.) -A2- A^alifN [properly so called] is one of the letters of prolongation and of softness and of augmentation; the letters of augmentation being ten, which are comprised in the saying, Alyawoma tanosaAhu [“to-day thou wilt forget it”]. (S.) There are two species of Alf; namely, lay~inapN [or soft], and mutaHar~ikapN [or movent]; the former of which is [properly] called A^alifN; and the latter, hamozapN; (S, TA;) which is a faucial letter, pronounced in the furthest part of the fauces [by a sudden emission of the voice after a total suppression, so that it resembles in sound a feebly-uttered E whence the form of the character (') whereby it is represented]: but this latter is sometimes tropically called Alf; and both [as shown above] are of the letters of augmentation. (S in art. Aw, and TA.) There are also two other species of Alf; namely, A^alifu waSolK [the alif of conjunction or connexion, or the conjunctive or connexive alif]; and A^alifu qaToEK [the alif of disjunction, or the disjunctive alif]; every one that is permanent in the connexion of words being of the latter species; and that which is not permanent, [i. e. which is not pronounced, unless it is an alif of prolongation,] of the former species; and this is without exception augmentative; [but it is sometimes a substitute for a suppressed radical letter, as in A@bonN, originally banaYN or banawN;] whereas the alif of disjunction is sometimes augmentative, as in the case of the interrogative alif [to be mentioned below, and in other cases]; and sometimes radical, as in A^axa*a and A^amara: (S, TA:) or, according to Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà and Mohammad Ibn-Yezeed, (T, TA,) the primary A^alifaAt are three; the rest being subordinate to these: namely, A^alifN A^aSoliy~apN [radical alif], (T, K, TA,) as in A_ilofN and A^akala (T) and A^axa*a; (K;) and A^alifN qaToEiyapN [disjunctive alif], as in A^aHomadu (T, K) and A^aHomaru (T) and A^aHosana; (T, K;) and A^alifN waSoliy~apN [conjunctive or connexive alif], (T, K,) as in A@sotaxoraAjN (T) and A@sotaxoraja. (T, K.) ― -b2- The A^alif which is one of the letters of prolongation and of softness is called AlA^alifu AlhaAdiy^apu [the quiescent alif, and AlA^alifu Als~aAkinapu, which signifies the same]: (MF, TA:) it is an aerial letter, (Mughnee, MF, TA,) merely a sound of prolongation after a fet-hah; (T, TA;) and cannot have a vowel, (IB, Mughnee, MF,) wherefore it cannot commence a word: (Mughnee:) when they desire to make it movent, if it is converted from w or Y, they restore it to its original, as in EaSawaAni and raHayaAni; and if it is not converted from w or Y, they substitute for it hemzeh, as in rasaAy^ilu, in which the hemzeh is a substitute for the A in [the sing.] rasaAlapN. (IB.) IJ holds that the name of this letter is laA, [pronounced lá or lé, without, or with, imáleh, like the similar names of other letters, as baA and tA and vaA &c.,] and that it is the letter which is mentioned [next] before Y in reckoning the letters; the l being prefixed to it because it cannot be pronounced at the beginning of its name, as other letters can, as, for instance, S and j; and he adds that the teachers [in schools] err in pronouncing its name laAma A@lifo. (Mughnee.) ― -b3- The grammarians have other particular appellations for alifs, which will be here mentioned. (T, TA.) ― -b4- AlA^alifu Almajohuwlapu [The unknown alif] is such as that in faAEilN [or faAEala] and faAEuwlN; i. e., every A, (T, K,) of those having no original [from which they are converted, not being originally A^ nor w nor Y, but being merely a formative letter, and hence, app., termed “unknown”], (T,) inserted for the purpose of giving fulness of sound to the fet-hah in a verb and in a noun; (T, K;) and this, when it becomes movent, becomes w, as in the case of xaAtamN and xawaAtimu, becoming w in this case because it is movent, and followed by a quiescent A, which A is the A of the pl., and is also mjhwlp. (T.) ― -b5- A^alifaAtu Almad~aAti [The alifs of prolongations] are such as those [which are inserted for the same purpose of giving fulness of sound to the fet-hah] in kalokaAlN, for kalokalN, and xaAtaAmN, for xaAtamN, and daAnaAqN, for daAnaqN. (T, K.) In like manner, w is inserted after a dammeh, as in A^anoZuwru; and Y after a kesreh, as in $iymaAlN. (TA.) An alif of this species is also called A^alifu AlA_i$obaAEi [The alif added to give fulness of sound to a fet-hah preceding it]: and so is the alif in manaA used in imitation [of a noun in the accus. case; as when one says, raA^ayotu rajulFA (pronounced rajulaA) “I saw a man,” and the person to whom these words are addressed says, manaA Whom?]. (Mughnee.) ― -b6- A^alifu AlS~ilapi [The alif of annexation, or the annexed alif,] is that which is an annex to the fet-hah of a rhyme, (T, K,) and to that of the fem. pronoun haA: in the former case as in
baAnato suEaAdu waA^amosaY HaboluhaA A@noqaTaEaA
in which A is made an annex to the fet-hah of the E [of the rhyme]; and in the saying in the Kur [xxxiii. 10], wataZun~uwna biA@ll~`hi AlZ~unuwnaA, in which the A after the last n is an annex to the fet-hah of that n; and in other instances in the final words of verses of the Kur-án, as qawaAriyra and salosabiylaA [in lxxvi. 15 and 18]: in the other case as in DarabotuhaA and mararotu bihaA. (T.) The difference between it and A^alifu AlwaSoli is, that the latter is in the beginnings of nouns and verbs, and the former is in the endings of nouns [and verbs]. (T, K.) It is also called A^alifu AlA_iTolaAqi [The alif of unbinding, because the vowel ending a rhyme prevents its being muqay~d, i. e. “bound” by the preceding consonant]: (Mughnee;) and A^alifu AlfaASilapi [the alif of the final word of a verse of poetry or of a verse of the Kur-án or of a clause of rhyming prose]. (TA.) [This last appellation must not be confounded with that which here next follows.] ― -b7- AlA^alifu AlfaASilapi [The separating alif] is the A which is written after the w of the pl. to make a separation between that w and what follows it, as in $akaruwA (T, K) and kafaruwA, and in the like of yagozuwA and yadoEuwA [and yaroDawoA]; but when a pronoun is affixed to the verb, this A, being needless, does not remain: (T:) also the A which makes a separation between the n which is a sign of the fem. gender and the heavy [or doubled] n [in the corroborated form of the aor. and imperative], (T, K,) because a triple combination of n is disliked, (T,) as in [yafoEalonaAn~i and tafoEalonaAn~i and] AifoEalonaAn~i (T, K) and laA tafoEalonaAn~i. (T.) ― -b8- A^alifu Aln~uwni Alxafiyfapi [The alif of the light, or single, noon in the contracted corroborated form of the aor. and imperative], as in the phrase in the Kur [xcvi. 15], lanasofaEFA biAln~aASiyapi [explained in art. sfE], (T, K,) and the phrase [in xii. 32], walayakuwnFA mina AlS~aAgiriyna [And he shall assuredly be of those in a state of vileness, or ignominy], in both of which instances the pause is made with A [only, without tenween, so that one says lanasofaEaA and layakuwnaA, and this seems to be indicated in Expositions of the Kur-án as the proper pronunciation of these two words in the phrases here cited, the former of which, and the first word of the latter,
I find thus written in an excellent copy of the Mughnee, with a fet-hah only instead of tenween, though I find them written in copies of the Kur-án and of the K with tenween, and for this reason only I have written them therewith in the first places above], this A being a substitute for the light n, which is originally the heavy n: and among examples of the same is the saying of El-Aashà,
walaAtaHomida Almuvoriyna waA@ll~`ha faA@HomadaA
[And praise not thou the opulent, but God do thou praise], the poet meaning faA@Homadano, but pausing with an A: (T:) and accord. to 'Ikrimeh Ed-Dabbee, in the saying of Imra-el-Keys,
qafaA naboki mino *ikary HabiybK wamanozili
[what is meant is, Do thou pause that we may weep by reason of the remembrance of an object of love, and of a place of abode, for] the poet means qifano, but substitutes A for the light n; (TA;) or, accord. to some, qfA is in this case [a dual] addressed to the poet's two companions. (EM p. 4.) ― -b9- A^alifu AlEiwaDi [The alif of exchange] is that which is substituted for the tenween (T, K) of the accus. case when one pauses upon it, (T,) as in raA^ayotu zayodaA (T, K [and so in the copy of the Mughnee mentioned above, but in the copies of the T I find zayodFA,]) and faEalotu xayoraA and the like. (T.) ― -b10- A^alifu Alt~aEaAyiY [The alif of inability to express what one desires to say], (T,) or A^alifa AltagaAbiY [the alif of feigning negligence or heedlessness], (K,) [but the former is evidently, in my opinion, the right appellation,] is that which is added when one says A_in~a Eumara, and then, being unable to finish his saying, pauses, saying A_in~a EumaraA, [in the CK EumaraA=,] prolonging it, desiring to be helped to the speech that should reveal itself to him, (T, K,) and at length saying munoTaliqN, meaning to say, if he were not unable to express it, A_in~a Eumara munoTilaqN [Verily 'Omar is going away]. (T.) The A in a case of this kind is [also] said to be lilt~a*ak~uri [for the purpose of endeavouring to remember]; and in like manner, w, when one desires to say, yaquwmu zayodN, and, forgetting zyd, prolongs the sound in endeavouring to remember, and says yaquwmuw. (Mughnee in the sections on A and w.) It is also added to a curtailed proper name of a person called to, or hailed, as in yaA EumaA for yaA Eumaru [which is an ex. contrary to rule, as Eumaru is masc. and consists of only three letters]. (T.) ― -b11- A^alifu Aln~udobapi [The alif of lamentation], as in waA zayodaAho [Alas, Zeyd!], (T, K,) i. e. the A after the d; (T;) and one may say waA zayodaA, without the h of pausation. (Alfeeyeh of Ibn-Málik, and I 'Ak p. 272.) ― -b12- A^alifu AlA@isotinokaAri [The alif of disapproval], (T,) or AlA^alifu liloA_inokaAri [which means the same], (Mughnee,) is similar to that next preceding, as in A^aA^abuw EumaraAh~ [What! Aboo- 'Omar?] in reply to one who says, “Aboo-'Omar came;” the h being added in this case after the letter of prolongation like as it is in waA fulaAnaAho said in lamentation. (T.) [The ex. given in the Mughnee is A= EamoraAho, as said in reply to one who says, “I met 'Amr;” and thus I find it written, with A=; but this is a mistranscription of the interrogative A^a, which see below.] In this case it is only added to give fulness of sound to the vowel; for you say, A^alr~ajuluwho [What! the man? for A^aA@lr~ajuluwho,] after one has said “The man stood;” and A^alr~ajulaAho in the accus. case; and A^alr~ajuliyho in the gen. case. (Mughnee in the section on w. [But in my copy of that work, in these instances, the incipient A, which is an A of interrogation, is written A=.]) ― -b13- AlA^alifu Almunoqalibapu Eano yaA='i AlA_iDaAfapi [The alif that is converted from the affixed pronoun Y], as in yaA gulaAmaA A^aqobilo [O my boy, advance thou,] for yaA gulaAmiY; (TA in art. Hrz;) [and yaAEajabaA lizayodK (I 'Ak p. 271) O my wonder at Zeyd! for yA EajabiY lzyd;] and in yaA A^abataA for yaA A^abatiY, and yaA wayolataA for yaA wayolatiY, and yaAbiA^abaA and yaA biA^abaAho for yaA biA^abiY (T and TA in art. bA^.) [This is sometimes written Y, but preceded by a fet-hah.] ― -b14- AlA^alifu AlmuHaw~alapu [The transmuted alif, in some copies of the K A^alifu AlmuHaw~alapi, which, as MF observes, is put for the former,] is every A that is originally w or Y (T, K) movent, (T,) as in qaAla [originally qawala], and baAEa [originally bayaEa], (T, K,) and gazaA [originally gazawa], and qaDaY [originally qaDaY], and the like of these. (T.) ― -b15- A^alifu Altavoniyapi [The alif of the dual, or rather, of dualization], (T, K,) in verbs, (TA,) as in yajolisaAni and ya*ohabaAni, (T, K,) and in nouns, (T,) as in Alz~ayodaAni (T, K) and AlEamoraAni; (T;) [i. e.] the A which in verbs is a dual pronoun, as in faEalaA and yafuEalaAni, and in nouns a sign of the dual and an indication of the nom. case, as in rajulaAni. (S.) ― -b16- It is also indicative of the accus. case, as in raA^ayotu faAhu [I saw his mouth]. (S.) ― -b17- A^alifu AljamoEi [The alif of the plural, or of pluralization], as in masaAjidu and jibaAlN (T, K) and furosaAnN and fawaAEilu. (T.) ― -b18- A^alifu Alt~aA^oniyvi [The alif denoting the fem. gender], as in HubolaY (Mughnee, K) and sakoraY [in which it is termed maqoSuwrap shortened], and the meddeh in HamoraA='u (K) and bayoDaA='u and nufasaA='u [in which it is termed mamoduwdap lengthened]. (TA.) ― -b19- A^alifu AlA_iloHaAqi [The alif of adjunction, or quasi-coordination; that which renders a word an adjunct to a particular class, i. e. quasi-coordinate to another word, of which the radical letters are more in number than those of the former word, (see the sentence next following,)], (Mughnee, TA,) as in A^aroTFA (Mughnee) [or A^aroTFY; and the meddeh in EilobaA='N &c.]. ― -b20- A^alifu Altakoviyri [The alif of multiplication, i. e. that merely augments the number of the letters of a word without making it either fem. or quasi-coordinate to another, unaugmented, word], as in qabaEovaraY (Mughnee, TA) [correctly qabaEovarFY], in which the A [here written Y] is not to denote the fem. gender, (S and K in art. qbEvr,) because its fem. is qabaEovaraApN, as Mbr. says; (S and TA in that art.;) nor to render it quasi-coordinate to another word, (K and TA in that art.,) as is said in the Lubáb, because there is no noun of six radical letters to which it can be made to be so; but accord. to Ibn-Málik, a word is sometimes made quasi-coordinate to one comprising augmentative letters, as AiqoEanosasa is to AiHoranojama. (TA in that art.) -A3- A^alifaAtu AlwaSoli [The alifs of conjunction or connexion, or the conjunctive or connexive alifs], (T, K,) which are in the beginnings of nouns, (T,) [as well as in certain well-known cases in verbs,] occur in A@bonN (T, K) and A@bonumN (K) and A@bonapN and A@vonaAni and A@vonataAni and A@moruw^N and A@moraA^apN and A@somN and A@sotN, (T, K,) which have a kesreh to the A when they commence a sentence, [or occur alone, i. e., when immediately preceded by a quiescence,] but it is elided when they are connected with a preceding word, (T,) [by which term “word” is included a particle consisting of a single letter with its vowel,] and A@yomunN and A@yomu [and variations thereof, which have either a fet-hah or a kesreh to the A when they commence a sentence, or occur alone], (K,) and in the article A@lo, the A of which has a fet-hah when it commences a sentence. (T.) -A4- A^alifu AlqaToEi [The alif of disjunction, or the disjunctive alif,] is in the beginnings of sing. nouns and of pl. nouns: it may be known by its permanence in the dim., and by its not being a radical letter: thus it occurs in A^aHosanu, of which the dim. is A^uHayosinu: (I Amb, T:) in pls. it occurs in A^alowaAnN and A^azowaAjN (I Amb, T, K) and A^alosinapN [&c.]: (I Amb, T:) [it also occurs in verbs of the measure A^afoEala, as A^akorama; in which cases it is sometimes lils~alobi, i. e. privative, (like the Greek alpha,) as in A^aqosaTa “he did away with injustice,” which is termed qusuwTN and qasoTN, inf. ns. of qasaTa:] it is distinguished from the radical A, as shown above: (I Amb, T:) or it is sometimes augmentative, as the interrogative A^a [to be mentioned below]; and sometimes radical, as in A^axa*a and A^amara; and is thus distinguished from the conjunctive A, which is never other than augmentative. (S.) ― -b2- A^alifu Alt~afoDiyli wa Alt~aqoSiyri [The alif denoting excess and deficiency, i. e., denoting the comparative and superlative degrees], as in fulaAnN A^akoramu minoka [Such a one is more generous, or noble, than thou], (T, K, *) and A^aloA^amu minoka [more ungenerous, or ignoble, than thou], (T,) and A^ajohalu Aln~aAsi [the most ignorant of men]. (T, K. *) ― -b3- A^alifu AlEibaArapi [The alif of signification], (T, K,) as though, (T,) or because, (TA,) significant of the speaker, (T, TA,) also called AlEaAmilapi [the operative], as in A^anaA A^asotagofiru A@ll~`ha [I beg forgiveness of God], (T, K,) and A^anaA A^afoEalu ka*aA [I do thus]. (T.) ― -b4- A^alifu AlA@isotifohaAmi [The alif of interrogation, or the interrogative alif], (T, S, Msb in art. hmz, Mughnee,) as in A^azayodN qaAy^imN [Is Zeyd standing?], (Mughnee,) and A^azayodN Einodaka A^amo EamorNw [Is Zeyd with thee, or at thine abode, or 'Amr?], (S,) and A^aqaAma zayodN [Did Zeyd stand?], said when the asker is in ignorance, and to which the answer is laA or naEamo; (Msb;) and in a negative phrase, as A^alamo na$oraHo [Did we not dilate, or enlarge? in the Kur xciv. 1]. (Mughnee.)
When this is followed by another hemzeh, an A is interposed between the two hemzehs, [so that you say A^aAA^anota, also written A=A^anota,] as in the saying of Dhu-r-Rummeh,
A^ayaA Zaboyapa AlwaEosaA='a bayona jalaAjilK
wabayona Aln~aqaA A^aAA^anoti A^amo A^um~u saAlimi
[O thou doe-gazelle of El-Waasà between Jelájil and the oblong gibbous hill of sand, is it thou, or Umm-Sálim?]; (T, S;) but some do not this. (T.) [It is often conjoined with A_in~a, as in the Kur xii. 90, A^ay^in~aka laA^anota yuwsufu Art thou indeed Joseph?] It is sometimes used to make a person acknowledge, or confess, a thing, (T, Msb in art. hmz, Mughnee,) and to establish it, (Msb,) as in the phrase in the Kur [v. 116], A^aA^anota qulota liln~aAsi or A=A^anota [Didst thou say to men?], (T,) and A^alamo na$oraHo [explained above], (Msb in art. hmz,] and in A^aDarabota zayodFA or A^aA^anota Darabota [Didst thou beat Zeyd?], and A^azayodFA Darabota [Zeyd didst thou beat?]. (Mughnee.) And for reproving, (T, Mughnee,) as in the phrase in the Kur [xxxvii. 153], A^SoTafaY A@lobanaAti EalaY A@lobaniyna [Hath He chosen daughters in preference to sons?], (T,) [but see the next sentence,] and [in the same ch., verse 93,] A^ataEobuduwna maA tanoHituwna [Do ye worship what ye hew out?]. (Mughnee.) And to express a nullifying denial, as in [the words of the Kur xvii. 42,] A^afaA^aSofaAkumo rab~akumo biA@lobaniyna waA@t~axa*a mina A@lomalaAy^ikapi A_inaAvFA [Hath then your Lord preferred to give unto you sons, and gotten for himself, of the angels, daughters?]. (Mughnee.) And to denote irony, as in [the Kur xi. 89,] A^aSalawaAtuka taA^omuruka A^ano natoruka maA yaEobudu A=baAw^unaA [Do thy prayers enjoin thee that we should leave what our fathers worshipped?]. (Mughnee.) And to denote wonder, as in [the Kur xxv.47,] A^alamo tara A_ilaY rab~ika kayofa mad~a A@lZ~il~a [Hast thou not considered the work of thy Lord, how He hath extended the shade?]. (Mughnee.) And to denote the deeming a thing slow, or tardy, as in [the Kur lvii., 15,] A^alamo yaA^oni lil~*iyna A=manuwA [Hath not the time yet come for those who have believed?]. (Mughnee.) And to denote a command, as in [the Kur iii. 19,] A^aA^asolamotumo, meaning A^asolimuwA [Enter ye into the religion of El-Islám]. (Mughnee, and so Jel.) And to denote equality, occurring after sawaA='N and maA A^ubaAliY and maA A^adoriY and layota $iEoriY, and the like, as in [the Kur lxiii.6,] sawaA='N Ealayohimo A^asotagofarota lahumo A^amo lamo tasotagofiro lahumo [It will be equal to them whether thou beg forgiveness for them or do not beg forgiveness for them], and in ,aA A^ubaAliY A^aqumota A^amo qaEadota [I care not whether thou stand or sit]: and the general rule is this, that it is the hemzeh advening to a phrase, or proposition, of which the place may be supplied by the inf. n. of its verb; for one may say, sawaA='N Ealayohimu A@lA@isotigofaAru waEadamuhu [Equal to them will be the begging of forgiveness and the not doing so], and maA A^abaAliY biqiyaAmika waEadamihi [I care not for thy standing and thy not doing so]: (Mughnee.) ― -b5- A^alifu Aln~idaA='i [The alif of calling, or vocative alif], (T, S,* Mughnee,* K,) as in A^azayodu, meaning yaA zayodu [O Zeyd], (T, K,) and in A^azayodu A^aqobilo [O Zeyd, advance], (S,) used in calling him who is near, (S, Mughnee,) to the exclusion of him who is distant, because it is abbreviated. (S.) A= with medd, is a particle used in calling to him who is distant, (Mughnee, K,) as in A=azayodu A^aqobilo [Ho there, or soho, or holla, Zeyd, advance]. (TA.) Az says, You say to a man, in calling him, A=fulaAnu and A^afulaAnu and A=yaA fulaAnu (TA) or A^ayaA. (S and K in art. AyA.) ― -b6- A_iA@ll~`hi, for A_iYo waA@ll~`hi: see A_iY. ― -b7- In a dial. of some of the Arabs, hemzeh is used in a case of pausing at the end of a verb, as in their saying to a woman, quwliy^o [Say thou], and to two men, quwlaA^o [Say ye two], and to a pl. number, quwluw^o [Say ye]; but not when the verb is connected with a word following it: and they say also laA^o, with a hemzeh, [for laA,] in a case of pausation. (T.) But Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà says, All men say that when a hemzeh occurs at the end of a word, [i. e. in a case of pausation,] and has a quiescent letter before it, it is elided in the nom. and gen. case, though retained in the accus. case [because followed by a quiescent A], except Ks alone, who retains it in all cases: when it occurs in the middle of a word, all agree that it should not be dropped. (T.) AZ [however] says that the people of El-Hijáz, and Hudheyl, and the people of Mekkeh and ElMedeeneh, do not pronounce hemzeh [at all]: and 'Eesà Ibn-’Omar says, Temeem pronounce hemzeh, and the people of El-Hijáz, in cases of necessity, [in poetry,] do so. (T.) ― -b8- Ks cites, [as exhibiting two instances of a rare usage of A^aA, or A=, in a case of pausing, in the place of a suppressed word,]
Alxayoru xayoraAni wa A_ino $ar~N faA^aA
daEaA fulaAnN rab~ahu faA^asomaEaA
walaA A^uriydu Al$~ar~a A_il~aA A^ano taA^aA
[written without the syll. signs in the MS. from which I transcribe this citation, but the reading seems to be plain, and the meaning, Such a one supplicated his Lord, and made his words to be heard, saying, Good is double good; and if evil be my lot, then evil; but I desire not evil unless Thou will that it should befall me]: and he says, he means, A_il~aA A^ano ta$aA='a; this being of the dial. of Benoo-Saad, except that it is [with them] taA, with a soft A [only]: also, in replying to a person who says, “Wilt thou not come?” one says, faA^o, meaning faA@*ohabo [Then go thou with us]: and in like manner, by fA^A, in the saying above, is meant fa$~ar~N. (TA.) -A5- Hemzeh also sometimes occurs as a verb; A_ih, i. e.! with the A_i of pausation added, being the imperative of waA^aY as syn. with waEada. (Mughnee.) -A6- [As a numeral, 1 denotes One.]

1 A^ab~a * , (T, S, M, &c.,) aor.
Aabi3a , (M, K,) agreeably with analogy in the case of an intrans. verb of this class, (TA,) and
Aabu3a , (AZ, T, S, M, K,) contr. to analogy, (TA,) inf. n. A^ab~N (T, S, M, K) and A^abiybN (M, K) and A^abaAbN and A^abaAbapN (S, M, K) and A_ibaAbapN; (M;) and ↓ A@y^otab~a [written with the disjunctive alif Aiytab~a]; (T, K;) He prepared himself, (AZ, S, M, A, K,) and equipped himself, (AZ, S, A,) for (li) departing, or going away, (AZ, S,) or for journeying: (M, A, K:) or he determined upon journeying, and prepared himself. (T.) El-Aashà says,
Saramotu walamo A^aSorimokumu wakaSaArimK
A^axN qado TawaY ka$oHFA waA^ab~a liya*ohabaA
(T, S, M, TA,) i. e. I cut [in effect, while I did not really cut] you: for like one who cuts is a brother who has determined and prepared to go away. (TA.) [Hence,] laA EabaAba wa laA A^abaAba, [or lA EabaAbi wlA A^abaAbi,] a prov. [which see explained in art. Eb]. (TA.) [And hence the saying,] huwa fiY A^abaAbihi, (S, M, K,) and A^abaAbatihi, and A_ibaAbatihi, (M,) He is in his [state of, or he is engaged in his,] preparation or equipment [for departing or journeying]. (S, M, K.) The hemzeh in A^ab~a is sometimes changed into w; and thus wab~a, inf. n. wab~N, signifies He prepared himself to assault, or charge, in battle. (T, TA.) ― -b2- A^ab~ato A^abaAbatuhu, and A_ibaAbatuhu, His way, or course, of acting, or conduct, or the like, was, or became, rightly directed, or ordered. (M, K.) ― -b3- ↓ A^ab~a A^ab~ahu i. q. qaSada qaSodahu, (K,) which signifies He tended, repaired, betook himself, or directed his course, towards him, or it: (S and Msb in art. qSd:) and also, he pursued his (another‘s) course, doing as he (the latter) did. (L in art. wkd.) ― -b4- A^ab~adi A_ilaY waTanihi, (M, K,) aor.
Aabi3a (IDrd, M, K) and
Aabu3a , (K,) inf. n. A^ab~N (AA, S, M, K) and A_ibaAbapN and A^abaAbapN (M, K,) and A^abaAbN, (TA,) He yearned for, longed for, or longed to see, his home. (AA, S, M, K.)

10 AisotaA^ab~ahu *
He adopted him as a father; an extr. form; (IAar, M;) from A^ab~N, a dial. var. of A^abN: (TA:) regularly, AisotaA^obaAhu. (M.) And AstA^b~ A^abFA and AisotaA^obaba A^abFA He adopted a father. (TA in art. Abw.)
A^abN * : see art. Abw.

A^ab~N *
Herbage, (M, K,) whether fresh or dry: (M, * K, * TA:) or pasture, or herbage which beasts feed upon, (Fr, AHn, Zj, T, S, M, A, Msb, K,) of whatever kind, (AHn, Zj,) [or] not sown by men: (Msb:) it is, to cattle and other beasts, what fruit is to men: (Mujáhid, T, Msb:) or whatever grows upon the face of the earth; (Atà, Th, T, M;) whatever vegetable the earth produces: (K, * TA:) and also, green herbage, or plants: (K, * TA:) and, as some say, straw, (Jel in lxxx. 31, and TA,) because cattle eat it: (TA:) or herbage prepared for pasture and for cutting: (TA:) accord. to IF, (Msb,) dried fruits; because prepared for winter (Bd in lxxx. 31, and Msb) and for journeying: (Msb:) pl. [of pauc.] A^awub~N, originally A^aA^obubN. (I' Ak p. 367.) You say, fulaAnN raAEa lahu AlHab~u waTaAEa lahu AlA^ab~u, meaning Such a one's seed-produce
[or grain] increased, and his pasture became ample. (A.) -A2- Also a dial. var. of A^abN, A father. (T, and MF from the Tes-heel of Ibn-Málik.) -A3- A^ab~a A^ab~ahu: see 1.
A^abaAbapN * and A_ibaAbapN A way, or course, of acting, or conduct, or the like. (M, K.) [See 1.]

A_ib~aAnN A^bAn A_bAn AbAn The time, or season, of a thing: (Msb:) or the time of preparing, or making ready, of a thing: (Mgh:) as, for instance, of fruit: (Mgh, Msb:) it is of the measure fiEolaAnN, (Mgh, Msb,) from A^ab~a in the first of the senses assigned to it above, (Mgh,) the n being augmentative; (Msb;) or of the measure fiE~aAlN, (Mgh, Msb,) from A^ab~ana “he watched” or “observed” a thing, (Mgh,) the n being radical: (Msb:) but the former derivation is the more correct. (Mgh.) [See also art. Abn.]

A^abojado *
The first of a series of eight words comprising the letters of the Arabic alphabet [in the order in which they were originally disposed, agreeing with that of the Hebrew and Aramaic, but with six additional letters: they are variously written and pronounced; generally as follows: A^abojada haw~azo HuT~iY kalamano saEofaSo qara$ato vaxa*o DaZago: but the Arabs of Western Africa write the latter four thus: SEfD qrst vx* Zg$]: (K and TA in art. bjd: [in both of which are related several fables concerning the origin of these words:]) accord. to the general opinion, the word Abjd is of foreign origin, [like each of the words following it,] and therefore its first letter [as well as each of the others] is a radical. (TA.) [Hence, AlA^abojadu signifies The alphabet. You say Huruwfu AlA^abojadi The letters of the alphabet. ― -b2- It is probable (as De Sacy has observed in his Ar. Gram., 2nd ed., i. 8,) that the Arabic alphabet originally consisted of only twenty-two letters: for some of the ancient Arabs called Saturday Abjd, Sunday hwz~, and so on to qr$t inclusive; calling Friday Earuwbapu. ― -b3- In the lexicon entitled “El-'Eyn,” the letters of the alphabet are arranged nearly according to their places of utterance; as follows: E, H, h, x, g, q, k, j, $, D, S, s, z, T, d, t, Z, *, v, r, l, n, f, b, m, w, A, Y: and this order has been followed in the Tahdheeb and Mohkam and some other lexicons.]

1 A^abada * , aor.
Aabida , inf. n. A^ubuwdN, He remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, (T, S, M, K,) constantly, continually, or permanently, without quitting, (T, L,) bimakaAnK in a place; (T, S, M, K;) and so A^abada having for its aor.
Aabuda . (TA.) ― -b2- A^abada, (S, M, A, &c.,) aor.
Aabida and
Aabuda , (T, S, M, L, Msb, K,) inf. n. A^ubuwdN; (M, L, Msb;) and ↓ tA^b~d; (T, M, A, Mgh, L;) He (a beast) became wild, or sky; syn. tawaH~a$a: (S, M, A, Mgh, L, Msb, K:) [because wild animals live long, unless killed by accident; accord. to what is said by As and others in explanation of A^waAbidN (sing. A=bidapN) applied to animals, as meaning wild:] took fright, and fled, or ran away at random: (Mgh:) took fright at, and shunned, mankind. (T, Msb.) A^ubuwdN also signifies The shrinking from a thing, or shunning it; syn. nufuwrN. (Kull pp. 30 and 31.) And A^abida, (S, K,) aor.
Aabada ; (K;) and ↓ tA^b~d; (A, K;) He (a man, S, A,) became unsocial, unsociable, unfamiliar, or sky; like a wild animal; syn. twH~$. (S, A, K.) ― -b3- [Hence,] A^abada, (K,) aor.
Aabida , inf. n. A^ubuwdN, (TA,) (tropical:) He (a poet) made use, in his verses, of words, or phrases, strange, unusual, unfamiliar, or far from being intelligible, (K, * TA,) such as were not understood (K) at first sight, or on first consideration. (TA.) ― -b4- [And perhaps from A^abida in the sense explained above, but more probably, I think, by the substitution of A^ for w,] A^abida, aor,
Aabada , (T, S, &c.,) inf. n. A^abadN, (L,) He (a man, S) was angry; (T, S, M, L, K;) as also A^amida and wabida and wamida and Eabida. (T, L.) You say, A^abida Ealayohi He was angry with him. (L.)

2 A^b~d * , inf. n. taA^obiydN, He made, or rendered, perpetual. (S, K.) [See also the pass. part. n. below.] lamo A^afoEalo taA^obiydFA is a phrase used as though meaning ↓ lamo A=ti biA=bidapK [I did not a deed ever to be remembered, or mentioned]. (Ham p. 191.) ― -b2- He, or it, made [a beast] to take fright; to become wild, or sky. (KL.)

5 tA^b~d * : see 1, in two places. ― -b2- He (a man) was long distant from his home; expl. by TaAlato gurobatuhu; (K;) or was long in a state of celibacy; TAlt Euzobatuhu, as in one copy of the K; (TA;) and became little in need, or little desirous, of women. (K.) ― -b3- It (a place of abode or sojourning) became deserted [by mankind]: (T, M, K:) and became inhabited by wild animals. (T, M, A.)
A_ibodN A^bAd A^bd A^bdY Abd bAd bd bdA |bd : see A_ibidN

A^abadN *
Time, syn. dahorN, (S, M, Msb, K,) in an absolute sense: (TA:) or a long time, syn. dahorN TawiylN: (A, and Mgh: [and this may be meant in the S &c. by the syn. dahorN alone, q. v.:]) or, properly, a long time (dhr Twyl) that is unlimited: (Msb, TA:) or an extended space of time that is indivisible; for you say zamaAnu ka*aA: “ the time of such a thing,” but not A^abadu ka*aA: (Er-Rághib:) [and generally, time, or duration, or continuance, or existence, without end; endless time, &c.; prospective eternity; opposed to A^azalN, which signifies “ time, or duration, &c., without beginning: ” (see the latter word for further explanations, &c.:) each of these significations may be meant by the explanation in the S and M and K, which is also given in the Msb: each correctly applies in particular instances:] pl. [of pauc.] A=baAdN (S, M, Msb, K) and [of mult.] A^ubuwdN (S, M, K) [and A^abaduwna, of which an ex. will be found below]: but the use of these pls. is restricted to particular cases, to signify portions of time, or to serve as corroboratives to the sing.: (MF:) as signifying an extended indivisible space of time, [or the like,] A^abadN should have neither dual nor pl.; but A=baAdN is sometimes said, when the sing. is restricted to denote a particular part, or portion, of the whole of that to which it applies, in like manner as a generic noun is restricted to a special and partial signification: some, however, have mentioned A=baAdN as being post-classical; not of the language of the Arabs called AlEarabu AlEarobaA='u. (Er-Rághib.) TaAla AlA^abado EalaY lubado [The time became long to Lubad, the last, and the longest of life, of Luk- mán's seven vultures, to the term of the life of which his own term of life was decreed to extend,] is a proverb applied to any thing that has been of long duration. (M.) And you say, razaqaka A@ll~`hu EumurFA Tawiyla AlA=baAdi baEiyda AlA=maAdi [May God grant thee a life long in duration (lit. durations, the pl. form being used not in its proper sense, but to give intensiveness of signification), and remote in limit (lit. limits)]. (A.) And kaAna h`*aA fiY A=baAdi Ald~ahori This was a long time ago. (Mgh.) And ↓ A^abadN A=bidN (TA) and ↓ A^abadN A^abiydN, (S, M, TA,) meaning daAy^imN [in an intensive sense]; (TA;) [A long, or an endless, period of time;] like as you say, dahorN daAhirN (S) or dahorN dahiyrN. (M.) [In each of these phrases, the latter word is added as a corroborative, or to give intensiveness to the signification.] liloA^abida and liA^abidK and [in an intensive sense, as will be seen below,] liA^abida A^abadK and liA^abadi AlA^abadi, accord. to different recitals of a trad., signify To the end of time; for ever; and for ever and ever. (TA.) A^abadFA is an adv. n., of which the signification includes all future time; [meaning Ever; like qaT~u in relation to past time;] (El-Khafájee, El-Bedr Ed-Demámeenee, MF;) and EalaY AlA^abadi signifies the same. (TA.) [So, too, does AlA^abada, unless used in a limited sense known to the hearer.] When you say, laA A^ukal~imuhu A^abadFA, you mean, [I will not speak to him as long as I live, or henceforth, or ever; or I will never speak to him; i. e.,] from the time of your speaking to the end of your life. (Msb.) [In this case, A^abadFA may also be considered as a mere corroborative. It is used in both these ways (llt~aA^osiysi and lilt~awokiydi) in affirmative as well as negative sentences. For exs. of its use in affirmative sentences, see the Kur xviii. 2 and iv. 60, &c.] One also says, laA A^afoEaluhu, (S, M, A,) and laA A=tiyhi, (T, K,) A^abada AlA=baAdi, (T, M, A, K,) which, though of classical authority, is said to be no evidence of the use of A=bAd as a pl. of A^abadN in a general way by the Arabs of the classical ages, as it is here added merely as a corroborative, as A=zAl is in the phrase A^azala AlA=zaAli; (MF;) and A^abada AlA^abadiyna, (M, A, K,) in which the latter word is not a rel. n., for if so it would be AlA^abadiy~iyna, but app. a pl., (M,) like A^araDuwna; (M, K;) and ↓ A^abada AlA=bidiyna, (S, K,) like as you say, dahora AlA=bidiyna; (S;) and ↓ A^abada AlA^abadiy~api; (M, K;) and ↓ A^abada AlA^abiydi; (T, S, M, A, K;) and A^abiyda ↓ AlA^abiydi; (M, K;) and A^abada AlA^abadi; (K;) and A^abada
Ald~ahori; (M, K; [in the T yada Ald~ahori;]) all of which phrases are the same in meaning; (K;) [i. e. I will not do it, and I will not come to him, (or lA A=tyh may here mean the same as lA AfElh,) during the endless space of all future times, or time; or the like; or for ever and ever; εἰς αἰῶνα τῶν αἰώνων ; in seculum seculorum; in omne ævum;] the last word in every case being a corroborative. (MF.) ― -b2- Also, [for *uw A^abadK, and (applied to a fem. n.) *aAtu A^abadK,] Lasting: or everlasting. (S, A, K.) So in the saying, Ald~unyaA' A^amadN waAlA=xirapu A^abadN [The present state of existence is limited in duration, but the final state of existence is everlasting]. ('Obeyd Ibn-'Omeyr and L.) And AlA^abadu signifies [The Everlasting; i. e. God; because He alone is ↓ AlbaAqiY AlA^abadiy~ The Enduring without end or cessation; for the Muslims hold that all living creatures (even the angels) must die, and be raised again to life: or] The Ancient without beginning. (K.) -A2- Also Offspring that is a year old. (K.)

A^abidN *
Unsocial, unsociable, unfamiliar, or shy; like a wild animal; applied to a man, and to a young camel: (S, L:) and ↓ A_ibidN, applied to a female slave, and to a she-ass, signifies shunning mankind, shy, or wild. (K.) [See also A=bidN.] -A2- See also A_ibidN, in four places.

A_ibidN A^bAd A^bd A^bdY Abd bAd bd bdA |bd : see A^abidN. -A2- This word, (Lth, ISh, S, K,) said by Lth and ISh to be the only word of its measure heard from the Arabs except A_ibilN and nikiHN and xiTibN, but Az says that he had not heard the last two from any person worthy of reliance, and that they are pronounced nikoHN and xiTobN, (L,) [see A_ibilN,] and ↓ A^abidN and ↓ A_ibodN, (K,) which are thought by Az to be dial. vars. of the first, (L,) applied to a female slave, and to a she-ass, signify Prolific; that breeds, or brings forth, plentifully; (S, K;) and ↓ A^abidN and ↓ A^abidapN (Aboo-Málik, TA) and ↓ A_ibidapN, (Aboo-Málik, K,) applied to a she-camel, signify the same: (Aboo-Málik, K, TA:) and A_ibidN (Lth, ISh, L) and ↓ A^abidN, (M, L,) applied to a female slave, (M, L,) and to a she-ass, (Lth, ISh, M, L,) and to a mare, (M, L,) that brings forth every year; (Lth, ISh, L;) or applied as a pl. to the female slave and the mare and the she-ass, that breed, or bring forth: (M, L:) and AlA_ibidaAni the female slave and the mare. (K, TA.) In the following saying,
Al~aAbijad~i *iY AlA_ibido
lano yuqoliEa Aljad~u Aln~akido
fiY kul~i maA EaAmK talido
[Hard fortune will not depart save with the fortune which is the necessary attendant of the possessor of the female slave, as long as he possesses her, (or, if we take *Y in the sense of h`*ihi, save with the fortune of this female slave,) who every year (mA being redundant) brings forth,] AlAbd means the female slave because her being prolific is an obstacle to prosperity, and is not good fortune; i. e., she only increases evil [and brings reproach upon her master by bearing him children; for the Arab in ancient times was considered as dishonoured by his having a child by a slave]. (S.) The Arabs also said, lano yaboluga Aljad~a Aln~akido ↓ AlA~a AlA^abido, meaning Nothing will attain to the object of removing hard fortune save female slaves and beasts or cattle which breed, or bring forth. (M, L: [in the latter of which is added, fiY kul~i EaAmK talido in every year bringing forth.])
A^abidapN * : see A_ibidN.
A_ibidapN A^bAd A^bd A^bdY A^bdh Abdh Abdp bAd bd bdA bdh |bd |bdh |bdp : see A_ibidN.
A^abadiY~N * : see A^abadN, last sentence but one.

A^abadiy~apN * [The quality, or attribute, of unlimited, indivisible, or endless, duration; everlastingness]. (M, K.) See A^abadN. ― -b2- A^abadiy~aAtN a term applied to Sayings of which the following is an ex.: laA A=tiyka maA bal~a baHorN SuwfapF. (M in art. Swf [q. v.]; &c.)
A^abuwdN * : see A=bidN.
A^abiydN * : see A^abadN, in three places.

A=bidN A=bd
Remaining, staying, abiding, or dwelling, constantly, continually, or permanently, in a place; applied to a man [and to a bird]. (L.) And A^awaAbidu [pl. of A=bidapN] Birds that remain in a country constantly, winter and summer; (T, L;) contr. of qawaATiEu. (A, L.) ― -b2- For the phrases A^abadN A=bidN and A^abada AlA=bidiyna, see A^abadN. ― -b3- A wild animal; (M, L, Msb;) that shuns, and takes fright at, mankind, amp;c.: (L, Msb:) fem. with p: pl. [properly fem.] A^awaAbidu, (M, Mgh, L,) and [masc. and fem.] A^ub~adN: (M, L:) and ↓ A^abuwdN is syn. with A=bidN; (M;) as also ↓ mutaA^ab~idN. (A.) Wild animals are called A^awaAbidu (S, M, L, K) and A^ub~adN (M, L, K) because they endure for a long, or [naturally] unlimited, time; (M, L;) because they do not die a natural death, (As, M, L, K,) but from some evil accident; and the same is asserted of the serpent. (As, M, L.) [See also A^abidN.] [Hence,] qayodu AlA^awaAbidi (assumed tropical:) The light, or active, horse, which overtakes the wild animals, and which they can hardly, or never, escape: so called because he prevents their escaping the pursuer like a shackle. (Msb.) [See also art. qyd.] [Hence also the saying,] Aln~iEamu A^awaAbidu faqay~iduwhaA biAl$~ukori (tropical:) [Benefits are fugitive, or fleeting; therefore detain ye them by gratitude]. (A trad.)

A=bidapN A=bdh A=bdp fem. of A=bidN, q. v. ― -b2- Also, [as a subst.,] (assumed tropical:) A deed, (Har p. 364,) or a calamity, (S, M, K,) ever to be remembered, or mentioned, (S, M, K, Har,) by reason of its extraordinary nature, and its grievousness: (Har:) or a great, or formidable, event, at which people take fright, or are alarmed: (TA:) or a strange, abominable, or evil, thing: (Ham p. 627:) pl. A^awaAbidu. (K.) You say, jaA'a fulaAnN biA=bidapK Such a one did, or brought to pass, [a deed or] calamity ever to be remembered, or mentioned. (S.) See also 2. ― -b3- (tropical:) A strange, an unusual, or an unfamiliar, word or saying; one far from being intelligible; (M;) pl. A^awaAbidu, signifying expressions of subtile meanings; so called because remote from perspicuity. (Msb.) ― -b4- The pl. also signifies (tropical:) Strange, unusual, unfamiliar, or extraordinary, rhymes, or verses, or poems; syn. $awaAridu mina AlqawaAfiY, (S,) or qawaAfK $ur~adN. (K.) El-Farezdak says,
lano tudorikuwA karamiY biluw^omi A^abiykumu
wa A^awaAbidiY bitanaH~uli AlA^a$oEaAri
[Ye will not attain to my nobility with the ignobleness of your father, nor to my extraordinary verses by arrogating to yourselves the verses of other men]. (S.) [See A^abada.]

muw^ab~adN * [Made, or rendered, perpetual]. You say, waqafa A^aroDahu waqofFA muw^abadFA He made his land an unalienable bequest for pious uses in perpetuity, not to be sold nor to be inherited. (T.) ― -b2- Also, with p, A she-camel that is wild, and intractable, or unmanageable; syn. waHo$iy~apN muEotaASapN. (K.)
mutaA^ab~idN * : see A=bidN.

Aabira and
Aabura , (K,) inf. n. A^aborN, (TA,) He gave the dog, to eat, a needle in bread: (S, K:) and [app., in like manner, A^abara Al$~aApa he gave the sheep, or goat, to eat, a needle in its fodder: for you say,] A^ubirati Al$~aAp the sheep, or goat, ate a needle in the fodder. (A.) ― -b2- A^abaratohu AlEaqorabu (tropical:) The scorpion stung him with the extremity of its tail. (S, M, A, K.) ― -b3- A^abarahu (tropical:) He spoke evil of him behind his back, or in his absence, or otherwise, with truth, or though it might be with truth; or defamed him; (IAar, T, A, K;) and annoyed him, or hurt him. (IAar, T, A.) -A2- A^abara, (T, S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
Aabira and
Aabura , inf. n. A^aborN (M, Msb, K) and A_ibaArN and A_ibaArapN, (M, K,) He fecundated a palm-tree [by means of the spadix of the male tree, which is bruised, or brayed, and sprinkled upon the spadix of the female; or by inserting a stalk of a raceme of the male tree into the spathe of the female, after shaking off the pollen of the former upon the spadix of the female (see A^aloqaHa)]; (T, S, A, Msb;) as also ↓ A^b~r, (S, A,) inf. n. taA^obiyrN: (S:) or the latter has an intensive and frequentative signification [meaning the doing so much, or frequently, or to many palmtrees]: (Msb:) and the former (S, M, A, K) and ↓ latter, (M, A, K,) he dressed, or put into a good or right or proper state, a palm-tree, (S, M, A, K,) and seed-produce, (M, K,) or any thing, as, for instance, a snare for catching game. (A Hn, M.) You say also, A^ubirati Aln~axolapu, and ↓ A^ub~irat, and wubirat, The palm-tree was fecundated. (Aboo- 'Amr Ibn-El-'Alà, L.) -A3- A^abira, aor.

(M, K.) ― -b6- AlA_borapu also signifies (tropical:) The bone of what is termed watarapu [i. e. of the heel-tendon of a man, or of the hock of a beast], (M, K,) which is a small bone adhering to the kaEob [i. e. to the ankle or to the hock]: (M, TA:) and [app. more correctly “or”] the slender part of the Erqwb [or hock] of the horse: (M, * K, * TA:) in the ErqwbAn [or two hocks] are [what are termed] A_iborataAni, which are the external extremity of each hock. A maker of needles: (T, M, K:) and a seller thereof: or the latter is called ↓ A_iboriY~N of which A_ibariY~N is a corruption. (K.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) The flea. (K.) -A2- See also baA^~rN, in art. bA^r

(Aboo-'Abd-Er-Rahmán, TA.) ― -b2- maA bihaA A=birN (assumed tropical:) There is not in it [namely the house (AldAr)] any one. (TA from the Expositions of the Fs.)
maA^obirN * : see miy^obarN

miy^obarN * The place [or case] of the needle. (K.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) The tongue. (L.) ― -b3- See also A_iborapN ― -b4- and miy^obarapN -A2- Also, (T, L, K,) and ↓ maA^obirN, (T, L,) and ↓ A^abuwrN, (Msb,) That. (Msb, K,) [namely] what is called ju$r, (T, TT,) or ju$~, (so in a copy of the T,) [in the L and TA it is said to be “ like (what is termed) AlH$, ” thus written with the unpointed H, and without any syll. signs, perhaps a mistranscription for Hu$or, and doubtless meaning the anthers, or the pollen,] with which palm-trees are fecundated. miy^obarapN * (Lh, S, M, K) and ↓ miy^obarN and ↓ A_iborapN (M, K) (tropical:) Malicious and mischievous misrepresentation; calumny; or slander; (Lh, S, M, K;) and the (assumed tropical:) marring, or disturbance, of the state of union or concord or friendship or love between a people or between two parties: (Lh, S, K, TA:) pl. maA=birN. (S, M.) You say, xabuvato minohumu AlmaxaAbiro fama$ato bayonahumu AlmaA=biro (tropical:) [Their internal states, or qualities, became bad, or evil, or corrupt, and in consequence calumnies became current among them]. (A.)
muw^ab~arN * : see what follows.

maA^obuwrN * A dog that has had a needle given him, to eat, in bread: (S:) and, with p, applied to a sheep or goat ($Ap) that has eaten a needle in its fodder, and in whose inside it has stuck fast; in consequence of which the animal eats nothing, or, if it eat, the eating does it no good. (TA.) It is said in a trad., Almuw^ominu kaA@lokalobi AlmaA^obuwri The believer is like the dog that has had a needle given to him, to eat, in bread. (S.) [Accord. to Ibr D, the meaning is, that he is generous and incautious, so that he is easily deceived.] -A2- Also, (T, S, A,) and ↓ muw^ab~arN, (S,) A palm-tree fecundated: (T, S, A:) and the same, and seed-produce, dressed, or put into a good or right or proper state. (T, TA.) The former is the meaning in the phrase sik~apN maA^obuwrapN, (T, S,) occurring in a trad., [q. v. voce maA^omuwrN,] i. e. A row of palm-trees [or perhaps a tall palm-tree] fecundated: or, as some say, this phrase means a ploughshare properly prepared for ploughing. (TA.)

1 A^abaDahu * , aor.
AabiDa (S, A, K) and
AabuDa (L,) inf. n. A^aboDN (S) and A^ubuwDN (L,) He tied, or bound, the pastern of his (a camel's) fore leg to his (the camel's) EaDud [or arm], so that his fore leg became raised from the ground; (S, A, K;) as also ↓ tA^b~Dhu: (S, K:) and accord. to IAar, A^aboDN signifies [simply] the act of tying, or binding. (TA.) -A2- [Also, inf. n. A^aboDN, He loosed him, or it: for] A^aboDN also signifies the act of loosing; syn. taxoliyapN; i. e. contr. of $ad~N: (IAar, K:) thus bearing two contr. significations. (TA.) -A3- Also, (K,) inf. n. A^aboDN, (TA,) He hit, or hurt, his vein called the A_ibaAD. (K, TA.) -A4- A^abaDa (S, L, K,) inf. n. A^aboDN`; (TA;) and A^abiDa; (S, L, K;) It (the vein called Aln~asaA) became contracted, (S, L, K,) and strengthened the hind legs; (L;) as also ↓ tA^b~D: (S, L:) and ↓ taA^ab~uDN in the hind legs signifies their being contracted (A, TA) and tense: (TA:) taA^ab~uD of the hind legs of a horse, and ta$an~uj [or contraction] of the vein above mentioned, are qualities approved; and the latter is known by means of the former. (AO, TA.) -A5- A^aboDN also signifies The being in a state of rest, or motionless. (IAar, K.) -A6- And The being in a state of motion: (I Aar, K:) thus, again, having two contr. significations. (TA.)

5 tA^b~D *
He (a camel) had his pastern of his fore leg tied, or bound, to his arm, so that his fore leg became raised from the ground. (S, K.) You say, taqab~aDa kaA^an~amaA taA^ab~aDa [He contracted himself as though he had his leg thus bound]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- tA^b~Dt She (a woman) sat in the posture of the ↓ mutaA^ab~iD [app. meaning having her shanks pressed back against her thighs]. (TA.) ― -b3- See also A^abaDa, in two places. -A2- tA^bDhu: see A^abaDahu.

A^aboDN * , or A^ubuDN, or A_ibiDN, or A^ub~aDN: see maA^obiDN. -A2- Also, the first, i. q. dahorN [Time; or a long period of time; or a period of time whether long or short; &c.]: pl. A=baADN. (S, K.)

A_ibaADN A^bD AbAD |bAD The cord, or rope, with which the pastern of a camel's fore leg is tied, or bound, to his arm, so that his fore leg is raised from the ground: (As, S, A, K:) pl. A^ubuDN. (K.) The dim. is ↓ A^ubay~iDN. (S.) ― -b2- A certain vein (Eiroq) in the hind leg (AO, K) of a horse. (AO.)
A^abuwDN * , (K,) or A^abuwDu Aln~asaA, (ISh,) A very swift horse: (ISh, K:) as though he bound up his hind legs by the quickness with which he raised them when he put them down. (ISh.)
A^ubay~iDN * : see A_ibaADN.

maA^obiDN * The inner side of the knee (S, A, K) of any thing: (S:) or the inner sides of the two knees are called maA^obiDaA Als~aAqayoni: (T, TA:) or any part upon which a man bends, or folds, his thigh: or what is beneath each thigh, in the prominent places of the lower parts thereof: or the inner side of each thigh, as far as the belly: and also the wrist; the joint of the hand in the fore arm: (TA:) and in the camel, (K,) [i. e.] in each of the fore legs of the camel, (T, TA,) the inner side of the elbow: (T, K, TA:) as also ↓A^NboDN; (IDrd, K;) or, as in [some of] the copies of the S in art. byD, ↓ A^ubuDN; [in one copy of the S ↓ A^ub~aDN; and in another, imperfectly written;] but some write it ↓ A_ibiDN: and one says, A^axa*a biA_ibiDihi, meaning He put his hands, or arms, beneath his knees, from behind, and then carried him. (TA.) The pl. of maA^obiDN is maA=biDu. (S.)

maA^obuwDN * A camel having the pastern of his fore leg tied, or bound, to his arm, so that his fore leg is raised from the ground; (A, * TA;) as also ↓ mutaA^ab~iDN: (S:) or the latter, having his fore shank bound to his arm with the A_ibaAD (K.) -A2- Hit, or hurt, in the vein called the A_ibaAD. (TA.)

muw^otabiDu Aln~asaA *
The crow: because it hops as though it were maA^obuwD (K.)

i. q. habaTahu, q. v.: (IAar, Az, Sgh, K:) said of God. (K.)

5 tA^b~Thu *
He put it (a thing, S Mgh, Msb) beneath his A_iboT [or arm-pit]; (S, Msb, K;) or in
his A_iboT. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Hence, (K,) taA^ab~aTa $ar~aA, the surname of Thábit the son of Jábir (S, K) ElFahmee: (S:) because they assert that the sword never quitted him: (S:) or because he put beneath his arm—pit a quiver of arrows, and took a bow, or put beneath his arm—pit a knife, and came to an assembly of Arabs, and smote some of them. (K.) It is invariable: but if you desire to express the dual or pl., you say, *awaA taA^ab~aTa $ar~FA and *awuw taA^ab~aTa $ar~KA, or you say kilaAhumaA and kul~uhumo. (S.) It does not admit of the formation of a dim., nor is it abridged: (S, K:) but some of the Arabs used to say taA^ab~aTu [so written with refa], using a single word, accord. to Sb, as is said in the L. (TA.) Its rel. n. is ↓ taA^ab~aTiY~N. (S, K.) ― -b3- [Hence also] tA^b~T fulaAnN fulaAnFA (assumed tropical:) Such a one placed such a one under his protection. (TA.) ― -b4- tA^b~T also signifies He put his ridaA=', (S,) or garment, (Mgh, K,) under his right arm, and then threw [a portion of] it over his left shoulder, (S, Mgh, K,) in prayer, or in A_iHoraAm; (Mgh;) as also AiDoTabaEa. (S.) [See also tawa$~aHa.]

A_iboTN A^bT A_bT AbT bT [The armpit;] the inner side of the shoulderjoint: (ISd, K:) or the part beneath the janaAH [which signifies the arm, upper arm, armpit, and wing, &c.]: (S, Msb:) also written ↓ A_ibiTN; (Msb, K;) which is said to be a dial. var. by some of the moderns; but this is strange, on account of what is said respecting A_ibilN; (Msb;) for Sb says that there are only two substs. of the measure fiEilN, which are A_ibilN and HibirN; and one epithet, namely bilizN: other instances have been mentioned, but their transmission from Sb is not established: (Msb. in art. Abl:) it is also said that there is no other word like A_ibilN; but this means, in its original form, and does not deny that there are words like it by the insertion of a second vowel like the first, such as this and many other words: (TA:) [see also A_ibidN:] it is fem.; (Mgh;) or masc. and fem.; (S, Msb;) sometimes the latter; (Lh, K;) but the making it mase. is more approved: (TA:) Fr cites, from certain of the Arabs, the phrase, (S,) farafaEa Als~awoTa Hat~aY baraqato A_iboTuhu [And he raised the whip so that his armpit shone]: (S, Msb:) the pl. is A=baATN. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Daraba A=baATa AlA^umuwri wamagaAbinahaA (tropical:) [He hit the secret and occult particulars of the affairs]. (A, TA [followed by the words wa A@$otaq~a DamaAy^irahaA wabawaATinahaA, a pleonastic addition, merely explaining what goes before.]) ― -b3- And Daraba A=baATa AlmafaAzapi (tropical:) [He traversed the recesses of the desert]. (TA.) ― -b4- And A_iboTu jabalK (assumed tropical:) The foot, or bottom, or lowest part, (safaHo,) of a mountain. (TA.) ― -b5- And A_iboTu ramolK (assumed tropical:) The place where the main body of sand ends: (S:) or what is thin, of sand: (K:) or the lowest part of an oblong tract of sand collected together and elevated, where the main body thereof ends, and it becomes thin. (TA.) ― -b6- And A_ibETu Al$~imaAli (assumed tropical:) Evil fortune; ill luck. (TA.)
A_ibiTN A^bT A_bT AbT bT : see A_iboTN.
A_iboTiy~N A_bT A_bTy A_bTyy AbTY AbTy [Of, or relating to, the armpit]. ― -b2- AlA_iboTiY~u The axillary vein. (Golius, on the authority of Meyd.)

Als~ayofu A_ibaATN liY Alsyf AbAT lY Alsyf AbAT ly
The sword is beneath my A^iboT [or armpit]: and Als~ayofu EiTaA fiY wa A_ibaATiY I put, or place, the sword upon my side, and beneath my A_iboT. (TA.) And jaEalotuhu I put it (namely the sword, TA) next my A_iboT (K, TA.) The Hudhalee, (S, TA,) El-Mutanakhkhil, describing water to which he came to drink, (TA,) says, (S, TA,) accord. to the Deewán, but some ascribe the words to Taäbbata—Sharrà, (TA,)
$aribotu bij~amihi waSadarotu Eanohu
wa A^aboyaDu SaArimN *akarN A_ibaATiY
meaning [I drank of the main body thereof, and returned from it, and a sharp steel—edged sword was] beneath my A_iboT: (S, TA:) or, accord. to one relation, the poet said, biA^aboyaDa SaArimK *akarK: and accord. to another, wa EaDobN SaArimN: Skr says that the last word of the verse is a contraction of A=baATiY: and Ibn-Es-Seeráfee, that it is originally ↓ A_ibaATiY~N; and if so, it is an epithet. (TA.)
A_ibaATiY~N A_bT AbATY AbATy |bATy : see what next precedes.
taA^ab~aTiY~N * : see 5.

1 A^abaqa * , aor.
Aabiqa , (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) which is the most common form, (Msb,) and
Aabuqa , (S, TS, Mgh, Msb,) and
Aabaqa , (K,) so in the copies of the K in the place of
Aabuqa ; (TA;) and A^abiqa, aor.
Aabaqa ; (IDrd, Msb, K;) inf. n. A_ibaAqN (S, Mgh, Msb) and A^aboqN and A^abaqN, (K,) or the first of these is a simple subst., and the second and third are the inf. ns.; (Msb;) He (a slave) ran away, or fled, (T, S, Mgh, Msb,) or went away, (K,) from his master, (T, Msb,) without [being induced to do so by] fear, or severity of work: (Msb, K:) thus the signification is restricted in the 'Eyn: (Msb:) and in this case, the law ordains that the slave shall be restored; but if the act arise from severity of work or from fear, he is not to be restored: (Lth, TA:) in the Kur xxxvii. 140, it is said of Jonas, (T, Bd,) because he fled from his people without the permission of his Lord: (Bd:) and it is also, tropically, said of a fish: (Mgh:) or he (a slave) hid himself, and then went away: (M, K:) as also ↓ tA^b~q: (M:) or this signifies, simply, he hid, or concealed, himself: or he confined, restricted, limited, restrained, or withheld, himself: (S, K:) or it has both of the last two significations: (Sgh:) and he abstained from a thing, as from a sin, or crime. (IAar, K *.) A poet says, (S,) namely, 'Ámir Ibn—Kaab, (AZ,) or 'Ámán Ibn-Kaab, or, as some say, Ghámán, (AA,)
↓ A^alaA qaAlato bahaAni wa lamo taA^ab~aqo
kabirota walaA yaliyqu bika Aln~aEiymu
[Now surely Baháni said, and she did not hide herself, or did not restrain herself, Thou hast grown old, and enjoyment doth not befit thee]: (S:) or she did not hide herself [or her mind], but said openly: (TA:) or she did not go far [from the person whom she addressed, or from the truth]; so says AZ, taking it from A_ibaAqN as relating to a slave: (TA:) or she did not abstain from her speech, as from a sin, or crime: (IAar:) or she did not disdain, or scorn. (TA.) AHát says that he asked As respecting ↓tA^b~q, and he answered that he knew it not. (TA.)

5 taAab~aqa see 1, in three places. ― -b2- taA^ab~aqato She (a camel) withheld her milk. (TA.) ― -b3- tA^b~q Al$~aYo'a [or mina Al$~aYo'i] He denied, or disacknowledged, the thing. (K.) One says to a man, “ Verily in thee is such a quality; “ and he replies, maA A^ataA^ab~aqu I do not deny, or disacknowledge: and one says, “ O son of such a woman; ” and the man replies, maA A^ataA^ab~aqu minohaA I do not deny, or disacknowledge, her. (IF.)
A^abuwqN * : see A=biqN.
A^ab~aAqN * : see A=biqN.

A=biqN A=bq A slave running away, or fleeing, &c.; a runaway, or fugitive, slave; part. n. of A^abaqa; (Mgh, Msb, K;) as also ↓ A^abuwqN [but in an intensive, or frequentative, sense, i. e. who runs away, or flees, &c., much, or often; and so ↓ A^ab~aAqN, occurring in the K, in art. mlx]: (IF, K:) pl.A^ub~aAqN (Mgh, Msb, K) and A^Nb~aqN. (K.)

1 A^abila * , aor.
Aabala ; (S, M, K;) and A^abala, aor.
Aabula ; (K;) inf. n. A^abaAlapN, (S, M, K,) of the former verb, (S, M, TA,) or, accord. to Sb, A_ibaAlapN, because it denotes an office, and, if so, of the latter verb, (TA,) and A^abalN, (M, K,) which is of the former verb, (M, TA,) and A^abalapN [like galabapN]; (T;) He (a man, S) was, or became, skilled in the good management of camels (S, M, K) and of sheep or goats. (M, K.) A_ibaAlapN, like kitaAbapN [in measure], signifies The management, or tending, (A, K, TA,) of maAl [meaning camels or other beasts]. (A, TA.) You say, huwa Hasanu AlA_ibaAlapi He is good in the management, or tending, of his mAl [or camels, &c.]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- A^abala, aor.
Aabila : see 2, second signification. ― -b3- A^ubilati AlA_ibilu The camels were gotten, or acquired, as permanent property. (S, TA.) ― -b4- A^abilati AlA_ibilu, aor.
Aabala ; and A^abalat, aor.
Aabula ; (K;) inf. n. [of the former] A^abalN and [of the latter] A^ubuwlN; (TA;) The camels became many, or numerous. (K.) ― -b5- Also A^ubalati AlA_ibilu, (S, M, K,) and the like is said of wild animals, (S, M,) or others, (K,) aor.
Aabula and
Aabila , inf. n. A^ubuwlN (S, M, K) and A^abolN; (M, K;) and A^abilat; and ↓ tA^bl~t; (M, K;) The camels were content, or satisfied, with green pasture, so as to be in no need of water: (S, M, K:) the last verb is mentioned by Z, and he says that it is tropical, and hence A^abiylN applied to “a monk.“ (TA.) ― -b6- [Hence,] A^abala Alr~ajulu Eani A@moraA^atihi, and ↓ tA^b~l, (S, M, K,) The man was content to abstain from conjugal intercourse with his wife; syn. AijotazaA^aEanohaA; (M;) the man abstained from conjugal, or carnal, intercourse with his wife. (S, K, TA.) ― -b7- [Hence also] A^abala, (K,)
inf. n. A^abolN, (TA,) (tropical:) He devoted himself to religious exercises; or became a devotee; (K, TA;) as also A^abula, like faquha, inf. n. A^abaAlapN: or this signifies he became a monk. (TA.) ― -b8- And A^abala, aor.
Aabila , (Kr, M, K,) inf. n. A^abolN, (Kr, M,) (assumed tropical:) He overcame, and resisted, or withstood; (Kr, M, K;) as also ↓ A^b~l, (K,) inf. n. taA^obiylN; (TA;) but the word commonly known is A^abal~a. (M, TA.) ― -b9- Also (K, TA, but in the CK “ or ”) A^abalati AlA_ibilu signifies The camels were left to pasture at liberty, and went away, having with them no pastor: (K:) or they became wild, or shy. (K, * TA.) ― -b10- And The camels sought by degrees, or step by step, or bit by bit, after the A^ubul [q. v.], i. e. the xilofap of the herbage or pasture. (TA.) ― -b11- And, inf. n. A^ubuwlN, The camels remained, or abode, in the place: (M, K:) or remained, or abode, long in the pasturage, and in the place. (El-Moheet, TA.) ― -b12- A^abala AlEu$obN, inf. n. A^ubuwlN, The herbage became tall, so that the camels were able to feed upon it. (K.) ― -b13- A^abala Al$~ajaru, inf. n. A^ubuwlN, The trees had green [such, app., as is termed A^ubulN] growing in its dried parts, mixing therewith, upon which camels, or the like, fatten. (Ibn- 'Abbád.) -A2- A^abalahu, inf. n. A^abolN, He assigned to him, or gave him, (jaEala lahu) pasturing camels, or camels pasturing by themselves. (K.)

2 A^b~l * , (S, K,) inf. n. taA^obiylN, (K,) He took for himself, got, gained, or acquired, camels; he acquired them as permanent property. (S, K.) [See also 5.] ― -b2- He was one whose camels had become numerous; (T, M, K;) as also ↓ A=bl, (M, K,) inf. n. A_iybaAlN; (TA;) and ↓ A^abala, aor.
Aabila , (K,) inf. n. A^abolN. (TK.) ― -b3- taA^obiylN AlA_ibili The managing, or taking good care, of camels; (M;) and the fattening of them: (M, K:) mentioned by AHn, on the authority of Aboo—Ziyád ElKilábee. (M.) -A2- See also 1.
4 A=bala see 2.
5 taAab~ala see 1, in two places: ― -b2- and see 8 -A2- tA^b~l A_ibilFA He took for himself, got, gained, or acquired, camels; (AZ, T, M, K;) like tgn~m ganamFA. (AZ, T.) [See also 2.]

8 laA yaA^otabilu * , (S, M, K,) in the O ↓ lA yataA^ab~ilu, (TA,) He does not, or will not, keep firmly, or steadily, to the pasturing of camels, nor tend them well; (M, K;) he does not, or will not, manage them, or take care of them, in such manner as to put them in good condition: (As, A 'Obeyd, T, S:) or it signifies, (M, K,) or signifies also, (S,) he does not, or will not, keep firmly, or steadily, upon them when riding them; (T, S, M, K, TA;) used in this sense by a man excusing himself for not putting on a camel his aged father who was walking. (T.)
A_ibolN A^bAl A^bl A^blY A_bl Abl bAl bl blA bly wbl : see A_ibilN: ― -b2- and A^abilN.
A^abalN * : see A^abalapN.

A^abilN *
Skilled in the good management of camels (S, M, K) and of sheep or goats; (M, K;) as also ↓ A=bilN: (S, M, K:) and A^abilN biAlA_ibili, and in poetry ↓ A_ibolN, skilled in the management, or care, of camels. (T.) ― -b2- A man possessing camels; (Fr, M, K;) as also ↓ A=bilN, (M, K,) similar to taAmirN and laAbinN, (Ham p. 714,) but this is disapproved by Fr; (TA;) and ↓ A_ibaliY~N, (S, M, O,) with fet-h to the b (S, O,) because several kesrehs together are deemed uncouth; (O;) in the K, erroneously, ↓ A^abaliY~N, with two fet-hahs; (TA;) and ↓ A_ibiliY~N also, (M, K,) with two kesrehs. (K.) ― -b3- baEiyrN A^abilN A fleshy he-camel. (Ibn- 'Abbád, K.) ― -b4- naAqapN A^bilapN A she-camel blessed, prospered, or made to have increase, in respect of offspring. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) In one place in the K, mina Alwaladi is put for fiY Alwaladi. (TA.)

A^ubulN * [mentioned in two places in the latter part of the first paragraph,] The xilofap of herbage, (K,) i. e., of dry herbage; [app. meaning what grows in the season called AlS~ayof, or summer, among herbage that has dried up;] growing after a year; upon which camels, or the like, fatten. (TA.)

A_ibilN A^bAl A^bl A^blY A_bl Abl bAl bl blA bly wbl (T, S, M, Msb, K, &c.,) said by Sb to be the only subst. of this form except HibirN, and to have none like it among epithets except bilizN; for though other instances are mentioned, they are not of established authority; (Msb;) but IJ mentions, with these, HibikN and A_iTilN [which may be of established authority]; (TA;) [and to these may be added A_ibiTN and A_ibidN, and perhaps nikiHN and xiTibN; respecting which see A_ibidN;] and for A_ibilN one says also ↓ A_iblN, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) sometimes, by way of contraction; (S, Msb;) or this may be a dial. var. of the former; (Kr, MF;) [Camels: and a herd of camels: or] at the least, applied to a Siromap; i. e. a number [of camels] more than a *awod [which is at least nine,] up to thirty; after which is the hajomap, i. e. forty and upwards; and then, hunayodapu, which is a hundred of A_ibil: (T:) or, accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, a hundred of A_ibil: (TA:) it is a quasi-pl. n.; (Az, S, ISd, Z, O, Msb, &c.;) a word having no proper sing.; (S, M, O, Msb;) and is of the fem. gender, because the quasi-pl. n. that has no proper sing. is necessarily fem. (S, O, Msb) when not applied to human beings, (S, O,) or when applied to irrational beings, (Msb,) and has p added in the dim.; (S, Msb;) the dim. of A_ibilN being ↓ A^ubayolapN: (S, Msb, K:) it is said in the K that it is a sing. applied to a pl. number, and is not a pl., nor a quasi-pl. n.; but in this assertion together with the saying that the dim. is as above is a kind of contradiction; for if it be a sing., and not a quasi-pl. n., what is the reason of its being fem.? (TA:) the pl. is A=baAlN (S, M, Msb, K) and A^abiylN [like EabiydN pl. of EabodN, q. v.]; (Msb, TA;) the pl. meaning herds [of camels]; and in like manner A^agonaAmN and A^aboqaArN mean flocks of sheep or goats and herds of bulls or cows: (Msb, TA:) and the dual, A_iblaAni, means two herds [of camels], (Sb, T, S, M, Msb,) each with its pastor; (T;) like as ganamaAni means two flocks of sheep or goats: (S:) or, accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, the dual means two hundreds of A_ibil. (TA.) ― -b2- AlA_ibilu AlS~ugoraY [The smaller camels] is an appellation applied to sheep; because they eat more than goats. (IAar in TA art. DbT.) ― -b3- It is said in the Kur [lxxxviii. 17], A^afalaA yanoZuruwna A_ilaY A@loA_ibili kayofa xuliqato, meaning, accord. to 'Aboo-Amr Ibn-El- 'Alà, (T, TA,) (tropical:) [Will they not then consider] the clouds that bear the water for rain, [how they are created?] (T, K, TA:) but accord. to him who reads AlA_iboli, the meaning is, the camels. (T, TA.)

A^ubolapN *
A blight, blast, taint, or the like: (T, K:) thus written by IAth, agreeably with the authority of Aboo-Moosà; (TA;) occurring in a trad., in which it is said that one should not sell dates until he is secure from AlAubolapN; (T, TA;) but accord. to a commentary on the Nh, it is correctly written ↓ A^abalapN [q. v.] (TA.)

A_ibolapN A^bAl A^bl A^blY A^blh A^blp A_bl A_blh Ablh Ablp bAl bl blA blh bly wbl
Enmity; hostility. (Kr, M, K.)

A^abalapN *
Unwholesomeness and heaviness of food; (S, M, K;) originally wabalapN, like as A^aHadN is originally waHadN; (S;) as also ↓ A^abalN. (K.) It is said in a trad. that this departs from every property for which the poor-rate has been paid. (S, M.) ― -b2- See also A^ubolapN. ― -b3- An evil quality of herbage or pasture. (AHn, TA in art. n$r.) ― -b4- A cause of harm or injury; evil; mischief. (TA.) ― -b5- A consequence of an action, or a claim which one seeks to obtain for an injury; and a cause of blame or dispraise: having these meanings in the saying, A_ino faEalota *aAka faqado xarajota mino A^abalatihi [If thou do that, thou wilt escape from its consequence, &c.]. (T.) ― -b6- A fault, vice, or the like. (Aboo-Málik, T.) So in the saying, maA Ealayoka fiY h`*aA AlA^amori A^abalapN [There is not to be charged against thee, in this affair, any fault, &c.]. (T.) ― -b7- A crime; a sin; an unlawful action. (K.) ― -b8- Rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite. (IB.)
A^abaliY~N * : see A^abilN
A^abuliY~N * : see A^abiylN
A_ibaliY~N A^blY A^bly A_bl A_bly AblY Ably blA bly , with fet-h to the b because several kesrehs together are deemed uncouth, Of, or relating to, camels. (S.) ― -b2- See also A^abilN.
A_ibiliY~N A^blY A^bly A_bl A_bly AblY Ably blA bly : see A^abilN

A^abiylN * (assumed tropical:) A Christian monk; (S M, Msb, K;) so called because of his abstaining (litaA^abulihi) from women: (TA:) or the chief monk: (T:) or a derotee: (TA:) or an old man, or elder: (M:) or the chief, or head-man, of the Christians: (M, K:) or the man who calls them to prayer by means of the naAquws; (A Heyth, M, * K;) the beater of the nAqws: (IDrd:) as also ↓ A^ayobaliY~N, (M and K, but according to the M as meaning “ a monk, ”) which is either a foreign word, or changed by the relative Y, or of the same class as A_inoqaHolN [in which the first letter as well as th second is augmentative], for Sb says that there is not in the language an instance of the measure fayoEalN; (M;) and ↓ A^ayobuliY~N, and hayobaliY~N, and ↓ A^abuliY~N and ↓ A^ayobalN, (K,) which last is disallowed by Sb for the reason stated above; (TA;) and ↓ A^ayobulN like A^ayonuqN; and ↓ A^ayobiliY~N; (K;) the last with fet-h to the hemzeh, and kesr to the b, and with the
[first] Y quiescent; or A^ayobaliY~N [app. a mistranscription for A^ayobiliY~N] is used by poetic licence for ↓ A^abiyliY~N, like A^ayonuqN for A^anowuqN: (TA:) pl. A=baAlN (M, K) and A^ubolN, or A^ubulN, [accord. to different copies of the K,] with damm [which indicates that the former is meant, though it is irregular]. (K.) By A^abiylN AlA^abiyliyna is meant 'Eesà [or Jesus], (S, K,) the Messiah. (S.) ― -b2- In the Syriac language it signifies Mourning, or sorrowing. (K.) -A2- Also A staff, or stick. (M, K.) ― -b2- See also A_ibaAlapN.
A^ubaAlap * : see the next paragraph.

A_ibaAlapN A^bAl A^bAlh A_bAlp AbAlh AbAlp bAlY : see A_ib~awolN. -A2- Also A bundle of firewood; (T, S, Msb;) and so ↓ A_ib~aAlapN: (T, S:) or a great bundle of firewood; and so ↓ A^ubaAlapN and bulapN (K) and ↓ A_ib~aAlapN: (Bd in cv. 3; but there explained only as signifying a great bundle:) or a bundle of dry herbage; (M, TA;) and so ↓ A_ib~aAlapN (K) and ↓ A^abiylN and ↓ A^abiylapN (M, K) and ↓ A_iybaAlapN, (K, [in the CK AayobaAlap,]) with one of the two b s changed into Y, and mentioned by Az, but it is said in the S and O that this is not allowable, because this change may not be made in a word of the measure fiE~aAlapN, with p, but only in one without p, as in the cases of diynaArN and qiyraATN; (TA;) and wabiylapN signifies the same, (K,) belonging to art. wbl. (TA.) Hence the prov., (S, TA,) SigovN EalaY A_ibaAlapK and ↓ A_ib~aAlapK, (S, K, &c.,) but the former is the more common, and ↓ A_iybaAlapK, which is allowed by Az but disallowed by J; (TA;) [lit. A handful of herbage, or the like, upon a bundle, or great bundle, of firewood, or a bundle of dry herbage;] meaning (assumed tropical:) a trial, or trying event, upon another (S, O, K) that had happened before: (S, O:) or plenty (xiSobN) upon plenty; as though bearing two contr. significations. (K.)
A^abiylapN * : see A_ibaAlapN.
A^ubaylapN * dim of A_ibilN, q. v. (S, Msb, K.)
A^abiyliY~N * : see A^abiylN.
A^abaAbiylN * : see A_ib~awolN.

A^ab~aAlN *
A pastor of camels, (M, K, TA,) who manages them, or takes care of them, well. (TA.)
A_ib~aAlN A^bAl AbAl bAlY : see the next paragraph.

A_ib~awolN A^bwl Abwl bAl bwl , (T, S, M, Msb, K,) like Eij~awolN, (S, Msb, K, [in the CK, erroneously, Eajuwl,]) A separate, or distinct, portion of a number of birds, and of horses, and of camels, (M, K,) and of such following one another; (K;) as also ↓ A_ibiylN and ↓ A_ib~aAlapN, (M, K,) and ↓ A_ibaAlapN, and ↓ A_iyobaAlN: (K:) or it signifies a bird separating itself from the row of other birds; (T, TA;) accord. to IAar. (TA.) It is said to be the sing. of ↓ A^abaAbiylN: (T, S, M, and Jel in cv. 3:) Ks says, I used to hear the grammarians say that this latter has for its sing. A_ib~awolN, like Eij~awolN, of which the pl. is EajaAjiylN: (Msb:) or its sing. is ↓ A_ibaylN; (S, Msb;) but he who says this adds, I have not found the Arabs to know a sing. to it: (S:) or each of these is its sing.; (M, Jel;) and so is ↓ A_ib~aAlN: (Jel:) or its sing. is ↓ A_ib~aAlapN, (Bd in cv. 3, and Msb,) originally signifying “a great bundle:” (Bd:) it is said that this seems to be its sing.; and so ↓ A^ab~aAlapN: or the sing. may be ↓ A_iybaAlapN, like as diynaArN is sing of danaAniyrN: (T:) or it has no sing., (T, S, M, Bd, Msb, K,) accord. to Fr (T, Msb) and Akh (S) and AO, (T, M,) like $amaATiyTu (Fr, T, Bd) and EabaAdiydN. (AO, M, Bd.) A^abaAbiylN signifies, accord. to some, A company in a state of dispersion: (M:) or dispersed companies, one following another: (Msb:) or distinct, or separate, companies, (Akh, S, Msb, K,) like leaning camels: (Msb:) or companies in a state of dispersion. (AO, Msb.) One says, jaA='ato A_ibiluka A^abaAbiyla Thy camels came in distinct, or separate, companies. (Akh, S.) And TayorN A^abaAbiylu [in the Kur cv. 3 means Birds in distinct, or separate, flocks or bevies]: (Akh, S:) [or] birds in companies from this and that quarter: or following one another, flock after flock: (Zj, T:) or (assumed tropical:) birds in companies; (Bd, Jel;) likened to great bundles, in respect of their compactness. (Bd.) [Respecting these birds, Fei, in the Msb, quotes many fanciful descriptions, which I omit, as absurd.]
A_ib~iylN A^bAl A^byl Abyl : see A_ib~awolN, in two places.
A^ab~aAlapN * : see A_ib~awolN.
A_ib~aAlapN A^bAl A^bAlh A_bAlp AbAlh AbAlp bAlY : see A_ibaAlapN, in three places: ― -b2- and A_ib~awolN, in two places.

A=balN A=bl
More, and most, skilled in the good management of camels. (S, M, K, TA.) Hence the prov., A=balu mino Hunayofi AlHanaAtimi [More skilled &c. than Honeyf-el-Hanátim]. (TA.) And the phrase, huwa mino A=bila Aln~aAsi [He is of the most skilled &c. of men]. (S, M, K.) Mentioned by Sb, who says that there is no verb corresponding to it. (M.) [But see 1, first signification.]

A=bilN A=bl : see A^abilN, in two places. ― -b2- A_ibilN A^awaAbilN, (S, M, K,) and A^ub~alN, and A^ub~aAlN, (M,) [all pls. of A=bilN or A=bilapN,] and ↓ muw^ab~alapN, (M,) Many, or numerous, camels: (S, M, K:) or this, [app. meaning the last,] as some say, put in distinct herds; (M;) and so A^ub~aAlN: (TA:) or gotten, gained, or acquired, for permanent possession: (M:) this last is the meaning of the last of the epithets above. (S, K.) ― -b3- A=bilN, applied to a camel, also signifies Content, or satisfied, with green pasture, so as to be in no need of water: pl. A^ub~aAlN: (S, K:) and so A^awaAbilu, applied to she-camels, (T, * TA,) and to wild animals. (S in art. bl.) ― -b4- And A_ibilN A=bilapN Camels seeking by degrees, or step by step, or bit by bit, after the A^ubul [q. v.], i. e. the xilofap of the herbage or pasture. (TA.) ― -b5- And A_ib~ilN A^ub~alN Camels left to themselves, (S, M, K, TA,) without a pastor. (TA.)
A^ayobalN * and A^ayobulN: see A^abiylN.
A^ayobaliY~N * and A^ayobuliY~N and A^ayobiliY~N: see A^abiylN.
A_iyobaAlN AybAl : see A_ib~awolN.
A_iyobaAlapN AybAlh AybAlp : see A_ibaAlapN, in two places: ― -b2- and see A_ib~awolN.

A^aroDN maA^obalapN *
A land having camels. (S, K.)
A_ibilN muw^ab~alapN * : see A=bilN.

1 A^abanahu * , aor.
Aabuna and
Aabina , inf. n. A^abonN, He made him an object of imputation, or suspected him: and he found fault with him, or blamed him: (M:) or he cast a foul, or an evil, imputation upon him. (IAar, T.) You say, A^abanahu bi$aYo'K, (S, K,) or bi$~arK (as in one copy of the S,) or bixayorKwa$~arK, (Lh, M,) aor. as above, (Lh, S, M, K,) and so the inf. n., (Lh, M,) He made him an object of imputation, or suspected him, (Lh, S, M, K,) of a thing, (S, K,) or of evil, (S, accord. to one copy,) or of good, and evil: (Lh, M:) and ↓ A^b~nhu signifies the same. (M.) And bixayorK ↓ fulaAnN yuw^ab~anu, or bi$~arK, Such a one is made an object of imputation, or suspected, of good, or of evil: (AA, * Lh, T [as in the TT; but perhaps yuw^ab~anu is a mistranscription for yuw^obanu; for it is immediately added, fahuwa maA^obuwnN:]) when, however, you say yw^bn [i. e. yuw^obanu or ↓ yuw^ab~anN] alone, it relates to evil only. (AA, T. [But see 2.]) And fulaAnN yaw^abanu bika*aA, or ↓ yuw^ab~anu, Such a one is evil spoken of by the imputation of such a thing. (S, accord. to different copies.) And it is said respecting the assembly of the Prophet, fiyhi AlHuramu, ↓ laA tuw^ab~anu, (T, and so in a copy of the S,) or lA tuw^obanu, (so in some copies of the S,) i. e. Women (T) shall not be mentioned in an evil manner therein: (T, S:) or shall not have evil imputations cast upon them, nor be found fault with, nor shall that which is foul be said of them, nor that which ought not, of things whereof one should be ashamed. (IAar, T.) ― -b2- Also, and ↓ A^b~nhu, (M, K,) inf. n. taA^obiynN, (K,) He found fault with him, or blamed him, to his face; (M, K;) and he upbraided him, or reproached him. (M.)

2 A^b~n Al$~aYo'a * , (AZ, S,) inf. n. taA^obiynN, (K,) He watched, or observed, the thing; or he expected it, or waited for it. (AZ, S, K.) ― -b2- A^b~n AlA^avara, (M,) inf. n. as above, (As, T, S, K,) He followed the traces, or footprints, or footsteps, (As, T, S, M, K,) of a thing; (As, S, K;) as also ↓ tA^b~n. (K.) And hence the next signification. (As, T.) -A2- A^b~n Alr~ajula, (S, M,) inf. n. as above, (Sh, T, S, K,) He praised the man, or spoke well of him, (Sh, Th, T, S, M, K,) after his death, (Th, S, M, K,) or in death and in life, (Sh, T,) used in poetry to signify praise of the living; (M;) and wept for him: (S:) he praised him; and enumerated, or recounted, his good qualities or actions: you say, lamo yazala yuqar~iZu A^aHoyaAkumo wayuw^ab~inu mawotaAkumo [He ceased not to eulogize your living and to praise your dead]: (Z, TA:) for he who praises the dead traces his [good] deeds. (As, T.) ― -b2- See also 1, in six places.
5 taAab~ana see 2.
AibonN A^bAn A^bn A^bnn Abn bAn bnY {bn |b : see art. bny.

A^ubonapN *
A knot in wood, or in a branch; (S, M, K;) or in a staff, or stick; (T;) and in a bow, (TA,) [i. e.] the place of the shooting forth of a branch in a bow, (M,) which is a fault therein; (TA;) and in a rope, or cord: (M in art. Avl:)
pl. A^ubanN. (T, S.) ― -b2- Hence, (M,) (tropical:) A fault, defect, or blemish, (T, M, K, TA,) in one's grounds of pretension to respect, (T, TA,) and in speech, or language. (M, TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Particularly The enormity that is committed with one who is termed maA^obuwn. (TA.) ― -b4- And (tropical:) Rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite: (K, TA:) and enmity: pl. as above. (TA.) You say, bayonahumo A^ubanN (tropical:) (S, TA) Between them are enmities. (S.) ― -b5- Also The [part called] galoSamap [meaning the epiglottis] of a camel. (M, K.)
AibonapN A^bAn A^bn A^bnh A^bnnh Abnh Abnp bnY {bn {bnh {bnp |b : see art. bnY

A_ib~aAnN A^bAn A_bAn AbAn The time of a thing; (T, S, M, K, and Msb in art.
