Ab;) the season of a thing; (Msb in that art.;) the time of the preparing, or making ready, of a thing; (Mgh in that art.;) as, for instance, of fruit, (S, Mgh, Msb,) of the fresh ripe dates, and of the gathering of fruits, and of heat or cold: (T.:) or the first of a thing. (M, K.) You say, A^axa*a Al$~aYo'a biA_ib~aAnihi He took the thing in its time: or in, or with, the first thereof. (M.) The n is radical, so that it is of the measure fiE~aAlN; or, as some say, augmentative, so that it is of the measure fiEolaAnN. (TA.) [See art. Ab.]
muw^ab~anN * occurs as meaning Dead, or dying; i. e., [properly,] wept for. (S.) [See 2.]

muw^ab~inN *
A praiser of the dead; because he traces his [good] deeds. (As, T.)

maA^obuwnN *
Made an object of imputation, or suspected, of evil: thus when used alone: otherwise you add bixayorK [of good], and bi$~arK [of evil]. (M, K.) ― -b2- Hence, [A catamite;] one with whom enormous wickedness is committed; (TA;) i. q. muxan~avN. (Idem, voce duEobuwvN.) ― -b3- Also One who is imprisoned; because suspected of a foul fault, or crime. (T.)
Abns Abns , accord. to the Msb; or bns, accord. to the TA.

A=binuwsN A=bnws , with medd to the A and kesr to the b, (TA,) or with damm to the b, [i. e. A=bunuwsN, and by some written A=banuwsN,] or with the bquiescent, [i. e. A^abonuwsN,] and without w, [app. A^abonusN,] (Msb,) [Ebony;] a thing well known, which is brought from India: an arabicized word: (Msb [in which is added the proper Arabic appellation; but the word in my copy of that work is imperfectly written; app. jEfr; which, however, does not seem to be the word intended:]) some say that it is the same as saAsam: others, that it is different therefrom: and respecting the measure of the word, authors differ. (TA.)

1 A^abaha lahu * , (JK, K,) and bihi; (K;) and A^abiha; aor. [of both] yaA^obahu; inf. n. A^abohN, (JK, K,) of the former, (TA,) and A^ubuwhN, [also of the former,] (JK,) and A^abahN, (JK, K,) which is of the latter; (TA;) He knew it; or understood it; or knew it, or understood it, instinctively: or he recognised it readily; knew it, or understood it, readily, after he had forgotten it. (K.) You say, maA A^abahotu lahu, (AZ, JK, S, Mgh,) aor. A=bahu, inf. n. A^abohN; (AZ, S) and maA A^abihotu lahu, (JK, S,) aor. as above, inf. n. A^abahN; (S;) I did not know it, or understand it; or did not know of it; was not cognizant of it: (JK, Mgh:) or I did not have my attention roused to it after I had forgotten it: (AZ, S:) the former is like wabahotu; (Mgh;) and the latter, like [wabihotu and] nabihotu. (S.) ― -b2- laA yuw^obahu lahu (Mgh, K, TA) He will not be cared for, minded, or regarded, because of his lowness of condition, or abjectness. (Mgh, TA.) ― -b3- A^abahotuhu bika*aA I imputed to him, or suspected him of, such a thing. (JK, K, TA.)

2 A^ab~ahotuhu * , inf. n. taA^obiyhi, I roused his attention: and I made him to know, or understand. (Kr, K.) The two meanings are nearly alike. (TA.) And ↓ A=bahotuhu I made him to know; informed, apprized, advertised, or advised, him; gave him information, intelligence, notice, or advice. (IB.)
4 A=baha see 2.

5 tA^b~h *
He magnified himself; behaved proudly, or haughtily. (JK, S, K.) You say, taA^ab~aha Alr~ajulu EalaY fulaAnK The man magnified himself against such a one, and held himself above him. (JK, * TA.) And taA^ab~ahu Eano ka*aA He shunned, avoided, or kept himself far from, such a thing; (JK, Z, K;) he was disdainful of it, he disdained it, or held himself above it. (Z, K.)

A^ub~ahapN *
Greatness, or majesty; (JK, S, K;) a quality inspiring reverence or veneration; (TA;) goodliness and splendour; (K;) and goodliness of aspect: (TA:) and pride, self-magnification, or haughtiness. (JK, * S, * K.)

1 A^abawotu * , [third pers. A^abaA,] (T, S, M, K,) and A^abayotu, [third pers. A^abaY,] (T, M, K,) the latter accord. to Yz, (T,) aor. A=buw, (TK,) inf. n. A^ubuw~apN, (Yz, T, S, Msb,) or this is a simple subst., (M,) I became a father. (T, * S, * M, K.) ― -b2- A^abawotuhu, (ISk, T, M, K,) aor. A=buwhu, (IAar, ISk, T,) inf. n. A_ibaAwapN, (M, K,) I was, (IAar, ISk, T,) or became, (M, K,) a father to him. (IAar, ISk, T, M, K.) ― -b3- [Hence, I fed him, or nourished him; and reared him, or brought him up.] You say, fulaAnN yaA^obuw h`*aA Alyatiyma, inf. n. A_ibaAwapN, Such a one feeds, or nourishes, this orphan, like as the father does his children. (Lth, T.) And maAlahu A^abN yaA^obuwhu (ISk, T, S) He has not a father to feed him, or nourish him, and to rear him, or bring him up. (S.)

2 A^ab~ayotuhu * , inf. n. taA^obiyapN, I said to him biA^abiY [meaning fudiyati biA^abiY Mayest thou be ransomed with my father! or the like: see A^abN, below]. (K, TA. [In the CK, erroneously, yA AabiY.])

5 tA^b~Ahu *
He adopted him as a father; (M, K, TA;) as also ↓ AstA^bAhu; (M in art. Ab;) and so tA^b~Ahu A^abFA, accord. to A'Obeyd: (TA:) [or,] accord. to A'Obeyd, you say, taA^ab~ayotu A^abFA I adopted a father: (T:) and you say also, AisotaA^ab~a A^abFA and AisotaA^obaba A^abFA he adopted a father. (TA.)
10 A_isotaAobawa see 5.

A^abN * is originally A^abawN, (S, Msb, K,) as is shown by the first of its dual forms and of its pl. forms mentioned below; (S, Msb;) and signifies A father [in the ordinary sense: and also as meaning (assumed tropical:) an ancestor]: (M:) as also ↓ A^abFA, a dial. var., (M, K,) the same in the nom. and accus. and gen. cases, like qafFA: (M:) and A^ab~N is a dial. var. of the same, [the second letter being doubled to compensate for the w suppressed, as is the case in A^ax~N, (TA voce A^axN)] but is rare. (Msb.) Accord. to the dial. commonly obtaining, when you use it as a prefixed noun, you decline it with the letters w and A and Y, saying, h`*aAA^abuwhu [This is his father], (Msb,) and A^abuwka [thy father]; (M;) and raA^ayotu A^abaAhu [I saw his father]; and mararotu biA^abiyhi [I passed by his father]: (Msb:) but accord. to one dial., you say, h`*aA A^abaAhu, (Msb:) and A^abaAka; (M;) and raA^ayotu A^abaAhu; and mararotu biA^abaAhu: (Msb:) and accord. to one dial., which is the rarest of all, it is defective in every case, like yadN and damN; (Msb;) and [thus] you say, h`*aA A^abuwka [&c.]. (M.) The dual is A^abawaAni, (S, M, Msb,) meaning [two fathers, and] father and mother; and some say A^abaAni: (S, M:) you say, humaAA^abawaAhu, meaning They two are his father and mother; and in poetry you may say, humaA A^abaAhu; and in like manner, raA^ayotu A^abayohi [I saw his father and mother], (T,) and A^abayoka [thy father and mother]; (S;) but the usual, or chaste, form is raA^ayotu A^abawayohi. (T.) The pl. is A=baA='N, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) the best form, (T,) and A^abuwna, (T, S, M, K,) and A^ubuw~N (M, K, [in the CK AlAabowN is erroneously put for AlA^ubuw~N,]) and A^ubuw~apN, (Lh, T, S, M, K, *) like EumuwmapN and xuw^uwlapN: (T, S:) you say, h`w^ulaA='i A^abuwkumo, meaning A=baAw^ukumo [These are your fathers]; (T;) and hence, in the Kur [ii. 127], accord. to one reading, waA_il`ha A^abiyka A_ibr`hiyma waA_isom`Eiyla waA_isoH`qa [And the God of thy fathers, Abraham and Ishmael and Isaac], meaning the pl. of A^bN, i. e. A^abiynaka, of which the n is suppressed because the noun is prefixed [to the pronoun]; (S;) and some of the Arabs say, A^abuw~atunaA A^akoramu AlA=baA='i [Our fathers are the most generous of fathers]. (T.) The dim. is ↓ A^ub~aY~N; originally A^ubayowN, with the final radical letter restored. (Msb.) ― -b2- maA yadoriY lahu mino A^abK, and maA A^abN, mean- ing He knows not who is his father, and what is his father, are sayings mentioned by Lh on the authority of Ks. (M.) ― -b3- laA A^abaA lika, (T, S, M, K, &c.,) [accord. to the dial. of him who says A^abFA instead of A^abN,] as also laA A^aba laka, and laA A^abaAka, (S, K,) [the last, accord. to J, because the l (meaning the l in lk in the preceding phrases) is as though it were redundant, but he seems not to have known the dial. var. A^abFA, and I rather think that laA A^abaAka, is for laA A^aboqaY A@ll~`hu A^abaAka, or the like,] and laA A^abaka, (Mbr, Sgh, K,) and laAba laka, (K,) which is for laA A^aba laka, (M,) means Thou art, in my estimation, one deserving of its being said to him, Mayest thou have no father! it is used in the manner of a proverb, is of frequent occurrence in poetry, (M,) is said to him who has a father and to him who has not a father, and is an imprecation as to the meaning, of necessity, though enunciative as to the letter; (M, K;) and hence the saying of Jereer,
yaA tayomu tayoma EadiY~K laA A^abaA lakumo
[O Teym, Teym of 'Ades, may ye have no
father!]; which is the strongest evidence of its being a proverb, and not having a literal meaning; for all of [the tribe of] Teym could not have one father, but all of them were fit objects of imprecation and rough speech: (M:) it is an expression of praise: (S:) [i. e.] it is an imprecation against him to whom it is addressed, not, however, said with the desire of its having effect, but on an occasion of intense love, like laA A^um~a laka, &c.: (Har p. 165:) and sometimes in dispraise, like laA A^um~a laka: and in wonder, like lil~hi dar~uka: (TA:) or, as A Heyth says, on the authority of Aboo-Sa'eed Ed- Dareer, it expresses the utmost degree of reviling; [meaning Thou hast no known father;] and laA A^um~a laka expresses reviling also, but means Thou hast no free, or ingenuous, mother: (Meyd in Har p. 165: [see A^um~a:]) sometimes it means Strive, or exert thyself, in thine affair; for he who has a father relies upon him in some circumstances of his case: (TA:) accord. to Kh, it means Thou hast none to stand thee in stead of thyself: (ISh, TA:) Fr says that it is a phrase used by the Arabs [parenthetically, i.e.,] to divide their speech: (TA:) [thus, for instance,] Zufar Ibn-El-Hárith says,
A^ariyniY silaAHiY laA A^abaA laka A_in~aniY
A^araY AlHaroba laA tazodaAdu A_il~aA tamaAdiyaA
[Show thou me my weapons: (mayest thou have no father! or thou hast no father: &c.:) verily I see the war, or battle, increases not save in perseverance]. (TA.) [Aboo-'Alee, as cited in the M, observes that the A (meaning the final A) in A^abaA, in the phrase laA A^abaA laka, indicates that it is a prefixed noun, and determinate; whereas the l in lk together with the government exercised upon the noun by lA indicates that it is, on the contrary, indeterminate, and separate from what follows it: but it seems that he was unacquainted with the dial. var. A^ab~aA; for laA A^abaA laka in the dial. of him who uses the form A^ab~aA instead of A^abN is the same grammatically as laA A^aba laka in the dial. of him who uses the form A^abN.] Suleymán Ibn-'Abd-El-Melik heard an Arab of the desert, in a year of drought, say, A^anozilo EalayonaA Algayova laA A^abaA laka, and Suleymán put the best construction upon it, [as though it meant, Send down upon us rain: Thou hast no father], and said, I testify that He hath no father nor female companion nor offspring. (TA.) They say also, in paying honour [to a person], laA A^aba li$aAniy^ika, and laA A^aba li$aAniy^ika, (TA,) i. e. May thy hater have no father! or, accord. to ISk, each is a metonymical expression for laA A^abaA laka. (S in art. $nA^, q. v.) ― -b4- One also says, on the occasion of an occurrence that is approved and commended, by way of expressing wonder and praise, lal~ihi A^abuwka, meaning To God, purely, is attributable [the excellence of] thy father, seeing that he begat thee a generous son, and produced the like of thee! (TA;) [or to God be attributed (the excellence of) thy father!] it means that to God [alone] belongs the power to create the like of this man [to whom it relates], from whom has proceeded this wonderful action. (Har p. 44.) ― -b5- And hiYa binotu A^abiyhaA, meaning She resembles her father in strength of mind, or spirit, and sharpness of disposition, and in hastening, or striving to be first, to do things: said of Hafsah, by 'Áïsheh. (TA.) ― -b6- biA^abiY, (TA,) or biA^abiY A^anota, (T in art. bA^,) [said to a person,] means [fudiyta biA^abiY Mayest thou be ransomed with my father! (see the next sentence but one;) or] A^afodiyka biA^abiY [I will ransom thee with my father]; (T ubi suprà;) or A^anota mafodiY~N biA^abiY Thou art, or shalt be, ransomed with my father]; or fadayutuka biA^abiY [I have in my heart ransomed thee, or I would ransom thee, with my father]; the b being dependent upon a word suppressed, which, accord. to some, is a [pass. participial] noun, and accord. to others, a verb; and this word is suppressed because of the frequent usage of the phrase. (TA.) You say also, biA^abiY A^anota wa A^um~iY [With my father mayest thou be ransomed, and with my mother!]. (TA.) And biA^abiY mano wadadt~uhu, i. e. fudiYa biA^abiY mano wadadt~uhu [May he whom I love be ransomed with my father!], meaning may he [my father] be made a ransom for him [whom I love]! (El-Wáhidee on the Deewán of El-Mutanebbee, in De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, sec. ed. vol. iii. p. 35 of the Arabic text.) Sometimes they change the Y into A: a poet says,
waqado zaEamuwA A^an~iY jaziEotu EalayohimaA
wahalo jazaEN A^ano qulotu waA biA^abaA humaA
[And they have asserted that I have become impatient on account of them two: but is it an evidence of impatience that I said, Alas, with my father may they two be ransomed?]; meaning waA biA^abiY humaA. (S.) And some of the Arabs used to say, waA biA^abaA A^anota [Alas, with my father mayest thou be ransomed!]: this, says AM, being like yaA wayolataA for yaA wayolatiY; as also yaA bayobaA, with the hemzeh changed into Y, originally yaA biA^abaA, meaning yaAbiA^abiY: and hence what is related, in a trad., of Umm- 'Ateeyeh; that she used not to mention the Prophet without saying, biyabaA [for biA^abi huwa]. (TA in art. bA^.) A woman said,
yaA biA^abiY A^anota wa yaA fawoqa Albiyabo
[O thou to whom I would say, With my father mayest thou be ransomed! and O thou who art above him to whom I would address the saying, With my father mayest thou be ransomed!]; respecting which Fr observes that the two words [bi and A^ab] are made as one [by prefixing the article] because of their frequent occurrence; (S;) and Aboo-'Alee says that the Y in biyab is substituted for ', not necessarily; but ISk quotes the words as commencing with yaA biyabaA, which is the right reading, in order that this expression may agree with Albiy^abo, which is derived from it: EtTebreezee, however, relates Abu-l-'Alà's reciting the words as ending with Albiy^abo; saying that this is compounded from the phrase biA^abiy, and that therefore the ' is preserved. (TA.) [See also the first paragraph in art. bA^.] ― -b7- You say also, yaA A^abati [meaning O my father], (S, M, K,) as in yaA A^abati AfoEalo [O my father, do thou such a thing]; (S;) and yaA A^abata; (S, M, K;) and yaAA^abatu; (Z in the Ksh xii. 4;) and yaA A^abaho (S, M, K) when you pause after it. (S, M.) The p, [here written t,] (Kh, M,) the sign of the fem. gender, (S, Z,) is substituted for the [pronominal] affix Y, (Kh, S, M, Z,) as in yaAA^um~ati; (S;) and is like the p in EamapN and xaAlapN, as is shown by your saying, in pausing, yaA A^abahN, like as you say, yaA xaAlapN: (Kh, M:) the annexing of the fem. t to a masc. noun in this case is allowable, like as it is in HamaAmapN *akarN and $aApN *akarN and rajulN raboEapN and galaAmN yafaEapN: its being made a substitute for the affix Y is allowable because each of these is an augmentative added at the end of a noun: and the kesreh is the same that is in the phrase yaA A^abiY: (Z ubi suprà:) the t does not fall from Ab in the phrase yaA A^abati when there is no pause after it, though it [sometimes] does from A^um~ in the like phrase in that case, because the former word, being of [only] two letters, is as though it were defective. (S.) yaA A^abata is for yaA A^abataA, (Aboo-'Othmán El-Mázinee, S, * M, [the latter expression mentioned also in the K, but not as being the original of the former,]) the A [and h] being suppressed; (the same Aboo- 'Othmán and M;) or for yaA A^abataA, the A being suppressed, like as the Y is in yaA gulaAmi; or it may be after the manner of yaAA^abiYa. (Z ubi suprà.) yaA A^abatu is thus pronounced after the usual manner of a noun ending with the fem. p, without regard to the fact that the t is in the former a substitute for the suffix Y. (Z ubi suprà.) yaA A^abaho is said in a case of pause, except in the Kur-án, in which, in this case, you say, yaA A^abaho, following the written text; and some of the Arabs pronounce the fem. p, in a case of pause, t [in other instances], thus saying, yaA TaloHatu. (S.) yaA A^abaAhu is also said; (M, K;) though scarcely ever. (M.) A poet uses the expression yaA A^abaAta, for yaA A^abataAho: (S, M:) IB says that this is used only by poetic license, in a case of necessity in verse. (TA.) ― -b8- A^abN is tropically applied to signify (tropical:) A grandfather, or any ancestor. (Msb.) ― -b9- It is also applied to signify (assumed tropical:) A paternal uncle; as in the Kur ii. 127, quoted before. (M.) ― -b10- [It is also (like A^um~ and Aibon and binot) prefixed to nouns of various significations. Most of the compounds thus formed will be found explained in the arts. to which belong the nouns that occupy the second place. The following are among the more common, and are therefore here mentioned, as exs. of different kinds.] ― -b11- A^abuw AlmaroA^api (assumed tropical:) The woman's husband: (Ibn-Habeeb, M:) it is said in the TS that AlA^abu, in certain of the dials., signifies the husband: MF deems this meaning strange. (TA.) A^abuw AlmavowaY (assumed tropical:) The master of the dwelling, or of the place of abode: (TA:) and (assumed tropical:) the guest. (K in art. vwY.) A^abuw AlA^aDoyaAfi (assumed tropical:) The very hospitable man. (TA.) ― -b12- A^abuw AlHaArivi (assumed tropical:) The lion. (TA.) A^abuw jaEodapa (assumed tropical:) The wolf. (TA.) A^abuw AlHuSayoni (assumed tropical:) The fox. (TA.) ― -b13- A^abuw jaAbir (assumed tropical:) Bread. (S and K in art. jbr.) ― -b14- A^abuw maAlikK (assumed tropical:) Extreme old age: (TA:) and (assumed tropical:) hunger. (MF in art. jbr.)
A^ab~aA * : seeA^abN.
A_ibowaA='N AbwA=' or A^abowaA='N: see A^ubuwapN.

A^abawiY~N *
Of, or relating or belonging to, a father; paternal. (S, TA.)
A^abaY~N * dim, of A^abN, q. v. (Msb.)

A^ubuwapN * [in copies of the K ↓ A_ibowaA=', and in the CK ↓ AabowA', both app. mistranscriptions for A^ubuw~ap, which is well known,] Fathership; paternity; the relation of a father. [S, * M.) You say, bayoniy w bayona falaAnK A^ubuwapN [Between me and such a one is a tie of fathership]. (S.)

1 A^abaY * , aor. yaA^obaY, (S, M, Msb, K,) which is anomalous, (S, M, Msb,) because it has no faucial letter (S, Msb) for its second or third radical, (Msb,) and yaA^obiY, (M, Msb, K,) mentioned by IJ as sometimes said, (M,) agreeably with analogy, (TA,) and yiy^obaY, which is doubly anomalous, first because the pret. is of the measure faEala, and this pronunciation of the Y of the aor. is [regularly allowable only] in the case of a verb of the measure faEila, aor. yafoEalu, and secondly because it is only in an aor. like yiyojalu, (Sb, M,) i. e., of a verb of which the first radical letter is w or Y, (TA in art. wjl,) and yiy^obiY, (IB, [who cites as an ex. a verse ending with the phrase Hat~aY tiy^obiyaho,]) inf. n. A_ibaA='N (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and A_ibaA='a pN, (K,) or A_ibaApN, (so in a copy of the M,) or A_ibaAyapN, (so in the Msb,) He refused; or refrained, forbore, abstained, or held back; syn. AimotanaEa; (S, Msb, MF, Bd in ii. 32, Kull p. 8,) voluntarily, or of his own free will or choice: (Bd ubi suprà, Kull:) [thus when used intransitively: and it is also used transitively:] you say, A^abaY AlA^amora he refused assent, or consent, to the thing, or affair; disagreed to it; and did not desire [to do] it: (Mtr in Har p. 483:) he did not assent to, consent to, approve, or choose, it; he disallowed it; rejected it: (Mgh:) and A^abay Al$~aYo 'a he disliked, was displeased with, disapproved of, or hated, the thing. (M, K.) Fr says that there is no verb with fet-h to its medial radical letter in the pret. and fut. [or aor.] unless its second or third radical is a faucial letter, except A^abaY: that AA adds rakana: but that one says rakana with yarokunu for its fut., and rakina with yarokanu for its fut.: (T:) so that the instance mentioned by AA is one of an intermixture of two dial. vars.: (TA:) Th adds qalaY and gasaA and $ajaA; and Mbr adds jabaA: but most of the Arabs say yaqoliY and yagosuw and ya$ojuw and yajobiY. (T.) [Some other instances are mentioned by other authors; but these are verbs of which the aors. are rarely with fet-h, or are instances of the intermixture of two dial. vars.] A^abayota All~aEona is a greeting which was addressed to kings in the time of ignorance; meaning Mayest thou refuse, or dislike, (ISk, * S, * M, * Har p. 491,) to do a thing that would occasion thy being cursed! (ISk, S, M;) or, to do that for which thou wouldst deserve the being cursed! for it implies the meaning of a prayer; i. e., may God make thee to be of those who dislike the being cursed! and hence it occurs parenthetically. (Har ubi suprà.) You say also, A^abaY A^ano yuDaAma [He refused, or did not submit, to be harmed, or injured]. (T.) [And sometimes laA is inserted after A^ano, and is either redundant, or corroborative of the meaning of the verb, as in the case of A^ana laA or A^al~aA after manaEa.] It is said in the Kur ix. 32, wayaA^obaY All~hu A_il~aA A^ano yutim~a nawrahu, meaning But God will not consent or choose [save to complete, or perfect, his light]. (Bd.) And in the same xvii. 91, faA^abay A^akovaru AlnaAsa A_il~aA kufuwrFA, i. e. [But the greater number of men have not consented to, or chosen, aught] save denying [its truth, or disbelieving it]; this phrase with A_il~aA being allowable because it is rendered by means of a negative. (Bd.) You also say, kaAna yaA^obaY All~aHoma [He used to refuse, or dislike, flesh-meat], (K,) or A^akola All~aHomi [the eating of flesh-meat]. (Mgh.) And A^abaY falaAnN AlmaA='i [Such a one refused, or disliked, water, or the water]: (S:) or A^abaY mino $urobi AlmaA='i [he refused, or voluntarily refrained from, the drinking of water, or the water]. (AAF, M.) And A^abaY Ealayohi AlA^amara, (Mgh, and Mtr. [author of the Mgh] in Har p. 483,) and Ealayohi ↓ taA^ab~aAhu, both signify He refused him his assent, or consent, to the thing, or affair. (Mtr ubi suprà, in Har.) Hence, (Mtr ubi suprà,) A^abaY Ealayohi, (Mgh, and Mtr ubi suprà,) and Ealayohi ↓ taA^ab~aY, (T, S, and Mtr ubi suprà,) He was incompliant, or unyielding, to him; he resisted him, withstood him, or repugned him; syn. AimotanaEa (T, S, Mgh, and Mtr ubi suprà) Ealayohi: (T:) thus explained because the objective complement (AlA^amora) is suppressed. (Mtr ubi suprà.) -A2- A^abiyotu AlT~aEaAma, (K,) or mina AlT~aEaAmi, and All~abani, (M, TA, [in a copy of the former of which the verb is written Abayotu, but this I suppose to be a mistranscription, on account of what here follows,]) like raDiyotu, (K,) inf. n. A^ab~aY, (M, and so in some copies of the K,) or A_ib~aY, (so in some copies of the K,) with kesr, and with the short final alif, (TA, [i.e. like riD~aY, but perhaps this may have been supposed to be the right reading only because the verb is likened to raDiytu, of which riD~aY is the most common inf. n.,]) I left, or relinquished, the food, (M, K,) and the milk, (M, TA,) without being satiated, or satisfied. (M, K.) ― -b2- A^abiYa AlfaSiylu, and A^ubiYa, inf. n. A^ab~aY, The young camel, or young weaned camel, suffered indigestion from the milk, and became affected with a dislike of food. (M, K.) -A3- A^abayotu as syn. with A^abawotu: see the latter.

4 A=bayotuhu A_iy~aAhu A=byth AyAh A=byth AyAp [in the CK, erroneously, A^abayotuhu] I made him to refuse it; or to refrain, forbear, abstain, or hold back, from it, voluntarily, or of his own free will or choice: (S: [this meaning being there implied, though not expressed:]) or I made him to dislike it, to be displeased with it, to disapprove of it, or to hate it: (M, K:) namely, water [&c.]. (S, M.) One says, fulaAnN baHorN laA buw^obiY, (ISk, S, K, * [in the CK, erroneously, lA yuw^obY,]) i. e., laA yajoEaluka taA^obaAhu [Such a one is like a sea, or great river, that will not make thee to refuse it, or dislike it, &c.]; (K;) i. e., that will not fail, or come to an end, (ISk, S, K,) by reason of its abundance. (ISk, S.) In like manner one says, of any water, maA='N laA yuw^obiY [Water that will not fail, or come to an end]. (TA.) And EinodanaA maA='N maA yuw^obiY With us, or at our abode, is water that does not become scanty, or little in quantity. (Lh, T, M.) And A=baY AlmaA='u The water decreased, or became deficient. (AA, from El-Mufaddal.) And qaliybN laA yuw^obiY A well that will not become exhausted: (IAar, M:) one should not say, yuw^obaY. (M, TA.) In like manner, also, one says, kalaA^a laA yuw^obaY Herbage, or pasture, that will not fail, or come to an end. (S.) And Einodahu daraAhimu laA tuw^obiY He has dirhems, or money, that will not fail, or come to an end. (TA.) And A=baY AlmaA='u signifies also The water [in a well] was, or became, difficult of access (AimotanaEa), so that no one was able to descend to it but by exposing himself to peril or destruction: (M:) if a drawer of water descend into the well, (T, TA,) and the water be altered for the worse in odour, (TA,) he expose himself to peril, or destruction. (T, TA.)
5 taA^ab~aY Ealayohi AlA^amora * : and tA^b~Y Ealayohi alone: see 1, latter half of the paragraph.

A_iboyapN A^b A^by A^byh A^byp Abyh Abyp |by |byh |byp
A paucity, or deficiency, and revulsion, of the milk in the breast: (Fr, TS:) or a revulsion of the milk in the udder; (K;) but the saying “in the udder” requires consideration. (TA:) You say to a woman, when she has a fever on the occasion of childbirth, A_in~amaA h*ihi AlHum~aY A_iboyapN vadoyika [This fever is only occasioned by the paucity, or deficiency, and revulsion, of the milk in thy breast.] (TA.)
A^aboyaAnN * and A^aboyaAnu and A^abayaAnN: see A=bK, in four places.

A^ubaA='N * , (T, S, M,) or A^ubaA='N mina AlT~aEaAmi, (K,) A dislike, or loathing, of food: (T, S, M, K:) of the measure fuEaAlN, (S, M,) with damm, (S, K,) because it is like a disease, and nouns significant of diseases are generally of that measure. (M.) You say, A^axa*ahu A^ubaA='N (T, S, M, K) mina AlT~aEaAmi (K) He was, or became, taken, or affected, with a dislike, or loathing, of food. (T, S, M, K.)
A_ibaA='N AbA=' inf. n. of A^abaY, q. v. (S, M, &c.) ― -b2- See also A^ub~iy~apN.

A^abiY~N * and A^abiyapN: see A=bK, in three places. ― -b2- Also, the former (A^abiY~N), She [app. a camel, or any beast,] that refuses, or refrains from, fodder, by reason of her suffering from indigestion: and she that refuses, or refrains from, the stallion, by reason of her having little appetency. (AA.) [See also A^awaAbK, voce A=bK.]
A^ab~aA='N * A man who refuses, or does not submit, to be harmed, or injured. (T.)

A^ubiyapN * , with damm, (K,) and kesr to the b, and with teshdeed of this letter and of the Y, (TA,) [in the CK Auboyap,] Pride; self-magnification, or greatness, or majesty: (K:) and ↓ A_ibaA='N [also] signifies pride, self-magnification, or haughtiness. (Ham p. 118.)

A=bK A=b , and ↓ A^abiY~N, (S, M, Msb, K, TA,) and ↓ A^abayaAnN,
(S, TA,) part. ns. of A^abaY, signifying Refusing; or refraining, forbearing, abstaining, or holding back [voluntarily, or of his own free will or choice]: (S, Msb, TA: *) [refusing assent or consent; &c.:] disliking, being displeased with a thing, disapproving of it, or hating it: (M, * K, * TA:) or the first and second, a man disliking, or loathing, food: (M, K, TA:) and the third, (K,) and ↓ A^aboyaAnN, (so in a copy of the M,) or A^bayaAnN, (K,) a man who refuses, or refrains from, or dislikes, or hates, (yaA^obaY,) food; or, things that are base, or mean, (M, K, TA,) and causes of dispraise or blame: (TA:) or the second (A^abiY~N), a man who refuses, or refrains, &c., vehemently, or much; incompliant, unyielding, resisting, withstanding, or repugning: (T:) and ↓ A^aboyaAnu and A^aboyaAnN, a man having vehement AbA=' [app. A^ubaA=', i. e. dislike, or loathing, of food; agreeably with a common quality of words of the measure faEolaAn]: (T, TA: [but in copy of the T, accord. to the TT, AbA=' in this last explanation is written AibA=': in the TA it is without any vowel-sign:]) the pl. of A=bK is A=buwna and A^ubaApN (M, K) and A^ubiY~N, (K,) with damm, then kesr, and then teshdeed, (TA, [in the CK AubaY~, and in a copy of the M Aubiyn,]) and A^ub~aA='N, (M, TA,) or A_ibA='N, (K, TA,) like rijaAlN: (TA: [in the CK AubA':]) the pl. of ↓ A^abiY~N is A^abiy~uwna; (M, K;) of which an instance occurs wherein the pl. n is likened to a radical n; the gen. case being written, at the end of a verse, A^abyiyni: (M:) the pl. of ↓ A^aboyaAnN, (M,) or A^abayaAnN, (K,) is A_iboyaAnN. (Kr, M, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AlA=biY The lion. (K.) ― -b3- And A=biyapN, (M,) so in some copies of the K, but in others ↓ A^abiy~apN, (TA,) She [app. a camel] that dislikes, or loathes, and will not drink, water: and she that desires not the evening-food: and she (a camel) that is covered and does not conceive, or become pregnant: (M, K:) and A^awaAbK, [its pl.,] she-camels that refuse, or refrain from, the stallion. (TA. [See also A^abiY~N.]) It is said in a prov., AlEaA$iyapN tahiyju AlA=biyapa [She that is eating her eveningfood, or pasturing in the evening, excites her that has no desire for that food]; i. e., when the camels that desire not the evening-food see the camels eating that food, they follow them, and pasture with them. (M, and so in the S in art. E$w.)
muw^obK * [act. part. n. of 4, q. v.] Water failing, or coming to an end: (TA:) or water that is scanty, or little in quantity.] (Lh, M, TA.)
maA='K maA^obaApN * , (M,) or maA='a pN maA^obaApN, (K,) Water which the camels refuse, or dislike. (M, K.)

2 A^at~abahaA A_itobFA * , (M, K, [but in the latter the pronoun is masc.,]) and biA_tobK, (M,) or simply A^t~bhA, (S,) inf. n. taA^otiybN, (S, K,) He put on her, or clad her with, an A_itob: (S, M, K:) or A^t~bhA signifies he put on her, or clad her with, a shift. (AZ, T.) ― -b2- A^ut~iba, (M, K,) inf. n. as above, (K,) It (a garment, or piece of cloth,) was made into an Atob. (M, K.)

5 tA^t~b biA^tobK * , (M, K,) and ↓ Ay^ttb, [written with the disjunctive alif Aiytataba], (M,) or ↓ Ay^tb~, (K, [but this I think a mistranscription,]) He put on himself, or clad himself with, an A_itob: (M, K:) or ↓ Ay^ttbt, alone, she put on herself, or clad herself with, an A_itob. (AZ, T, S, M.) ― -b2- tA^t~b Ald~iroEa wa Als~ilaAHa (assumed tropical:) He put on (i. e. on himself) the coat of mail, and the arms, or weapons. (A.) And tA^t~b Alqawosa (assumed tropical:) He put forth his shoulderjoints from the belt of the bow, [the belt being across his breast,] so that the bow was on his shoulder-blades: (A:) accord. to AHn, (M,) taA^at~ubN signifies (assumed tropical:) a man's putting the suspensory of the bow across the breast, and putting forth the shoulder-joints from it, (M, K,) so that the bow is on the shoulder-joints: (M:) and you say also, tA^t~b qawosahu EalaY Zahorih (assumed tropical:) [he put his bow in the manner above described upon his back]. (S.) ― -b3- [And hence,] tA^t~b signifies also (assumed tropical:) He prepared himself, or made himself ready, (K,) lilA^amori [for the affair]. (TK.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) He acted, or behaved, with forced hardness, firmness, strength, hardiness, courage, or vehemence. (K.)
8 A_iAotataba see 5, in two places.
9 A_iAotab~a see 5.

A_itobN A^tb Atb tAb tb (T, S, M, A, K) and ↓ miy^otabapN (M, K) A baqiyr, (S,) or baqiyrap, (M, K,) i. e., (S, M, [but in the K what here follows is given as a meaning distinct from that of bqyrp,]) a burod [q. v.], (S, M, K,) or piece of cloth, (S, A,) which is slit (S, M, A, K) in the middle, (S,) and worn by a woman, (A, K,) who throws it upon her neck, (S, M,) [putting her head through the slit;] having neither an opening at the bosom (a jayob), nor sleeves: (S, M, A, K:) and a woman's shift: (T, M, K:) and, (K,) or accord. to some, (M,) a garment that is short, reaching half-way down the shank: (M, K:) or [a garment like] drawers, or trousers, without legs; (M, K;) i. q. nuqobahN: (M:) or a shirt without sleeves, (S voce baqiyrN, M, K,) worn by women: (S ubi suprà:) the first explanation alone is given in most lexicons: (TA:) some say that it is different from the A_izaAr; that it has no band like that of drawers or trousers, and is not sewed together after the manner of drawers or trousers, but is a shirt of which the two sides are not sewed together: (M:) or i. q. EiloqapN and SidaArN and $awo*arN; all signifying one and the same thing: (T:) pl. [of pauc.] A=taAbN (M, K [in the CK and a MS. copy of the K written AatAbN]) [originally A^aA^otaAbN which is mentioned as one of the pls. by MF] and A=tubN [originally A^aA^otubN which is also mentioned as one of the pls. by MF] and by transposition A^atow^ubN, (MF,) and [of mult.] A^utuwbN, (S,) or A_itaAbN, (M,) or both. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A_tobN also signifies (assumed tropical:) The husk of barley. (M, K.)

miy^otabN *
A [wrapper, or wrapping garment, such as is called] mi$omalN. (T.)
miy^otabapN * : see A_itobN.
muw^at~abu AlZ~ufuri * (assumed tropical:) A man whose nail is crooked. (K.)

1 A^atomN * , (M, K,) in, or in relation to, a siqaA=' [or skin for water or milk], (TA,) signifies The having two punctures of a seam (xuzorataAni) rent so as to become one. (M, K.) You say, A^atamati AlqirobapN, aor.
Aatima , inf. n. A^atomN, The water-skin had its two punctures (xzrtAhA [or rather two of its punctures, agreeably with the explanation of the inf. n. in the M and K, as given above,]) rent so that they became one. (TK.) ― -b2- [And hence,] The meeting together of the masolakaAni [or vagina and rectum]: whence A^atuwmN [q. v.] as an epithet applied to a woman. (Ham p. 373.) ― -b3- [It seems to be indicated in the T, that one says, A^atima AlnisaA='u, aor.
Aatama , and A^atama, aor.
Aatima ; as meaning, or perhaps the former only, The women assembled, or came together: for I there find, immediately after maA^otamN as signifying “a place in which women assemble,” “one says, A^atima, aor.
Aatama , and A^atama, aor.
Aatima :” but it is then added that, accord. to Khálid Ibn-Yezeed, mA^tm is from A^atima, aor.
Aatama .] -A2- I. q. fatoqN [The act of rending, rending asunder, ripping, or the like; or undoing the sewing of a thing]. (TA.) ― -b2- The act of cutting. (Sgh, K.) You say, A^atamahu He cut it. (TK.) -A3- A^atama, aor.
Aatima , also signifies He brought together, or united, two things. (T.) [See A^atuwmN, and maA^otamN.] -A4- A^atama biAlmakaAni, (Sgh, Msb,) with two forms of aor., [app.
Aatima and
Aatuma ,] (Msb,) inf. n. A^atomN, (Sgh, K,) or A^utuwmN; (Msb;) and A^atima, aor.
Aatama ; (Msb;) He stayed, remained, dwelt, or abode, in the place. (Sgh, Msb, K.)
2 Aat~ama see 4.
4 A=tamahaA A=tmhA , inf. n. A_iytaA=mN; and ↓ A^at~amahaA, inf. n. taA^otiymN; He rendered her such as is termed A^atuwm, q. v. (O, K.)

A^atuwmN * is primarily used in relation to the siqA=' [or skin for water or milk; as meaning] Having two punctures of a seam (xurozataAni) rent so that they become one. (S.) ― -b2- And hence, (S,) or from A^atama as meaning “he brought together, or united,” two things, (T,) A woman whose masolakaAni [or vagina and rectum] meet together in one, [by the rupture of the part between them,] (T, M,) becoming conjoined, so that the faroj is enlarged thereby, (TA,) on the occasion of devirgination; (M;) i. q. mufoDaApN, (T, S, M,) as some say; (T;) or mufaADapN; (K; [said in the TA to be a mistake: but mufoDaApN and mufaADapN are said in the M, in art. fyD, to have the same signification;]) a woman whose masolakaAni have become one: (Ham p. 271:) or, as some say, small in the faroja [or vagina]: (M:) or it has these two contr. significations. (K.)

maA^otamN * is a quasi-inf. n. of A^atama in the last of the senses explained above. (Msb.) [Thus it signifies A staying, remaining, dwelling, or abiding, in a place. But it more commonly signifies] The assembling of women [and of men also] in a case of rejoicing and of mourning. (Har p. 234.) ― -b2-
It is also a noun of time from the same. (Msb.) [Thus it signifies A time of staying or remaining, &c.] ― -b3- And it is also a noun of place from the same. (Msb.) [And thus it signifies A place of staying or remaining, &c. But it more commonly signifies] A place of assembling of women [and of men also] in a case of rejoicing and of mourning: from A^atima, aor.
Aatama , accord. to Khálid Ibn-Yezeed. (T.) ― -b4- And hence, tropically, (Msb,) (tropical:) Women assembling together (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) in a case of rejoicing and of mourning, (T, M, Mgh, K,) or in a case of good and of evil: (S, Msb:) or any assembly, (M, K,) of men and of women, (M,) in a case of mourning or of rejoicing: (M, K:) or particularly of young women; (M, K,) accord. to some; but it is not so: and some assert that the word is derived from A^atomN, in the first of the senses explained in this art.; and from A^atuwmN, as an epithet applied to a woman; because it signifies women coming together, and meeting face to face, in a case of good and of evil: (M:) the pl. is maA=timu. (S, Mgh.) Abu-l-'Atà Es-Sindee says,
Ea$iy~apa qaAma Aln~aAy^iHaAtu wa $uq~iqato
juyuwbN biA^ayodiY maA^otamK wa xuduwdu
[In the evening when arose the wailing women to wail, and openings at the necks and bosoms of garments were rent with the hands of assembled mourning women, and cheeks also were lacerated]: (S, M, Mgh:) i. e., biA^ayodiY nisaA='K. (S.) And another says,
Hat~aY taraAhun~a ladayohi quy~amaA
kamaA taraY Hawola AlA^amiyri AlmA^otamaA
[So that thou seest them (referring to women) standing in his presence, or at, or by, it, like as thou seest the assembly of men around the prince, or commander]: AlmA^tm here necessarily denoting men. (M.) ― -b5- IKt says, (Msb,) it is used by the vulgar to denote An affliction, or evil accident; (S, Mgh, Msb;) [and Mtr adds,] and a wailing: (Mgh:) they say, kun~aA fiY maA_otami falaAnK [meaning We were present at the affliction of such a one]: (S, Msb:) or kun~aA fiY maA^otami baniy fulalnK [meaning, We were present at the affliction, and wailing, of the sons of such a one]: (Mgh:) but the correct word in this case, (S, Mgh,) or the better, (Msb,) is manaAHap: (S, Mgh, Msb:) so says IAmb. (Mgh.) But accord. to IB, nothing forbids that it may occur in the sense of A place of wailing; and in the sense of mourning, and wailing, and weeping; for therefore do women assemble: and thus it may be in the saying of Et-Teymee, respecting Mansoor Ibn-Ziyád,
wa Aln~aAsu maA^otamuhumo Ealayohi waAHidN
fiY kl~i daArK ran~apN wa zafiyru
[The people's mourning, &c., for him was one: in every house was a moaning, and a sighting]: and in the saying of another,
A^aDoHaY banaAtu Als~ubiY~i A_i*o qutiluwA
fiY maA^otamK waAls~ibaAEu fiY Eurusi
i. e. [The daughters of the captives, when they were slain, became, in the early part of the day,] in a state mourning; and the beasts of prey, in a state of rejoicing. (TA.)

1 A^atana biAlmakaAni * , (S, M, Msb, K, *) aor.
Aatuna , (Msb,) or
Aatina , (K,) inf. n. A^utuwnN (M, Msb, K) and A^atunN, (K,) He remained, continued, stayed, or abode, in the place; (S, M, Msb, K; *) or became fixed, or settled, therein. (M.)

10 AstA^tn * [lit.] He (an ass) became a she-ass. (M.) The saying, kaAna HimaAr~aA faAsotaA^otana, said of a man, [lit.] signifies [He was a he ass,] and he became a she ass; meaning (assumed tropical:) he was mighty, or of high condition, [like the wild he-ass,] and he became base, abject, or vile. (S, TA.) ― -b2- Also, (S, TA,) or AstA^tn A^ataAn~aA, (M,) He (a man) purchased a she-ass; (S;) he took for himself a she-ass. (S, M.)

A^ataAnN * (T, S, M, Msb, K) and ↓ A_itaAnN, (K,) but one should not say A^ataAnapN, (ISk, S, Msb,) or this is of rare occurrence, (K,) occurring in certain of the trads., (IAth,) A she-ass [domestic or wild]: (S, M, Msb, K:) pl. (of pauc., T, S, Msb) A=tunN and (of mult., T, S, Msb) A^utunN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and A^utonN and (quasi-pl. n., M) ↓ maA^otuwnaA='u. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- Hence, A^ataAnN signifies (tropical:) A foolish and soft or weak woman; as being likened to a she-ass. (TA.) ― -b3- Also The station of the drawer of water at the mouth of the well; (S, M, K;) and so ↓ A_itaAnN. (M, K.) And A rock, or great mass of stone, (AA, T, S, M,) in water; (AA, T, M;) or, as some say, at the bottom of the casing of a well, so that it is next the water. (AA, T.) And A large, round mass of rock, which, when it is in shallow water, is called A^ataAnu AlD~aHli; and a she camel is likened thereto, in respect of her hardness: (S:) or A^ataAnu AlD~aHli signifies a large mass of rock projecting from the water. (T:) or a mass of rock, (M, K, TA,) large and round, in the water, (TA,) at the mouth of the well, overspread with [the green substance called] TuHolub, so that it is smooth, (M, K, TA,) more smooth than other parts: (M, TA:) or a mass of rock, part of which is immerged (gaAmirN, M, K) in the water, (K,) and part apparent. (M, K.) And A^ataAnu Alv~amiyli signifies A large mass of rock in the interior of the water-course, which nothing raises or moves, of the measure of the stature of a man in length and likewise in breadth. (ISh.) ― -b4- Also The [piece of wood called] qaAEidap [which is one of four forming the support] of the fawodaj [more commonly called hawodaj, q. v.]: pl. A=tunN, (K, TA,) with medd. (TA: [but in the CK AutunN.])
A_itaAnN A^tAn AtAn : see A^ataAnN, in two places.

A^atuwnN * (T, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and A^at~uwnN, (K,) or, accord. to J, (Msb,) it is thus, with teshdeed, but pronounced without teshdeed by the vulgar, (S, Msb,) A certain place in which fire is kindled, (S, Mgh,) called in Persian kulaxon [or kuloxano], pertaining to a bath: and metaphorically applied to (tropical:) that in which bricks are baked, and called in Persian tuwnaqo and daA$uwzano [or simply tuwno and daA$o]: (Mgh:) accord. to Az, (Msb,) it is that of the bath, and of the place in which gypsum is made: (T, Msb:) or the trench, hollow, or pit, of the jay~aAra [or lime-burner, (in the CK, erroneously, the xab~Az,]) and of the preparer of gypsum; (M, K, TA;) and the like: (K:) the pl. [said in the TA to be of the latter, but it is implied in the T and M and Mgh that it is of the former,] is A^ataAtiynu, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K, [in the CK, erroneously, AatAniyonu,]) by common consent of the Arabs, (Mgh,) with two ts, (T,) accord. to Fr, who says that they sometimes double a letter in the pl. when they do not double it in the sing., (T,) and accord. to IJ, who says that it seems as though they changed A^atuwnN to A^at~uwnN; (M;) and [of A^atuwnN, as is said in the TA and implied in the M,] A^utunN. (M, K.) [J says that] it is said to be post-classical; (S;) [and ISd says,] I do not think it to be Arabic. (M.)
maA^otuwnaA='u * : see A^ataAnN.

1 A^ataA * , aor. yaA^otuw; (Msb;) and A^atawotuhu, (T, S, M, K,) aor. A=tuwhu; (S;) inf. n. A^atowN, (M, Msb,) or A^atowapN, (S,) or the latter is an inf. n. of un.; (T, TA;) He came; (Msb;) and I came to him, or it; (S;) the former a dial. var. of A^ataY, aor. yaA^otiY; (Msb;) and the latter, of A^atayotuhu. (T, S, M, K.) [See art. AtY, to which, as well as to the present art., belong several words mentioned in this.] -A2- A^ataA, aor. as above, (TK,) inf. n. A^atowN, (M, K, TK,) also signifies He pursued a right, direct, straight, or even, course, in going, or pace. (M, K, TK.) ― -b2- And He (a man, TK) hastened, made haste, or sped; or he was quick, hasty, speedy, rapid, swift, or fleet. (M, K, TK.) ― -b3- And A^atati AlnaAqapu, inf. n. as above, The she-camel returned her fore legs, [drawing the feet back towards the body, and lifting them high,] in her going. (M.) You say, maA A^aHosana A^atowa yadaYo h*ihi Aln~aAqapi, and A^atoYa yadayohaA, How good, or beautiful, is this she-camel's returning of her fore legs in her going! i. e. rajoEa yadayohaA fiY sayorihaA. (T, * S, M.) ― -b4- And A^atowN signifies also The act of impelling, or propelling; particularly, of an arrow from a bow. (TA.) See also this word below. -A3- A^atawotuhu, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor. A=tuwhu, (S, Msb,) inf. n. A_itaAwapN, (S, M, Msb, K,) so accord. to A'Obeyd, (M,) and mentioned by Sgh on the authority of AZ, (TA,) and A^atowN, (S, TA,) [I gave him what is termed A_itaAwap, as meaning the tax called xaraAj: this is the signification which seems to be indicated in the S: or] I bribed him; gave him a bribe. (M, Msb, K.) [See also A_itaAwapN below.] -A4- A^atati Aln~axolapu, (T, S, M, K,) and Al$~ajarapu, (M, K,) aor. taA^otuw, (S,) inf. n. A_itaA='N, with kesr, (Kr, M, K,) [in a copy of the T, and in two copies of the S, A^ataA='N, but this is said in the M to be a subst.,] and A^atowN; (M, K;) and Alnxlp ↓ A=tati, inf. n. A_iytaA='N; (T;) The palm-tree [and the tree]
bore: (S:) or put forth its fruit: or showed its being in a good state: (M, K:) or bore much: (T, M, K:) and AtA=' signifies also the increasing, or thriving, of seed-produce. (T.) ― -b2- And A^atati AlmaA$iyapN, inf. n. A_itaA='N, [in a copy of the M A^ataA='N,] The cattle, or camels &c., increased, or yielded increase. (M, K. [In the CK, immediately before this phrase, wAlv~imAri is erroneously put for waAln~amaA='u.]) -A5- taA^otaY for tA^otawiY: see 1 in art. AwY.
4 A=tawa see 1, near the end of the paragraph.

A^atowN * an inf. n. of 1, q. v. -A2- A way, course, mode, or manner. (M, K.) You say, of speech, or language, (M,) and of a speaker, or reciter of a xuTobap, (IAar, M,) maA zaAla EalaY A^atow waAHd It, and he, ceased not to follow one [uniform] way, &c. (M.) -A3- An impulsion; a propulsion; particularly an act of shooting an arrow from a bow: so in a trad., where it is said, kun~aA naromiY AlA^atowayoni We used to shoot one shooting and two shootings; meaning, of arrows from bows, after the prayer of sunset. (TA.) -A4- Death: or [so in the T, but in the K “and,”] a trial; or an affliction. (T, K.) You say, A^ataY EalaY fulaAnK A^atowN Death came upon such a one: or a trial; or an affliction. (ISh, T.) And A_ino A^ataY Eal~aY A^atowN fagulAmiY Hur~N If I die, [or if death befall me,] my slave shall be free. (T.) ― -b2- A vehement sickness or disease: (T, K:) or the fracture of an arm, or of a leg. (T.) -A5- A gift. (S, K.) ― -b2- Butter; (S;) as also ↓ A^ataA='N, (A,) or ↓ A_itaA='N. (TA: [in which it is said to be like kitaAbN; but this I think a mistake: see A^ataA='N below.]) You say, when a skin of milk is agitated, and its butter comes, qado jaA='a A^atowuhu [Its butter has come]. (S, TA.) And you say, ↓ labanN *uw AtA='K Milk having butter. (A, TA.) -A6- A great body or corporeal form or person ($axoSN EaZiymN). (AZ, Sgh, K.)

A^atowapN *
A single coming; as also A^atoyapN. (T.)

A^atowaAnu * a corroborative [or imitative sequent] of A^asowaAnu, which signifies grieving mourning, or sorrowful: (TA:) or i. q. HariySN [vehemently desirous; eager; &c.]. (Mirkát el-Loghah, cited by Golius.)

A^ataA='N * , (T, S, M,) or A_itaA='N, like kitaAbN, (K, [but it is said in the M that the former is a subst. and the latter an inf. n.,] Increase; syn. namaA='N, (S, M, K, [in the CK wAlv~imaAri is erroneously put for waAln~amaA='u,]) and barakapN: (S:) increase, and produce, or net produce, of land; as though from AlA_itaAwapN signifying AlxaraAju: (TA:) gain, or revenue, arising from the increase of land, or from the rent thereof, or the like: (TA, and so in a copy of the S:) the produce of land, and fruits, &c.: (As, T:) what is produced of the fruits (A=kaAl [in the CK AukAl]) of trees: (M, K:) the fruit of palm-trees. (S.) ― -b2- See also A^atowN, in three places.

A^atiY~N * (S, M, Sgh, K) and A^utiY~N [respecting which see what follows] and A_itiY~N, (Sgh, K,) of all which, the first is said by A'Obeyd to be the form used by the Arabs, (TA,) [and all belong to art. AtY, as well as to the present art.,] and ↓ A^ataAwiY~N (M, Sgh, K) and A^utaAwiY~N and A_itaAwiY~N, (Sgh, K,) all these, and the three preceding them, mentioned by Sgh on the authority of AA, but the last of all said by him to be strange, (TA,) A rivulet for which a man makes a way or channel, or an easy course or passage, to his land: (S, M, K:) or a torrent, or flow of water, from another region or quarter: (M, K: [both these meanings mentioned in the M in art. Atw, and the former in art. Aty also, of that work:]) or A^atiY~N signifies a conduit of water; and any channel in which water is made to have an easy course; as also A^utiY~N, mentioned by Sb; or, as some say, this is a pl.: (M:) or any rivulet: (As, T:) or a rivulet less than the [trench called] nuw^oY: (IB:) and sayolN A^atY~N (Lh, T, S, M) and A^ataAwiY~N, (Lh, S, M,) a torrent, or flow of water, that comes one knows not whence: (M:) or that comes when the rain that has produced it has not fallen upon the people to whom it comes: (Lh, S, M:) or that comes from a land upon which rain has fallen to a land upon which rain has not fallen. (T, Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, (T, M,) or the reverse is the case, (T, M, Msb,) all the words above, (AA, T, K,) or A^atiYa and A^ataAwiY~u, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, [the last said in the T to be the most approved,]) A stranger; or a man not of one's own people, or not of one's own kindred: (AA, T, S, M, Mgh:) or a man who asserts his relation to a people of whom he is not: (Msb:) or A^atiY~N signifies one who is among a people of whom he is not: (As, T:) and A^ataAwiY~N, a stranger, who is not in his own country; or, accord. to Ks, a stranger, who is not in his own home: (T:) the pl. of this last is A^ataAwiy~uwna: (S:) [the fem. sing. is A^ataAwy~apN:] and the pl. fem. A^ataAwy~aAtN. (T, S, M.)

A_itaAwapN A_tAwp AtAwh AtAwp
i. q. xaraAjN [i. e. A tax, a tribute, or an impost], (T, S, M, K,) such, for instance, as is levied on land, (TA in the present art.,) and such as is imposed on a slave; (TA in art. Drb;) and any tax or other exaction that is taken by compulsion, or against the will, or that is apportioned to a people: (M: [in the TA “to a place” instead of “to a people:”]) and also, a bribe: or, (accord. to some, M,) particularly, a bribe for water: (M, K:) the pl. is A^ataAwaY, (T, M, K, TA, [but in some copies of the K A^ataAwiY~u, and accord. to copies of the S it is A^ataAwK, being written, with the article, AlA^ataAwiY; both of which appear to be wrong; for it is said to be] like EalaAwaY and haraAwaY, pls. of EilaAwapN and hiraAwapN, (M, TA,) and like sakaAraY; (TA;) changed, [in the accus. case, with the article prefixed,] at the end of a verse, into AlA^ataAwiyaA, for the sake of the rhyme: (M, TA:) this occurs in a verse of El-Jaadee: (S:) it has also for a pl. A_itaAwaAtN, (T,) and A^ut~ay, [in the CK, erroneously, AatiY~N,] which is extr., (M, K,) as though its sing. were A^utowapN, being like ru$~aY, pl. of ru$owapN, (M,) and like Eur~aY, pl. of EurowapN. (TA.) You say, A^ad~aY A_itaAwapa A^aroDihi [He payed the tax of his land]; i. e. xaraAjahaA: and Duribato Ealayohimu AlA_itaAwapu [The tax, or tribute, or impost, was imposed upon them]; i. e. AljibaAyapu: and some assert it to be tropical. (TA.) You say also, $akama faAhu biAloA_itaAwapi [He stopped (lit. bitted) his mouth with the bribe]; i. e. baAl~ri$owapi. (TA.)
A^ataAwiY~N * and its vars.: see A^atY~N, above.

1 A^ataY * , aor. yaA^otiY, (Msb,) and, in the dial. of Hudheyl, yaA^ot, without Y; (S;) and A^atayotuhu, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) [aor. A=tiyhi;] and in the imperative, some of the Arabs say, ti, suppressing the A, like as is done in xu*o and kulo and muro; (IJ, M;) inf. n. A_itoyaAnN, (T, S, * M, Mgh, Msb, K,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb.) and A_itoyaAnapN, (M, K,) which should not be used as an inf. n. of un., unless by a bad poetic licence, (Lth, T,) and A^atoYN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and A^utiYN and A_itiYN and maA^otaApN; (M, K;) He [or it] came; (Msb;) and I came to him, or it; (S, M, Mgh, * Msb, K;) or was, or became, present at it, namely, a place: (Mgh:) as also A^ataA, aor. yaA^otuw; (Msb;) and A^atawotuhu, (T, S, M, K), aor. A=tuwhu: (S:) for which reason, we assign the generality of the words mentioned in art. Atw to the present art. also. (M.) [Accord. to the authorities here indicated for the signification of A^ataY, this verb and jaA='a are syn.: some attempt to distinguish them; but contradict one another in so doing: the slight distinctions that exist between them will be best seen by a comparison of the exs. in this art. with those in art. jyA^:] accord. to Er-Rághib, the proper [or primary] signification of AlA_itoyaAnu is The coming with ease. (TA.) ― -b2- A^ataAhaA, (Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. A_itoyaAnN, (Msb,) [lit. He came to her,] means (assumed tropical:) he lay with her; syn. jaAmaEahaA; (Mgh, Msb;) namely, a woman, (Mgh,) or his wife. (Msb.) Hence an expression in the Kur xxvi. 165. (TA.) ― -b3- A^ataY Alqawoma [He came to the people: and hence,] he asserted his relationship to the people, not being of them. (Msb.) [See A^atiY~u in art. Atw.] ― -b4- A^atay bihi [He came with, or brought, him, and it; or] he made him (a man), and it (a thing, such, for instance, as property), to come. (Kull.) [See also 4: and see, in what follows, other significations of A^ataY trans. by means of bi. Hence, A^ataY biwaladK He begot a child, or children. And A^atato bihi She brought him forth; gave birth to him.] Accord. to Aboo-Is-hák, the meaning of the words in the Kur [ii. 143] A^ayonamaA takuwnuwA yaA^oti bikumu All~`hu jamiyEFA is, Wherever ye be, God will bring you all back unto Himself. (M.) [You say also, A^ataY bibay~inapK He adduced a proof.] See also 3. ― -b5- A^ataY AlA^amora [He entered into, engaged in, or occupied himself with, the thing, or affair: and, as also A^ataY bihi,] he did, executed, or performed, the thing, or affair; (M. K;) and in like manner, Al*~anoba, [and baAl*~anobi,] the crime, sin, or offence. (M.) It is said in the Kur [ix. 54], walaA yaA^otuwna AlS~alaApa A_il~aA wahumo kusaAlaY, meaning And they do not enter into, or engage in, prayer, unless when they are heavy, or sluggish. (TA.) And you say, A^ataY AlfaAHi$aha, [and biAlfaAHi$api,
(see Kur iv. 23 and lxv. 1,)] He entered into, engaged in, or occupied himself with, [or he did, or committed,] that which was excessively foul or evil. (TA.) And A^ataY biAljay~idi mino qawolK A^awo fiEolK [He said, gave utterance to, uttered, or expressed, or he brought to pass, did, or effected, what was good, or excellent; he said, or did, well, or excel-lently]. (Msb in art. jwd.) And A^ataY bijaroYi baEoda jaroYK[He (a horse) performed, or fetched, run after run]. (S in art. tA^m, &c.) ― -b6- walaA yufoliHu Als~aAHiru Hayovu A^ataY[in the Kur xx. 72] means Hayovu kaAna [And the enchanter shall not prosper where he is, or wherever he may be]; (M, Bd, K;) and where he cometh: (Bd:) or Hayovu A^ataY bisiHorihi[where he cometh with his enchantment; or where he performeth his enchantment]: (Jel:) and it is said to mean that where the enchanter is, he must be slain: such is the doctrine of the lawyers. (M.) ― -b7- Z mentions that A^ataYoccurs in the sense of SaAra [He, or it, became; like as we sometimes say, he, or it, came, or came to be]; like jaA='ain the saying, jaA='a AlbinaA='u muHokamFA. (Kull.) [So you say, AlbinaA='u muHokamFA The building became, or came to be, firm, strong, or compact.] ― -b8- The saying, in the Kur [xvi. 1], A^ataY A^amoru A=ll~`hi falaA tasotaEojiluwhumeans [The threatened punishment ordained of God hath approached: therefore desire not ye to hasten it:] its coming hath approached. (TA.) [And in like manner,] A^utiYa fulaAnN, like EuniYa, means Such a one was approached by the enemy come in sight of him. (K.) A^utiyta yaA fulaAnN[Thou art approached &c., O such a one,] is said when one is warned of an enemy that has come in sight of him. (Sgh, TA.) And A^ataY Ealayohimu AlEaduw~umeans The enemy came to them, [or came down upon them, for, as MF observes, A^ataYwhen trans. by means of EalaYseems to imply the meaning of nazala,] overcoming, or overpowering, them. (Bd in xviii. 40.) ― -b9- Hence, A^ataY Ealayohi[and A^ataAhu, as will be seen by what follows,] (assumed tropical:) He destroyed him, or it. (Bd ubi suprà.) And hence, from A_itoyaAnu AlEaduw~i, (Mgh,) A^ataY Ealayohi Ald~ahoru(tropical:) Time, or fortune, destroyed him. (M, Mgh, Msb, K.) Destruction is meant in the Kur [lix. 2], where it is said, fA^atAhumu All~`hu mino Hyovu lamo yaHotasibuwA(assumed tropical:) [But God brought destruction upon them whence they did not reckon, or expect]. (EsSemeen, TA.) And it is said in the Kur [xvi. 28], faA^ataY All~`hu bunoyaAnahumo mina AlqawaAEidi, i. e. (assumed tropical:) But God removed their building from the foundations, and demolished it upon them, so that He destroyed them. (TA.) A^ataY Ealayohialso signifies (assumed tropical:) He caused it to come to an end; made an end of it; consumed it; [devoured it;] exhausted it; came to, or reached, the end of it; namely, a thing; (Kull;) as, for instance, what was in a bowl; (K in art. jrdm;) and what was in a vessel; (K in art. jrjb;) like faraga minohu: (ISd cited in the TA in art. nk$:) or i. q. mar~a bihi[which may be rendered he went away with it; but this, as an explanation of A^ataY Ealayohi, has another meaning, which see in what follows]. (Kull.) And one says, A^utiYa fulaAnN mino maA^omanihi(assumed tropical:) Destruction came to such a one from the quarter whence he felt secure. (TA.) And A^utiYa Ealay yadi fulaAnK(assumed tropical:) Property belonging to such a one perished. (T.) And yuw^otaY duwnahu(assumed tropical:) He is taken away, or carried off, and overcome. (TA.) A poet says,
A^ataY duwna HulowiAlEayo$i Hat~aY A^amar~ahu
nukuwbN Ealay A=vaArihin~a nukuwbu
meaning (assumed tropical:) [Misfortunes, in the footsteps of which were misfortunes,] took away [what was sweet, of life, and rendered it bitter]. (TA.) One says also, mino h`hunaA A^utiyato, [so I find it written, but I think that the last word should be A^utiyta, agreeably with a preceding phrase from the T,] (assumed tropical:) Hence the trial, or affliction, came in upon thee. (Mgh.) And A^utiYa mino jihapi ka*aA, with the verb in the passive form, (assumed tropical:) He missed [his object in respect of such a thing] by laying hold upon it when it was not fit to be laid hold upon. (Msb.) And A^utiYa Alr~ajulu, [also] like EuniYa, (assumed tropical:) The man was deceived, or deluded, and his faculty of sense became altered to him, so that he imagined that to be true which was not true. (TA.) ― -b10- A^ataY Ealayohi is also syn. with mar~a bihi[meaning He, or it, (as, for instance, a period of time,) passed by him, or over him]. (Msb.) You say, A^ata Ealayohi HawolN[A year passed over him; or he became a year old]. (S, K, Msb, in art. Hwl; &c.) ― -b11- A^atati Aln~aAqahu, and maA A^aHosana A^atoYa yadaY h*ihi Aln~Aqapi: see art. Atw.

2 A^t~Y lilmaA='i * , (T, S, M,) or AlmaA='a, (K,) or both, (TA,) inf. n. taA^otiyapNand taA^otiY~N, He smoothed, made easy, or prepared, (sah~ala, S, K, or hay~aA^a, T,) the way, course, passage, or channel, of the water, (T, S, K,) in order that it might pass forth to a place; (S;) he directed a channel for it (M, TA) so that it ran to the places wherein it rested or remained. (TA.) And A^t~Y liA^aroDihi A^atiy~aA He made a rivulet, or a channel for water, to run to his land. (M.) ― -b2- A^t~Y All~`hu lifulaAnK A^amorahu, inf. n. taA^otiyapN, (T, M, * TA,) God prepared, disposed, arranged, or put into a good or right state, [and thus rendered feasible or practicable or easy,] for such a one, his affair. (M, * TA.)

3 A=taAhu A=tAh A=tAp , [inf. n. as below,] He requited, compensated, or recompensed, him. (M, K.) The saying, in the Kur [xxi. 48], waA_ino kaAna mivoqaAla bihaA ↓ Hab~apK mino xarodalK A^atayonaA, some read thus, (M, * TA,) meaning [Though it be the weight of a grain of mustard,] we will bring it [forward for requital]: others read bhA↓ A=tayonaA, meaning we will give [a recompense] for it; in which case the verb is of the measure A^afoEala: or we will requite for it; in which case the verb is of the measure faAEala. (M, TA.) ― -b2- A=tayotuhu EalaY AlA^amori, (T, S, M, Msb,) inf. n. muw^aAtaApN, (T, S,) I agreed with him, or was of one mind or opinion with him, upon, or respecting, the thing, or affair; I complied with him respecting it; (T, S, M, Msb;) in a good manner: (T:) the vulgar say, waAtayotuhu: (S:) this is of the dial. of the people of El-Yemen, inf. n. muwaAtaApN; and is the form commonly current: (Msb:) but it should not be used, except in the dial. of the people of El-Yemen. (T.) ― -b3- [Hence, app., A=taYas meaning He aided; a signification mentioned by Golius, on the authority of Z and Ibn-Maaroof.]

4 A=taAhu A=tAh A=tAp , (S, M, &c.,) inf. n. A_iytaA='N, (TA,) i. q. A^ataY[He came with, or brought, him, or it]; (S;) he made it (a thing) to come, A_ilayohi to him; (TA;) he made, or caused, him, or it, to be present; (Ksh, TA;) he made, or caused, it (a thing) to go, pass, or be conveyed or transmitted, (syn. saAqahu,) A_ilayohi to him. (M, K.) It is said in the Kur [xviii. 61], A=tinaA gadA='a naA, i. e. AiytinaA[Come thou to us with, or bring thou to us, our morningmeal]. (S.) ― -b2- Hence, (Ksh, TA,) inf. n. as above, (T, S,) He gave him (T, S, M, Msb, K) a thing, (M, K,) or property: (Msb:) and you say, haAtiin the sense of the [imperative] A=ti[give thou]. (T.) We read in the Kur. [v. 60, &c.] wayuw^otuwna Alz~akaApa[And they give the portion of property which is the due of the poor]. (TA.) And in [xxvii. 23 of] the same, waA^uwtiyato mino kul~i $aYo'K, meaning And she hath been given somewhat of everything. (M, TA.) [You say also, A^uwtiYa ka*aA as meaning He was gifted, or endowed, with such a thing; as, for instance, a faculty.] See also 3. ― -b3- A=tayotu AlmukaAtaba I made a gift to the slave between whom and me was a contract that he should become free on payment of a certain sum: or I abated, or took off, somewhat of his appointed part-payments, or instalments. (Msb.) ― -b4- maA A=taAkumu Alr~asuwlu, in the Kur lix. 7, means What the Apostle giveth you, of the [spoil termed] faYo', (Bd, Jel,) &c.: (Jel:) or what command he giveth you: (Bd:) or what he commandeth you [to receive]. (Kull.) ― -b5- A^uwtiYa fiY $aYo'K A dispute, or an altercation, was held before him, respecting the meaning of a thing: [perhaps more properly signifying he was given authority to decide respecting a thing:] occurring in a trad. (Mgh.)

5 tA^t~Y lahu *
It (an affair, T, Mgh, Msb, K, or a thing, S, M) was, or became, prepared, disposed, arranged, or put into a good or right state, for him; (T, * S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) and hence, it (a thing) was, or became, feasible or practicable, and easy, to him; (Mgh;) it (an affair) was, or became, facilitated, or easy, to him; (Msb;) the way thereof (i. e. of an affair) was, or became, facilitated, or easy, to him. (TA.) The following is an ex.:
taA^at~aY lahu Ald~ahoru Hat~aY Anojabaro
[Fortune became well, or rightly, disposed for him, so that he became restored to wealth, or competence]: (T:) or taA^at~aY lahu Alxayoru Alx[good fortune, or prosperity, became prepared, &c., for him, &c.]. (So in the TA.) And hence the saying, h`*aA mim~aA yataA^at~aY liYa AlmaDogu This is of the things which it is feasible or practicable, and easy, to me to chew. (Mgh). ― -b2- He applied himself to it with gentleness, (As, S, K,) and so tA^t~Y lahaA, meaning liHaAjatihi, to his needful affair or business, (T,) and entered into it, engaged in it, occupied himself with it, did it, executed it, or performed it, by the
way, or manner, proper, or suitable, to it. (As, T, S, K. [In the CK, for A^ataAhu mino wajohihi, we find AtAhu En wajohih.]) And tA^t~Y fiY A^amrihi He used gentleness, or acted gently, in his affair. (Msb.) ― -b3- tA^t~Y lahu bisahomK Hat~aY A^aSaAbahu He sought him leisurely or repeatedly [with an arrow, app. taking aim in one direction and then in another, until he hit him]. (Z, TA.) ― -b4- jaA='a fulaAnN yataA^at~aYis explained by Fr as meaning yataEar~aDu limaEoruwfika[Such a one came, or has come, addressing, or applying, or directing, himself, or his regard, or attention, or mind, to obtain thy favour, or bounty]. (S.) And you say, tA^t~Y limaEruwfihi, meaning taEar~aDa lahu[He addressed, applied, or directed, himself, &c., to obtain his favour, or bounty]. (TA.) ― -b5- Some say that tA^t~Ysignifies He prepared himself to rise, or stand. (TA.)

10 AstA=tY flaAnAF AstA=ty flAnA
He asked such a one to come, deeming him slow, or tardy. (K.) ― -b2- AstA^tt Aln~aAqapu The she-camel desired to be covered; (A, TA;)IE desired the stallion; (S, M, K;) being excited by lust. (S, A.)
A_it~aY A^tY AtY Aty |tY |ty |tyy : see A^atiY~N.

A^atoyapN *
A single coming; as also A^atowapN; but not ↓ A_itoyaAnapN, unless by a bad poetic licence. (T.) ― -b2- See also A^utiy~apu AljurHi.
A_itoyaAnN A_tyAn AtyAn |ty |tyAn is either an inf. n. of A^ataY, or a simple subst. [signifying A coming]. (Msb.)
A_itoyaAnapN A_tyAn A_tyAnh AtyAnh AtyAnp an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]: (M, K:) see also A^atoyapN.
A^ataA='N * or A_itaA='N: see A^tiY~N.

A^atiY~N * as syn. with A^taAwiY~N: see art. Atw. ― -b2- Also, (M, and so in some copies of the K, where it is said to be like raDiY~N,) or ↓ A_itFY, like riDFY, (so in other copies of the K,) and ↓ A^ataA='N, (M, K,) written by some A_itaA='N, (TA,) What falls, of wood or leaves, into a river: (M, K:) from AlA_itoyaAnu: (M:) pl. A=taA='N[in the CK AitA'] and A^utiY~N. (M, K.) ― -b3- rajulN A^atiY~N A man who is sharp, energetic, vigorous, and effective, in affairs; who applies himself to them with gentleness, and enters into them, or performs them, by the way, or manner, proper, or suitable, to them. (M.) ― -b4- farasN A^atiY~N: see musotaA^otK.

A^utiy~apu AljuroHi * , (so in a copy of the M,) or ↓ A^ut~iy~atuhu, (so in some copies of the K, and accord. to the TA,) or ↓ A^atoyatuhu, (so in other copies of the K,) and ↓ A=tiyatuhu, (so in the M, and in some copies of the K,) or ↓ A_it~iyatuhu, (so in some copies of the K, and accord. to the TA,) or A^atiy~atuhu, (so in a copy of the K,) The matter which comes from the wound: (M, K:) from Aboo-'Alee. (TA.)

A^at~aY *
i. q. Hat~aY; (K;) a dial. var. of the latter. (TA.)
A_itiyatuhu AljurHi Atyth AljrH and A^ut~y~atuhu: see A^utiy~apu AlA=juroHi.
A=tK A=t [Coming; (see also maA^otiY~N;) applied to a man, &c.; and to time, meaning future: also a comer: ― -b2- and hence,] An angel. (Mgh, Msb.)
A=tiyapu AljurHi A=typ AljrH : see A^utiy~apu AljuroHi.

maA^otFY *
A place of coming. (Msb.) [And ↓ maA^otaApF signifies the same: or A road, or way, by which one comes; a way of access; an approach; as also maA^otFY: or, more properly, a means of coming.] ― -b2- maA^otaY AlmaroA^api[The place of access of the woman; i. e. the meatus of her vagina; or her vagina itself;] the maHiyD, or place of menstruation, of the woman. (Zj in the TA in art. HyD.) ― -b3- maA^otaYi AlA^amriand ↓ maA^otaAtuhu The way, or manner, (wajoh, S, or jihap, M, K,) of the affair, (S, M, K,) by which it is, or is to be, entered into, engaged in, done, executed, or performed; like as you say maEonay AlkalaAmiand maEonaAtuhu, meaning the same by both. (S.) You say, A^atayotu AlA^amora mino maA^otAhuand ↓ maA^otaAtihi, (S, M,) i. e., mino wajohihi Al~a*iy yuw^utaY minohu[I entered into, engaged in, did, executed, or performed, the affair by the way, or manner, whereby it should be entered into, &c.], (S,) or mino jihatihi [which means the same]. (M.)
muw^otFY * : see musotaA^otK.
maA^otaApF * : see maA^otFY, in three places.

maA^otiY~N * [pass. part. n. of 1; Come: come to:] is of the measure mafoEuwlN; the wbeing changed into Yand incorporated into the Ywhich is the final radical letter. (S.) In the saying, in the Kur [xix. 62], A_in~ahu kaAna waEoduhu maA^otiy~FA, the meaning is ↓ A=tiyFA [Verily that which He hath promised, or the fulfilment of his promise, is coming]; like as, in the phrase HijaAbFA masotuwrFA, in the Kur [xvii. 47], saAtirFA is meant: or it may be a pass. part. n. [in signification as well as form]; for what cometh to thee, of that which God commandeth, thou comest thereto. (S.) It is said in a prov., maA^otiY~N A^anota A^ay~uhaA Als~awaAdu[lit. Thou art come to, O thou person], meaning there is no escape for thee from this event. (TA.) ― -b2- Applied to a man, it also signifies A^utiYa fiyhi[in a sense indicated in the Kur xxvi. 165]. (TA.)

TariyqN miy^otA='N *
A road to which people come (Th, M, Mgh, Msb) much, or often; (Mgh, Msb;) the latter word being of the measure mifoEaAl, (Th, M, Mgh, Msb,) originally miy^otaAYNor miy^otaAwN; (Msb;) from A^atayotu, (Th, M,) or AlA_itoyaAnu; [or from A^atawotu;] like daArN miHolAalN, i. e. a house where people alight or abide much, or often: (Mgh, Msb:) a road that is frequented (S, M, K) and conspicuous: (M, K:) in [some of] the copies of the K, incorrectly, miy^otaA='apN: (TA:) A' Obeyd has inadvertently written it without [the radical] ', and in the category of fiEolaA='N. (M.) Death is thus termed in a trad., as being a way which every one travels: (TA:) and as that trad. is related, it is without [the radical] '. (M.) ― -b2- my^otaA='N AlT~ariyqi The main part, or middle, of the road; or the part of the road along which one travels: (Sh, TA:) or the space within which the road is comprised; (S, Msb, K;) as also miydaA='u AlTryqi: (TA:) or this last, as also miytaA='u AlTryqi, signifies the measure of the two sides, and the distance, of the road. (L in art. myt.) ― -b3- miy^otaA='Nalso signifies The extreme limit of the distance to which horses run; (S, Msb;) and so miydaA='N. (S, TA.) ― -b4- And i. q. tiloqaA='N(K.) You say, daAriY bimy^otaA='i daAri fulaAnK My house is opposite to the house of such a one; facing it, or fronting it; and so bimiydaA='i diArihi; (S;) and bimiytaA='i daArihi. (L in art. myt.) ― -b5- And banaY Alqawomu buyuwtahumo EalaY miy^otaA='K waAHidK(S) and miydaA='K waAHidK(S, and L in art. myd,) The people built their houses, or constructed their tents, after one mode, manner, fashion, or form. (L in art. myd.) -A2- rajulN miy^taA='N A man who requites, compensates, or recompenses; who gives much, or largely. (M, K.)

farasN musotaA^otK * , and ↓ A^atiY~N, and ↓ muw^otFY, and mstwtY, [so I find it written, perhaps for musotawotK, which may be a dial. van. of musotA^otK, like as waAtayotuhuis of A=tayotuhu,] A mare desiring the stallion. (TA.)

1 A^av~a * , aor.
Aavi3a (T, S, M, L, K) and
Aavu3a and a, (M, L, K,) inf. n. A^avaAvapN(T, S, M, L, K) and A^avaAvN(M, L, K) and A^uvuwvapN, (M,) or A^uvuwuvN, (L, K,) It (anything) was, or became, much in quantity, abundant, or numerous: and great, or large: (M, L:) it (herbage, or a herb,) was, or became, abundant, or plenteous, and tangled, or luxuriant; (T, S, K;) or abundant and tall: (M:) it (hair) was, or became, abundant and long. (M, TA.) ― -b2- A^av~ato, (M, K,) aor.
Aavu3a , inf. n. A^av~N, (M,) said of a woman, She was, or became, large in the hinder parts. (M, K.)

2 A^v~vhu *
He made it plain, level, smooth, soft, or easy to lie or ride or walk upon. (M, K.)

5 tA^v~v *
He obtained, or acquired, goods, household-goods, or furniture and utensils and the like; or abundance of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life; (S;) or property; (S, M;) or wealth; or what was good. (M.)
A^av~N * , fem. with p: see A^aviyvN, in two places.

A^avaAvN *
Goods; or utensils and furniture of a house or tent; household-goods; syn. mataAEN; (T, M;) or mataAEu bayot; (S, Msb, K;) of whatever kind; consisting of clothes, and stuffing for mattresses or the like, or outer garments [&c.]: (M, TA:) or (so accord. to the M and K, but in the T “also,”) all property, (AZ, T, S, M, K,) [consisting of] camels, and sheep or goats, and slaves, and utensils and furniture or householdgoods: (AZ, T, S:) or abundant property: or abundance of property: (M, TA:) [in which last sense it is an inf. n. used as simple subst.:] or what is made, or taken, for use, and i. q. mataAEN; not what is for merchandise: or what is new, of the utensils and furniture of a house or tent; not what is old and worn out: (TA:) [it is a coll.
gen. n., and] the n. un. is with Avr: (AZ, T, S, M, Msb, K:) or it has no n. un.: (Fr, T, S, Msb, K:) if you form a pl. from AvAv, you say, valaAvapu A=v~apK, [originally A^aA^ovivap, like A^aToEimap, pl. of TaEaAm,] and A^uvuvN kaviyrapN. (Fr, T.)

A^aviyvN *
Much in quantity, abundant, or numerous: and great, or large: as also ↓ A^av~N; (M, K;) which is, in my opinion, [says ISd, originally A^avivN,] of the measure faEilN: (M:) the fem. is A^aviyvapN: and the pl. is A_ivaAvNand A^avaAy^ivu; (M, K; *) both being pls. of the masc. and of the fem.; (K;) or the latter is pl. of the fem. only; (M, * MF;) but the former is [pl. of the masc.,] like kiraAmNas pl. of kariymN, (TA,) and is pl. of the fem. also. (M.) You say, nabaAtN A^aviyvN Herbage, or a herb, that is abundant, or plenteous, and tangled, or luxuriant: (T, S:) or abundant and tall. (M.) And $aEarN A^aviyvN Hair that is abundant, and tangled, or luxuriant: (S:) or abundant (T, M) and long. (M.) And liHoyapN A^aviyvapN, and ↓ A^av~apN, A thick beard. (M, TA.) And AimoraA^apN A^aviyvapN A fleshy woman: (M, TA:) pl. A^avaAy^ivu, (M,) signifying fleshy women; (S, M, K;) as also A_ivaAvN: (M:) or the former of these pls. signifies tall, full-grown, women. (K.)

A^avaAviY~u *
i. q. A^avaAfiY~u, (K,) i. e. The [three] stones which are set up and upon which the cooking-pot is placed: the [second] vis said to be a substitute for f, and some hold the hemzeh to be augmentative. (TA.)

1 A^avara xuf~a AlbaEiyri * , aor.
Aavura , inf. n. A^avorN, He made an incision in the foot of the camel [in order to know and trace the footprints]; as also ↓ A^v~rhu. (M.) And A^avara AlbaEiyri He made a mark upon the bottom of the camel's foot with the iron instrument called miy^ovarap in order that the footprints upon the ground might be known: (T, TT:) or he scraped the inner [i. e. under] part of the camel's foot with that instrument in order that the footprints might be traced. (S.) -A2- A^avara AlHadiyva, (T, S, M, A, &c.,) Eani Alqawomi, (M,) aor.
Aavura (S, M, Msb, K) and
Aavira , (M, K,) inf. n. A^avorN(T, S, M, Msb, K) and A^avaArahNand A^uvorahN, (M, K,) the last from Lh, but in my opinion, [says ISd,] it is correctly speaking a subst., and syn. with maA^ovurahNand maA^ovarahN, (M,) He related, or recited, the tradition, narrative, or story, as received, or heard, from the people; transmitted the narrative, or story, by tradition, from the people: (T, S, * M, A, L, Msb, * K: *) or he related that wherein they had preceded [as narrators: so I render A^anobaA^ahumo bimaA sabaquwA fiyhi, believing hmto have been inserted by a mistake of a copyist in the M, and hence in the L also:] from AlA^avaru. (M, L.) [See A^avarN.] You say also, A^vara Eanohu Alka*iba, meaning He related, as heard from him, what was false. (L, from a trad.) ― -b2- A^avorN, aor.
Aavura , (M,) inf. n. A^avorN, (M, K.) also signifies Multum inivit camelus camelam. (M, K.) -A3- A^avira liloA^amori, aor.
Aavara , He applied, or gave, his whole attention to the thing, or affair, having his mind unoccupied by other things. (K.) -A4- A^avira Ealay AloA^amori He determined, resolved, or decided, upon the thing, or affair. (T, K.) -A5- laqado A^avirotu A^ano A^afoEala ka*aA w ka*aA, (Lth, T, L,) inf. n. A^avorNand A^avarN, (L,) I have assuredly purposed to do such and such things. (Lth, T, L.) -A6- See also 4. -A7- And see 10.

2 A^v~r fiyhi * , inf. n. taA^oviyrN, He, or it, made, (Msb,) or left, (M, K,) or caused to remain, (S,) an impression, or a mark, or trace, upon him, or it. (S, * M, Msb, K. *) It is said of a sword, [meaning It made, or left, a mark, or scar, upon him, or it,] and in like manner of a blow. (T, TA.) [Whence,] A^av~ara fiY EiroDihicross; [He scarred his honour]. (K in art. wx$.) You say also, A^av~ara biwajohihi wabijabiynihi Als~ujuwdu[Prostration in prayer made, or left, a mark, or marks, upon his face and upon his forehead]. (T, * TA.) See also 1, first sentence. -A2- He, or it, made an impression, or produced an effect, upon him, or it; impressed, affected, or influenced, him, or it. (The Lexicons passim.) -A3- A^av~ara ka*aA bika*aA, (T, TT,) or ↓ A=vara, (K,) He, or it, made such a thing to be followed by such a thing. (T, TT, K. *)

4 A=vara see 2, last sentence. -A2- [Hence, app.,] A=vrhu, (As, T, M, Msb,) inf. n. A_iyvaArN, (As, T,) He preferred him, or it. (As, T, M, Msb, TA.) You say, A=vrhu Ealayohi He preferred him before him: so in the Kur xii. 91. (As, M.) And A=varotu fulAanFA EalaY nafosiY[I preferred such a one before myself], from AlA_iyvaAr. (S.) And qado A=varotuka I have preferred for thee it; I have preferred to give thee it, rather than any other thing. (T.) And A=vara A^ano yafoEala ka*aA He preferred doing such a thing; as also ↓ A^avira, inf. n. A^avarN; and A^avara. (M.) -A3- A=vralso signifies He chose, or elected, or selected. (K.) -A4- And A=virhu He honoured him; paid him honour. (M, K.)

5 tA^v~r *
It received an impression, or a mark, or trace; became impressed, or marked. (Msb.) -A2- He, or it, had an impression made, or an effect produced, upon him, or it; became impressed, affected, or influenced. (The Lexicons passim.) -A3- See also 8.
8 Ay^otavarahu * , [written with the disjunctive alif Aiytavarahu,] and ↓ tA^v~rhu, He followed his footsteps: (M, K:) or did so diligently, or perseveringly. (TA.)

10 AstA^vr EalaY A^aSoHaAbihi * ; (ISk, S, K;) and Ealayohimo ↓ A^avira, aor.
Aavara ; (K;) He chose for himself [in preference to his companions] (ISk, S, K) good things, (K,) in partition, (TA,) or good actions, and qualities of the mind. (ISk, S.) And AstA^vr bAl$~aYo'i, (S, K,) or Al$~aYo'a, (Msb,) He had the thing to himself, with none to share with him in it: (S, Msb, K:) and the former signifies he appropriated the thing to himself exclusively, (M, K,) EalaY gayorihi in preference to another or others. (M.) It is said in a trad., A_i*aA AsotaA^ovara All~`hu bi$aYo'K faAloha Eanuhu When God appropriateth a thing to Himself exclusively, then be thou diverted from it so as to forget it. (M.) And one says, AisotA^ovara All~`hu bifulaAnK, (and fulaAnFA, TA,) [God took such a one to Himself,] when a person has died and it is hoped that he is forgiven. (S, M, A, K.)

A^avorN * , (AZ, T, S, A, L, K, &c.,) said by Yaakoob to be the only form known to As, (S,) and ↓ A^avarN, which is a form used by poetic licence, (M, L,) and ↓ A^vorapN, (M, L, K,) and ↓ A^uvurN, (M,) and ↓ A^uvurN, which is in like manner a sing., not a pl., (T, L,) and ↓ A^vorapN, (El-Leblee,) and ↓ A^aviyro, (K,) The diversified wavy marks, streaks, or grain, of a sword; syn. firinodN; (As, T, S, M, A, L, K;) and tasalosulN; and diybaAjapu; (AZ, T;) and its lustre, or glitter: (M, L:) pl. [of the first] A^uvuro: (T, M, L, K:) the pl. of A^uvorapNis A^uvarN. (El-Leblee.) Khufáf Ibn-Nudbeh Es-Sulamee says, [describing swords,]
jalaAhaA AlS~ayoqaluwna faA_axolaSuwhaA
xifaAfAF kul~uhaA yatoqiY biA^avori
[The furbishers polished them, and freed them from impurities, making them light: each of them preserving itself from the evil eye by means of its lustre]: i. e., each of them opposes to thee its firinod: (S, L:) yatoqiYis a contraction of yat~aqiY; and the meaning is, when a person looks at them, their bright rays meet his eye, so that he cannot continue to look at them. (L.)
