A^uvorN * The scar of a wound, remaining when the latter has healed; (As, Sh, T, S, M, K;) as also ↓ A^uvurN(S, K) and ↓ A^avarN: (Sh, T:) pl. A=vaArN, though properly A_ivaArN, with kesr to the A [but why this is said, I do not see; for A=vaArNis a regular pl. of all the three forms of the sing.;] and A_uvuwrNmay be correctly used as a pl. (Sh, T, L.) -A2- A mark made with a hot iron upon the inner [i. e. under] part of a camel's foot, by which to trace his footprints: (M, K:) pl. A^uvuwrN. (M.) [See also A^uvorapN.] -A3- Lustre, or brightness, of the face; as also ↓ A^uvurN. (M, K.) -A4- See A^avorN. -A5- See also A_ivorN.

A_ivorN A^vAr A^vr A^vrY A_vr Avr vAr vr vry wvr |vr : see A^avarN, in three places: ― -b2- and A^avorN: ― -b3- and see A=virN, in two places. -A2- Also, (S, M, K,) and ↓ A^uvorN, (M, K,) but the latter is disallowed by more than one authority, (TA,) What is termed the xulaASap[q. v.] of clarified butter: (S, M, K:) or, as some say, the milk when the clarified butter has become separated from it. (M.) [See also qi$odapN.]

A^avarN *
A remain, or relic, of a thing; (M, Msb, K;) as of a house; as also ↓ A^avaArapN: (Msb:) a trace remaining of a thing; and of the stroke, or blow, of a sword: (S:) see also A^uvorN: a sign, mark, or trace; opposed to the Eayon, or thing itself: (TA:) a footstep, vestige, or track; a footprint; the impression, or mark, made by the foot of a man [&c.] upon the ground; as also ↓ A_ivorN: and an impress, or impression, of anything: (El-Wá'ee:) pl. A=vaArNH(M, Msb, K) and A_uvuwrN. (M, K.) [The sing. is also frequently used in a pl. sense: and the former of these pls. is often used to signify Remains, or monuments, or memorials, of anti-
quity, or of any past time.] It is said in a prov., laA A^aTolubu A^avarFA baEoda EayonK I will not seek a trace, or vestige, [or, as we rather say in English, a shadow,] after suffering a reality, or substance, to escape me: or, as some relate it, laA taTolubo seek not thou. (Har pp. 120 and 174.) And one says, qaTaEa All~`hu A^avarahu [May God cut short his footsteps]: meaning may God render him crippled: for when one is crippled, his footsteps cease. (TA.) And fulaAnN layaSoduqu A^avaruhu, and A^avarahu, Such a one, if asked, will not tell thee truly whence he comes: (M in art. Sdq:) a prov. said of a liar. (TA.) And xarajotu, (S, M, * K,) and jay^otu, (El-Wá'ee, Msb,) fyi A^avarihi, and ↓, fy A_ivorihi, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) the former of which is said by more than one to be the more chaste, (TA,) [but the latter seems to be the more common,] and EalaY A^avarihi, and ↓ ElY A_ivorihi, (El-Wá'ee, Msb,) I went out, (S, &c.,) and I came, (El-Wá'ee, Msb,) after him: (M, A, K:) or at his heel: (Expos. of the Fs:) or following near upon him, or hard upon him, or near after him, or following him nearly: (Msb:) as though treading in his footsteps. (El-Wá'ee.) And A^avara *iY A^aviyrayoni: see A=virN. (K.) ― -b2- An impress or impression, a mark, stamp, character, or trace, in a fig. sense; an effect. (The Lexicons passim.) You say, EalaY maA$iyatihi A^avarN HasanN Upon his camels, or sheep, or goats, is an impress of a good state, or condition; of fatness, and of good tending; like A_iSobaEN. (TA in art. SbE.) And A_in~ahu laHasanu AlA^avarifiY maAlihi Verily he has the impress of a good state, or condition, in his camels, or sheep, or goats; like Hasanu AlA_iSobaEi, and Almasi. (TA ubi suprà.) And Ealayohi A^avaru ka*aA He, or it, bears the mark, stamp, character, or trace, of such a thing. (The Lexicons passim.) ― -b3- [The pl.] A=vaArNalso signifies Signs, or marks, set up to show the way. (K.) ― -b4- Also the sing., i. q. A^avorN, q. v. (M, L.) ― -b5- Also i. q. xabarN [both of which words are generally held to be syn., as meaning A tradition, or narration relating or describing a saying or an action &c., of Mo- hammad]: (M, K:) or, accord. to some, the former signifies what is related as received from [one or more of] the Companions of Mohammad; (TA;) but it may also be applied to a saying of the Prophet; (Kull p. 152;) and the latter, what is from Mohammad himself; (TA;) or from another; or from him or another: (Kull p. 152:) or the former signifies i. q. sun~apN[a practice or saying, or the practices and sayings collectively, of Mo- hammad, or any other person who is an authority in matters of religion, namely, any prophet, or a Companion of Mohammad, as handed down by tradition]: (S, A:) pl. A=vaArN. (S, M.) You say, wajadotuhu fiy AlA^avari[I found it in the traditions of the practices and sayings of the Prophet; &c.]: and fulaAnN mino Hamalapi AlA=vaAri[Such a one is of those who bear in their memories, knowing by heart, the traditions of the practices and sayings of the Prophet; &c.]. (A.) ― -b6- A man's origin; as in the sayings, maA yudoraY lahu A^ayona A^avarN It is not known where was his origin; and maA yudoraY lahu maA A^varN It is not known what is his origin. (Ks, Lh, M.) ― -b7- The term, or period, of life: so called because it follows life: (Msb, TA:) or from the same word as signifying the print of one's foot upon the ground; because when one dies, his footprints cease to be seen. (TA.) ― -b8- [For the former of these two reasons,] A=vaArahumoin the Kur xxxvi. 11 means The rewards and punishments of their good and evil lives. (M, L.) -A2- A=vaArNis also a pl. of vaA^orN, q. v.; formed by transposition from A^avoA=rN. (Yaa- Koob, and M in art. vA^r.)

A^avurN * A man who chooses for himself [in preference to his companions] (ISk, S, M, K) good things, (K,) in partition, (M, TA,) or good actions, and qualities of the mind; (ISk, S;) as also ↓ A^avirN (M, K.)
A^avirN * : see A^avurN.
A^uvurN * : see A^uvorN, in two places: ― -b2- and see A^avorN.
A^avurN * : see A^avaArapN.

A^uvorapN * : see A^avaArapN. ― -b2- A mark which is made by the Arabs of the desert upon the inner [i. e. under] part of a camel's foot; as also ↓ taA^ovuwrN, and, accord. to some, ↓ tuw^ovuwrahu, whence one says, raA^ayotu A^uvoratahu, and ↓ tuw^ovuwrahu, I saw the place of his footsteps upon the ground: (M:) or the abrasion of the inner [i. e. under] part of a camel's foot with the instrument of iron called miy^ovarap and tuw^ovuwr, in order that his footprints may be traced. (S.) [See also A^uvorN.] ― -b3- See also A^avorN. ― -b4- And see maA^ovurapN. ― -b5- Preference. (A.) You say, lahu EinodiY A^uvorapN He has a preference in my estimation. (A.) And huwa *uw A^uvorapK Einoda AlA^amiyri He has a preference in the estimation of the prince, or commander. (A.) And fulaAnN *uw A^uvorapK Einoda fulaAnK, (TA,) or ↓ A^avarapK, (T,) Such a one is a favourite with such a one. (T, TA.) See also A^avarapN, in two places. ― -b6- A^uvorapa *iY A^aviyrK: see A=virN. -A2- Dearth, scarcity, drought, or sterility, (jadobN[in the CK ja*ob],) and an unpleasant state or condition. (M, K.)
A_ivorapN A^vAr A^vr A^vrY A^vrh A^vrp A_vr A_vrh Avrh Avrp vAr vr vry wvr |vr |vrh : see A^avarapN. ― -b2- A_ivorapF: see A=virN.

A^avarapN * : see A^avaArapN. ― -b2- A subst. [signifying The appropriation of a thing or things to oneself exclusively: the having a thing to oneself, with none to share with him in it:] from AisotaA^ovara biAl$~aYo'i. (S, M.) And, as also ↓ A^uvorapNand ↓ A_ivorapNand ↓ A_uvoraY, The choice for oneself [in preference to his companions] of good things, (M, * K, * TA,) in partition; (M, TA;) the choice and preference of the best of things, and taking it, or them, for oneself: (TA:) the pl. of the second is A^uvarN. (TA.) You say, A^axa*ahu bilaA A^avarapK, and ↓ blA A^uvorapK, [&c.,] He took it without a choice and preference of the best of the things, and the taking the best for himself. (T, TA.) And a poet says,
faqulota lahu yaA *iy^obu halo laka fYi A^axK
Ealayoka walaA buxoli ↓ yuw^aAsiy bilaA A^uvoray
[And I said to him, O wolf, hast thou a desire for a brother who will share without choice of the best things for himself in preference to thee, and without niggardness?]. (M, TA.) See also A^uvorapN.
A^uvoraY * : see A^avarapN, in two places.

A^aviyrN * : see A^avarapN. ― -b2- [That makes a large footprint, or the like.] You say, daAb~apN A^aviyarpN A beast that makes a large footprint upon the ground with its hoof, (AZ, S, M, K,) or with its soft foot, such as that of the camel. (AZ, S.) ― -b3- A man possessing power and authority; honoured: pl. A^uvaraA='u: fem. A^aviyrapN. (M.) ― -b4- fulaAnN A^aviyriY Such a one is my particular friend: (S, K:) or is the person whom I prefer. (A.) fulaAnN A^aviyrNEinoda fulaAnK Such a one is a favourite with such a one. (T.) ― -b5- A=vira *iY A^aviyrK, and A^aw~ala *iY A^aviyrK, &c.: see A=virN. ― -b6- $aYo'N kaviyrN A^aviyrN[A thing very abundant, copious, or numerous]: Avyris here an imitative sequent, (S, K, *) like baviyrN. (S.) -A2- AlA^aviyru [ ὁ αἰθήρ, The ether;] the ninth, which is the greatest, sphere, which rules over [all] the other spheres: [said to be] so called because it affects the others (yuw^aviru fiY gayorihi). (MF.) [It is also called falaku AlA^aTolasi, and falaku AlEaro$i; and is said to be next above that called falaku AlkurosiY~i.]

A^avaArapN * : see A^avarN. You say, saminati AlA_bilu EalaY A^avaArapK, (S, M, *) or ElY A^avaArapK mino $aHomK, (A,) The camels acquired fat, upon, or after, remains of fat. (S, M, * A.) And gaDiba Ealay A^avaArapK qibola *aAka He became angry the more, having been angry before that. (Lh, M.) And A^agoDabaniy fulaAnN EalaY A^avaArapi gaDabK Such a one angered me when anger yet remained in me. (A.) And A^avaArapN mino EilomK, and ↓ A^avarapN, (T, S, M, K,) and ↓ A^uvorapN, (M, K,) or ↓ A^avorapN, (T,) the first of which is the most approved, (M,) and is [originally] an inf. n., [see A^avara AlA=Hadiyva,] (T,) signify A remain, or relic, of knowledge, (Zj, T, S, M, K, and Jel in xlvi. 3 of the Kur,) transmitted, or handed down, (K, Jel,) from the former generations: (Jel:) or what is transmitted, or handed down, of knowledge: (Zj, M:) or somewhat transmitted from the writings of the former generations: (TA:) by the knowledge spoken of [in the Kur ubi suprà] is meant that of writing, which was given to certain of the prophets. (I'Ab.)

A=virN A=vr One who relates, or recites, a tradition, narrative, or story, or traditions, &c., as received, or heard, from another, or others; a narrator thereof. (T, S, * L.) The saying of 'Omar, on his being forbidden by Mohammad to swear by his father, maA Halafotu bihi *aAkirAF walaA A=virFA, means I did not swear by him uttering (the oath) as proceeding in the first instance from myself, nor repeating (it) as heard from another particular person. (A'Obeyd, T, S, TA.) ― -b2- A^afoEalu h*aA A=virFA m~aA, (IAar, T, S, K,) and A=virFAwithout mA, (IAar, T,) and ↓ A=vira *iY A^aviyrK, (S, K,) mean I will do this the first of every thing. (S, K. *) And in like manner, after laqiytuhu[I met him, or it], one says, A=virFA m~aA, [and ↓ A=vira *iY A^aviyrK,] and ↓ A^aw~ala *iY A^aviyrK, (M, K,) and
A=vira *aAti yadiY, (M,) or *aAti yadayoni, (K,) and *iY yadayoni, (IAar, M, K,) and ↓ A^aviyrapa *iY A^aviyrK, and ↓ *iY A^viyrayoni ↓ A_uvorapa, (K,) and ↓ A=vira *iY A^aviyrayoni, (M, as from Lh,) or ↓ *iY A^aviyrayoni ↓ A^avara, (K,) and ↓ *iY A^aviyrayoni, ↓ A_ivora and m~aA ↓ A_ivorapF : (Lh, M, K:) or, as some say, ↓ AlA^aviyrusignifies the daybreak, or down; and ↓ *uw A^aviyrK, the time thereof. (M, TA.) Fr says that AibodaA^o bih*aA A=virFA m~aA, and ↓ A=vira *iY A^aviyrK, and ↓ A^aviyra *iY A^aviyrK, signify Begin thou with this first of every thing. (TA.) One says also, AifoEalohu, A=virFA m~aA, (T, M, TA,) and m~aA ↓ A_ivorFA, (M, TA,) meaning Do thou it [at least], if thou do nothing else: (T, M, TA:) or, as some say, do thou it in preference to another thing, or to other things: mAbeing redundant, but [in this case] not to be omitted, because [it is a corroborative, and] the meaning of the phrase is, do thou it by choice, or preference, and with care. (M, TA.) Mbr says that the phrase xu*o h*aA A=virFA m~aAmeans Take thou this in preference; i. e., I give it thee in preference; as though one desired to take, of another, one thing, and had another thing offered to him for sale: and mAis here redundant. (T, TA.)
taA^ovuwrN * : see A=uvorapN.
tuw^ovuwrN * : see A=vorapN, in two places: and see miy^ovarapN, in two places.

maA^vurapN * (T, S, M, K, &c.) and maA^ovarapN(S, M, K) and ↓ A^uvorapN(M, K) A generous quality or action; (AZ, S;) so called because related, or handed down, by generation from generation: (S:) or a generous quality that is inherited by generation from generation: (M, K:) a generous quality, or action, related, or handed down by tradition from one's ancestors: (A:) a cause of glorying: (AZ:) and precedence in A^uvorapN[or grounds of pretension to respect, &c.]: pl. of the first and second, Hasab. (AZ, T.)

miy^ovarapN * and ↓ tuw^ovuwrN An iron instrument (S, M, K) with which the bottom of a camel's foot is marked, in order that his footprints upon the ground may be known: (M:) or, with which the inner [i. e. under] part of a camel's foot is scraped, in order that his footprints may be traced: (S, K:) or ↓ tw^vwrhas a different meaning, explained above, voce A^uvorapN. (M.) The miyvarapof a horse's saddle is without hemz. (S.)

maA^ovuwrN * A camel having a mark made upon the bottom of his foot with the iron instrument called miy^ovarap, in order that his footprints upon the ground may be known: (T:) or having the inner [i. e. under] part of his foot scraped with that instrument, in order that his footprints may be traced. (S.) ― -b2- A sword having in its maton[or broad side; or the middle of the broad side, of the blade,] diversified wavy marks, streaks, or grain, or lustre or glitter: (M, K: [in some copies of the latter of which, instead of A^avorN, I find A^avarN:]) or having its mtn of female, or soft, iron, and its edge of male iron, or steel: (K:) or that is said to be of the fabric of the jinn, or genii; (S, M, K*) and not from AlA^avor, as signifying Alfirinod: (S, M:) so says As: (S:) [ISd says,] mA^vwris in my opinion a pass. part. n. that has no verb: (M:) or it signifies an ancient sword, which has passed by inheritance from great man to great man. (A.) ― -b3- A tradition, narrative, or story, handed down from one to another, from generation to generation. (T, S, A.)

1 A^avafa Alqidora * : see 2. -A2- A^avafahu, aor.
Aavifa , (T, S, M, K,) inf. n. A^avofN, (T, M,) He followed him. (Ks, T, S, M, K.) ― -b2- He drove away, or drove away and pursued closely, or hunted, him; syn. Taradahu. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b3- He sought, or sought after, or pursued after, him, or it: in which sense the aor. is Av~f AlqidNra, (AA, K) and taA^oviyfNalso. (So in some copies of the K.)

2 Av~f Alqidora Avf Alqdr , (T, S, M, K,) inf. n. taA^oviyfN, (S, K,) He put the cooking-pot upon the A^avaAfiY[pl. of A^uvofiy~apN, q. v.]; (T,* S, M,* K;) as also ↓ A^avafahaA, (M, TA,) inf. n. A^avofN; (TA;) or ↓ A=vafahaA, (so in some copies of the K in art. vfY,) inf. n. A_iyvaAfN; (TA in that art.;) the first of which is a dial. var. of vaf~aAhaA, inf. n. tavofiyapN; (S;) and ↓ A^avofaAhaA, whence qidorN muw^avofaApN. (M.)
4 A=vafa see 2.

5 taA^av~Ffati Alqidoru *
The cooking-pot was put upon the A^avaAfiY. (TA.) -A2- taA^av~afuwhu They surrounded him, or it: (S, K: *) they became around him, or it, like the A^uvofiy~ap[or rather like the A^avaAfiY]: (M:) they collected themselves together around him, or it. (A, TA.) ― -b2- tA^v~f AlmakaAna, (T, S, K,) or biAlmakaAni, (M,) He (a man, S) kept to the place; (T, K;) remained in it; (M;) did not quit it. (AZ, T, S, M.) ― -b3- tA^v~fhualso signifies He followed after him, and pressed or importuned him, and ceased not to incite him. (T, K.) In my opinion, [says Az,] this is not in any way derived from AlA^uvofiy~apu; but from A^avafotu Alr~ajula, meaning “ I followed the man.” (T.) ― -b4- And tA^v~fwA EalaY AlA^amori They aided, or assisted, one another to do, or accomplish, the thing, or affair. (M, L.)

Q. Q. 1 A^avofaY Alqidora * : see 2. [But accord. to Az, in the T, yuw^avofiY, as aor. of A^avofaY, is yuvofiYreduced to its original form; and the like is said in the S and M in art. vfY. If this be the case, muw^avofaApN, q. v., may be muvofaApNreduced in the same manner, i. e., to its original form.]

A^avifN * [probably a mistake for ↓A=vifN] Continuing, permanent, constant, firm, or established: (K, TA:) so in the Moheet. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (K, and so in a copy of the S,) or ↓ A=vifN, [agreeably with analogy, and therefore more probably the correct form,] (so in other copies of the S and in the T,) Following. (Ks, T, S, K.)

A^uvofiy~apN * and A_ivofiy~apN[the former of which is the more common, and this only I find in copies of the T,] The stone [which is one of the three] whereon the cooking-pot is placed: (A'Obeyd, M, K:) it is, with the Arabs, a stone like the head of a man: (T:) the pl. is A^avaAfiy~uand A^avaAfK; (T, S, [in which latter it is written differently in different copies, with the article prefixed, AlA^avaAfiy~uand AlA^avaAfiy, but in both manners in art. vfY,] M, K;) the latter being allowable; (T,) or, accord. to Akh, the latter only is used by the Arabs; (M;) applied to the three stones mentioned above: (TA in art. sfE; &c.:) upon these the cooking-pot is set up; but what is of iron, having three legs, is not called Avfy~p, but minoSabN; (T;) [and this is what is meant by A^avofiy~apN mino HadiydKin art. sfEin the K;] i. e. an iron trivet upon which a cooking-pot is set up. (TA in art. nSb.) A^uvofy~apNmay be of the measure fuEoluwyapN[from Avf], and it may be of the measure A^ufoEuwlapN[from vfY; in either case originally A^uvofuwyapN]. (A, L.) vaAlivapu AlA^avaAfiYsignifies The part, not detached, of a mountain; by the side of which, two pieces are put [for the cookingpot to be set thereon]. (A'Obeyd, T, K.) And hence the saying, (A'Obeyd, T,) ramaAhu All~`hu bvaAlivapi, AlA^avaAfiy(A'Obeyd, T, K) May God smite him with the mountain; meaning, with a calamity; (Th, TA, K in art. vfY;) with a calamity like the mountain [in greatness]; (Th, M;) for when they do not find the third of the AvAfY, they rest the cooking-pot [partly] upon the mountain: (M, K, in art. vfY:) or, with difficulties, or troubles, or calamities: (As, T:) or, with all evil; evils being likened to one Avfy~pafter another, and the third being the last: (T, K:) so says Aboo-Sa'eed: (T:) or, with the last of evil; and the last of everything hateful: (AO in Har p. 84:) or, with a great calamity. (Har ib.) One says also, AlA^avaAfiY fulaAnN vaAlivapu, meaning (tropical:) Such a one is the heaviest, most burdensome, or most troublesome, of the people. (Har ubi suprà.) ― -b2- [Hence also,] AlA^avaAfiYis a name applied to (assumed tropical:) certain stars [accord. to Ideler, as mentioned by Freytag in his Lex., the stars σ and τ and υ Draconis] over against the head of the qidor; which is the name of certain stars disposed in a round form. (AHát, K.) [Also] a name given by the vulgar to (assumed tropical:) [The three chief stars in the constellation called] Al$~aloyaAqu[i. e. Lyra]. (Kzw.) ― -b3- The sing., (K,) i. e. each of the two forms thereof, but written in the copies of the S with damm [only], (TA in art. vfY,) or [only] the latter, with kesr, (M, and so in the K in art. vfY,) also signifies (assumed tropical:) A number, (M,) or a great number, (K, and so in the S in art. vfY,) and a company, or congregated body, of men: (M, K:) pl. as above. (M.) You say, humo Ealayohi A^uvofiy~apN waAHidapN(assumed tropical:) [They are against him one band]. (TA.) And baqiyato mino baniY fulaAnK A^uvofiy~apN xa$onaA='u There remained of the sons of such a one a great number. (S in art. vfY.)
A=vfN A=vf : see A^avfN, in two places.

muw^av~afN * (assumed tropical:) Short, broad, plump, and fleshy. (K.) ― -b2- And, with p, (tropical:) A woman whose husband has two wives beside her; she being the third of them: they being likened to the A^avaAfiYof the cookingpot. (M.) [See also muvaf~aApN, in art. vfY.)

qidorN muw^avofaApN *
A cooking-pot put upon the A^avaAfiY
[pl. of A^uvofiy~apN, q. v.]. (M, and K in art. vfY: in some copies of the latter, mw^ovafaApN.) [See Q. Q. 1.]

A_i$okaAlN * and A^u$okuwlN i. q. $imoraAxN [A fruit-stalk of the raceme of a palm-tree, upon which are the dates]; like EivokaAlN and EuvokuwlN: the hemzeh in each is a substitute for E; but by J [and others] it is held to be augmentative, and the words are mentioned in art. $kl, q. v. (TA.)

1 A^avala * , aor.
Aavila , inf. n. A^uvuwlN, It (anything, M) had, or came to have, root, or a foundation; or it was, or became, firm, or established, and firmly rooted or founded; as also ↓ tA^v~l. (M, K.) ― -b2- Also, inf. n. as above, It (dominion) was, or became, great; (TA;) and so ↓ the latter verb. (M, K. *) ― -b3- And A^avula, inf. n. A^avaAlapN, said of high rank, or nobility, It was, or became, old, of ancient origin, or of long standing. (TA.) -A2- See also 5.

2 A^v~lhu * , (M, K,) inf. n. taA^oviylN, (S, K,) He made it (his wealth, or property, M, K, and so applied it is tropical, TA) to have root, or a foundation; or to become firm, or established, and firmly rooted or founded; syn. A^aS~alahu (S, * M, K.) ― -b2- He (God, T, M,* TA) made it (a man's dominion, T, M, K) to be, or become, firm, firmly established, stable, or permanent: (T:) or great: (M, K:) and he (a man) made it (a thing) lasting, or permanent. (TA.) IAar the following verse,
tuw^av~ilu kaEobN EalaY~a AlqaDaA
farab~iY yugay~iru A^aEomaAlahaA
[app. meaning Kaab would oblige me to make payment, or the like, (as though establishing against me the duty of doing so,) but my Lord changes their actions,] explaining it by saying, i. e. tulozimuniY; but (ISd says,) I know not how this is. (M.) ― -b3- He (God, M) made it (a man's wealth, or property,) to increase; or put it into a good, or right, state, or condition; syn. zak~aApa. (M, K.) ― -b4- A^at~alotuhu birijiAlK I multiplied him [meaning his party] by men. (TA.) ― -b5- A^av~alotu Ealayohi Ald~uyuwna I collected against him the debts. (TA.) ― -b6- A^v~l A^aholahu He clad his family with the most excel-lent of clothing: (M:) or he clad them (M, K) with the most excellent of clothing, (K,) and did good to them, or acted well towards them. (M, K.) -A2- A^v~l, [used intransitively,] (M, K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He (a man, K) became abundant in his wealth, or property. (M, K.)

5 tA^v~l * : see 1, in two places. ― -b2- Also It (a thing) became collected together. (K.) ― -b3- He took for himself, got, or acquired, what is termed A^avolap, i. e. miyrp [meaning victuals, or provision]; (M, K;) baEoda HaAjapK [after want]. (M.) ― -b4- He took for himself, got, or acquired, a source, stock, or fund, (A^aSolK,) of wealth, or property. (S, TA.) ― -b5- And tA^v~l maAlFA He collected, or gained, or acquired, wealth, or property, (M, K,) and took it for himself: (M:) [said in the TA to be tropical:] or he collected wealth, or property, and took it for himself, or got it, or acquired it, as a source, stock, or fund: (Mgh:) and maAlAF ↓ A^avala, inf. n. A^uvuwlN, signifies the same as tA^v~lhu. (TA.) ― -b6- hump yataA^av~aluwna Aln~aAsa They take A^uvaAl, i. e. wealth, or property, from men. (TA.) ― -b7- tA^v~l biy^orAF He dug a well (T, S, M, K) for himself. (T, TA.)

A^avolN *
A kind of trees; (S, K;) a species of the TarofaA=' [or tamarisk; so applied in the present day; termed by Forskål (Flora Aeg. Arab. p. lxiv.) tamarix orientalis]; (S, TA;) or a kind of trees, (T, M,) or a certain tree, (Mgh,) resembling the TrfA=', (T, M, Mgh,) except that it is of a better kind, (T,) or except that it is larger, and better in its wood, (M,) of which are made yellow and excellent [vessels of the kind called] A^aqodaAH, and of which was made the Prophet's pulpit; it has thick stems, of which are made doors and other things; and its leaves are of the kind called Eabal, like those of the TrfA=': (TA:) AHn says, on the authority of Aboo-Ziyád, that it is of the kind termed EiDaAh, tail, and long in its wood, which is excellent, and is carried to the towns and villages, and the clay houses of these are built upon it; [app. meaning that its wood is used in forming the foundations of the walls;] its leaves are of the kind called hadab, [syn. with Eabal,] long and slender, and it has no thorns; of it are made [bowls of the kinds called] qiSaAE and jifaAn; and it has a red fruit, like a knot of a rope: (M:) or a kind of large trees, having no fruit: (Msb:) or i. q. TrfA=', having no fruit: (Bd in xxxiv. 15:) n. un. with p; (S, M, Msb, K;) explained in the A as the samurap [or gum-acacia tree]: or a tall, straight [tree such as is termed] EiDaAhap, of which are made the like of A^aqodaAH: (TA:) the pl. [of A^avolN] is A^uvuwlN (M, K) and [of A^avolapN] A^avalaAvN. (S, K, TA (in the CK AavolAtN].) ― -b2- [See also A^avolapN, below.] -A2- fulaAnN A^avolu maAlK Such a one is a collector of wealth, or property. (Ibn-'Abbád.)

A^avolapN * n. un. of A^avolN, q. v. (S, M, &c.) Because of the tallness of the tree thus called, and its erectness, and beauty of proportion, the poets liken thereto a woman of perfect stature and erect form. (M.) ― -b2- Metaphorically, (Msb,) (tropical:) Honour, or reputation; or grounds of pretension to respect on account of the honourable deeds or qualities of one's ancestors, &c.; syn. EiroDN; (Msb, TA;) or HasabN (S, O, K, TA.) So in the saying, fulaAnN yanoHitu A^avolatanaA, or yanoHatu, (S accord. to different copies, and so in the O, but in the copies of the K, incorrectly, yanoHatu fiY A^avolatinaA, TA,) (tropical:) Such a one speaks evil of, (S, O,) or impugns, or speaks against, (K,) our honour, or reputation, &c. (S, O, K.) And naHata A^avolatahu (tropical:) He detracted from his reputation; spoke against him; impugned his character; censured him; blamed him. (A, Msb.) And fulaAnN tunoHatu A^avalaAtuhu (tropical:) [Such a one's grounds of pretension to respect, &c., are impugned]. (TA.) And huwa laA tunoHatu A^avolatuhu (tropical:) He has not any vice, or fault, nor any imperfection, or defect. (Msb.) ― -b3- The root, foundation, origin, source, stock, or the like, syn. A^SolN; (T, S, M, Mgh, K;) of a thing, and of a man; (T;) of anything; (M;) [a source, stock, or fund,] of wealth, or property: (Mgh, TA:) pl. A_ivaAlN. (K.) So in the saying, lahu A^avlapu maAlK [He has a source, or stock, or fund, of wealth, or property]. (TA.) ― -b4- Victuals, or provision; syn. miyrapN (M, K.) ― -b5- The goods, furniture, and utensils, of a house or tent; as also ↓ A^avalapN. (M, K. *) ― -b6- Apparatus, accoutrements, implements, or the like. (Ibn-' Abbád, K.) So in the saying, A^axa*otu A^avolapa Al$~itaA='i [I took the apparatus, &c., of, i. e. for, the winter]. (Ibn- ' Abbád.)
A^avalapN * : see A^avolapN, near the end.

A^avaAlN * , (T, S, M,) with fet-h, (S,) or A^uvaAlN, with damm, (Mgh,) or both, (K,) (tropical:) Glory, honour, dignity, nobility, or high rank. (AA, T, S, M, Mgh, K.) You say, lahu A^uvaAlN kaA^an~ahu A^uvaAlN (tropical:) He has glory, or honour, &c., as though it were the mountain called Othál. (TA.) [But the next signification seems to be here more appropriate.] ― -b2- (tropical:) Wealth, or property. (Mgh.)

A^aviylN *
A place of growth of trees of the kind called A^araAk [perhaps a mistranscription for A^avol]: mentioned by Th, from IAar. (T.) -A2- Abundant, and luxuriant, or long, hair. (TA.) ― -b2- See also maw^av~alN in two places.
A=vilN A=vl : see muw^av~alN.

muw^av~alN *
Having root, or a foundation; or firm, or established, and firmly rooted or founded: (S:) or having a permanent source, or firm foundation: (Munjid of Kr:) or of old foundation or origin: or collected together so as to [become stable or permanent, or] have root or a foundation: (T:) or old; of ancient origin; or of long standing: (M, TA:) or permanent: (IAar:) (tropical:) applied to glory, honour, dignity, nobility, or high rank; (T, Kr, S, M, TA;) and so ↓ A^aviylN: (S, TA:) and to wealth, or property: (Kr, S:) and to anything; (T, M;) and so ↓ A^aviylN, and ↓ mutaA^av~ilN: (M:) and ↓ A=vilN, also, has the first of these significations, applied to dominion. (T.) ― -b2- Prepared, disposed, arranged, or put into a right or good state. (AA.)

mutaA^av~ilN * : see muw^avalN. ― -b2- Also Taking for oneself, getting, or acquiring, a source, stock, or fund, (A^aSol,) of wealth, or property: (S, TA:) or collecting wealth, or property, (T, Mgh,) and taking it for oneself, or getting it, or acquiring it, as a source, stock, or fund. (Mgh.) So in a trad. on the subject of a charge respecting the orphan, yaA^okulu mino maAlihi gayora mutaA^av~ilK maAlFA [He may eat of his wealth, or property, not taking for himself a source, stock, or fund, of wealth, or property: or, not collecting &c.]: (T, S, Mgh:*) or, accord. to Bkh, not acquiring abundance of wealth: but the former explanation is more correct lexically. (Mgh.)

1 A^avima * , (Lth, S, M, &c.,) aor.
Aavama , (Lth, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_ivomN, (S, K,) or A^avamN, the former being a simple subst., (Msb,) and maA^ovamN, (S, K,) He fell
into what is termed A_ivomN [i. e. a sin, or crime, &c.]; (Lth, T, S, M, Msb, * K *;) [he sinned; committed a sin, or crime;] he did what was unlawful: (M, * K:) and ↓ taA^oviymN signifies the same as A_ivomN: (K:) it may be either an inf. n. of ↓ A^avama, which [says ISd] I have not heard, or, as Sb holds it to be, a simple subst. like tanobiytN: (M:) and is said to be used in the sense of A_ivom in the Kur lii. 23 [and lvi. 24]. (TA.) [It should be added also, that ↓ tA^ovaAmN, like tako*aAbN, is syn. with tA^oviymN and A_ivomN; and, like tA^vym, may be an inf. n. of ↓ A^av~ama, or a simple subst.: see an ex. voce baruwqN.] In the dial. of some of the Arabs, the first letter of the aor. is with kesr, as in tiEolamu and niEolamu; and as the hemzeh in A_ivomN is with kesr, the radical hemzeh [in the aor.] is changed into Y; so that they say A_iyvamu and tiyvamu [for A=vamu and taA^ovamu.] (TA.) In the saying,
lawo qulota maA fiY qawomahaA lamo tiyvami
yafoDulahaA fiY HasabK wamiysami
the meaning is, [Shouldst thou say, thou wouldst not sin, or do wrong, in so saying,] There is not, among her people, any one who excels her [in grounds of pretension to respect, and in impress, or character, of beauty]. (M.) -A2- A^avamahu All~`hu fiY ka*aA, aor.
Aavuma (S, K) and
Aavima , (S,) or
Aavama , (K,) but there is no other authority than the K for this last, nor is there any reason for it, as the medial radical letter is not faucial, nor is the final, and in the Iktitáf el-Azáhir the aor. is said to be
Aavima and
Aavuma , (MF, TA,) [God reckoned him to have sinned, or committed a crime or the like, in such a thing; or] God reckoned such a thing against him as an A_ivom: (S, K:) or A^avamahu, aor.
Aavima (Fr, T, M, Msb) and
Aavuma , (Msb,) inf. n. A^avomN (Fr, T, Msb) and A^avaAmN (Fr, T, TA) and A_ivaAmN, (Fr, TA,) He (God) requited him, (Fr, T,) or punished him, (M,) for what is termed A_ivomN [i. e. sin, or crime, &c.]: (Fr, T, M:) [see also A^avaAmN below:] or he (a man) pronounced him to be A=vm [i. e. a sinner, or the like]: (Msb:) [or] ↓ A=vamahu, aor. yaw^ovimuhu, has this last signification, said of God; and also signifies He found him to be so. (T.) ― -b2- You say also, A^avamati Aln~aAqapu Alma$oYa, aor.
Aavima , inf. n. A^avomN, The she-camel was slow. (M.)

2 A^v~mhu * , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. taA^oviymN, (Msb, K,) He said to him A^avimota [Thou hast fallen into a sin, or crime, &c.; hast sinned, &c.]. (S, Msb, K.) -A2- See also 1, first and second sentences.

4 A=vmhu A=vmh A=vmp
He made him, or caused him, to fall into what is termed A_ivomN [i. e. a sin, or crime, &c.], (Zj, S, M, K,) or what is termed *anobN. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also 1, last sentence but one.

5 tA^v~m *
He abstained from what is termed A_ivomN [i. e. sin, or crime, &c.]; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) like taHar~aja meaning “ he preserved himself from what is termed HarajN: ” (Msb:) or he did a work, or deed, whereby he escaped from what is termed A_ivomN: (TA:) and he repented of what is so termed, (M, K,) and begged forgiveness of it; as though he removed the A_ivom itself by repentance and by begging forgiveness; or sought to do so by those two means. (M.) You say also, tA^v~m mino ka*aA He abstained from such a thing as a sin, or crime; syn. taH~anava, q. v. (S, K, in art. Hnv.)

A_ivomN A^vm A_vm Avm |vm [accord. to some, an inf. n.; see A^avima: accord. to others, only a simple subst., signifying] A sin, a crime, a fault, an offence, or an act of disobedience, syn. *anobN, (S, M, Msb, K,) for which one deserves punishment; differing from *anobN inasmuch as this signifies both what is intentional and what is unintentional: (Kull:) or [so accord. to the M, but in the K “ and, ”] an unlawful deed: (M, K:) or a deed which retards from recompense: or, accord. to Fr, what is exclusive of the [punishment termed] Had~: accord. to Er-Rághib, it is a term of more general import than EudawAnN: (TA:) ↓ maA^ovamN [which is originally an inf. n. of A^avima] is syn. with A_ivomN; (T, * Mgh;) and so, too, is ↓ A^avaAmN, (Msb,) or ↓ A_ivaAmN, signifying a deed retarding recompense: (TA:) the pl. of A_ivomN is A=vaAmN: (M:) and the pl. of ↓ maA^ovamN is maA=vimu. (T.) ― -b2- [Sometimes it is prefixed to a noun or pronoun denoting its object: ― -b3- and sometimes it means (assumed tropical:) The punishment of a sin &c.: see explanations of a passage in the Kur v. 32, voce baA='a.] ― -b4- Wine: (Aboo-Bekr El-Iyádee, T, S, M, K:) sometimes used in this sense; (S;) but tropically; not properly: (IAmb:) I think, [says ISd,] because the drinking thereof is what is thus termed. (M.) ― -b5- [And for a like reason,] (assumed tropical:) Contention for stakes, or wagers, in a game of hazard; syn. qimaArN; (M, K;) which is a man's destruction of his property. (M.) It is said in the Kur [ii. 216, respecting wine and the game called Almayosir], qulo fihiymaA A_ivomN kabiyrN wa manaAfiEu liln~aAsi [Say thou, In them both are great sin and means of profit to men]: and Th says, when they contended in a game of this kind, and won, they gave food and alms, and these were means of profit. (M.)

A^avaAmN * : see A_ivomN. ― -b2- Also The requital, or recompense, of A_iv~m [i. e. sin, or crime, &c.]: (T, S, M, Msb:) so says Zj, (T, M,) and in like manner say Kh and Sb: (T:) or punishment (Yoo, Lth, T, M, K) thereof: (Lth, T, M:) and ↓ A_ivaAmN and ↓ maA^ovamN signify the same; (M, K;) the latter like maqoEadN. (TA. [In the CK this is written maA^vim.]) So in the Kur [xxv. 68], yaloqa A^avaAmaA [He shall find a requital, or recompense, or a punishment, of sin]: (T, S, M:) in my opinion, [says ISd,] the correct meaning is, he shall find the punishment of A=vaAm [or sins]: but some say, the meaning is that which here follows. (M.) ― -b3- A valley in Hell. (M, K.)
A_ivaAmN A_vm AvAm |vAm : see A_ivomN: ― -b2- and A^avaAmN.
A^avuwm~a * : see A=vimN; and A^aviymN.

A^aviymN * : see A=vimN. ― -b2- Also A great, or habitual, liar; or one who lies much; and so ↓ A^avuwmN. (K.) So in the Kur ii. 277: or it there signifies Burdened with A_vom [or sin, &c.]. (TA.) In the Kur xliv. 44, it means, accord. to Fr, The unrighteous, or sinning; like ↓ A=vimN: (T:) or the unbeliever: (TA:) or, accord. to Zj, in this instance, (M,) by the Avym is meant Aboo-Jahl. (M, K.) -A2- Also The commission of A_ivom [sin, or crime, &c.,] much, or frequently; and so ↓ A^aviymapN. (M, K.)
A^aviymapN * : see A^aviymN.
A^avaAmN * : see A=vimN.

A=vimN A=vm
Falling into what is termed A_ivmN [i. e. a sin, or crime, &c.]; (S, Msb, * K; *) [sinning; committing a sin, or crime;] doing what is unlawful: (K:) and in like manner, (S, Msb, K,) but having an intensive signification, (Msb,) ↓ A^aviymN, and ↓ A^avuwmN, (S, M, Msb, K,) and ↓ A^av~aAmN: (M, Msb, K: [in the CK, erroneously, without teshdeed:]) the pl. of the first of these three is A^uvamaA='u; that of the second, A^uvumN; and that of the third, A^av~aAmuwna. (M.) See also A^aviymN. ― -b2- A=vimapN, (S,) and A=vimaAtN, (S, M, K, [in the CK, erroneously, AavimAtN.]) A she-camel, (S,) and she-camels, slow, or tardy; (S, M, K;) weary, fatigued, or jaded. (K. [In the CK, we find muEiyobAtN erroneously put for muEoyiyaAtN.]) Some pronounce it with t. (Sgh.) [In like manner,] ↓ muw^aAvimN signifies That is slack, or slow, in pace, or going; Aal~a*iY yako*ibu fiY Als~ayori. (Sgh, K. [In Golius's Lex., as from the K, Aal~a*iY yuka*~ibu Als~ayora. Both are correct, signifying the same.])
taA^ovaAmN * : see 1.
taA^oviymN * : see 1.
maA^ovamN * : see A_ivomN, in two places: ― -b2- and see A^avaAmN.
maA^ovuwmN * [Reckoned to have sinned, or the like;] having a thing reckoned against him as an A_ivom: (S:) or requited for what is termed A_ivomN. (Fr, T.)
muwaAvimN mwAvm : see A=vimN.
AivonaAni AvnAn {vnAn and AivonataAni: see art. vnY.

1 A^aj~ati Aln~aAru * , (S, A, Msb,) aor.
Aaju3a (S, Msb) and
Aaji3a , (M, TA,) [the former contr. to analogy, and the latter agreeable therewith, in the case of an intrans. verb of this class,] inf. n. A^ajiyHN, (S, A, Msb, K,) The fire burned, burned up, burned brightly, or fiercely, (Msb,) blazed, or flamed, or blazed or flamed fiercely; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also ↓ tA^j~jt (S, A, K) and ↓ Ay^tj~t [written with the disjunctive alif Aiytaj~at]: (S, K:) or made a sound by its blazing or flaming. (ISd, TA.) ― -b2- A^aj~a, aor.
Aaju3a , (S, K, &c.,) contr. to analogy, (TA,) and
Aaji3a , (Jm, TS, L, K,) but this is rejected by AA, (MF,) inf. n. A^aj~N (S) and A^ajiyHN, (TA,) (tropical:) He (an ostrich) ran, making a [rustling] sound, or noise, such as is termed HafiyfN. (S, L, K, &c.) And, aor.
Aaju3a , (T, A,) inf. n. A^aj~N, (T, TA,) (assumed tropical:) He hastened, or was quick, in his pace; walked quickly; or went a pace between a walk and a run; (T, Nh;) said of a man; (Nh, from a trad.;) and of a camel: (IB:) or (tropical:) he made a sound, or noise, in his pace or going, like that of the blazing, or flaming, of fire. (A.) You say, A^aj~a A^aj~apa AlZ~aliymi
(tropical:) [He made a rustling sound in going along, like that of the ostrich]. (A.) And A^aj~a, aor.
Aaji3a , [so in the TA,] inf. n. A^ajiyHN, (assumed tropical:) It (a camel's saddle) made a sound or noise [produced by his running]. (AZ, TA.) And A^ajiyHN signifies also (assumed tropical:) The sounding of water in pouring forth. (TA.) ― -b3- A^aj~a, (S, K,) aor.
Aaju3a , (S, L,) inf. n. A^ujuwHN, (S, K,) It (water) was, or became, such as is termed A^ujaAH. (S, L, K.) -A2- A^aj~ahu He rendered it (namely water) such as is termed A^ujaAj. (K.)

2 A^j~j Aln~aAra * , (S, A, K,) inf. n. taA^ojiyHN, (K,) He made the fire to [burn, burn up, burn brightly or fiercely, (see 1,)] blaze, or flame, or blaze or flame fiercely. (S, A, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A^j~j bayonahumo $ar~aA (assumed tropical:) He kindled evil, or mischief, among them. (TA.)
5 taAaj~a3a see 1. ― -b2- Hence tA_j~j also signifies It gave light; shone; or shone brightly. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b3- See also 8, where a contracted form of this verb is mentioned.

8 A_iAotaja3a see 1. ― -b2- [Hence,] Ay^tj~ Aln~ahaAru [written with the disjunctive alif Aiyotaj~a] The day was, or became, intensely hot, or fiercely burning; (S, K;) as also ↓ taA^aj~a and tA^j~j. (K.)

A^aj~apN *
Intenseness of heat, and its fierce burning; (S, K;) as also ↓ A^ajiyHN [inf. n. of 1], and ↓ A^ajaAjN, and ↓ A@y^ostijaAjN [inf. N. of 8]: pl. A_ijaAjN. (S.) You say, jaA=to A^aj~apN AlS~ayofi The intense heat, or fierce burning, of summer came. (TA.) ― -b2- The sound of fire; as also ↓ A^ajiyHN. (ISd, TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) The sound, or noise, and commotion, of an ostrich running, and of people walking or passing along. (A.) You say, A^aj~a A^aj~apa AlZaliymi [explained above: see 1]. (A.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) Confusion: (S, K:) or, as also ↓ A^ajiyHN, the confusion arising from the talking of a people, and the sound, or noise, of their walking or passing along. (L.) You say, Alqawomu fiy A^aj~apK The people are in a state of confusion [&c.]. (S.)
A^ajaAjN * : see A^aj~apN.

A^ujaAjN * Anything burning to the mouth, whether salt or bitter or hot. (MF.) [Hence,] maA='N A^ujaAjN, (S, A, K, &c.,) and ↓ A_ijaAjN, (Msb,) Water that burns by its saltness: (A:) or salt water: or bitter water: (TA:) or salt, bitter water: (S, K:) or very salt water: (I' Ab:) or bitter and very salt water: (Msb:) or very salt water, that burns by reason of its saltness: or very bitter water: or water very salt and bitter, like the water of the sea: (TA:) or water of which no use is made for drinking, or for watering seed-produce, or for other purposes: (El-Hasan:) or very hot water: (TA:) the pl. is the same [as the sing.; or A^ujaAjN is also used as a quasi-pl. n.]. (TA.)
A_ijaAjN A^jAj AjAj : see A^ujaAjN.

A^ajuwjN *
Giving light; shining; or shining brightly. (AA, S, K.)
A^ajiyjN * inf. n. of 1, which see: and see also A^aj~apN, in three places.
hajiyrN A^aj~aAjN * [A vehemently hot, or fiercelyburning, summer-midday]. (A.)
A^j~u * ; fem. with p: see AlA^awaAjju, below.
A=juwju A=jwj : see yaA^ojuwju, below.

Als~amaAy^imu AlA^awaAjiju * [The fiercely-burning hot winds; the latter word being pl. of ↓ A=j~apN, fem. of ↓ A=j~N, which is the act. part. n. of A^aj~a;] is used by poetic licence for AlA^awaAj~u. (TA.)
A@y^sitjaAjN * inf. N. of 8, which see: and see also A^ajapN.
maA^ojuwju * : see what follows.

yaA^ojuwjN * One who walks quickly, and runs, in this and that manner. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- yaA^ojuwju and ↓ maA^ojuwju, (S, Msb, K,) imperfectly decl., (S,) [Gog and Magog;] two tribes of God's creatures; (TA;) or two great nations; (Msb;) or two tribes of the children of Japheth the son of Noah: or, as some say, the former, of the Turks; and the latter, of the Jeel [meaning Jeel-Jeelán, said in the TA in art. jyl, on the authority of ISd, to be a people beyond the Deylem; and on the authority of Az, to be believers in a plurality of gods; (the Geli and Gelœ of Ptolemy and Strabo, as observed by Sale, in a note on ch. xviii. v. 93 of the Kur, on the authority of Golius in Alfrag. p. 207;)]: (Bd in xviii. 93:) [said by the Arabs to be Scythians of the furthest East; particularly those on the north of the Chinese: (Golius:) or, as some say, the descendants of Japheth, and all the nations inhabiting the north of Asia and of Europe: (Freytag:)] said in a rad., (TA,) on the authority of I' Ab, (Msb,) to compose nine tenths of mankind: (Msb, TA:) or yA^jwj is the name of the males, and mA^jwj is that of the females: (Msb:) he who pronounces them thus, and makes the A^ a radical letter, says that the former is of the measure yafoEuwlu, and the latter of the measure mafoEuwlu; as though from A^ajayju Aln~aAri; (Akh, S, Msb; *) or from maA='N A^ujaAjN; (TA;) or from A^aj~a said of an ostrich; and imperfectly decl. as being determinate and fem.: (Bd ubi suprà:) he who pronounces them without ', making the A in each an augmentative letter, says that the former is from yajajotu, and the latter from majajotu: (Akh, S, K:) this is the case if they be Arabic: (TA:) but some say that they are foreign names; (Msb, TA;) their being imperfectly decl. is said to indicate this; (Bd ubi suprà;) and if so, the A in them is similar to that in haAruwt and maAruwt and daAwuwd and the like; and the ', anomalous, as that in EaA^olimN and the like; and their measure is faAEuwlu. (Msb.) Ru-beh used to read ↓ A=juwju and maAjuwju [in the CK mA^juwj]; and Aboo-Mo'ádh, yamojuwju. (K.)

1 A^ajarahu * , aor.
Aajura and
Aajira , (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) which latter form of the aor., though known to most of the lexicologists, is disacknowledged by a few of them, (TA,) inf. n. A^ajorN; (S, Msb;) and ↓ A=jrhu, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) a form disacknowledged by As, but said by some to be the more chaste of the two, of the form A^afoEala, not faAEala, as IKtt by evident inadvertence makes it to be by saying that its aor. is yuw^aAjiru, (TA,) inf. n. A_iyjaArN; (S;) He (God, S, A, Mgh, Msb, and a man, Mgh) recompensed, compensated, or rewarded, him, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) Ealay maA faEala for what he had done. (A.) [See A^ajorN, below.] A^ujira fulaAnN xamosapF mino waladihi [Such a one became entitled to a reward for five of his children, by their death, (for it is believed that the Muslim will be rewarded in Paradise for a child that has died in infancy)], (S,) and A^ujira waladahu, (A,) and A^ujira fiy A^awolaAdihi, (K,) mean that his children died, and became [causes of] his reward. (S, A, K.) ― -b2- A^ajarahu, (K,) aor.
Aajura , (S,) [He served him for hire, pay, or wages;] he became his hired man, or hireling. (S, K.) So in the Kur xxviii. 27. (TA.) ― -b3- A^ajarahu, aor.
Aajura , (L, Msb, K,) and
Aajira , (Msb, K,) inf. n. A^ajorN, (L, K,) He let him (namely his slave) on hire, or for pay, or wages; (L, * Msb, * K;) as also ↓ A=jrhu, inf. n. A_iyjaArN; ('Eyn, Mgh, Msb, K;) and ↓ A=jrhu, inf. n. mw^Ajrp: (K:) all these are good forms of speech, used by the Arabs: (L:) or ↓ A=jrhu having for its inf. n. mw^Ajrp signifies he appointed him (namely another man) hire, pay, or wages, for his work; (Mj, Mgh;) or he engaged with him to give him hire, pay, or wages; (A, Mgh, Msb;) and can have only one objective complement: whereas, ↓ when it is of the measure A^afoEala it is doubly trans.; (Mgh, Msb;) so that one says, mamoluwkahu ↓ A=jaraniy He let me his slave on hire. (Mgh.) One also says, A^ajara Ald~aAra, aor.
Aajura and
Aajira , inf. n. A^ajorN, He let the house on hire; and so Ald~aAra ↓ A=jr, [inf. n. A_iyjaArN:] (Msb, TA:) and Ald~aAra ↓ A=jrhu, [inf. n. A_iyjaArN,] He let to him the house on hire: (S, A, Mgh, Msb:) the latter verb being of the measure A^afoEala, not of the measure faAEala: (A, Mgh, Msb:) and the vulgar say, waAjara: (S:) some, however, say, Ald~aAra ↓ A=jarotu, inf. n. muw^aAjarapN, making the verb of the measure fAEl: (Msb, TA:) some also say, Ald~aAra zayod~aA ↓ A=jarotu [I let the house to Zeyd], inverting the order of the words: (Msb, TA:) and the lawyers say, Ald~aAra mino zayodK ↓ A=jarotu [in the same sense, like as biEotu mino zayodK Ald~aAri means the same as biEotu zayodAF Ald~aAra]. (Msb: [but in the Mgh, the like of this is said to be vulgar.])

3 A=jr A=jr , inf. n. muw^aAjarapN: see 1, latter half, in three places: and see 10. One says also, of a woman, (K,) or a whorish female slave, (TA,) A=jarato, [of the measure faAEalato, not A^afoEalato, (see muw^ojirN, below,)] meaning She prostituted herself for hire. (K.)
4 A=jaratN A=jrt , inf. n. A_iyjaArN: see 1, first sentence: ― -b2- and see the latter half of the same paragraph, in seven places.

8 Ay^tjr * [written with the disjunctive alif Aiytajara] He gave alms, seeking thereby to obtain a reward
[from God]: (L, K *:) and Ay^tjrbihi He gave it as alms, seeking thereby a reward. (L.) A@t~ajara for Ay^tjr is not allowable, because ' cannot be incorporated into t: [or, accord. to some, this is allowable, as in A@t~azara for Ay^tzr, and A@t~amana for Ay^tmn, &c.:] Hr allows it; and cites an ex. in a trad.; but IAth says that the proper reading in this instance is yaA^otajiru, not yat~ajiru; or, if the latter be allowed, it is from Alt~ijaArapu, not from AlA^ajoru. (L.) ― -b2- Auwtujira Ealayohi bika*aA [in which the radical ' is changed into w because the alif preceding it is made disjunctive and with damm, (in one copy of the S, and in the L and TA, erroneously written Aiyotajara,) He was hired to do it for such a sum or thing, (see muw^otajarN, below,)] is from AlA^ujorapu. (S, L.)

10 AstA^jrhu * , (S, K,) and ↓ A=jrhu, (K,) [the latter of the measure faAEala, as has been clearly shown above, from the A and Mgh and Msb,] He hired him; took him as a hired man, or hireling. (S, K, TA.) You say also, AstA^jr Ald~aAra [He hired the house; took it on hire]. (A, Mgh,)

A^ajorN *
A recompense, compensation, or reward, (S, K, &c.,) for what one has done; (K;) i. q. vawaAbN; (S;) as also ↓ A_ijaArapN and ↓ A^ajaArapN and ↓ A^NjaArapN, (K,) of which three forms the first is the most generally known and the most chaste, (TA,) and ↓ A^ujorapN: (TA:) or, as some say, there is a distinction between A^ajorN and vawaAbN: El-'Eynee says, in the Expos. of El-Bukháree, that what is obtained by the fundamental practices of the law, and by obligatory religious services, is termed vwAb; and what is obtained by supererogatory acts of religion, Ajr; for vwAb is properly a substitute for a thing itself; and Ajr, for the profit arising from a thing; though each is sometimes used in the sense of the other: (TA:) it is well known that Ajr signifies a recompense, or reward, from God to a man, for righteous conduct; (MF;) and ↓ A_ijaArapN, recompense, compensation, hire, pay, or wages, from one man to another, for work; (Mgh, MF;) and hence AlA^ajiyru; (MF;) and ↓ A^ujorapN also has this latter signification, (Mgh, TA,) and is syn. with kiraA='N; (S, Mgh, K;) [signifying likewise rent for a house, and the like;] but A^ajorN is used [sometimes] in the sense of A_ijaArapN and in that of A^ujorapN: (Msb:) the pl. of A^ajorN is A^ujuwrN (Msb, K) and A=jaArN; (K;) but the latter form was unknown to MF: (TA:) the pl. of ↓ A^ujorapN is A^ajarN and A^ujuraAtN and A^ujaraAtN. (Msb.) [One says, A^ajoruka Ealay All~`hi Thy recompense is due from God. And, to console a person for the death of a relation or friend, EaZ~ama All~`hu A^ajoraka fiyhi May God largely compensate thee for him! i. e., for the loss of him.] By the expression A^ajorK kiriymK in the Kur xxxvi. 10 is said to be meant Paradise. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A dowry, or nuptial gift; a gift that is given to, or for, a bride: (K:) pl. A^ujuwrN: so in the Kur xxxiii. 49 [&c.]. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Praise; good fame. (K.) So, as some say, in the Kur xxix. 26. (TA.)
A^ajur~N * and A^ujurN: see A=jur~N.
A^ujorapN * : see A^ajorN, in three places.
A_ijoriy~aA A^jrY A^jry A^jryA AjryA and A_ijoriy~aA='u: see A_ij~iyraY.
A^ajuwrN * : see A=jur~N.

A^ajiyrN * (S, K, &c.) A hired man; a hireling: (L:) or of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mufaAEalN, i. e. a man with whom one has engaged to give him hire, pay, or wages: (Mgh, Msb: *) pl. A^ujaraA='u. (L, Msb.)

A_ijaArapN A^jAr A^jArh A^jArp A_jArp AjArh AjArp jArY and A^ajaArapN and A^ujaArapN: see A^ajorN, in four places. ― -b2- A_ijaArapN also signifies The giving of usufructs for a compensation. (Mgh.) ― -b3- And Land which its owners have let to him who will build upon it: so explained by the lawyers. (Mgh.)

A_ij~aArN A^jAr AjAr jArY (S, M, IAth, Mgh, K) and ↓ A_ij~aArapN (M) and ↓ A_inojaArN (Mgh, K) The flat top, or roof, of a house, (S, M, IAth, Mgh, K,) that has not around it anything to prevent a person's falling from it: (M, * IAth:) of the dial. of the people of Syria and of El-Hijáz: (S:) pl. [of the first and second] A^ajaAjiyru and A^ajaAjirapN; (A'Obeyd, S, K;) and [of the third] A^anaA jiyru. (Mgh, K.)
A_ij~aArapN A^jAr A^jArh A^jArp A_jArp AjArh AjArp jArY : see A_ij~aArN.

A_ij~iyraY A^jyr A^jyry A^jyryy AjyrY Ajyry (ISk, K) and ↓ A_ijoriy~aA and ↓ A_ijoriy~aA='u (S in art. hjr) A custom; a habit. (ISk, K, and S ubi suprà.) The hemzeh is said to be a substitute for h [in hij~iyraY &c.] (TA.) You say, maA zaAla *`lika A_ij~iyraAhu That ceased not to be his custom, or habit. (ISk.)
A=jarN A=jr and A=jurN and A=jirN, and the pls. A=juruwna and A=jiruwna: see what next follows.

A=jur~N A=jr (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and ↓ A=jurN (AA, Ks, K) and ↓ A=juwrN (S, K) and ↓ A^ajuwrN and ↓ yaAjuwrN (K) and ↓ A^ajurN (as in some copies of the K) and ↓ A=jarN, (as in some copies of the K and in the TA,) or ↓ A^ujurN, (as in other copies of the K,) and ↓ A=jirN [to which is erroneously added in the CK A=jirapN] and [the pls.] ↓ A=juruwna and ↓ A=jiruwna (K) are syn., (S, K,) of Persian origin, (S,) [from A=Guwro or A=Guro,] arabicized, (S, Mgh, K,) signifying Baked bricks; (Msb;) baked clay, (Mgh, L,) with which one builds: (S, L:) A=jur~N and A=juwr~N and A=jurN [&c.] are pls., [or rather coll. gen. ns., except the two forms ending with w and n,] and their sings. [or rather ns. un.] are with p, i. e. A=jur~apN &c. (L.)
A=juwrN A=jwr : see A=jur~N.
A_inojaArN AnjAr : see A_ij~aArN.
muw^ojarN * [A slave, or] a house, let on hire; (Akh, T, Msb;) as also ↓ maA^ojuwrN; (L;) and some say, ↓ muw^aAjarN. (Akh, Msb.)

muw^ojirN * One who lets on hire [a slave, or] a house: one should not say ↓ muwaAjirN; for this is wrong with respect to the classical language, and abominable with respect to the conventional acceptation and common usage; a foul reproach being meant thereby [as is shown by the explanation of A=jarato, given above: or, accord to some, it is allowable when it relates to a house: (see A^ajarahu:) it seems to be disallowed only when used absolutely]. (A, Mgh.)
maA^ojuwrN * : see muw^ojarN.
muw^aAjarN * : see muw^ojarN.
muw^aAjirN * : see muw^ojirN.

muw^otajara * [part. n. of Auwtujira]. Mohammad Ibn-Bishr El-Khárijee, not [as is said in the S] Aboo-Dahbal, says, (L,)
yaA layota A^an~iY biA^avowaAbiy wa raAHilatiY
EabodN liA^aholika h`*aA Al$~ahora muw^otajaru
[O would that I were, with my clothes and my riding-camel, a hired slave to thy family, this month]: (S, L.) i. e., maEa A^avowaAbiy. (S.)
yaAjuwrN yAjwr : see A=jur~N.

A_ij~aASN A_jAS A_jASp AjAS [The plum;] a certain fruit, (K, TA,) of the description termed faAkihap, (TA,) well known; (Msb, K;) cold and moist; or, as some say, of moderate temperature; (TA;) which facilitates the flow of the yellow bile; (K;) i. e., its juice, or water, does so, when drunk with sugar-candy (Tabaroza*) and manna (taranojubiyn) added to it; (TA;) and allays thirst, and heat of the heart; (K;) but it relaxes the stomach, and does not agree with it; and it generates a watery mixture; and its injurious effect is repelled by the drinking of sugary sikanojubiyn [or oxymel]: it is of several kinds: (TA:) [the most common is the Damasc, or Damascene, plum:] the best is (K, TA) the Armenian, (TA,) that which is sweet and large: (K, TA:) the sour, or acid, is less laxative, and more cold: (TA:) the n. un. is with p: (S, Msb, K:) you should not say A_inojaASN; (Yaakoob, S, K;) or this is a word of weak authority, (K, TA,) and you say A_ij~aASN and A_injaASN like as one says A_ij~aArN and A_inojaArN: (TA:) in the dial. of the Syrians, the A_ij~aASN [or A_inojaAS or A_injaAs accord. to common modern usage among them] is the [pear which they formerly called] mi$omi$ and [which others call] kum~avoray: (K:) it is of the growth of the country of the Arabs: (AHn:) Aj~AS is an adventitious word, (S, K,) or arabicized, (Msb,) because j and S do not both occur in any Arabic word: (S, Msb, K:) or, accord. to Az, they do so occur; as, for instance, in HaS~aSa, and in Saj~N. (TA.)

1 A^ajila * , aor.
Aajala , (Msb, K,) inf. n. A^ajalN, (Msb,) It (a thing, Msb, [as, for instance, a thing purchased, and the price thereof, and a thing promised or threatened or foretold, and also payment for a thing purchased, and the fulfilment of a promise or threat or prediction, and any event,]) was, or became, delayed, postponed, kept back; [and therefore, future;] syn. taA^ax~ara; (K;) and A^ajala, aor.
Aajula , inf. n. A^ujuwlN, signifies the same. (Msb.) [See A=jilN and A^ajalN. The primary signification seems to be, It had a term, or period, appointed for it, at which it should fall due, or
come to pass.] -A2- A^ajalahu, aor.
Aajila , (K,) inf. n. A^ajulN; (TA;) and ↓ A^j~lhu, (K,) inf. n. taA^ojiylN; (TA;) and ↓ A=jlhu, (K,) inf. n. muw^aAjalapN; (TK;) He confined, restricted, restrained, withheld, debarred, hindered, or prevented, him. (K, TA.) Hence the phrase, A^ajaluwA maAlahumo They confined, restricted, &c., their cattle from the pasturage. (TA.) -A3- A^ajala Ealayohimo $ar~FA, (S, Msb,) or Al$~ar~a, (K,) aor.
Aajula (S, Msb, K) and
Aajila , (S, K,) inf. n. A^ajolN, (S, Msb,) He committed against them evil, (S, Msb, K,) and drew it, or procured it, to them: (Msb:) and (S, in the K “ or ”) he excited it, stirred it up, or provoked it, against them: (S, K:) or, accord. to AZ, A^ajalotu EalayohimN, inf. n. as above, signifies I committed a crime against them: and AA says that jalabotu Ealayohimo and jararotu and A^ajalotu have one and the same signification. (TA.) ― -b2- And A^ajala liA^aholihi, (Lh, K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He gained, acquired, or earned, and collected, and brought, or purveyed, and exercised skill in the management of affairs, for his family. (Lh, K.)

2 A^aj~ala AlA^ajala * , (TA,) inf. n. taA^ojiylN, (K, TA,) He defined the term, or period; (K, * TA;) assigned, appointed, or specified, it. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [vi. 128], wa balagonaA A^ajalanaA A@l~a*iy A^aj~alota lanaA [And we have reached our term which Thou hast assigned, or appointed, for us;] meaning, the day of resurrection; (Bd, * Jel;) or the term of death; or, as some say, the term of extreme old age. (TA.) And A^aj~alotuhu, inf. n. as above, signifies I assigned, or appointed, for him, or it, a term, or period. (Msb.) ― -b2- A^aj~alaniY He granted me a delay, or postponement. (TA.) You say, faA^aj~alaniY A^ilay mud~apK ↓ AisotaA^ojalotuhu (S, K, TA) I desired, asked, demanded, or requested, of him a term, or period, [of delay, or postponement,] and he granted me a delay, or postponement, to a certain term, or period. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 1.
3 A=jlhu A=jlh A=jlp , inf. n. muw^aAjalapN: see 1.

5 tA^j~l *
i. q. ↓ AstA^jl; (K, TA;) i. e. He asked, or requested, that a term, or period, should be assigned, appointed, or specified, for him. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of Mek-hool, kun~aA maraAbiTiyna biA ls~aAHili fataA^aj~ala mutaA^aj~ilN [We were keeping post on the frontier of the enemy, in the tract on the sea-coast, and] a person asked, or requested, that a term, or period, should be assigned, or appointed, or specified, for him, and that permission should be granted him to return to his family. (TA.)
10 A_isotaAojala see 2 and 5.

A^ajolN * is originally the inf. n. of A^ajala $ar~FA “ he committed evil; ” and is used to indicate the causation of crimes; and afterwards, by extension of its application, to indicate any causation: (Bd in v. 35:) one says, faEalotuhu mino A^ajolika, and ↓ mn A_ijolika, (S, K,) and faEalotuhu A^ajolaka, and ↓ A_ijolaka, (so in some copies of the K,) and mn A^ajolaAlika, and mn A_ijolaAlika, (K, [belonging to art. jlw, in which also they are mentioned,]) and mn A^ajolAlika, and mn A_ijolaAlika, (so in some copies of the K and in the TA, [belonging to art. jl,]) i. e. [I did it] mino jar~aAka, (S,) which means [originally] in consequence of thy committing it: (Bd ubi suprà:) [and then, by extension of its application, as shown above, because of thee, or of thine act &c.; on thine account; for thy sake; as also liA^ajolika, which is more common in the present day:] or mno jalalika: (K:) and mino A^ajolihi kaAna ka*aA, i. e. bisababihi [Because of him, or it, it was thus, or such a thing was]. (Msb.) An instance of its occurrence without mino [or li] is presented by the saying of 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd,
A^ajola A^an~a All~`ha qado faD~alakumo
[Because that God hath made you to have excel-lence, or hath preferred you]. (TA.)
A_ijolN A^jAl A^jl A^jlY Ajl jAl jl jlA jlY |jl , whence faEalotuhu mino A_ijolika, and faEalotuhu A_ijolaka: see A^ajolN, in two places.

A^ajalN * , (S, Mughnee, K,) with the l quiescent, (Mughnee,) is written with kesr and with fet-h [to the medial letter, i. e. ↓ A^ajilo as well as A^ajalo] like nEm [which is written naEimN as well as naEamo]: (TA:) it is a particle (Mughnee) denoting a reply; like naEamo; (S, Mughnee, K;) importing acknowledgment of the truth of the speaker, to him who gives information; and the making a thing known, to him who asks information; and a promise, to him who seeks, or demands; (Mughnee;) i. e. It is as thou sayest [in the first case; and yes, or yea, in the same, and in the other cases]; (K voce basalN;) therefore it occurs after such sayings as “ Zeyd stood ” and “ did Zeyd stand? ” and “ beat thou Zeyd: ” but ElMálakee restricts the information to that which is affirmative, and the saying expressive of seeking or demanding to that which is without prohibition: and it is said by some that it does not occur after an interrogation: (Mughnee:) Er-Radee says, in the Expos. of the Káfiyeh, after Z and others, that it is to denote acknowledgment of the truth of information, and does not occur after a saying in which is the meaning of seeking, or demanding: (TA:) or, accord. to Z and Ibn-Málik and others, it relates particularly to information: and accord. to Ibn-Kharoof, it occurs mostly after information: (Mughnee:) in the Expos. of the Tes-heel, it is said to be for denoting acknowledgment of the truth of information, past or other, affirmative or negative, and not to occur after an interrogation: (TA:) Akh says that it is better than naEamo (S, Mughnee, K *) after information, (Mughnee,) in acknowledging the truth of what is said; (S, Mughnee, K;) and nEm is better than it after an interrogation: (S, Mughnee, K:) so that when one says, sawofa ta*ohabu [Thou wilt, or shalt, go away], thou sayest A^ajalo [Yes]; and it is better than nEm: but when one says, A^ata*ohabu [Wilt thou go away?], thou sayest nEm; and it is better than Ajl. (S.)

A^ajalN * The term, or period, of a thing: (S, K:) its assigned, appointed, or specified, term or period: this is the primary signification: (TA:) or the term, or period, and time of falling due, of a thing: (Msb:) pl. A=jaAlN. (Msb, K.) ― -b2- Hence, The period of women's waiting, before they may marry again, after divorce: as in the Kur ii. 231 and 232. (TA.) ― -b3- The period, or extremity of time, in which falls due a debt (K, TA) and the like. (TA.) You say, baAEahu A_iy~aAhu A_ilay A^ajalK [He sold it to him for payment at an appointed period]: and sal~ama Ald~aAraAhima fiY TaEaAmK A_ilay A^ajalK [He delivered the money for wheat, or the like, to be given at an appointed period]. (Msb in art. klA^.) ― -b4- The term, or period, of death; (K;) the time in which God has eternally decreed the end of life by slaughter or otherwise: or, as some say, the whole duration of life: and its end: a man's life being thus termed: and his death, by which it terminates: (Kull p. 17:) the assigned, or appointed, duration of the life of a man. (TA.) One says, danaA A^ajaluhu, meaning His death drew near; originally, A@sotiyfaA='u AlA^ajali the completion of the duration of life. (TA.) In the Kur vi. 128, (see 2, above,) the meaning is, The term of death: or, as some say, the term of extreme old age: (TA:) or the day of resurrection. (Bd, * Jel.) The words of the Kur [vi. 2] vum~a qaDaY A^ajalFA wa A^ajalN masam~aY Einodahu mean [Then He decreed a term,] the term of death, and [there is a term named with Him,] the term of the resurrection: or the period between the creation and death, and the period between death and the resurrection; for Ajl is applied to the end of a space of time and to the whole thereof: (Bd:) or the meaning is, the period of sleep, and the period of death: (Bd, TA:) or the period of those who have passed away, and the period of those who remain and those who are to come: (Bd:) or the period of remaining in this world, and the period of remaining in the world to come: or in both instances death is meant; [accidental, and natural;] for the Ajl of some is by accidental means, as the sword, and drowning, and burning, and eating what disagrees, and other means of destruction; while some have their full periods granted to them and are preserved in health until they die a natural death: or the Ajl of some is that of him who dies in a state of happiness and enjoyment; and of others, that of him who reaches a limit beyond which God has no? appointed, in the natural course of this world, any one to remain therein; and to both of these, reference is made in the Kur [xvi. 72 and] xxii. 5. (TA.) ― -b5- Sometimes, also, it means Destruction: and thus it has been explained as occurring in the Kur [vii. 184], where it is said, waA^ano EasaY A^ano yakuwna qadi A@ qotaraba A^ajaluhumo [And that, may be, their destruction shall have drawn near]. (TA.)
A^ajilo * : see A^ajalN.
A^ajilN * : see A=jilN.

A^ajiylN *
Having a delay, or postponement, granted to him, to a certain time; i. q. A_ilaY waqotK ↓ muw^aj~alN. (Lth.) ― -b2- See also A=jilN.

A=jilN A=jl
Delayed; postponed; kept back; syn. mutaA^ax~irN; [but in some copies of the K, for A=jilN, we find ↓ A^ajilN;] as also ↓ A^ajiylN, of which the pl. is A^ujolN: (K:) and therefore, (TA,) not present; future; to come; contr. of EaAjilN: (S, Msb, TA:)
and ↓ mutaA^aj~ilN, also, signifies delayed, deferred, or postponed, to the time of the end of a period; originally, contr. of mutaEaj~ilN. (Mgh.) [See also A^ajiylN.] ― -b2- [Hence,] AlA=jilapu The [future,] latter, ultimate, or last, dwelling, or abode, or life; the world to come; syn. AlA=xirapu; (K, TA;) contr. of AlEaAjilapu. (S, TA.) -A2- Committing a crime; or a committer of a crime. (S, TA.)

muw^aj~alN *
Determined, defined, or limited, as to time; applied to a writing: so in the Kur iii. 139: (Bd, Jel, TA:) and to a debt; contr. of HaAl~N, q. v. (Mgh in art. Hl.) ― -b2- See also A^ajiylN.
mutaA^aj~ilN * : see A=jilN.

1 A^ajimahu * , with kesr, [aor.
Aajama ,] (AZ, S, O,) inf. n. A^ajamN; (KL, PS;) or A^ajamahu, aor.
Aajima , (so in the K,) inf. n. A^ajomN; (TK;) [but A^ajima is the form commonly known; and if it were incorrect, the author of the K would probably, accord. to his usual custom, have charged J with error respecting it;] He loathed it; disliked it; was, or became, disgusted with it; namely, food; (AZ, S, O, K;) &c.; (K;) from constantly keeping to it; (AZ, S, O;) or because of its not agreeing with him: (TA:) he reckoned it bad: (KL:) and ↓ tA^j~mhu also signifies he disliked, disapproved, or hated, it; or he expressed, or showed, dislike, disapprobation, or hatred, of it; syn. takar~ahahu. (TA.) -A2- A^ajama falaAn~aA, aor.
Aajima , (K,) inf. n. A^ajomN, (TK,) He incited, or urged, such a one to do that which he disliked, disapproved, or hated. (K.)
2 Aaj~ama see 4.

4 yuw^ojimu Aln~aAsa * , or Aln~aAsa ↓ yuw^aj~imu, [accord. to different copies of the K, the former being the reading in the TA,] He makes men's own selves to be objects of dislike, disapprobation, or hatred, to them. (K voce A^ajuwmN.) [Accord. to the TK, you say, A=jamahu minohu, inf. n. A_iyjaAmN, meaning He made him to be an object of dislike, disapprobation, or hatred, to him.]

5 tA^j~m *
He (a lion) entered his A^ajamap [or thicket]. (K.) -A2- tA^j~mhu: see 1.

A^ajomN *
Any square, roofed, house: (K:) mentioned by ISd as on the authority of Yaakoob: but see A^ujumN as explained by J [in the S] on the same authority. (TA.)
A^ujomN * : see A^ujumN. -A2- It is also a pl. of A^ajamapN. (M, K.)
A^ajamN * : see A^ajamapN.

A^ujumN *
A fortress; (Mgh, Msb, K;) like A^uTumN: (Mgh:) pl. A=jaAmN. (Mgh, Msb, K.) AlA^ujumu [is the name of] A fortress (S, K) in El-Medeeneh, (K,) built of stones by the people of that city: and Yaakoob says that A^ujumN signifies any square, roofed, house. (S, Sgh.) Imra-el-Keys says, [describing a vehement rain,]
watayomaA='a lamo yatoruko bihaA ji*oEa naxolapK
walaA A^ujum~aA A_il~aA ma$iydFA bijanodali
[And Teymà, (a town so called,) it left not therein a trunk of a palm-tree, nor a square, roofed, house, unless raised high with stones: but in the Calc. ed. of the Mo' allakát, (p. 54,) for A^ujum~aA, we find A^uTum~aA, which has the same meaning]. (S, Sgh.) See also A^ajomN. (TA.) Accord. to As, it is also pronounced ↓ A^ujomN. (S.)

A^ajamapN *
A thicket, wood, or forest; a collection, (Mgh, Msb,) or an abundant collection, (K,) of tangled, confused, or dense, trees, or shrubs: (Mgh, Msb, K:) or it is of reeds, or canes: (S:) or a [place such as is termed] magiyD of water collected together, in which, in consequence thereof, trees grow: (S in art. gyD:) [or] it signifies also a bed, or place of growth, of canes or reeds: (Mgh:) the pl. is A^ajamaAtN and A^ujumN (S, M, K) and A^ujomN (M, K) and ↓ A^ajamN, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) [or rather this last is a coll. gen. n., of which A^ajamapN is the n. un.,] and A_ijaAmN (S, M, K) and [pl. of pauc.] A=jaAmN, (S, M, Mgh, K,) or the last but one is pl. of A^ajamN, (M,) and so is the last. (Lh, M, Msb.) And hence, The haunt of a lion. (TA in art. Hrb.) ― -b2- A=jaAmN [in the CK AajAm] also signifies Frogs. (Sgh, K.) [App. because frogs are generally found in beds of canes or reeds.]

A^ajuwmN * signifies mano yuw^ojimu Aln~aAsa, or yuw^aj~imu Aln~aAsa; [accord. to different copies of the K; see 4;] i. e. One who makes men's own selves to be objects of dislike, disapprobation, or hatred, to them. (K.)

A=jimN A=jm
Loathing, disliking, or regarding with disgust. (S, TA.) -A2- maA='N A=jimN i. q. ↓ maA^ojuwmN [Water that is loathed, disliked, or regarded with disgust]. (TA.)
maA^ojuwmN * : see A=jimN.

1 A^ajana * , (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
Aajina and
Aajuna ; (S, Msb, K;) and A^ajina, (S, Mgh, &c.,) aor.
Aajana , (S, Msb,) mentioned by Yz; (S;) inf. n. of the former A^ujuwnN (S, Mgh, Msb, K *) and A^ajonN; (S, Msb, K; *) and of the latter A^ajanN; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) It (water) became altered for the worse (S, Mgh, Msb, K) in taste and colour, (S, Mgh, K,) from some such cause as long standing, (TA,) but was drinkable: (Mgh, Msb:) or became altered for the worse in its odour by oldness: or became covered with [the green substance called] TuHolub and with leaves: (Mgh:) A^ajuna, also, said of water, signifies it became altered for the worse: (Th:) and in the Iktitáf occurs A^ajana, aor.
Aajana , which is unknown, but may be a mixture of two dial. vars. [namely of A^ajana having for its aor.
Aajina and
Aajuna , and yaA^ojanu having for its pret. A^ajina]. (MF) -A2- A^ajana He (a qaS~aAra, or whitener of cloth) beat a piece of cloth or a garment [in washing it]. (S, K.)
A^ajonN * : see A=jinN.
A^ajinN * : see A=jinN.
A^ujonapN * (S, K) and A^ojonapN and A_ijonapN (K) i. q. wajonapN [The ball, or elevated part, of the cheek]. (S, K.)
A^ajiynN * : see A=jinN.

A_ijaAn~apN A^jAnh AjAnh AjAnp jAnY (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and ↓ A_inojiAnapu, (Lh, K,) the latter of the dial. of Teiyi, (Lh, TA,) or this is a vulgar form, (Mgh,) not allowable, (S,) and ↓ A_iyjaAnapN, (K,) with Y, (TA,) A thing well known; (K;) a vessel in which clothes are washed; (Msb;) a [vessel also called] mirokan, resembling a laqan [which is a kind of basin], in which clothes are washed: (Mgh:) or what is called in Persian PnGAn [i. e. PinoGAno a small cup]: (PS:) [it probably received this last meaning, and some others, in post-classical times: Golius explains it as meaning “ lagena, phiala, crater: ” adding, “ hinc vulgo Fingiána [i. e. finojaAnap] calix vocatur: item Urceus: hydria: [referring to John ii. 6:] Vas dimidiœ seriœ simile, in quo aqua et similia ponuntur: ” on the authority of Ibn-Maaroof: and, on the same authority, “ Labrum seu vas lapideum instar pelvis, in quo lavantur vestes: ”] pl. A^ajaAjiynu: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) meaning [also] what resemble troughs, surrounding trees. (Msb.)

A=jinN A=jn (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and ↓ A^ajinN (S, Msb, K) and ↓ A^ajonN (ISd, TA) and ↓ A^ajiynN (TA) Water altered for the worse (S, Mgh, Msb, K) in taste and colour, (S, Mgh, K,) from some such cause as long standing, (TA,) but still drinkable: (Mgh, Msb:) or altered for the worse in its odour by oldness: or covered with [the green substance called] TuHolub and with leaves: (Mgh:) pl. A^ujuwnN; thought by ISd to be pl. of A^ajonN and A=jinN. (TA.)
A_inojaAnapN AnjAnh AnjAnp : see A_ij~aAnapN.
A_iyjaAnapN AyjAnh AyjAnp : see A_ij~aAnapN.

miy^ojanapN * [in Golius's Lex. miy^ojanN] The instrument for beating used by the qaS~aAr [or whitener of cloth, in washing]: but better without ', [written miyjanpN,] because the pl. is mawaAjinu; or, accord. to IB, the pl. is maA=jinu. (TA.)

2 A^H~dhu * , [inf. n. taA^oHiydN,] He made it one; or called it one: as also wH~dhu. (TA in art. wHd.) You say, A^aH~idi AliAvonayoni Make thou the two to become one. (K.) It is related in a trad., that Mohammad said to a man who was making a sign with his two fore fingers in repeating the testimony of the faith, [There is no deity but God, &c.,] A^aH~idoA^aH~ido [meaning that he should make the sign with one finger only]. (S.) And A^aHad~a All~`ha means He declared God to be one; he declared, or professed, the unity of God; as also wH~dhu. (T and L in art. wHd.) ― -b2- A^aH~idi AlEa$arapa, (S, K,) inf. n. taA^oHiydN, (K,) Make thou the ten to become eleven, (S, K,) is a phrase mentioned by Fr on the authority of an Arab of the desert. (S.)
8 Ait~aHada A^tHd AtHd tHdY {tHd : see art. wHd: and see what here next follows.

A^aHadN * , originally waHadN, the w being changed into A^, (Msb,) One; the first of the numbers; (S;) syn. [in many cases] with waAHidN; (S, Msb, K;) with which it is interchangeable in two cases, to be explained below: (Msb:) pl. A=HaAdN and A^NHodaAnN (K) and A^aHaduwna, which last occurs in a phrase hereafter to be mentioned; (TA;) or it has no pl. in this sense; (Msb, K, * TA;) and as to A=HaAdN, it may be pl. of waAHidN, [and originally A^awoHaAdN,] like A^a$ohaAdN as pl. of $aAhidN, (Th, Msb,) a pl. of pauc. (Msb.) The fem. is ↓ A_iHodaY only; and this is only used in particular cases, to be shown below: (Msb:) most agree that the Y in this word is the characteristic of the fem. gender: but some say that it is to render it quasi-coordinate to the quadriliteral-radical class: [this, however, is inconsistent with its pronunciation, which is invariably A_iHodaY, not A_iHod~aY:] (TA:) its pl. is A_iHadN, as though the sing. were A_iHodapN, like as is said of *ikarN as pl. of *ikoraY: one of the expositors of the Tes-heel writes it A^uHadN, with damm and then fet-h; but a pl. of this measure is not applicable to a sing. of the measure fiEolaY, with kesr. (MF.) The dim. of A^aHadN is ↓ A^uHayodN; and that of A_iHodaY is ↓ A^uHayodaY. (L in art. wHd.) ― -b2- It is interchangeable with waAHidN in two cases: first, when it is used as an epithet applied to God: (Msb:) for AlA^aHadu, as an epithet, is applied to God alone, (Msb, K,) and signifies The One; the Sole; He who has ever been one and alone: or the Indivisible: or He who has no second [to share] in his lordship, nor in his essence, nor in his attributes: (TA:) you say, huwa AlwaAHidu and huwa AlA^aHadu: and in like manner, A^aHadN, without the article, is used as an epithet specially in relation to God, and is interchangeable in this case [but not in other cases] with waAHidN: therefore you do not say rajulN A^aHadN nor dirohamN A^aHadN and the like [but rajulN waAHdN and dirhamN waAHidN &c.] (Msb.) [See also waAHidN, in art. wHd.] In the phrase in the Kur [cxii. 1], qulo huwa All~`hu A^aHadN [Say, He is God, One God], A^aHadN is a substitute for All~`hu; for an indeterminate noun is sometimes a substitute for a determinate noun, as in another passage in the Kur, xcvi. 15 and 16. (S.) Secondly, it is interchangeable with waAHidN in certain nouns of number: (Msb:) you say A^aHada Ea$ara [masc.] and A_iHodaY Ea$orapa [fem.] (S) [meaning Eleven: and in these two cases you may not substitute waAHidN and waAHidapN for A^aHadN and A_iHodaY: but] in A^aHadNwEa$oruwna [One and twenty, and the like,] A^aHadN is interchangeable with waAHidN. (Msb.) Ks says, When you prefix the article Al to a number, prefix it to every number; therefore you should say, maA faEalati AlA^aHada AlEa$ara AlA^alofa Ald~irohama [What did the eleven thousand dirhems?]: but the Basrees prefix it to the first only, and say, mA fElt AlA^aHada Ea$ara A^alofa dirohamK. (S.) ― -b3- In [most] cases differing from these two, there is a difference in usage between A^aHadN and waAHidN: the former is used in affirmative phrases as a prefixed noun only, governing the noun which follows it in the gen. case; [as in exs. which will be found below;] and is used absolutely in negative phrases; [as will also be seen in exs. below;] whereas waAHidN is used in affirmative phrases as a prefixed noun and otherwise: the fem. A_iHodaY, also, is only used as a prefixed noun, except in numbers (Msb) [and in one other instance, which see below]. Using A^aHadN and its fem. in affirmative phrases as prefixed nouns, you say, qaAma A^aHadu Alv~alaAvapi [One of the three stood]; and qaAlato A_iHodaA humaA [One of them two (females) said]; and xu*o A_iHodaY Alv~alaAvapi [Take thou one of the three]. (TA.) The phrase A_iHodaY banaAti TabaqK means A calamity: (K:) or, as some say, (TA, but in the K “ and, ”) a serpent; (K, TA;) so called because it twists itself round so as to become like a Tabaq. (TA.) And the phrase A_iHodaY AlA_iHadi, (L, K, TA,) in which the latter word has kesr to the A_ and fet-h to the H, and is pl. of the former, also written AlA^uHadi, but this form is disapproved by MF, as has been shown above, (TA, [in several copies of the K incorrectly written AlA^aHadi,]) [lit. means One of the ones; and] is applied to a great, or mighty, event; (L, K, TA;) one that is difficult, distressing, grievous, or terrible. (L, TA.) You say, A^ataY biA_iHodaY AlA_iHadi [the last of which words is here again written in several copies of the K AlA^aHadi] He brought to pass a grievous, and great, or mighty, event, (K, TA,) when you desire to express the greatness and terribleness of an event. (TA.) You also say, fulaAnu A^aHadu AlA^aHadiyna, and waAHidu AlA^aHadiyna, (K, TA,) the latter in one copy of the K written waAHidu AlwaAHidiyna, in which the latter word is pl. of the former, (TA,) and waAHidu AlA=HaAdi, and A_iHodaY AlA_iHadi, (K, TA,) like a phrase before mentioned, only the former is applied to a calamity, and this to an intelligent being, and written in the two manners before mentioned, the difference being only in application, (TA, [in several copies of the K here again written A_iHodaY AlA^aHadi, and in the CK AaHadiY~u AlAaHadi,]) and A_iHodaY AlA^aHadiyna, (Et-Tes-heel,) and A_iHodaY AlA=HaAdi, (TA,) which are expressions of the utmost praise, (IAar, A Heyth, K,) [lit. Such a man is one of the ones; meaning] such a one is unique among the uniques; (TA;) one who has no equal; unequalled; incomparable. (IAar, Tes-heel.) It seems that the form of pl. used in the phrase A^aHadu AlA^aHadiyna is used only as applied to rational beings; but it is said in the Expositions of the Tes-heel that this phrase signifies One of the calamities; the form of the rational pl. being given to nouns significant of things deemed great, mighty, or grievous. (AHeyth.) In the phrase A_iHodaY AlA_iHadi, the fem. forms are said to be used for the purpose of giving intensiveness to the signification, as though the meaning were daAhiyapu Ald~awaAhiY, the word dAhyp being [an intensive epithet] from dahaA='N as signifying intelligence, or intelligence mixed with craft or cunning and forecast; or by dAhyp being meant a calamity. (Expositions of the Fs, TA.) AHei thought A^aHadu AlA^aHadiyna to be an epithet applied to a male, and A_iHodaY AlA_iHadi to be applied to a female: but his opinion has been refuted by EdDemámeenee in the Expos. of the Tes-heel: and this latter author there remarks, that in expressions meant to denote praise [of a man], A^aHadN and A_iHodaY are prefixed to their own proper pls., as A^aHaduwna and A_iHadN; or to an epithet, as in the case of A^aHadu AlEulamaA='i [One of the learned]; but that they have not been heard prefixed to generic nouns. (TA.) You say likewise, huwa A@bonu A_iHodaAhaA He is born of noble, or generous, ancestors, both on the father's and the mother's side; speaking of a man and of a camel. (L and K in art. wHd.)
