And laA yaquwmu bih`*aA AlA^amori A_il~aA A@bonu A_iHodaAhaA None will manage this thing, or affair, but a noble, or generous, man. (AZ, L in art. wHd.) And ↓ laA yasotaTiyEuhaA A@bonu A_iHodAtihaA [None will be able to perform it but a noble, or generous, man]. (L in art. wHd.) ― -b4- One instance is mentioned, of the occurrence, in a trad., of A_iHodaY not used as a part of a number [i. e. not as a part of the compound A_iHodaY Ea$orapa] nor as a prefixed noun; viz., A_iHodaY mino saboEK [One of seven]; in which sbE is said to mean the nights of 'Ád [during which that tribe was destroyed], or the years of Joseph [during which Egypt was afflicted with dearth]. (MF, from the Fáïk &c.) ― -b5- Used in a negative phrase, A^aHadN signifies Any one with whom one may talk or speak: and in this manner it is used without variation as sing. and pl. and fem. (S) as well as masc. (Msb.) You say, laA A^aHada fiy Ald~aAri [There is not any one in the house]: but you do not say, fiyhaA A^aHadN [as meaning the contrary]. (S.) We read in the Kur [lxix. 47, this ex. of its use as a masc. pl.], famaA minokumo mino A^aHadK Eanohu HaAjiziyna [And not any persons of you should have withheld me from punishing him]. (S.) And in the same [xxxiii. 32, we find this ex. of its use as a fem. pl.], lasotun~a kaA^aHadK mina Aln~isaA='i [Ye are not like any others of women]. (S.) ― -b6- It is also used in interrogative phrases; as in the saying, halo A^aHadN raA^ay mivola h`*aA [Has any one seen the like of this?]; (A'Obeyd, L;) and in the saying, yaA Hado raA=haA [for yaA A^aHadN, O, has any one seen her, or it?]. (L, from a trad.) ― -b7- It is [said to be] also used in the sense of $aY'N [meaning Anything], applied to an irrational being; as in the saying, maA biA ld~aAri mino A^aHadK A_il~aA HimaArFA There is not in the house anything, rational or irrational, except an ass: so that the thing excepted is united in kind to that from which the exception is made [accord. to this rendering; but this instance is generally regarded as one in which the thing excepted is disunited in kind from that from which the exception is made].
(Msb.) So too in the Kur lx. 11, accord. to the reading of Ibn-Mes'ood: (Msb:) but others there read $aYo'N, which may mean any one or any thing. (Bd, Jel.) ― -b8- AlA^aHadN, (K,) as also yawoma AlA^aHadi, (S, Msb,) as a proper name, (Msb,) is applied to A certain day; (K;) [Sunday;] the first day of the week; or, as some say, [i. e. as some term it,] the second of the week; (TA;) for the Arabs are said, by IAar, to have reckoned the Sabbath, or Saturday, as the first, though they called Sunday the first of the days: (Msb in art. jmE:) it is sing., and masc.: (Lh:) pl. [as above, i. e.] A=HaAdN (S, Msb, K) and A^uHodaAnN: (K:) or it has no pl. (K: [but in the TA this last observation is very properly restricted, as relating only to A^aHadN as syn. with waAHidN, and as applied to any unknown person.]) In this sense, it has no dim. (Sb, in S, art. Ams.) ― -b9- AlA=HaAdu in lexicology signifies What have been transmitted by some of the lexicologists, but not by such a number of them as cannot be supposed to have agreed to a falsehood: what has been transmitted by this larger number is termed mutawaAtiru. (Mz 3rd nwE.)
A_iHoday AHdY AHdy A^Hd A^HdY A^Hdy A^Hdyy A_HdY HdA Hdy : fems. of A^aHadN, q. v.
A_iHodaApN AHdAh AHdAp A^Hd A^HdAh A_HdAh : fems. of A^aHadN, q. v.
A^aHadiy~apN * The unity of God; (Msb;) as also waHodaAniy~apN. (L and K in art. wHd.)

A^uHaAda * [accus. of A^uHaAdu] is imperfectly decl., because of its deviation from its original, (S, K,) both in form and in meaning; (S;) [being changed in form from waAHidFA, and in meaning from A@waAHidFA: (see vulaAva:)] you say, jaAw^uwA A^uHaAda A^uHaAda, [AHAd being repeated for the purpose of corroboration,] meaning, They came one [and] one, one [and] one; or one [by] one, one [by] one. (S, K.) The dim. of A^uHaAdu is ↓ A^uHay~idN, perfectly decl., like vulay~ivN [q. v.] &c. (S, in art. vlv.)
A^uHayodN * dim. of A^aHadN, q. v.
A^uHay~idN * : see A^aHaAda.
A^uHayodaY * dim. of A_iHodaY fem. of A^aHadN, q. v.

1 A^aHina * (S, Msb, K) Ealayohi, (S, TA,) aor.
AaHana , (Msb, K,) inf. n. A^aHanN, (Msb,) or A^aHonN, and A_iHonapN, (TA,) or this last is a simple subst.; (Msb;) and A^aHana Ealayohi, aor.
AaHana , inf. n. A^aHonN; (Kr, TA;) He retained enmity against him in his bosom, watching for an opportunity to indulge it, or exercise it; or hid enmity against him in his bosom; or bore rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, against him: (S, Msb, K: *) and he was affected with anger (K, TA) against him, such as came upon him suddenly from the retention or hiding of enmity in the bosom, or from rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite. (TA.)
3 A=Hanahu A=Hnh A=Hnp , (TA,) inf. n. muw^aAHanapN, (S, K,) He treated him, or regarded him, with enmity, or hostility. (S, * K, * TA.)

A_iHonapN AHnh AHnp A^Hnh HAn
Retention of enmity in the bosom, with watchfulness for an opportunity to indulge it, or exercise it; or concealment of enmity in the bosom; or rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite: (S, Msb, K:) and anger (K, TA) coming upon one suddenly therefrom: (TA:) pl. A_iHanN. (S, Msb, K.) It is said in the S that one should not say HinapN; and this is disallowed by As and Fr and Ibn-El-Faraj: in the T it is said that it is not of the language of the Arabs; and As is related to have disapproved of Et-Tirimmáh for using its pl. in poetry: but it is said in a trad., maA bayoniY wbayona AlEarabi HinapN [There is not between me and the Arabs retention of enmity in the bosom, &c.]; and it occurs in another trad., in a similar phrase; and the pl., in a third trad.; therefore we say that it is a dial. var. of rare occurrence. (TA.)
A^axN * : see art. Axw.
A^uxotN * fem. of A^axN, q. v. in art. Axw.

1 A^xa*a * , (S, A, L, &c.,) in the first pers. of which, A^axa*otu, [and the like,] the * is generally changed into t, and incorporated into the [augmentative] t, [but in pronunciation only, for one writes A^axa*t~u and the like,] aor.
Aaxu*a , imperative xu*o, originally A@w^oxu*o, (S, L,) which latter form sometimes occurs, [but with w in the place of w^o when the A is pronounced with damm,] (TA,) inf. n. A^axo*N (S, L, Msb, K, &c.) and taA^oxaA*N, (S, L, K,) the latter having an intensive signification; (MF;) and waxa*a is a dial. var., as mentioned by Ibn-Umm-Kásim and others on the authority of AHei; (MF in art. tx*;) He took; he took with his hand; he took hold of; (S, A, L, Msb, K;) a thing. (S, L.) You say, xu*i AlxiTaAma and xu*o biAlxiTaAma Take thou, or take thou with thy hand, or take thou hold of, the nose-rein of the camel: (S, L, Msb:) the b in the latter phrase being redundant. (Msb.) [And A^axa*a biyadihi, lit. He took his hand, or arm; meaning (assumed tropical:) he aided, or assisted, him: a phrase of frequent occurrence.] And A^axa*a EalaYyadi fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) He prevented, restrained, or withheld, such a one from doing that which he desired; as though he laid hold upon his hand, or arm: (L:) and A^axa*a EalaY yadihi duwna maA yuriyudhu [signifies the same]. (K in art. lgd.) ― -b2- Also, inf. n. A^axo*N, He took, or received; contr. of A^aEoTay. (L.) [Hence,] A^axa*a Eanohu, (assumed tropical:) He received from him traditions, and the like. (TA passim.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) [He took, or derived, or deduced, a word, a phrase, and a meaning.] ― -b4- (tropical:) He took, received, or admitted, willingly, or with approbation; he accepted. (B, MF.) So in the Kur [vii. 198], xu*i AlEafowa (tropical:) [Take thou willingly, or accept thou, superfluous property, or such as is easily spared by others]. (MF.) So too in the same [iii. 75], wa A^axa*t~umo Ealay *`likumo A_iSoriY (tropical:) [And do ye accept my covenant to that effect?]. (B.) [And in the phrases, A^axa*onaA miyvaAqakumo biAlEamali bimaA fiy Alt~awoAraApi, (Jel ii. 60,) and Ealay AlEam~li bmA fy AltwArp, (Idem ii. 87,) (assumed tropical:) We accepted your covenant to do according to what is in the Book of the Law revealed to Moses.] xu*o Eanoka [is elliptical, and] means xu*o maA A^aquwlu wadaE Eanoka Al$~aka wAlmirA='a (assumed tropical:) [Accept thou what I say, and dismiss from thee doubt and obstinate disputation]. (S, L.) ― -b5- He took a thing to, or for, himself; took possession of it; got, or acquired, it; syn. HaAza; (Z, Er-Rághib, B;) which, accord. to Z and Er-Rághib and others, is the primary signification; (MF;) and HaS~ala. (B.) [See also 8.] ― -b6- [He took and kept;] he retained; he detained: as in the Kur [xii. 78], faxu*o A^aHadanaA makaAnahu [Therefore retain thou one of us in his stead]. (B.) ― -b7- [He took, as meaning he took away. Hence,] A^axa*a minohu Als~ayoru Journeying, or travel, took from him strength; (Alquw~apa being understood;) weakened him. (Har p. 529.) And A^axa*a mina Al$~aAribi, (Mgh,) and mina Al$~aEari, (Msb,) He clipped, or cut off from, (Mgh, Msb,) the mustache, (Mgh,) and the hair. (Msb.) ― -b8- He, or it, took by force; or seized: (B:) (assumed tropical:) he, or it, overcame, overpowered, or subdued: said by some to be the primary signification. (MF.) [See also A^axa*ahu Ealow~aA, &c., in art. Elw: and A^axa*ahu mino fawoqu, &c., in art. fwq.] It is said in the Kur [ii. 256], laA taA^oxu*uhu sinapi wa laA nawomN (assumed tropical:) Neither drowsiness nor sleep shall seize [or overcome] Him. (B.) [And you say, A^axa*atohu riEodapN (assumed tropical:) A tremour seized, took, affected, or influenced, him. And A^axa*ahu baTonuhu (assumed tropical:) His belly affected him with a desire to evacuate it.] You say also, A^axa*a fiyhi Al$~araAbu (assumed tropical:) The wine affected him, or influenced him, so that he became intoxicated. (TA in art. vml.) And A^axa*a Alr~aA^osa (Msb in art. swr, &c.) and A^axa*a biAlr~aA^osi (K in art. HmY, &c.) (assumed tropical:) [It had an overpowering influence upon the head]; meaning wine. (Msb, K.) And A^axa*a biAlHaloqi [It (food, &c.) choked]. (IAar in art. n$b in the TA, and S in art. b$E, &c.) And laA yaA^oxu*u fiyhi qawolu qaAy^ilK (assumed tropical:) [Nothing that any one may say will have any power, or effect, or influence, upon him]; meaning that he obeyeth no one. (L in art. lyt.) ― -b9- He took captive. (L, Msb, B.) So in the Kur [ix. 5], faA@qotuluwA A@lmu$orikiyna Hayovu wajadt~umuwhumo waxu*uwhumo [Then slay ye the believers in a plurality of gods wherever, or whenever, ye find them, and take them captives]. (Bd, L, B.) ― -b10- See also 2, in three places. ― -b11- He gained the mastery over a person, and killed, or slew, him; (Zj, L;) as also ↓ A=xa*a: (L:) or simply, (assumed tropical:) he killed, or slew. (B.) It is said in the Kur [xl. 5], waham~ato k~ulu A^um~apK birasuwlihimo liyaA^oxu*uwhu, meaning [And every nation hath purposed against their apostle] that they might gain the mastery over him, and slay him; (Zj, L;) or (assumed tropical:) that they might slay him. (B.) ― -b12- (assumed tropical:) He (God, Msb) destroyed a person: (Msb, MF:) and (assumed tropical:) extirpated, or exterminated. (MF.) faA^axa*ahumu A@ll~`hu bi*unuwbihimo [in the Kur iii. 9 and xl. 22] means But God destroyed them for their sins. (Jel.) ― -b13- (tropical:) He punished, or chastised; (L, Msb, B, K, MF;) as also ↓ A=xa*a: (L, Msb, MF:) as in the phrases, A^axa*ahu bi*anobihi
(Msb, K *) and bihi ↓ A=xa*ahu, inf. n. of the latter muw^aAxa*apN, (S, L, Msb, K,) (tropical:) he punished, or chastised, him for his sin, or offence: (Msb:) and A^uxi*a bi*anobihi means (assumed tropical:) he was restrained and requited and punished for his sin, or offence: (L:) or, accord. to some, A^axa*a signifies he extirpated, or exterminated; and ↓ A=x* he punished, or chastised, without extirpating, or exterminating. (MF.) [For ↓ A=x*,] some say waAxa*a, (S, L,) which is not allowable, (K,) accord. to some; but accord. to others, it is a chaste form; (MF;) of the dial. of El-Yemen, and used by certain of the seven readers [of the Kur-án] in the instance of laA yuwaAxi*ukumu A@ll~`hu [ii. 225 and v. 91]; and the inf. N. in that dial. Is muwaAxa*apN, and the imperative is waAxi*o. (Msb.) ― -b14- (tropical:) He made a violent assault upon a person, and wounded him much. (K, TA.) [You say also, A^axa*ahu bilisaAnihi, meaning (assumed tropical:) He assailed him with his tongue; vituperated him; spoke against him.] ― -b15- [He took, took to, or adopted.] You say, A^axa*a A^axa*ahumo and A_ixo*ahumo &c.: see A^axo*N, below. And A^axa*a fiY Tariyqi ka*aA [He took such a road]: and A^axa*a Eano yamiynihi A^awo yasaArihi [he took the way by, or on, the right of him, or it, or the left of him, or it]. (S in art. nZr.) [And A^axa*a biAlHazomi, and fiy AlHazomi, (the former the more common, the latter occurring in art. HwT in the K,) (assumed tropical:) He took the course prescribed by prudence, discretion, precaution, or good judgment; he used precaution: and, like A^axa*a biAlv~iqahi, (assumed tropical:) he took the sure course in his affair.] And A^axa*a Hi*orahu (assumed tropical:) He took care; became cautious, or vigilant. (Bd in iv. 73 and 103.) [And A^axa*a bimaA qaAla fulaAnN (assumed tropical:) He took to, or adopted and followed, or adhered to, what such a one said: see Har p. 367; where it is said that Ax* when thus used is made trans. by means of b because it implies the meaning of ta$ab~ava.] ― -b16- He took to, set about, began, or commenced; as in the saying, A^axa*a yafoEalu ka*aA He took to, set about, began, or commenced, doing such a thing; in which case, accord. to Sb, Ax* is one of those verbs which do not admit of one's putting the act. part. n. in the place of the verb which is its enunciative: [i. e., one may not say faAEilFA in the place of yfEl in the phrase above:] and as in A^axa*a fiY ka*aA He began, commenced, or entered upon, such a thing. (L.) ― -b17- [It is used in a variety of other phrases, in which the primary meaning is more or less apparent; and several of these will be found explained with other words occurring therein. The following instances may be here added.] ― -b18- TariyqN yaA^oxu*u fiY ramolapK [A road leading into, or through, a tract of sand]. (K in art. frz.) And A^axa*a bihimu AlT~ariyqu fiY gayori AlmaHaj~api [The road lead them otherwise than in the beaten track]. (T * and A in art. bhrj.) ― -b19- maA A^axa*atoka EayoniY muno*u HiynK (assumed tropical:) My eye hath not seen thee for some time; like maAZafiratoka. (T in art. Zfr.) And maA fiy AlHaY~i A^aHadN taA^oxu*uhu Eayoniy [explained to me by Ibr D as meaning (assumed tropical:) There is not in the tribe any one whom my eye regards as worthy of notice or respect by reason of his greatness therein]. (TA in art. jhr.) ― -b20- A^axa*otu Einodahu yadaY, and maEorwfAF: see 8. -A2- A^axi*a, aor.
Aaxa*a , inf. n. A^axa*N, (S, L, K,) He (a young camel) suffered heaviness of the stomach, and indigestion, from the milk: (S:) or became disordered in his belly, and affected with heaviness of the stomach, and indigestion, from taking much milk. (L.) ― -b2- He (a camel, L, K, or a sheep or goat, L) became affected by madness, or demoniacal possession; (K;) or by what resembled that. (L.) ― -b3- A^axi*ato Eayonuhu, aor.
Aaxa*a , inf. n. A^axa*N, His eye became affected by inflammation, pain, and swelling, or ophthalmia. (Ibn-Es-Seed, L, K. *) -A3- A^axu*a, aor.
Aaxu*a , inf. n. A^uxuw*apN, It (milk) was, or became, sour. (K.) [See A=xi*N.]

2 A^ax~a*atohu * , (S, L, K, *) inf. n. taA^oxiy*N, (S, L,) She captivated, or fascinated, him, (namely, her husband,) and restrained him, by a kind of enchantment, or charm, and especially so as to withhold him from carnal conversation with other women; (S, * L, K, * TA;) as also ↓ A^axa*atohu; and ↓ A=xa*atohu [of which the inf. n. is app. A_iyxaA*N]. (L, TA.) A woman says, A^uw^ax~i*u jamaliY I captivate, or fascinate, my husband, by a kind of enchantment, or charm, and withhold him from other women. (L, from a trad.) And one says, of a man, yuw^ax~i*u Eani A@moraA^atihi He withholds others [by a kind of enchantment, or charm,] from carnal conversation with his wife. (Msb.) The sister of Subh El-'Ádee said, in bewailing him, when he had been killed by a man pushed towards him upon a couch-frame, or raised couch, ↓ A^axa*t~u Eanoka Alr~aAkiba waAls~aAEiYa waAlmaA$iYa wAlqaAEida waAlqaAy^ima walamo A=xu*o Eanoka Aln~aAy^ima [I withheld from thee by enchantment the rider and the runner and the walker and the sitter and the stander, and did not so withhold from thee the prostrate]. (L.) And one says of a beautiful garment, Alquluwba maA^oxa*ahu ↓ A^axa*a [It captivated hearts in a manner peculiar to it]: (K in art. HSr: [in the CK, incorrectly, Aaxa*at and Alquluwbu:]) and Ax* biqalobihi [He, or it, captivated his heart; or] he [or it] pleased him, or excited his admiration. (TA in art. Alh.) -A2- A^x~* All~abana, inf. n. as above, He made the milk sour. (K.) [See A=xi*N.]
3 A=x* * , inf. n. muw^aAxa*apN: see 1, in the middle portion of the paragraph, in five places.
4 A=x* * , inf. n., app., A_iyxaA*N: see 2.

8 Ay^tx* * [written with the disjunctive alif Aiytaxa*a] occurs in its original form; and is changed into A@t~axa*a [with the disjunctive alif Ait~axa*a]; this being of the measure AftEl from A^axo*u, the [radical] ' being softened, and changed into t, and incorporated [into the augmentative t]: hence, when it had come to be much used in the form of AftEl [thus changed], they imagined the [former] t to be a radical letter [unchanged], and formed from it a verb of the measure faEila, aor. yafoEalu; saying, taxi*a, aor. yatoxa*u, (S, L, Msb, *) inf. n. taxa*N and taxo*N: (Msb:) and ↓ A@sotaxa*a [written with the disjunctive alif Aisotaxa*a], of which exs. will be found below, is also used for At~x*; one of the two ts being changed into s, like as s is changed into t in sit~N [for sidosN]: or Astx* may be of the measure AstfEl from taxi*a; one of the two ts being suppressed; after the manner of those who say Zalotu for Zalilotu: (S, L:) and IAth says that At~x*, in like manner, is of the measure AftEl from taxi*a; not from A^axa*a: (L and K in art. tx*:) but IAth is not one who should contradict J, whose opinion on this point is corroborated by the fact that they say A@t~azara from A_izaArN, and A@t~amana from A^amonN, and A@t~ahala from A^aholN; and there are other instances of the same kind: or, accord. to some, At~x* is from waxa*a, a dial. var. of A^axa*a, and is originally Aiwotaxa*a. (MF.) [The various significations of At~x* and taxi*a and Astx* will be here given under one head.] ― -b2- You say, A_iy^otaxa*uwA fiY AlqitaAli, (S, L, K, *) and fY AlHarobi, (Msb,) with two hemzehs, (S, L, K,) or, correctly, A_iytaxa*uwA, with one hemzeh, [or Aiytaxa*uwA,] as two hemzehs cannot occur together in one word, (marginal note in a copy of the S,) [but in a case of wasl, the first hemzeh being suppressed, the second remains unchanged,] They took, or seized, (A^axa*uwA,) one another (S, L, Msb, K) in fight, (S, L,) and in war; (Msb;) and so Ait~axa*uwA. (Msb.) And Aiytaxa*a Alqawomu The people, of company of men, wrestled together, each taking hold in some manner upon him who wrestled with him, to throw him down. (L, TA.) ― -b3- [At~x*, as also ↓ Astx*, and] taxi*a, aor.
Aaxa*a , (K in art. tx*,) inf. n. taxa*a and taxo*N, (TA in art. tx*,) likewise signifies i. q. A^axa*a, (K in art. tx*, and B and TA in the present art.,) as meaning He took a thing to, or for, himself; took possession of it; got, or acquired, it; syn. HaAza and HaS~ala. (B, TA.) Some read, [in the Kur, xviii. 76,] lataxi*ota Ealayohi A^ajorAF [Thou mightest assuredly have taken for thyself a recompense for it]: (S, L, K in art. tx*, and TA in the present art.:) this is the reading of Mujáhid, (Fr, TA,) and is authorized by I'Ab, and is that of Aboo-'Amr Ibn-El-'Alà and AZ, and so it is written in the model-copy of the Kur, and so the readers [in general] read: (AM, L, TA:) so read Ibn-Ketheer and the Basrees; he and Yaakoob and Hafs pronouncing the *; the others incorporating it [into the t]: (Bd:) some read lAA@t~axa*t~a; (L and K in art. tx*;) but these read at variance with the scripture. (AM, L, TA.) A^aroDAF ↓ Astx* is a phrase mentioned by Mbr as used by some of the Arabs, (S, L,) and signifies i. q. Ait~axa*ahaA [He took for himself a piece of land]. (S, L, K.) And At~x* walad~aA [in the Kur, ii. 110, &c.,] signifies He got a son, or offspring. (Bd &c. See also below.) And taxi*a, aor.
Aaxa*a , inf. n. taxa*N and taxo*N, also signifies He gained, acquired, or earned, wealth, (L, and Msb in arts. Ax* and tx*,) or a thing. (Msb.) ― -b4- Ealayohimo yadFA ↓ Astx* and Einodahumo signify alike, i. q. At~x* [He did to them a benefit, or favour; as though he earned one for himself in prospect, making it to be incumbent on them as a debt to him]: (ISh:) and Ait~axa*otu Einodahu maEorwfFA means [in like manner, as also Endh mErwfA ↓ A^axa*otu, and yad~aA, (and Ait~axa*a fiyhi HusonAF has a similar meaning; see Kur xviii.
85;)] I did to him a benefit, or favour; syn. A^asodayotuhu A_ilayohi. (Msb in art. sdy.) ― -b5- At~x* also signifies He made a thing; syn. Eamila; like taxi*a, [aor.
Aaxa*a ,] inf. n. taxa*N and taxo*N: (L:) he made, or manufactured, a bow, a water-skin, &c., mino ka*aA of such a thing: he made, or prepared, a dish of food, a medicine, &c.: either absolutely or for himself. (The Lexicons passim.) ― -b6- Also He made, or constituted, or appointed; syn. jaEala; doubly trans.; (B, Msb;) and so taxi*a. (Msb in art. tx*.) You say, At~x*hu SadiyqFA He made him [or took him as] a friend; (Msb in the present art.;) and so taxi*ahu. (Idem in art. tx*.) And At~x*hu huzuw^FA [in the Kur ii. 63 and 231, &c.,] means He made him, or it, a subject of derision. (Bd, Jel.) And At~x*hu waladFA [in the same, xii. 21 and xxviii. 8,] He made him, or took or adopted him as, a son. (Bd. See also above.)
10 A@sotaxa*a * , written with the disjunctive alif Aisotaxa*a: see 8, in four places. [Other meanings may be inferred from explanations of musotaA^oxi*N, q. v. infrà.]

A^axo*N * inf. n. of A^axa*a, q. v. ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A way, or manner, of life; as also ↓ A_ixo*N. (S, L, K.) You say, *ahaba banuw fulaAnK wamano A^axa*a A^axo*ahumo, (S, L, K, *) and ↓ A_ixo*ahumo, (L, K,) the former of the dial. of Temeem, and the latter of the dial. of El-Hijáz, (TA,) meaning (assumed tropical:) The sons of such a one went away, or passed away, and those who took to their way of life, (S, L, K,) and adopted their manners, or dispositions: (K:) and mano A^axa*a A^axo*uhumo and ↓ A_ixo*uhumo, and mano A^axa*a A^axo*uhumo [in the CK Aaxo*uhumo] and ↓ A_ixo*uhumo, signify [virtually] the same: (K:) or mano A^axa*ahu A^axo*uhumo and ↓ A_ixo*uhumo signify [properly] mano A^axa*ahu A^axo*uhumo wasiyratuhumo [those whom their way of life took, or influenced]. (ISk, S L.) One says also, A@sotuEomila fulaAnN Eala Al$~aAmi ↓ wamaA A^axa*a A_ixo*ahu, with kesr, meaning (assumed tropical:) [Such a one was appointed prefect over Syria,] and he did not take to that good way of life which it was incumbent on him to adopt: you should not say A^axo*ahu: (AA, S, L:) or it means and what was adjacent to it: (Fr, L:) or, accord. to the Wá'ee, one says, in this case, ↓ wamaA A^axa*a A_ixo*ahu and A^axo*uhu and ↓ A^uxo*uhu, with kesr and fet-h and damm [to the hemzeh, and with the * marfooah, as in instances before]. (Et-Tedmuree, MF.) One also says, ↓ lawo kunota min~aA laA^axa*t~a biA_xo*inaA, (S, L,) with kesr to the A, (L,) [in a copy of the S biA^axo*inaA, which seems to be also allowable, accord. to the dial. of Temeem,] meaning Wert thou of us, then thou hadst taken to, or wouldst take to, our manners, or dispositions, and fashion, (S, L,) and garb, and way of life. (L.) The words of the poet,
falawo kunotumo mun~aA A^axa*onaA biA_ixo*ikumo
IAar explains as meaning And were ye of us, we had caught and restored to you your camels: but no other says so. (L.) ― -b3- nujuwmu AlA^axo*i The Mansions of the Moon; (S, L, K;) also called nujuwmu AlA^anowaA='N; (L; [see art. nw';]) called by the former appellation because the moon every night enters (yaA^oxu*u fiY) one of those mansions: (S, L:) or the stars which are cast at those [devils] who listen by stealth [to the conversations of the angels]: (L, K:) but the former explanation is the more correct. (L.) ― -b4- See also A_ixaA*o.
A^uxo*N * , whence maA A^axa*a A^uxo*uhu: see A^axo*N. ― -b2- It is also a pl. of A_ixaA*N; (S, L;) and of A_ixo*N or A_ixo*apN, explained below with A_ixaA*N. (L.)

A_ixo*N * [The act of taking, taking with the hand, &c.], a subst. from A^axa*a. (S, L, Msb.) ― -b2- See also A^axo*N, in nine places. ― -b3- And see A_ixaA*N. ― -b4- Also A mark made with a hot iron upon a camel's side when a disease therein is feared. (K.)

A^axa*N *
Heaviness of the stomach, and indigestion, of a young camel, from the milk. (K.) [See A^axi*a.] ― -b2- See also A^uxu*N.

A^axi*N * A young camel disordered in his belly, and affected with heaviness of the stomach, and indigestion, from taking much milk. (AZ, Fr, L.) [See also SaboHaAnu.] ― -b2- A camel, or a young camel, or a sheep or goat, affected by what resembles madness, or demoniacal possession. (L.) ― -b3- A man affected with inflammation of the eye; with pain and swelling of the eye; with ophthalmia; (S, L;) as also ↓ musotaA^oxi*N. (L.) See also this latter. ― -b4- See also A=xi*N.
A^uxu*N * (S, L, K) and ↓ A^axa*N, (Ibn-Es-Seed, L, K,) which latter is the regular form, (L,) Inflammation of the eye; pain and swelling of the eye; ophthalmia. (S, L, K.)

A^axo*apN * [inf. n. un. of A^axa*a, An act of taking, &c.: an act of punishment, or chastisement, or the like; as in the Kur lxix. 10: pl. A^axa*aAtN]. ― -b2- A^axa*uwA A^axa*aAtihimo They took their places of abode. (IAth and L, from a trad.)

A^uxo*apN *
A manner of taking, or seizing, of a man with whom one is wrestling: pl. A^uxa*N. (L.) ― -b2- A kind of enchantment, or fascination, like siHor, (S, L, Msb, * K,) which captivates the eye and the like, (L,) and by which enchantresses withhold their husbands from other women; called by the vulgar ribaATN and EaqodN; and practised by the women in the time of ignorance: (TA:) or a kind of bead (xazarapN, S, L, K) with which one captivates, or fascinates, or restrains; (K;) with which women captivate, or fascinate, or restrain, men, (S, L,) and withhold them from other women: (L:) or i. q. ruqoyapN. (A.) ― -b3- A pitfall dug for catching a lion. (A, TA.) ― -b4- baAdiro bizanodika A^uxo*apa Aln~aAri [Strive thou to be before the time called (that of) Ax*p AlnAr with thy wooden instrument for producing fire; i. e. haste thou to use it before that time;] means the time a little after the prayer of sunset; asserted to be the worst time in which to strike fire. (K.)
A_ixo*apN * : see A_ixaA*N.

A_ixaA*N * and ↓ A_ixaA*apN A pool of water left by a torrent: pl. A^uxu*N: (AO, K:) both signify the same: (L:) or ↓ A_ixaA*apN signifies a thing like a pool of water left by a torrent; and A_ixaA*N is its pl. [or a coll. gen. n.]; and the pl. of this latter is A^uxu*N, like as kutubN is pl. of kitaAbN, and sometimes it is contracted into A^uxo*N: (S, L:) the like of this is said by Aboo-'Adnán: (L:) and A_ixaA*aAtN is also a pl. of A_ixA*apN, occurring in a trad., and signifying pools which receive the rain-water, and retain it for drinkers: (IAth, L:) or the correct word is A_ixaA*N, without p, and it signifies a place where beasts assemble at a pool of water left by a torrent; and its pl. is A^uxu*N (AA, A'Obeyd, L) and A=xaA*N, which latter is extr.: (L:) but as to ↓ A_ixaA*apN, it has a different signification, which will be found below; i. e. land of which a man takes possession for himself, &c.: (AA, L:) or A_ixaA*N is a coll. gen. n., and ↓ A_ixaA*apN is its n. un., and signifies a receptacle made for water to collect therein: and ↓ A^axo*N signifies a thing that one digs for himself, in the form of a watering-trough, which retains water for some days; and its pl. is A^uxo*aAnN: (L:) and ↓ A_ixo*N and ↓ A_ixo*apN also signify a thing that one digs in the form of a wateringtrough; and the pl. is A^uxo*N and A_ixaA*N. (L.) In a trad. of Mesrook Ibn-El-Ajda', A_ixaA* are likened to the Companions of Mohammad; and it is added, that one ↓ A_ixaA*ap suffices for a rider; and one, for two riders; and one, for a company of men: (S, L:) meaning that among them were the young and the old, and the possessor of knowledge and the possessor of more knowledge. (L.) ― -b2- See also A_ixaA*apN.

A^axiy*N *
i. q. ↓ maA^oxuw*N [Taken; taken with the hand; &c.]. (Msb.) ― -b2- A captive: (S, L, Msb, K:) fem. with p. (S, L.) Hence the saying, A^ako*abu mino A^axiy*i Aljay$i More lying than the captive of the army: meaning him whom his enemies have taken captive, and whom they desire to conduct them to his people, and who lies to them to his utmost. (Fr, L.) [See another ex. voce SaboHaAnu.] ― -b3- A strange, or foreign, old man. (K.)

A_ixaA*apN *
Land which a man, (S, L, K,) or a Sul- tán, (S, L,) takes for himself; as also ↓ A_ixaA*N: (S, L, K:) or land which a man takes for himself, and brings into a state of cultivation after its having been waste: (AA, Mgh, L:) or waste land which the owner gives to him who shall cultivate it: (Mgh:) and land which the Imám gives to one, not being property, (K,) or not being the property of another. (TA, as from the K.) ― -b2- See also A_ixaA*N, in five places. ― -b3- Also The handle of a [shield of the kind called] Hajafap; (K; [in the L written jHofp, with the j before the H;]) also called its vqAf. (L.)

A^axiy*apN *
A thing that is taken by force. (L.) [See also A^axiy*N.]

A^ax~aA*N * One who takes eagerly, or greedily: whence the saying, maA A^anota A_il~aA A^ax~aA*N nab~aA*N Thou art none other than one who taketh a thing eagerly, or greedily, and then throweth it away quickly. (A.)

A=xi*N * , (as in some copies of the K, in both of
the senses here explained,) or ↓ A^axi*o (as in other copies of the K, and in the L and TA, [but the former is the more agreeable with the form of the pl.,]) A camel beginning to become fat; (L, K;) or to become aged: (K:) pl. A^awaAxi*u (L.) -A2- Milk that bites the tongue; syn. qaAriSN. (K.) [See A^axu*a.]

maA^oxa*o * [A place where, or whence, a thing is taken: pl. maA=xi*u.] [Hence,] maA=xi*u AlT~ayori The places whence birds are taken. (K, TA.) ― -b2- [The source of derivation of a word or phrase or meaning.] ― -b3- A way [which one takes]; as in the phrase, AlmaA^oxa*a AlA^aqoraba salaka He went the nearest way. (Msb. in art. xSr.) ― -b4- [See also 2, last sentence but one.]
maA^oxuw*N * : see A^axiy*N.

rajulN muw^ax~a*N Eani Aln~isaA='i *
A man withheld [by a kind of enchantment or charm (see 2)] from women. (L.)
muw^otaxi*N * : see what follows.

musotaA^oxi*N * [Requiring to be clipped; i. e.] long; applied to hair. (K.) -A2- Lowering his head, or stooping, (As, S, L, K,) by reason of inflammation of the eyes, or ophthalmia, (As, S, L,) or by reason of pain, (As, S, L, K,) or from some other cause; (L;) as also ↓ A^axi*N, q. v. (TA.) Lowly, or submissive, (AA, L, K,) by reason of disease; as also ↓ muw^otaxi*N. (AA, L.)

2 A^x~r * , (S, K, &c.,) inf. n. taA^oxiyrN, (K,) is trans. (S, K, &c.) and intrans.: (K:) as a trans. verb it signifies He made to go back or backwards, to recede, retreat, retire, or retrograde: he put, or drove, back: he put, or placed, behind, or after; back, or backward: he made to be behind, or posterior, or last: he made to remain behind, hold back, hang back, or lag behind: he kept, or held, back: he postponed, put off, procrastinated, deferred, delayed, or retarded: he made backward, or late: contr. of qad~ama. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- A^ax~araniY A_ilaY mud~apK He granted me a delay, or postponement, to a certain term, or period. (TA in art. Ajl.) -A2- For its significations as an intrans. verb, see 5, in two places.

5 tA^x~r * is quasi-pass. of the trans. verb A^x~r; (S, A, Msb;) i. e. He, or it, went back or backwards, drew back, receded, retreated, retired, or retrograded: became put, or driven, back: became put, or placed, behind, or after: became behind, posterior, or last: he remained behind, or in the rear; held back, hung back, lagged behind, or delayed; was, or became, backward, or late: it was, or became, kept back, postponed, put off, procrastinated, deferred, delayed, or retarded: contr. of taqad~ama: (TA:) and ↓ AstA^xar is syn. therewith; (S, K:) and ↓ A^x~r, inf. n. taA^oxiyrN, signifies the same, being intrans. as well as trans. (K.) An ex. of the latter occurs in a saying of Mohammad to 'Omar: Ean~Yi ↓ A^ax~iro Retire thou from me: or the meaning is, A^ax~iroEan~iY raA^oyaka [hold thou back from me thine opinion; or reserve thou thine opinion until after mine shall have been given]. (TA.) You say, taA^ax~ira Eanohu taA^ax~urapF waAHidapF [He went back, &c., from him, or it, once]. (Lh.) And tA^x~r Eani Al$~aYo'i, or AlA^amori, He went back, &c., from the thing, or the affair: he was, or became, behind, behindhand, or backward, with respect to it: he held back, hung back, refrained, or abstained, from it; and Eanohu ↓ AstA^xr signifies the same. (The Lexicons in many places.) faA_i*aA jaA='a saAEapF ↓ A^ajaluhumo laA yasotaA^oxiruwna, in the Kur vii. 32 and other places, means And when their time is come, for punishment, they will not remain behind, or be respited, [any while, or] the shortest time: or they shall not seek to remain behind, by reason of intense terror. (Bd.)
10 A_isotaAoxara see 5, in three places.

A^axirN * [an epithet variously explained]. One says, in reviling, (S, TA,) but not when the object is a female, (TA,) A^aboEada Aall~`hu AlA^axira, (Th, S, A, &c.,) and ↓ AlA=xira (M, &c.,) or this latter is wrong, (Meshárik of 'Iyád, Mgh, Msb,) as is also ↓ AlA=xara, (Meshárik of 'Iyád,) meaning (tropical:) May God alienate, or estrange, from good, or prosperity, or may God curse, him who is absent from us, (A, Msb, TA,) distant, or remote: (A, Msb:) or the outcast; the alienated: (Msb:) or him who is put back, and cast away: so says Sh: or, accord. to ISh, him who is put back, and remote from good: and he adds, I think that ↓ AlA^axiyr is meant: (L:) or the base fellow : or the most ignoble: or the miserable wretch: (Et-Tedmuree and others:) or the last speaker: (Nawádir of Th:) or AlAxr is here a metonymy for the devil: (Lb:) it is a word used [for the reason explained voce A^aboEadu] in relating what has been said by one of two persons cursing each other, to the other; (Expositions of the Fs;) and the phrase above mentioned is meant to imply a prayer for those who are present [by its contrasting them with the person to whom it directly applies]. (A.) One also says, laA maroHabFA biAloA^axiri, [alluding to a particular person,] meaning [May the place, or land, not be ample, or spacious, or roomy,] to the remote from good. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of Mázin, A_in~a AlA^axiraqado zanaY Verily the outcast, (Mgh, Msb,) or he who is remote, and held back, from good,, (Mgh, * TA,) hath committed adultery, or fornication: the speaker meaning himself; (Mgh, Msb;) as though he were an outcast. (Msb.) And in another trad. it is said, AlmasoA^alapu A^axiru kasobi Almaro'i Begging is the most ignoble [mode of] gain of man: but El-Khattábee relates it with medd, [i. e. ↓ A=xiru,] explaining it as meaning begging is the last thing whereby man seeks sustenance when unable to gain [by other means]. (TA.)

A^uxurN * The back, hinder, or latter, part: the hindermost, or last, part: contr. of qudumN. (K.) [See also muw^ax~arN; from which it appears to be distinguished by its being used only adverbially, or with a preposition: and see A=xirN.] You say, $uq~a vawobuhu A^uxurFA, and mino A^uxurK, (S, K, *) His garment was rent, or slit, in its back, or hinder, part, (S,) or behind. (K.) And taA^ax~ara A^uxurFA [He retired backwards]. (A.) And jaA='i A^uxurFA: see A=xirN, in two places.
A^uxorapF * and biA^uxorapK: see A=xirF.
A^axarapF * and biA^axarapK: see A=xirN, in five places.

biEotuhu biA^axirapK *
I sold it (namely the article of merchandise, TA) with postponement of the payment; upon credit; for payment to be made at a future period; syn. binaZirpK; (S, A, K;) i. e. binasiy^apK. (S.)
A^uxarapF * and biA^uxarapK: see A=xirN.
A^uxoraApN * : see A=xaru, of which it is the fem.: and see also A=xirN.
A^uxoraApN * another fem. of A=xaru. (K.)
A^uxoriy~aA * and A_ixoriy~aA and A_ixiriy~aA: see A=xirN.

[
A^uxorawiY~N * and A^uxoraAwiY~u Relating to the other state of existence, or the world to come.]
A^axiyrN * and A^axiyrFA: see A=xirN, in five places. See also A^axirN.
A^uxayoraY * dim. of A^uxoraY, fem. of A=xaru, q. v. (S.)

A=xaru A=xr a subst., of the measure A^afoEalu, but implying the meaning of an epithet, (S,) from A^ax~ara in the sense of taA^ax~ara, (TA,) Another; the other; a thing [or person] other than the former or first; (L;) i. q. gayorN; (K;) as in the phrases, rajulN A=xaru another man, and vawobN A=xaru another garment or piece of cloth: (TA:) or one of two things [or persons]; (S, Sgh, Msb;) as when you say, jaA='a Alqawomu fawaAHidN yafoEalu ka*aA waA=xaru ka*aA The people came, and one was doing thus, and one [i. e. another] thus: (Sgh, Msb:) originally meaning more backward: (TA:) fem. ↓ A^uxoraY (S, Msb, K) and ↓ A^uxoraApN; (K) which latter is not well known: (MF:) pl. masc. A=xaruwna and A^uxaru; (S, K;) [the latter irreg. as such;] and, applied to irrational things, A^awaAxiru, like as A^afaADilu is pl. of A^afoDalu: (Msb:) and pl. fem. A_uxorayaAtN and A_uxaru; (S, Msb, K;) which latter is imperfectly decl.; for an epithet of the measure A^afoEalu which is accompanied by mino has no [dual nor] pl. nor fem. as long as it is indeterminate; but when it has the article Al prefixed to it, or is itself prefixed to another noun which it governs in the gen. case, it has a dual and a pl. and a fem.; but it is not so with A=xaru; for it has a fem. [and dual] and pl. without mino and without the article Al and without its being prefixed to another noun: you say, mararotu biraxulK A=xara, and birijaAlK A^uxara and A=xariyna, and biANmoraA^apK, and binisowapK [I passed by another man, and by other men, and by another woman, and by other women;] therefore, as it [namely A_uxaru] is thus made to deviate from its original form, [i. e. A=xaru, (I' Ak p. 287,) which is of a class of words used, when indeterminate, alike as sing. and dual and pl.,] and is [essentially and originally] an epithet, it is imperfectly decl.,
though a pl.: but when you name thereby a man, it is perfectly decl., when inderminate, accord. to Akh, or imperfectly decl. accord. to Sb. (S, L.) The dim. of A=xaru is ↓ A^uwayoxiru; the A with the ' suppressed following the same rule as the A in DaAribN: (TA:) and the dim. of A_uxoraY is ↓ A^uxayoraY. (S.) See also AlA^uxoraY voce A=xirN. ― -b2- laA A^afoEaluhu A^uxoraY All~ayaAliY, (S, K,) or AxrY Almanuwni, (K,) means I will not do it ever: (S, K:) or the latter, I will not do it to the end of time. (S.) And A^uxoraY Alqawomi, The last of the people. (S, K.) One says, jaA='a fiY A^uxoraY Alqawomi He came among the last of the people. (TA.) And jaA='i fiY A^uxorayaAti Aln~aAsi He came among those who were the last of the people. (S, A, K.) [See also A=xirN.] ― -b3- In A^aboEada All~`hu AlA=xara, the last word is a mistake for AlA^axira q. v. (Meshárik of 'Iyád.)

A=xirN A=xr , (S, Msb, K,) an epithet, of the measure faAEilN, (S,) and ↓ A^axiyrN, (S, Msb,) The last; aftermost; hindmost: and the latter; after; hinder: and [as a subst.] the end: contr. of A^aw~alu: [or of A^aw~alN when used as a subst.:] (A, Msb, K:) or of mutaqad~imN: (Lth, Msb:) or what is after the first or former: (S:) fem. of the former A=xirapN: (S, Msb, K:) pl. [masc.] A=xiruwna (Kur xxvi. 84, &c.,) and (masc. and fem., Msb) A^awaAxiru (S, Msb) and fem. A=xiraAtN also: (Th:) and ↓ maA=xiyru is syn. with A^awaAxiru; as in maA=xiyruAll~ayoli [occurring in the S and K in art. jhm, meaning The last, or latter, parts, or portions, of the night]. (TK in art. jhm.) You say, jaA='i A=xirFA and ↓ A^axiyrFA and ↓ A^uxurFA and ↓ biA^axarapK, all meaning the same [He came lastly, or latterly]: and in like manner, ↓ maA Earafotuhu A_il~aA A^axiyrFA and ↓ Al~A biA^axarapK [I did not know it save at the last, or lastly, or latterly]: (S:) or ↓ jaA='i A^axiyrFA and ↓ A^uxurFA and ↓ A^axorapN and ↓ biA^uxorapK and ↓ A^uxarapK and ↓ biA^uxarapK (K,) or ↓ A^uxorapN and ↓ biA^uxorapK (Lh, L,) and biA=xirapK (TA) and ↓ A_ixoriy~aA and ↓ A^uxoriy~aA and ↓ A_ixiriy~aA and ↓ A=xiriy~aA (K) mean he came lastly of everything. (K.) It is said in a trad., respecting Mohammad, A_i*aA A^araAda A^ano yaquwma mina Almajolisi ↓ kaAna yaquwlu biA^axarapK ka*aA waka*aA He used to say, at the end of his sitting, when he desired to rise from the place of assembly, thus and thus: or, accord. to IAth, it may mean, in the last, or latter, part of his life. (TA.) And you say, A^atayotuka A=xira mar~atayoni and A=xira mar~atayoni (IAar, M, K. *) And laA A^ukal~imuhu A=xira Ald~ahori I will not speak to him [to the end of time, or] ever. (A.) [See a similar phrase above, voce A=xaru.] And jaAw^uwA Eano A=xirihimo [They came with the last of them; En being here syn. with bi; meaning they came all, without exception]. (A.) [And kaAna *lika fiY A=xiri Al$~ahori, and Als~anapi; and fY A^awaAxiri himaA, That was in the end of the month, and of the year; and in the last days thereof.] And Aln~ahaAru yajurN Eano A=xirK faA=xirK [The day lengthens] hour by hour. (A.) See also A^axirN, last sentence. ― -b2- AlA=xiru is a name of God, signifying [The last; or] He who remaineth after all his creatures, both vocal and mute, have perished. (Nh.) ― -b3- AlA=xiraAni The two hinder dugs of the she-camel; opposed to the qaAdimaAni; (TA;) the two dugs that are next the thighs. (K.) ― -b4- AlA=xirapN, (K,) for Ald~Aru AlA=xirapu, (Bd in ii. 3,) [and AlHayaApu AlA=xirapu,] and ↓ AlA^uxoraY, (K,) [The latter, ultimate, or last, and the other, dwelling, or abode, and life; i. e. the latter, ultimate, or last, and the other, world; the world, or life, to come; and the ultimate state of existence, in the world to come;] the dwelling, or abode, [and life,] of everlasting duration: (K:) [each] an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates. (Z, and Bd ubi suprà.) [Opposed to Ald~unoyaA. And A=xirapN also signifies The enjoyments, blessings, or good, of the ultimate state; of the other world; or of the world, or life, to come: in which sense likewise it is opposed to dunoyaA: (see an ex. of both voce baAEa, in art. byE: so too ↓ A^uxoraY.)] ― -b5- A=xirapu Alr~aHoli, (S, Msb, K,) and Als~aroji, (Msb,) and A=xiruhu, (S in art. qdm, and K,) and ↓ muw^oxiratuhu, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) which is a rare form, or, accord. to Yaakoob, not allowable, (S,) and ↓ muw^xiruhu, and muw^ax~aratuhu, and ↓ muw^ax~aruhu, (S in art. qdm, and K,) and ↓ muw^ax~iratuhu, (Msb, K,) or this is a mistake, (Mgh, Msb,) and ↓ muw^ax~iruhu, (K,) but the first of all is the most chaste, (Msb,) The thing, (S,) or piece of wood, (Msb,) of the camel's saddle, (S, Msb,) and of the horse's, (Msb,) against which the rider leans [his back]; (S, Msb;) the contr. of its qaAdimap [by which term qAdmp is meant the waAsiT]: (K:) the wAsT of the camel's saddle is the tall fore part which is next to the breast of the rider; and its A=xrp is its hinder part; (Az, L;) i. e. its broad piece of wood, (Mgh,) or its tall and broad piece of wood, (Az, L,) which is against, or opposite to, (tuHaA*iY,) the head [and back] of the rider: (Az, Mgh, L:) [for] the A=xrp and the wAsT are the $aroxaAni, between which the rider sits: this is the description given by En-Nadr [ISh]; and all of it is correct: there is no doubt respecting it: (Az, L:) the pl. of A=xrp is is A^awaAxiru. (Msb.) ↓ A=xirapu AlEayoni: see muw^oxiruAlEayoni. ↓ A=xirN and ↓ A^axiyrN [accord. to some] also signify Absent. (K.) But see A^axirN, second sentence.
A=xiriy~aA A=xryA : see A=xirN.
A^uwayoxiru * dim. of A=xaru, q. v. (TA.)

muw^oxiru AlEayoni * , (T, S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, [in the CK muw^ax~arhA,]) said by AO, (Msb,) or A 'Obeyd, (TA,) to be better without teshdeed, from which observation it is to be understood that teshdeed in this case is allowable, though rare, but Az disallows it, (Msb, TA,) and muw^oxiratuhaA, and ↓ A=xiratuhaA, (K,) [The outer angle of the eye;] the part of the eye next the temple; (S, A, Mgh, Msb;) the part next the laHaAZ: (K:) opposed to its muqodim, which is the extremity thereof next the nose: (S, Mgh, Msb:) pl. maA=xiru. (Mgh.) You say, A_alay~a bimuw^oxiri [He looked at, or towards, me from (lit. with) the outer angle of his eye]. (S.) ― -b2- muw^oxiru Alr~aHoli, and muw^oxiratuhu: see A=xirN.

muw^ax~arN * The back, hinder, or latter, part of anything: its hindermost, or last, part: contr. of muqad~amN: as in the phrase, Daraba muw^ax~ara raA^osihi [He struck the back, or hinder part, of his head]. (S, Msb.) [See also A^uxurN and A=xirN.] ― -b2- muw^ax~aruAlr~aHoli, and muw^ax~aratuhu: see A=xirN.

Almuw^ax~iru * a name of God, [The Postponer, or Delayer;] He who postpones, or delays, things, and puts them in their places: [or He who puts, or keeps, back, or backward: or He who degrades:] contr. of Almuqad~imu. (TA.) ― -b2- muw^ax~iru Al~arHoli, and muw^ax~iratuhu: see A=xirN.

naxolapN miy^oxaArN *
A palm-tree of which the fruit remains until the end of winter: (AHn, K:) and until the end of the time of cutting off the fruit of palm-trees: (S, M, K:) contr. of mibokaArN and bakuwrN: pl. maA=xiyru. (A.)
maA=xiyru mA=xyr [reg. pl. of miy^oxaArN]: see A=xiru, first sentence.
mutaA^ax~irN * : see its verb. ↓ [An author, or other person, of the later, or more modern, times.]

AlmusoA^oxiriyna * in the Kur xv. 24 is said by Th to mean Those who come to the mosque after others, or late: (TA:) or it means those who are later in birth and death: or those who have not yet come forth from the loins of men: or those who are late, or backward, in adopting the Muslim religion and in fighting against unbelievers and in obedience. (Bd.)

1 A^axawota * , [third pers. A^axaA,] (S, K,) aor. taA^oxuw, (S,) inf. n. A^uxuw~apN; (S, K, &c.;) and ↓ A=xayota, (K, TA,) [in the CK Aaxayotu, which is wrong in respect of the pers., and otherwise, for it is correctly] with medd, (TA,) inf. n. A_ixaA='N and muw^aAxaApN; (Lth;) and ↓ taA^ax~ayota; (K;) Thou becamest a brother [in the proper sense of this word, and also as meaning a friend, or companion, or the like]. (S,* K,* TA.) ↓A^uxuw~apN is also [used as] a simple subst., (TA,) signifying Brotherhood; fraternity; the relation of brother; as also ↓A_ixaA='N and muw^aAxApN; and ↓taA^axK: (Lth, TA:) and the relation of sister. (S.) You say, bayoniY wabayonahu A^uxuw~apN and ↓A_ixaA='N [&c., meaning] Between me and him is brotherhood. (JK, TA.) And ↓bayona Als~amaAHapi waAlHamaAsapi taA^axK (assumed tropical:) [Between liberality and courage is a relation like that of brothers]. (TA.) And xuw~apN is a dial. var. of A^uxuw~apN, occurring in a trad. (IAth, TA.) -A2- [It is also trans.] You say, A^axawotu Ea$arapF I was, or became, a brother to ten. (TA.)

2 A^ax~ayotu lild~aAb~api * , (S, K,) or Ald~aAb~apa, (Msb, [so accord. to a copy of that work, but probably this is a mistranscription,]) inf. n. taA^oxiyapN, (S, Msb, K,) I made an A=xiy~ap [q. v.] for the beast, (Msb, K,) and tied the beast therewith; (Msb;) [and
so, app., ↓ A=xayotu (which, if correct, is probably of the measure A^afoEalotu); for it is related that] an Arab of the desert said to another, liY A=xiy~apF ↓ A=xi A^arobiTu A_alayohaA muhoriY [Make thou for me an A=xy~p to which I shall tie my colt]. (TA.) And you say, fulaAnN fiY fulaAnK A=xiy~apF fakafarahaA ↓ A=xiY (assumed tropical:) Such a one did a benefit to such a one, and he was ungrateful for it. (TA.) [But perhaps A=xi and A=xaY in these two exs. are mistranscriptions for A^ax~i and A^ax~aY.]

3 A=xAhu A=xAh A=xAp , (S, K,) vulgarly waAxaAhu, (S,) or the latter is a dial. var. of weak authority, (K,* TA,) said by some to be of the dial. of Teiyi, (TA,) inf. n. muw^aAxaApN and A_ixA='N (S, K) and wixaA='N, (K) and [quasi-inf. n.] ↓ A_ixaAwapN (Fr, K) and wixaAwapN, (CK,) He fraternized with him; acted with him in a brotherly manner: (S,* K,* PS, TK:) A'Obeyd mentions, on the authority of Yz, A=xayotu and waAxayotu, and A=sayotu and waAsayotu, and A=kalotu and waAkalotu: the pret. is said to be thus assimilated to [a form of] the fut.; for they used [sometimes] to say, yuwaAxiY, changing the hemzeh into w. (IB, TA.) ― -b2- It is said in a trad., A=xaY bayona AlmuhaAjiriyna waAlA^anoSaAri, meaning He united the emigrants [to El-Medeeneh] with the assistants [previously dwel-ling there] by the brotherhood of El-Islám and of the faith. (TA.) You say also, A=xayotu bayona Al$~ayoy^anoni [I united the two things as fellows, or pairs]; and sometimes one says, waAxayotu, like as one says, waAsayotu, for A=sayotu; mentioned by ISk. (Msb.) ― -b3- See also 1, in three places.
4 A=xawa see 2, in three places.

5 taA^ax~ayota * , and the inf.n. taA^axK: see 1, in three places. -A2- taA^ax~ayotu A^axFA I adopted a brother: (S, K:) or [taA^ax~ayotuhu signifies] I called him brother. (K.) ― -b2- taA^ax~ayotu Al$~aYo'a, (S, K, TA,) or biAl$~aYo, (Msb,) I sought, endeavoured after, pursued, or endeavoured to reach or attain or obtain, the thing; (S, Msb, K, TA;) as the brother does the brother; and in the same manner the verb is used with a man for its object: but tawax~ayotu, in the same sense, is more common. (TA.) You say, taA^ax~ayotu maHab~ataka I sought, &c., thy love, or affection. (TA in art. wxY.)

6 taA=xayaA tA=xyA
They became brothers, or friends or companions or the like, to each other. (S,* TA.)

A^axN * , (S, Msb, K,) originally A^axawN, (Kh, S, Msb,) as is shown by the first of its dual forms mentioned below, and by its having a pl. like A=baA='K, (S,) and A^ax~N, (K,) with the second letter doubled to compensate for the w suppressed, as is the case in A^ab~N, (TA,) and ↓ A^axFA, [like A^abFA,] and ↓ A^axuw, (IAar, K, TA, [the last, with the article prefixed to it, erroneously written in the CK AlAuxuw~N,]) and ↓ A^axowN, like dalowN, (Kr, K,) a well-known term of relationship, (K, TA,) i. e. A brother; the son of one's father and mother, or of either of them: and also applied to a foster-brother: (TA:) and (assumed tropical:) a friend; and a companion, an associate, or a fellow: (K:) derived from A=xiy~apN [q. v.]; as though one A^ax were tied and attached to another like as the horse is tied to the A=xy~p: (Har p. 42 :) or, accord. to some of the grammarians, it is from waxaY meaning qaSada; because the A^ax has the same aim, endeavour, or desire, as his A^ax: (TA:) when A^ax is prefixed to another noun, its final vowel is prolonged: (Kh:) you say, h*aA A^axuwka [This is thy brother, &c.], and mararotu biA^axiyka [I passed by thy brother, &c.], and raA^ayotu A^axaAka [I saw thy brother, &c.] : (S: [in which it is also asserted that one does not say A^axuw without prefixing it to another noun; but this is inconsistent with the assertion of IAar and F, that AlA^axuw is a syn. of AlA^axu:]) the dual is A^axawaAni, (S, Msb, Kur xlix. 10, Ham p. 434,) or A^axowaAni, with the x quiescent, (TA, [but this I have found nowhere else,]) and some of the Arabs say A^axaAni, (S, Msb,) and Kr mentions A^axuwaAni, with damm to the x, said by IB to occur in poetry, and held by ISd to be dual of A^axuw, with damm to the x: (TA:) the pl. is A_ixowapN and A_ixowaAnN, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) the former generally applied to brothers, and the latter to friends [or the like], (T, S,*) but not always, as in the Kur xlix. 10, where the former does not denote relationship, and in xxiv. 60 of the same, where the latter does denote relationship, (T, TA,) and sometimes the former is applied to a [single] man, as in the Kur iv. 12, (S,) and A^uxowapN, (Fr, S, Msb, K, [in the CK AaxowapN,]) or this is a quasi-pl. n., (Sb, TA,) and A^uxowaAnN, (Kr, Msb, K,) and A=xaA='N, (S, K,) like A=baA='N, (S,) and A^uxuw~N, and A^uxuw~apN, (ISd, K,) the last mentioned by Lh, and thought by ISd to be formed from the next preceding by the addition of p characterizing the pl. as fem., (TA,) and A^axuwna, (S, Msb, K,) and AxAwwn. (Msb: [there written without any syll. signs, and I have not found it elsewhere.]) The fem. of A^axN is ↓ A^uxotN [meaning A sister: and (assumed tropical:) a female friend, &c.]: (S, Msb, K, &c. :) written with damm to show that the letter which has gone from it is w; (S;) the t being a substitute for the w; (TA;) not to denote the fem. gender, (K, TA,) because the letter next before it is quiescent: this is the opinion of Sb, and [accord. to SM] it is the correct opinion: for Sb says that if you were to use it as a proper name of a man, you would make it perfectly decl.; and if the t were to denote the fem. gender, the name would not be perfectly decl.; though in one place he incidentally says that it is the sign of the fem. gender, through inadvertence: Kh, however, says that its t is [originally] h [meaning p]: and Lth, that A^uxotN is originally A^axapN: and some say that it is originally A^axowapN: (TA:) the dual. is A^uxotaAni: (Kh:) and the pl. is A^axawaAtN. (Kh, S, Msb, K.) The saying laA A^axaAlaka bifulaAnK [Thou hast no brother, or (assumed tropical:) friend, in such a one] means layosa laka biA^axK [such a one is not a brother, or friend, to thee]. (S, K.) It is said in a prov., mano laka biA^axiyka kul~ihi [Who will be responsible to thee for thy brother, or (assumed tropical:) thy friend, altogether? i. e., for his always acting to thee as a brother, or friend]. (JK.) And in another, rub~a A^axK laka lamo talidohu A^um~uka [(assumed tropical:) There is many a brother to thee whom thy mother has not brought forth]. (TA.) And in another, A^axuwka A^ami Al*~ay^obu [Is it thy brother, or the wolf?]; said in suspecting a thing: as also A^axuwka A^ami All~ayolu [Is it thy brother, or is it the night that deceives thee?]. (Har p. 554.) And another saying is, Alr~umoHu A^axuwka warub~amaA xaAnaka [(assumed tropical:) The spear is thy brother, but sometimes, or often, it is unfaithful to thee]. (TA.) ― -b2- Ibn-'Arafeh says that when A^uxuw~apN does not relate to birth, it means conformity, or similarity; and combination, agreement, or unison, in action: hence the saying, h*aA Alv~awobu A^axuw h*aA [(assumed tropical:) This garment, or piece of cloth, is the like, or fellow, of this] : and hence the saying in the Kur [xvii. 29], kaAnuwA A_ixowaAna Al$~ayaATiyni (assumed tropical:) They are the likes, or fellows, of the devils: and in the same [xliii. 47], ↓ A_il~aA hiYa A^akobaru mino A^uxotihaA (assumed tropical:) But it was greater than its like, or fellow; i. e., than what was like to it in truth &c. (TA.) It is said in a trad., Aln~awomu A^axu Almawoti [Sleep is the like of death]. (El-Jámi' es-Sagheer.) One says also, laqiYa fulaAnN A^axaA Almawoti (assumed tropical:) Such a one met with the like of death. (Msb, TA.) And they said, lahaA ↓ wamaAhu A=ll~`hu bilayolaPK laA A^uxota [(assumed tropical:) God afflicted him with a night having none like to it], i. e., a night in which he should die. (TA.) And laA A^ukal~imuhu A_il~aA A^axaA Als~irAri (assumed tropical:) I will not speak to him save the like of secret discourse. (As, TA.) [And hence,] suhayolK ↓ A^uxotaA [(assumed tropical:) The two sisters of Canopus;] the two stars called Al$~EoraY AlEabuwru and Al$~EoraY AlgumayoSaA='u. (S and K in art. $Er, q. v.) ― -b3- yaAa A^axaA bakorK, or tamiymK, means (assumed tropical:) O thou of [the tribe of] Bekr, or Temeem. (Ham p. 284.) ― -b4- Lh mentions, on the authority of Abu-d-Deenár and Ibn-Ziyád, the saying, Alqumomu biA^axiY Al$~ar~a, as meaning (assumed tropical:) The people, or company of men, are in an evil state or condition. (TA.) [But accord. to others,] one says, tarakotuhu biA^axiY Alxayori, meaning (tropical:) I left him in an evil state or condition: (JK, * Msb, K, TA:) and biA^axiY Al$~ar~i (tropical:) in a good state or condition. (TA.) ― -b5- You say also, huwaA^axuw AlS~adoqi (assumed tropical:) He is one who cleaves, or keeps, to veracity. (Msb.) ― -b6- [A^ixuw, as a prefixed noun, is also used in the sense of A^aholu, meaning (assumed tropical:) Worthy, or deserving, of a thing: and meet, fit, or fitted, for it. So in the phrase A^axuw viqapK (assumed tropical:) Worthy, or deserving, of trust, or confidence; expl. by W (p. 91) as meaning a person in whom one trusts, or confides. And so in the prov., layosa A^axuw AlkiZaAZi mano yasoA^amuhu (assumed tropical:) He who is fit, or fitted, for vehement striving for the mastery is not he who turns away from it with disgust: see art. kZ.] ― -b7- It is also used in the sense of *uw: as in the phrase, huwaA^axuw AlginaY [(assumed tropical:) He is possessed, or a possessor, of wealth, or competence, or sufficiency]. (Msb.) [So too in the phrase, A^axuw Alxayori (assumed tropical:) Possessed, or a possessor, of good, or of what is good. And in like manner,] A^axuw AlxanaEi means [*uw AlxanaEi, i. e. *uw Al*~il~api, i. e.] Al~*~aliylu [(assumed tropical:) The low, base, or abject]. (Ham p. 44.) [So too] sayorunaA A^axuw Aljiyodi means [sayorunaA *uwAljayodi, i. e.] sayorunaA jaAhidN
[(assumed tropical:) Our journeying is laborious: see an ex. in the first paragraph of art. gdr]. (TA.) ― -b8- Hum~aY AlA^axawayoni (assumed tropical:) A fever that affects the patient two days, and quits him two days; or that attacks on Saturday, and quits for three days, and comes [again] on Thursday; and so on. (Msb.) ― -b9- damu AlA^axawayoni: see damN, in art. dmY.
A^axFA * :see A^axN.
A^axowN * :see A^axN.
A^axuw * :see A^axN.
A^uxotN * : see A^axN, in four places.

[
A^uxay~N * and A^uxay~apN dims. of A^axN and A^uxotN.]

A^axawiy~N *
Brotherly; fraternal; of, or relating to, a brother, and a friend or companion: and also, sisterly; of, or relating to, a sister; because you say A^axawaAtN [meaning “sisters”]; but Yoo used to say ↓ A^uxotiY~u, which is not agreeable with analogy. (S, TA.)
A^uxotiY~u * : see A^axawiY~u.
A_ixowaAnN A^x A^xwAn A_xwAn AxwAn , besides being a pl. of A^axN, q. v., is a dial. var. of xiwaAnN. (TA. [See art. xwn.])
A_ixaAwapN A^xAwh A_xAwp AxAwh AxAwp xAwY : see 3.

A^uxuw~ahN * an inf. n. of 1: and also [used as] a simple subst. (TA.) See 1. ― -b2- When it does not relate to birth, it means (assumed tropical:) Conformity, or similarity; and combination, agreement, or unison, in action. (Ibn-'Arafeh, TA.)

A=xiy~apN A=xyh A=xyp , (Lth, S, Msb, K, &c.,) originally of the measure faAEuwlapN, [i. e. A=xuwyapN,] (Msb,) and A=xiyapN, (Lth, Msb, K,) and A^axiy~apN, (JK, K, TA, [but in the K the orthography of these three words is differently expressed in different copies, and somewhat obscurely in all that I have seen,]) A piece of rope of which the two ends are buried in the ground, (ISk, JK, S,) with a small staff or stick, or a small stone, attached thereto, (ISK, S,) a portion thereof, resembling a loop, being apparent, or exposed, to which the beast is tied; (ISk, JK, S;) it is made in soft ground, as being more commodious to horses than pegs, or stakes, protruding from the ground, and more firm in soft ground than the peg, or stake: (TA:) or a loop tied to a peg, or stake, driven [into the ground], to which the beast is attached: (Msb:) or a stick, or piece of wood, (K, TA,) placed crosswise (TA) in a wall, or in a rope of which the two ends are buried in the ground, the [other] end [or portion] protruding, like a ring, to which the beast is tied: (K, TA:) or a peg, or stake, to which horses are tied: (Har p. 42:) [see also A=riY~u:] the pl. of the first is A^awaAxiY~u; (JK, S, Msb, K;*) and of the second, A^waAxK; (Msb;) and of the third, A^axaAyaA, (JK, K,*) like as xaTaAyaA is pl. of xaTiy~apN. (TA.) In a trad., the believer and belief are likened to a horse attached to his A=xy~p; because the horse wheels about, and then returns to his A=xy~p; and the believer is heedless, and then returns to believe. (TA.) And in another, men are forbidden to make their backs like the A^axaAyaA of beasts; i. e., in prayer; meaning that they should not arch them therein, so as to make them like the loops thus called. (TA.) ― -b2- Also i. q. TunubN; (K;) i. e. The kind of tent-rope thus called. (TA in art. Tnb, q. v.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) A sacred, or an inviolable, right or the like; syn. HuromapN and *im~apN. (S, K.) You say, lifulaAnK A^awaAxiY~u waA^asobaAbN turoEaY [(assumed tropical:) To such a one belong sacred, or inviolable, rights, and ties of relationship and love, to be regarded]. (S.) And lahu EinodiY A=jiy~apN (assumed tropical:) He has, with me, or in my estimation, a strong, sacred, or inviolable, right; and a near tie or connexion, or means of access or intimacy or ingratiation. (TA.) ― -b4- In a trad. of 'Omar, in which it is related that he said to El-'Abbás, A^anota A=xiy~apu A=baA='i rasuwli Aall~`hi, it is used in the sense of baqiy~apa; [and the words may therefore be rendered Thou art the most excellent of the ancestors of the Apostle of God;] as though he meant, thou art he upon whom one stays himself, and to whom one clings, of the stock of the Apostle of God. (TA.)

1 A^ad~at~apu daAhiyapN * , aor
Aadu3a (T, S; M, K) and
Aadi3a , (M, K,) but this latter is strange, [anomalous,] and unknown, (TA,) and
Aada3a , (M, K,) mentioned by Lh, whence it seems that he made the pret. to be of the measure faEila, or that it is co-ordinate to A^abaY, aor yaA^obaY, (M,) inf. n. A^ad~u, (T, S, M,) A calamity befell him. (M, K.) And in like manner, A^ad~ahu A^amorN, aor. and inf. n. as above, An event befell him: (M:) or oppressed him, distressed him, or afflicted him. (Bd in xix. 91.) -A2- See also 5.
5 tA^d~d * ; (T, K;) and ↓ A^ad~a, inf. n. A^ad~u; (TA;) i. q. ta$ad~ada [He acted, or behaved, with forced hardness, firmness, strength, vigour, &c.]. (T, K.)

A^ad~u * (S, M, K) and ↓ A_id~u (T, K) and ↓ A=d~u (K) Strength; power; force: (S, M, K:) superior power or force or influence; mastery; conquest; predominance. (M, K, TA.) ― -b2- See also A_id~u, in two places. ― -b3- Also, the first, The sound of treading. (T.)

A_id~u A^d A_d Ad wdY |d : see A^ad~u. ― -b2- Also, and ↓ A_id~apN, A wonder, or wonderful thing: (M, L, K:) a very evil, abominable, severe, thing, or affair: (S, M, A, L, K:) a calamity; (S, A, L, K,) or thus the former word signifies; (M;) as also ↓ A^ad~u, (as in the copies of the K,) or ↓ A=d~u, [originally A=didF] of the measure faAEilo: (so in the S and L:) pl. (of A_id~u M, TA) A_idAdu (K, TA,) or A^adaAdu (T, CK, [but this, if correct, is a quasi-pl. n.,]) or A=daAdu (M,) and (of A_id~apN, S, M) A_idadN (T, S, M, K.) You say also A^amoroA_id~u [meaning as above], using A_id~u as an epithet, accord. to Lh. (M.) And ↓ daAhiyapN A_id~apN [A very evil, abominable, or severe, calamity]. (A.) Hence the saying in the Kur [xix. 91], laqado jiy^otumo $ayoy^FA A_id~FA Verily ye have done a very evil, or abominable, thing: (S, M: *) or, accord. to one reading, ↓ A^ad~uA; both meaning great, or grievous: and some of the Arabs say, ↓ bi$aYo'K A=d~K, which means the same. (T, TA.)
A_id~apN A^d A^dh A_d A_dh Adh Adp dhY dhy wdY |d |dh : see A_id~u in two places.
A=d~u A=d : see A^ad~u: ― -b2- and see A_id~u in two places.

1 A^adaba * , aor.
Aadiba , inf. n. A^idobN, He invited (people, S, or a man, K) to his repast, or banquet; (S, K;) as also ↓ A=daba, (K,) or A=daba A_ilaY TaEaAmihi aor yuwdibu [or yuw^odibu], (AZ, S,) inf. n. A_iydaAbN [originally A_iy^odaAbN]. (AZ, S, K.) You say, A^adaba Alqawoma, (S,) or A^adaba EalaY Alqawomi, aor. as above, (T,) He invited the people to his repast. (T, S.) And A^adabahumo EalaY AlA^amri He collected them together for the affair. (A.) And jiyraAnaka litu$aAwirahumo ↓ A^uwdibu [I will collect thy neighbours in order that thou mayest consult with them]. (A.) The primary signification of A^adobN is The act of inviting. (T.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A^adabN, aor.
Aadiba ; (Msb, K;) or A^adiba, aor.
Aadaba ; (so in a copy of the M;) inf. n. A^adobN, (M, Mgh, Msb,) or A^adabN; (K;) He made a repast, or banquet, (M, Msb, K,) and invited people to it; (Msb;) as also ↓ A=daba, (M,) aor. and inf. n. as above: (TA:) or he collected and invited people to his repast. (Mgh.) ― -b3- [Hence also, as will be seen below, voce A^adabN] A^adabahu, aor.
Aadiba , inf. n. A^adobN, He taught him the discipline of the mind, and the acquisition of good qualities and attributes of the mind or soul; (Msb;) and ↓ A^d~bhu, [inf. n. taA^odiybN, signifies the same;] he taught him what is termed A^adab [or good discipline of the mind and manners, &c.; i. e. he disciplined him, or educated him, well; rendered him well-bred, wellmannered, polite; instructed him in polite accomplishments; &c.]: (S, M, A, Mgh, K:) or the latter verb, inf. n. taA^odiybu, signifies he taught him well, or much, the discipline of the mind, and the acquisition of good qualities and attributes of the mind or soul: and hence, this latter also signifies he disciplined him, chastised him, corrected him, or punished him, for his evil conduct; because discipline, or chastisement, is a means of inviting a person to what is properly termed AlA^adabu. (Msb.) -A2- A^aduba, aor.
Aaduba , (AZ, T, S, M, K,) inf. n. A^adabN, (M, K,) He was or became, characterized by what is termed A^adab [or good discipline of the mind and manners, &c.; i. e., well disciplined, well-educated, well-bred, or well-mannered, polite, instructed in polite accomplishments, &c.]. (AZ, T, S, M, K.)
2 Aad~aba see 1.
4 A=daba see 1, in three places. ― -b2- A=daba AlbilaAda, aor. and inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) He filled the provinces, or country, with justice, or equity. (K * TA.)

5 tA^d~b *
He learned, or was taught, what is termed A^adab [or good discipline of the mind and manners, &c.; i. e. he became, or was rendered, well-disciplined, well-educated, well-bred, wellmannered, polite, instructed in polite accomplishments, &c.]; as also ↓ AstA^db. (S, Mgh, K.)
10 A_isotaAodaba see 5.

A^adobN * , (S, M, K,) or, accord. to some, ↓ A_idobN, (TA,) Wonderful; or a wonderful thing; syn. EajabN; (S, M, K;) as also ↓ A^udobapN [used in the latter sense]. (K.) You say, ↓ jaA='a fulaAnN biA^amorK A_idobK Such a one did a wonderful thing. (As, T. *) -A2- See also A^adabN, last sentence.
A_idobN A^db Adb dAb db |db : see A^adabN, in two places.

A^adabN * , so termed because it invites men to the acquisition of praiseworthy qualities and dispositions, and forbids them from acquiring such as are evil, (T, Mgh,) signifies Discipline of the mind; and good qualities and attributes of the mind or soul: (Msb:) or every praiseworthy discipline by which a man is trained in any excellence: (AZ, Mgh, Msb:) [good discipline of the mind and manners; good education; good breeding; good manners; politeness; polite accomplishments:] i. q. ZarofN [as meaning excellence, or elegance, of mind, manners, address, and speech]: and a good manner of taking or receiving [what is given or offered or imparted, or what is to be acquired]: (M, A, K:) or good qualities and attributes of the mind or soul, and the doing of generous or honourable actions: (El-Jawáleekee:) or the practice of what is praiseworthy both in words and actions: or the holding, or keeping, to those things which are approved, or deemed good: or the honouring of those who are above one, and being gentle, courteous, or civil, to those who are below one: (Towsheeh:) or a faculty which preserves him in whom it exists from what would disgrace him: (MF:) it is of two kinds, A^adabu Aln~afosi [which embraces all the significations explained above], and A^adabu Ald~arosi [which signifies the discipline to be observed in the prosecution of study, by the disciple with respect to the preceptor, and by the preceptor with respect to the disciple: see ‘Haji Khalfæ Lexicon,’ Vol. I. p. 212]: (S, Btl, Mgh:) [also deportment, or a mode of conduct or behaviour, absolutely; for one speaks of good A^adab and bad A^adab:] the pl. is A=daAbN [which is often employed, and so is the sing. also, as signifying the rules of discipline to be observed in the exercise of a function, such as that of a judge, and of a governor; and in the exercise of an art, such as that of the disputer, and the orator, and the poet, and the scribe; &c.]. (Msb.) ― -b2- Eilomu AlA^adabi signifies [The science of philology; or] the science by which one guards against error in the language of the Arabs, with respect to words and with respect to writing; (‘Haji Khalfæ Lexicon,’ Vol. I. p. 215;) [and so, simply, AlA^adabu: which is also used to signify polite literature: but in this sense, and like wise] as applied to the sciences relating to the Arabic language, [or the philological sciences, which are also termed ↓ AlEuluwmu AlA^adabiy~aAtu,] AlA^adabu is a post-classical term, innovated in the time of El-Islám. (El-Jawá- leekee.) -A2- A^adabu AlbaHori, (A, K,) or AlbaHori ↓ A^adobu, (T, L,) (tropical:) The abundance of the water of the sea. (T, A, L, K.)
A^udobapN * : see maA^odubapN: -A2- and see also A^adobN.

A^adabiy~N *
Of, or relating to, what is termed A^adab, or AlA^adab. Hence, AlEuluwmu AlA^adabiy~aAtu: see A_adabN, last sentence but one.]

A^adiybN *
Characterized by what is termed A^adab [or good discipline of the mind and manners, &c.; i. e. well-disciplined, well-educated, well-bred, or well-mannered; polite; instructed in polite accomplishments, or an elegant scholar; &c.]: (T, S, M, Mgh, K:) pl. A^udabaA='K. (M, K.) ― -b2- See also maw^ad~abN.

A=dabu A=db [originally A^aA^odabu, More, or most, characterized by what is termed A^adab; i. e. better, or best, disciplined, educated, bred, or mannered; more, or most, polite; &c.]. You say, huwamino A=dabi Aln~aAsi [He is of the best disciplined, &c., of men]. (A.)
A=dibN A=db One who invites people to a repast, or banquet: (T, S, Msb:) pl. A^adabapN. (TA.)
maA^odabapN * : see what next follows, in two places.

maA^odubapN *
A repast, or banquet, to which guests are invited; (A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) or made on account of a wedding: (M, K:) as also ↓ maA^odubapN, (S, M, Msb, K,) or, accord. to A 'Obeyd, this latter has a different signification, as will be seen below, (TA,) and ↓ maA^odubapu, (IJ,) and ↓ A^udobapN: (M, K:) pl. maA=dibu. (S.) In a trad., the Kur-án is called maA^odubapu All~`hi fiY AlA^aroDi, or ↓ maA^odabap; and A 'Obeyd says that, if we read mA^dubp, the meaning is, God's repast which He has made in the earth, and to which He has invited mankind; but if we read mA^dabp, this word is of the measure mafoEalapN from AlA^adabu, [and the meaning is, a means which God has prepared in the earth for men's learning good discipline of the mind, &c.; it being a noun similar to mavoraApN and makovarapN &c.:] El-Ahmar, however, makes both words synonymous. (T, M, * TA.)
maA^odibapN * : see what next precedes.
muw^ad~abN * ↓ A^adiybN A camel well-trained and broken. (T, L.)
maA^oduwbapN * , occurring in a verse of 'Adee, [which I do not anywhere find quoted,] She [app. a bride] for whom a repast, or banquet, has been made. (TA.)

1 A^adira * , aor.
Aadaba , (T, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. A^adarN (Lth, T, S, Mgh) and A^adarapN, (Lth, TA,) or A^udorapN, (as in the TT,) or A^udorapN is a simple subst., (M, K,) and so is A^udorapN, (K,) He (a man, S) had the disorder termed A^udorapN. (T, S, M, &c.)

A^udorapN * a subst. from A^adira; [see A=daru, below;] (K;) as also ↓ A^adarapN: (M, K:) the former signifies [A scrotal hernia;] an inflation in the xuSoyap [or the testicle, or the scrotum]: (T, * S:) or an inflation of the xuSoyap: (Msb:) or a disorder consisting in an inflation, or a swelling, of the xuSoyataAni, and their becoming greatly enlarged with matter or wind therein: (Esh-Shiháb, on the Soorat el-Ahzáb:) or a largeness of the xuSa: (Mgh:) and ↓ A^adarapN also signifies what is vulgarly termed qayolapN [meaning in the present day a scrotal hernia]: or, accord. to some, i. q. xuSoyapN. (TA.) [See also 1.]
A^adarapN * : see A^udorapN, in two places. [See also 1.]

A=daru A=dr (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and ↓ maA^oduwrN (M, K) A man (S) [having a scrotal hernia; or] having an inflation in the xuSoyap [or the testicle, or the scrotum]: (T, * S:) or having an inflation of the xuSoyap: (Msb:) or having his SifaAq [or inner skin] ruptured, so that [some of] his intestines fall into his scrotum; the rupture being in every instance only in the left side: or afflicted by a rupture in one of his xuSoyaAni [or in either half of the scrotum]: (M, K:) or having a largeness of the xuSaY (Mgh:) pl. of the former, A^udurN; (Msb, K;) and of the latter, maA=diyru. (K.) Accord. to some, (M,) A^adoraA='u xuSoyapN signifies [A testicle, or scrotum,] large, without rupture. (M, K.)
maA^oduwrN * : see A=daru.

1 A^adama Alxuboza * , aor.
Aadima , (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. A^adomN; (M, Msb;) and ↓ A=dmhu, (Msb, K,) inf. n. A_iydaAmN; (TK;) He mixed the bread with A^udom [or seasoning; i. e. he seasoned it]; (M, K;) he made the swallowing of the bread to be good, or agreeable, by means of A_idaAm [or seasoning]. (Msb.) You say also, A^adama Alxuboza biAll~aHomi, aor.
Aadima , [he seasoned the bread, or rendered it savoury, with flesh-meat,] from A^udomN and A_idaAmN, signifying maA yuw^otadmu bihi. (S.) ― -b2- A^adama Alqawoma, aor.
Aadima , (K,) inf. n. A^adomN; (TA;) or ↓ A=damahumo; (M;) or both; (TA;) He seasoned for the people, or company of men, (A^adama lahumo, [in the CK, erroneously, AadAma lhm,]) their bread; (M, K, TA;) i. e., mixed it [for them] with A_idaAm (TA.) ― -b3- [From A^adama in the first of the senses explained above, is app. derived the phrase,] A^adamahu biA^aholihi He mixed him, associated him, or united him in company, with his family. (M.) [And in like manner,] A^adama bayonahumaA, (T, S,) or bayonahumo, (M, Msb, * K,) aor.
Aadima , (T, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. A^adomN; (T, M, M$sudot;b;) and ↓ A=dm, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_iyadAmN; (T, TA;) He (God, T, S, M, or a man, Msb) effected a reconciliation between them; brought them together; (S, M, Msb, K; [expl. in the M and K by laA'a ma, for which we find in the CK laAuma;]) made them sociable, or familiar, one with another; (S, Msb, TA;) and made them to agree: (TA:) or induced love and agreement between them: held by A "Obeyd to be from A^udomN, because thereby food is made good and pleasant. (T.) It is said in a trad., faA_in~ahu A^aHoraY A^ano yuw^odama bayonakumaA, meaning For it is most fit, or meet, that there should be, between you two, love and agreement: (T, S:) or, that peace, or reconciliation, and friendship, should continue between you two. (Msb.) And a poet says,
↓ A_il~aA muw^odamaA ↓ waAlbiyDu laA yuw^odimona
i. e. [And the pure, or free from faults, among
women,] do not love any save one who is made an object of love [by his good qualities], (T, S,) a proper object of love. (T.) -A2- A^adamahumo, (T, M, K,) aor.
Aadima , (T,) or
Aaduma , (M, K,) inf. n. A^adomN, (M,) (tropical:) He was, or became, to them, what is termed A^adamap; (T, M, K;) i. e., one who made people to know them; (T;) or a pattern, an exemplar, an example, or one who was imitated, or to be imitated; and one by means of whom they were known: (M, K:) so says IAar. (M.) -A3- A^adama AlA^adiyma He pared, or removed the superficial part of, the hide: (T, * TA:) and AlA^adiyma ↓ A=dama, with medd, he pared off the A^adamap [q. v.] of the hide: (TA:) or the latter signifies he exposed to view the A^adamap [in the CK, erroneously, the Audomap] of the hide. (M, K.) -A4- A^adima, aor.
Aadama , (M, K,) inf. n. A^adamN; (TK;) and A^aduma, aor.
Aaduma , (M, K,) inf. n. A^uduwmapN (T, K) [or, more probably, A^udomapN, like sumorapN &c.]; He (a camel, and a gazelle, and a man,) was, or became, of the colour termed A^udomap, q. v. infrà. (M, K.)
2 A^d~mhu * , inf. n. taA^odiymN, He put much A_idaAm [or seasoning] into it. (TA.)
4 A=dama see 1, in five places.

8 Ay^tdm bihi * [written with the disjunctive alif Aiytadama] He made use of it [to render his bread pleasant, or savoury]; namely A^udom, (M, * TA,) or A_idaAm. (M.) [A_idaAmN is explained in the T and S &c. by the words maA yuw^otadamu bihi, meaning That which is used for seasoning bread.] ― -b2- Ay^tdm AlEuwdu (tropical:) The wood, or branch, had the sap (AlmaA=') flowing in it. (Z, K.)

10 AstA^dmhu *
He sought, or demanded, of him A_idaAm [or seasoning]. (Z, TA.)
A^adomN * : see A^udomapN -A2- huwa A^adomu A^aholihi: see A^adamapN.
A^udomN * : see A_idaAmN. ― -b2- huwa A^udomu A^aholihi: and A^udomu baniY A^abiyhi: see A^adamapN.
A^adamN * : see A^adiymN, in two places: ― -b2- and A^adamapN. -A2- A^adamu: see A=damu.
huwa A^adomapu A^aholihi * : see A^adamapN.

A^udomapN *
A state of mixing, or mingling, together [in familiar, or social, intercourse]. (Lth, T, M, K.) You say, bayonahumaA A^udomapN Between them two is a mixing, &c. (Lth, T.) ― -b2- Also, (M, K,) or ↓ A^adomN, (S,) Agreement: (S, M, K, TA:) and familiarity, sociableness, companionship, or friendship. (S, TA. [The meanings in this sentence are assigned in the S only to the latter word: in the TA, only to the former.]) ― -b3- And the former, Relationship. (M, K.) ― -b4- And A means of access (wasiylapN, Fr, T, S, M, K) to a thing, (Fr, T, S,) and to a person; (Fr, T;) as also ↓ A^adamapN. (K.) You say, fulaAnN A^udomatiY A_ilayoka Such a one is my means of access to thee. (Fr, T.) ― -b5- And [hence,] A present which one takes with him in visiting a friend or a great man; in Peraian dasot A=wiyz. (K, L.) ― -b6- huwa A^udomapu A^aholihi: and huwa A^udomapN lifulaAnK: see A^adamapN. -A2- In camels, A colour intermixed, or tinged, with blackness, or with whiteness; or clear whiteness; (M, K;) or, as some say, (TA,) intense whiteness; (S, TA;) or whiteness, with blackness of the eyeballs: (Nh, TA:) and in gazelles, a colour intermixed, or tinged, with whiteness: (M, K:) or in gazelles and in camels, whiteness: (T:) and in human beings, (M, K,) a tawny colour; or darkness of complexion; syn. sumorapN [q. v.]; (S, M, K;) or an intermixture, or a tinge, of blackness; (Lth, T;) or intense sumorap [or tawniness]; and it is said to be from A^udomapu AlA^aroDi, meaning the colour of the earth: (Nh, TA:) or [in men,] i. q. HumorapN [which, in this case, signifies whiteness of complexion]: (TA:) accord. to AHn, it signifies whiteness; syn. bayaADN. (M.) [See also A=damu.]

A^adamapN * : see A^udomapN. ― -b2- huwa A^adamapu A^aholihi, (M, K,) and ↓ A^udomatuhumo, (M,) or ↓ A^adomatuhumo, (K,) and ↓ A^udomuhumo, (M,) or ↓ A^adomuhumo, and ↓ A_idaAmuhumo, (K,) (tropical:) He is the pattern, exemplar, example, or object of imitation, of his people, or family, by means of whom they are known: (M, K:) so says IAar. (M.) And jaEalotu fulaAnFA A^adamapa A^aholiY (tropical:) I made such a one to be the pattern, exemplar, example, or object of imitation, of my people, or family. (T, S.) And huwa A^adamapN lifulaAnK, and ↓ A^udomapN, (tropical:) He is a pattern, &c., to such a one. (Fr, TA.) And fulaAnN A^adamapu baniY fulaAnK (tropical:) Such a one is he who makes people to know the sons of such a one. (T.) And huwa A^adamapu qawomihi (tropical:) He is the chief, and provost, of his people. (A, TA.) And qawomihi ↓ fulaAnN A_idaAmu, and banY A^abiyhi ↓ A^udomu, (tropical:) Such a one is the aider, and manager of the affairs, and the support, and right orderer of the affairs, of his people, and of the sons of his father.
