(A, TA.) -A2- [The inner skin; the cutis, or derma;] the interior of the skin, which is next to the flesh; (S, M, K;) the exterior thereof being called the ba$arap: (S:) or (as some say, M) the exterior thereof, upon which is the hair; the interior thereof being called the ba$arap: (M, K:) and ↓ A^adamN may be its pl.; [or rather, a coll. gen. n.;] or, accord. to Sb, it is a quasi-pl. n. (M.) ― -b2- Accord. to some, (M,) What appears of the skin of the head. (M, K. [See ba$arapN.]) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) The interior of the earth or ground; (M, K;) the surface thereof being called its A^adiym: (M, TA:) or, as some say, its surface. (TA.)

A^adamiY~N *
A seller of [A^adam, or] skins, or hides: (TA:) and ↓ A^ad~aAmN signifies the same; and particularly a seller of goats' skins. (Golius, from the larger work entitled Mirkát el-Loghah.)
A^udomAanN * and A^udomaAnapN: see A=damu.

A_idaAmN A^dAm A_dAm AdAm (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and ↓ A^udomN (the same except the K) [Seasoning, or condiment, for bread; and any savoury food;] what is used for seasoniny (maA yuw^otadamu bihi, T, S, M, * Mgh, Msb, K) with bread; (T, TA;) that which renders bread pleasant and good and savoury; (IAmb, Mgh;) whether fluid or not fluid; (Mgh, Msb;) SibogN and SibaAgN being peculiarly applied to that which is fluid: (Mgh:) or A^udomN is anything that is eaten with bread: (TA:) the pl. [of mult.] of A_idaAmN is A^udumN, (Mgh, Msb,) and, by contraction, A^udomN, which is also used as the sing., (Msb,) and [pl. of pauc.] A=dimapN (M, K) and A=daAmN; (K;) or this last is pl. of A^udomN. (M, Mgh, Msb, TA.) It is said in a trad., niEoma AlA_idaAmu Alxal~u [Excellent, or most excel-lent, is the seasoning, vinegar!]. (T, TA.) And in another, say~idu A=daAmi Ald~unoyaA waAlA=xirapi All~aHomu [The prince of the seasonings of the present world and of the world to come is flesh-meat]. (TA.) ― -b2- huwa A_idaAmu A^aholihi, and A_idaAmu qawomihi: see A^adamapN. ― -b3- Anything conforming, or conformable; agreeing, or agreeable; suiting, or suitable. (M, K.) [Used also as a pl.: thus,] 'Ádiyeh Ed-Dubeyreeyeh says,
kaAnuwA limano xaAlaTahumo A_idaAmaA
[They were, to those who mixed with them in social intercourse, conformable, or agreeable.] (M.)

A^adiymN *
i. q. ↓ maA^oduwmN [Seasoned]: (T:) or TaEaAmN ↓ maA^oduwmN [seasoned food]; (M, K;) food in which is A_idaAm. (TA.) Hence the prov., samonukumo huriyqa fiY A^adiymikumo [Your clarified butter is poured into your seasoned food]; (T, TA;) applied to a niggardly man; (Har p. 462;) meaning, your good, or wealth, returns unto you: (TA:) or, as some say, the meaning is, into your siqaA=' [or skin]: (T, Har * ubi suprà:) and the vulgar say, fiY daqiyqikumo [into your flour]. (TA.) And the saying, samonuhumo fiY A^adiymihimo [Their clarified butter is in their seasoned food]; meaning, their good, or wealth, returns unto them. (M.) And the saying of Khadeejeh to the Prophet, A_in~aka latakosibu wa tuToEimu AlmaA^oduwma ↓ AlmaEoduwma (M, TA) Verily thou gainest what is denied to others, or makest others to gain what they have not, of the things they want, or makest the poor to gain, (TA in art. Edm,) and givest to eat food in which is A_idaAm. (TA in the present art.) [Hence also,] A^aToEamotuka ↓ maA^oduwmiY (M, K) meaning A^atayotuka biEu*oriY [I gave thee my excuse; or, perhaps, my virginity; see Eu*orapN]: (K:) [or,] as some say, the meaning is, my good manners: said by the wife of Dureyd Ibn-Es-Simmeh, on the occasion of his divorcing her. (M, TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (Ham p. 205, Mgh,) Tanned skin or hide; leather: (M, Ham, Mgh, Msb:) or skin, or hide, (M, K,) in whatever state it be: (M:) or red skin or hide: (M, K:) or skin, or hide, in the state after that in which it is termed A^afiyqN; that is, when it is complete [in its tanning] and has become red: (M:) or the exterior of the skin of anything: (T:) pl. [of pauc.] A=dimapN (S, M, K) and A=daAmN and [of mult.] A^udumN, (M, K,) the last from Lh, and [says ISd] I hold that he who says rusolN says A^udomN, (M,) and ↓ A^adamN, (T, S, Msb, K,) or this is a quasi-pl. n., (Sb, M, Mgh,) [often used as a gen. n.,] of which A=daAmN may be pl. (M.) ― -b3- Aiboni A^adiymK and Aibonu A^adiymayoni and Aibonu valaAvapi A=dimapK: see AibonN in art. bnY. One says, A_in~amaA yuEaAtabu AlA^adiymu *uw Alba$arapi [lit.] Only the hide that has the exterior part, upon which the hair grows, is put again into the tan: (T:) a prov.; (TA;) meaning, only he is disciplined, or
reproved, who is an object of hope, and in whom is full intelligence, and strength; (T, TA, and AHn in TA, art. b$r [where, however, in the TA, duwna is erroneously put for *w];) and only he is disputed with in whom is place for dispute. (TA.) ― -b4- A^adiymu AlHarobi is used metaphorically for A^adiymu A^aholi AlHarobi (tropical:) [The skin of the warriors, or of the people engaged in war or fight]. (M.) ― -b5- fulaAnN SaHiyHu AlA^adiymi [lit. Such a one is sound of skin] means (tropical:) such a one is sound in respect of origin, and of honour, or reputation. (Har p. 135.) You say also, fulaAnN bariYo'u AlA^adiymi mim~aA luTixa bihi [meaning (tropical:) Such a one is clear in honour, or reputation, of that with which he has been aspersed]. (M, * TA.) And ↓ maz~aqa A^adamiY (tropical:) He rent my honour, or reputation. (Har ubi suprà.) ― -b6- A^adiymN also signifies (tropical:) The surface of the earth or ground: (S, M:) [see also A^adamapN, last sentence:] or what appears thereof, (K,) and of the sky. (M, K.) ― -b7- And (tropical:) The first part of the period called AlD~uHaY. (M, K, TA.) You say, jiy^otuka A^adiyma AlD~uHaY (tropical:) I came to thee in the first part of the DHY; (Lh, M;) app. meaning, Einoda A@rotifaAEi AlD~uHaY [when the morning was becoming advanced; when the sun was becoming high]. (M.) ― -b8- And (tropical:) The whiteness of day: (IAar, M, K, TA:) and (tropical:) the darkness of night: (IAar, M, TA:) or (tropical:) the whole of the day, (M, A, K, TA,) and of the night. (A, TA.) You say, Zal~a A^adiyma Aln~ahaAri SaAy^imFA waA^adiyma All~ayoli qaAy^imFA (tropical:) He continued the whole of the day fasting, and the whole of the night standing [in prayer, &c.]. (A, TA.)
A^ad~aAmN * : see A^adamiY~N.

A=damu A=dm
Of the colour termed A^udomapN: pl. A^udomN and ↓ A^udomaAnN; (S, M, K;) the latter like HumoraAnN as a pl. of A^aHomaru: (M:) the fem. sing. is A^adomaA='u and ↓ A^udomaAnapN; (S M, K;) the latter anomalous; (K;) occurring in poetry, but disapproved (S, M) by As; (S;) said by Aboo-'Alee to be like xumoSaAnapN; (M;) and the fem. pl. is A^udomN: (S, M, K:) applied to a camel, of a colour intermixed, or tinged, with blackness, or with whiteness; or of a clear white; (M, K;) or, as some say, intensely white; (TA;) or white, and black in the eyeballs; (S;) or white; (As, T;) and so applied to a gazelle: (T:) or, applied to a gazelle, of a colour intermixed, or tinged, with whiteness; (M, K;) Lth, however, says that A^adomaA='u is applied to a female gazelle, but he had not heard A=damu applied to the male gazelle; (TA;) and As says, (S,) A^udomN applied to gazelles signifies white, having upon them streaks in which is a dust-colour, (S, M,) inhabiting the mountains, and of the colour of the mountains; (S;) if of a pure white colour, they are termed A=raAmN: (T, TA:) or, accord. to ISk, white in the bellies, tawny in the backs, and having the colour of the bellies and of the backs divided by two streaks of the colour of musk; and in like manner explained by IAar: (T:) applied to a human being, A=damu signifies tawny; or dark-complexioned; syn. A^asomaru; (S, M, K;) or, thus applied, it signifies A^Homaru All~awoni [which, in this case, means white of complexion]; (TA;) and the pl. is A^udomiAnN. (S.) The Arabs say, qurayo$u AlA_ibili A^udomuhaA waSuhobuhaA, meaning The best of camels are those of them which are A^udom and those of them which are Suhob; [see A^aSohabu;] like as Kureysh are the best of men. (M.) ― -b2- Also [Adam,] the father of mankind; (S, M, K;) and likewise ↓ A^adamu; but this is extr.: (K:) there are various opinions respecting its derivation; but [these it is unnecessary to mention, for] the truth is that it is a foreign word, [i. e. Hebrew,] of the measure faAEalu, like A=zaru: (MF:) and [therefore] its pl. is A^awaAdimu. (S, M, K.)
A=damiY~N A=dmY A=dmy [Of, or relating to, Adam: and hence, human: and a human being:] a rel. n. from A=damu. (TA.)

A_iydaAmapN AydAmh AydAmp (assumed tropical:) Level, hard, but not rugged, ground: (As:) or hard ground without stones; (K;) from A^adiymN signifying the “surface” of the earth or ground: (TA:) or ground somewhat elevated; not much so; only found in plains, and producing vegetation, which, however, is disapproved, because its situation is rugged, and little water remains in it: (ISh:) pl. A^ayaAdiymu, (As, Esh-Sheybánee, IB, K,) which J erroneously says has no sing.: (K:) for he says, [in the S,] A^ayaAdiymu signifies hard and elevated tracts (mutuwn) of ground; and has no sing. (TA.)

muw^odamN * , as in an ex. cited above, (see 1,) Made an object of love; (T, S;) a proper object of love. (T.) -A2- rajulN muw^odamN mubo$arN (tropical:) A man who is skilful, and experienced in affairs, (M, K,) who combines [qualities like] softness of the interior skin and roughness of the exterior skin: (T, S, M, K:) or who combines softness and hardness, or gentleness and force, with knowledge of affairs: (T:) or who combines such qualities that he is suited to hardship and to easiness of circumstances: (As, T:) or, accord. to IAar, having a thick and good skin: (M:) or beloved: (TA:) the fem. is with p: (M, K:) you say, AimoraA^apN muw^odamapN mubo$arapN, meaning (tropical:) a woman goodly in her aspect and faultless in her intrinsic qualities: and sometimes the former epithet, with and without p, as applied to a woman and to a man respectively, is put after the latter. (M.) See also art. b$r.
maA^oduwmN * : see A^adiymN, in four places.

4 A=dY A=dY A=dy
He took his A^adaApN [q. v.]; (M;) he prepared himself; (M, K; [mentioned in the latter in art. AdY;]) or equipped, or accoutred, himself; or furnished, or provided himself with proper, or necessary, apparatus, equipments, or the like; (M;) or he was, or became, in a state of preparation; (Yaakoob, T, S;) lils~afari for journeying, or the journey: (Yaakoob, T, S, M, K:) part. n. muw^dK. (Yaakoob, T, S.) And ↓ tA^d~Y He took his A^adaAp, [or prepared himself, &c.,] liloA^amori for the affair: (M:) or ↓ tA=dY he prepared, furnished, equipped, or accoutred, himself for the affair; (Ibn-Buzurj, Az, TA;) from AlA^adApu: (Az, TA:) or ↓ the former of these two verbs, (so in some copies of the S and K,) or ↓ the latter of them, (so in other copies of the S and K, and in the TA,) he took his A^adaAp [or equipments, &c., i. e. he prepared himself,] for [the vicissitudes of] fortune: (S, K:) and ↓ taA=dawoA, inf. n. taA=dK, they took the apparatus, equipments, or the like, that should strengthen, or fortify, them against [the vicissitudes of] fortune &c.: (T:) [accord. to some,] Alt~aA=diY is [irregularly derived] from AlA=du, meaning “strength.” (TA.) ― -b2- He was, or became, completely armed; (T, TA;) part. n. as above; (T, S, M, Msb;) from AlA^adaApu: (T, TA:) or he was, or became, strong by means of weapons and the like; part. n. as above: (Msb:) or he was, or became, strong [in an absolute sense]; (S, K; [mentioned in the latter in art. AdY;]) said of a man; from AlA^adaApu; (S;) part. n. as above. (K.) -A2- A=dAhu is originally A^aEodaAhu; the second A [in A=, for A^aA,] being hemzeh substituted for E in the original; meaning He aided, or assisted, him: [or he avenged him:] or it may be from AlA^adaApu; meaning he made him to have, or gave him, or assigned to him, weapons, or arms. (Ham p. 387.) [In either case, it should be mentioned in the present art.; as AEdY belongs to art. Edw, and AlAdAp has for its pl. AlA^adawaAtu.] You say, A=dAhu EalaY ka*aA, aor. yuw^odiyhi, inf. n. A_iydaA='N, He strengthened him, and aided him, or assisted him, against such a thing, or to do such a thing. (S.) And A=dAhu EalaY fulaAnK, meaning A^aEodaAhu and A^aEaAnahu [He avenged him of such a one; or he aided, or assisted, him against such a one]. (M and K in art. EdY .) And mano yuw^diyniY EalaY fulaAnK Who will aid me, or assist me, against such a one? (S.) The people of El-Hijáz say, EalaY fulaAnK ↓ AsotaA^odayotuhu faA=daAniY Ealayohi, meaning AisotaEodayotuhu faA^aEodaAniY (T, S) and A^EaAnaniY (T) [I asked of him (namely the Sultá, T, or the Emeer, S) vengeance of such a one, or aid against such a one, and he avenged me of him, or aided me against him].
5 taAad~awa see 4, in two places.
6 taAaAodawa see 4, in three places.

10 AstA^dAhu Ealayohi *
i. q. AisotaEodaAhu [He asked of him aid, or assistance, against him; or vengeance of him]: (T, S, M, K: *) or he complained to him of his (another's) deed to him, in order that he might exact his (the complainant's) right, or due, from him. (TA.) See also 4, last sentence.

A^adaApN *
An instrument; a tool; an implement; a utensil: and instruments; tools; implements; utensils; apparatus; equipments; equipage; accoutrements; furniture; gear; tackling: syn. A=lapN: (T, S, M, Msb, K:) of any tradesman or craftsman; with which he performs the work of his trade or craft: and of war; A^adaApu AlHarobi signifying weapons, or arms: (Lth, T:) and for an affair [of any kind]: (M:) [applied also to the apparatus of a camel, or of a camel's saddle, &c.: (see HidojN:)] and ↓ A_idaAwapN signifies the same; (M, TA;) and ↓ A^adaAwapN: (TA:) and ↓ A^adiY~N, (S, TA,) like ganiY~N , (TA,) [in some copies of the S A=diY~N ,] signifies apparatus,
equipments, equipage, accoutrements, furniture, gear, tackling, implements, tools, or the like; syn. A^uhobapN: (S, TA:) the pl. of A^adaAhN is A^adawaAtN. (T, S, Msb, K.) You say, A^axa*a A^adaAtahu [He took his apparatus, &c.; or prepared, furnished, equipped, or accoutred, himself]; (S, M, K;) liloA^amori [for the affair], and lils~afari [for journeying, or the journey], (M,) and lild~ahori [for the vicissitudes of fortune]: (T, S, K:) and it is related on the authority of Ks, that they said A^axa*a hadaAtahu; substituting h for A^. (Lh, M). And A^xa*otu li*`lika ↓ AlA^amor A^adiy~ahu i. e. A^uhobatahu [I took for that affair its apparatus, &c.]. (S, TA.) And naHonu EalaY lilS~alaApi ↓ A^adiY~K We are in a state of preparation for prayer. (S, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, in grammar, A particle; as being a kind of auxiliary; including the article Al, the preposition, the conjunction, and the interjection; but not the adverbial noun.]
A^adiY~N * : see A^adaApN, in three places. -A2- Also A journey; or a journeying: from A=daY lils~afari. (M.)
A^adaAwapN * : see A^adaApN.

A_idaAwapN A^dAwh AdAwh AdAwp dAwY
i. q. miTharapN; (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) i. e. A small vessel [or bag] of skin, made for water, like the saTiyHap: (TA:) or, as some say, only of two skins put face to face: (M, TA:) pl. A^adaAwaY; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) originally, by rule, A^adaAy^iYu; which is changed, as in the cases of maTaAyaA and xaTaAyaA, from the measure faEaAy^ilu to the measure faEaAlaY, so that the w in A^adaAwaY is a substitute for the augmentative A in the sing., and the final alif [written Y] in A^adaAwaY is a substitute for the w in the sing. (S.) ― -b2- See also A^adaApN.

A=daY A=dY A=dy [a noun denoting the comparative and superlative degrees, irregularly formed from the verb A=daY; like as the noun A=daY in art. AdY is irregularly formed from the verb A^ad~aY in that art.]. You say, huwa A=daY $aYo'K, meaning A^aqowaAhu and A^EodaAhu [It is the strongest kind of thing, and, app., the most effectual to aid or assist, or to avenge]. (TA.) -A2- See also art. AdY.
muw^odK * part. n. of the intrans. verb A=dY [q. v.]. (T, S, M, &c.) -A2- [And act. part. n. of A=daAhu.] -A3- muwdK, without ', is from A^awodaY signifying “he perished” [&c.]. (S.)

2 A^d~Ahu * , (T, S, M, &c.,) inf. n. tA^NdiyapN (T, S, K) and A^adaA='N, (T,) or the latter is a simple subst., (S, M, Msb, K,) [and so, accord. to the Msb, is the former also, but this is a mistake,] He made it, or caused it, to reach, arrive, or come [to the appointed person or place &c.]; he brought, conveyed, or delivered, it; syn. A^awoSalahu; (M, Msb, K;) namely, a thing; (M;) as, for instance, AlA^amaAnapa A_ilaY A^holihaA [the thing committed to his trust and care, to its owner]: (Msb:) he delivered it, gave it up, or surrendered it: (T:) he payed it, or discharged it; (S, K;) namely, his debt, (S,) a bloodwit, a responsibility, and the like; (Msb in art. grm;) [and hence,] A^ad~aY maA Ealayohi [he acquitted himself of that which was incumbent on him; or payed, or discharged, what he owed]: (T:) he performed, fulfilled, or accomplished, it; namely, [for instance,] AlHaj~a [the pilgrimage]; (Msb in art. qDY;) and in like manner, AlmanaAsika [the religious rites and ceremonies of the pilgrimage]. (Jel in ii. 196, and Msb ubi suprà.) It is said in the Kur [xliv. 17], A^ano A^ad~uwA A_laY~a EibaAda A@ll~`hi, meaning Deliver ye to me [the servants of God,] the children of Israel: or, as some say, the meaning is, A^ad~uwA A_ilaY~a maA A^amarakumu A@ll~`hu bihi yaA EibaAdaA@ll~`hi [perform ye to me that which God hath commanded you to do, O servants of God]: or it may mean listen ye, or give ye ear, to me; as though the speaker said, A^ad~uwA A_ilaY~a samoEakumo; the verb being used in this sense by the Arabs. (T.) And one says, lahu ↓ tA^ad~ayotu, mino Haq~ihi, (K, TA,) and A_layohi, in the place of lahu, meaning A^ad~ayotuhu; (TA;) i. e. I payed him his due, or right. (K, TA.) And a man says, ↓ maA A^adoriY kayofa A^ataA^ad~aY [I know not how to pay]. (TA.) One says also, A^d~Y Eanohu [meaning He payed, or made satisfaction, for him]: and A^d~Y Eanohu AlxaraAja [He payed for him, or in his stead, the land-tax]. (Mgh in art. jzA^.) [Hence,] El-Akhnas says,
faA^ad~ayotu Ean~iY maA A@sotaEartu mina AlS~ibaA
wa lilomaAli EinodiYi Alyawoma raAEK wa kaAsibu
i. e. But I have put away from me [what I had borrowed, or assumed, of the folishness of youth, and amorous dalliance,] and now I am [or there is at my abode] a keeper and collector to the camels, or cattle, or property. (Ham p. 346.) ― -b2- [A^ad~aY A_ilY ka*aA is a phrase often used as meaning It brought, conducted, led, or conduced, to such a thing or state; as, for instance, crime to punishment or to ignominy.]
4 A=dY A=dY A=dy , intrans. and trans.: see art. Adw.

5 tA^d~Y A_ilayohi Alxabaru *
The information, or news, reached him. (S.) -A2- See also 2, in two places.

10 AstA^dAhu maAlFA *
He desired, or sought, to obtain from him property, or sued, or prosecuted, him for it, or demanded it of him, (S, K,) and extracted it, (S,) or took it, or received it, (K,) from him. (S, K.) -A2- See also art. Adw.

A^adaA='N * a subst. from 2 [signifying The act of making, or causing, to reach, arrive, or come to the appointed person or place &c.; of bringing, conveying, or delivering; of giving up, or surrendering; payment, or discharge, of a debt &c.; the act of acquitting oneself of that which is incumbent on him; performance, fulfilment, or accomplishment]. (S, M, Msb, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] huwa Hasanu AlA^adaA='i He has a good manner of pronouncing, or uttering, the letters. (TA.) ― -b3- A^adaA='N as a term of the law signifies The performance of an act of religious service [such as prayer &c.] at the appointed time: opposed to qaDaA='N, performance at a time other than that which is appointed. (Msb and TA in art. qDY.)
A^adiY~N * : see art. Adw.

A=daY A=dY A=dy [a noun denoting the comparative and superlative degrees, irregularly formed from the verb A^ad~Y; like as the noun A=daY mentioned in art. Adw is irregularly formed from the verb A=daY]. You say, huwa A=daY lilA^amaAnpi [He is more, or better, disposed to deliver, give up, or surrender, the thing committed to his trust and care] (T, S, M, K) minoka [than thou], (S,) or mino gayorihi [than another than he]. (M, * K.) [Az says,] the vulgar say, A^ad~aY liloA^amaAnapi; but this is incorrect, and not allowable; and I have not known any one of the grammarians allow A=daY, because A^afoEal denoting wonder [and the comparative and superlative degrees] is not formed but from the triliteral [verb], and one does not say, A^adaY in the sense of A^ad~aY: the proper phrase is A^aHosanu A^adaA='F. (T.) -A2- See also art. Adw.
muw^odK * : see art. Adw.

A_i*o * a word denoting past time: (Lth, T, S, M, L, Mughnee, K:) it is a noun, (S, L, Mughnee, K,) indecl., with its last letter quiescent; and properly is prefixed to a proposition; (S, L, K;) as in jiy^otuka A_i*o qaAma zaydN [I came to thee when Zeyd stood], and A_i*o zayodN qaAy^imN and A_i*o zayodN yquwmu [When Zeyd was standing]. (S, L.) The proposition to which it is prefixed is either nominal, as in [the words of the Kur viii. 26,] waA@*okuruwA A_i*o A^anotumo qaliylN [And remember ye when ye were few]; or verbal, having the verb in the pret. as to the letter and as to the meaning, as in [the Kur ii. 28, &c.,] waA_i*o qaAla rab~uka lilomalaAy^ikapi [And when thy Lord said unto the angels]; or verbal with the verb in the pret. as to the meaning but not as to the letter, as in [the Kur ii. 121,] wa A_i*o yarofaEu A_ibor`hiymu AlqawaAEida [And when Abraham was rearing the foundations]; all three of which kinds are comprised in the Kur where it is said, [ix. 40,] A_il~aA tanoSuruwhu faqado naSarahu A@ll~`hu A_i*o A^axorajahu A@l~a*iyna kafaruwA vaAniYa A@vonayoni A_i*o humaA fiY AlgaAri A_i*o yaquwlu liSaAHibihi laA taHzano A_in~a A@ll~`ha maEanaA [If ye will not aid him, verily God aided him, when those who disbelieved expelled him, being the second of two, when they two were in the cave, when he was saying to his companion, Grieve not thou, for God is with us]. (Mughnee.) But sometimes one half of the proposition is suppressed, as in A_i*o *aAka, [also written A_i*~aAka,] meaning A_i*o *aAka ka*`lika [When that was so], or A_i*o *aAka kaAy^inN [When that was, i. e. then, at that time]. (Mughnee.) And sometimes the whole of the proposition is suppressed, (M, Mughnee,) as being known, (Mughnee,) and tenween is substituted for it; the * receiving kesreh because of the occurrence of two quiescent letters together, (M, Mughnee,) namely the * and the tenween, (M,) and thus one says, yawomay^i*K; the kesreh of the * not being, as Akh holds it to be, the kesreh of declension, although A* here occupies the place of a noun governed in the gen. case by another prefixed to it, (M, Mughnee,) for it still requires a proposition
to be understood after it, (Mughnee,) and is held to be indecl. (M, Mughnee) by general consent, like kamo and mano, (M,) as being composed of two letters. (Mughnee.) [J says,] when A_i*o is not prefixed to a proposition, it has tenween: (S:) and hence Aboo-Dhu-eyb says, (S, M,)
nahayotuka Eano TilaAbika A^um~a EamorKw
biEaAfiyapK waA^anota A_i*K SaHiyHu
[I forbade thy suing Umm-'Amr in health, thou being then sound]; (S, M, L, Mughnee, TA; [but in two copies of the S, for biEaAfiyapK, I find biEaAqibapK; and in the L it is without any point;]) in which [J says] the poet means Hiynay^i*K, like as one says yawomay^*K and layolatay^i*K: (S:) and Fr says that some of the Arabs say, kaAna ka*aA w ka*aA wahuwa A_i*K SabiY~N, meaning huwa A_i*o *aAka SabiY~N [Such and such things were, he being then a boy]. (T.) A_i*iY also occurs for A* [app. A_i*K, but whether this or A_i*o is not clear in the MS. from which I take this]. (M.) When A_i*K is adjoined to nouns signifying times, the Arabs join it therewith in writing, in certain instances: namely Hiynay^i*K [At that time, or then], and yawomay^i*K [In, or on, or at, that day], and layolatay^i*K [In, or on, or at, that night], and gadaAtay^i*K [In, or on, that morning], and Ea$iy~atay^i*K [In, or on, that evening], and saAEatay^i*K [In that hour: or at that time; then], and EaAmay^i*K [In that year], [and waqotay^i*K At that time; then]; but they did not say AlA=nay^i*K, because AlA=na denotes the nearest present time, except in the dial. of Hudheyl, in which it has been found to occur. (T.) When it is followed by a verb, or by a noun not having the article Al prefixed to it, or [rather] by any movent letter, the * of A_i*o is quieseent; but when it is followed by a noun with Al, [or by any A@,] the * is mejroorah, as in the saying,
A_i*i Alqawomu kaAnuwA naAziliyna bikaAZimaho
[When the people, or company of men, were alighting, or taking up their abode, at Kádhimeh]. (T.) ― -b2- In general, (Mughnee, K,) it is an adverbial noun denoting past time, (M, Mughnee, K,) when it is a noun denoting such time, (Mughnee, K,) as in wa A_i*o qaAla rab~uka lilomalaAy^ikapi [explained above], (M,) and in faqado naSarahu A@ll~`hu A_i*o A^axorajahu A@l~a*iyna kafaruwA [also explained above, and in other instances already mentioned]: (Mughnee, K:) in the former of which instances, AO says that it is redundant; (M, Mughnee;) but Aboo-Is-hák says that this is a bold assertion of his; (M;) [and IHsh says,] this assertion is of no account, and so is that of him who says that it here denotes certainty, like qado: (Mughnee:) [J holds the opinion of AO on this point; for he says,] A_i*o is sometimes redundant, like A_i*aA, as in the saying in the Kur [ii. 48], waA_i*o waAEadonaA muwsaY, meaning wawaAEadonaA muwsaY [And We appointed a time with Moses; but instances of this kind are most probably elliptical: see the next sentence]. (S.) As a noun denoting past time, it is [said to be] also an objective complement of a verb, as in [the Kur vii. 84,] waA@*okuruwA A_i*o kunotumo qaliylAF [And remember ye when ye were few]: (Mughnee, K:) and generally in the commencements of narratives in the Kur, it may be an objective complement of A^u*okuro understood, as in wa A_i*o qaAla rab~uka lilomalaAy^ikapi [before cited], and the like. (Mughnee: but see the third of the sentences here following.) As such, it is [said to be] also a substitute for the objective complement of a verb, as in [the Kur xix. 16,] wa A@*okuro fiY A@lokitaAbi maroyama A_i*i A@notaba*ato [And mention thou, or remember thou, in the Scripture, Mary, the time when she withdrew aside], where A* is a substitute of implication for mrym. (Mughnee, K: but see the second of the sentences here following.) As such, it also has prefixed to it a noun of time, of such a kind that it is without need thereof, as in yawomay^i*K, or not of such a kind that it is without need thereof, as in [the Kur iii. 6,] baEoda A_i*o hadayotanaA [After the time when Thou hast directed us aright]. (Mughnee, K.) And it is generally asserted, that it never occurs otherwise than as an adverbial noun, or as having a noun prefixed to it; that in the like of waA@*okuruwA A_i*o kunotumo qaliylAF, it is an adverbial noun relating to an objective complement suppressed, i. e. wa A@*okuruwA niEomapa A@ll~`hi Ealayokumo A_i*o kunotumo qaliylAF [And remember ye the grace of God towards you when ye were few]; and in the like of A_i*i A@notaba*ato, that it is an adverbial noun relating to a suppressed prefixed noun to [that which becomes by the suppression] the objective complement of a verb, i. e. [in this instance] wa A@*okuro qiS~apa maroyama [And mention thou, or remember thou, the case of Mary]: and this assertion is strengthened by the express mention of the [proper] objective complement in [the Kur iii. 98,] wa A@*okurwA niEomapa A@ll~`hi Ealayokumo A_i*o kunotumo A^aEodaA='F [And remember ye the grace of God towards you when ye were enemies]. (Mughnee.) ― -b3- Also, (Mughnee, K,) accord. to some, (T, Mughnee,) it is used (T, Mughnee, K) as a noun (Mughnee, K) to indicate future time, (T, Mughnee, K,) and A_i*aA is said to denote past time, (T,) [i. e.] each of these occurs in the place of the other; (TA;) the former being used to indicate future time in the Kur [xxxiv. 50], where it is said, walawo taraY A_i*o faziEuwA [And couldst thou see the time when they shall be terrified], meaning the day of resurrection; this usage being allowable, says Fr, only because the proposition is like one expressing a positive fact, since there is no doubt of the coming of that day; (T;) and in [the Kur xcix. 4,] yawomay^i*K tuHad~ivu A^axobaArahaA [On that day, she (the earth) shall tell her tidings]; (Mughnee, K;) this being generally regarded as similar to the expression of a future event which must necessarily happen as though it had already happened; but it may be urged in favour of those who hold a different opinion that it is said in the Kur [xl. 72 and 73], fasawofa yaEolamuwna A_i*i AlA^aglaAlu fiY A^aEonaAqihimo [They shall hereafter know, when the collars shall be on their necks]; for yElmwn is a future as to the letter and the meaning because of its having swf conjoined with it, and it governs A*, which is therefore in the place of A_i*aA. (Mughnee.) ― -b4- It also indicates a cause, as in [the Kur xliii. 38,] lano yanofaEakumu A@loyawoma A_i*o Zalamotumo [It will not profit you this day, since, or because, ye have acted wrongfully], (Mughnee, K,) i. e. because of your having acted wrongfully in the sublunary state of existence; (Bd, Mughnee;) but it is disputed whether it be in this instance a particle in the place of the causative l, or an adverbial noun: (Mughnee:) Aboo-'Alee seems to hold that A* Zlmtm [as meaning when ye have acted wrongfully] is a substitute for, or a kind of repetition of, Alywm; an event happening in the present world being spoken of as though it happened in the world to come because the latter immediately follows the former. (IJ, M, L, Mughnee.) You say also, AlHamodu lil~`hi A_i*o jiy^ota [Praise be to God because, or that, thou camest, or hast come]. (S in art. jyA^.) ― -b5- It is also used to denote one's experiencing the occurrence of a thing when he is in a particular state; (S, L;) or to denote a thing's happening suddenly, or unexpectedly; (S, Mughnee, K;) like A_i*aA; (S;) and in this case is only followed by a verb expressing an event as a positive fact, (S, L,) and occurs after bayonaA and bayonamaA; (Mughnee, K;) as [in exs. voce bayona; and] in bayonamaA A^anaA ka*aA A_i*o jaA='a zayodN [While I was thus, or in this state, lo, or behold, or there, or then, at that time, (accord. to different authorities, as will be seen below,) Zeyd came]; (S, L;) and as in the saying of a poet,
Aisotaqodiri A@ll~`ha xayorAF waA@roDayan~a bihi
fabayonamaAA@loEusoru A_i* daArato mayaAsiyru
[Beg thou God to appoint for thee good, and do thou be content therewith; for while there has been difficulty, lo, easy circumstances have come about]: (Mughnee, K: *) but it is disputed whether it be [in this case] an adverbial noun of place, (Mughnee, K,) as Zj and AHei hold; (TA;) or of time, (Mughnee, K,) as Mbr holds; (TA;) or a particle denoting the sudden, or unexpected, occurrence of a thing, (Mughnee, K,) as IB and Ibn-Málik hold; (TA;) or a corroborative, i. e. [grammatically] redundant, particle, (Mughnee, K,) an opinion which Ibn-Ya'eesh holds, and to which Er-Radee inclines. (TA.) ― -b6- It is also a conditional particle, but only used as such coupled with mA, (S, L, Mughnee, *) and causes two aorists to assume the mejzoom form, (Mughnee,) as when you say, A_i*omaA taA^otiniY A=tika [When, or whenever, thou shalt come to me, I will come to thee], like as you say, A_ino tA^otiniY waqotFA A=tika [If thou come to me at some, or any, time, I will come to thee]; and you say also A_i*omaA A^atayota [like as you say, A_ino A^atayota, using the pret. in the sense of the future]: (S, L:) it is a particle accord. to Sb, used in the manner of the conditional A_ino; but it is an adverbial noun accord. to Mbr and Ibn-Es-Sarráj and El-Fárisee. (Mughnee.) ― -b7- [What I have translated from the S, L, K, and TA, in this art., is mostly from fSl Alhmzp of bAb Al*Al : the rest, from bAb AlAlf Allyn~p.]

A_i*aA * denotes a thing's happening suddenly, or unexpectedly; (Mughnee, K;) or one's experiencing the occurrence of a thing when he is in a particular state; (S;) like A_i*N: (S voce A_i*N:) it pertains only to nominal phrases; does not require to
be followed by a reply, or the complement of a condition; does not occur at the commencement of a sentence; and signifies the present time, (Mughnee, K,) not the future; (Mughnee;) as in xarajotu faA_i*aA AlA^asadu bAlbaAbi [I went forth, and lo, or behold, or there, or then, at that present time, (accord. to different authorities, as will be seen below,) the lion was at the door]; and (in the saying in the Kur [xx. 21], TA,) faA_i*aA hiYa Hay~apN tasoEaY [And lo, or behold, &c., it was a serpent running]; (Mughnee, K;) and in the saying, xarajotu faA_i*aA zayodN qaAy^imN, which means I went forth, and Zeyd presented himself to me suddenly, or unexpectedly, at the time, by standing. (S, TA.) Accord. to Akh, it is a particle, (Mughnee, K,) and his opinion is rendered preferable by their saying, xarajotu faA_i*aA A_in~a ziyodAF biAlbaAbi [I went forth, and lo, or behold, verily Zeyd was at the door]; for [A*A cannot here be a noun governed in the accus. case, as] what follows A_in~a, which is with kesr, does not govern what precedes it: (Mughnee:) accord. to Mbr, it is an adverbial noun of place: accord. to Zj, an adverbial noun of time. (Mughnee, K.) Ibn-Málik adopts the first of these opinions; Ibn-'Osfoor, the second; (Mughnee;) and so El-Fenjedeehee; (TA;) and Z, the third; and he asserts that its governing word is a verb understood, derived from AlmufaAjaA^apu; [agreeably with the explanation cited above from the S;] but others hold that the word which governs it in the accus. case is the enunciative, which is either expressed, as in xarajotu faA_i*aA zayodN jaAlisN [I went forth, and there, in that place, or then, at that time, Zeyd was sitting], or meant to be understood, as in faA_i*aA AlA^asadu, i. e. HaADirN [And there, or then, the lion was present]; or if it be supposed to be [itself] the enunciative, its governing word is musotaqir~u or Aisotaqar~a [understood]: and in the last of the phrases here mentioned, it may be an enunciative accord. to the opinion of Mbr, the meaning being fabiA@loHaADirapi AlA^asadu [And among the things present was the lion]; but not accord. to the opinion of Zj, because a noun signifying time cannot be the enunciative of one signifying a corporeal thing; nor accord to the opinion of Akh, because a particle cannot be used to denote the enunciative of such a thing; or, as signifying time, it may be the enunciative of such a thing if we suppose a prefixed noun to be suppressed, the meaning of faA_i*aA AlA^asadu being faA_i*Aa HuDuwru AlA^asadi [And then was the presence of the lion]. (Mughnee.) You may say either xarajotu faA_i*aA zayodN jaAlisN or jaAlisAF [I went forth, and lo, or behold, &c., Zeyd was sitting or Zeyd was there sitting], with the nom. as an enunciative and with the accus. as a denotative of state. (Mughnee.) The Arabs said, qado kunotu A^aZun~u A^an~a AlEaqoraba A^a$ad~u lasoEapF mina Alz~unobuwri faA_i*Aa huwa hiY [I used to think that the scorpion was more vehement in stinging than the hornet, and lo, he is (as vehement as) she], and also, faA_i*Aa huwa A_iy~aAhaA, which Sb disallowed, in contending with Ks, who allowed it, and appealed for confirmation thereof to certain Arabs, whose judgment was pronounced in his favour; but it is said that they were bribed to give this judgment, or that they knew the place which Ks held in the estimation of Er-Rasheed; and if the latter expression be of established authority, it is irregular and unchaste. (Mughnee.) ― -b2- It also denotes the complement of a condition, like fa, (S, Msb,) with which it is in this case syn., (Msb,) as in the words of the Kur [xxx. 35], waA_ino tuSibohumo say~iy^apN bimaA qad~amato A^ayodiyhimo A_i*aA humu yaqonaTuwn [And if an evil befall them for that which their hands have sent before, (i. e. for sins which they have committed,) then they despair]. (S, Msb.) ― -b3- It is also an adverbial noun denoting future time, (S, Msb, Mughnee, K, *) and implying the meaning of a condition, (Msb, Mughnee,) and this is generally the case when it is not used in the manner first explained above. (Mughnee.) In this case it is not used otherwise than as prefixed to a proposition, (S, Mughnee,) which is always verbal, as in the words of the Kur [xxx. 24], vum~a A_i*aA daEaAkuma daEowapF mina AlA^aroDi A_*aA A^anotumo taxorujuwna [Then, when He shall call you, or when He calleth you, (for, as in Arabic, so in English, a verb which is properly present is often tropically future,) with a single call from out the earth, lo, or behold, or then, ye shall come forth], in which occur both the usages of A*A here mentioned; (Mughnee;) and in the phrase, A_i*aA jiy^ota A^akoramotuka [When thou shalt come, I will treat thee with honour]; (Msb;) and in the phrase, A^ajiyow^uka A_i*aA A@Homar~aAlbusoru [I will come to thee when the fullgrown unripe dates shall become red], and A_i*aA qadima fulaAnN [when such a one shall arrive], which shows it to be a noun because this is equivalent to yawoma yaqodamu fulaAnN [on the day when such a one shall arrive]: (S:) or in the phrase qumo A_i*aA A@Homar~a Albusoru [and in many other cases] it denotes time divested of any accessory idea, the meaning being [Arise thou] at the time of the full-grown unripe dates' becoming red: and so in the saying of EshSháfi'ee, If a man were to say, A^anoti TaAliqN A_i*aA lamo A^uTal~iqoki, or mataY lm ATl~qk, [Thou art divorced when I do not divorce thee,] and then be silent for a time sufficient for the divorce to be pronounced therein, she would be divorced; but should he make it dependent upon a thing in the future, the divorce would be delayed to that time, as if he said, A*A AHmr~ Albsr [using it in the sense first assigned to this phrase above]. (Msb.) The verb after it is in most cases a pret.: in other cases, an aor.: both occur in the saying of Aboo-Dhu-eyb,
wa Aln~afosu raAgibapN A_i*aA rag~abotahaA
waA_i*aA turad~u A_ilaY qaliylK taqonaEu
[And the soul is desirous when thou makest it desirous; and when thou reducest it, or restrictest it, to little, it is content]. (Mughnee.) When it is immediately followed by a noun, as in [the phrase in the Kur lxxxiv. 1,] A_*aA A@ls~amaA='u A@no$aq~ato, the noun is an agent with a verb suppressed, explained by what follows it; contr. to the opinion of Akh; (Mughnee;) the complete phrase being A_i*aA A@no$aq~ati Als~amaA='u A@no$aq~ato [When the heaven shall be cleft, (when) it shall be cleft]; and in like manner, A_ino, as in the saying, in the Kur [ix. 6], wa A_ino A^aHadN mina Almu$orikiyna A@sotajaAraka. (I 'Akp. 123.) And in the saying of the poet,
A_i*aA baAhiliY~N taHotahu HanoZaliy~apN
lahu waladN minohaA fa*aAka Almudar~aEu
kaAna is meant to be understood after A*A [so that the meaning is, When a Báhilee (a man of the tribe of Báhileh) has, or shall have, as his wife a Handhaleeyeh (a woman of the tribe of Handhaleh, who were renowned for generosity), he having offspring from her, that (offspring) is, or will be, the mail-clad]. (Mughnee.) ― -b4- Sometimes it denotes past time, (Mughnee, K,) like as A_i*o sometimes denotes future time, (Mughnee,) as in [the saying in the Kur lxii. 11,] wa A_i*aA raA^awoA tijaArapF A^awo lahowAF A@nofaD~uwA A_ilayohaA [And when they saw merchandise or sport, they dispersed themselves to it]. (Mughnee, K.) [Thus] it occurs in the place of A_i*o, like as A_i*o occurs in the place of A_i*aA. (TA.) ― -b5- And sometimes it denotes the present time; and this is after an oath, as in [the phrase in the Kur xcii. 1,] waAll~ayoli A_i*aA yago$aY [By the night when it covereth with its darkness]. (Mughnee, K.) ― -b6- It also occurs in the sense of the conditional A_ino, as in the saying, A^ukorimuka A_i*aA A^akoramotaniY, meaning A_ino A^akoramotaniY [I will treat thee with honour if thou treat me with honour]: (T:) [for] what is possible is made dependent upon it as well as what is known to be certain, as in the phrases, A_i*aA jaA='a zayodN [If Zeyd come] and A_i*aA jaA='a raA^osu Al$~ahori [When the beginning of the month shall come]; or, accord. to Th, there is a difference between A_i*aA and A_ino; (Msb;) the latter being held by him to denote what is possible, and the former to denote what is ascertained; so that one says, A_ino jaA='a zayodN and A_*aA jaA='a raA^osu Al$~ahri. (Msb in art. An.) ― -b7- When a verb in the first person sing. of the pret. is explained by another verb after it immediately preceded by A_i*aA, [taquwlu is understood before the former verb, and therefore] the latter verb must be in the second pers. sing., as in lujotuhu A_i*aA A^adarotahu fiY fyika [meaning Thou sayest (of a thing) lujotuhu when, or if, thou hast turned it about in thy mouth]. (MF in art. lwj. See also A^aYo; last sentence but one.) ― -b8- It is sometimes redundant, like as A_i*o is sometimes [accord. to some], as in the saying of 'Abd-Menáf Ibn-Riba El-Hudhalee,
Hat~aY A_i*aA A^asolakuwhum fiY qutaAy^idapK
$al~aA kamaA taTorudu Aljam~aAlapu Al$~urudaA
[Until they made them to pass along Kutáīdeh, (here meaning a certain mountain-road so named, S in art. qtd,) urging on, like as the owners, or attendants, of camels drive those that take fright and run away]; for it is the end of the poem: or he may have abstained from mentioning the enunciative because of its being known to the hearer. (S.) When A_i*aA is preceded by Hat~aY, [as in this instance,] it is generally held that A*A is not
governed by Ht~Y in the gen. case, but is still an adverbial noun, Ht~Y being an inceptive particle without government. (Mughnee.) ― -b9- As to what it is that governs A_i*aA in the accus. case, there are two opinions; that it is its conditional proposition; or a verb, or the like, in the complement thereof: (Mughnee, K:) the former is the opinion of the critical judges; so that it is in the predicament of mataY and HayovumaA and A^ay~aAna. (Mughnee.) ― -b10- Sometimes it is used so as not to denote a condition, as in the words of the Kur [xlii. 35], waA_i*aA maA gaDibuwA hum yagfiruwna [And when, or whenever, they are angry, they forgive], in which it is an adverbial noun relating to the enunciative of the inchoative after it; for if it denoted a condition, and the nominal proposition were a complement, it would be connected by fa: and the same is the case when it is used after an oath, as in an ex. given above. (Mughnee.) ― -b11- See also what follows.

A_i*FA * , (Msb, TA, the latter as on the authority of Lth,) with tenween, (TA,) or A_i*an, (T, S, M, Msb, Mughnee, K, the first as on the authority of Lth,) written in the former manner, (TA,) or in the latter, (T,) when connected with a following proposition, (T, TA,) and in a case of pause written ↓ A_i*FA, (T, S, M, Msb, Mughnee, K, TA,) and therefore the Basrees hold that in other cases it should be written A_i*FA, (Msb,) though El-Má- zinee and Mbr hold that it should be in this case also with n, while Fr holds that it should be written with A; when it governs, and otherwise with n, in order to distinguish between it and [the adverbial noun] A_i*aA: (Mughnee:) a particle, (S, Msb, Mughnee, TA,) accord. to the general opinion; and accord. to this opinion, it is a simple word, not compounded of A_i*o and A^ano; and as being simple, it is that which renders an aor. mansoob, not A^ano suppressed and meant to be understood after it: some say that it is a noun: (Mughnee:) [but a knowledge of its meaning is necessary to the understanding of the reason given for asserting it to be a noun.] It denotes a response, or reply, corroborating a condition; (Lth, T, TA;) or compensation, or the complement of a condition; (Msb;) or a response, or reply, (Sb, S, Mughnee, K,) in every instance; (TA;) and compensation, or the complement of a condition, (Sb, S, M, Mughnee, K,) though not always: (Mughnee, TA:) and its virtual meaning is [Then; i. e., in that case; or] if the case, or affair, be as thou hast mentioned, (M, K, TA,) or as has happened: (M, TA:) [and hence,] accord. to those who say that it is a noun, the original form of the phrase A_i*ano A^ukorimaka [Then, or in that case, or if the case be so, I will treat thee with honour, said in reply to one who says “ I will come to thee,”] is A_i*aA jiy^otaniY A^ukrimuka [When thou shalt come to me, I will treat thee with honour]; then the proposition [jy^tnY] is thrown out, and tenween [or n] is substituted for it, (Mughnee,) for which reason, and to distinguish between it and [the adverbial] n, the Koofees hold that it should be written with A_i*aA, (Msb,) and A^ano [preceded by yajibu EalaY~a or the like] is suppressed and meant to be understood [as that which renders the aor. mansoob; so that when one says A_i*ano A^ukorimaka, it is as though he said A_i*aA jiy^otaniY When thou shalt come to me, it will be incumbent, or obligatory, on me to treat thee with honour]. (Mughnee.) It renders an aor. following it mansoob on certain conditions: (Mughnee, TA:) to have this effect, the aor. must have a future signification, (T, S, Mughnee, TA,) not present: (TA:) yajibu EalaY~a A^ano A^ukurimaka must commence the phrase in which the aor. occurs; (Mughnee, TA;) [or, in other words,] the aor. must not be syntactically dependent upon what precedes A*A: (TA:) and there must be nothing intervening between A*A and the aor., (T, Mughnee, TA,) unless it is a particle, (T,) or an oath, (T, Mughnee,) or the negative laA: (Mughnee:) therefore, to a person who says, “To-night I will visit thee,” (S,) or who says, “I will come to thee,” (Mughnee,) you say, A_i*ano A^ukorimaka [Then, or in that case, &c., I will treat thee with honour]; (T, S, Mughnee;) and to one who says, “I will treat thee with honour,” you say, A_i*FA A^ajiyoy^aka [Then, or if the case be so, I will come to thee]. (TA.) When the verb after A*n has the present signification, it does not govern: (S, Mughnee, TA:) therefore, to a person who says, “I love thee,” you say, A_i*ano A^aZun~uka [Then, or if the case be so, I think thee veracious]; for this is a mere reply: (Mughnee:) and to one talking to thee, A_i*FA A^aZun~uka kaA*bFA [Then I think thee to be lying]. (TA.) When it is put in a middle place, (S,) not commencing the phrase, (Mughnee,) the verb after it not being syntactically dependent upon what is before it, (S, TA,) it does not govern: (S, Mughnee, TA:) therefore, to one who says, “I will come to thee,” (Mughnee, TA,) you say, A^anaA A_i*ano A^ukorimuka [I, in that case, will treat thee with honour]: (S, Mughnee, TA:) for A*n among the words which govern verbs is likened to AlZ~an~u among those which govern nouns: (S:) and when it is put at the end, it does not govern; as when you say, A^ukroimuka [I will treat thee with honour in that case]. (S.) The saying [of the poet, or rájiz],
laA tatorukan~iY fiyhimu $aTiyraA
A_in~iY A_i*FA A^aholika A^awo A^aTiyraA
is explained by regarding it as an instance of the suppression of the enunciative of A_in~, so that the meaning is, A_in~iY lAa A^aqodiru EalaY *`lika, and then a new phrase commences [wherefore the verse means Do not thou leave me among them remote, or a stranger: verily I cannot endure that: in that case I should perish, or I should flee]. (Mughnee.) When it is immediately preceded by a conjunction such as wa or fa, the aor. may be either marfooa or mansoob. (S, Mughnee.) When a noun is introduced between it and the aor., the latter is marfooa, (T, Mughnee,) as in the saying, A_i*ano A^axuwka yukorimuka [Then, or in that case, thy brother will treat thee with honour], (T,) or A_i*FA yaA Eaboda A@ll~`hi A^ukurimuka [Then, or in that case, O ‘Abd-Allah, I will treat thee with honour]; but Ibn-’Osfoor allows the intervention of an adverbial noun [without annulling the government]; and Ibn-Bábshádh, that of the vocative, and of a prayer; and Ks and Hishám, that of a word governed by the verb; but Ks in this case prefers nasb; and Hishám, refa. (Mughnee.) When you put an oath in the place of the noun, you make the aor. mansoob, as in the saying, A_i*FA wa A@ll~`hi tanaAma [Then, or if the case be so, by God, thou wilt sleep]: but if you prefix l to the verb with the oath, you make the aor. marfooa, saying, A_*ano waA@ll~`hi latanodahum [Then, or if the case be so, by God, assuredly thou wilt regret, or repent]. (T.) When you introduce a particle between it and the aor., you make the latter either marfooa or mansoob, saying, A_i*ano laA A^ukorimuka and laA A^ukurimaka [Then, or in that case, I will not treat thee with honour]. (T.) ― -b2- Sometimes the A is rejected, and they say, *ano laA A^afuEalu [Then, (a word exactly agreeing with *ano in sound as well as in meaning,) or in that case, I will not do such a thing]. (M, K, * TA.) ― -b3- IJ relates, on the authority of Khálid, that A_i*FA is used in the dial. of Hudheyl for A_i*FA. (M.) ― -b4- A_i*ano or A_i*FA is mentioned and explained in the S and K and TA in art. A*n, and in the TA in bAb AlAlf Ally~np also.]

A=*aAru *
The sixth of the Greek [or Syrian] months [corresponding to March O. S.]. (K.) [This is not to be confounded with A=*aro or A=*uro, which is the ninth month of the Persian calendar.]

1 A^a*ina laho * (T, S, M, Msb, K) and A_ilayohi, (M, K,) aor.
Aa*ana , (T, Msb, K,) inf. n. A^a*anN, (T, S, Msb, K,) He [gave ear or] listened to it, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) or him: (T, S, M, K: *) or it signifies, (K,) or signifies also, (M,) he listened to it, or him, pleased, or being pleased. (M, K.) It is said in a trad., (T,) maA A^a*ina A@ll~`hi li$aYo'K linabiY~K yatagan~aY bAlqurA=ni (T, S) God hath not listened to anything [in a manner] like his listening [to a prophet chanting the Kur-án]. (T.) And in the Kur [lxxxiv. 2 and 5], waA^a*inato lirab~ihA And shall listen to its Lord, (M, Bd, Jel,) and obey; (Jel;) i. e., shall submit to the influence of his power as one listens to the commander and submits to him. (Bd.) And you say, A^a*ina lil~ahowi He listened and inclined to sport, or play. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence, perhaps,] A^a*ina liraAy^iHapi AlT~aEaAmi (assumed tropical:) He desired eagerly, or longed for, the food, [perceiving its odour,] (ISh, K,) and inclined to it. (ISh, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also, app.,] A^a*ina lahu fiY Al$~aY', (S, M, K,) or fiY A^amori ka*aA, (T,) or fiY ka*aA, (Msb,) aor.
Aa*ana , (T, K,) inf. n. A_i*onN, (T, S, M, K,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb,) and A^a*iynN, (K,) [as though originally signifying He gave ear to him in respect of such a thing; and then] he permitted him, allowed him, or gave him permission or leave, to do the thing, or such a thing. (M, Msb, K.) [See also A_i*onN, below.] You say, A^a*inotu liloEabodi fay Alt~ijaArapi [I gave permission, or leave, to the slave to traffic]. (Msb.) ― -b4- A^a*ina
lahu Ealayohi He took, or got, permission, or leave, for him from him. (M.) You say, Aiy*ano liY EalaY AlA^amiyri (S, TA) Take thou, or get thou, permission for me from the commander, or governor, or prince. (TA.) El-A'azz Ibn-'AbdAllah says,
wa A_in~iY A_i*aA Dan~a AlA^amiyru bA_i*onihi
Ealay AlA_i*ni mino nafosiY A_i*A $iy^otN qaAdirN
[And verily I, when the prince is niggardly of his permission, am able to take permission of myself when I will]. (TA.) And a poet says,
qulotu libaw~aAbK ladayohi daAruhaA
tiy^o*ano faA_in~iY Hayow^uhaA wajaAruhaA
[I said to a door-keeper, near by whom was her house, take thou, or get thou, permission for me to enter, for I am her husband's father, and her neighbour]: meaning, says Aboo-Jaafar, litaA^o*ano; for the suppression of the l is allowable in poetry, and the pronunciation with kesr to the t is accord. to the dial. of him who says A^anota tiEolamu. (S.) ― -b5- A^a*ina biAl$~aY'i, (S, * M, Msb, K,) aor.
Aa*ana , (S, M, K,) inf. n. A_i*onN and A^a*anN and A^a*aAnN and A^a*aAnapN, (M, K,) He knew the thing; knew of it; had knowledge of it; became informed, or apprized, of it. (S, M, Msb, K.) It is said in the Kur [ii. 279], faA^o*anuwA biHarobK mina A@ll~`hi warasuwlihi (S, M, K) Then be ye informed, or apprized, of war [that shall come upon you] from God and his apostle: (M, K:) or then be ye sure, or assured, &c. (T.) [See also A_i*onN, below.] -A2- A^a*anahu, (T, S, M, K,) inf. n. A^a*onN, (T,) He hit, or hurt, his ear; (T, S, M, K;) or struck his ear; (so in some copies of the S;) and ↓ A=*anahu signifies the same, (M, K,) inf. n. A_iy*aAnN. (TA.) [See also 2.] ― -b2- A^u*ina [as though originally signifying He had his ear hit or hurt;] he complained, or had a complaint, of his ear; (K;) said of a man. (TA.)

2 A^*~nhu * , (S, M, K,) inf. n. taA^o*iynN, (K,) He wrung, or twisted, (Earaka,) his (a boy's, S) ear: (S, K:) or he struck, (Daraba, TA,) or struck with his finger, or fillipped, (naqara, M, TA,) his ear. (M, TA.) [See also A^a*anahu.] They say, (in a prov., TA in art. jwz,) likul~i jaAbihK jawozapN vum~a yuw^o*~anu, (M, TA,) i. e. For every one that comes to water is a single watering for his family and his cattle; then his ear is struck, to apprize him that he has nothing more to receive from them: (TA in the present art., and the like is said in the same in art. jwz:) or, (assumed tropical:) then he is repelled from the water: (TA in art. jwz:) [for A^*~nhu signifies also] ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) He repelled him, (IAar, T, M, K,) namely, a man, (IAar, T, M,) from drinking, (K,) and did not give him to drink. (M, K.) You say also, A^a*~inuwA Ean~iY A^uwalahaA, [in which the pronoun appears, from the context, to relate to camels,] (assumed tropical:) Send ye away from me the first ones of them. (En-Nadr, T.) -A2- A^*~n Aln~aEola, (inf. n. as above, S,) He put to the sandal what is termed A^u*unN, q. v. infrà: (S, M, K:) and in like manner one says with respect to other things. (S, K.) -A3- A^*~n, (M, K,) inf. n. as above, (K,) also signifies He made known, or notified, a thing (bi$aYo'K) much; (M, K; *) he proclaimed, or made proclamation; syn. naAdaY: (Jel in vii. 42, and Bd and Jel in xii. 70 and xxii. 28:) Sb says that some of the Arabs make A^a*~ana and ↓ A=*ana to be syn.: but some say that the former signifies he called out publickly; and the latter, i. q. A^aEolama [he made to know, &c.: see 4]. (M, TA.) It is said in the Kur [xxii. 28], waA^a*~ino fiY Aln~aAsi biAlHaj~i (M) And proclaim thou, among the people, the pilgrimage. (Bd, Jel.) ― -b2- Also, (S, K,) or A^*~n biAlS~alaApi, (Msb,) inf. n. as above, (M, K,) or A^a*aAnN, (S,) or both, (TA,) or the latter is [properly speaking] a simple subst. [used as an inf. n.], as in the instances of wad~aEa wadaAE~aA and sal~ama salaAmFA and kal~ama kalaAmFA &c., (Msb,) He called to prayer; (M, K;) he notified, or made known, or proclaimed, [i. e., chanted, from the miy^o*anap,] the time of prayer; (S, * Msb, * TA;) and ↓ A=*ana signifies the same, (K,) inf. n. A_iy*aAnN. (TA.) IB says, the phrase A^a*~ana AlEaSoru, with the verb in the act. form, [a phrase commonly obtaining in the present day,] is wrong; the correct expression being A^u*~ina biAlEaSori [The time of the prayer of afternoon was proclaimed, i. e., chanted], with the verb in the pass. form, and with the preposition to connect it with its subject. (Msb.) ― -b3- You say also, A^a*~ana biA_irosaAli A_ibilihi He spoke of sending away his camels. (En-Nadr, T.)

4 A=*nhu * : see 1, last sentence but one. ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] inf. n. A_iy*aAnN, (assumed tropical:) He prevented him, or forbade him; (K;) and repelled him. (TA.) [See also 2.] ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) It (a thing, M) pleased, or rejoiced, him, (M, K,) and he therefore listened to it. (M.) -A2- A=*anotuhu, inf. n. A_iy*aAnN, (T, Msb,) in the place of which the subst. A^a*aAnN is also used, (T,) signifies A^aEolamotuhu [I made him to know, or have knowledge; informed, apprized, advertised, or advised, him; gave him information, intelligence, notice, or advice: and I made it known, notified it, or announced it]: (T, Msb:) and ↓ taA^a*~anotu, also, signifies A^aEolamotu [as meaning I made to know, &c.: and I made known, &c.]. (Msb.) You say, A=*nhu biAlA^amori, (T, K, [in the CK, erroneously, Aa*anahu,]) or biAl$~aYo'i, (S,) and A=*nhu AlA^amora, (M, K,) inf. n. A_iy*aAnN, (T,) meaning A^aEolamahu [He made him to know, or have knowledge of, the thing; informed, apprized, advertised, or advised, him of it; gave him information, intelligence, notice, or advice, of it; made it known, notified it, or announced it, to him]; (T, S, M, K;) as also AlA^amora ↓ tA^*~nhu. (M.) So, accord. to one reading, in the Kur [ii. 279], faA=*inuwA biHarobK mina All~`hi Then make ye known, or notify ye, or announce ye, war from God. (M. [For the more common reading, see 1, latter part.]) And so in the Kur [vii. 166], rab~uka ↓ wa A_i*o taA^a*~ana And when thy Lord made known, or notified, or announced: (Zj, S, M, K: *) or the meaning here is, swore: (M, K: *) [for] you say, layafoEadana ↓ taA^a*~ana, meaning he swore that he would assuredly do [such a thing]: (M:) Lth says that laA^a foEalan~a ka*aA wa ka*aA ↓ taA^a*~anotu signifies the making the action obligatory. (T.) You say also, AlA^amiyru fiY Aln~aAsi ↓ taA^a*~ana The commander, or governor, or prince, proclaimed (naAdaY) among the people, with threatening (S, K) and prohibition; i. e. taqad~ama and A^aEolama. (S.) And you say of a building that has cracked in its sides, A=*ana biA@liAnohidaAmi waAls~uquwTi (assumed tropical:) [It gave notice of becoming a ruin and of falling down]. (Msb in art. dEw.) [See also a similar ex. in a verse cited voce A^alaA. And hence,] A=*ana AlEu$obu [in the CK (erroneously) Aa*ana] (tropical:) The herbage began to dry up; part of it being still succulent, and part already dried up. (M, K, TA.) And A=*ana AlHub~u The grain put forth its A^a*anap, or leaves. (TA.) See also 2, latter half, in two places. -A3- A=*ana and ↓ tA^*~n are [also] used in one and the same sense [as meaning He knew; had knowledge; or became informed, apprized, advertised, or advised, of a thing]; like as one says A^ayoqana and tayaq~ana. (S, TA.) You say, ↓ taA^a*~ano, meaning AiEolamo [Know thou]; like as you say taEal~amo, meaning AiEolamo. (M.)
5 taAa*~ana see 4, in eight places.

10 AstA^*nhu *
He asked, or demanded, of him permission, or leave, (M, Msb, K,) fiY ka*aA to do such a thing. (Msb.) [You say, AstA^*n meaning He asked, or demanded, permission, or leave, to enter, or to come into the presence of another; and to go. And AstA^*n fiY Ald~uxuwli Elyh, and, elliptically, AstA^*n Elyh, He asked, or demanded, permission, or leave, to go in to him.]
A^u*onN * : see A^u*unN.

A_i*onN * [is held by some to be an inf. n., like ↓ A^a*ayinN: (see 1:) by others, to be] a simple subst.; (Msb;) signifying Permission; leave; or concession of liberty, to do a thing: and sometimes command: and likewise will; (Msb, TA;) as in the phrase biA_i*oni A@ll~`hi by the will of God: (Msb:) or, accord. to El-Harállee, the withdrawal, or removal, of prevention or prohibition, and the giving of power or ability, in respect of being and creation: or, accord. to Ibn-El-Kemál, the rescission of prohibition, and concession of freedom of action, to him who has been prohibited by law: or, accord. to Er-Rághib, the notification of the allowance or permission of a thing, and of indulgence in respect of it; as in A_il~aA liyuTaAEa biA_i*oni A@ll~`hi, [in the Kur iv. 67,] meaning [but that he may be obeyed] by the will of God, and [also] by his command: (TA:) or, as explained in the Ksh, facilitation; an explanation founded upon the opinion that the actions of men are by their own effective power, but facilitated by God; and in this sense, Esh-Shiháb regards it as a metaphor, or a non-metaphorical trope: (MF:) and accommodation; syn. tawofiyqN; (Hr in explanation of a clause of iii. 139 of the Kur [which see below];) but Es-Semeen says that this requires consideration. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Knowledge; syn. EilomN; (T, M, K;) and so ↓ A^a*iynN; (M, K;) as in the saying faEalahu biA_i*oniY (T, * M, K) and ↓ biA^a*iynY (M, K) [He did it with my knowledge]: or A_i*onN has a
more particular signification than EilomN, being scarcely ever, or never, used save of that [knowledge] wherein is will, conjoined with command or not conjoined therewith; for in the saying [in the Kur iii. 139, referred to above,] wamaA kaAna linafosK A^ano tamuwta A_il~aA biA_i*oni A@ll~`hi [And it is not for a soul to die save with the knowledge of God], it is known that there are will and command; and in the saying [in the Kur ii. 96], wamaA humo biD~aAriyna bihi mino A^aHadK A_il~aA bA_i*oni A@ll~`hi [But they do not injure thereby any one save with the knowledge of God], there is will in one respect, for there is no difference of opinion as to the fact that God hath made to exist in man a faculty wherein is the power of injuring another: (Er-Rághib:) but Es-Semeen says that this plea is adduced by Er-Rághib because of his inclining to the persuasion of the Moatezileh. (TA.) You say also, faEalotu ka*aA biA_i*onihi meaning I did thus by his command. (T.)
A^a*anN * : see A^a*anapN

A^u*unN * and ↓ A^u*onN, (S, M, Msb, K,) the latter a contraction of the former, [which is the more common,] (Msb,) [The ear;] one of the organs of sense; (M, TA;) well known: (M:) of the fem. gender: (S, M, Msb, K:) as also ↓ A^a*iynN: (K:) pl. A=*aAnN, (S, M, Msb, K,) its only pl. form: (M:) dim. ↓ A^u*ayonapN; but when used as a proper name of a man, A^u*ayonu, though A^u*ayonapu has been heard. (S.) You say, jaA='a naA$ir~aA A^u*unayohi [He came spreading, or, as we say, pricking up, his ears: meaning] (tropical:) he came in a state of covetousness, or eagerness. (T, K, TA. [See also na$ara.]) And wajadotu fulaAnFA laA bisFA A^u*unayohi (tropical:) I found such a one feigning himself inattentive, or heedless. (T, TA.) And labisotu A^u*unaY~a lahu (tropical:) I turned away from him, avoided him, or shunned him: or I feigned myself inattentive, or heedless, to him. (K, TA. [See also labisa.]) ― -b2- (tropical:) A man who listens to what is said to him: (M, K, TA:) or a man who hears the speech of every one: (S:) or who relies upon what is said to him; as also waAbiSapu Als~amoEi: (M in art. wbS:) applied as an epithet to one and to a pl. number, (S, M, K,) alike, (S, M,) and to two, and to a woman; not being pluralized nor dualized [nor having the fem. form given to it]: (IB:) you say rajulN A^N*onN (AZ, S, M) and A^u*onN, and rijaAlN A^u*unN and A^u*onN [&c.]: (AZ, M:) and sometimes it is applied to a man as a name of evil import. (M.) It is said in the Kur [ix. 61], wayaquwluwna huwa A^u*unN qulo A^u*unu xayorK lakumo (T, M) And they say, “He is one who hears and believes everything that is said to him:” as though, by reason of the excess of his listening, he were altogether the organ of hearing; like as a spy is termed EayonN; or A^u*un is here from A^a*ina “he listened,” and is like A^unufN and $ululN in its derivation: (Bd:) for among the hypocrites was he who found fault with the Prophet, saying, “If anything be told him from me, I swear to him, and he receives it from me, because he is an A^u*un:” (M:) therefore he is commanded to answer, Say, “A hearer of good for you.” (T, M, Bd.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A sincere, or faithful, adviser of a people, who counsels to obedience: (Msb:) a man's intimate, and special, or particular, friend. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A certain appertenance of the heart; (M;) [i. e. either auricle thereof;] A^u*unaA Alqalobi signifying two appendages (zanamataAni) in the upper part of the heart: (K:) and (tropical:) of a naSol [or arrow-head or the like; i. e. either wing thereof]: and (tropical:) of an arrow; A=*aAnu Als~ahomi signifying the feathers of the arrow, as AHn says, when they are attached thereon; and *uw valaAvi A=*aAnK [a thing having three such feathers] meaning an arrow: all so called by way of comparison: (M:) and (assumed tropical:) of a sandal; (S, M, K;) i. e. the part thereof that surrounds the qibaAl [q. v.]: (M:) or A^u*unaA Aln~aEoli signifies the two parts, [or loops,] of the sandal, to which are tied the EaDudaAni of the $iraAk, [or two branches of the thong that is attached to another thong between two of the toes, which two branches, however, sometimes pass through the A^u*unaAni, encompassing the heel,] behind the narrow part (xaSor) of the sole. (AO in an anonymous MS in my possession. See also xaSorN.) ― -b5- (tropical:) A handle, (M,) or [a loopshaped, or an ear-shaped, handle, such as is termed] Eurowap, (T, K,) of anything; (M, K) as, for instance, (M,) of a kuwz [or mug]; (T, M;) and of a dalow [or bucket]: so called by way of comparison: and in all cases fem.: (M:) pl. as above. (T.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) What becomes sharp, or pointed, and then falls off, or out, of the plants called Earofaj and vumaAm when they put forth their xuwS [q. v.], or when their xwS become perfect; because it has the shape of an ear. (AHn, M.)
A_i*ano * , also written A_i*FA: see art. A*A.

A^a*anapN * The leaves of trees, (En-Nadr, T,) or of grain. (K.) ― -b2- [The kind of leaf called xuwSap of the vumaAm.] ― -b3- (tropical:) The young ones of camels and of sheep or goats; (En-Nadr, T, K;) as being likened to the xuwSap of the vumaAm. (TA.) ― -b4- A piece of straw: pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] ↓ A^a*anN [in the CK A^u*unN]. (IAar, T, K.) -A2- Appetite, appetency, longing, yearning, or strong desire. (En-Nadr, T.) You say, h`*ihi baqolapN tajidu bihaA AlA_ibilu A^a*anapa $adiydapF This is a herb for which the camels feel a strong appetite &c. (En-Nadr, T.) And h`*aA TaEaAmN laA A^a*anapa lahu This is food for the odour of which there is no appetite. (K, * TA.)

A^a*aAnN *
A making known; a notification; an announcement. (T, S, Mgh.) [See 4.] So in the Kur [ix. 3], wa A^a*aAnN mina A@ll~`hi warasuwlihi A_ilaY Aln~aAsi [And a notification, or an announcement, from God and his apostle to men, or the people]. (T, Mgh.) ― -b2- Also, and ↓ A^a*iynN, (T, S, M, K,) and taA^o*iynN, [the last an inf. n. of 2, and the second a quasi-inf. n. of the same, which see,] (M, K,) The notification, or announcement, of prayer, and of the time thereof; (T, S;) the call to prayer. (M, K.) [The words of this call (which is usually chanted from the miy^o*anap, or turret of the mosque,) are Aall~`hu A^akobaro (four times) A^a$ohadu A^no laA A_il`ha A_il~aA A@ll~`ho (twice) A^a$ohadu A^an~a muHam~adFA r~asuwlu A@ll~`hu (twice) Hay~a EalaY AlS~alaAhN (twice) HaY~a EalaY AlfalaAHo (twice) Aall~`hu A^akobarN (twice) laA A_il`ha A_il~aA A@ll~`hN.] ― -b3- AlA^a*aAnu also signifies The [notification, or announcement, called] A_iqaAmap; (M, K;) because it is a notification to be present at the performance of the divinelyordained prayers. (TA.) [This (which is chanted in the mosque) consists of the words of the former A^a*aAn with the addition of qado qaAmati AlS~alaAho pronounced twice after HaYa EalaY AlfalaAHo.] ― -b4- AlA^a*aAnaAni signifies The A^a*aAni [more commonly so called] and the A_iqaAmap. (TA.)
A^a*uwnN * [An animal having an ear; as distinguished from SamuwxN, which means “having merely an ear-hole”]. (Msb in art. byD.)

A^a*iynN * : see A^u*unN. -A2- See also A_i*onN, in three places. ― -b2- And see A^a*aAnN. -A3- I. q. ↓ muw^o*inN [Making to know or have knowledge, biA^amorK of a thing; informing, apprizing, advertising, or advising; giving information, intelligence, notice, or advice; making known, notifying, or announcing]: like A^aliymN and wajiyEN as meaning muw^olimN and muwjiEN. (M.) ― -b2- See also muw^a*~inN. -A4- One who is responsible, answerable, amenable, or a surety; [biA^amorK for a thing; and perhaps also bigayorihi for another person;] syn. kafiylN (S, M, K) and zaEiymN [which signifies the same as kafiylN, and is plainly shown in the M to be here used as a syn. of this latter; but SM assigns to it here another meaning, namely ray^iysN, in which sense I find no instance of the use of A^a*iynN]; (AO, M;) and ↓ A=*inN also is syn. with A^a*iynN in the sense of kafiylN. (K.) -A5- Also A place to which the A^a*aAn [or call to prayer] comes [or reaches] from [or on] every side. (S, K.)
A^u*ayonapN * dim. of A^u*unN, q. v. (S.)

A^u*aAniY~N * (S, M, Mgh, K) and ↓ A=*anu (M, K) Largeeared; (S, M, Mgh, K;) long-eared; (M;) applied to a man, (S, M, K,) and to a camel, and to a sheep or goat: (M:) [or] the latter epithet is applied to a ram; and its fem. A^a*onaA='u to a ewe. (T, S, M.)
A^u*ayoniY~N * One who hears everything that is said: but this is a vulgar word. (TA.) [See A^u*unN.]
A=*anu * : see A^u*aAniY~N.
A=*inN * [act. part. n. of 1. As such, Permitting, or allowing; one who permits, or allows. And hence,] A doorkeeper, or chamberlain. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also A^a*iynN.
muw^o*anN * : see maA^o*uwnN.

muw^o*inN * : see A^a*iynN. You say, siymaAhu biAlxayori muw^o*inapN His impress notifies [or is indicative of] goodness. (TA.) ― -b2- muw^o*inaAtN, signifying The women who notify, or announce, the times of festivity and rejoicing, [particularly on the occasions of weddings,] is a vulgar word. (TA.) -A2- Herbage beginning to dry up; part of it being still succulent, and part already dried up: and a branch, or wood, that has dried, but has in it some succulency. (TA.)
maA^o*anapN * : see what next follows.
muw^o*anapN * : see what next follows.

miy^o*anapN * (which may also be pronounced miy*anapN, Msb) The place [generally a turret of a mosque] upon which the time of prayer is notified, made known, or proclaimed; (T, M, * K; *) i. q. manaArapN [which has this meaning and others also]; (AZ, T, S, Msb;) as also ↓ muw^o*anapN: (AZ, T:) or it signifies, (as in some copies of the K,) or signifies also, (as in other copies of the same,) i. q. manaArapN: and SawomaEapN: [see these two words:] (K:) or i. q. manaArapN, meaning SawomaEapN; (Lh, M, TA;) by way of comparison [to the turret first mentioned]: but as to ↓ maA^o*anapN, it is a vulgar word: (TA:) the pl. is maA=*inu, agreeably with the original form of the sing. (Msb.)

muw^a*~inN *
One who notifies, makes known, or proclaims, [by a chant,] the time of prayer; (M, * Msb, K; *) [i. e., who chants the call to prayer;] as also ↓ A^a*iynN. (M, K.)

maA^o*uwnN * , as meaning A slave permitted, or having leave given him, by his master, to traffic, is used for maA^o*uwnN lahu, (Msb, TA,) by the lawyers. (Msb.) -A2- Also Having his ear hit, or hurt; and so ↓ muw^o*anN. (TA.)

1 A^a*iYa * , aor.
Aa*aYa , inf. n. A^a*FY, (T, M, Msb, K,) in [some of] the copies of the K written A^a*FA, and so by IB, (TA,) and A^a*aA='N, (CK, [but not found by me in any MS. copy of the K nor in any other lexicon,]) and, accord. to IB, A^a*aApN and A^a*iy~apN, (TA,) or these two are simple substs.; (M, K;) and ↓ tA^*~Y; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) [He was, or became, annoyed, molested, harmed, or hurt;] he experienced, or suffered, slight evil, [i. e., annoyance, molestation, harm, or hurt,] less than what is termed Darar; (El-Khattábee;) or he experienced, or suffered, what was disagreeable, or hateful, or evil, (Msb, K,) in a small degree; (K;) bihi [by him, or it]; (T, S, M, K;) [and minohu from him, or it:] ↓ Alt~aA^a*~iY signifies the being affected by what is termed AlA^a*aY [i. e. what annoys, molests, harms, or hurts, one]: and also the showing the effect thereof; which is forbidden by the saying of 'Omar, biAln~aAsi ↓ A_iy~aAka waAlt~aA^a*~iY [Avoid thou, or beware thou of, showing the being annoyed, molested, harmed, or hurt, by men]; for this is what is within one's power. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Also, aor. and inf. n. as above, It (a thing) was unclean, dirty, or filthy. (Msb.)

4 A=*Y * signifies faEala AlA^a*aY [He did what annoyed, molested, harmed, or hurt]. (M, K.) ― -b2- And A=*iAhu, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) aor. yuw^o*iyhi, (S,) inf. n. A_iy*aA='N (T, IB, Msb) and [quasi-inf. n.] A^a*iy~apN, (T,) or A^a*~aY and A^a*aApN and A^a*iy~apN, (S, K,) but IB refuses his assent to this, saying that these three are inf. ns. of A^a*iYa, and MF says of A_iy*aA='N, which is expressly disallowed by the author of the K, though he himself uses it, that others assert it to have been heard and transmitted, and to be required by rule, but he adds that he had searched for examples of it in the language of the Arabs, and investigated their prose and their poetry, without finding this word; (TA;) [He, or it, annoyed him, molested him, harmed him, or hurt him; or] he did what was disagreeable, or hateful, or evil, to him. (Bd in xxxiii. 53, Msb.) It is said in the Kur [xxxiii. 47], wadaEo A^a*aAhumo, meaning And leave thou the requiting of them until thou receive a command respecting them; (M, Bd, Jel;) namely, the hypocrites: (M:) or leave thou unregarded their doing to thee what is [annoying, molesting, harmful, hurtful, or] disagreeable, &c., to thee. (Bd.)
5 taAa*~aYa see 1, in three places.

A^a*~aY * inf. n. of 1. (T, M, Msb, K.) [As a simple subst., A state of annoyance or molestation.] ― -b2- And [Annoyance, molestation, harm, or hurt: quasi-] inf. n. of A=*aAhu. (S, K.) ― -b3- It signifies also, [like ↓ A^a*iy~apN and ↓ A^a*aApN,] kul~u maA taA^o*~ayota [Anything by which thou art annoyed, molested, harmed, or hurt]; (T;) or maA yuw^o*iyka [a thing that annoys, molests, harms, or hurts thee]: (Mgh:) or a slight evil; less than what is termed Darar. (El-Khattábee.) You say, A^amaATa AlA^a*aY Eani AlT~ariyqi He removed, or put away, or put at a distance, what was hurtful from the road, or way. (Mgh and TA in art. myT.) ― -b4- Also A thing held to be unclean, dirty, or filthy: so in the Kur ii. 222. (Mgh, Msb.) [Filth; impurity: often used in this sense in books on practical law.]

A^a*K *
Experiencing, or suffering, [annoyance, molestation, harm, hurt, or] what is disagreeable, or hateful, or evil, (M, * K, * Msb,) in a great, or vehement, degree; (M, K;) applied to a man; (M, Msb;) as also ↓ A^a*iY~N: (M, K:) and both signify the contr.; i. e. doing what is disagreeable, or hateful, or evil, in a great, or vehement, degree. (K.) ― -b2- Also, applied to a camel, That will not remain still in one place, by reason of a natural disposition, not from pain, (El-Umawee, A'Obeyd, S, M, K,) nor disease; (K;) as also ↓ A^a*Y~N: (M:) fem. of the former A^a*iyapN; (El-Umawee &c.;) and of the latter ↓ A^a*iy~apN. (TA.)
A_i*aA * : and A_i*FA: see art. A*A.
A^a*aApN * an inf. n. of 1. (IB.) ― -b2- And [quasi-] inf. n. of A=*aAhu. (S, K.) ― -b3- See also A^a*~ay and A^a*iy~apN.
A^a*iy~N * , and A^a*iy~apN as its fem.: see A^a*K, in three places.

A^a*iy~apN * an inf. n. of 1. (IB.) ― -b2- And [quasi-] inf. n. of A=*aAhu. (S, K.) ― -b3- And a subst. from A=*aAhu; (Msb;) or, as also ↓ A^a*aApN, a subst. from A^a*iYa and taA^a*~aY; (M, K;) signifying A thing that is disagreeable, or hateful, or evil, in a small degree. (K.) See also A^a*FY.

A=*iY~N * , (S, M, K, &c.,) with medd and teshdeed, (TA, [in the CK, erroneously, Aa*iY~,]) Waves (S, M, K) of the sea: (S:) or vehement waves: (TA:) or the A^aTobaAq [app. meaning rollers, because they fall over like folds,] which the wind raises from the surface of the water, less than (duwna [but this sometimes signifies above]) what are termed mawoj: (ISh, TA:) pl. A^awaA*iY~u. (S.)
1 A^ar~ahaA * , aor. yaw^ur~u (S,) inf. n. A^ar~N, (S, K,) Inivit eam; he compressed her. (S, K.)
A^ar~a A_ir~a * , (M, TT, L, [and so in the present day,]) or A^aro A^aro, (K,) A cry by which sheep or goats are called. (M, L, K.)

miy^or~N * A man (S,) much addicted to venery: (S, K:) so accord. to A'Obeyd, as related by Sh and El-Iyádee, but thought by Az to be may^iyrN, of the same measure as maEiyrN, i. e., mafoEilN, [originally maA^oyirN,] from A=rahaA. (T.)

1 A^aruba * , aor.
Aaruba , (T, S, M, K,) inf. n. A^araAbapN (AZ, T, S, M, K) and A_irabN, like SigarN, (S, K,) He was, or became, cunning, characterized by intelligence with craft and forecast, or simply intelligent, excellent in judgment, sagacious, (T, [in which it is said that As is related to have assigned this signification to A^ariba, aor.
Aaraba , inf. n. A^arabN,] S, M, K,) and knowing in affairs. (M.) [The TA assigns the former inf. n. to it when it signifies simply intelligence, and the latter when it has the more comprehensive signification of cunning.] ― -b2- A^ariba biAl$~aYo'i, [aor.
Aaraba ,] He became expert, or skilful, in the thing: (M:) or he became accustomed to, or practised or exercised in, the thing, (S, K, *) and became knowing, or skilful [therein]. (S.) ― -b3- A^ariba, inf. n. A^arabN, is also syn. with A^anisa [app. as meaning He became familiar with a person or thing]. (M.) ― -b4- And A^ariba biAl$~aYo'i also signifies He devoted, or addicted, himself, or clave, or kept, to the thing: (T, K:) and he was, or became, niggardly, avaricious, or tenacious, of the thing. (T, M, TA.) ― -b5- And A^ariba fiY AlA^amori, and fiyhi ↓ tA^r~b, He exerted, or employed, his power and ability in the affair, and understood it: (ISh, T:) or tA^r~b signifies he exerted his strength, force, or energy; or strained himself; (As, S, M;) fiy Al$~aYo'i [in the thing]; (As, S;) and fiY HaAjatihi [in his needful affair, or in the accomplishment of his want]. (As, S, M.) ― -b6- A^ariba Ealayohi He had, or obtained, power over him, or it. (M.) -A2- A^ariba, aor.
Aaraba , (T, S, K,) inf. n. A^arabN, (T, S,) He was, or became, in want, or need. (T, S, K.) [See A^aribota Eano *iY yadayoka, and two other phrases following it, in a later part of this paragraph.] ― -b2- A^ariba A_ilayohi, (M, Msb,) or bihi (T,) aor. and inf. n. as above, He wanted it; was, or became, in want, or need, of it; (T, M, Msb;) and sought it, or desired it; (T;) namely, a thing. (T, Msb.) ― -b3- A^ariba Ald~ahoru Fortune was, or became, hard, or adverse: (T, S, K:) as though it wanted something of us, for which it pressed hard. (M, TA.) And A^ariba Ealayohi He was, or became, hard upon him in his demand. (TA, from a trad.) -A3- A^arabahu, [from A_irabN,] He struck upon a member, or limb, belonging to him. (K, *
TA.) ― -b2- A^ariba, (T, S, K, TA,) His member, or limb, (generally meaning the arm, or hand, M,) was cut off: (M, K:) or dropped off: (T:) and his members, or limbs, (generally relating to [the members, or fingers, of] the arm, or hand, TA,) dropped off, one after another, (S, K, TA,) in consequence of his being affected by the disease termed ju*aAm: (TA:) and it (said of a member, or limb,) dropped off. (TA.) The phrase, A^aribota Eano *iY yadayoka, (T, TA,) or mino *Y ydyk, (S, TA, [and said in the latter to be likewise found in the T, but I have consulted two copies of the T and found only En,]) or fiY *Y ydyk, (IAar, as related by Sh,) or mino yadayoka, (K,) but MF says that mn in this phrase is a mistranscription, (TA,) means, May the members [or fingers] of thy hands, or arms, drop off: (S, K, TA:) or it means, may what is in thy hands depart from thee, so that thou shalt be in want: occurring in a trad. (IAar, T, TA.) And A^ariba maA lahu, said by Mohammad on the occasion of a man's coming to him and asking him to acquaint him with some work that should introduce him into Paradise, means, accord. to Kt, May his members, or limbs, drop off, or be cut off: what aileth him? (TA:) or, accord. to IAar, may he become in want: what aileth him? (T, TA:) but IAth says that this has been related in three different ways: first, A^ariba, signifying an imprecation, [as rendered above,] and used as expressive of wonder: secondly, m~aA lahu ↓ A^arabN; i. e.
