HaAjapN lahu; maA being [syntactically] redundant, denoting littleness; the meaning being, he has some little want: or, as some say, a want hath brought him: what aileth him? thirdly, ↓ A^aribN; i. e. huwa A^aribN; meaning he is intelligent, or sagacious, or skilful, [as is said in the T,] and perfect: what aileth him? or what is his affair? the inchoative being suppressed. (TA.) maA lahu A^aribato yaduhu, (M, K, *) another form of imprecation, (M,) means What aileth him? may his arm, or hand, be cut off: or, may he become poor, and want what is in the hands of others. (M, K. *) ― -b3- [Hence, perhaps,] A^aribato maEidatuhu His stomach became vitiated, disordered, or in an unsound state. (K.) ― -b4- A^ariba also signifies He prostrated himself firmly, or fixedly, upon his [seven] members [mentioned in the explanations of the word A_irobN]. (T.)

2 A^r~b * , inf. n. taA^riybN, He, or it, [made, or rendered, cunning, or intelligent, excellent in judgment, sagacious, and knowing in affairs; (see A^aruba;)] made to have knowledge, or skill; or made to understand. (M, TA.) -A2- He was, or became, avaricious; [in a state of vehement want of a thing;] eagerly desirous. (A'Obeyd, TA.) [See also 1.] -A3- He cut up, or cut into pieces, (T, A, Mgh,) a sheep, or goat, (A, Mgh,) limb by limb. (T, A, Mgh.) ― -b2- He cut off a member, or limb, entire. (M, TA.) ― -b3- He made entire, or complete, (T, S, M, K,) a thing, (S,) a lot, or portion, (T, TA,) or anything. (M.)

3 A=rbhu A=rbh A=rbp , (S, A,) inf. n. muw^aArabapN, (M, A,) He strove, or endeavoured, to outwit, deceive, beguile, or circumvent, him; syn. daAhaAhu. (S, M, * A. *) It is said in a trad., (TA,) muw^aArabapu AlA^ariybi jaholN waEanaA='N [The striving to outwit the cunning, or intelligent, or sagacious, is ignorance, and labour without profit]: (A, TA:) i. e., the intelligent is not to be outwitted. (TA.) And A=rb bihi signifies He practised an artifice, a stratagem, or a fraud, upon him. (TA, from a trad.)
4 A=rb Ealayohimo A=rb Elyhm , (T, S, M, K,) of the measure A^afoEala, (T,) inf. n. A_iyraAbN [originally A_iy^oraAbN], (K,) He was successful against them, and overcame them. (T, S, M, K.)

5 tA^r~b *
He affected, or endeavoured to acquire, (takal~afa,) cunning, or intelligence, and excellence of judgment, (K, TA,) and deceit, guile, or artifice, and wickedness, mischievousness, or malignity. (TA.) [See A_irobN.] ― -b2- tA^r~b fiy AlA^amori: see 1.
A^arobN * : see what next follows, in two places.

A_irobN A^rAb A^rb A^rbY A_rb Arb rAb rb rbA rbY |rb
Cunning, intelligence with craft and forecast, or simply intelligence, excellence of judgment, sagacity, (T, S, M, L, K,) and knowledge in affairs; (M, L;) as also ↓ A_irobapN and ↓ A^urobapN (M, K) and ↓ A^arabN, (M, A,) or ↓ A^arobN. (L.) You say, huwa *uw A_irobK [He is a possessor of cunning, or intelligence, &c.]. (S.) ― -b2- Intelligence and religion. (Th, M, K.) ― -b3- Deceit, guile, artifice, or fraud; syn. makorN: so in the L and other lexicons: in the K, nukorN [i. e. “cunning,” &c., as above]: (TA:) and so ↓ A_irobapN; syn. HiylapN. (K.) ― -b4- Wickedness, mischievousness, or malignity; hidden rancour, malevolence, or malice. (K, TA.) [In a trad. it occurs in this sense written, in the TA, ↓ A^arob.] -A2- See also A^arabN, in four places. -A3- Also A member; a distinct and complete part of an animal body; a limb; (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) or such as is made complete, or entire, not wanting anything: (M:) pl. A=raAbN (S, M, Mgh, Msb) and A^aroA=bN; (S, Mgh;) the latter formed by transposition. (Mgh.) You say, qaT~aEotuhu A_irobFA A_irobFA I cut him up, member by member, or limb by limb. (TA.) And Als~ujuwdu EalaY saboEapi A=raAbK or A^aroA=bK Prostration [in prayer] is [performed] on seven members; (S, Mgh;) namely, the. forehead, the hands, the knees, and the feet. (TA.) ― -b2- Also The membrum genitale; the pudendum; syn. farojN: (M, K:) but some say that this signification is not known: [see A^arabN:] in some copies of the K, the explanation is written faraHN, with the unpointed H. (TA.) ― -b3- A=raAbN [the pl.] also signifies Pieces of flesh, or of flesh-meat. (M.)

A^arabN * : see A_irobN. -A2- Want, or need; (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also ↓ A_irobN and ↓ A_robapN (the same, and A) and ↓ A^urobapN (K) and ↓ maA^orabapN and ↓ maA^orubapN (T, S, M, A, Msb, K) and ↓ maA^oribapN (K) and ↓ maA^orabN: (M, A:) the pl. [of A^arabN or A_irobN] is A=raAbN, and [of A_irobapN, and perhaps of the other sings. commencing with A] A_irabN; (M;) and the pl. of mA^rbp is maA=ribu. (T, Msb.) It is said in a trad., respecting Mo- hammad, kaAna A^amolakakumo lArbh He had the most power, of you, over his want, and desire: (M, * Mgh, * Msb, * TA:) IAth says that the most common reading is liA^arabihi, meaning liHaAjatihi: but some read ↓ liAorbihi, [as in the M and Mgh,] i. e., either the same as above, [and so in the Mgh,] or liEuDowihi, by which is specially meant the membrum genitale: (TA:) but this is not known. (M.) Respecting the phrase A^araba m~aA lahu, see 1. You say also, A^ilay h`*aA ↓ maA A_irobuka What is [the reason of] thy want of this? (A.) And maA liY ↓ fiyhi A_irbN I have no want of it. (A.) By gayori ↓ A^uwliy AlA^arobapi, in the Kur [xxiv. 31], are meant Idiots; or persons deficient in intellect: [from A_irobapN as meaning “intelligence:”] (Sa'eed Ibn-Jubeyr, S:) or not such as have need of women. (Jel.) laA HafaAwapN ↓ maA^arabapN, (S, A,) or laA HafaAwapN ↓ maA^orabN, (M,) is a proverb, (S, A,) meaning He only honours thee for the sake of something which he wants of thee; not for love of thee: (A, Meyd:) or only thy want brought thee; not the object of paying extraordinary honour to me. (M.) [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 690.] You say also, mina AlA^aroDi ↓ A^aloHiqo bimaA^orabika, meaning, Go thou whither thou wilt [so as to attain thy want]. (A.)

A^aribN * : see A^ariybN. ― -b2- Also [Expert; skilful: (see A^ariba, of which it is the part. n.:) or] accustomed to, or practised or exercised in, a thing, and knowing, or skilful. (S, TA.) See also 1, in the latter part of the paragraph. -A2- A^aribN bi$aYo 'K, [or A_ilay $aYo'K, (see A^ariba,)] or ↓ A=ribN, of the measure faAEilN, (Msb,) Wanting, needing, or desiring, a thing. (Msb, * TA in art. mhr, &c.)
A^urobapN * : see A_irobN: -A2- and A^arabN.
A_irobapN A^rAb A^rb A^rbY A^rbh A^rbp A_rb A_rbh Arbh Arbp rAb rbA rbY |rb |rbh : see A_irobN, in two places: -A2- and A^arabN, in two places.

A^urabaY *
Calamity; misfortune: (T, S, M, A, K:) [said to be] the only word of this measure except A^uramaY and $uEabaY [names of two places]. (TA.)
A^urobaAnN * (M, K): dial. vars. of EurobaAnN and EurobuwnN and EarabuwnN. (M, * K, * TA.)
A^urobuwnN * (TA): dial. vars. of EurobaAnN and EurobuwnN and EarabuwnN. (M, * K, * TA.
A^arabuwnN * (TA): EurobaAnN (TA): dial. vars. of EurobuwnN and EarabuwnN. (M, * K, * TA.

A^ariybN *
Cunning, characterized by intelligence with craft and forecast, or simply intelligent [as in the S], excellent in judgment, sagacious, (T, S, * M, K,) and knowing in affairs; (M;) as also ↓ A^aribN: (K:) pl. of the former A^arabaA='u. (T, M.) -A2- A=rabu A wide, an ample, or a capacious, cooking-pot. (K.)

qidorN A^ariybapN *
More, or most, cunning, or intelligent, excellent in judgment, or sagacious. (A.) [See A^ariybN.]

or an entire, unbroken, member, or limb: (S:) and anything made entire, complete, or perfect. (S, K.) You say, katifN muw^ar~abapN A shoulder cut off entire, (Mgh, TA,) having none of its flesh taken from it, (Mgh,) without any deficiency. (TA.)

A_irovN A^rv A_rv Arv rAv rv rvA rvY wrv , originally wirovN, (T, S,) Inheritance; or a person's obtaining possession of property left to him by one who has died. (MF.) ― -b2- An inheritance, or a heritage; what is inherited. (S, A, K.) ― -b3- An old condition, case, or state of things, which the last has inherited from the first. (S, A, K.) So in the phrase, huwa EalaY A_irovK mino ka*aA [He is conforming, in respect of such a thing, with an old state of things, or an old usage, which he has inherited from his ancestors]. (S.) And in the following ex., from a trad., A_in~akumo EalaY A_irovK mino A_irovi A^abiykumo A_iboraAhiyma [Verily ye are conforming with an old state of things, or an old usage, which ye have inherited from your father Abraham], the meaning is, that his religion was their heritage. (T, * TA.) [See also wirovN.] ― -b4- A remainder, or what remains, (M, L, K,) of a thing, (K,) or of the original of a thing: (M, L:) pl. A_iraAvN. (L.) ― -b5- And [hence, app.,] Ashes. (M, K.) ― -b6- Also Origin, race, or stock. (S, M, A, K.) You say, huwa fiY A_irovi SidoqK He is of an excellent origin, race, or stock. (S.) And A_in~ahu lafiY A_irovi majodK [Verily he is of a glorious origin, race, or stock]; as also A_irofi majodK, by a change of letters. (Yaa- koob, M.) Accord. to IAar, A_irovN relates to Hasab [or grounds of pretension to respect or honour, on account of one's ancestors' or one's own deeds or qualities, &c.]; and wirovN, to property, or wealth. (M.) [See art. wrv.]
A^urovapN * : see A_iraAtN, in three places.

Fire; (T, M, L, K;) as also ↓ A_iraAvapN and ↓ A^ariyvN: (TA:) or (so accord. to the M and L, but in the K “and”) tinder, and the like, prepared for fire; (M, L, K;) [as also ↓ A_iraAvapN and ↓ A^urovapN; or these two words signify a means of kindling or inflaming; as will be seen from what follows:] or a lump of the dung of a horse or the like, or a similar thing, with which one kindles a fire; as also ↓ A^urovapN: (A:) or this last signifies dung of camels or horses or the like, (S, K,) or wood, or a stick, (T,) that is prepared, or put in readiness, by the ashes, (S, K,) or buried in them, (T,) for the time when it may be wanted (T, S, K) for fuel. (T.) It is said in a prov., mentioned in the collection of Meyd, AlEadaAwapi ↓ Aln~amiymapu [Calumny, or slander, is a means of kindling, or inflaming, enmity]. (TA: but in Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 773, in the place of ArAvp, we find ↓ A^urovap.)

Aaraja , inf. n. A^arajN (S, A, Msb, K) and A^ariyjN (S, A, K) and A^ariyjapN, (K, [in which it is only mentioned as syn. with the first and second of these ns., so that it may be a simple subst.,]) It (perfume) diffused, or exhaled, its odour; (S, A;) as also ↓ tA=r~j: (A:) it had a hot, or strong, odour; syn. tawah~aja riyHuhu. (S, A, K.) ― -b2- It (a place) was, or became, strongly fragrant. (Msb.) -A2- A^araja: see 2, in three places.

Aaruja , (TK,) inf. n. A^arojN; (K, TA;) (assumed tropical:) He excited discord, dissension, disorder, strife, quarrelling, or animosity, (S, K, TA,) bayona Alqawomi between, or among, the people, or company of men, like A^ar~a$a, (S, TA,) and fiy AlHarobi in war. 2 A^ar~axa AlkitaAba * , (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. taA^oriyxN; (S, Mgh;) and ↓ A^araxahu, (IKtt, Msb, K,) inf. n. A^aroxN; (TA;) but the former is the more common, (Msb,) and the latter is by some rejected, though correct accord. to IKtt and others; (MF;) and ↓ A=rxhu, (K,) inf. n. muw^aAraxapN; (TA;) as also war~axahu, inf. n. taworiyxN; (S, Mgh, * Msb;) in which the w is a substitute for the '; (Yaakoob, Msb;) a form seldom used; (Msb;) He dated the writing, or letter; inscribed it with a date, or note of the time when it was written. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) You say also, A^ar~axa AlkitaAba biyawomi ka*aA He inscribed the writing, or letter, with the date of such a day. (S, L.) And A^ar~axa Albay~inapa He dated, or mentioned the date of, the evidence, proof, or voucher: in the contr. case saying, A^aTolaqa. (Msb.) Some say that tA^ryx is an arabicized word, (L, Msb,) borrowed by the Muslims from the people of the Bible: [i. e., from the Jews or Christians; app. from the Hebr. יָרֵחַ the “moon,” or יֶרַח “a month;“ or from the Chald. יְרַח “a month;” as observed by Golius:] (L:) others say that it is [pure] Arabic: (Msb, TA:) some, that it is formed by transposition from taA^oxiyrN. (TA.)
3 AaAoraxa see 2.

taA^oriyxN * inf. n. of 2. ― -b2- Also, [as a subst., generally pronounced without ',] A date; an era; an epoch; (Msb;) and ↓ A^uroxapN is a subst. [signifying the same,] from A^araxa. (K.) taA^oriyxu Alhijorapi is The era, or epoch, of the Emigration [or Flight (for such it really was)] of Mohammad [from Mekkeh to El-Medeeneh], (L, Msb,) which his companions, in the time of 'Omar, agreed to make their era, commencing the year from the first appearance of the new moon of [the month] ElMoharram, [two months before the Flight itself,] and making the day to commence from sunset: (Msb:) it is also called taA^oriyxa Almusolimiyna the era, or epoch, of the Muslims. (L.) ― -b3- Also The utmost limit, term, or time, of anything: whence the saying, fulaAnN taA^oriyxu quwomihi Such a one is the person from whom date the nobility, or eminence, and dominion, or authority, of his people. (Es- Soolee, Mgh, TA.) ― -b4- [Also, A chronicle; a book of annals; a history: pl. tawaAriyxu, from taworiyxN.]

[
muw^ar~ixN *
A chronicler; a writer of annals; a historian..]

A^arozN * and ↓ A^urozN The pine-tree; syn. $ajaru AlS~anawobari: (K:) or this is called ↓ A^arorapN, and A^arozN is the pl.: (A 'Obeyd, S:) [or rather A^arozN is a coll. gen. n., and A^arozapN is the n. un.:] or the male of that kind of tree; (AHn, K;) as also ↓ A^arozapN; (K;) and the author of the Minháj adds, it is that which does not produce fruit; but pitch (zifot) is extracted from its trunks and roots, and its wood is employed as a means of light, like as candles are employed; and it grows not in the land of the Arabs: A 'Obeyd says, ↓ A^arozapN is the name of a tree well known in Syria, called with us SanawobarN, because of its fruit: he says also, I have seen this kind of tree, called A^arozapN, and it is called in El-'Irák SanawobarN, but this last is the name of the fruit of the A^aroz: (TA:) or i. q. EaroEarN [a name given to the cypress and to the juniper-tree]. (K.) It is said in a trad., Almujo*iyapi ↓ mavalu AlkaAfiri mavalu AlA^arozapi EalaY AlA^aroDi Hat~aY yakuwna A=nojiEaAfuhaA bimar~apK waAHidapK [The similitude of the unbeliever is the similitude of the pine-tree standing firmly upon the ground until it is pulled up at once]: respecting which AA and AO say that it is ↓ AlA^arazap, with fet-h to the r; meaning the tree called AlA^arozan: but A 'Obeyd thinks this to be a mistake, and that it is ↓ AlA^arozap, with the r quiescent. (L.)
A^urozN * : see A^arozN: -A2- and see also A^aruz~N.
A^aruzN * : see A^aruz~N.
A^uruzN * : see A^aruz~N.
A^arozapN * : see A^arozN, in five places.

A^arazapN * The tree called A^arozanN [which is a hard kind, from which staves are made]: (AA, S, K:) some say that it is ↓ A=rizapN, of the measure faAEilapN; but A 'Obeyd disapproves of this. (TA.) See also A^rozN.

A^aruz~N * and ↓ A^uruz~N and ↓ A^urozN and ↓ A^uruzN (S, Msb, K) and ↓ A^aruzN and ↓ A=ruzN (Kr, K) and ruzN (S, Msb, K) and runozN, (S, K,) the first of which is the form commonly obtaining among persons of distinction; the last but one, that commonly obtaining among the vulgar; (TA;) and the last, of the dial. of 'AbdEl-Keys; (S, TA;) [Rice;] a certain grain, (S, K,) well known: (K:) [said in the TA to be a species of bur~; but this is an improper explanation:] there are several kinds; Egyptian and Persian and Indian; and the best kind is the jwhrY [perhaps a mistake for miSorY~, or Egyptian]: it is cold and dry in the second degree; or, as some say, moderate; or, as some say, hot in the first degree; and its husk is poisonous. (El-Minháj, TA.)
A^uruz~N * : see A^aruz~N.
A=ruz~N A=rz : see A^aruz~N.
A=rizapN A=rzh A=rzp : see A^arazapN.

1 A^ara$ahu * , (TA,) aor.
Aaru$a , (TK,) inf. n. A^aro$N, (K, TA,) He scratched with the nails, or lacerated, him, [a man,] or it, [the skin, or (as in the TK) the face,] little or much, so as to bring blood or not; syn. xada$ahu. (K, * TA.) [This signification is probably derived from A^aro$N as syn. with taA^oriy$N, in which sense it seems to be the inf. n. of an obsolete verb.] -A2- A^ara$ahu, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (K, TA,) He gave him (K, * TA) the fine, or mulct, for a wound. (TA.) ― -b2- A^ara$uwhu, inf. n. as above, They sold the milk of their camels for the water of his well. (Sgh.) -A3- A^uri$a, like EuniYa, (Sgh,) inf. n. as above, (Sgh, K,) He sought to obtain, or demanded, the fine, or mulct, for a wound. Sgh, K. *)

2 A^r~$ bayona Alqawomi * , (S, L, Msb,) and bayona Alr~ajulayoni, (TA,) inf. n. taA^oriy$N, (S, Msb,) He made mischief; or excited disorder, disturbance, disagreement, discord, dissension, strife, or quarrelling; (S, L, Msb, TA;) between, or among, the people, or company of men, (S, L, Msb,) and between the two men: (TA:) accord. to some, its original is Har~a$a. (Msb.) ― -b2- And Ar~$ Aln~aAra, inf. n. as above, He kindled the fire; or made it to burn: (S, K:) and in like manner, AlHaroba (assumed tropical:) war, or the war. (S.)

8 A=y^otari$o * [written with the disjunctive alif Aiytari$o] Take thou from him the fine, or mulct, for thy xumaA$ap, q. v. (K.) ― -b2- A=y^otara$a liloxumaA$api [He surrendered himself to pay the fine, or mulct, for the injury termed xumaA$ap,] is like Aisotasolama liloqiSaASi. (K.)

A^aroDN * The making mischief; or exciting disorder, disturbance, disagreement, discord, dissension, strife, or quarrelling; [like taA^oriy$N; see 2, and see also 1;] syn. fasaAdN [in the sense of A_ifosaAdN]; (Msb;) and A_igoraA='N. (K.) ― -b2- Disagreement, discord, or dissension; and contention, or altercation: you say, bayonahumaA A^aro$N Between them two is disagreement, &c. (K.) -A2- A fine, or mulct, for a wound: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) from the first of the significations in this paragraph; (Msb;) or from its being one of the causes of contention, or altercation; or, accord. to AM, from the same word as inf. n. of A^aruw$N in the first of the senses explained in this art.; accord. to IF, originally haro$N: (TA:) pl. A^uruw$N. (Mgh, Msb.) Hence the saying mentioned by IAar, AinotaZironiY Hat~aY taEoqila falayosa laka EinodanaA A^aro$N A_il~aA AlA^asin~apu [Wait thou for me until thou accept a fine for a wound in lieu of retaliation; for thou hast no compensation for a wound to receive from us except the spearheads]: meaning, thou shalt not slay a man for whom we will ever give bloodwit. (L, TA.) ― -b2- What is diminished [of the price] by reason of a defect in a garment or piece of cloth: as being a cause of contention, or altercation. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- What is payed [by way of adjustment of the difference] between freedom from defect and defect in an article of merchandise: (Kt, K:) for when the purchaser of a garment or piece of cloth as being free from defect discovers in it a hole or other defect, contention ensues between him and the seller. (TA.) ― -b4- A bribe. (Aboo-Nahshal, Sh, K.)

maA^oruw$N *
Scratched with the nails, or lacerated, little or much, so as to bleed or not. Ru-beh says,
faqulo li*aAka AlmuzoEaji AlmaHonuw$i
A^aSobiHN famaA mino ba$arK maA^oruw$i
Then say thou to that man who is disquieted by envy, and as though he were stung, Act thou gently, for [there is no scarf-skin scratched; meaning,] my honour is uninjured, having in it no defect nor scratch. (L, * TA.)

A^araADapN, (S, M, K,) The land became thriving, or productive; (S, K;) as also ↓ AstA^rDt; (TA;) it became pleasing to the eye, and disposed by nature to yield good produce; (K, TA;) it became fruitful, and in good condition; (M;) it collected moisture, and became luxuriant with herbage; it became soft to tread upon, pleasant to sit upon, productive, and good in its herbage or vegetation: (AHn:) and A^araDati AlA^aroDu, (K,) aor.
AaruDa , (TA,) the land became abundant in herbage, or pasture. (K.) ― -b2- A^aruDa, inf. n. A^araADapN, is also said of a man, meaning (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, lowly, or submissive, and naturally disposed to good, or to do good. (L, TA,) -A2- A^araDa AlA^aroDa He found the land to be abundant in herbage, or pasture. (K.) -A3- A^uriDati Alxa$abapu, (S, A, Msb, TA,) in the pass. form, (Msb,) like EuniY, (TA,) aor. tuw^oraDu, (S, TA,) inf. n. A^aroDN, (S, A, TA,) with sukoon [to the r]; (S, TA;) and some add A^ariDat, aor. taA^oraDu, inf. n. as above; (TA; [and so in a copy of the S in the place of what here precedes;]) The piece of wood was, or became, eaten by the A^araDap, q. v. (S, A, Msb, TA.) -A4- A^ariDati AlqaroHapN, (S, M. K,) aor.
AaraDa , (S, K,) inf. n. A^araDN, (S, M,) The ulcer, or sore, became blistered, (S, M, K,) and wide, (M,) and corrupt (S, M, K) by reason of thick purulent matter, (S,) and dissundered; (M;) so says As; (TA;) as also ↓ AstA^rDt. (Sgh, K.) -A5- A^uriDa, like EuniYa, (K,) inf. n. A^aroDN; (TA;) or A^ariDa, like samiEa, aor.
AaraDa , inf. n. A^aroDN; (L;) He was, or became, affected with zukaAm [or rheum]. (L, K.)

2 Ar~D A^rD A^rDY ArD rAD rD rDY rDy , (TK,) inf. n. taA^oriyDN, (K,) He depastured the herbage of the earth, or land: and he sought after it: (K:) or, accord. to some, taA^oriyDN denotes this latter signification with respect to a place of alighting, or abiding: (TA:) and you say [also], Almanozila ↓ tA^r~D he sought after, and chose, the place for alighting, or abiding: (M, TA:) and lilomanozili ↓ tarakotu AlHaY~a yataA^ar~aDuwna I left the tribe seeking after a tract of country in which to alight, or abide. (TA.) -A2- He, or it, rendered heavy; [app. meaning slow, or sluggish; see 5;] syn. vaq~ala. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b2- He made to tarry; to tarry and wait, or expect; or to be patient, and tarry, and wait, or expect. (Ibn- 'Abbád, K.)

4 A=rD A=rD , inf. n. A_iyoraADN: see 5. -A2- maA A=raDu h*aA AlmakaAna How abundant is the herbage (Eu$ob) of this place! or, as some say, maA A=raDa h*ihi AlA^aroDa How level, or soft, and productive, and good, is this land! (Lh, AHn.) -A3- A=raDahu, (S, K, [in the CK, incorrectly, AaraDahu,]) inf. n. as above, (S,) He (God) caused him to be affected with zukaAm [or rheum]. (S, K.)

5 tAr~D tArD
It (herbage) became in such a state that it might be cut. (S, K.) -A2- He clave, or kept, to the ground, not quitting it: (A:) and ↓ A=rD, inf. n. A_iyraADN, he remained upon the ground: and tA^r~D biAlmakaAni he remained fixed in the place, not quitting it: or he waited, or expected, and stood upon the ground: and, as also bAlmkAn ↓ AstA^rD, he remained, and tarried, or tarried in expectation, in the place: or he remained fixed therein: (TA:) and tA^r~D alone, he tarried, loitered, stayed, waited, or paused in expectation: (S, TA:) and he was, or became, heavy, slow, or sluggish, inclining, or propending, to the ground; (S, K;) [as also ↓ AstA^rD, accord. to IB's explanation of its act. part. n.] You say, fulaAnN A_ino raA^aY maToEamFA taA^ar~aDa waA_ino A^aSaAba maToEamFA A^aEoraDa [Such a one, if he see food, cleaves, or keeps, to the ground, not quitting it; and if he obtain food, turns away: or tA^r~D may here be rendered agreeably with the explanation next following]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- jaA='i fulaAnN yataA^ar~aDu liY (S, K, * TA) Such a one came asking, or petitioning, for a thing that he wanted, to me; syn. yataSad~aY, and yataEar~aDu; (S, K, TA;) and taDar~aEa is also a syn. of taA^ar~aDa, used in this manner. (TA.) -A3- See also 2, in two places.

10 A_isotaAoraDa see 5, in two places. ― -b2- AstA^rD Als~aHaAbu The clouds expanded, or spread: or, as some say, became fixed, or stationary. (M, TA.) -A2- See also 1, first signification: -A3- and see 1 again, last signification but one.

AlA^aroDu * [The earth;] that whereon are mankind: (TA:) [and earth, as opposed to heaven: and the ground, as meaning the surface of the earth, on which we tread and sit and lie; and the floor: without Al signifying a land, or country: and a piece of land or ground: and land, or soil, or ground, considered in relation to its quality:] it is fem.: (S, A, Msb, K:) and is a coll. gen. n.; (S, A, K;) of which the n. un. should be A^aroDapN, but this they did not say: (S:) or a pl. having no sing.; (A, K;) for A^aroDapN has not been heard: (K:) its pl. is A^araDaAtN, (S, K,) in [some of] the copies of the K A^aroDaAtN, (TA,) for they sometimes form the pl. of a word which has not the fem. p with A and t, as in the instance of EurusaAtN; (S;) and A^araDuwna, [which is more common,] (AZ, AHn, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) with fet-h to the r, (AZ, AHn, Mgh, Msb,) and with w and n, though a fem. has not its pl. formed [regularly] with w and n unless it is of the defective kind, like vubapN and ZubapN, but they have made the w and n [in this instance] a substitute for the A and t which they have elided [from A^araDaAtN], and have left the fet-hah of the r as it was; (S;) but they also said A^aroDuwna, (AZ, AHn, S,) sometimes, making the r quiescent; (S;) and A^uruwDN (AZ, AHn, Msb, K) is sometimes used as a pl., as in the saying maA A^akovara A^uruwDa baniY fulaAnK [How many are the lands of the sons of such a one!]; (TA;) and another [and very common] pl. is [A^araADK, with the article written] AlA^araADiY, contr. to rule, (S, Msb, K,) as though they had formed a pl. from A=ruDN; (S;) thus written in all the copies of the S; [accord. to SM; but in one copy of the S, I find kaA^an~ahumo jamaEuwA AArADFA; and in another, ArDFA;] and in one copy [is added], “ thus it is found in his [J's] handwriting; ” but IB says that correctly he should have said A^aroDaY, like A^aroTaY; for as to A=ruDN, its regular pl. would be A^awaAriDu; and [SM says] I have found it observed in a marginal note to the S that the pl. of A=ruDN would be A^aA=riDu, like as A^akaAlibu is pl. of A^akolubN; and wherefore did he not say that AlArADY is a pl. of an unused sing., like layaAlK and A^ahaAlK, so that it is as though it were pl. of A^aroDaApN, like as layaAlK is pl. of layolaApN? yet if any one should propose the plea that it may be formed by transposition from A^aA=riDu, he would not say what is improbable; its measure being in this case A^aEaAlifu; the word being A^araADiy^u, and the ' being changed into Y: (TA:) accord. to Abu-l-Khattáb, (S,) A=raADN is also a pl. of A^aroDN, (S, K,) like as A=haAlN is a pl. of A^aholN; (S;) but IB says that, in the opinion of the critics, the truth with respect to what is related on the authority of Abu-l-Khattáb is, that from A^aroDN and A^aholN are formed A^araADK and A^ahaAlK, as though they were pls. of A^aroDaApN and A^aholaApN; like as they said layolapN and layaAl, as though this were pl. of layolaApN. (TA.) It is said in proverbs, A^ajomaEu mina AlA^aroDi [More comprehensive than the earth]: (TA:) and A=manu mina AlA^aroDi [More trustworthy than the earth, in which treasures are securely buried]: and A^a$ad~u mina AlA^aroDi [Harder than the earth, or ground]: (A, TA:) and A^a*al~u mina AlA^aroDi [More vile, or more submissive, than the earth, or ground]. (TA.) And you say, mano A^aTaAEaniY kunotu lahu A^aroDaA (tropical:) [Whoso obeyeth me, I will be to him as ground whereon one treads]; denoting submissiveness. (A, TA.) And fulaAnN A_inN Duriba faA^aroDN (tropical:) [Such one, if he be beaten, is like ground]; i. e. he cares not for beating. (A, TA.) One says also, laA A^aroDa laka [Mayest thou have no land, or country! or thou hast no land, or country]; like as one says, laA A^um~a laka. (S, K,) ― -b2- [And hence,] huwa Abonu A^aroDK He is a stranger, (A, K, TA,) of whom neither father nor mother is known. (TA.) ― -b3- Aibonu AlA^aroDi [with the art. Al prefixed to the latter word] is A certain plant, (AHn, K,) which comes forth upon the summits of the [hills called] A=kaAm, having a stem (A^aSol), but not growing tall, (AHn,) which resembles hair, and is eaten, (AHn, K,) and quickly dries up; (AHn;) a species of baqol, as also binotu AlA^aroDi: (S in art. bnY:) and banaAtu AlA^aroDi plants: (M in art. bsr:) and the places which are concealed from the pastor. (S in that art.) Also The pool that is left by a torrent: (T in art. bnY:) and banaAtu AlA^aroDi pools in which are remains of water: (IAar in TA art. bsr:) and rivulets. (T in art. bnY.) ― -b4- A^aroDN is also used to signify (assumed tropical:) A carpet; or anything that is spread: and in this sense, in poetry, it is sometimes made masc. (Msb.) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) Anything that is low. (S, K.) And (tropical:) The lower, or lowest, part of the legs of a horse or the like: (S, K:) or the legs of a camel or of a horse or the like: and the part that is next to the ground thereof. (TA.) You say baEiyrN $adiydu AlA^aroDi (tropical:) A camel strong in the legs. (TA.) And farasN baEiydN maA bayoma A^aroDihi wasamaAy^ihi (tropical:) A horse that is large and tall. (A, TA.) ― -b6- Also, of a man, (tropical:) The knees and what is beneath, or below, (lit. after,) them. (TA.) ― -b7- And of a sandal, (assumed tropical:) [The lower surface of the sole;] the part that touches the ground. (TA.) -A2- A febrile shivering; a tremor: (S, K:) or vertigo: or it signifies also vertigo arising from a relaxed state, and occasioning a defluxion from the nose and eyes. (TA.) I'Ab is related to have said, on the occasion of an earthquake, A^azulozilati AlA^aroDu A^amo biY A^aroDN, (S,) i. e. [Hath the earth been made to quake, or is there in me] a tremor? or a vertigo? (TA.) [A^aholu AlA^aroDi signifies A certain class of the jinn, or genii; by whom human beings are believed to be possessed, and affected by an involuntary tremor; whence it seems that this appellation may perhaps be from A^aroDN as signifying “ a tremor. ” See maA^oruwDN: and see xabalN, as explained in the S.] ― -b2- Also Rheum; syn. zukaAmN: (S, K:) in this sense masc.; or, accord. to Kr, fem., on the authority of Ibn-Ahmar. (TA.) -A3- See also maA^oruwDN.
A^araDN * : see A^araDapN.
A^uroDapN * : see what next follows.

A_iroDapN A^rD A^rDY A^rDh A^rDp ArDh ArDp rAD rD rDY rDy of herbage, What suffices the camels, or other pasturing animals, for a year: (IAar, AHn, M:) or abundant herbage or pasture; as also ↓ A^uroDapN and ↓ A_iraDapN. (K.)

A^araDapN * [The wood-fretter;] a certain insect that eats wood, (S A, Msb, K,) well known; (A, K;) it is a white worm, resembling the ant, appearing in the days of the [season called] rabiyE: (TA:) there are two kinds: one kind is small, like the large of the *ar~ [or grubs of ants]; and this is the bane of wood in particular: (AHn, TA:) or this kind is the bane of wood and of other things, and is a white worm with a black head, not having wings, and it penetrates into the earth, and builds for itself a habitation of clay, or soil; and this is said to be that which ate the staff of Solomon [as is related in the Kur xxxiv. 13, where it is called daAb~apu AlA^aroDi, as is said in the A]: (TA:) the other kind [is the termite, or white ant; termes fatale of Linn.; called by Forskål (in his Descr. Animalium &c., p. 96,) termes arda, destructor; and this] is like a large common ant, having wings; it is the bane of everything that is of wood, and of plants; except that it does not attack what is moist, or succulent; and it has legs: (AHn, TA:)
the pl. is ↓ A^araDN (AHn, Msb, TA) and A^araDaAtN; (Msb;) or, as some [more properly] say, A^araDN is a quasi-pl. [or coll. gen.] n. (AHn, TA.) It is said in a prov., A=kalu mina AlA^araDapi [More consuming than the wood-fretter, or the termite]. (TA.) And in another, A^afosadu mina AlA^araDapi [More marring, or injuring, or destructive, than the wood-fretter, or the termite.] (A, TA.)
A^ariDapN * : see A^ariyDN.
A_iraDapN A^rD A^rDY A^rDh A^rDp ArDh ArDp rAD rD rDY rDy : see A_iroDapN.
A^aruwDN * : see A^aryDN.

A^ariyDN * part. n. of A^aruDa. ― -b2- You say A^aroDN A^ariyDapN (S, A, K) and ↓ A^ariDapN (TA) Land that is thriving, or productive; (S, A, K;) pleasing to the eye; (AA, S, A, K;) and disposed by nature to yield good produce: (A, K, TA:) or fruitful; increasing in plants or herbage: (IAar:) or level, or soft: (ISh:) or that collects moisture, and becomes luxuriant with herbage; that is soft to tread upon, pleasant to sit upon, productive, and good in its herbage or vegetation: (AHn:) it also signifies a wide land; syn. EariyDapN: (TA:) and A_iraADNK [as pl. of A^ariyDN] is syn. with EiraADN and wisaAE; (AA, K, TA;) as though the ' were a substitute for the E. (TA.) ― -b3- A^ariyDN is also an imitative sequent to EariyDN; (S, K;) as in the phrase A^ariyDN $aYo'N EariyDN [A very wide thing]: (S:) or it signifies fat, as an epithet: (K:) some use it in this sense without EriyD, applied to a kid. (S.) And you say, AimoraA^apN EariyDapN A^ariyDapN [A very wide, or wide and fat, woman; or, as seems to be indicated in the TA in art. EraD, prolific and perfect]; and in like manner, ↓ muw^oriDapN. (TA.) You say also rajulN A^ariyDN, (S,) and liloxayori ↓ A^aruwDN, (A,) A man lowly, or submissive; (S;) naturally disposed to good, or to do good. (S, A.) And nafosN waAsiEN A^ariyDN: see raAbiTN.

huwaA=raDuhumo bihi hwA=rDhm bh hwA=rDhm bp
He is the most adapted, meet, suited, fitted, or fit, of them, for it; or most worthy of them of it. (K.) And huwaA=raDuhumo A^ano yafoEala *lika He is the most adapted, &c., or most worthy, of them to do that. (As, S.)
muw^oriDapN * : see A^ariyDN.

maA^oruwDN * Wood eaten by the A^araDap [or woodfretter, or termite, but generally meaning the former]; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also ↓ A^aroDN. (TA.) -A2- A person affected with xabal [q. v.] from the jinn, or genii, and [what are called] A^aholu AlA^aroDi, (S, K,) i. e. (so accord. to the S and TA, but in the K “ and ”) he who moves about his head and body involuntarily. (S, K.) ― -b2- A person affected with zukaAm [or rheum]: (S, K:) accord. to Sgh, [who seems, like J, not to have known A^uriDa,] from A=raDahu; (Sgh, TA;) whereas by rule, [if from A=riDahu,] it should be muw^oraDN. (TA.)

fasiylN musotaA^oriDN * , and wadiy~apN musotaA^oriDapN, A young palm-tree, and a small young palm-tree, having a root in the ground: such as grows forth from the trunk of the mother-tree is called raAkibN. (S, K.) ― -b2- musotaA^oriDN also signifies Heavy, slow, or sluggish, inclining, or propending, to the ground. (IB.)

1 AarVTa [The unaugmented verb from this root seems to be unknown, if it were ever in use, for it is not mentioned, though the pass. part. n., maA^oruwTN, is mentioned as having three significations, which see below.]
2 Aar~aTa see 4.

4 A=raTati AlA^aroDu * , (AHeyth, K,) of the measure A^afoEalat, [originally] with two alifs, (TA,) [aor. yuw^oriTu, inf. n. A_iyraATN,] The land produced the kind of trees called A^aroTFY [or A^aroTaY]; (AHeyth, K;) as also A^aroTat, inf. n. A_iroTaA='N; or this is a corruption, attributable to J: so says the author of the K, following AHeyth: but it is no corruption, for it is mentioned by the authors on verbs and by ISd and others; (MF, TA;) for instance, by AHn, in his book on plants, and by IF, in the Mj: (TA:) [and J mentions it in its proper place, in art. rTY, as well as in the present art.:] ↓ A^ar~aTat, with the r musheddedeh, has also been found in the handwriting of certain of the men of letters; but this is a corruption. (K.)

A^ariTN *
A colour like that of the A^aroTFy [or A^aroTay]. (Sgh, K.)

A^aroTFy * , (Mbr, S, K,) of the measure faEolFY, because you say A^adiymN maA^oruwTN, [explained below,] (Mbr, S,) the alif (Mbr, S, K) ending it (Mbr) [written Y] being a letter of quasi-coordination, (S, K,) not to denote the fem. gender, (Mbr, S,) its n. un. being A^aroTaApN, (Mbr, S, K,) wherefore it is with tenween when indeterminate, but not when determinate: (S, K:) or it is of the measure A^afoEalN, (Mbr, * S,) the last letter being radical, (Mbr,) because you say A^adiymN maroTiy~u, (Mbr, S,) and in this case it should be mentioned among words with an infirm letter [for the last radical], and is with tenween both when determinate and when indeterminate; (S;) [but this is a mistake, for when it is determinate, it can be with tenween only if used as a proper name; therefore,] IB observes, that if you make its last letter radical, its measure is A^afoEal, and a word of this measure, if a subst., is imperfectly decl. when determinate, but perfectly decl. when indeterminate: (TA:) [the author of the K copies the error of the S, saying, “ or its alif is radical, ” (meaning its last letter,) “ and in this case it is always with tenween; ” and he adds, “ or, ” (for which he should have said “ and, ”) its measure is A^afoEal: to all which it is necessary to add, that some of the grammarians hold it to be also of the measure faEolaY, ending with a fem. alif, and therefore assign to it no n. un.:] A kind of tree, (S, K,) of those growing in sands, (S, TA,) resembling the kind called EiDaAh, growing as a branch [in the TA EaSabFA, for which I read guDonFA,] from a single stem, to the height of the stature of a man, the leaves whereof are what are termed hadab [q. v., and are included among those termed xuwS], (AHn, TA,) and its flower is like that of the xilaAf [or salix ægyptia], (AHn, K,) save in being smaller, the colour being one; and the odour thereof is pleasant: it grows in sands, and therefore the poets make frequent mention of the wild bulls' and cows' taking refuge among this and other trees of the sands, burrowing at their roots to hide themselves there, and to protect themselves from the heat and cold and rain, but not among the trees in hard ground, for burrowing in the sand is easy: (AHn, TA:) its fruit is like the Eun~aAb [or jujube], bitter, and is eaten by camels in its fresh moist state, and its roots are red, (AHn, K,) intensely red: (AHn, TA:) AHn adds, a man of the Benoo-Asad informed me, that the leaves (hadab) of the ArTy are red like the red pomegranate: its fruit also is red: (TA:) the dual is A^aroTayaAni: (AHn, TA:) and the pl. A^aroTayaAtN and A^araATayi and A^araATK, (AHn, K,) in the accus. case A^raATiy. (TA.)
A^aroTawiY~N * : see what next follows.
A^aroTaAwiY~u * : see what next follows.

maA^oruwTN * A hide tanned with A^aroTFy; (S, K;) i. e. with the leaves thereof; (S in art. rTy;) as also ↓ muw^aroTFy; (TA;) and so maroTiy~N. (S.) ― -b2- A camel having a complaint from eating A^aroTFy: (L, K: *) and a camel that eats A^aroTFy, (AZ, S, K,) and keeps to it; (K;) as also ↓ A^aroTawiY~u (AZ, S, K) and ↓ A^aroTaAwiY~N. (Ibn-'Abbád, Sgh, L, K.)
muw^aroTFy * : see what next precedes.

2 A^ar~afahaA * , (T, M, Mgh,) namely Ald~aAra, and AlA^aroDa, (T, M,) inf. n. taA^oriyfN, (T,) He set, or put, limits, or boundaries, [A^uraf,] to it; (M, Mgh;) and marked it out: (Mgh:) or he divided it; and set, or put, limits, or boundaries, to it: (T:) namely the house, and the land. (T, M.) And A^ur~ifa EalaY AlmaAli, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or ElY AlA^aroDi, inf. n. as above, (K,) The property, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or the land, (K,) had limits, or boundaries, set, or put, to it, (S, Msb, K,) or around it; (Mgh;) and was divided. (K.) When this is done, it is said that there is no $ufogap [or right of preemption] with respect to the property. (S, Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- taA^oriyfN also signifies The tying a rope, or cord, so as to form a knot or knots. (K.)

A_an~ahu lagiY A_irofi majodK Anh lgy Arf mjd
i. q. A_rovi majodK [Verily he is of a glorious origin, race, or stock]: mentioned by Yaakoob as an instance of a change of letters. (M.)

A^urofapN *
A limit, or boundary, (As, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) making a separation (Msb) between two pieces of land; (Msb, K;) a sign, or mark, (As, T, S, Mgh,) of the limits, or boundaries, between two pieces of land: (S:) and a separation between houses and estates: (M:) and a dam between two pieces of land sown or for sowing: (Th, M:) Yaakoob asserts that its f is a substitute for the v of A^urovapN [which is, however, less com-
mon]: (M:) the pl. is A^urafN, (T, S, M, &c.,) signifying, accord. to Lh, like A^uravN, limits, or boundaries, between two pieces of land [&c.]; (T;) and it is said in a trad., that these cut off Al$~ufoEap [i. e. the right of preemption]; (T, S, Mgh;) meaning, in the language of the people of El- Hijáz, signs, or marks, and limits, or boundaries. (T.) Th relates that an Arab woman said, jaEala Ealay~a zawojiY A^urofapF laA A^ajuwzuhaA, i. e. My husband set me a sign, or mark, [or limit,] beyond which I should not pass. (M.) And A^urofapu A^ajalK signifies An extreme limit of a period of existence. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b2- Also A knot. (Sgh, K.)

A^urofiY~N *
A measurer of land, (K, * TA,) who marks it with limits, or boundaries. (TA.)

huwamuw^aArifiY *
He has his limit, or boundary, next to mine, in dwelling, and in place: (K:) a phrase like huwamutaAximiY. (TA.)

1 A^ariqa * , aor.
Aaraqa , inf. n. A^araqN, (T, S, K, &c.,) He was sleepless, or wakeful, or sleep departed from him, (JK, T,) by night; (T;) i. q. sahira (S, Mgh, Sgh, K) biAll~ayoli; (Sgh, K;) or i. q. sahida: (S, and L and K in art. shd:) or sleep departed from him by reason of a malady, or a distracting accident or event: (M:) or he was sleepless or wakeful (sahira) in a case that was disliked, or evil; sahira having a general sense: (M, F:) or he shut his eyes one while and opened them another, [being unable to continue sleeping,] whereas sahira signifies he did not sleep at all: (Deewán of the Hudhalees, cited by Freytag in his Lex.:) or A^araqN signifies sleeplessness, or wakefulness, engendered by anxiety and grief: (Har p. 162:) and ↓ Ay^trq [with the disjunctive alif written Aiytaraqa] signifies the same as A^ariqa. (S, K.) -A2- A^uriqati Aln~axolapu [and A^uriqa Alz~roEu] The palm-tree [and the seed-produce] was affected, or smitten, by what is termed A^araqaAn. (JK.)

2 A^ar~aqaniY ka*aA * , (JK, S, K, *) inf. n. taA^oriyqN. (S, Mgh,) Such a thing rendered me, or caused me to be, sleepless or wakeful; (JK, S, Mgh, * K; *) as also ↓ A=rqnY, (K,) inf. n. A_iyraAqN. (TA.)

8 A_iAotaraqa see 1.

A^aruqN * : see what next follows.

A^ariqN *
Sleepless or wakeful (S, K) by night (K) [by reason of a malady, or a distracting accident or event, &c. (see 1)]; as also ↓ A=riqN (IF, K) and ↓ A^aruqN and ↓ A^uruqN; or the last signifies habitually so. (TA.)
A^uruqN * : see what next precedes.

A^araqaAnN * (JK, S, K) and A^aruqaAnN and A^aroqaAnN and A_iriqaAnN and A_iroqaAnN and ↓ A^aroqN and ↓ A^uraAqN (K) i. q. yaraqaAnN; (JK, S, K;) A^raqaAnN being a dial. var. of this last; (S;) or the hemzeh is a substitute for the Y; (L;) and yrqAn is the word most commonly known; (K;) A blight, or disease, which affects, or smites, seed-produce: (JK, S, K:) and a disease [namely jaundice] which affects, or smites, man, (S, K,) causing the person to become yellow [or blackish]; (TA;) it is a disease which changes the colour of the person excessively to yellowness or blackness, by the flowing of the yellow or black humour to the skin and the part next thereto, without putridity. (Ibn-Seenà [Avicenna], K.)
A^uraAqN * : see A^araqaAnN.
A=riqN A=rq : see A^ariqN.

ziroEN maA^oruwqN *
Seed-produce affected, or smitten, with a blight, or disease, (JK, S, K,) such as is termed A^araqaAn; (JK, S;) as also mayoruwqN [from yaraqaAn]: (S, K:) and naxolapN maA^oruwqapN a palm-tree affected, or smitten, therewith. (JK, TA.)

1 A^arakati AlA_ibilu * , aor.
Aaruka and
Aarika , inf. n. A^uruwkN, The camels fed upon the kind of tree called A^araAk: (S, Msb, K:) or remained, or continued, among trees of that kind, (ISk, S, K,) i. e., what are termed HamoD, (ISk, S,) eating them: (K:) or found, or lighted on, any trees whatever, and remained, or continued. among them: (K:) or, accord. to As, kept in a place (bimakaAnK), not removing therefrom: (ISk, S:) or remained, or continued, in a place for the purpose of feeding upon the ArAk: and hence the signification next following, which is tropical. (Er-Rághib.) ― -b2- A^araka biAlmakaAni, (S, Msb, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Msb, TA,) (tropical:) He (a man, S) remained, continued, or abode, in the place, (S, Msb, K,) not quitting it; (TA;) as also A^arika, aor.
Aaraka , (K,) inf. n. A^arakN. (TA.) ― -b3- And A^araka, (K,) inf. n. A^arokN and A^uruwkN (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He persisted, or persevered, syn. laj~a, (K,) i. e. A^aSar~a, (T, K,) in an affair. (T, K.) ― -b4- And, (K,) inf. n. A^uruwikN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He held back, or drew back, (taA^ax~ara,) in an affair. (K.) -A2- A^araka AlA_ibila, (K,) aor.
Aaruka , (TA,) inf. n. A^arokN, (K,) He fed the camels, or made them to feed, upon the kind of the tree called A^araAk: or made them to remain, or continue, among trees of that kind: or brought them to any trees whatever, and made them to remain, or continue, among them. (K.) ― -b2- A^araka AlA^amorafiY Eunuqihi, (L, K,) inf. n. A^uruwkN, so in the L, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He compelled him, or constrained him, to do the thing, or affair; or made him to keep, or cleave, to it. (L, K.) -A3- A^arakat AlA_ibilu, aor.
Aaraka , (S, K,) inf. n. A^arakN; (S;) and A^arakat, aor.
Aaruka ; and A^urikat; (K;) The camels had a complaint, or suffered pain, (S, K,) of, or in, their bellies, (S,) from eating the A^araAk. (S, K.)
2 A^ar~akahaA * , inf. n. taA^oriykN, He concealed her (namely a woman, TA) by means of an A^ariykap, q. v. (K.)

8 Ay^trk * [written with the disjunctive alif Aiytaraka] It (the kind of tree called A^araAk) became firm, strong, or compact, and big: (O, K:) or attained to maturity: (K:) or became tangled, or luxuriant, and abundant. (TA.)
A_irokN A^rk Ark rA^Y rk wrY |r |rk : see A^araAkN. ― -b2- Eu$obN lahu A_irokN Herbage in which the camels remain, or continue. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

A^araAkN A^arikN *
Abundant, and tangled, or luxuriant, trees of the kind called ArAk; (K, TA; [in the CK A=rikN, but said in the TA to be like katifN;]) as also ↓ muw^otarikN. (K.) ― -b2- A^aroDN A^arikapN Land abounding with the kind of trees called ArAk. (K.) ― -b3- A_ibilN A^arikapN and A^araAkay, [the latter being the pl.,] Camels having a complaint, or suffering pain, (S, K,) of, or in, their bellies, (S,) from eating the ArAk. (S, K.)

A^araAkN * The [kind of trees termed] HamoD; (AHn, K;) as also ↓ A_irokN: (Ibn-'Abbád, K:) and (K) certain trees of the kind termed HayoD, (T, S, Msb, K,) well known, bearing what resemble bunches of grapes, (T, TA,) and of which sticks for cleaning the teeth are made, (AHn, Aboo-Ziyád, Msb, K,) that is, of its branches, (AHn, Aboo-Ziyád, Msb,) and of its roots, which latter are more esteemed for this purpose: (Aboo-Ziyád:) it is the best of the trees of which the branches are used for this purpose, and the best of those upon which beasts feed with respect to the odour of the milk [yielded by those beasts]: (AHn:) or one of the large thorny trees, upon which camels feed: the milk of [the camels that feed upon] it is the best of milk: and it is not allowable to prohibit the public from feeding their beasts upon it: (Mgh:) or a kind of tall, smooth, or soft, tree, abounding with leaves and branches, the wood of which is weak, and which has a fruit in bunches, or racemes, called bariyr, one [bunch] of which will fill the hand: (Msb:) n. un. with p: (S, Msb:) pl. (of the n. un., T) A^urukN (T, K) and A^araAy^iku, (IB, K,) which is a form sometimes used, and is also pl. of the n. un. (IB.) ― -b2- A piece of land (K, TA) in which are trees of the kind thus called. (TA.)
A^ariykN * : see the end of the next paragraph.

A^ariykapN *
A raised couch (sariyr) in a Hajalap, (K, and Jel in xviii. 30,) which is a tent, or pavilion, or chamber, (byt,) adorned with cloths and curtains, [or a kind of curtained canopy or alcove or the like,] for a bride; (Jel ubi suprà;) a raised couch (sryr) in a Hajalap, and having before it a curtain; when alone, not thus called: (TA:) or a bed, or thing spread upon the ground to sit or lie upon, in a Hajalap: (Zj, TA:) or a raised couch (sryr), absolutely, whether in a Hjlp or not: (TA:) or [in the CK “ and ”] anything upon which one reclines such as is termed sariyr or mnaS~ap or firaA$: (K, TA:) or [in some copies of the K “ and ”] a raised couch (sryr) ornamentally furnished and decorated, in a [tent, or pavilion, or the like, such as is termed] qub~ap, or in a chamber, or an apartment, bayot, [or by this may be meant here a tent of any kind, though I think that in this instance it more probably denotes an inner apartment, or an alcove,]) which, when there is not in it a sryr, is termed Hajalap: (S, Sgh, K:) accord. to Er-Rághib, so named because
originally made of [the wood of] the A^araAk; or because it is a place of abode; from A^arak biAlmakaAni “ be abode in the place: ” (TA:) pl A^araAy^iku (S, K) and [coll. gen. n.] ↓ A^ariykN. (K.)

A^awaAriku. (S, Msb.) Their milk is said to be the best of milk. (TA.)

A_iramN A^rm A_rm Arm rAm rm rmY wrm (T, S, M, K) and ↓ A^arimN, (M, K,) like katifN, (K,) or ↓ A_iromN, (so in a copy of the M,) and ↓ A_iramiY~N and ↓ A^aramiY~N, (M, K,) from Lh, (TA,) or ↓ A^aromiY~N, from Lh, (so in a copy of the M,) and ↓ A_iromiY~N, from Lh, (TA,) and yaramiY~N, (M, K,) from Lh, (TA,) and A^ayoramiY~N, (T, K,) A sign, or mark, set up to show the way; (M, K;) stones set up as a sign, or mark, to show the way in the desert: (S:) or particularly one belonging to [the tribe of]' Ád: (M, K:) accord. to ISh, the A_iram is [a thing] like a man in a standing posture upon the head of a hill, whereby one is directed to the right way, and whereby the land is marked, composed of stones set one upon another, and is only the work of the Muslims, and such is made by people in the present day, upon the road: (T:) or such as was made by the people in the time of ignorance, who were accustomed, when they found a thing in their way and could not take it with them, to leave upon it some stones, whereby to know it, until, when they returned, they took it: (TA:) the pl. [of pauc.] is A=raAmN and [of mult.] A^uruwmN (ISh, T, S, M, K:) or A^uruwmN signifies the graves, or sepulchres, of [the tribe of]' Ád. (M, K.) -A2- [A_iramN in the phrase A_iramu *aAtu AlEimaAdi (see art. Emd) is a proper name; but whether of a place, or a tribe, or an individual, is disputed: it is commonly believed to be the name of The terrestrial paradise of Sheddád the son of 'Ád: see Bd lxxxix. 6.]

Land in which there is not a root, or stock, of a tree; as though it were ↓ maA^oruwmap [or extirpated]: (O:) or land in which neither root nor branch is left; as also ↓ maA^oruwmapN. (M, K.)
A^aromiY~N * and A_iromiY~N and A^aramiY~N and A_iramiY~N: see A_iramN.

A^aSol, (T, S, M, K,) of a tree (T, S) of any kind; (T;) and of a horn: (S:) or, of a tree, [or plant, the root-stock, or rhizoma, or] the part from which branch off the Euruwq [or roots properly so called]. [See an instance of its use voce janobapN; another, voce jinovN; and another, voce jazarN.]) ― -b2- And [hence,] (assumed tropical:) The origin, or stock, of a man: (TA:) (tropical:) The origin of Hasab [or grounds of pretension to respect or honour, &c.]. (Har p. 99.)
sanapN A=rimapN snp A=rmh snp A=rmp (S, K, TA [in the CK, erroneously, AarimapN]) An extirpating year of dearth or drought or sterility: (S:) or a year of dearth &c. cutting off people. (K.)

1 A^arati Ald~aAb~apu marobaTahaA * , (M, K,) and miEolafahaA, [aor. taA^oriY,] inf. n. A^aroYN, (M,) The beast kept to its place where it was tied, (M, K,) and to its manger. (M.) ― -b2- A^arati Ald~aAb~ipu A_ilaY Ald~aAb~api, (K,) aor. as above, (S,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) The beast joined itself, or became joined, to the beast, and kept with it to one manger. (S, K.)

2 A^ar~ayotu lild~aAb~api * , (S, M, K,) and Ald~aAb~apa, (M, K,) inf. n. tA^oriyapN, (S, M, K,) I made for the beast an A=riY~ [q. v.], (S, * M,) or an A=riy~ap. (K: [in the CK Aariy~ap; but this and A=riy~ap are probably mistakes of copyists.]) ― -b2- A^ar~aYa Al$~aYo'a, inf. n. as above, He rendered the thing permanent, or steadfast; confirmed it; established it. (M, K.) Hence, in a trad., Aall`hum~a A^ar~imaA bayonahumo, i. e. O God, make permanent, or confirm, or establish, what is between them, of love, or affection; said in praying for a man and his wife. (M, TA.) Mohammad is also related to have said, with this intention, Aall`hum~a A^ar~ibayonahumaA, meaning O God, render permanent, or confirm, the union, or concord, or love, of them tow; (A'Obeyd, TA;) or cause union to subsist, and render permanent, or confirm, love, or affection, between them two: (IAth, TA:) or Aall`hum~a A^ar~i kul~a waAHidK minohumaA SaAHibahu, meaning O God, confine each of them two to the other, so that the heart of neither may become turned away to any but that other: the correct form of speech, however, is Ealay SaAHibihi, unless it be like taEal~aqotu fulaAnFA for tEl~qt bifulaAnK. (IAmb, TA.)

I joined the beast to another beast, and made it to keep with the other to one manger: (S, in the present art.; and K:) or A=rayotu Ald~aAb~atayoni I joined the two beasts together, and made them both keep to one manger. (So accord. to the S in art. wA^r.)

(M, K.) ― -b2- tA^r~YEanohu He remained behind him, not going with him; held back, or hung back, from him. (M, K.)

A=riY~N A=rY A=ry , (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) with medd and teshdeed, (TA,) [originally A=ruwYN,] of the measure faAEuwlN, (T, S, Mgh, Msb,) from taA^ar~aY biAlmakaAni as explained above, (Mgh,) or hence this verb, (Msb,) and ↓ A^ariY~N, (M, K, * [but accord. to the latter, the second form may be either thus (as it is written in the M) or ↓ A=rK, (agreeably with the latter of the two pls. mentioned below,) for the two forms are there expressed by AlA=riY~u wa yuxaf~afu, (in the CK, erroneously, AlAarY~u w yuxaf~afu,) and in another place in the K we find it written ↓ A=riy~ap, or, as in the CK, ↓ Aariy~ap,]) The place of confinement of a beast: (ISk, T, S:) or i. q. A=xiy~apN; (M, Mgh, Msb, K;) used in this sense by the Arabs; (Mgh, Msb,;) or sometimes having this application; meaning a rope to which a beast is tied in its place of confinement;; (S;) or a loop of a rope to which a beast is tied in that place: (Mgh:) so called because it withholds beasts from escaping: (TA:) sometimes, (Msb,) improperly, (ISK, T, S,) by the vulgar, and by the lawyers, (Mgh,) applied to a manger::(ISk, T, S, Mgh, Msb:) pl. A^awaAriY~u (T, S, Mgh, Msb) and A^awaArK (S.) -A2- Hence, A^awaAriY~u is metaphorically applied to (tropical:) The places (A^aHoyaAz) that are made, in shops, for grain and other things: and to (tropical:) the water-tanks, or troughs,
in a bath. (Mgh.) -A3- El-'Ajjáj says, describing a [wild] bull, and his covert,
waA@EotaAda A^arobaAD~aA lahaA A=riY~u
meaning [And he frequented lodging-places] having a firm foundation for the quiet of the wild animals therein [as having been from the first occupied by such animals and unfrequented by men]. (S.)— A=riY~u is also said to signify Land of a kind between even and rugged. (M.)
A=riy~apN A=ryh A=ryp : see A=riY~N.

1 A^az~ati Alqidoru * , (S, K,) or Alburomapu, (A,) aor
Aazu3a (S, K) and
Aazi3a , (K,) inf. n. A^aziyzN (S, A, K) and A^az~N and A^azaAzN, (K,) The cooking-pot made a sound in boiling: (S, accord. to an explanation there given of the inf. n.; and A:) or boiled: (S:) or boiled vehemently; (K;) as also ↓ Ay^tz~t [written with the disjunctive alif Aiyt~az~at], (S, K,) inf. n. A@y^otizaAzN; (S;) and ↓ tA^z~t, (K,) inf. N. taA^az~uzN: (TA:) or all signify it boiled not vehemently. (K.) It is said in a trad., kaAna yuSal~iY wa lijawofihi A^aziyz kaA^aziyzi A@lomirojali mina A@lobukaA='i (tropical:) [He used to pray, his inside making a sound like the sound of the boiling of the cooking-pot, by reason of weeping]: (S, A, Mgh:) this is said of Mohammad: Azyz meaning boiling, or the sound thereof. (Mgh.) ― -b2- A^az~ati Als~aHaAbapu The cloud made a sound from afar. (K.) [In this instance, the TA assigns only one form to the aor., namely
Aazi3a , and gives only A^az~N and A^aziyzN as inf. ns.] A^aziyzN signifies The sounding of thunder; (S, A;*) and of a millstone. (A.) You say, haAlaniY A^aziyzu Alr~aEodi [The sounding of the thunder terrified me]: and Sad~aEaniY A^aziyzu Alr~aHaY [The sounding of the mill-stone made my head to ache]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- Also, inf. n. A^aziyzN, It flamed, or blazed, like fire in firewood, and was in motion, or in a state of commotion. (AO.) -A2- A^az~abiAlqidori, [aor.
Aazu3a ,] inf. n. A^az~N, He kindled a fire, or made it to burn or to burn fiercely, beneath the cooking-pot, in order that it might boil: or you say, A^az~a Alqidora, inf. n. as above, meaning he collected firewood beneath the cooking-pot so that the fire flamed, or blazed: and he made the fire to flame, or blaze, beneath the cooking-pot. (TA.) And A^az~a Aln~aAra, (K,) aor.
Aazu3a , inf. n. A^az~N, (TA,) He kindled the fire, or made it to burn or to burn fiercely. (K, TA.) ― -b2- A^az~a Al$~aYo'a, (K,) aor.
Aazu3a , inf. n. A^az~N and A^aziyzN, (TA,) He put the thing into a state of violent motion or commotion: (ISd, K:) so accord. to IDrd: (ISd:) but Ibráheem El-Harbee explains A^az~N only as signifying the act of moving. (TA.) ― -b3- A^az~ahu, (A, TA,) aor.
Aazu3a , (TA,) inf. n. A^az~N, (S, TA,) He put him in motion; disquieted him; (A,* TA;) stirred up, roused, or provoked, him; and incited, urged, or instigated, him; (S,* A,* TA;) EalaY ka*aA to do such a thing. (A, TA.*) It is said in the Kur [xix. 86], A^alamo tara A^an~A A^arosalonaA Al$~ayaATiyna EalaY AlkaAfiriyna taw^uz~uhumo A^az~aA Seest thou not that we have sent the devils against the unbelievers inciting them strongly to acts of disobedience? (S, TA.) Or A^az~N signifies The inciting a man to do a thing by artifice, or cunning, and gentleness. (El-Harbee.)

miy^ozaAbN * , (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and miyzaAbN, (S, Msb,) A water-spout; a pipe, or channel, that spouts forth water: (Mgh, TA:) or that by which water pours down from a high place: (Towsheeh:) or a water-spout of wood, or the like, to convey away the water from the roof of a house: (MF in art. zwb:) the former is from the verb above mentioned: (A, K:) or it is arabicized, (A, Mgh, K,) from the Persian, (Mgh, K,) signifying “make water:” (K:) its pl. is maA=ziybu: (ISk, S, Mgh, Msb:) and the pl. of myzAb is mayaAziybu and mawaAziybu, from wazaba, said of water, meaning “it flowed,” (Mgh, Msb,) accord. to IAar; (Mgh;) or this is arabicized; or postclassical: (Msb:) but myzAb, without ', is altogether disallowed by Yaakoob [i. e. ISk]: (Mgh:) it is also called mirozaAbN, (T, S, Msb,) accord. to IAar; (T, Msb;) but this is disallowed by ISk, Fr, and AHát, (Msb,) and by Az [the author of the T]; (Mgh;) and mizoraAbN also, accord. to IAar and Lth and others, as is mentioned in the T. (Msb.)
2 A^z~j * , inf. n. taA^oziyjN, (Msb, K,) He built a structure of the kind called A^azajN, and made it long: (K:) or he built a house, or chamber, in the form of what is so called. (Msb.)

A^azajN *
A certain kind of structure; (S, K;) or a house, or chamber, built in a long, or an oblong, form; (Mgh, L, Msb;) called in Persian A^uwisotaAnN, (Mgh, L,) and also, in the same language, sago, and kamaro: (Mgh:) [i. e. an oblong, arched, or vaulted, structure or edifice; (such as a bridge; see qanoTarapN;) a portico, gallery, or piazza; accord. to Golius and Freytag, ædificii genus oblongum et fornicatum, porticus instar; to which Freytag adds, portæ arcus superior:] or, accord. to some, a roof: (Msb:) pl. [of pauc.] A=zaAjN (S, Msb, K) and A=zujN (S, K) and [of mult.] A_izajapN. (K.)

Aazira , (TK,) inf. n. A^azorN. (IAar, K,) It surrounded, or encompassed, it, (IAar,* K,* TA,) namely, a thing. (TK.) ― -b2- See also 2, in two places: and see 3.

Strength. (IAar, S, A, K.) ― -b2- And (or as some say, TA) Weakness: thus bearing two contr. significations. (IAar, K.) ― -b3- And The back. (IAar, S, K.) Au$odudo bihi A^azoriY, in the Kur [xx. 32], means Strengthen Thou by him my back: (IAar, S:) or confirm Thou by him my strength: or strengthen Thou by him my weakness. (IAar.) ― -b4- Aid, assistance, or help. (Msb.) ― -b5- Also, (S,) or ↓ A^uzorN, (K,) The place, (K,) or part of [each of] the two flanks, (S,) where the A_izaAr is tied in a knot. (S, K.)

A_izorapN A^zAr A^zr A^zrY A^zrh A_zAr Azrh Azrp wzr zAr zr zrY |zr |zrh
Any particular mode, or manner, of putting on, or wearing, the A_izaAr. (S, K.) You say, A_in~ahu laHasanu AlA_izorapi [Verily he has a good manner of putting on, or wearing, the AzAr]. (A.) And Aiytazara A_izorapF HasanapF He put on, or wore, the AzAr in

And it is said in a trad., A_izorapu Almuw^omini A_ilaY niSofi Als~aAqi walaA junaAHa Ealayohi fiymaA bayonahu wabayona AlkaEobayoni [The believer's mode of wearing the AzAr is to have it reaching to the middle of the shank; and there shall be no sin chargeable to him with respect to what is between that and the two ankles]. (TA.)

A_izaArN A^zAr A_zAr AzAr , masc. and fem., and ↓ A_izaArapN, and ↓ miy^ozarN, (S, Msb, K,) and ↓ miy^ozarapN, (Lh,) and ↓ A_izorN, (K,) A thing well known; (S, Msb;) [a waist-wrapper;] a wrapper for covering, or which covers, the lower part of the body, [from the waist downwards, concealing the thighs, and generally the upper half, or more, of the shanks, (see A^azorN, or A^uzorN, and A_izorapN,)] not sewed: or such as is beneath the shoulders, or on the lower half of the body: the ridaA='i is that which covers the upper half of the body; or that which is upon the shoulders and back; and this also is not sewed: each of these explanations is correct: (MF:) or i. q. miloHafapN: (K:) [in the present day, A_izaAr, vulgarly pronounced A_iyzaAr, is also applied to a woman's outer covering, or wrapper, of white calico; described in my “Modern Egyptians:” and ↓ miy^ozarN, to a pair of drawers: and app., in post-classical writings, to anything resembling a waist-wrapper, worn on any part of the person, and in any manner; sometimes as a turban:] and A_izaArN also signifies anything with which one is veiled, concealed, or covered: (Th, K:) its pl. is A=zirapN, (S, Msb, K,) a pl. of pauc., (S, Msb,) and (of mult., S, Msb) A^uzurN (S, Msb, K) and A^uzorN, (K,) which is of the dial. of Temeem, or, accord. to MF, a contraction of A^uzurN: (TA:) and the pl. of my^zr is maA=ziru (Msb.) You say, ↓ $ad~a lilA^amori miy^ozarahu (tropical:) He prepared himself for the thing, affair, or business. (A.) And ↓ $ad~a Almiy^ozara (tropical:) He abstained from sexual intercourse: or he prepared himself for religious service. (TA, from a trad.) And AixoDar~a A_izaAriY (tropical:) (The place of) my AzAr became black: or, rather, became of a [blackish] hue inclining to green: because the hair when it first grows is of that hue. (Har p. 494.) And daAriY A_izaAriY [My house is my covering]: said by Es-Sarawee to IAar, on the latter's expressing his surprise at the former's walking in his house naked. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Continence; chastity. (K, TA.) A^azalN *
i. q. qidamN [i. e. Eternity, with respect to past time, or considered retrospectively; existence from eternity; or ancientness] (S, K, TA) that is without beginning; (TA;) or the continuance of existence in decreed times interminable in respect of the past; like as A^abadN is the continuance of existence in decreed times interminable in respect of the future; (KT;) or that [existence, or time,] which has no extremity in its beginning; like qidamN; and A^abadN is that which has no extremity in its latter part; like baqaA='N: the former is existence without any beginning: (Kull p. 31:) said to be from the phrase lamo yazalo [“he, or it, has not ceased” to be &c.; i. e. “has ever” been &c. (see A^azaliY~N)]: or, accord. to some, from A^azolN signifying “narrowness;” because the intellect is prevented by its narrowness from perceiving its beginning: (MF:) Azl is a name for that of which the mind is prevented by its narrowness from determining the limit of the beginning; from A^azolN meaning “narrowness;”; and Abd is a name for that of which the mind shrinks from, or shuns, the determining the limit of the end; from A^ubuwdN meaning the act of “shrinking” from a thing, or “shunning” it. (Kull pp. 30 and 31.) Hence the saying, kaAna fiY AlA^azali qaAdirFA EaAlimFA [He was, or has been, ever, powerful, knowing]. (A, TA.) The phrase A^azala AlA=zaAli [During the space, without beginning, of all past times; or ever, in all past times;] is like the phrase A^abada AlA=baAdi; said to be no evidence of the use of A=zaAlN as a pl. of A^azalN in a general way by the Arabs of the classical ages, as it is here added merely as a corroborative. (MF in art. Abd.) [See also A^azaliY~N.]
A^azilN * : see A=zilN.

A^azaliY~N * [Eternal, with respect to past time; existing from eternity; or ancient without beginning; as is implied in the S and K &c.;] a thing, or being, which has not been preceded by non-existence: it is applied to God: and to [his] knowledge: that which exists must be one of three kinds only: A^azaliY~N A^abadiY~N [existing from eternity, and consequently existing to eternity]; and this is God [who is also called Alqadiymu AlA^azaliY~u the Ancient without beginning]: and laA A^azaliY~N wa laA A^abadiY~N [not existing from eternity nor existing to eternity]; and such is the present world: and A^abadiY~N gayoru A^azaliY~ [existing to eternity without existing from eternity]; and such is the world to come; the reverse of which [last] is impossible: (TA:) it is a rel. n. from A^azalN: or, accord. to some, it is not [genuine] Arabic: (TA:) or it is originally yazaliY~N, a rel. n. from lamo yazalo, (S, K,) a phrase applied to that which is qadiym; and is formed by contraction; (S;) then, the Y is changed into A, as being easier of pronunciation; as in A^azaniY~N, applied to a spear, in relation to *uw yazan; (S, K,* Sgh, TA;) and as in A^avorabiY~N, applied to a blade, (S, Sgh, TA,) in relation to yavorib: (TA:) so say some of the learned. (S.)

A^azomN, (Msb, K,) He held, refrained, or abstained, (S, K, *) Eani Al$~aYo'i from the thing: (S, TA:) and he held, refrained, or abstained, from desiring much: (TA:) and from food (Msb, K *) and drink; (Msb;) as also A^azima, aor.

AlA_izaA='u AlAzA='
i. q. AlHi*aA='u [The front, as meaning the part, place, or location, that is over against, opposite, facing, fronting, or in front]. (Msb, and K &c. in art. H*w.) (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence, biA_izaA=y^ihi signifies also Corresponding to it; as when one says,] AlA^abojalu EiroqN mina Alfarasi wa AlbaEiyri biA_izaA='i AlA^akoHali mina AlA_inosaAni [The Abjl is a vein of the horse and the camel, corresponding to the AkHl of man]. [You say also, waDaEa lafoZFA biA_izaA='i maEon~aY He applied a word, or phrase, as correspondent to an idea, or a meaning.] -A2- A_izaA='N is also applied to a man, and to a woman, and to a number of persons, in senses here following. (TA.) You say, huwa A_izaA='u AlA^amori He is the manager, conductor, orderer, regulator, or superintendent, of the affair. (S, Msb, TA.) And in the same sense the word is used by Homeyd, in the phrase A_izaA='u maEaA$K [The manager, or orderer, of the means of subsistence], applied to a woman. (TA.) And in an instance in which a poet likens the A_izaA=' of a watering-trough or tank to the [stinking animal called] ZaribaAn: (S, TA:) in this case it means The water-drawer [of the trough or tank]. (As, IB, TA.) [But in relation to a watering-trough or tank, it generally has another meaning, which see below.] You say also, fulaAnN A_izaA='N maAlK (S) [Such a one is] a manager, tender, or superintendent, of cattle, or camels &c.; (K, * TA;) a good pastor thereof. (TA.) And A_izaA='u AlHarobi The vigorous wager, or prosecutor, of war. (K.) And fulaAnN A_izaA='u fulaAnK Such a one is the fellow and assistant of such a one. (TA.) Eqr:) or, accord. to AZ, a mass of stone, and what is put for protection [of the brink of the trough or tank (as it is generally constructed of stones cemented and plastered with
mud)] upon the place where the water is poured when the bucket is emptied: (S in the present art.:) or the whole (jamiyE [said in the TA to be a mistake for jmE, but this I think extremely improbable,]) of what is between the wateringtrough or tank and the cavity of the well, [namely,] of the [casing of stones, or bricks, called] T~aY: (K:) or a stone, or skin, or jul~ap [i. e. a thing made of palm-leaves woven together, generally used as a receptacle for dates], put [for protection] upon the mouth [or part of the border where the water is poured in] of the wateringtrough or tank: (K, * TA:) in the K, yuwDaEu EalayohaA AlHawoDu is erroneously put for ywDE EalaY fami AlHawoDi. (TA.)

AisotN A^sA A^sY A^st Ast {st |sY |st , signifying The podex, or the anus, (K,) or signifying the former, and sometimes used as meaning the latter, (S in art. sth,) is with a conjunctive hemzeh, [written A@sotN, when not immediately preceded by a quiescence,] and its final radical letter is clided; for the original form is satahN; (Msb;) and it is mentioned in art. sth. (K.) [It is of the fem. gender.] It is said in a prov., applied to him who fails of attaining the object that he seeks, A^axoTaA^ati A@sotuhu AlHuforapa [His anus missed the hole in the ground]. (Meyd.) — [Hence,] Aisotu Ald~ahori (tropical:) The first, or beginning, of time; (A;) old, or ancient, time. (IB, A, * K. *) One says, maA zaAla EalaY A@soti Ald~ahori majonuwnFA (tropical:) [He ceased not, or has not ceased, from the beginning of time, or from old time, to be insane, or mad; or] he always was, or always has been, known as being insane, or mad: like as one says, EalaY A_is~i Ald~ahori. (AZ, S.) And Aboo-Nukheyleh says,
maA zaAla mu*o kaAna EalaY A@ soti Ald~ahori
*aA HumuqK yanomiY waEaqolK yaHor$Y
(tropical:) [He ceased not, or has not ceased, to be, since he was in the beginning of time, or in old time, i. e., from the first of his existence, a person of increasing foolishness, and of decreasing intellect]. (AZ, S.) IB says, J has erred in mentioning Ast in this section [of the S]; its proper place being in art. sth, where he has also mentioned it; for its hemzeh is conjunctive, by common consent; and if conjunctive, it is augmentative: also, his saying that they have changed the [final] s in A_is~N into t, like as they have changed the [final] s of Tas~N into t, making this word TasotN, is a mistake; for, were it so, the hemzeh of Ast would be disjunctive [in every case; whereas it is always conjunctive except after a pause, when it is pronounced with kesr]: moreover, he has attributed this assertion to AZ, who never made it, but only mentioned Ast Aldhr with As~ Aldhr because of their agreement in meaning. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence also,] Aisotu Alkalobapi (assumed tropical:) Calamity, or misfortune: (K:) adversity; difficulty; distress; affliction: (TA:) what is hated, disliked, disapproved, foul, abominable, or evil. (K.) ― -b3- And Aisotu Almatoni (assumed tropical:) The desert: (K:) or the wide desert. (TA.) ― -b4- See also art. sth.

He called a lion. (M.) -A2- See 1, in two places. ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) He became accustomed, or habituated, [to a thing, as a dog to the chase,] and emboldened; syn. DariYa (Msb.) ― -b3- (tropical:) It (a plant, or herbage,) became strong, and tangled, or luxuriant: (S:) or became tall and large: or grew to its utmost height: (M:) or attained its full growth, and became tangled, or luxuriant, (M,) and strong: (TA:) or became tall, and dry (jaf~a [perhaps a mistake for Ailotaf~a, as in the S and M,]) and large, (A, TA,) and spread every way: (A:) or became tall, and attained its full growth. [of pauc.] A=sudN (S, K [in the TA with two hemzehs, A^aA^osudN, which is the original form, but deviating from the regular pronunciation,]) and A=saAdN (S, M, K) and [of mult.] A^usuwdN (S, M, Msb, K) and A^usudN (S) and A^usodN, (S, M, Msb, K,) the last two of which are contractions of the form next preceding them, (S) and A^usodaAnN (K) and ↓ maA^osadapN, (Msb, K,) the last called by some a pl., but [rightly] said by others to be a quasi-pl. n.: (TA:) the female is called A^asadapN; (AZ, Ks, S, M, A, Msb, K;) or A^asadN is applied to the male and the female, and sometimes the female is called A^asadapN. [See Aljabohapu.]

A_isaAdapN A^sd AsAdh AsAdp |sAdh (S, K) and A^usaAdapN (K) i. q. wisaAdapN [A pillow, &c.]: (S, K:) like A_i$aAHN for wi$aAHN. (TA.)

Aasira , inf. n. A^asorN (S, M, K) and A_isaArN, (M, TA,) He bound, braced, or tied, him, [namely, his captive,] or it, (S, M, A, K,) namely, his qatab [or camel's saddle], (S, A,) or his horse's saddle, (A,) with an A_isaAr, i. e. a thong of untanned hide, (S, A,) by tying the two extremities of the EaroquwotaAni of the camel's saddle, or of the curved pieces of wood of the horse's saddle. (A.) ― -b2- Also, aor. as above, and so the inf. n., i. e. A^asorN (S, Msb) and A_isaArN, (Lth, S,) He made him a captive; captived him; or took him a prisoner; whether he bound him with an A_isaAr or did not; (S;) as also ↓ A=srhu, of the same form as A^akorama; (Msb;) and ↓ AstA^srhu, accord. to a trad., in which it occurs thus used, transitively: (Mgh:) and he imprisoned him. He submitted himself as a captive to the enemy. (Mgh.) You say, AisotaA^osiro, meaning Be thou a captive to me. (S,) -A2- See also 1.

A^asorN *
i. q. A_isaArN, q. v. (S.) Hence the saying, h`*aA Al$~aYo'u laka biA^asorihi This thing is for thee, or is thine,[lit.] with its thong of untanned hide [wherewith it is bound]; meaning, altogether; like as one says, birum~atihi. (S.) And xu*ohu biA^asorihi Take thou it all, or altogether. (Msb.) And jaA='a Alqawomu biA^asorihimo The people came altogether. (Aboo-Bekr.) ― -b2- Strength of make, or form. (M, K.) [Accord. to the copies of the K in my hands, it also signifies Strength of natural disposition; but instead of waAlxuluq, in those copies,
we should read waAlxaloqu, agreeably with other lexicons, as is implied in the TA: see 1.] You say, fulaAnN $adiydN A^asorK Alxaloqi (tropical:) Such a one is of strong, firm, or compact, make, or form.
