(IAar, K.)

A^usorN * , (S, M, IKtt, A,) a subst., (M, IKtt,) as also ↓ A^usurN, (M, Lb,) meaning Suppression of the urine: (S, M, &c.:) suppression of the feces is termed HuSorN: (S:) or a dribbling of the urine, with a cutting pain in the bladder, and pangs like those of a female in the time of parturition. (IAar.) You say, A^axa*ahu AlA^asoru [Suppression of urine, &c., took him, or affected him]. (A.) And A^anaAlahu A@ll~`hu A^usorAF [May God give him a suppression of urine, &c.]: a form of imprecation. (A.) ― -b2- Hence, (M,) Euwdu A^usorK (IAar, S, M, A, K) and EuwdN A^usorN and Euwdu AlA^usori (Expositions of the Fs) and Euwdu yusori, (IAar, K,) or this is a corruption, (K,) or a vulgar mistake, (A,) and should not be said, (Fr, S, A,) unless meant to be used as ominous of good, (A,) A stick, or piece of wood, which is put upon the belly of a man affected by a suppression of his urine, (S, A, K, &c.,) and which cures him. (A.)
A^usurN * : see A^usorN.

A^usorapN * (assumed tropical:) A man's kinsmen that are more, or most, nearly related to him; his near kinsmen: (S, * M, A, * Msb, * K:) or a man's nearer, or nearest, relations on his father's side: (Aboo-Jaafar En-Nahhás:) so called because he is strengthened by them. (S, A.)

A_isaArN A^sAr AsAr sAr
A thing with which one binds; (M, K;) a thong of untanned hide, (S, A, Msb,) with which one binds a camel's saddle, (As, S,) [as also A_iSaArN,] and a captive; and so A^asorN, q. v.: (S:) and a rope, or cord, with which a captive is bound: and a pair of shackles: (TA:) pl. A^usurN. (M, K.) [See also 1.] You say, Hal~a A_isaArahu faA^aTolaqahu He untied his thong of untanned hide wherewith he was bound, and released him. (A.) -A2- See also A^asiyrN.

A^asiyrN *
i. q. ↓ maA^osuwrN; (S, TA;) Bound with an A_isaAr: (M, TA:) shackled: (K:) imprisoned: (Mujáhid, M, K:) captived, or a captive; (S, M, K;) absolutely, (TA,) although not bound with an AsAr: (S:) and ↓ A_isaArN is sometimes used in the same sense. (Msb.) Asyr is also applied as an epithet to a woman, (Mgh, Msb,) when the woman is mentioned; but otherwise A^asiyrapN is used as the fem.: you say, qatalotu AlA^asiyrapa [I slew the female captive], like as you say, raA^ayotu Alqatiylapa. (Msb.) The pl. is A^asoraY (S, M, Msb, K) and A^asaraA='u (M, K) and (accord. to several authors, pls. of A^asoraY, TA) A^usaAraY (S, M, Msb, K) and A^asaAraY: (M, K:) the first of these forms of pl. is proper to epithets applied to those who are hurt or afflicted in their bodies or their intellects: (Aboo-Is-hák:) it is used in this instance because a captive is like one wounded or stung. (Th, M.)
taA=siyru Als~aroji tA=syr Alsrj [in the CK, erroneously, taA^osiyr] The thongs of the horse's saddle, whereby it is bound: (K:) accord. to the more correct opinion, a pl. without a sing. (MF.)

maA^osuwrN * : see A^asiyrN. A camel's saddle bound with an A_isaAr: pl. maA=siyru. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A man, and a beast, having strongly-knit joints. (M.) ― -b3- A man suffering suppression of his urine. (S.)

A^asoTurolaAbN * or A^usoTurolaAbN, [accord. to different copies of the K,] and with S in the place of s, [from the Greek ἀστρολαβόν, An astrolabe: a word of which F gives the following fanciful derivation:] lAb was a man who traced some lines, and founded upon them calculations; whence A^asoTurulaAbK [the lines of Láb], from which was formed the compound word AsTrlAb, and ASTrlAb, the s being changed into S because of the T following. (K in art. lwb.) It is either an arabicized or a post-classical word: accord. to the Niháyet el-Adab, the names of all the instruments by which time is known, whether by means of calculation or water or sand, are foreign to the Arabic language. (MF.)

1 A^asifa * , aor.
Aasafa , inf. n. A^asafN, (M, Msb, K,) He grieved, lamented, or regretted: and he was angry: (Msb:) or he grieved exceedingly: and he was exceedingly angry: (M:) or he grieved most intensely: (K:) some say that A^asafN signifies the grieving for a thing that has escaped; not in an absolute sense: (MF:) or it properly signifies the rising, or swelling, or mantling, of the blood of the heart, from desire of vengeance; and when this is against an inferior, it is anger; but when against a superior, it is grief. (Er-Rághib.) Mo- hammad, being asked respecting sudden death, answered, saying, raAHapN lilomuw^omini waA^axo*apu A^asafK lilokaAfiri, or accord. to one recital, ↓ A^asifK, i. e. [Rest, or ease, to the believer, and an act of punishment] of anger [to the unbeliever], or of one who is angry. (K.) You say, A^asifa EalaY maA faAtahu, inf. n. as above; (S;) and ↓ tA^s~f; (S, M, * K; *) He grieved, or lamented, for, or at, or regretted, most intensely, what had escaped him: (S, M, * K:) and A^asifa Ealayohi, (S, K,) inf. n. as above, (S,) he was angry with him, or at it: (S, K:) or A^asifa fulaAnN EalaY ka*aA waka*aA and ↓ tA^s~f, signify, accord. to some, such a one grieved, or lamented, for, or at, such and such things which had escaped him: or, accord. to others, grieved, or lamented, most intensely. (IAmb.) A^asafFA in the Kur xviii. 5 means, accord. to Ed-Dahhák, jazaEFA [i.e. In grief, or in most violent grief, &c.]: or, accord. to Katádeh, in anger. (TA.) And yaA A^asafaA EalaY yuwsufi, in the Kur [xii. 84], means yaA jazaEaAhu [O my grief for Joseph: or O my most violent grief]. (TA.)

4 A=sfhu A=sfh A=sfp (in [some of] the copies of the K, erroneously, A^asafahu, TA) He angered him; made him angry: (S, M, * O, L, Msb, K:) and he grieved him; made him to grieve, or lament. (M,* TA.)
5 taAas~afa see 1, in two places. ― -b2- taA^as~afato yadahu (tropical:) i. q. ta$aE~avato [app. meaning His hand became bruised, or mangled; or became cracked, or chapped]. (M, TA.)
A^asafN * inf. n. of 1, which see throughout. [Used as a subst., i. q. A^asaAfpN.]

A^asifN * (M, Mgh, Msb) and ↓ AsifN and ↓ A^asofaAnu and ↓ A^asiyfN (M, TA) and ↓ A^asuwfN (M) Angry: (Mgh, Msb, TA:) or exceedingly angry. (M.) For an ex. of the first, see 1. See also A^asiyfN, in two places.
A^asofaAnu * : see A^asifN: and A^asiyfN.

A_isaAfN AsAf (S, M, Sgh, &c.) and A^asaAfN (IAth, K) A certain idol, (S, M, K,) belonging to Kureysh, (S, M,) as was also naAy^ilapu; (S;) the former of which was placed, by 'Amr Ibn-Loheí, upon Es-Safà, and the latter upon El-Marweh; and he used to sacrifice to them, in front of the Kaabeh: (S, K:) or, (S, M, K,) as some assert, (S,) these two were two persons of Jurhum, (S, K,) a man and a woman, (M,) AsAf the son of 'Amr, and nAy^lp the daughter of Sahl, (S, K,) who committed fornication in the Kaabeh, and were therefore changed into two stones, (S, M, K,) which Kureysh afterwards worshipped. (S, K.) [Other accounts of them are also given, slightly differing from the latter above.]
A^asuwfN * : see A^asiyfN, in two places: and see A^asifN.

A^asiyfN *
Grieving, lamenting, or regretting, (K, * TA,) most intensely, on account of a thing that has escaped: (M, TA:) and quickly affected with grief, (S, Mgh, K,) and tender-hearted; as also ↓ A^asuwfN: (S, K:) or, as also ↓ A^asuwfN (M) and ↓ A^asofaAnu and ↓ A=sifN (M, TA) and ↓ A^asifN , (M,) grieving exceedingly: (M:) or grieved: (TA:) and sometimes the first signifies angry, and at the same time grieving, or lamenting: (S:) pl. A^usafaA='u. (M.) See also A^asifN. ― -b2- A slave: (ISk, S, M, K:) and a hired man: (ISk, M, K:) because of their state of abasement and subjection: fem. with p: (M:) and pl. as above. (S, M.) ― -b3- A captive. (TA.) ― -b4- A very old man: (K:) pl. as above: so in a trad., in which the slaying of such is forbidden. (TA.) ― -b5- One who scarcely, or never, becomes fat. (K.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) A region, or country, that does not give growth to anything, or produce any vegetation; as also A^asiyfapN and ↓ A^usaAfapN and ↓ A^asaAfapN: (M:) and ↓ A^asaAfapN also signifies (assumed tropical:) thin, or shallow, earth: (AHn, M:) and A^aroDN A^asiyfapN, (tropical:) thin, or shallow, earth, which scarcely, or never, gives growth to anything, or produces any vegetation: (S:) or which is not commended for its vegetation: (A, TA:) or, as also ↓ A^usaAfapN and ↓ A^asaAfapN, (assumed tropical:) thin, or shallow, earth: or such as does
not produce vegetation: and ↓ (assumed tropical:) A^aroDN A^asifapN land which scarcely, or never, produces vegetation. (K.)

A^asaAfapN * [Grief, lamentation, or regret: and anger: (see 1:) or] excessive grief: and excessive anger: (M:) or most intense grief: (K:) a subst. from A^asifa. (M, K.) ― -b2- The state, or condition, of a slave: (M, K:) and, of a hired man. (M.) ― -b3- (tropical:) The state, or condition, of land which scarcely, or never, produces vegetation. (K, TA.) -A2- See A^asiyfN, in three places.
A^asaAfapN * : see A^asiyfN, in two places.
A=sifN A=sf : see A^asiyfN: and A^asifN.

A_isofiydaAjN AsfydAj [Ceruse; or white lead;] ashes of lead (ramaAdu Alr~aSaASi wAlA=nuki, K, which last word is as though it were added to explain that immediately preceding, TA): when subjected to a fierce heat, it becomes what is termed A_isoranojN: [so in the CK: more probably A_isorinojN:] it has clearing and mitigating properties, (K,) and other useful qualities: (TA:) an arabicized word [from the Persian AsfydAj isfédáj]. (K.)

1 A^asakahaA * , aor.
Aasika , inf. n. A^asokN, He hit, hurt, or wounded, her (a woman's) A_isokataAni. (TA.) And A^usikato She (a woman) was hurt, or wounded, in a place not that of circumcision, [i.e., in her A_isokataAni,] by the circumcising woman's missing the proper place. (Msb.) [See baZorq.]
A^asokN * : see AlA_isokataAni.

A_isokN A^s A^sk Ask sAk sk |s |sk see AlA_isokataAni.― -b2- Also The side of the Aisot [i. e., of the podex, or of the anus]. (Sh, TA.) [Hence,] one says of a man, A_in~amaA huwa A_isoku A^amapK, meaning He is but a stinking fellow. (TA.)

AlA_isokataAni AlAsktAn (T, S, M, Mgh, Sgh, Msb, K) and AlA^asokataAni, (M, K,) The two sides [or labia majora] of the vulva, or external portion of the female organs of generation, (T, S, Mgh, Msb,) i. e., of a woman, above [or rather within] the $uforaAni; (Mgh; the $uforaAni being the two borders thereof; T, Msb;) i. e. the qu*~ataAni thereof; (S and M and L in art. q*;) the two sides, on the right and left, of the vulva, or external portion of the organs of generation, of a woman, between which is the ma$aq~: (Zj in his “ Khalk el-Insán ”) or [accord. to some, but incorrectly,] the $uforaAni [in the CK the $afor] of the raHim [here meaning, as in many other instances, the vulva, i. e. faroj], (M, K,) or of the HayaA=' [which also means the vulva, but seldom that of a woman]: (El-Khárzenjee:) or [agreeably with general usage, and with the explanations given before this last,] its two sides, next to its $uforaAni: (M, K:) or, [what is the same,] its qu*~ataAni: (K:) pl. A_isakN (El-Khárzenjee, K) and [quasi-pl. ns.] ↓ A_isokN and ↓ A^asokN. (M, K.)

maA^osuwkapN * A woman hit, hurt, or wounded, in her A_isokataAni: (TA:) a woman (Msb) hurt, or wounded, in a place not that of circumcision, by the circumcising woman's missing the proper place; (S Msb, K;) [i. e.,] hurt, or wounded, by that cause, in her A_isokataAni. (T, TA.)

A^asula * , aor.
Aasula , (S, M, K,) inf. n. A^asaAlapN, (S, M, IAth,) It was smooth and even: (M:) it (anything) was lank: (S:) it (a cheek, M, IAth, K) was smooth and long: (M:) or long, or oblong, and not high in its ball: (IAth:) or long, (K, TA,) soft in make, (TA,) and lank. (K, TA.) A^asaAlapN in the cheek of a horse is approved, and is an indication of generous quality: you say, tunobiy^u A^asaAlapu xad~ihi Eano A^aSaAlapi jad~ihi [The smoothness and longness, &c., of his cheek tells of the generous origin of his ancestor]. (AO, Z.) -A2- See also 2.

2 A^s~lhu *
He made it (an iron thing) thin. (TA.) [He made it (anything) sharp, or pointed. (See the pass. part. n., below.)] ― -b2- A^s~l AlmaTara, inf. n. taA^osiylN, The rain moistened to the measure of the A^asalap [or thin part] of the arm. (K.) When it has moistened to the measure of the EaZamap [or thick part] of the arm, you say of it EaZ~ama, inf. n. taEoZiymN: one says, kayfa kaAnato maToratukumo A^as~alato A^amo EaZ~amato [How was your rain? Did it moisten to the measure of the thin part of the arm, or did it moisten to the measure of the thick part thereof?]. (TA.) And A^s~l Alv~araY, (TA,) or ↓ A^asala, (M, [so in a copy of that work, but probably a mistranscription,]) The moisture reached to the measure of the A^asalap. (M, TA.)
5 tA^s~l A^abaAhu * , (M, K,) as also tA^s~nhu, (M, TA,) He resembled his father, (M, K, TA,) and assumed his natural dispositions; and so taqay~alahu. (TA.) [See A=saAlu, below.]

A^asalN * [Rush, or rushes: so called in the present day:] a kind of trees: (S:) or [rather] a kind of plant, (M, Mgh, TA,) having shoots (M, Mgh) which are slender, (Mgh,) without leaves; (M, Mgh;) or of which the shoot is slender, and of which sieves are made; as is said in the A; and Sgh adds, [growing] in El-' Irák: (TA:) AHn says, (TA,) accord. to Aboo-Ziyád, it is of the kind called A^agolaAv, and comes forth in slender shoots, not having branches growing out from them, nor wood, (M, TA,) and sometimes men beat them, and make of them well-ropes and other cords, (TA,) and it seldom or never grows but in a place wherein is water, or near to water: (M, TA:) AHn says [also], it signifies shoots, or twigs, growing (M, K) long and slender and straight, (M,) without leaves; of which mats are made: (M, K:) or A^asalapN, (K,) which is the n. un. of A^asalN applied to the plant mentioned above, (M, K,) signifies any shoot, or twig, in which is no crookedness. (K.) ― -b2- Hence, (M,) (tropical:) Spears; (S, M, K;) as being likened to the plant mentioned above, in respect of its evenness and length and straightness and the slenderness of its extremities: n. un. as above: (M:) and (assumed tropical:) arrows, or Arabian arrows; syn. nabolN; (M, K:) applied to both of these in a trad. of 'Omar, which refutes an assertion that it is peculiarly applied to spears, or long spears, and not to nbl: (A'Obeyd, TA:) Sh says that it is applied to spears because of the points of the heads fixed upon them. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Any thin thing of iron, such as a spear-head, and a sword, and a knife. (TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) The prickles of palm-trees: (M, K:) n. un. as above: (M:) by way of comparison [to the plant mentioned above]: (TA:) or any long thorns, or prickles, of a tree. (S.) ― -b5- [See also what next follows.]

A^asalapN * n. un. of A^asalN, q. v. (M, K.) ― -b2- Hence, by way of comparison, the significations here following from the K. (TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) Anything in which is no crookedness. (M.) ― -b4- (tropical:) The thin part of a blade of iron, such as that of an arrow &c.: (M, K:) and of the fore arm; (S, M, K;) i. e. the half thereof next the hand; the half next the elbow being called the EaZamap. (K in art. EZm.) ― -b5- (tropical:) The thin part,, (S,) or extremity, or tip, (M, K,) of the tongue; (S, M, K;) the thick part thereof being called the EaZamap. (K in art. EZm.) One says, A^asalaAtu A^alosinatihimo A^amoDaY mino A^asin~api A^asalihimo (tropical:) [The tips of their tongues are sharper than the heads of their spears]. (A, TA.) ― -b6- (tropical:) The nervus, (K,) or the extremity thereof, (M,) of a camel. (M, K.)― -b7- (tropical:) The head, [or what we tern the toe, or foremost extremity, also called A^anofN and *unaAbapN,] of a sandal; (M, K;) which is tapering. (M.)
A^asaliy~apN * an epithet applied to the letters z and s and S because Pronounced with the tip of the tongue. (TA.)

A^asiylN *
Smooth and even: (M, K:) anything lank; (S, A;) syn. saboTN, (A,) [i. e.] musotarosilN: (S, A:) applied to a cheek, (AZ, K, TA,) [smooth and long: or long, or oblong, and not high in its ball: (see 1:) or] soft, tender, thin, and even: (AZ:) or long, (K, TA,) soft in make, (TA,) and lank. (K, TA.) You say rajulN A^asiylu Alxad~i A man having the cheek soft and long: (S:) and in like manner, farasa a horse. (TA.) And kaf~N A^asiylapu AlA^aSaAbiEi A hand small and slender, and lank, or long, in the fingers. (TA.)

A=saAlN A=sAl a pl. having no sing.: (K:) mentioned by ISk as a word of which he had not heard any sing. (S.) You say, huwa EalaY A=saAlK mino A^abiyhi [in the CK, erroneously, AasAlK,] He is of a semblance and of characteristics and natural dispositions which are those of his father; (S, K;) like A=saAnK. (S.)
muw^as~alN * Anything sharpened, or pointed. (M, K.) You say A^u*unN muw^as~alapN An ear [of a horse or the like] slender, pointed, and erect. (M.)
1 A^asamahu * a dial. var. of wasamahu, q. v. (TA.)
AisomN A^sAm A^sm A^smY Asm sAm sm smA smY wsm {sm : see art. smw.

A^usaAmapu * , determinate, (S, M, K,) and imperfectly decl., (M, Msb,) as a proper name, (Msb, K,)
The lion; (S, M, Msb, K;) as also AlA^usaAmapu. (Sgh, K.)

1 A^asana * , aor.
Aasuna (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and
Aasina , (S, M, K,) inf. n. A^usuwnN (S, M, Msb) and A^asonN; (M;) and A^asina, aor.
Aasana , (S, M, &c.,) inf. n. A^asanN; (S, M, Msb;) said of water, i. q. A^ajana and A^ajina; (S, K;) [i. e.] It became altered for the worse (M, Mgh, Msb) in odour, (M,) [or in taste and colour, from some such cause as long standing, (see A^ajana,)] but was drinkable; (M;) or so as not to be drunk, (Msb, TA,) thus differing from A^ajana and A^ajina. (TA.) [See also A^aSila.]
A^asinN * : see what follows.

A=sinN A=sn (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and ↓ A^asinN, (S, Mgh, Msb,) applied to water, (S, Mgh, &c.,) i. q. A=jinN [and A^ajinN]; (S, K;) [i. e.] Altered for the worse (Mgh, Msb) in odour, (Mgh,) [or in taste and colour, from some such cause as long standing but drinkable; (see above, and see A=jinN;)] or so as not to be drunk, (Msb, TA,) thus differing from A=jinN and A^ajinN: (TA:) pl. [of the former] A=saAnN [like as A^aTohaArN is pl. of TaAhirN, or perhaps it may have for its sing. A^asonN, like A^ajonN]. (M, TA.) mano maA='K gayori A=sinK, in the Kur [xlvii. 16], is explained by Fr as meaning Of water not altered for the worse; not A=jin. (TA.)

1 A^asaA AljuroHa * , (aor. yaA^osuw S,) inf. n. A^asowN and A^asFA, [but in the S, the latter seems to be mentioned as a simple subst.,] He dressed the wound; treated it curatively, or surgically. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] h`*a A^amorN laA yuw^osaY kalomuhu (assumed tropical:) [This is an affair of which the evil (lit. the wound) will not be remedied]. (S.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] A^asaA bayonahumo, (first pers. A^asawotu, S, Msb, inf. n. A^asowN, S, M,) (tropical:) He made peace, effected a reconciliation, or adjusted a difference, between them; (S, M, Msb, K;) as also bynhm ↓ A^s~Y. (El-Muärrij, TA.) -A2- A^asiya aor. yaA^osay, inf. n. A^asFA or A^asFy, He grieved, or mourned, (S, M, Msb, K,) Ealayohi [for him, or it], (M, K,) and EalaY muSiybapK [for an affliction], and lifulaAnK [for such a one]. (S.) [This belongs to the present art. and to art. AsY; but is distinguished in the M and K by being mentioned only in the latter art.; though the inf. n. is mentioned in the K in both arts.] Hence the saying, AlA_isaA='u yadofaEu AlA^asaA [Medicine dispels grief, or mourning] (TA.)

2 A^s~Y bayonahumo * : see 1. -A2- A^s~Ahu, (S, M, K,) inf. n. taA^osiyapN, (S, K,) i. q. Eaz~aAhu [He exhorted him, or enjoined him, to be patient; to take patience; or to take example by, or console himself by the example of, him who had suffered the like affliction]; (S, M, K, TA;) saying to him, Wherefore dost thou grieve, or mourn, when such a one is thine example (A_isowatuka) ? i. e. what has befallen thee befell him, and he was patient; therefore take thou example by him and so be consoled (taA^as~i bihi). (TA.) You say, A^s~Ahu bimuSiybapK i. e. Eaz~aAhu [He exhorted him, or enjoined him, to be patient, &c., by mentioning an affliction that had befallen another; unless bmSytp be a mistranscription for limuSiybapK on account of an affliction]; as also ↓ A=sAhu, with medd. (TA.)

3 A=siyotuhu bimaAliY A=syth bmAlY A=syth bmAly , (S, Mgh,) inf. n. muw^aAsaApN, (S, M, K,) I made him my object of imitation (A_isowatiY), [meaning I made myself like him,] in respect of my property: (S:) or I made him an object of imitation [with, or in respect of, my property], I imitating his example, and he imitating my example: (Mgh:) and waAsayotuhu is a dial. var., but of weak authority: (S, Mgh:) and A=saAniY [alone] he made me an object of imitation to him by giving me of his property [and thus reducing himself to my condition in some degree while in the same degree raising me to his]; (Ham p. 696;) and A^uwaAsiyhi [thus without a second '] I make him the object of my own imitation and so share with him my property: (Id p. 198:) or A=sAhu bimaAlihi signifies he gave him of his property, and made him an object of imitation in respect of it: or only, of food sufficient for his want; not of what is superabundant: (M, K:) whence the saying, raHima A@ll~`hu rajulFA A^aEoTaY mino faDolK wawaAsaY mino kafaAfK [May God have mercy on a man who has given of superabundance, and imparted of food only sufficient for his want so as to make himself equal with him to whom he imparts of such food]: (TA:) [and A=sAhu signifies he shared with him: and he was, or became, equal with him: for] AlmuwaAsaApu occurs often in trads., signifying the sharing with another, or making another to share with one, in the means of subsistence [&c.]; and is originally [Almuw^aAsaApu,] with ': also, the being, or becoming, equal with another: (TA:) and you say, A=sayotuhu binafosiy, meaning I made him equal with myself; in the dial. of El-Yemen waAsayotuhu. (Msb.) A=si bayona Aln~aAsi fiY wajohika, in a letter of 'Omar, means Make thou the people to share [alike], one with another, in thy consideration and regard: or, as some say, make thou them equal [in respect thereof]. (Mgh.) The saying maA yuw^aAsiy fulaAnN fulaAnFA is explained in three different ways: accord. to El-Mufaddal Ibn-Mohammad, it means Such a one does not make such a one to share with him: accord. to El-Muärraj, does not good to such a one; from the saying of the Arabs, A=si fulaAnFA bixayorK Do thou good to such a one: or, as some say, does not give such a one any compensation for his love, or affection, nor for his relationship; from AlA^awosu, meaning AlEawoDu; being originally yuw^aAwisuhu, then yuw^aAsiwuhu, and then yuw^aAsiyhi: or it may be from A^asawotu AljuroHa. (IDrd, TA.) [See also an ex. voce A^avarapN].

and exterior part of a house: (Mirkát el-Loghah, and Meyd, as rendered by Golius:) or an intermediate place between the threshold or door and the house; a place which looks neither upon the public nor upon the interior parts, whether it be an area or a vestibule. (Ibn-Maaroof, as rendered by Golius.)

A^aSiydapN * : see A^uSodapu -A2- A [hind of enclosure for the protection of camels, sheep, or goats, such as is called] HaZiyrapN: (M, K:) or like a HZyrp, (S, and Ham p.223,) [but made] of rocks, or great masses of stone: (Ham:) a dial. var. of waSiydapN [q. v.]: (S:) pl. A_iSaAdN (Ham.)

muw^oSadN *
Closed; closed over, or covered: occurring in the Kur [xc. 20 and] civ. 8; (L;) in which AA reads muw^oSadapN [with hemz; others reading this word without hemz]. (S, L.) You say baAbN muw^oSadN [A closed door]. (A.) And qidorN muw^oSadapN A covered cooking-pot. (A.) And baAbu AlEafowi Eanohu muw^oSadN (assumed tropical:) [The door of forgiveness is closed from him; i. e., against him]. (A.)
muw^aS~adN * , or muw^aS~adapN: see A^uSodapN, in three places.

1 A^aSarahu * , aor.
AaSira , inf. n. A^aSorN, He, or it, (a thing, Ks,) confined, restricted, limited, kept close, kept within certain bounds or limits, shut up, imprisoned, held in custody, detained, retained, restrained, withheld, debarred, hindered, impeded, or prevented, him or it: (Ks, S, M, A, * K:) it straitened him. (TA.) You say, A^aSarotu Alr~ajula EalaY *`lika I confined, or restricted, the man to that thing, or affair. (Ks.) And A^aSarotuhu Eano HaAjatahu, and Eam~aA A^araAdahu, I withheld, restrained, or debarred, him from the thing that he wanted, and from the thing that he desired. (IAar.) ― -b2- A^aSara Albayota, aor. and inf. n. as above, He made, or put, to the tent an A_iSaAr. (K,* TK.) -A2- Also, aor. and inf. n. as above, He broke it. (ElUmawee, S, M, K.*) ― -b2- He inclined, or bent, it. (M, K* TA.) ― -b3- It inclined him, (As, S, K,) EalaY fulaAnK to such a one. (As, S.) See an ex. voce A=SirapN.
3 A=Srhu A=Srh A=Srp , inf. n. muw^aASirapN, He was his neighbour, having the A_SAr of his tent by the side of the A_iSaAr of the tent of the other. See the act. part. n. below.]

6 taA=SaruwA tA=SrwA
They were neighbours; they dwelt, or abode, near together. See the act. part. n. below.]
A^aSorN * see A_iSorN; each in three places.
A^uSorN * see A_iSorN; each in three places.

A_iSorN ASr A^Sr A_Sr SAr Sr
A covenant, compact, or contract; (S, K;) as also ↓ A^uSorN and ↓ A^aSorN: (K:) [see also wSorN:] any bond arising from relationship, or from a covenant or compact or contract, (Aboo-Is-hák,) and from an oath: (ISh:) a covenant, compact, or contract, which one does not fulfil, and for the neglecting and breaking of which one is punished: so in the Kur ii. 286: (I' Ab:) [see also what follows, in two places:] or a heavy, or burdensome, covenant, compact, or contract: so in the Kur iii. 75: (ISh, M:) so, too, in the same vii. 156: (T, M:) pl. A=SaArN, a pl. of pauc.: (M:) or a heavy, or burdensome, command; such as was given to the Children of Israel to slay one another: so in the Kur ii. 286, accord. to Zj. (TA.) ― -b2- A weight, or burden; (S, M, K;) as also ↓ A^uSorN and ↓ A^aSorN: (K:) so called because it restrains one from motion: (TA:) pl. as above. (M.) ― -b3- A sin; a crime; an offence; (S, M, K;) as also ↓ A^uSorN and ↓ A^aSorN: (K:) so called because of its weight, or burdensomeness: (TA:) or the sin of breaking a compact, or covenant: (Fr, Sh:) or a grievous punishment of a sin: so accord. to AM in the Kur ii. 286. (TA.) ― -b4- A thing that inclines one to a thing. (M, K.) [See also A=SirapN. It is said in the Ham (p. 321) that A^awaASiru is pl. of the former word: but it is evidently pl. of the latter.] ― -b5- A swearing by an oath which obliges one to divorce or emancipate or to pay a vow. (K, TA.) So in a trad., in which it is said, mano Halafa EalaY yamiynK A_iSorN falaA kaf~aArapa lahaA [Whoso sweareth an oath in which is an obligation to divorce or emancipate or to pay a vow, for it there is no expiation]: for such is the heaviest of oaths, and that from which the way of escape, or evasion, is most strait: the original meaning of ASr being a burden, and a binding. (TA.) -A2- The ear-hole: pl. A=SaArN (IAar, K) and A_iSoraAnN. (K.)

A_iSaArN ASAr A^SAr A_Sr SAr |SAr and ↓ A^ayoSarN (S, M, K) and ↓ A_iSaArapN and ↓ A=SirapN (M, K) A short rope, (S,) or small rope, (K,) by which the lower part of the [kind of tent called] xibaA=' is tied, or bound, (S, K,) to the peg: (S:) or a short peg, for the [ropes called] A^aTonaAb, with which the lower part of the [kind of tent called] xbA= is fastened: (M:) [or] A_iSaArN signifies also the peg, (K,) or short peg, (TA,) of the [kind of tent-rope called] Tunub: (K:) or a peg of the xbA=': (Ibn-Es-Seed, TA:) pl. of the first A^uSurN (S, M) and A=SirapN; (M;) and of the second A^ayaASiru. (S.) ISd thinks that ↓ A=SiraAt is the pl. of ↓ A=SirapN used in the first of the senses explained above in in the following verse:
laEamoruka laA A^a*onuw liwaSoli daniy~apK
wa laA A^ataSabaY A=SiraAti xaliyliY
the poet meaning [By thy life, I will not approach to hold loving communion, or intercourse, with an ignoble, or a low, female;] nor will I direct my regard to the short ropes which bind [to the pegs] the lower part of the tent of my friend, coveting his wife, and the like: or he may mean nor will I direct my regard to the female relations of my friend, such as his paternal aunt, and his maternal aunt, and the like. (TA.) [See A=SirapN, below.] ― -b2- Also, the first, A thing by which things are tied firmly, or made firm or fast. (TA.) ― -b3- A thong of untanned hide which binds together the EaDudaAni of a camel's saddle: and A_isaArN is a dial. var. thereof. (M.) ― -b4- Also, (M, K,) and ↓ A^ayoSarN, (AZ, As, K,) A [garment of the kind called] kisaA=' in which dry herbage, or fodder, is collected: (M, K:) or a ksA=' filled with herbage, and tied: (AZ:) or a ksA=' in which is dry herbage, or fodder: otherwise it is not thus called: (As:) pl. [of the former] A^uSurN and A=SirapN; (K;) and of the latter A^ayaASiru. (AZ.) ― -b5- And both words, (the former accord. to the S and M and K, and the latter accord. to As and the S and M and K,) Dry herbage, or fodder: (S, K:) or dry herbage, or fodder, collected together: (TA:) or dry herbage, or fodder, in a [garment of the kind called] ksA=': otherwise it is not thus called: (As:) or dry herbage, or fodder, contained in a miHa$~. (M.) [The following saying is cited as an ex. of the first of these significations:] lifulaAnK maHa$~N laA yujaz~u ↓ A^ayoSarahu [To such a one belongs a place, or land, abounding with dry herbage,] the dry herbage whereof will not be cut; (S;) meaning, because of its abundance. (TA.) ― -b6- Also, the former, A basket (zabiyl or znobiyl, as in different copies of the K) in which goods, or commodities, (mataAE,) are carried: so called as being likened to the thing in which dry herbage is put. (TA.)
A_iSaArapN ASArh ASArp A_Sr |SArh : see A_iSaArN.

kalaA^N A=SirN *
Pasturage that detains those that are on it [by reason of its abundance]: (M, TA:) or, to which one goes because of its abundance. (TA.)

A=SirapN A=Srh A=Srp , and its pl. A=SiraAtN: see A_SaArN, in three places: of which last word, the first is also a pl. ― -b2- The thing termed A=xiy~ap and A=riY~ [to which a beast is tied]. (TA.) ― -b3- A tie of kindred, or relationship, (S, M, K,) or affinity, (S,) or a favour, or benefit, (S, K,) that inclines one to a man; (S;) or because it inclines one: (M:) pl. A^awaASiru. (K.) One says, EalaY fulaAnK A=SirapN ↓ maA taA^oSiruniY No tie of relationship, nor any favour, or benefit, inclines me to such a one. (S.) And EaTafa EalaY~a bigayori A=Siraho wanaZara fiY A^amoriY bigayori baASiraho [He inclined to me without any tie of relationship, &c., and examined my case without eye]. (A.) [See also A_iSorN.]
A^ayoSarN * : see A_iSaArN, in three places.

maA^oSirN * and maA^oSarN A place in which a person or thing is confined, shut up, or imprisoned: pl. maA=SirN; for which the vulgar say, maEaASiru. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also, the former, (M, A,) or maASirN; (TA;) either of the measure mafoEilN from AlA^aSoru, or of the measure faAEilN from AlmiSoru; A thing intervening between two other things and preventing the passage from one to the other; a barrier: (A:) a rope across a road or river, preventing the passage of travellers and ships or boats, (M, L,) for the taking of the tithes from them. (L.)

muw^aASirN *
A neighbour: (K:) [or a close, or near, neighbour: as in the saying,] huwa jaAriY muw^aASiriY He is my neighbour, having the A_iSaAr of his tent by the side of the A_iSaAr of my tent. (El-Ahmar, S.)

HaY~N mutaA=Siruwna Hy mtA=Srwn
A tribe dwelling, or abiding, near together. (S, K. *)

A_iSoTabolN ASTbl A_STbl
A stable (K) for dawaAb~ [i. e. horses or mules or asses]: (S [in some copies of which it is omitted] and K:) the A is radical, because an augmentative does not occur at the beginning of a word of four or five letters unless derived from a verb: (S:) [probably from the barbarous Greek σταβλίον:] AA says that it is not of the [genuine] language of the Arabs: (S:) IB says that it is a foreign word, used by the Arabs: (TA:) accord. to some, (TA,) it is of the dial. of Syria: (K, TA:) the pl. is A^aSaATibu: and the dim. A^uSayoTibN. (TA.)
A^aSoTurolaAbN * or A^uSoTurolaAbN: see AsTrlAb.

1 A^aSula * , (K,) inf. n. A^aSaAlapN; (TA;) or A^aSila; (M;) It (a thing, M) had, or came to have, root, or a foundation; (M, K;) as also ↓ tA^S~l: (M:) or it was, or became, firm, or established, and firmly rooted or founded; as also ↓ tA^S~l: (K:) and [in like manner] ↓ AstA^Sl it (a thing) was, or became, firm in its root or foundation, and strong. (Msb.) You say, Al$ajarapu ↓ AisotaA^oSalati The tree [took root; or] grew, and became firm in its root. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A^aSula, (S, M, K,) inf. n. as above, (S, M,) He (a man, S, * M) was, or became, firm, (S, M, K;) or sound, (S,) of judgment; (S, M, K;) intelligent. (M: [and so, probably, in correct copies of the K; but in a MS. copy of the K and in the CK; and TA, instead of EaAqil, the reading in the M, I find EaAqib.]) ― -b3- Also, (S, * K,) inf. n. as above, (S, TA,) It (judgment, or opinion,) was, or became, firm, or sound, (S, * TA,) or good. (K.) ― -b4- And, inf. n. as above, It (a thing) was, or became, eminent, noble, or honourable. (Msb.) -A2- A^aSalahu, [aor. and inf. n. as in what follows next after this sentence,] He hit, or struck, its root, or foundation; that by being which it was what it was, or in being which it consisted; or its ultimate constituent. (A, TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (A, TA,) A^aSalahu EilomFA, (A, K, TA,) aor.
AaSula , inf. n. A^aSolN: (TA;) or ↓ A=Salahu [with medd, (which I think to be a mistake, unless this be a dial. var.,) and without ElmA]; (so in a copy of the M;) (assumed tropical:) He knew it completely, or thoroughly, or superlatively well, syn. qatalahu, (K,) [i. e.] qatalahu EilomFA, so that he was acquainted with its A^aSol [or root, or foundation, or its ultimate constituent, as is indicated in the A and TA]: (M:) or this is from A^aSalapN, as meaning “a certain very deadly serpent;” (A, TA;) [whence the phrase,] ― -b3- A^aSalatohu AlA^aSalapu, (K,) inf. n. A^aSolN, (TA,) The [serpent called] ASlp sprang upon him (K, TA) and slew him. (TA.) -A3- A^aSila, aor.
AaSala , (M, K,) inf. n. A^aSalN, (M,) said of water, i. q. A^asina; (M, K;) i. e. It became altered for the worse (M, TA) in its taste and odour, (TA,) from fetid black mud (K, TA) therein: so says Ibn-'Abbád: (TA:) and said of flesh-meat, it became altered (K, TA) in like manner. (TA.) -A4- A^aSila fulaAnN yafoEalu ka*aA wa ka*aA Such a one set about, or commenced, doing thus and thus, or such and such things. (TA.)

2 A^Sl~hu * , inf. n. taA^oSiylN, He made it to have a firm, or fixed, root, or foundation, whereon to build, (Msb, TA,) i. e., whereon another thing might be built. (El-Munáwee, TA.) [Hence,] A^S~l maAlahu i. q. A^av~alahu [He made his wealth, or property, to have root, or a foundation; or to become firm, or established, and firmly rooted or founded: see, below, A^aSolu maAlK, and maAlN lahu A^aSolN]. (M and K in art. Avl.) ― -b2- A^S~l AlA^uSuwla [He disposed, arranged, distributed, classified, or set in order, the fundamentals, fundamental articles, principles, elements, or rudiments, of a science, &c.,] is a phrase similar to baw~aba AlA^abowaAba and rat~aba Alr~utaba. (TA.)
4 A=Sl A=Sl , (inf. n. A_iySaAlN, TA,) He entered upon the time called A^aSiyl, q. v. (S, M, K.) -A2- See also A^aSalahu EilomFA.
5 tA^S~l * : see 1, first sentence, in two places.

10 AstA^Sl * : see 1, in two places, first and second sentences. -A2- AstA^Slhu He uprooted it; unrooted it; eradicated it; extirpated it; pulled it up, or out, or off, from its root, or foundation, or lowest part, (S, TA,) or with its roots, or foundations, or lowest parts;; (TA;) he cut it off (M, Msb) from its root, or lowest part, (M,) or with its roots, or lowest parts. (Msb.) You say, AisotaA^oSala A@ll~`hu $aA^ofatahumo, a precative phrase, meaning May God [extirpate or] remove (from them) their $A^fp; which is an ulcer, or a purulent pustule, that comes forth in the foot, and is cauterized, and in consequence goes away: (M:) or AstA^Sl $A^fthm [in general usage] means he extirpated them, or may he extirpate them; or he cut off, or may he cut off, the last remaining of them. (TA. [See also art. $A^f.]) And AstA^Sl Alqawoma, i. e. qaTaEa A^aSolahumo [He cut off the root, race, or stock, of the people; i. e. he extirpated them]. (M.) And AstA^Sl A@ll~`hu Alkuf~aAra God destroyed altogether or entirely, or may God destroy altogether or entirely, the unbelievers. (Msb.) And AstA^Sl AlxitaAna He performed the circumcision so as to remove the prepuce utterly. (TA in art. sHt.)

A^aSolN * The lower, or lowest, part of a thing; [i. e. its root, bottom, or foot;] (M, Msb, K;) as also ↓ yaA^oSuwlN: (M, K:) so of a mountain: and of a wall; (TA;) i. e. its foundation, or base: (Msb:) and of a tree [or plant]; (TA;) i. e. [its stem, or trunk, or stock, or] the part from which the branches are broken off: (TA in art. ksr:) [and also its root, or foot; for] the saAq of a tree is said to be the part between its A^aSol and the place where its branches shoot out: (TA in art. swq:) [and a stump of a tree: and hence, a block of wood: (see exs. voce naqiyrN:)] pl. A^uSuwlN (S, M, Msb, K) and [pl. of pauc.] A=SulN: (AHn, K:) [ISd says that] the former is its only pl.: (M:) [but] the latter pl. occurs in a verse of Lebeed, (which see below,) as cited by AHn. (TA.) You say, qaEada fiY A^aSoli jabali He sat upon, or at, the lowest part [&c.] of the mountain; and fiY A^aSoli AlHaAy^iTi at the lowest part [&c.] of the wall. (TA.) And qalaEahu mino A^aSolihi [He pulled it up, or out, or off, from its root, or foundation, or lowest part]; and bA^uSuwlihi [with its roots, or foundations, or lowest parts; both meaning, utterly, entirely, or altogether]. (TA in explanation of AstA^Slhu, q. v.) And qalaEa A^aSola Al$~ajarapi He pulled up, or out, the lowest part, [or stem or stock or root or foot or stump,] of the tree. (TA.) Lebeed says, [of a wild cow,]
tajotaAfu A=Sula qaAliSK mutanab~i*K
biEujuwbi A^anoqaA='K yamiylu hayaAmuhaA
[She enters into the midst of the stems of trees with high branches, apart from others, i. e. from other trees, in the hinder parts of sand-hills, the fine loose sand thereof inclining upon her]: (AHn, TA:) but as some relate it, A^aSolFA qaAliSFA. (TA. [See EM, p. 161.]) ― -b2- A thing upon which another thing is built or founded [either properly or tropically]: (KT, Kull p. 50, TA:) the foundation, or basis, of a thing, [either properly or tropically,] which being imagined to be taken away, or abstracted, by its being taken away, or abstracted, the rest thereof becomes also taken away, or abstracted: (Er-Rághib, TA:) that upon which the existence of anything rests [or depends]; so the father is ASl to the offspring, and the river is ASl to the streamlet that branches off from it: (Msb:) or a thing upon which another thing depends as a branch; as the father in relation to the son: (Kull:) [i. e. the origin, source, beginning, or commencement, of a thing: the origin, original, root, race, or stock, from which a man springs. Hence $aYo'N lahu A^aSolN A thing having root, or a foundation; and consequently, having rootedness, fixedness, im- mobility, stability, or permanence; rooted, fixed, immoveable, stable, or permanent. Whence,] maAlN lahu A^aSolN, (Mgh voce EaqaArN,) and milokN vaAbitN lahu A^aSolN, (Msb in explanation of that word,) and maA lahu A^aSolN, (KT in explanation of the same,) [Real, or immoveable, property;] property such as consists in a house or land yielding a revenue; (Mgh;) or such as a house and palm-trees; (Msb;) or such as land and a house. (KT.) [Hence, also, A^aSolN maAlK signifying A source of wealth or profit; a stock, fund, capital, or principal. You say,] Ait~axa*otuhu linafosiY A^aSola maAlKliln~asoli laA lilit~ijaArapi [I took it for myself as a source of wealth or profit, for breeding, not for traffic]. (Mgh in art. qnw.) You say also, baAEa A^aSola A^aroDihi [meaning He sold the fundamental property, i. e. the property itself, of his land]. (S voce EikorN.) [See also an ex. in conjugation 4 in art. bqaY: and another in the first paragraph of art. Hbs.] And A^axa*ahu biA^aSolihi [He took it as it were with its root, or the like; meaning, entirely]. (K. [See A^aSiylapN.]) And qaTaEa A^aSolahumo [He cut off their root, race, or stock; i. e. he extirpated them]. (M.) And fulaAnN fiY A^aSoli Sidoqi, (S and L in art. DnA^,) and
fiY A^aSoli suwo'K, (L ibid.,) Such a one is of an excel-lent origin, or race, or stock, (S, L,) and of a bad origin, or race, or stock; (L;) ASl being here syn. with Dino' (S, L) and maEodin. (S.) And fulaAnN fiY A^aSoli Alkarami Such a one is of [a race] the source of generosity, or nobleness; ASl being here syn. with buw^obuw^. (S in art. bA^.) And laA A^aSola lahu wa laA faSola He has no Hasab [i. e. grounds of pretension to respect or honour; or rank, or nobility, or the like]; nor tongue [i. e. eloquence]: (Ks, S, O, Msb:) or he has no intellect, (IAar, Msb, El-Munáwee,) nor eloquence: (El-Munáwee, TA:) or he has no lineage, nor tongue: (L:) or he has no father, nor child: (Kull p. 53:) [or he has no known stock nor branch; for] faSolN is the contr. of A^aSolN, and in relationship signifies a branch. (Msb in art. fSl.) You say also, maA faEalotuhu A^aSolFA, meaning I have not done it ever; and I will not do it ever; the last word being in the accus. case as an adverbial noun; i. e. I have not done it at any time; and I will not do it at any time. (Msb, El-Munáwee, TA.) ― -b3- [It also signifies The original, or elemental, matter, material, substance, or part, of a thing; syn. with EunoSurN;] that from which a thing is taken [or made]. (KT voce daAxilN.) ― -b4- [The fundamental, or essential, part of a thing. Hence, sing. of A^uSuwlN as signifying The fundamentals, fundamental articles or dogmas, principles, elements, or rudiments, of a science &c. Whence,] Eilomu AlA^uSuwli, (TA,) [meaning] Eilomu A^uSuwli Ald~iyni [The science of the fundamentals, fundamental articles or dogmas, or principles, of religion; the science of theology, or divinity; according to the system of the Muslims, as distinguished from that of the philosophers;] the science of the articles, or tenets, of belief; also called Alfiqohu AlA^akobaru; (Kull. voce fiqoh;) and [more commonly] Eilomu AlkalaAmi. (Hájjee Khaleefeh.) [See also 2.] ― -b5- A radical (as opposed to an augmentative) letter; as being an essential element of a word. (The Lexicons passim.) ― -b6- The original form of a word. (The same passim.) ― -b7- The original, or primary, signification of a word. (The same passim.) ― -b8- An original copy of a book: and a copy of a book from which one quotes, or transcribes, any portion. (TA, &c., passim.) ― -b9- [The original, or primary, state, or condition: or] the old state, or condition. (Kull p. 50.) You say, AlA^aSolu fiY AlA^a$oyaA='i AlA_ibaAHapu wa AlT~ahaArapu The old state, or condition, of things is that of being allowable, or lawful, and that of being pure, or clean. (Kull ubi suprà.) And rajaEato A_ilaY A^aSolihaA She returned, or reverted, [to her original, or old, state, or condition; or to her natural disposition;] to a natural disposition which she had relinquished. (S voce EitorN.) ― -b10- [The utmost point, or degree, to which a person, or thing, can go, or be brought or reduced: and, app., the utmost that one can do. Hence the saying,] laA^aDoTar~an~aka A_ilaY A^aSolika [I will assuredly impel thee, or drive thee, against thy will, to the utmost point to which thou canst go, or be brought or reduced: or, constrain thee to do thine utmost]. (IAar in L, art. qH [where it is given in explanation of the phrases laA^aDoTar~an~aka and quHaAHika; and so in the T in art. tr in explanation of the former of these two phrases; which is said in the M, in art. tr, to mean I will assuredly make thee to have recourse to thine utmost effort, or endeavour; and in the L in art. qH this is given as another explanation of the latter of the same two phrases. See also the saying, laA^ulojiy^an~aka A_ilaY qur~i qaraArika, explained voce qaraArN.]) ― -b11- [That by being which a thing is what it is, or in being which it consists; or its ultimate constituent; syn. HaqiyqapN; a meaning well known; and indicated, in the A and TA, by the coupling of Haqiyqap with A^aSol, evidently as an explicative adjunct.] ― -b12- [The prime of a thing; the principal, purest, best, or choicest, part thereof; what is, or constitutes, the most essential part thereof; its very essence. Hence,] A^aSolu daArK [The principal part of a country]; (As, S, Msb, K, voce EaqorN;) [which is] the place where the people dwell, or abide. (As and S ibid. [See EaqorN.]) And A^aSolN qawomK [The principal place of abode of a people]. (S and K voce bayoDapN. [See this word.]) And huwa fiY A^aSoli qawomihi He is of the prime, or of the purest in race, the best, or the choicest, of his people; i. q. Suy~aAbatihimo, and Suy~aAbihimo. (TA in art. Syb.) ― -b13- What is most fit, or proper: as when one says, AlA^aSolu fiY AlA_inosaAni AlEilomu [What is most fit, or proper, in man, is knowledge]; i. e., knowledge is more fit, or proper, than ignorance: and AlA^aSolu fiY AlmubotadaA_i Alt~aqodiymu What is [most] fit, or proper, in the case of the inchoative, is the putting [it] before [the enunciative], whenever there is no obstacle. (Kull p.50.) ― -b14- What is preponderant in relation to what is preponderated: as, in language, the word used in its proper sense [in relation to that used in a tropical sense]. (Kull ibid.) ― -b15- What is [essential, or] requisite, or needful: as when one says AlA^aSolu fiY AlHayawaAni Algi*aA='u [What is essential, or requisite, or needful, in the case of the animal, is food]. (Kull ibid.) ― -b16- A [primary, or] universal, or general, rule, or canon. (Kull ibid.) ― -b17- An indication, an evidence, or a proof, in relation to that which is indicated, or evidenced, or proved. (Kull ibid.)
A^aSalN * : see its n. un., A^aSalapN

Msb, K,) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.,] and [pl. of pauc.] A=SaAlN. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] (assumed tropical:) Short and broad: applied to a man and to a woman. (TA.)

And $ar~N A^aSiylN Vehement evil or mischief. (Ibn-'Abbád.) -A2- See also A^aSilN, in two places. ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] AlA^aSiylu Destruction: and death: as also, in both senses, ↓ AlA^aSiylapu. (K.) -A3- [The evening; or] i. q. Ea$iY~N; (M, K, Msb, TA;) i. e. (Msb, TA) the time from the EaSor, (S, TA,) from the prayer of the ESr, (Msb,) to sunset; (Sudot;, Msb, TA;) as also ↓ A^aSiylapN: (R, TA:) the pl. is A^uSulN, (S, M, R, Msb, K,) or ↓ this is a sing., (TA,) or it may be a sing., (M,) for it is used as such, (M, TA,) and A^uSolaAnN, (S, M, K,) and A=SaAlN, (S, M, Sgh, K,) [a pl. of pauc.,] or, accord. to Es- Saláh Es-Safadee, this is a pl. of A^uSulN, the sing., not the pl., (TA,) or it is pl. of A^uSulN, (Zj, M,) which may be a pl. or a sing., (M,) and A^aSaAy^ilu, (S, M, K,) as though pl. of A^aSiylapN, (S,) or it is pl. of this last word. A^uSolaAnu is formed the dim. ↓ A^uSayolaAnN, (S, M, K,) which is extr., (M, K,) because the dim. of a pl. is [regularly] formed only from a pl. of pauc., which ASlAn is not; or, if ASlAn be a sing., like rum~aAnN and qurobaAnN, this

AaTi3a , (K,) inf. n. A^aTiyTN (S, K) and A^aT~N, (TA,) It produced, made, gave, emitted, or uttered, a sound, noise, voice, or cry; (S, K;) [and particularly, it creaked; and it moaned;] said of a camel's saddle, (S, * K, [in the CK, Alr~ajulu is put by mistake for Alr~aHolu ]) [and particularly of a new camel's saddle,] and the like, (K,) such as a [plaited or woven girth called] nisoE and of everything of which the sound resembles that of a new camel's saddle, (TA,) and of a palm-trunk, and of a tree of the kind called sidor, (S TA,) or of the kind called saroH, (TA,) and of a cane or reed on the occasion of its being straightened, [in which instance it is said to be tropical, but if so it is tropical in several other instances,] and of a bow, (TA,) and of the belly by reason of emptiness, (S,* TA,) and, in a trad. of Aboo-Dharr, (tropical:) of heaven, or the sky, notwithstanding there being [really] no A^aTiyT in this instance, for it is meant to denote [the presence of] multitude, and confirmation of the majesty of God. (TA.) [It is also said of other things, as will be shown by phrases here following, and by explanations of A^aTiyTN below.] You also say, A^aT~ati AlA_ibilu, (K,) aor. as above, inf. n. A^aTiyTN, (TA,) The camels moaned by reason of fatigue, or uttering their yearning cry to their young, (K, TA,) and sometimes by reason of fulness of their udders with milk. (TA.) And laA A=tiyka maA A^aT~ati AlA_ibilu I will not come to thee as long as camels utter cries [or moan] by reason of the heaviness of their loads. (S.) And laA A^afoEalu *`lika maA A^aT~ati AlA_ibilu, meaning I will not do that ever. (TA.) And maA lanaA baEiyrN yay^iT~u We have not a camel that moans, or cries; meaning we have not any camel; for the camel cannot but do so. (TA, from a trad.) [See also A^aTiyTN, below.] And A^aT~ato lahu raHimiY (tropical:) [My feeling of relationship, or sympathy of blood,] became affected with tenderness, or compassion, and became moved, [or rather pleaded,] for him [or in his favour]: (K, TA:) and hence ↓Alt~aA^aT~uTu [inf. n. of the verb in the syn. phrase taA^aT~aTato lahu raHimiY]. (Sgh, TA.) And A^aT~ato bika Alr~aHimu [The feeling of relationship, or sympathy of blood, pleaded, or hath pleaded, in thee;] i. e., inclined thee to favour. (Ham p. 765.) [See another ex. voce HaAs~apN.]

A^aTiyTN * [as explained in what here follows seems to be properly an inf. n., though, like all inf. ns., it may be used as a subst.:] The sounding, or the like, or the sound, or the like, [and particularly the creaking, or creaking sound, and the moaning, or moaning sound,] of a camel's saddle (S, K, TA) when new; (TA;) and so ↓A^aT~N of the litters and saddles of camels when the riders are heavy thereon; and the former, also, of a door; said, in a trad., of the gate of paradise, by reason of its being crowded; (TA;) and of a plaited or woven thong when stretching; (Ez-Zejjájee, TA;) and of the back [when strained]; (K;) and of the bowels, (TA,) and of the belly, or inside, by reason of hunger, (K,) or by reason of vehement hunger; (TA;) and of camels, (S, K,) by reason of their burdens, (K,) or by reason of the heaviness of their burdens; (S;) and the prolonging of the cries of camels: (TA:) but 'Alee Ibn- Hamzeh says that the cry of camels is termed rugaA='N, and that A^aTiyTN signifies the sounding, or sound, of their bellies, or insides, by reason of repletion from drinking. (IB, TA.) A^aholN SahiylK w^aA^aTiyTK, occurring in a trad., means (assumed tropical:) Possessors of horses and of camels. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Hunger, (K, TA,) itself, as well as the sound of the bowels or belly by reason thereof: from EzZejjájee. (TA.)

Sounding much; noisy; (K, TA;) having a sound: applied [to any of the things mentioned above in the explanations of A^aT~a and A^aTiyTN; and] to a hide; and to a camel repleted with drink; and to a road: fem. with p: which, applied to a woman, signifies one whose faroj has a sound A_i*aA juwmiEato. (TA.)

AaTira (S, Msb, K) and
AaTura , (K,) inf. n. A^aTorN; (S, Msb, K;) and ↓A^T~rhu inf. n. taA^oTiyrN; (K;) He bent it, or curved it; (S, Msb, K, &c.;) namely, a bow, (S, A,) and a twig, or the like: (A:) he laid hold upon one of its two extremities, and curved it: he bent it, or curved it; namely, anything; EalaY $~aYo'K upon a thing: and the latter verb, [or both,] he bent it into the form of a hoop, bringing its two extremities together. (TA.) ― -b3- And one says, A^axa*a EalaY yadaYi AlZ~aAlimi waA^aTarahu EalaY AlHaq~i (tropical:) [He laid hold upon the two hands, or arms, of the wrongdoer, or prevented, restrained, or withheld, him from doing that which he desired,] and bent him to [conformity with] what was right. (AA, from a trad.) And A^aTarota fulaAnFA EalaY mawad~atika (tropical:) [Thou hast bent such a one to love thee]. (A.) ― -b4- A^aTara Als~ahoma (S, K,) aor.
AaTira and
AaTura , (K,) inf. n. as above, (S, K,) He wound an A^uTorap upon the arrow. (S, K.) ― -b5- A^aTara Albayota, (TK,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He made an A_iTaAr, which is a thing resembling a zone or belt, to the tent or house. (K, TK.)

It (a spear) bent: (S, K:) it (a thing) became crooked, curved, or bent; as also ↓ AnA^Tr: (K, TA:) it became bent into the form of a hoop, its two extremities being brought together. (TA.) ― -b2- taA^aT~arato She affected a bending of her person, body, or limbs, in her gait. (A.) -A2- He confined himself (K, TA) in a place. (TA.) ― -b2- taA^aT~arato She (a woman) remained, or stayed, in her house, or tent; (S, K;) she kept to it. (TA.) [See also 2.]

(Skr, TA.)

(K, TA.) ― -b3- The flesh surrounding the nail: (K:) pl.A^uTarN and A_iTaArN. (TA.) ― -b4- A mixture of ashes and blood with which a fracture in a cooking-pot is smeared (S, K) and repaired. (TA.)

A_iTaArN ATAr A_TAr
Anything that surrounds another thing: (S, A, Msb, K:) as the hoop of a tambourine, (A, Mgh, TA,) and of a sieve. (S, A, Mgh, K.) ― -b2- A ring of hair surrounding the head, the
middle of it being bald. (TA.) ― -b3- ― -b4- The branches of a vine, bent, or wreathed, so as to form a covering over-head. (S.) ― -b7- A_iTaAru Al$~afapi (S, K, &c.) (tropical:) The part, (A,) or flesh, (Msb,) surrounding the lip: (A, Msb:) or the part that separates between the lip and the hairs of the mustache: (K:) or the edge of the upper lip, between the lip itself and the parts where the hair grows: (IAth:) or the rising edge, or ridge, between the part where the mustache is clipped and the lip, intermixing with the mouth. (A'Obeyd.) The Muslim should clip his mustache so that this part shall appear. (Msb, TA.) ― -b8- A_iTaAru bayotK A thing resembling a zone, or belt, of a tent or house. (K.) ― -b9- A_iTaAri mina Aln~aAsi (tropical:) A ring, or circle, of men. (K.) One says, humo A_iTaArN libaniY fulaAnK (tropical:) They have alighted and taken up their abode [so that they form a ring] around the sons of such a one. (A, Msb.)

A^aTiyrN *
A sin; a crime; an offence. (S, K.) One says, A^axa*aniY biA^aTiyri gayoriY He punished me for the sin, crime, or offence, of another than myself. (S.)

maA^oTuwrapN *
A bow. (A.) ― -b2- A milking-vessel of skin (EulobapN) for the head of which a twig is bent into the form of a hoop, and put round, after which its lip is covered; (K, TA;) or, sometimes, the edges of the skin of the Elbp are folded upon the hoop-formed twig, and dry upon it. (TA.)

Ajm) A fortress: or, as some say, any lofty building: (Mgh:) or a [building such as is termed] qaSor [q. v.]: (IAar, K:) and any fortress built of stones: and any square, roofed, house: (K:) pl. (of pauc., TA) A=TaAmN (S, Mgh. K) and (of mult., TA) A^uTuwmN: (K:) A=TaAmN signifies fortresses of the people of El-Medeeneh: and one of these is termed ↓ A^aTamapN: (S:) or this signifies [simply] a fortress; and its pl. is A=TaAmN (TA.)

Lofty [fortresses, &c.]: (A, TA:) [or it may signify fortresses, &c., disposed in order, or grouped together; for it is said to be] a phrase like A^abowaAbN mubaw~abapN, (O, TA,) or like A^ajonaAdN mujan~adapN. (K.)

1 A^af~a * , aor. yaw^uf~N (IDrd, M, Mgh, K,) and yay^if~u, (IDrd, M, K,) the latter agreeable with analogy, (TA,) [but the former, though irregular, is the more common,] inf. n. A^af~N; (M, Mgh;) and ↓ A^f~f, inf. n. tA^ofiyfN; (S, Mgh, K;) and ↓ tA^f~f; (M, K;) He said A^uf~i [q. v.], (IDrd, S, M, Mgh, K,) by reason of anxiety, or disquietude of mind, or by reason of vexation, distress of mind, or disgust: (IDrd, M, K:) held by Sb to be of the same class as sab~aHa and hal~ala meaning “ he said suboHaAna A@ll~`hi ” and “ he said laA A_il`ha A_il~aA A@ll~`hu. ” (M.) And Ealayohi ↓ A_in~ahu yataA^af~afu Verily he is angry with him, or enraged against him. (TA.)

A_ifo A^f A_f Af wfY and its vars. (differing only in having the f movent): see the next paragraph.

A^uf~N *
Dirt, or filth; as also ↓ A^uf~apN: (S:) you say, A^uf~aA lahu, and ↓ A^uf~apF, Dirt, or filth, to him; in which the tenween is for the purpose of rendering them indeterminate; (S;) and A^uf~a lahu wa tuf~N; (T;) and watuf~apF ↓ A^uf~apF; and A^uf~aA watuf~aA; (T, S;) the latter of which is an imitative sequent: (S:) or A^uf~N signifies the dirt of the ear; and tuf~N, the dirt of the nails; (As, T, M, K; but in the last, of the nail;) the phrases mentioned above being used on the occasion of deeming a thing dirty or filthy, and afterwards on the occasion of experiencing annoyance or disgust at anything; (As, T, M,* TA;) and ↓ A^afafN, also, has the former of these two meanings: (TA:) or A^uf~N signifies the dirt around the nail; (M;) or the dirt of the nail; (K;) and tuf~N, the dirt in the nail: (M:) or the former, a paring of the nail: and a piece of stick, or a reed, which one takes up from the ground: (K:) in these various senses they are explained as used in the saying, A^uf~aA lahu watuf~aA: (TA:) or the former signifies stink: (Zj, TA:) or paucity; (T, M, K) as also ↓ A^afafN; (M;) or from ↓ A^afafN signifying a thing little in quantity; (T; and the same meaning is assigned to this word in the K;) and tuf~N is an imitative sequent, (T, M, K,) of the same meaning. (M.) ― -b2- A^uf~, also, is a word expressive of vexation, distress of mind, or disgust; (M, Mgh;) or of dislike, displeasure, or hatred; (K;) and has six forms; (T, S;) mentioned by Akh; (S;) or ten; (M;) or forty; (K;) or more; (TA;) as follow: A^uf~i and A^uf~a and A^uf~u and A^uf~K and A^uf~aA and A^uf~N (T, S, M, K) and A^uf~i and A^ufa and A^ufu and A^ufK and A^ufFA and A^ufN (K) and A^ufo (M, K) and A^uf~o and ↓ A^uf~aY, pronounced with imáleh, (M, K,) i. e. with pure imáleh, and ↓ A^uf~aY with intermediate imáleh, and ↓ A^uf~aY without imáleh, the alif [written Y] in these three denoting the fem. gender, and ↓ A^uf~iY, with kesr to the f, (K,) i. e., as a prefixed noun with its complement, [the latter being the pronoun of the first pers.,] (TA,) and ↓ A^uf~uwoho, (K,) with damm to the A^ and f, which latter is with teshdeed, and with the w and h quiescent, (TA,) and ↓ A^uf~apo [in a copy of the M ↓ A^uf~apF] and ↓ A^ufiho and ↓ A^uf~uho (K) and ↓ A_ifo and ↓ A_if~o and ↓ A_ifi and ↓ A_ifK and ↓ A_ifFA and ↓ A_ifN and ↓ A_if~K and ↓ A_if~F and ↓ A_if~N and ↓ A_if~u, with damm to the f, which is with teshdeed, [in a copy of the M ↓ A_if~a,] and ↓ A_if~aA, like A_in~aA, and ↓ A_if~aY, pronounced with imáleh, and ↓ A_if~iY, with kesr, (K,) i. e., prefixed to the pronoun of the first person, (IAmb,) and ↓ A^afo and ↓ A^af~i (K) and ↓ A^af~K or ↓ A^afK and ↓ A=fi, or ↓ A=f~i, and ↓ A=fK, or ↓ A=f~K, (accord. to different copies of the K,) [all these forms, making the number (forty) mentioned by the author of the K, I have drawn from a comparison of three copies of that work, and I believe them to be correct: some other forms are mentioned by SM as perhaps indicated in the K; but I see no good reason for this: he then adds,] and ↓ A^afaho and ↓ A^afuwho and ↓ A^af~aho, the last mentioned by IB on the authority of IKtt. (TA.) A^uf~i, [with its variants,] in its primary sense, denotes one's blowing at a thing that falls upon him, such as dust or ashes; or at the place, to remove therefrom what is annoying; therefore people say, at anything that they deem troublesome, or displeasing, or hateful, A^uf~i lahu [as though meaning A puff, or blast of breath, to it]: (Kt, T:) or [rather] it is a word imitative of a sound; [like ugh in English, both in sound and meaning; and in meaning like our interjections foh and faugh;] (Bd on the ex. in the Kur which will be found below, and TA;) denoting vexation, or distress of mind, or disgust; (Bd ubi suprà) or denoting contempt: (TA:) or it is a verbal noun, meaning I am vexed, or distressed in mind, or disgusted: (Bd ubi suprà:) or it is an imperative verbal noun [denoting disgust or abhorrence, like out, and away]: (IJ, M:) or he who says A^uf~aA laka uses it in the manner of an imprecation, like as one says wayolFA lilokaAfiriyna; and he who says A^uf~N laka puts it in the nom. case because of the l, like as one says wayolN lilokaAfiriyna; and he who says A^uf~K laka puts it in the gen. case likening it to words imitative of sounds. (IAmb.) It is said in the Kur [xvii. 24], walaA taqulo lahumaA A^uf~i, (T, S, TA,) or A^uf~K, (TA, [in which other readings also are mentioned,]) [And say not thou to them (i. e. to thy father and mother) Ugh, &c.,] meaning, do not thou deem anything of their affairs burdensome, nor be contracted in bosom thereby, nor be rough, or harsh, or coarse, to them: (Kt, T:) or do not thou say to them anything expressive of the least disgust, when they have become old, but take upon thyself their service; A^uf~i signifying stink. (Zj, T.)
A_ifo A^f A_f Af wfY and its vars. (differing only in having the f movent): see A^uf~N. -A2- For A_if~N, see also A_if~aAnN, in three places.
A^af~apN * : see A_if~aAnN, in two places.

A^uf~apN * : see A^uf~N, in four places. -A2- Also A dirty, a filthy, an unclean, man: (K:) from A^uf~N signifying the “dirt of the nail.” (TA.) ― -b2- One in want; poor; possessing little: (K:) from A^afafN signifying “a thing little in quantity.” (TA.) ― -b3-
A coward: (K:) as though originally *uw A^uf~apK, i. e. holding back, by reason of disgust, (mutaA^af~ifN,) from fight: (TA:) or experiencing vexation or disgust, and languid or sluggish, in war: (IAar:) also heavy, or sluggish. (IAth.)
A_if~apN A^fh Afh Afp fAh wfY |fp : see A_if~aAnN in three places.

A^afafN *
Vexation, distress of mind, or disgust. (T, IAth, K.) ― -b2- See also A^uf~N, in three places. -A2- And see A_if~aAnN, in three places.
A^afaho * and A^af~ahN and A^Nf~ahN and A^uf~iho and A^uf~uho: see A^uf~N.
A^uf~aY * , pronounced in three different ways; and
A^uf~iY * : see A^uf~N.
A_if~aA AfA : and A_if~aY and A_if~iY: see A^uf~N.
A^afuwho * : see A^uf~N.
A^ufuwfapN * : see what next follows.

A^af~aAfN * A man who says A^uf~i much or often; (M, TA;) as also ↓ A^uwfuwfapN, accord. to the copies of the O and TS and K; but in other lexicons ↓ A^uwfuwfapN: in the O, one who ceases not to say to another A^uf~i laka: in the Jm, the last of these three words is explained as meaning one who ceases no to say this at some of his affairs. (TA.)

A_if~aAnN A^fyn A_fAn A_yfAn AfAn (T, S, M, K) and A^af~aAnN (T, TS, L, K) and ↓ A_if~N (S, M, K) and ↓ A^afafN (T, L, K) and ↓ A_if~apq (L, M) and ↓ A^af~apN (M) and ↓ tiy^if~apN, (T, M, S, K, &c.,) of the measure tafoEilapN, [being originally taA^ofifapN,] accord. to J, who appears to be right in saying so, (IB,) and so accord. to Aboo-'Alee, who states, on authority of Aboo-Bekr, that it is thus in some of the copies of the Book of Sb, (L,) though in other copies of that book said to be of the measure faEil~apN, (IB, L,) A time; (T, S, M, K;) as in the sayings, *`lika ↓ kaAna *`lika Ealay A_if~i, and A_if~aAnihi (S, TA) and ↓ A^afafihi, and ↓ A_if~atihi, and ↓ tay^if~atihi, (TA,) That was at the time of that; (S, TA;) and A^ataAniY fiY A_if~aAni *`lika, (IAar, L,) and EalaY A_if~aAni *`lika, (IAar, T, M, L,) and A^af~aAnihi, (T, L,) and ↓ A_if~ihi, (M, L,) and ↓ A^afafihi, (IAar, T, L,) and ↓ A_if~atihi, (M, L,) and ↓ A^af~atihi, (M,) and ↓ tay^if~atihi, (IAar, T, S, M, L,) preceded by ElY, (IAar, T, S, &c.,) and by fY, (L,) He came to me at the time of that. (IAar, T, &c.)
A^uf~uwoho * : see A^uf~N.
A=fi A=f and A=f~i and A=fK and A=f~K: see A^uf~N.
A^uwfuwfapN * : see A^af~aAfN.
tay^if~apN * : see A_if~AnN, in three places.
mutaA^af~ifN Eani AlqitaAli * [app. Holding back, by reason of disgust, from fight; as though saying A^uf~ at the mention thereof: see A^uf~apN]. (TA.)

1 A^afaxahu * , (A'Obeyd, S, L, &c.,) aor.
Aafixa , inf. n.
A^afoxN * , (L,) He, [or it] struck him, or hit him, [or hurt him,] on the part of his head called the yaA^ofuwx. (A'Obeyd, S, L, Msb, K.) He who pronounces yAfwx without ' says yafaxahu. (Msb.)
maA^ofuwxN * A man having his head broken in the part called the yaA^ofuwx. (L.)

yaA^ofuwxN * , (Lth, Az, S, Msb, K,) as also yaAfuwxN, without ', but the former is the more correct and the better, (Lth, Az, Msb,) and is of the measure yafoEuwlN, (Lth, Az, S, Msb,) whereas the latter is of the measure faAEuwlN, (Lth, Az, Msb,) [The top, vertex, or crown, of the head; or the part of the top of the head which is crossed by the coronal suture, and comprises a portion of the sagittal suture;] the part where the anterior and posterior bones of the head meet; (K;) the place that is in a state of commotion in the head of an infant; (S;) the place which, in the head of a child, does not close up until after some years; or does not become knit together in its several parts; and this is where the bone of the anterior part of the head and that of its posterior part meet; (Zj in his “ Khalk el-Insán; ”) the place that is soft, in a child's head, before the two bones called the nam~aAgap and ram~aAEap meet, between the haAmap [or middle of the head] and the forehead: (L:) or the middle of the head when it has become hard and strong; before which it is not thus called: (Msb:) pl. yaA=fiyxu; (S;) so in the old lexicons [in general]; but in the T and K yawaAfiyxu [which is pl. of yAfwx without '; or, as pl. of yA^fwx, is like tawaAriyxu as pl. of taA^oriyxN]; and because of this form of the pl., F says that J is in error in mentioning the word in the present art.: it has been shown, however, that J is not in error in this case. (TA.) — [Hence the saying,] A^anotumo yaA=fiyxu Al$~arafi (tropical:) Ye are the centres and summits of the heads of nobility. (L, from a trad.) And yaA^ofuwxu All~ayoli (assumed tropical:) The main [or middle] part of the night. (S, K.) — [See also art. yfx.]

1 A^afaqa * , (JK, S, K,) aor.
Aafiqa , (JK, K,) inf. n. A^afoqN, (TK,) He went his own way, at random, or heedlessly, (rakiba raA^osahu,) and went away in the A=faAq [or regions, &c., of the land]: (Lth, JK, K:) or he went away in, or into, the land, or country: (S:) and he took his way into the A=fAq [or regions, &c.,] of the land. (JK.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] A^afaqa, aor. as above; thus, says IB, accord. to Kz, and thus it is given on the authority of Kr; (TA;) [see A=fiqN;] or A^afiqa, aor.
Aafaqa , (S, O, K,) inf. n. A^afaqN; (S;) He attained the utmost degree, [as though he reached the A^ufuq (or horizon, or furthest point of view,)] in generosity; (S, O, K;) or in knowledge, or science; or in chasteness of speech, or eloquence, and in the combination of excellent qualities. (K.) ― -b3- Also, A^afaqa, aor.
Aafiqa , (Kr, Ibn-'Abbád, JK, K,) inf. n. A^afoqN, (JK, TA,) He overcame, or surpassed. (Kr, Ibn-'Abbád, JK, K.) ― -b4- And, inf. n, A^ufuwqN, He was goodly, or beautiful; he possessed the quality of exciting admiration and approval by his beauty and the pleasingness of his aspect; said of a camel, and of a horse. (JK.) ― -b5- A^afaqa Ealayohi (JK, TA) He (a man) excelled him; namely, another man: (JK:) or he preceded him in excellence; or outwent him therein; as also A^afaqahu, aor.
Aafiqa . (TA.) [It is like faAqahu.] ― -b6- A^afaqa fiY AlEaTaA='i, aor.
Aafiqa , (S, K,) inf. n. A^afoqN, (TA,) He gave to some more than to others. (S, K.) So in the saying of El-Aashà,
walaA Almalika Aln~uEomaAnu yawoma laqiytuhu
bigiboTatihi yuEoTiY AlquTuwTa wa yaA^ofiqu
[Nor the King En-Noamán, on the day that I met him, in his goodly, or happy, condition, giving gifts, or stipends, or written obligations conferring gifts, and giving to some more than to others]: (S:) or the meaning is, writing [writs of] gifts, and sealing them: or, as some say, taking his way into the A=fAq [or regions, &c.,] of the land. (JK.) -A2- A^afaqahu, aor.
Aafiqa , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. A^afoqN, (S, Msb,) He tanned it (namely a hide) until it became what is termed A^afiyq. (S, Msb, * K.)

5 tA^f~q binaA *
He (a man, As, TA) came to us mino A^ufuqK [from a region, &c., of the land]: (As, K:) or came to us, and alighted at our abode as a guest: and in the Nawádir el-Aaráb, tA^f~q bihi is said to signify he reached him, or overtook him; as also tl~fq bh (TA.)
A^ufoqN * : see A^ufuqN.

A^afaqN * The main and middle part (sanan) of a road; (K;) the face, or surface, thereof: (IAar, K:) pl. A=faAqN. (K.) Hence the saying, qaEada fulaAnN EalaY A^afaqi AlT~ariyqi [Such a one sat upon the main and middle part, or face, or surface, of the road]. (TA.) ― -b2- The flanks, or ilia: or, as some say, skins; or skin; as in the saying, $aribotu Hat~aY malaA^otu A^afaqiy I drank until I filled my skin: (JK:) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of ↓ A^afaqapN; (IAar;) which signifies the flank; (IAar, K;) as does also ↓ A=fiqapN. (Th, K.) ― -b3- Also pl., (S, K,) or [rather] quasi-pl. n., (M, K,) of A^afiyqN, q. v. (S, M, K.)
A^afiqN * : see A^afiyqN, in two places.

A^ufuqN * (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.) and ↓ A^ufoqN (S, K) A side; meaning a lateral, or an outward or adjacent, part or portion; or a part, region, quarter, or tract, considered with respect to its collocation or juxtaposition or direction, or considered as belonging to a whole; or a remote side; syn. naAHiyapN; (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K;) and a border, or an extremity; (JK;) of a land, or of the earth; and of the sky, or heavens: (JK, Mgh, Msb:) [or the horizon, or part next to the horizon, of the sky and of the earth;] or what appears of the sides (Aln~awaAHiY) of the celestial sphere, (K, TA,) and of the borders, or extremities, of the earth: (TA:) or the place whence blows the south wind, and the north wind, and the west wind, and the east wind: (K, * TA:) pl. A=faAqN: (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K:) and the sing. also is used as a pl.; like fulokN, as is said in
the Nh: (MF:) thus in the verse of El-'Abbás, in praise of the Prophet:
A^anota lam~a wulidota A^a$oraqati AlA^aro
DuwaDaA='a to binuwrika AlA^ufuqu
[When thou wast born, the earth became bright, and the tracts of the horizon, or the regions, shone with thy light]: or, as some say, AlAfq is made fem. by him as meaning Aln~aAHiyapu. (TA.) The phrase Hiyna yagiybu AlA^ufuqu means When the redness, or whiteness, in the A^ufuq [or horizon] disappears. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Also, in like manner, The side, or lateral part, of a tent: (JK:) or the part between the [two] anterior [pieces of wood called the] zir~aAni, in the [fore part called the] riwaAq, of a tent: (K:) and the sides, or lateral parts, of a tent of the kind belonging to the Arabs of the desert. (TA.) -A2- A^ufuqN is also said to be a pl. of A^afiyqN; but this is disallowed by Lh. (TA.) -A3- See also A=fiqN.
A^afaqapN * : see A^afaqN. -A2- Also A burying of a skin, or hide, in the earth, so that its hair may be removed, and it may become ready for tanning. (Lth, K,* TA.) [See A^afiyqN.]

A^afaqiY~N * , (ISk, JK, T, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) contr. to rule, (T, Msb,) and ↓ A^ufuqiY~N, (As, ISk, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) agreeably with rule, (S,) being a rel. n. from A^ufuqN, (Msb,) and some (namely the lawyers, in relation to pilgrimage and the like, MF) say ↓ A=faAqiY~N, (Mgh, MF,) which is incorrect, (Mgh, Msb,) or whether it be correct, after the manner of A^anoSaAriY~N and the like, requires consideration, (MF,) an epthet applied to a man, (ISk, S, Msb,) meaning One who is from the A=faAq [or lateral parts, or regions,] of the land; (ISk,* S, Msb;*) mentioned by Aboo-Nasr: (S, referring to the first form of the word:) or one who goes about in the A=faAq: (JK:) or one who goes through the A=fAq of the land in search of sustenance: (K,* TA:) as also ↓ A^af~aAqN. (K, TA.) A^ufuqiY~u mak~apa or A^afaqiY~u mk~p means He who is without the places where the pilgrims coming to Mekkeh enter upon the state of A_iHoraAm. (Mgh.)
A^ufuqiY~N * : see A^afaqiY~N.

A^afiyqN * : see A=fiqN. ― -b2- Applied also to a bucket (dalow), meaning Excelling other buckets. (AA, K.) -A2- Also, (As, Th, JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and ↓ A^afiyqapN, (K,) or the latter is a more particular term than the former, like as jilodapN is more so than jilodN, (Mgh,) and ↓ A^afiqN, (K, [but see what follows,]) The skin, or hide, that is not completely tanned, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) so that it is unsubstantial, not firm, or strong, or tough: (Mgh:) when its tanning is complete, and it becomes red, it is termed A^adiym: therefore A^afiyqN is of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: (Msb:) or in the second stage of its tanning; for in the first stage it is termed maniyoy^ap; then, Afyq; and then, Adym: (TA:) or that is tanned, but before it is sewed: (As, S, K:) or before it is cut, or slit: (K:) or when it comes forth from the tan, its tanning being finished, (JK, TA,) its [original] odour being [still] in it: (TA:) or after it is tanned: (Msb:) or not tanned: (Th, TA:) or that is tanned without qaraZ or A^aroTaY or any of the tans of the people of Nejd: (TA:) ISd says, I think that Th has mentioned ↓ A^afiqN as syn. with A^afiyqN, and explained it as signifying the skin, or hide, that is not tanned; but I am not sure of it: (TA:) the pl. is A^afaqN, (Lh, JK, S, Msb, K,) like as A^adamN is pl. of A^adiymN, (S,) or this is a quasi-pl. n., (M, K,) and A^ufuqN (JK, K) is allowable, (JK,) or, accord. to Lh, it is not allowable, (TA,) and [pl. of pauc.] A=fiqapN, (As, S, K,) like as A=dmapN and A^arogifapN are pls. of A^adiymN and ragiyfN. (As, S.) ↓ A^afiyqapN signifies also A siqaA=' [or skin for water or milk &c.] made of a hide of the kind termed A^afiyq. (Mgh.) And A^afiyqN also signifies The skin of a man, and of any beast. (TA.)
A^afiyqapN * : see A^afiyqN, in two places.
A^af~aAqN * : see A^afaqiY~N.

A=fiqN A=fq , (S, K, &c.,) of the measure faAEilN, (S, Kz, TA, [in the CK AafiqN, and in like manner in a copy of the JK,]) from A^afiqa, (S, K,) or, as IB says, accord. to Kz, from A^afaqa, aor.
Aafiqa , and so accord. to Kr, and shown to be of the measure faAEilN by several verses in which it occurs, (TA,) One who has attained the utmost degree in generosity; (S, K;) or in knowledge, or science; or in chasteness of speech, or eloquence, and in the combination of excellent qualities; (K;) as also ↓ A^afiyqN: (K:) fem. with p. (IF, K.) Also applied to a horse, Generous with respect to both parents: fem. with p. (S.) And applied to a camel, That excites admiration and approval by his generousness, excellence, high blood, or the like; (JK;) and so ↓ A^ufuqN, (JK, S, K,) applied to a horse, (S, K,) and a mare, (JK, S, K,) and a she-camel. (JK.).
A=fiqapN A=fqh A=fqp : see A^afaqN.
A=faAqiY~N A=fAqY A=fAqy : see A^afaqiY~N.

1 A^afakahu * , aor.
Aafika , inf. n. A^afokN, (with fet-h, S, TA, its only form, TA, [in the CK Aifok,]) He changed his, or its, manner of being, or state; (S, K;) and he turned him, or it, (i. e., anything, Msb,) away, or back; (S, Msb, K;) Eani Al$~aYo'i [from the thing]; (S;) or Eano wajohihi [from his, or its, mode, or manner, of being, &c.]: (Msb:) so in the Kur xlvi. 21, A^ajiy^otanaA litaA^ofikanaA Eano A=lihatinaA Hast thou come to us to turn us away, or back, from our gods? (Bd:) or he turned him away, or back, by lying: (TA:) or he changed, or perverted, his judgment, or opinion: (K:) or he deceived him, or beguiled him, and so turned him away, or back: and simply he deceived him, or beguiled him: and A^ufika signifies he was turned from his judgment, or opinion, by deceit, or guile. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [li. 9], yuw^ofaku Eanohu mano A^ufika, i. e., He will be turned away from it (namely, the truth,) who is turned away in the foreknowledge of God: (TA:) or, accord. to Mujáhid, yuw^ofanu Eanohu mano A^ufina [he will be weak in intellect and judgment so as to be thereby turned away from it who is weak in intellect and judgment]. (S, TA.) You say also, A^ufika Alr~ajulu Eani Alxayori The man was turned away, or back, from good, or prosperity. (Sh.) And A^afakahu, (K, TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He forbade him what he wished, (K, TA,) and turned him away, or back, from it. (TA.) ― -b2- A^afaka, aor.
Aafika ; (Msb, K;) and A^afika, aor.
Aafaka ; (IAar, K;) inf. n. A_ifokN (Msb, K) and A^afokN and A^afakN and A^ufuwkN; (K;) He lied; uttered a falsehood; said what was untrue; (Msb, K;) as also ↓ A^f~k, (K,) inf. n. taA^ofiykN: (TA:) because a lie is a saying that is turned from its proper way, or mode. (Bd in xxiv. 11.) ― -b3- A^afaka Aln~aAsa, aor.
Aafika , inf. n. A^afokN, He told the people what was false; A^afaka and A^afakotuhu being like ka*aba and ka*abotuhu. (Az, TA.) ― -b4- A^afaka fulaAnFA, (K,) inf. n. A^afokN; (TA;) or the verb is ↓ A=faka; (so in the printed edition of Bd, xlvi. 27;) He, or it, made such a one to lie, or say what was untrue. (K.) ― -b5- A^ufika He was weak [as though perverted] in his intellect and judgment or opinion. (K,* TA.) But A^afakahu A@ll~`hu as meaning God rendered weak his intellect is not used. (L, TA.) ― -b6- (tropical:) It (a place) was not rained upon, and had no vegetation, or herbage. (K, TA.)
2 Aaf~aka see 1.
4 A=faka see 1.

8 A@y^otafakati Albalodapu * [written with the disjunctive alif Aiytafakat], (S, K,) biA^aholihaA, (S,) The land, or district, or the town, or the like, was, or became, overturned, or subverted, (S, K,) with its inhabitants: (S:) as were the towns of the people of Lot. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence it is said of El-Basrah, qadi A@y^otafakato biA^aholihaA mar~atayoni, meaning (tropical:) It has been submerged with its inhabitants twice; as though subverted. (Sh.) ― -b3- You say also, Aiytafakato tiloka AlA^aroDu (tropical:) That land has been burnt up by drought. (IAar.)

A_ifokN A^fk A_fk Afk fk wfY [an inf. n. used as a subst.;] A lie; a falsehood; (S, TA;) as also ↓ A^afiykapN: pl. (of the latter, K) A^afaAy^iku. (S, K.) You say, ↓ yaA laloA^afiykapi, and ↓ yaA liloA^afiykapi; [and ↓ laloA^afay~ikapi, using the dim. form for the purpose of enhancement; i. e. O the lie! and O the great lie!] the l with fet-h denoting calling to aid; and with kesr denoting wonder, as though the meaning were, O man, wonder thou at this great lie. (TA.)

Afkp A^fk A^fkh A_fk A_fkh Afkh Afkp fk fkh [so in the TA, without any syll. signs; app. either A^afokapN, an inf. n. of un., or ↓ A=fikapN, like daAhiyapN;] A punishment sent by God, whereby the dwellings of a people are overturned: occurring in a trad. relating to the story of the people of Lot. (TA.)

sanapN A^afikapN * (tropical:) A year of drought or sterility: (K,
TA:) pl. A^awaAfiku [contr. to rule, as though the sing. were ↓ A=fikapN]. (Z, TA.)
A^afuwkN * : see A^af~aAkN.

A^afiykN * One who is turned from his judgment, or opinion, by deceit, or guile; as also ↓ maA^ofuwkN. (K.) ― -b2- Lacking strength or power or ability, and having little prudence and artifice. (Lth, K.) -A2- See also A^af~aAkN.
A^ufay~ikapN * : see A_ifokN, in three places. ― -b2- Also A severe, or distressing, calamity. (Ibn-Abbád.)
A^ufay~ikapN * : see A_ifokN.

A^af~aAkN *
A great, or habitual, liar; (S, Msb, K;) as also ↓ A^afuwku, (Msb, K,) and ↓ A^afiykN: (K:) fem. of the first [and last] with p: but the second is both masc. and fem.: (Msb:) the pl. of the second is Afk with damm [i. e. A^ufokN, accord. to the rule of the K, but the TA seems to indicate that it is A^ufukN, by likening it to the pl. of SabuwrN]. (K.)
A=fikapN A=fkh A=fkp : see Afkp: ― -b2- and see sanapN A^afikpN.

A^afiykN * [Changed in his, or its, manner of being, or state: turned away, or back, from a thing: &c.]: see maA^ofuwnN. ― -b2- Weak [as though perverted] in his intellect (AZ, S, K) and judgment or opinion; as also p: (AZ, S:) accord. to A'Obeyd, (or AA, as in one copy of the S,) a man who does not attain, or obtain, good, or prosperity. (S.) ― -b3- Also, (K,) fem. with maA^ofuwnN, (S, K,) (tropical:) A place, (K,) or land, (A^aroDN, S, Z,) not rained upon, and having no vegetation, or herbage. (S, Z, K.)
