Almuw^otafikaAtu * (S, K) and AlmuwotafikapN, (TA,) both occurring in the Kur, [the former in ix. 71 and lxix. 9, and the latter in liii. 54,] The cities overthrown, or subverted, by God, upon the people of Lot. (S, K.) ― -b2- The former also signifies The winds that turn over [the surface of] the earth, or ground: (K:) or the winds that blow from different quarters: it is said (by the Arabs, S) that when these winds blow much, the earth (i. e. its seed-produce, TA) thrives, or yields increase. (S, K, TA.)

1 A^afala * , (T, S, Msb, K,) said of a thing, (Msb,) or of the moon, (T,) and A^afalato, said of the sun, (T, S, M,) and of the stars, (M,) aor.
Aafila and
Aafula , inf. n. A^ufuwlN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and A^folN, (M, Msb,) It was, or became, absent, or hidden, or concealed; (T, S, Msb, K;) it set; (T, S, M, &c.;) and so A^afila, aor.
Aafala . (K.) ― -b2- Hence, A^afala fulaAnN Eani Albaladi Such a one became absent, or went away, from the country, or town. (Msb.)

A^afiylN *
A young camel such as is termed Aibonu maxaADK [i. e. that has entered its second year]; (As, ElFárábee, S, M, Msb, K;) and the like; (S;) or, and also such as is above this [in age]; (ElFárábee, M, Msb, K;) or, and also such as is termed Aibonu labuwnK [i. e. that has entered the third year]; beyond which it is not so called: (As, TA:) or that is seven months old, or eight: (As, Msb:) or a youthful camel: (AZ, Msb:) and also (M, K) a young weaned camel; syn. faSiyl~N: (T, M, Msb, K:) fem. with p: (As, S:) pl. A_ifaAlN (T, S, M, K) and A^afaAy^ilu, (Sb, S, M, K,) which latter they liken to *anaAy^ibu as pl. of *nuwbN. (M.) [In my copy of the Msb, the pl. is said to be A_fAlp: and it is also there said, on the authority of IF, that AfAlp signifies the young ones of sheep.] It is said in a prov., A_in~amaA Alqaromi mina AlA^afiyli [The stallion-camel is only that which has increased in growth from the young one in its second year, &c.]; i. e. what is great has begun small. (TA.)

A=filN A=fl part. n. of 1, (T, TA,) applied to the moon, and to any star: (TA:) fem. with p: (T, TA:) pl. A=filuwna (Kur vi. 76 [the rational form of the pl. being there used because it is applied to stars as being likened to gods]) and A^uf~alN and A^ufuwlN. (TA.)
A^afaho * and A^af~aho and A^uf~aho and A^uf~iho and A^uf~uho and A^afuwho and A^uf~uwho: see A^uf~N.

A^afoyuwnN * , [like SaEofuwqN, but this is of a very extr. measure; or, as some write it, A^ufoyuwnN, like EuSofuwrN &c.;] or A_ifoyawonN, [like biro*awonN;] (accord. to different copies of the K, art. fyn;) [an arabicized word, from the Greek A^aPoyuwno, either immediately or through the Persian xa$oxaA$; meaning Opium:] the milk [or juice] of the black Egyptian x$xA$ [or poppy, or papaver somniferum]; (K;) or the milk of the x$xA$, the best of which is the black Egyptian; (TA;) or the expressed juice of the black Egyptian x$xA$, dried in the sun: cold and dry in the fourth degree: (Ibn-Seenà, or Avicenna, i. 133:) beneficial for hot tumours, especially in the eye; torporific (to the intellect, TA): in a small quantity, beneficial, and soporific: in a large quantity, a poison: (K:) [the lexicographers regard the word as Arabic:] some, among whom is the author of the K, hold that it belongs to art. fyn: others, that it belongs to art. Afn. (TA.)
A^uqoHuwaAnN * : see art. qHw

1 A^aqaTahu * , aor
AaqiTa (S, K,) inf. n. A^aqoTN, (S,) He made it (namely food) with A^aqiT q. v. infrà. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also, (aor. and inf. n. as above, TA,) He fed him with A^aqiT: (A'Obeyd, K:) like labanahu from labanN and labaA^ahu from libaA^N Lh mentions the verb in this sense as used without its being made transitive. (TA.) ― -b3- [A^aqiTa in the CK is a mistake for A=qaTa q. v.]

4 A=qaTa A=qT , (Lh, K, [in the CK, incorrectly, A^aqiTa,]) of the measure A^afoEala, agreeably with a common rule, applying to anything, (Lh, TA,) He had much A^aqiT; his A^aqiT became much, or abundant. (Lh, K.)
8 Ay^tqT * [written with the disjunctive alif AiytaqaTa] He made, or prepared, A^aqiT: (S:) strangely omitted in the O and in the K. (TA.)

A^aqiTN * (Fr, Az, S, Msb, K) and A_iqiTN (Fr, O, K) and A^aqaTN (Fr, K) and A_iqoTN, (S, O, Msb, K,) the last sometimes occurring in poetry, and formed from the first, by transferring the vowel of the q to the preceding letter, (S,) or a contraction of the second, accord. to a common usage of [the tribe of] Temeem in the cases of words of this measure, (O,) and A^aqoTN (K) and A^uqoTN, (As, K,) of all which the first is the most chaste, and the last is strange, (TA,) [A preparation of dried curd;] a preparation of, or thing made from, milk (Az, Msb, K) of sheep or goats, (K,) which has been churned, and of which the butter has been taken, (Az, Msb, K,) cooked, and then left until it becomes concrete: (Az, Msb:) or made from the milk of camels, in particular: (IAar:) or milk which is dried, and has become hard, like stone; with which one cooks; repeatedly mentioned in trads.: (TA:) or a thing made from milk; being a kind of cheese: (Har p. 587:) pl. A^uqoTaAnN. (K.)

A^aq~aATN *
A maker of A^aqiT. (TA.)
maA^oquwTN * Food made with A^aqiT. (S.)

1 A^akada *
He trod wheat. (IAar, K.)
2 A^k~d * , inf. n. taA^okiydN, i. q. wak~ada, (S, Msb, K,) of which it is a dial. var.; (S;) but it is not so chaste as the latter, and by some is disallowed. (TA.)

4 A=kd A=kd
i. q. A^awokada. (S in art. wkd.)

5 tA^k~d *
i. q. tawak~ada. (S and K in art. wkd.)

A_kaAdN A^kAd AkAd kAd sing. of A^akaAy^idN and taA=kiydN, (K,) both of which are irreg. in relation to their sing., (TA,) signifying (i. e. the pls.) Thongs, or straps, by which the qarabuws is bound to the two side-boards of a horse's saddle. (K.) [See also wikaAdN.]

Akr A^kr A^krY A^krp Akr kr krA krY kry |kr
Firm; (K, TA;) applied to a covenant, or compact. (TA.)

1 A^akara * , aor.
Aa^iaa , inf. n. A^akorN, He tilled the ground; ploughed it up for sowing. (Msb.) ― -b2- He dug the ground. (TA.) ― -b3- He cut, or dug, a river, or canal, or rivulet. (Msb.) ― -b4- And A^akara, aor
Aa^uaa , (TA,) inf. n. as above; (K;) and ↓ tA^k~r; (K;) He dug a hollow, or cavity, in the ground, for water to collect therein and to be baled out therefrom clear: (K, TA:) or A^ukar~aA ↓ tA^k~r signifies he dug hollows, or cavities, in the ground. (S.)

3 A=krhu A=krh A=krp , (TK.) inf. n. muw^aAkarapN, (S, K,) He made a contract, or bargain, with him to till and sow and cultivate land for a share of its produce; syn. of the inf. n. muxaAbarapN. (S, K, TA.) The doing of this is forbidden. (TA.)
5 taAa^~aaa see 1, in two places.

A^ukorapN *
A hollow, or cavity, dug in the ground, (S, Msb, K,) in which water collects, and from which it is baled out clear: (K:) pl. A^ukarN. (S, Msb.) -A2- Also a dial. var. of kurapN, (K,) [A ball] with which one plays: (TA:) [and a sphere, or globe:] but it is of weak authority. (K.)

A_ikaArapN A^kAr A^kArh A^kArp A_kArp AkArh AkArp kArY , as used in practical law, Land which is given by its owners to men who sow and cultivate it [app. for a certain share of its produce: see 3]. (Mgh.)

A^ak~aArN *
A tiller, or cultivator, of land: (Msb, K:) pl. A^akarapN; as though it were pl. of A=kirN, (S, Msb, K,) like as kafarapN is pl. of kaAfirN. (Msb.)
2 Ak~f AlA_ikaAfa Akf AlAkAf , inf. n. taA^okiyfN, He made the AkAf; (K;) as also wk~fhu, inf. n. tawokiyfN; which latter, accord. to IF, is the original form. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 4.

4 A=kf AlHimaAra A=kf AlHmAr , (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_iykaAfN, (K,) He bound, (S, K, TA,) or put, (Msb, TA,) the A_ikaAf upon the ass; (S, Msb, K;) as also ↓ A^k~fhu; (Sgh, K;) and Awkfhu; (S, Mgh, K;) which is of the dial. of the people of El-Hijáz; the first being of the dial. of Benoo-Temeem: and in like manner, Albagola the mule. (Lh.)

A_ikaAfN A^kAf AkAf kAfY (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and A^ukaAfN, (K,) as also wikaAfN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and wukaAfN, (K in art. wkf,) The baro*aEap, [i. e. pad, or stuffed saddle, generally stuffed with straw,] (K,) of the ass, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and also used for the mule, and for the camel; (TA in art. wkf;) a saddle like the raHol and qatab: (TA:) and a saddle of a horse made in the form of the ass's AkAf, having at its fore part [or pommel] a thing resembling a pomegranate: (Mgh:) [see also qatabN:] pl. [of pauc.] A=kifapN (TA) and [of mult.] A^ukufN. (S, Mgh, Msb, TA.) Yaakoob asserts that the A in A_ikaAfN is a substitute for the w in wikaAfN. (TA.) A rájiz says,
A_in~a lanaA A^aHomirapF EijaAfaA
yaA^okulona kul~a layolapK A_ikaAfaA
meaning [Verily we have some lean asses] which eat every night the price of an AkAf. (TA.)
A^ak~aAfN * The maker of the kind of saddle called A_ikaAf. (K.)

1 A^akalahu * , [aor.
Aakula ,] inf. n. A^akolN and maA^okalN, [He ate it,] (S, K,) namely, food. (S.) Er-Rummánee says that A^akolN properly signifies The swallowing food after chewing it; so that the swallowing of pebbles is not properly thus termed: (Msb:) or, accord. to Ibn-El-Kemál, the conveying, or transmitting, to the belly what may be chewed, whether [the thing be] chewed or not; so that it does not apply to milk, nor to sawiyq: and as to the saying of the poet,
mina AlA=kiliyna AlmaA='a ZulomFA famaA A^araY
yanaAluwna xayorFA baEoda A^akolihimu AlmaA='a
(assumed tropical:) [Of the eaters of what they purchase with the price of water, wrongfully, I do not see any attain good after their eating of what they have purchased with the price of the water,] he means a people who used to sell water and purchase with the price thereof what they would eat: (TA:) [for you say, A^akala ka*aA as meaning (assumed tropical:) He ate the price of such a thing: see another ex. voce A_ikaAfN; and another voce vadoYN.] ― -b2- The saying, in the Kur [v. 70], laA^akaluwA mino fawoqihimo wamino taHoti A^arojulihimo [They should eat things above them and things beneath their feet] means, their means of subsistence should be made ample; (Bd, TA;) by the pouring of the blessings of the heaven and the earth upon them; or by the abundance of the fruit of the trees, and the produce of the grains sown; or by their being blessed with gardens of ripe fruits, so that they should gather them from the upper part of each tree, and pick up what should have fallen upon the ground. (Bd.) ― -b3- AinoqaTaEa A^akoluhu [lit. His eating became cut off, or stopped,] means (tropical:) he died; [see also A^ukulN;] and so AisotawofaY A^akolahu [lit. he completed his eating]. (TA.) ― -b4- A^akala raw^oqahu [lit. He ate his life,] means (tropical:) he became extremely aged, and his teeth fell out, one after another. (TA.) ― -b5- huwa yaA^okulu Aln~aAsa, and yaA^okulu luHuwma Aln~aAsi [He eats men, and eats the flesh of men,] means (tropical:) he defames men; or does so in their absence: (TA:) and the action thus signified may be [with words, or by making signs] with the side of the mouth, and with the eye, and with the head. (TA in art. hmz.) It is said in the Kur [xlix. 12], A^ayuHib~u A^aHadukumo A^ano yaA^okla laHoma A^axiyhi mayotFA [lit. Would any one of you like to eat the flesh of his brother when dead?]; defamation, or defamation of the absent, being meant thereby. (S, * Ibn-' Arafeh, Bd, Jel.) ― -b6- A^akala ganamiY wa $aribahaA (tropical:) [He ate the flesh of my sheep, and drank the milk of them, means, like A^akala maAliY, he ate, fed upon, devoured, or consumed, my wealth, or property: see 2]. (TA.) ― -b7- A^akalati Aln~aAru AlHaTaba (tropical:) The fire devoured, or consumed, the firewood. (S, Mgh.) ― -b8- A^akalato A^aZofaArahu AlHijaArapu (tropical:) [The stones wore away his nails]. (TA.) ― -b9- AlwaAwu fiY maroy^Y~K A^akalatohaA AlyaA='u (assumed tropical:) [The w in maroy^iY~, the Y has swallowed it up]; because it is originally marow^uwYN: a phrase occurring in the 'Eyn. (TA.) ― -b10- A^akala Eumurahu (tropical:) He consumed his life. (Mgh.) ― -b11- It is said in a trad., (TA,) A^umirotu biqaroyapK taA^okulu AlquraY (tropical:) [I have been commanded to have given unto me a town which shall devour the other towns]; (K, TA;) said to be Yethrib [afterwards called El-Medeeneh]; (TA;) i. e., the people of which shall conquer the [other] towns and make spoil of their possessions: or it denotes the superior excellence of that town; and is like the saying, h`*aA HadiyvN yaA^okulu AlA^aHaAdiyva [This is a tradition which does away with, or overrules, the other traditions]. (Sgh. K, TA.) ― -b12- A^akolu Als~ik~iyni All~aHoma means (tropical:) The knife's cutting the flesh. (TA.) ― -b13- A^akalaniy raA^osiY, inf. n. A_ikolapN and A^ukaAlN and A^akaAlN, (tropical:) My head itched. (K, TA.) An Arab was heard to say, [as is often said in the present day,] jilodiY yaA^okuluniY (tropical:) My skin itches. (TA.) -A2- A^akila, aor.
Aakala , (K,) inf. n. A^akalN, (TA,) (tropical:) It (a limb, or member, [and a sore,] and a piece of stick, or wood,) became corroded or cankered, or decayed, by the mutual eating away of its several parts; as also ↓ Ay^tkl [written with the disjunctive alif Aiytakala], and ↓ tA^k~l. (K, TA.) ― -b2- A^akilati AlA^asonaAnu, (S, Msb, K,) aor. and inf. n. as in the next preceding sentence, (Msb,) (tropical:) The teeth rubbed together and wasted away; by reason of age; (S;) or fell out, one after another: (Msb:) or broke in pieces, or became much broken: (K:) and ↓ tA^k~lt signifies the same; (S, Msb;) and so ↓ Ay^tklt. (S.) ― -b3- A^akilati Aln~aAqapu, aor.
Aakala , inf. n. A^akaAlN, (assumed tropical:) The she-camel experienced an itching and annoyance in her belly, (S, O, K,) from the growth of the hair, (S, O,) or from the growth of the fur, (K,) of her fœtus. (S, O, K.)

2 Aak~ala [A^k~lhu, inf. n. taA^okiylN, He made him to eat a thing.] ― -b2- A^ak~ala maAliY wa $r~abahu, (S, K,) inf. n. as above, (K,) [lit. He made people to eat my property, and made them to drink it,] means (tropical:) he fed men, or the people, with my property, or cattle. (S, K, TA.) ― -b3- Zal~a maAliY yuw^ak~alu wa yu$ar~abu, (so in some copies of the K and in the TA,) or yuw^ak~ilu wyu$ar~ibu, (so in two copies of the S and in a copy of the K,) [of which the former is app. the right reading, as the lit. meaning seems to be My cattle passed the day made to eat and made to drink,] i. e., (tropical:) pasturing as they pleased. (S, K, TA.) ― -b4- A^k~lhu Al$~aYo'a, inf. n. as above, (tropical:) He charged against him, or accused him of doing, the thing; as also ↓ A=klhu, (K, TA,) inf. n. A_iykaAlN. (TA.) In [some of] the copies of the K, for Aid~aEaAhu, we here find, erroneously, daEaAhu. (TA.) You say, A^ak~alotaniY maA lamo A=kulo [lit. Thou hast made me to eat what I have not eaten,] meaning (tropical:) thou hast charged against me, or accused me of doing, what I have not done; as also ↓ A=kalotaniY. (S, TA.) So too, A^a$orabotaniY maA lamo A^a$orabN. (S and K in art. $rb.)

3 A=klhu A=klh A=klp , inf. n. muw^aAkalapN (S, K) and A_ikaAilN, (K,) He ate with him; (S, K;) as also waAkalahu, though of weak authority; (K;) or this latter is not allowable. (S, Sgh.) ― -b2- muw^aAkalapN which is forbidden in a trad. is (assumed tropical:) A debtor's giving a thing to his creditor in order that he may abstain from taking the debt. (TA.)

4 A=kl A=kl , [inf. n. A_iykaAlN,] said of the palm-tree, and of seed-produce, (S, K,) and of anything, (S,) It had ripe fruit; it supplied food. (S, K.) ― -b2- A=klhu Al$~aYo'a, (S, K,) inf. n. as above, (S,) He gave him to eat the thing; he fed him with the thing. (S, * K.) ― -b3- See also 2, in two places. ― -b4- A=kl Aln~aAra (assumed tropical:) He fed, or supplied, the fire with fuel. (S.) ― -b5- A=kl bayona Aln~aAsi, (A, K,) inf. n. as above, (S, O,) (tropical:) He busied himself among the people with propagating calumnies: (S, O, TA:) or he created, or excited, disagreement, dissension, or
strife, among them; or made, or did, mischief among them: (A, TA:) or he incited them, one against another. (K.) ― -b6- A=kalotuka fulaAnFA, (S,) or A=kala fulaAnN fulAnFA, (K, [in the CK, erroneously, fulaAnN fulaAnFA,]) (tropical:) I made thee, (S,) or he made such a one, (K,) to have dominion, or authority, or power, over such a one. (S, K.)

5 tA^kl~ * : see 1, latter part, in two places: ― -b2- and see also 8. ― -b3- Also, said of a sword, (S, K,) and of silver (K, TA) molten, (TA,) and of lightning, and of collyrium, and of aloes, (K,) and of anything shiny, (TA,) (tropical:) It shone, gleamed, or glistened, (S, K, TA,) much, or intensely; (K;) when said of a sword, by reason of its sharpness. (S, TA.)

8 Ay^tkl * [with the disjunctive alif Aiytakala]: see 1, latter part, in two places. ― -b2- A^amaA tanofak~u taA^otakilu Dost thou not cease to eat our flesh, [i. e., to wound our reputations, (see 1,)] and to defame us? (Aboo-Nasr, TA.) But see below. ― -b3- Ay^tklti Aln~aAru (tropical:) The fire flamed, or blazed, vehemently; as though one part thereof devoured another. (TA.) ― -b4- Ay^tkl gaDabFA, (K,) or mina AlgaDabi, (S,) (tropical:) He burned, or burned fiercely, with, or by reason of, anger. (S, K.) The phrase mentioned above, AmA tnfk~ tA^tkl, is also cited as an ex. of this meaning. (S, TA.) You say likewise, Ay^tkl minohu (tropical:) He was, or became, angry with him, and excited, or provoked, against him, (K, TA,) and vehement, or severe; (TA;) as also mnh ↓ tA^kl. (K.)

10 AstA^klhu Al$~aYo'a * (tropical:) He asked, or begged, of him to assign to him the thing, or to make it be to him, as a means of subsistence, or a thing to be eaten. (K, TA.) ― -b2- yasotaA^okilu AlD~uEafaA='a (tropical:) He takes (S, K, TA) and devours (TA) the possessions of the weak ones. (S, K, TA.)
A^ukolN * : see A^ukulN.
A^akalN * inf. n. of A^akila [q. v.]. ― -b2- fiY A^asonaAnihi A^akalN (tropical:) In his teeth is a rubbing together and wasting away; by reason of age. (S, TA.) See also A^ukulN

A^akilN * [part. n. of A^akila]. ― -b2- naAqapN A^akilapN (assumed tropical:) A she-camel experiencing an itching and annoyance in her belly, (S, K,) from the growth of the hair, (S,) or from the growth of the fur, (K,) of her fœtus. (S, K.) ― -b3- [AlAakilu is erroneously put, in the CK, for AlA=kilu, in a sense explained below.]

A^ukulN * and ↓ A^ukolN; (S, Msb, K, &c.;) the latter a contraction of the former; (Msb;) What is eaten; (S, Msb, TA;) as also ↓ A^ukolapN and ↓ A^akolapN (Lh, TA) and ↓ maA^okalapN and ↓ maA^okulapN (Msb, K) and ↓ maA^okuwlN; (Lh, Msb;) any eatable; i. e. anything that is eaten; (S;) and ↓ A^akaAlN signifies [the same, an eatable, or] food. (S, TA.) You say of one who is dead, AinoqaTaEa A^ukuluhu [His food has become cut off, or stopped: in the TA, A^akoluhu: see 1]. (S.) And ↓ maA *uqotu A^akaAl~aA I have not tasted food. (S, TA.) ― -b2- Fruit (S, K [in the latter of which, in some copies, Alt~amoru is put for Alv~amaru, erroneously, as is said in the TA]) of palmtrees and other trees [&c.]. (S.) So in the Kur [xiii. 35], A^ukuluhaA daAy^imN [Its fruit shall be perpetual]: (S, TA:) meaning that the fruits thereof shall be not as those of the present world, which come to one at one time and not at another. (TA.) [Pl. A=kaAlN; occurring in the M and K in art. Atw.] ― -b3- (tropical:) Means of subsistence: (K:) worldly good fortune, (S, K,) and ample means of subsistence. (S.) You say, fulaAnN *uw A^ukulK (tropical:) Such a one is possessed of worldly good fortune, and ample means of subsistence: (S:) and EaZiymu AlA^ukuli (tropical:) possessed of [great] good fortune; or of a [great and] good share of the means of subsistence. (TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) Thickness, substantialness, or closeness or compactness of texture, of a garment, or piece of cloth; (S, K, TA;) and strength thereof. (K.) You say vawobN *uw A^ukulK (tropical:) A garment, or piece of cloth, having thickness, &c.: and qiroTaAsN *uw A^ukulK (tropical:) paper having thickness, &c. (S, TA.) ― -b5- (tropical:) Intelligence; judgment; (Aboo-Nasr, S, K;) firmness of intellect. (K, TA.) You say rajulN *uw A^ukulK (tropical:) A man possessing intelligence and judgment. (Aboo-Nasr, S, TA.)

A^akolapN *
A single act of eating (S, Mgh, Msb, K) until one is satisfied. (S.) Hence the saying, AlmuEotaAdu A^akolataAni AlgadaA='u waAlEa$aA='u, meaning That to which people are accustomed is two acts of eating, the eating of the morning-meal and that of the evening-meal. (Mgh.) ― -b2- See also A^ukolapN, in two places. ― -b3- And see A^ukulN, first sentence.

A^ukolapN *
A morsel, or small mouthful, of food. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) [For the pl., see below.] You say, A^akalotu A^ukolapF waAHidapF I ate one morsel. (S.) And A^akla biA^axiyhi A^ukolapF (assumed tropical:) [He ate a morsel by means of defaming his brother] is said, in a trad., of a man who is on terms of brotherhood with another, and then goes to his enemy, and speaks of him in a manner not good, in order that he may give him a present for doing so. (TA.) ― -b2- A small round cake of bread; syn. quroSapN; (S, K;) a single quroS: (Mgh:) pl. A^ukalN, as below. (TA.) ― -b3- See also A^ukulN. ― -b4- Also (assumed tropical:) i. q. TuEomapN; (S, K;) which is also syn. with ↓ maA^okalapN; (S, Msb, K, in art. TEm;) i. e. An assigned, or appointed, means of subsistence; such as a grant of a tract of land; and a tax, or portion of a tax or taxes; and the like; (Mgh in explanation of TuEomapN, and TA in explanation of the same and of maA^okalapN in art. TEm;) and [it is also said that] ↓ maA^okalapN signifies a thing that is assigned, or appointed, or granted, to a man, so that he is not to be reckoned with, or called to account, for it: (TA in the present art.:) [thus it applies to any absolute grant, either of land, (as an allodium, an appanage, &c.,) or of revenue:] pl. A^ukalN (K) [and app. also A=kaAlN, which see below]. You say, h`*aA Al$~aYo'u A^uklapN laka This thing is a TuEomap to thee, or for thee. (S.) ― -b5- See also A^akiylapN. -A2- Also, and ↓ A_ikolapN (S, Z, Sgh, K) and ↓ A^akolapN, (Kr, K,) (tropical:) Defamation; or defamation of the absent. (S, Z, Sgh, K.) You say, A_in~ahu la*uw A^ukolapK and ↓ A_ikolapK (S, TA) and ↓ A^akolapK (TA) (tropical:) Verily he is one who defames men; or, who does so in their absence. (S, TA.)

A_ikolapN A^kl A^klh A^klp A_klyl Aklh Aklp kAl wkl |kl |klh |klp
A mode, or manner, (K,) or state, or condition, (S, K,) in which one eats: (S, K: *) like jilosapN and rikobapN: (S, TA:) and the posture of the eater, reclining or sitting. (TA.) You say, A_in~ahu laHasanu AlA_ikolapi [Verily he has a good mode, &c., of eating]. (S.) ― -b2- See also A^ukolapN, last two sentences. ― -b3- (tropical:) The itch: or an itching: (S, K:) as also ↓ A^ukaAlN, (As, S, K,) [see A^akalaniY raA^osiY, of which both are said to be inf. ns.,] and ↓ A^akilapN: (K:) so the last is written accord. to the correct copies of the K: accord. to Esh-Shiháb, in the Shifá el-Ghaleel, it would seem to be A^ukolapN; but this is at variance with the authority of the leading lexicologists: the same word, A^akilapN, is also explained in the K as signifying a disease in a limb, or member, in consequence of which one part is [as it were] eaten by another; [a meaning which I believe to be correct, (see A^ukaAlN,) although SM says,] but this is identical with the itch, or an itching: and ↓ A^akalaAnN is a vulgar term for the same; and so is ↓ A=kilapN, with medd, given as correct by Eth-Tha'álibee, in [his book entitled] the Mudáf and Mensoob, but disallowed by ElKhafájee. (TA.) One says, A_in~iY laA^ajidu fiY jasadiY A_ikolapF (tropical:) [Verily I experience in my body an itching.] (S.)
A^akilapN * : see A_ikolapN.
A^ukalapN * : see A^akuwlN.
A^akalaAnN * : see A_ikolapN.
A^akaAlN * : see A^ukulN, first and second sentences.

A^ukaAlN * (tropical:) A corrosion, or cankering, or decaying, of a limb, or member, [and of a sore,] from the mutual eating away of its several parts; as also ↓ A_ikaAlN. (K, TA.) [See also A^akilapN, voce A_ikolapN, where a similar meaning is assigned to the former of these two words; and the same seems to be indicated in the Msb.] ― -b2- See also another signification voce A_ikolapN. ― -b3- bahaA A^ukaAlN, said of a she-camel, (tropical:) She has an itching and annoyance in her belly, (S, K,) from the growth of the hair, (S,) or of the fur, (K,) of her fœtus. (S, K.)
A_ikaAlN A^kAl AkAl : see A^ukaAlN.
rajulN A^akuwlN * and ↓ A^ukalapN and ↓ A^akiylN all signify the same; (K;) i. e. A man who eats much; [who is a great eater; edacious; voracious;] as also ↓ A^ak~aAlN. (TA.)

A^akiylN *
One who eats with another. (S, TA.) ― -b2- See also A=kilN: ― -b3- and see A^akuwlN. -A2- I. q. ↓ maA^okuwlN [as signifying Eaten]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also A^akiylapN.

A^akuwlapN *
A sheep, or goat, which is set apart (S, Msb, K) to be eaten, (S, Mgh, K,) [i. e.] to be slaughtered, (Msb,) and which is fattened, (S, Mgh,) and the taking of which by the collector of the poor-rate is disapproved; (S;) not left to pasture by itself, being of the best of the beasts: (Msb:) and ↓ A^akiylapN occurs in the same sense,
applied to a sheep, or goat, fattened to be eaten. (Mgh.) Hence the prov., maroEFY walaA A^akuwlapF [lit. Pasturage, and no Akwlp]; meaning (assumed tropical:) wealth collected together, and none expended. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Barren; applied to a sheep or goat [app. because such is generally eaten]. (K.)
A^ukuwlapN * : see what next follows.

A^akiylapN * and ↓ A^akiylN and ↓ A^ukuwlapN, with two dammehs, (K,) so in the copies of the K, but perhaps a mistake for ↓ A^ukolapN, (TA,) a word of a bad dial., (K, * TA,) and ↓ maA^okuwlN and ↓ muw^aAkilN, (K, TA, [in some copies of the former of which, instead of wahiYa qabiyHapN wa AlmaA^okuwli wa Almaw^aAkili, meaning, as is said in the TA, wahiYa lugapN qabiyHapN &c., we find wahiYa qabiyHapN AlmaA^okuwli wa Almaw^aAkili,]) A sheep, or goat, which is set (K, TA) in the lurking-place of a hunter (TA) for the purpose of catching thereby the wolf and the like. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And the first two words, (K,) or A^akiylapN sabuEK, (S, Mgh, Msb,) A beast which has been eaten, (S, * K,) or partly eaten, (Mgh, Msb,) by a beast or bird of prey, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and then rescued from it: (Mgh, TA:) the p in Akylp being added because the quality of a subst. is predominant in it. (S.) ― -b3- See also A^akuwlapN.
A^ak~aAlN * : see A^akuwlN.

A=kilN A=kl
Eating; or an eater; as also ↓ A^akiylN: pl. A^akalapN. (S, K.) You say, humo A^akalapu raA^osK [lit. They are eaters of a head]; meaning (assumed tropical:) they are few; one head satisfying their stomachs. (S.) ― -b2- A=kilapN (tropical:) Pasturing beasts. (K, TA.) ― -b3- A=kilapu All~aHomi (assumed tropical:) The knife; (K, TA;) because it cuts the flesh: (TA:) and the pointed staff or stick; (K, TA;) as being likened thereto: (TA:) and fire: (K:) and whips; (Sh, K;) because they burn the skin. (TA.) ― -b4- AlA=kilu, [in the CK, erroneously, AlAakilu,] (tropical:) The king. (K, TA.) [Opposed to AlmaA^okuwlu, q. v.] ― -b5- A=kilu Alr~ibaA (tropical:) [The receiver of usury]: occurring in a trad., in which it is said, luEina A=kilu ↓ Alr~ibaA wa muw^okiluhu (tropical:) [The receiver of usury is cursed, and the giver thereof]. (TA.)
A=kilapN A=klh A=klp fem. of A=kilN, q. v. ― -b2- See also A_ikolapN.

A=kaAlN A=kAl [app. a pl. of pauc. of A^ukulN, q. v., and of A^ukolN, agreeably with analogy,] (tropical:) The [grants termed] maA=kil of kings; (K;) their TuEam [pl. of TuEomapN, explained above, voce A^ukolapN]. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) The stipends of soldiers. (K.) ― -b3- *awwAlA=kaAli, for which J has erroneously put AlA=kAl, [in the S,] (TS, K,) without *ww, (TA,) (tropical:) The lords, or chiefs, of the tribes, who take the mirobaAE [or fourth part of the spoil, which was the chief's portion in the time of ignorance] (S, TS, K, TA) &c. (TA.)
maA^okalN * , (S,) [in measure] like maqoEadN, (TA,) [an inf. n. of A^akala, q. v. : ― -b2- and also signifying] Gain. (S, TA.) ― -b3- Also A place, and a time, of eating: pl. maA=kilu.]
muw^okalN * (assumed tropical:) Fortunate; possessed of good fortune; prosperous. (Aboo-Sa'eed, K.)
muw^okilu Alr~ibaA * (tropical:) [The giver of usury: see A=kilN, last sentence]. (TA.)

maA^okalapN * and ↓ maA^okulapN: see A^ukulN: ― -b2- and for the former, see also A^ukolapN, in two places. ― -b3- Also, both words, i. q. miyrapN i. e. Corn, or any provision, which a man brings, or purveys, for himself or his family, or for sale]. (K.) ― -b4- Also used in the sense explained above, voce A^ukulN, [as a subst.,] and likewise as an epithet, so that one says $aApN mA^klhN [as meaning A sheep, or goat, that is eaten]. (K.) ― -b5- Both words signify [also] A place whence one eats. (S, O.) ― -b6- [And hence] one says, Ait~axa*otu fulaAnFA maA^okalapF and maA^okalapN (assumed tropical:) [I took for myself such a one as a person from whom to obtain what to eat]. (S, O.) ― -b7- [The pl. is maA=kilu: of which see an ex. voce A=kaAlN.]
maA^okulapN * : see the paragraph next preceding, throughout.

miy^okalapN *
Anything in [i. e. out of] which one eats: (Lh, K:) or [bowls of the kind called] SiHaAf, (S,) or a [bowl of the kind called] SaHofap, (TA,) in which the tribe find it easy to cook, (so in a copy of the S and in the TA,) or to put, (so in another copy of the S,) flesh-meat and [the kind of porridge called] EaSiydap: (S, TA:) or a bowl not so large as a SaHfp, but next to it in size, that satisfies the stomachs of two men, or three: (S voce SaHofapN:) [or] a small [bowl of the kind called] qaSoEapN, that satisfies the stomachs of three: and a small [cooking-pot such as is called] buromah. (K.)

maA^okuwlN * : see A^akiylN: ― -b2- and A^ukulN: ― -b3- and A^akiylapN. ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) The subjects of a king. (Z, K, TA.) Hence the trad., maA^okuwlN Himoyara xayorN mino A=kilihaA (tropical:) The subjects of Himyer are better than their king, or ruler. (Z, TA.)

miy^okaAlN *
A spoon: (K:) because one eats with it. (TA.)
muw^aAkilN * : see A^akiylapN. ― -b2- Also, [like ↓ musotaA^okilN,] (assumed tropical:) One who takes and devours the possessions of men. (TA.)
musotaA^okilN * : see what next precedes.
2 taA^okiymN * The being big in the kafal [i. e. the hinder parts, or posteriors, also termed maA^okamapN]. (O, K.) You say, A^ak~amati AlmaroA^apN The woman was large in the kafal. (TK.)

10 AstA^km *
It (a place) became what are termed A^akam, q. v. (K.) -A2- AstA^km majolisahu He (a man, TA) found his sitting-place to be plain, smooth, soft, or easy to sit upon. (K.)
A^akamN * : see what next follows.

A^akamapN *
A hill, or mound, syn. tal~N, (Msb, K,) [in an absolute sense, or] of what is termed quf~ [q. v.], (K,) or, as in the M, (TA,) of a single collection of stones: or it is inferior to mountains: or a place that is more elevated than what is around it, and is rugged, not to the degree of being stone: (K:) or an isolated mountain: (K voce jabalN:) or an eminence like what is termed raAbiyap: a collection of stones in one place, sometimes rugged and sometimes not rugged: (Msb:) or i. q. quf~N, except that the Akmp is higher and greater: (ISh, TA:) or what is higher than the quf~, compact and round, rising into the sky, abounding with stones: (TA:) pl. A^akamaAtN (S, Msb) and ↓ A^akamN, [or this is rather a coll. gen. n. of which A^akamapN is the n. un.,] (S, Msb, K,) and A_ikaAmN, (K, TA,) or this is pl. of A^akamN, (S, Msb, TA,) and A^ukumN, (K, TA,) or this is pl. of A_ikaAmN, (S, Msb, TA,) and A=kaAmN [a pl. of pauc.], (K,) or this is pl. of A^ukumN, (S, Msb, TA,) and A=kumN [which is also a pl. of pauc.], (IJ, K,) or this is a pl. of A^akamN: (TA:) IHsh says that A^akamN is the only word like vamarN in its series of pls.; for its sing. [or n. un.] is A^akamapN, and the pl. of this [or the coll. gen. n.] is A^akamN, and the pl. of this is A_ikaAmN, and the pl. of this is A^ukumN, and the pl. of this is A=kaAmN, and the pl. of this is A^akaAmiymu [or A^awaAkiymu?]. (MF in art. vmr.) It is said in a prov., used in ridiculing any one who has told of his committing some fault, not desiring to reveal it, jusotumuwniY wawaraA='a AlA^akamapi maA waraA='ahaA [in which I think the first word to be a mistranscription, for jiy^otumuwniY, and the literal meaning to be, Ye have come to me; but behind the hill is what is behind it]: related on the authority of Zeyd Ibn-Kethweh. (TA.) And one says, laA tabulo EalaY A^akampK, meaning (tropical:) Publish not what is secret of thine affair. (TA.)
maA^okamN * and maA^okimN: see what next follows.

maA^okamapN * , (El-Fárábee,) or maA^okimapN, (S,) or both, and ↓ maA^okamN and ↓ maA^okimN, (IAth, K,) The hinder part, posteriors, buttocks, or rump, of a woman; syn. EajiyzapN: (S:) or a portion of flesh on the head of the warik [or haunch]; one of two such portions: (Zj in his “Khalk el-Insán,“ and K:) or these are two protuberances of flesh on the heads of the upper parts of the warikaAni [or haunches]; on the right and left: (TA:) or they are two portions of flesh conjoining the Eajuz [or buttocks] and the matonaAni [or two portions of flesh and sinew next the back-bone, on each side]; (K, TA;) or, as in the Nh, conjoining the Eajob [or rump-bone] and the mtnAn: or two portions of flesh at the root of the warikaAi: (TA:) pl. maA=kimu. (S, K.) Lh mentions the saying, A_in~ahu laEaZiymu AlmA=kimi [Verily he is big in the hinder parts]; as though they called every portion thereof mA^km. (TA.) And one says in reviling a person, yaA A@bina A^aHomari AlmaA^okamapi, meaning O son of him who is red in the safilapi. (TA.)
muw^ak~imapN * : see what follows.
muw^aAkimapN * [in the CK, erroneously, muw^Akamap] and ↓ muw^ak~imapN She who is large in the maA^okamataAni. (K.)

Aalo A^l A_l Al wly |l is a particle of determination: (Mughnee &c.:) or, accord. to some, it is a conjunct noun, and this is the correct opinion; but some say it is a conjunct particle; and some, a particle of determination: (I 'AK p. 40:) [it is equivalent to our article The;] as in Alr~ajulu [The man]: (S and K in art. lwm, and I 'Ak p. 48:) accord. to Kh, [what is termed] the determinative is Aalo [altogether, and therefore it is called by some “the determinative alif and lám“]; but accord. to Sb, it is the l alone; [wherefore it is called by some, as in the S &c., “the lám of determination;”;] so that accord. to Kh, the hemzeh is a hemzeh of disjunction; but accord. to Sb, it is a hemzeh of conjunction: (I 'Ak ubi suprà:) [J says,] the l being quiescent, the conjunctive A is prefixed to it in order that it may commence therewith; but when it is conjoined with what precedes it, the A is dropped, as in lilr~ajuli. (S in art. lwm.) Sometimes the Arabs suppress hemzeh after it; and sometimes they also suppress the A of the article itself: thus, for AlA^aHomaru, they say AlaHomaru, and laHomaru. (Zj, cited in TA in art. Ayk.) In the dial. of some of the people of El-Yemen, (TA in art. Am, q. v.,) or in the dial. of Himyer, (TA in art. Tyb,) Amo is used in the sense of Al. (TA.) ― -b2- It is used to distinguish a noun as known [to the hearer or reader in a particular and definite sense]: (Mughnee, I 'Ak ubi suprà:) first, by its being mentioned [before]; (Mughnee;) as in [the words of the Kur lxxiii. 15 and 16,] kama A^arosalonaA A_ilaY firoEawona rasuwlFA faEaSaY firoEawonu Alr~asuwla [Like as we sent unto Pharaoh an apostle, and Pharaoh disobeyed the apostle]; (Mughnee, I 'Ak;) in which case, the pronoun may supply the place which it and the noun that it accompanies occupies: secondly, by its being conceived in the mind; as in [the Kur ix. 40,] A_i*o humaA fiY AlgaAri [When they two were in the cave]: and thirdly, by its being applied to a thing present; and accord. to Ibn-'Osfoor, this does not occur except after nouns of indication, as in jaA='a niY h`*aA Alr~ajulu [This man (lit. this, the man,) came to me]; or after A^aY~ in calling, as in yaA A^ay~uhaA Alr~ajulu [O man]; or after A_i*aA denoting a thing's happening suddenly, or unexpectedly, as in xarajotu faA_i*aA AlA^asadu [I went forth, and lo, there was the lion]; or after the noun denoting the present time, as AaloA=na [Now]: but this requires consideration; for you say to the reviler of a man in you presence, laA ta$otimi Alr~ajula [Revile not thou the man]; and because that which is after A_i*aA does not render determinate anything present at the time of speaking; and because that in AlA=n is really redundant, being inseparable, which the determinative is never known to be: the good example in this case is the saying in the Kur [v. 5], Aaloyawoma A^akomalotu lakumo diyonakumo [This day I have completed for you your religion]. (Mughnee.) ― -b3- It is also used to denote the species: first, to denote the totality of the individuals of the species; and this may have its place supplied by kul~ used in its proper sense; (Mughnee, I 'Ak * ubi suprà;) as in [the Kur iv. 32,] waxuliqa AlA_inosaAnu DaEiyfFA [For man was created weak]: secondly, to denote the totality of the properties of the individuals, or the combination of all those properties in one thing; and this may have its place supplied by kul~ used in a tropical sense; as in zayodN Alr~ajulu EilomFA [Zeyd is the man in respect of knowledge; as though he combined in himself the knowledge of all the individuals of his species]; i. e., he is the complete, or perfect, [or we would rather say, preeminent,] in knowledge; and hence, [in the Kur ii. 1,] *`lika AlkitaAbu [That is the book, or scripture; as though combining in itself the excellences of all other books or scriptures; or meaning that is preeminently the book, or scripture]: and thirdly, to denote the quiddity, or essence; and this may not have its place supplied by kul~ used either properly or tropically; as in the saying, [in the Kur xxi. 31,] wajaEalonaA mina AlmaA='i kul~a $aYo'K HaY~K [And we have made of water (meaning, accord. to common opinion, sperma genitale,) everything living]; or, accord. to some, it is used in this case to distinguish a thing as known [in a particular sense] by its being conceived in the mind. (Mughnee.) ― -b4- It is also used to denote predominance of application; as in Almadiynapu [The city], meaning the city of the Apostle; and AlkitaAbu [The book], meaning the book of Seebaweyh: and in this case, it may not be suppressed, except when the noun is used vocatively, or when it is prefixed to another noun which it governs in the gen. case; and in some anomalous instances, as in h`*aA Eay~uwqN TaAliEFA [This is the star Capella, rising], originally AlEay~uwqN. (I 'Ak p. 51.) [In a case of this kind, it is said in the Mughnee to be redundant; but I think it is clearly not so in any of the instances here mentioned, except the last; and this I would rather assign to a category yet to be noticed, in which Al is certainly redundant, and, by rule, inseparable.] ― -b5- It is also prefixed to a noun transferred from its original application to that of a proper name; it being so prefixed to convey an allusion to the original signification; and such noun being generally an epithet, as HaArivN; but sometimes an inf. n., as faDolN; and sometimes a generic noun, as nuEomaAnN; so that in any of these cases you may prefix Al, saying AlHaArivu and AlfaDolu and Aln~uEomaAnu, with a view to the original signification; and you may suppress it, with a view to the actual state [which is that of a proper name]: for when you mean that a name of this kind is given as one ominous of good, you prefix the Al in order to indicate this; as when you say AlHaArivu with a view to a person's being thus named to prognosticate that he will live and be a tiller, or cultivator; but when you only consider it as a proper name, you do not prefix the Al: thus the prefix Al conveys a meaning not obtained without it; and therefore it is not redundant, as some assert it to be. (I 'Ak p. 50.) [The author of the Mughnee is one of those who consider Al redundant in this case.] ― -b6- It is in some cases redundant: and in some of these, it is inseparable; as in [a proper name which cannot be used with a view to an original application from which it has been transferred to that of a proper name though it may have been so transferred, such as] All~aAtu, which is the name of a certain idol that was at Mekkeh [so called because a man used to moisten sawiyq with clarified butter, for the pilgrims, at the place thereof]; and, accord. to some, [as before mentioned,] in AlA=ni; and in the conjunct nouns Al~a*iY and its variations, accord. to those who hold that a noun of this kind is rendered determinate by its complement: in other cases, where it is redundant, it is separable; and this is when it is prefixed to a proper name by poetic licence, as in banaAtu AlA^awobari for banaAtu A^awobara, a species of truffle; or, accord. to Mbr, this is not a proper name, and the Al is not redundant; and when it is prefixed to a specificative, as in Tibota Aln~afosa for Tibota nafosFA, accord. to the Basrees, who hold, in opposition to the Koofees, that the specificative may only be indeterminate; (I 'Ak p. 49;) [and, in like manner, as redundant and separable,] it is irregularly prefixed [by poetic licence] in AlA^amosi [q. v.], when it is left in its original form with kesr. (T.) ― -b7- Accord. to the Koofees, and some of the Basrees, and many of the later authors, it may also supply the place of the affixed pronoun; and such they hold to be the case in the saying in the Kur [lxxix. 41], faA_in~a A@lojan~apa hiYa A@lomaA^wiY [Verily Paradise, it shall be his place of abode]; and in mararotu birajulK HasanK Alwajohu [I passed by a man beautiful in his face]; and Duriba zayodN AlZ~ahoru waAlbaTonu [Zeyd was beaten, his back and his belly]; when Alwjh and AlZhr and AlbTn are thus in the nom. case: but those who deny its being used in this manner hold that lahu is to be understood in the verse of the Kur, and minohu in the other examples: and Ibn-Málik restricts the licence to cases not including the Silap [or complement of Al used in the manner which is here next to be explained]. (Mughnee.) ― -b8- It is also a conjunct noun in the sense of Al~a*iY and its variations; and as such is prefixed to an act. part. n., and to a pass. part. n., and, as some say, to a simple epithet; (Mughnee, and I' Ak p. 43;) as AlD~aAribu [which is equivalent to Al~a*iY yaDoribu], and AlmaDoruwbu [which is equivalent to Al~a*iY Duriba], and AlHasanu Alwajohi: (I 'Ak:) but this last not to be regarded, as it cannot be rendered by means of a verb. (Mughnee.) As such, also, it is sometimes prefixed to an adverbial noun, (Mughnee and I 'Ak,) extraordinarily; (I 'Ak;) as in the saying,
mano laA yazaAlu $aAkirFA EalaY ylomaEaho
fahowa HarK biEiy$apK *aAti saEaho
[Whoso ceases not to be grateful, or thankful, for what is with him, or what he has, he is worthy of a state of life such as is attended with plenty.] (Mughnee and I 'Ak.) As such it is also sometimes prefixed to a nominal proposition; as in the saying,
mana Alqawomi Alr~asuwlu A@ll~`hi minohumo
lahumo daAnato riqaAbu binay maEad~i
[Of the people of whom is the apostle of God, of those to whom the necks of the sons of Ma' add
have become abased]. (Mughnee and I 'Ak.) And as such it is also sometimes prefixed to a verbal proposition, of which the verb is an aor.; which shows that it is not [in this case] a particle of determination; (Mughnee;) as in the phrase, Sawotu AlHimaAri Alyujad~aEu [The voice of the ass that has his ear, or ears, cut off]. (T and Mughnee.) But all these three cases are peculiar to poetry; contrary to the opinion of Akh, and, with respect to the last case, to that of Ibn-Málik. (Mughnee.) [Respecting the last instance, see also art. jdE.] Another instance of its usage prefixed in this sense to an aor. is the saying,
maA A^anota biAloHakama AlturoDaY Hukuwmatuhu
[Thou art not the judge whose judgment is approved]; (IAmb, T, I 'Ak) a saying of ElFarezdak: (IAmb, T:) it is an extraordinary case; (I 'Ak;) and is [said to be] an instance of a bad poetic license, the like of which in prose would be an error by common consent. (Expos. of the Shudhoor edh-Dhahab.) In like manner, one says, accord. to AZ, h`*aA AlyaDoribuka, meaning This is he who beats thee; and raA^ayotu AlyaDoribuka I saw him who beats thee; and h`*aA AlwuDiEa lil$~iEori This is what is appropriated to poetry. (T: [in which this last ex. is perhaps intended to intimate that the prefixing of Al in this manner to a verb is allowable only in poetry.]) ― -b9- The Arabs also say, hawa AlHaSiynu A^ano yuraAma wa huwa AlEaziyzu A^ano yuDaAma, meaning A^aHoSanu mino A^ano yuraAm waA^aEaz~u mino *ano yuDaAm [He is more strongly fortified, or protected against attack, than that he will be sought, or desired, and he is more mighty than that he will be injured; i. e., too strongly fortified, or protected against attack, to be sought, or desired, and too mighty to be injured: see min.] (TA in art. lwm. [But AlHiSonu is there erroneously put for AlHaSiynu.]) -A2- Among strange usages, is that of A^alo as an interrogative, mentioned by Ktr; as in A^alo faEalota in the sense of halo faEalota [Didst thou do? or hast thou done?]. (Mughnee.)

A_il~N A^l A_l Al wly |l
Anything which has a quality requiring it to be regarded as sacred, or inviolable; which has some right pertaining to it: and thus used in particular senses here following. (R, TA.) ― -b2- Relationship; or nearness with respect to kindred; (Fr, T, S, M, R, K;) as also ↓ A_il~apN, (Fr, T, K,) of which the pl. is A_ilalN. (K.) So in the Kur [ix. 8], laA yaroqubuwA fiykumo A_il~aA (Fr, T) They will not regard, with respect to you, relationship; (Bd, Jel;) accord. to some. (Bd.) And so in a trad. of 'Alee, yaxuwnu AlEahoda wa yaqoTaEu AlA_il~a [He is unfaithful to the covenant, and cuts the tie of relationship]. (TA.) Hassán Ibn-Thábit says,
laEamoruka A_in~a A_il~aka mino qurayo$K
kaA_il~i Als~aqobi mino raA^oli Aln~aEaAmi
[By thy life, thy relationship to Kureysh is like the relationship of the young camel to the young of the ostrich]. (S.) ― -b3- Good origin. (K.) So, accord. to some, in a saying of Aboo-Bekr, which see below. (TA.) ― -b4- I. q. maEodinN, (K,) or maEodinN SaHiyHN [as meaning A place, or person, whence a thing, or person, originates, free from imperfection, or from everything that would induce doubt or suspicion or evil opinion]. (El-Muärrij, TA: [in which the verse of Hassán cited above is given as an ex. of this signification.]) ― -b5- A compact, or covenant; or one by which a person becomes responsible for the safety, or safe-keeping, of a person or thing; syn. EahodN: (AO, Aboo-Is- hák, T, S, M, R, K:) a confederacy, or league; syn. HilofN; (Aboo-Is-hák, T, M, K;) and so, accord. to some, in the Kur ubi suprà: (Bd:) a covenant between two parties by which either is bound to protect the other; syn. juwaArN: (Aboo-Is-hák, T, R:) a promise, or an assurance, of security or safety; or indemnity; syn. A^amaAnN; (K;) a meaning which it has, accord. to some, in the verse of the Kur cited above. (TA.) Hence, wafiY~u AlA_ili A fulfiller, performer, or keeper, of the compact, or covenant. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b6- Lordship; syn. rubuwbiy~apN. (M, K.) So in the Kur ubi suprà, accord. to some. (Bd.) And so in the saying of Aboo-Bekr, above referred to, when he heard the rhyming prose of Museylimeh, h`*aA kalaAmN lamo yaxorujo mino A_il~K [This is language which did not proceed from lordship]: so explained by A 'Obeyd: (Suh, TA:) or it has here another signification, mentioned before; the meaning being, which did not come from the origin whence came the Kur-án: or, accord. to some, it has here the signification next following. (TA.) ― -b7- Revelation, or inspiration. (K, TA.) ― -b8- AlA_il~u also signifies God: [like the word אֵל or rather 165 as used in Hebrew:] (T, S, M, K:) so say Mujáhid and Esh-Shaabee: (T:) and so it is said to signify in the verse of the Kur cited above: (T, TA:) [and so it seems to signify in the saying of Aboo-Bekr, also cited above, accord. to the M:] but Aboo-Is- hák disallows this; and so does Suh, in the R. (TA.) Ibn-El-Kelbee says, (M,) when A_il~u ends any name, it has this meaning, and is the complement of a prefixed noun; and so A_iylu; (M, K;) as in jaboray^il~u [and jaboray^iylu &c.]; and so say most of the learned: (TA:) but this is not a valid assertion; for were it so, jaboray^il~u and the like would be perfectly decl.: (M:) some say that these names are constructed inversely, after the manner of the language of the 'Ajam; Al and Ayl meaning servant, and the first part of the name being a name of God. (Suh, TA.) -A2- I. q. $axoSN [used in a pl. sense]. (Mughnee in art. A_il~aA. [See what is said to be an ex. of this meaning in a verse of Dhu-r-Rummeh cited in art. AlA in the present work.]) ― -b2- [It is said that] A_il~N is also syn. with jaArN [A neighbour; &c.]. (K: [and so, accord. to the TA, in the M; but I have consulted the M without finding this explanation, and think it to be probably a mistranscription for juwaArN, (see above,) as in the T and R.])
A_il~apN A^lh A^lhY A_l`h Alh Alp lhA lhY lhy wlh wly |l |lh |lp : see A_il~N.

A^amorN A_il~aY~N *
A thing, or an affair, relating, or attributable, to AlA_il, meaning either God, or revelation or inspiration. (TA.)

A^alaA * [in its primitive acceptation, being composed of the interrogative hemzeh and the negative lA,] denotes an interrogation respecting a negative, as in the saying [of the poet],
A^alaA A@SoTibaAra lisalomaY A^amo lahaA jaladN
A_i*aA A^ulaAqiY A@l~a*iY laAqaAhu A^amovaAliY
[Is there not any patience belonging to Selmà, or has she hardiness, when I experience what persons like me have experienced?]: (Mughnee, K:) and when used in this manner, it is put before a nominal proposition only, and governs like the negative lA [when used without the interrogative hemzeh]. (Mughnee.) ― -b2- It also denotes a wish; as in the saying [of the poet],
A^alaA Eumora wal~aY musotaTaAEN rujuwEuhu
fayaroA^aba maA A^avoA^ato yadu AlgafalaAti
[May there not be a life which has declined whereof the returning is possible, so that it may repair what the hand of negligences hath marred?]; for which reason yrA^b is mansoob, because it is the complement of a wish, coupled with fa: and used in this manner, also, it is put before a nominal proposition only, [wl~Y in the verse above being a qualificative, like an epithet,] and it governs like the negative lA [without the interrogative hemzeh], and has no enunciative either expressed or understood. (Mughnee.) ― -b3- It also denotes reproof, or reproach, (T, Mughnee, K,) and disapproval; as in the saying [of the poet],
A^alaA A@roEiwaA='a limano walato $abiyobatuhu
waA*anato bima$iybK baEodahu haramu
[Is there no self-restraint to him whose youth hath declined, and announced hoariness, after which is to follow decrepitude?]: (Mughnee, K:) and used in this manner, also, it is put before a nominal proposition only, and governs as in the cases mentioned above, (Mughnee,) or before a verb [also], which is always marfooa; as in the phrase A^alaA tanad~ama EalaY fiEaAlika [Dost not thou repent of thine actions?] and A^alaA tasotaHoyiY mino jiyraAnika [Art not thou ashamed for thyself, or of thyself, with respect to thy neighbours?] and A^alaA taxaAfu rab~aka [Dost not thou fear thy Lord?]. (T.) ― -b4- It also denotes EaroDN, (T,) or AlEaroDu, and Alt~aHoDiyDu, both of which signify the asking, or requiring, a thing; (Mughnee, K; *) but the former means the doing so with gentleness; (Mughnee, K;) and the latter, the doing so with urgency: (Mughnee:) and when used in this manner, [also,] it is said to be composed of lA with the interrogative hemzeh; (TA;) and is put before a verbal proposition only; (Mughnee;) as in the saying [in the Kur xxiv. 22], A^alaA tuHib~uwna A^ano yagofira A@ll~`hu lakumo [Do not ye, or wherefore do not ye, (see A^amaA,) like that God should forgive you?] (Mughnee, K,) and [in the same, ix. 13,] A^alaAtuqaAtiluwna qFwomFA nakavuwA A^ayomaAnahumo [Will not ye, or wherefore will not ye, fight a people who have broken their oaths?]; (Mughnee;) or
before a mejzoom or marfooa aor., both of these forms being mentioned on the authority of the Arabs, as in A^alaA tanozilo taA^okulo and A^alaA tanozilu taA^okulu [Wilt not thou, or wherefore wilt not thou, alight and eat?]. (Ks, T.) ― -b5- It is also an inceptive particle, (S, Mughnee, K,) of which those who parse show the place but neglect the meaning, (Mughnee,) used to give notice of something about to be said, [like as Now, and why, (by the former of which I think it is generally best rendered when thus used,) are often employed in our language, and like as ἀλλὰ (which is remarkable for its near agreement with it in sound) is often used in Greek,] (S, Mughnee, K,) and importing averment, because it is composed of the interrogative hemzeh and the negative lA which, when thus composed, have this import, (Mughnee, K,) like A^alamo, and A^alayosa, because the interrogative particle resembles the particle of negation, and the negation of a negation is an affirmation, (Ham p. 589,) and like A^amaA before an oath: (Z, Mughnee:) [it may therefore be further rendered by our word surely;; for this word (as Dr. Johnson says in his Dictionary) "is often used rather to intend and strengthen the meaning of the sentence, than with any distinct and explicable meaning:"] or it signifies Haq~FA [verily, or truly]: (M voce A^amaA:) it is put before both the [kinds of] propositions, [the nominal and the verbal;] (Mughnee;) as in the saying [in the Kur ii. 12], A^alaA A_in~ahumo humu A@ls~ufahaA='u [meaning Now surely it is they who are the lightwitted], (Mughnee, K,) and [in the same, xi. 11,] A^alaA yawoma yaA^otiyhimo layosa maSoruwfFA Eanohumo [meaning Now surely, on the day of its coming to them, it shall not be averted from them], (Mughnee,) in which yawoma yaA^otiyhimo appears to be the object of government of maSoruwfFA, which is the enunciative of layosa whence it has been argued that, as the object of government of the enunciative of lys precedes that verb, the enunciative itself may precede it: (I 'Ak pp. 74 and 75:) [J says,] you say, A^alaA A_in~a zayodFA xaArijN [Now surely Zeyd is going forth], like as you say, A_iEolamo A^an~a zayodFA xaArijN [Know thou that Zeyd is going forth]: (S:) Ks says, A^alaA is used to give notice of what is about to be said, and is followed by a command and a prohibition and an enunciation, as in A^alaA qumo [Now stand thou], and A^alaA laA taqumo [Now stand not thou], and A^alaA A_in~a zayodFA qado qaAma [Now surely Zeyd has stood, or has just now stood]. (T.) When it is put before the particle [yaA] used to give notice of what is about to be said, it is merely an inceptive, as in the saying. [of the poet],
A^alaA yaA A@solamiY yaA daAra maY~a EalaY AlbilaY
[Now be thou free from evil, O abode of Meiyà, during wear and tear]. (AAF, M.) ― -b6- Lth says, sometimes A^alaA is immediately followed by another lA; and he cites the following ex.:
faqaAma ya*uwdu Aln~aAsa Ean~aA bisayofihi
yaquwlu A^alaA laA mino sabiylK A_ilaY hinodi
[Then he began to drive away the people from us, saying, Now is there no way to Hind?]: and one says to a man, "Did such and such things happen?" and he answers, A^alaA laA [Why no]: he holds AlA to be used to give notice of what is about to be said, and lA to be a negative. (T.)
A^ulaA * and AlA^ulaA, and A^ulaA='i &c.: see art. AlY.

A^al~aA * is a particle denoting taHoDiyD; (Msb in art. HD, Mughnee, K;) i. e., when followed by a future, exciting to an action, and seeking or desiring or demanding the performance of it; and when followed by a preterite, reproof for not doing a thing; (Msb ubi suprà;) syn. with hal~aA; (T, TA;) and peculiar to enunciative verbal propositions, (Mughnee, K,) like the other particles used for the same purpose. (Mughnee.) You say, [A^al~aA tafoEalu ka*aA Wherefore wilt not thou do such a thing? and] A^al~aA . faEalota ka*aA [Wherefore didst not thou such a thing?] (T, TA,) meaning, (TA,) or as though meaning, (T,) lima lamo tafoEalo ka*aA. (T, TA.) -A2- It also means A^ano laA; the n being incorporated into the l, which is written with teshdeed: (T, TA:) in which case, it is not to be confounded with the foregoing particle. (Mughnee.) You say, A^amarotuhu A^al~aA yafoEala *aAka [I commanded him that he should not do that]; and you may say, A^amarotuhu A^ano laA yafoEala *aAka: it occurs in the old copies of the Kur written in the former manner in some places, and in the latter manner in other places. (T, TA.) In the saying in the Kur [xxvii. 31], A^al~aA taEoluwA EalaY~a, [which may mean That ye exalt not yourselves against me, or exalt ye not yourselves against me,] it may be a compound of A^ano governing a mansoob aor. and the negative laA, or of the explicative A^ano and the prohibitive lA. (Mughnee.) [It often has li prefixed to it, forming the compound liy^al~aA, which signifies That, or in order that,... not; and may frequently be rendered by lest; as in the Kur ii. 145, liy^al~aA yakuwna liln~aAsi Ealayokumo Huj~apN That, or in order that, there may not be, or lest there should be, to men, against you, any allegation.]

A_il~aA A^lA A^nlA A_lA AlA |l |lA , [regarded as a simple word,] not to be confounded with the compound of the conditional A_ino and the negative laA, (Mughnee at the end of the article on this word,) is used in four manners. (The same in the beginning of the art.) First, (Mughnee,) it is used (as a particle, S, Msb,) to denote exception; [meaning Except, save, or saving; and sometimes but; and sometimes but not; as will be seen below;] (T, S, Msb, Mughnee, K; [in which last it is mentioned in art. Al, and again, as in the S, in the last division of the work;]) and to denote exception, it is used in five manners; after an affirmation, and a negation, and a portion of a sentence devoid of the mention of that from which the exception is made, and when the thing excepted precedes that from which the exception is made, and when these two are disunited in kind, in which last case it has the meaning of l`kin~a [but when the sentence is negative, and but not when the sentence is affirmative]. (S, TA.) You say, qaAma Alqawomu A_il~aA zayodFA [The people, or company of men, stood, except Zeyd]; i. e., Zeyd was not included in the predicament of the people, or company of men: (Msb:) and it is said in the Kur [ii. 250], (T,) fa$aribuwA minohu A_il~aA qaliylFA minohumo [And they drank of it, except a few of them]: (T, Mughnee, K:) here qlylA is governed in the accus. case by Al~A, (Mughnee, K,) accord. to the most correct opinion: (Mughnee:) accord. to Th, it is so because there is no negation in the beginning of the sentence. (T.) And it is also said in the Kur [iv. 69], (T,) maA faEaluwhu A_il~aA qaliylN minohumo [They had not done it, or they would not do it, except a few of them]: (T, Mughnee, K:) here qlyl is in the nom. case as being a partial substitute, (Mughnee, K,) accord. to the Basrees, (Mughnee,) i. e., as being a [partial] substitute for the [pronoun] w [in fElwh], for it may here be so without perversion of the meaning, whereas it cannot be so without such perversion when the sentence is affirmative: (TA:) accord. to the Koofees, Al~A is a conjunction, like the conjunctive laA: (Mughnee:) accord. to Th, qlyl is here in the nom. case because the sentence commences with a negative: (T:) or in a sentence [like this,] which is not affirmative, in which the thing excepted is united in kind to that from which the exception is made, accord. to the opinion which is generally preferred and which commonly obtains, the noun signifying the thing excepted is a substitute for the noun signifying that from which the exception is made; but it is allowable to put it in the accus. case according to the general rule respecting exception; so that one says, maA qaAma A^aHadN A_il~aA zayodN and A_il~aA zayodFA [There stood not any one, except Zeyd]: and the same is the case in a prohibitive sentence; as in laA yaqumo A^aHadN A_il~aA zayodN and A_il~aA zayodFA [Let not any one stand, except Zeyd]; and in an interrogative sentence; as in halo qaAma A^aHadN A_il~aA zayodN and A_il~aA zayodFA [Did any one stand, except Zeyd?]; when, in such sentences, the thing excepted is united in kind to that from which the exception is made. (I 'Ak p. 162.) You say also, maA jaA='aniY A_il~aA zayodN [There came not to me any, save Zeyd], without mentioning that from which the exception is made; (TA;) and maA Darabotu A_il~aA zayodFA [I beat not any, save Zeyd]; and maA mararotu A_il~aA bizayodK [I passed not by any, save by Zeyd]; (I' Ak p. 164;) the case of the noun signifying the thing excepted being the same as if Al~A were not mentioned: (I' Ak ubi suprà, and TA:*) but you may not say, affirmatively, Darabotu A_il~aA zayodFA, or the like. (I 'Ak ubi suprà.) When the thing excepted precedes that from which the exception is made, if the sentence is affirmative, the noun signifying the former must be in the accus. case; as in qaAma A_il~aA zayodFA Alqawomu [Except Zeyd, the people, or company of men, stood]: and so, accord. to the usage generally preferred, when the sentence is not affirmative; as in maAqaAma A_il~aA zayodFA Alqawomu [Except Zeyd, the people, or company of men, stood not]; but recorded instances allow one's saying also, maA qaAma A_il~aA zayodN Alqawomu. (I 'Ak p. 163.) When the thing excepted is disunited in kind from that from which the exception is made, if the sentence is affirmative, the noun signifying the former must likewise be in the accus. case; as in qaAma Alqawomu A_il~aA HimaArFA [The people, or company of men, stood, but
not an ass], and Darabotu Alqawoma A_il~aA HimaArFA [I beat the people, but not an ass], &c.: (I' Ak p. 162:) and so, accord. to the generality of the Arabs, when the sentence is negative; as in maA qaAma Alqawomu A_il~aA HimaArFA [The people stood not, but an ass]; (I' Ak p. 163;) and maA raA^ayotu Alqawoma A_il~aA HimaArFA [I saw not the people, but an ass]; Al~A being here syn. with l`kin~a; as also in the Kur [xlii. 22], where it is said, laA A^asoA^alukumo Ealayohi A^ajorFA A_il~aA A@lomawadapa fiY A@lqurobaY [I ask not of you a recompense for it, but affection in respect of relationship]; (Msb;) and in the same xx. 1 and 2, maA A^anozalonaA Ealayoka A@lquroA=na lita$oqaY A_il~aA ta*okirapF [We have not sent down unto thee the Kur-án that thou shouldest suffer fatigue, but as an admonition]; (Bd, Jel;) or it is here syn. with balo [which in this case means the same as lkn~]: (S:) so, too, when the sentence resembles a negative, being prohibitive or interrogative; (I' Ak p. 163, explained in p. 162;) [thus, laA taDoribi Alqawoma A_il~aA HimaArFA means Beat not thou the people, but an ass; and] falawlaA kaAnato qaroyapN A=manato fanafaEahaA A_iymaAnuhaA A_il~aA qawoma yuwnusa [in the Kur x. 98] means And wherefore did not any inhabitants of a town believe, before the punishment befell them, and their belief profit them, but the people of Jonas? for these were different from the former. (T.) When A_il~aA is repeated for the purpose of corroboration, it has no effect upon what follows it, except that of corroborating the first exception; as in maA mararotu biA^aHadK A_al~aA zayodK A_il~aA A^axiyka [I passed not by any one, except Zeyd, except thy brother], in which Axyk is a substitute for zyd, for it is as though you said, maA mararotu biA^aHadK A_il~aA zayodK A^axiyka; and as in qaAma Alqawomu A_il~aA zayodFA wa A_il~aA EamorFA [The people stood, except Zeyd, and except' Amr], originally A_il~aA zayodFA wa EamorFA. When the repetition is not for that purpose, if the sentence is devoid of the mention of that from which the exception is made, you make the governing word [which is the verb] to affect one, whichever you please, of the nouns signifying the things excepted, and put the others in the accus. case, so that you say, maA qaAma A_il~aA zayodN A_il~aA EamorFA A_il~aA bakorFA [There stood not any, save Zeyd, save' Amr, save Bekr]; but if the sentence is not devoid of the mention of that from which the exception is made, different rules are observed accord. as the things excepted are mentioned before that from which the exception is made or after it: in the former case, all must be put in the accus., whether the sentence be affirmative or not affirmative; as in qaAma A_il~aA zayodFA A_il~aA EamorFA A_il~aA bakorFA Alqawomu [Except Zeyd, except' Amr, except Bekr, the people stood], and maAqaAma A_il~aA zayodFA A_il~aA EamorFA A_il~aA bakorFA Alqawomu [Except Zeyd, except' Amr, except Bekr, the people stood not]: in the latter case, when the sentence is affirmative, all must likewise be put in the accus., so that you say, qaAma Alqawomu A_il~aA zayodFA A_il~aA EamorFA A_il~aA bakorFA [The people stood, except Zeyd, except' Amr, except Bekr]; but when the sentence is not affirmative, the same rule is observed with respect to one of them as when the exception is not repeated, accord. to the usage generally preferred, or it may be put in the accus., which is rarely done, and the rest must be put in the accus., so that you say, maA qaAma A^aHadN A_il~aA zayodN A_il~aA EamorFA A_il~aA bakorFA [There stood not any one, except Zeyd, except' Amr, except Bekr, accord. to the more approved usage], zyd being a substitute for AHd, or you may make the other nouns which remain to be substitutes. (I' Ak pp. 164 — 166.) ― -b2- Secondly, (Mughnee,) it is used as a qualificative, (S, Msb, Mughnee, K,) in the manner of gayoru, (Mughnee, K,) [i. e.] in the place of gayoru, (S,) [i. e.] as syn. with gayoru, (T, Msb,) and siwaY; (T;) [both meaning the same, i. e. Other than; or not, as used before a subst. or an adjective;] but its primary application is to denote exception, and its use as a qualificative is adventitious; whereas the primary application of gayoru is as a qualificative, and its use to denote exception is adventitious. (S.) It [generally] follows an indeterminate, unrestricted pl.; (Msb;) or an indeterminate pl., or the like thereof, is qualified by it and by that which follows it; (Mughnee, K;) the noun which follows it being put in the same case as that which precedes it. (S.) The following is an ex. of the indeterminate pl.: (Mughnee, K:) lawo kaAna fiyhimaA A=lihapN A_il~aA A@ll~`hu lafasadataA [If there had been in them (namely the heavens and the earth) deities other than God, or not God, assuredly they would have become in a state of disorder, or ruin; occurring in the Kur xxi. 22]; (Fr, T, S, Msb, Mughnee, K;) Al~A here meaning sawiY, (Fr, T,) or gayoru, (Msb, TA,) and Al~A All~h being a qualificative of A=lhp. (TA.) And the following is an ex. of the like of an indeterminate pl.:
A^uniyxato faA^aloqato balodapF fawoqi balodapK
qaliylK bihaA AlA^aSowaAtu A_il~aA bugaAmuhaA
[She (the camel) was made to lie down, and threw her breast upon a tract of ground in which were few sounds other than her broken yearning cry for her young one]; for the determination of AlASwAt [by the article Al] is generical: (Mughnee, K:) this verse is by Dhu-r-Rummeh. (S in art. bld.) The following is an ex. of the like of a pl..: (Mughnee:) it is by Lebeed: (T:)
lawo kaAna gayoriY sulayomaY Alyawoma gay~arahu
waqoEu AlHawaAdivi A_il~aA AlS~aArimu Al*~akaru
[If it had been other than I, (O) Suleymà, today, the befalling of misfortunes would have altered him; other than the sharp sword diversified with wavy marks or streaks or grain, or of which the edge is of steel and the middle of the broad side of soft iron]. (T, Mughnee. [But in the latter, in the place of Alyawoma, I find Ald~ahora, i. e. ever.]) What Sb says necessarily implies its not being a condition that the word qualified must be a pl. or the like thereof; for he gives as an ex., lawo kaAna maEanaA rajulN A_il~a [If there had been with us a man other than Zeyd, we should have been overcome]. (Mughnee.) Another ex. of the same usage of A_il~aA is the following: jaA='aniY Alqawomu A_il~aA zayodN [The people came to me, others than Zeyd, or not Zeyd]. (S.) [And ma A^anotumo A_il~aA ba$arN mivolunaA Ye are no other than human beings like us. (Kur xxxvi. 14.)] And the saying [in the Kur xliv. 56], laA ya*uquwna fiyhaA A@lomawota A_il~aA A@lmawotapa A@loA^uwlaY [They shall not taste therein death, other than the first death]; Al~A here meaning siwaY: (T:) or, accord. to some, it here means baEoda [after]. (Jel.) And the saying of 'Amr Ibn-Maadee-kerib,
wa kul~u A^axK mufaAriquhu A^axuwhu
laEamoru A^abiyka A_ilaA AlfaroqadaAni
[And every brother, his brother forsakes him, or separates himself from him, by the life of thy father, other than the Farhadán; which is the name of the two stars b and r of Ursa Minor]; as though he said gayoru Alfaroqadayoni: (S:) but Ibn-El-Hájib regards this instance as a deviation from a general rule; for he makes it a condition of the use of Al~A as a qualificative that it must be impossible to use it for the purpose of denoting exception: (Mughnee:) Fr says that this verse has the meaning of a negation, and therefore Al~A here governs the nom. case; as though the poet said, There is not any one but his brother forsakes him, except the Farkadán. (T.) When it is used as a qualificative, it differs from gayoru inasmuch as that the noun qualified by it may not be suppressed; so that one may not say, jaA='aniY A_il~aA zayodN [meaning There came to me not Zeyd]; whereas one says, jaA=y^aniY gayoru zayodK: and, accord. to some, in this also; that it may not be used as such unless it may be used to denote exception; so that one may say, EinodiY dirohamN A_il~aA daAniqN [I have a dirhem, not a dánik], because one may say A_il~aA daAniqFA [except a dánik]; but not A_il~aA jay~idN [not a good one], because one may not say A_il~aA jay~idFA [except a good one]; but it may be said that this is at variance with what they assert respecting the phrase lawo kaAna fiyhimaA A=lihapN, and with the ex. given by Sb, and with the saying of Ibn-El-Hájib mentioned above. (Mughnee.) ― -b3- Thirdly, (Mughnee,) sometimes, (S, Msb,) it is used as a conjunction, (Mughnee, K,) in the manner of wa (S, Mughnee, K,) consociating both literally and as to the meaning, as mentioned by Akh and Fr and AO, (Mughnee,) [i. e.] as syn. with wa [And]. (Msb.) Thus in the saying, liy^alA~a yakuwna liln~aAsi Ealayokumo HujapN A_il~aA A@l~a*iyna ZalamuwA [That there may not be to men, against you, any allegation, and (meaning nor) to those who have acted wrongfully]; (Msb, Mughnee, K;) occurring in the Kur [ii. 145]; (Msb;) so accord. to Akh and Fr and AO; (Mughnee;) i. e., and those who have acted wrongfully also, to them there shall not be, against you, any allegation: (Msb:) Fr explains it as meaning that the wrongdoer has no allegation of which account should be taken; and this is correct, and is the opinion held by Zj. (T.) Thus, too, in the saying [in the Kur xxvii. 10 and 11], laA yaxaAfu ladaY~a A@lomurosaluwna A_il~aA mano Zalama vum~a badala HusonFA baEoda suw'K [The apostles shall not fear in my presence, and neither shall he who hath acted wrongfully, then hath done good instead, after evil; as some explain it; but others say that walaA mano Zalama here denotes exception]. (Mughnee, in which it is explained as meaning ; and K.) And thus in the saying of the poet, [namely, El-Mukhabbal Es-Saadee, (S in art. xld,)]
waA^araY lahaA daArFA biA^agodirap Also
siydaAni lamo yadoruso lahaA rasomu
A_il~aA ramaAdFA haAmidFA dafaEato
Eanohu Alr~iyaAHa xawaAlidN suHomN
[And I see a dwelling formerly belonging to her, at the pools of Es-Seedán, (a hill so called,) the remains of which have not become effaced, and ashes wasted and compacted together, from which three black pieces of stone whereon the cooking-pot was wont to be placed turned back the winds]: he means, A^araY lahaA daArFA wa ramaAdFA. (S.) ― -b4- Fourthly, (Mughnee,) it is redundant, as in the following verse, (S in art. fk, Mughnee, K,) of Dhu-rRummeh, (S ubi suprà, Mughnee,) accord. to As and IJ: (Mughnee:)
HaraAjiyju maA tanofak~u A_il~aA munaAxapN
EalaY Alxasofi A^awo naromiY bihaA baladFA qaforaA
[She-camels long-bodied, or lean, (but other meanings are assigned to the word which I thus render,) that cease not to be made to lie down in a state of hunger, or with which we direct our course to a desert region]; (S ubi suprà, Mughnee; [but in one copy of the former, in the place of naromiY, I find yaromiY; and in my copy of the latter, taromiY;]) meaning, mA tnfk~ mnAxpF: (S ubi suprà:) but it is said that this is a mistake of the poet: (Mughnee:) so says Aboo-'Amr Ibn-El-'Alà; for, he says, Al~A is not to be introduced after tanofak~u and tazaAlu: (TA:) and some say that the right reading is A_il~FA, with tenween, [perhaps a mistranscription, for A=lFA,] meaning $axoSFA [in a pl. sense]: and some, that tnfk~ is a complete [or an attributive] verb, and mnAxp is a denotative of state; [consequently, that A_il~aA is a compound of A_ino and laA, as in some other instances hereafter to be mentioned;] the meaning being, that are not disengaged, or not free, from fatigue [unless when made to lie down]. (Mughnee.) The following is also given as an ex. of the same kind:
A^araY Ald~ahora A_il~aA manojanuwnFA biA^aholihi
[I see fortune, or time, to be like a water-wheel, with its people]: but the reading which is remembered to have been heard is wamaA Ald~ahoru: and if the former be correct, it may be explained on the supposition that ArY is the complement of an oath meant to be understood, and that lA is suppressed, as in [the saying in the Kur xii. 85,] taA@ll~`hi tafotaA^u ta*okuru yuwsufa; [so that the meaning is, I see not fortune, or time, to be aught save a water-wheel, with its people;] the form of the exceptive sentence which is devoid of the mention of that from which the exception is made indicating such an explanation. (Mughnee.) ― -b5- [Fifthly,] it occurs as syn. with lDaA [as a particle denoting exception, equivalent to our But; meaning both except and (after an oath or the like) only, or nothing more than]; as in the saying in the Kur [xxxviii. 13], A_ino kul~N A_il~aA ka*~aba Alr~usula [There was not any one but such as accused the apostles of lying], in which 'Abd-Allah reads, in its place, lam~aA; and for kul~N he reads kul~uhumo; and as in the saying, A^asoA^aluka biAll~`hi A_il~aA A^aEoTayotaniY [I ask, or beg, or beseech, thee by God but that thou give me; i. e., I do not ask of thee anything save thy giving me; the preterite here, as in many instances in which it is preceded by lam~aA (q. v.), not being a preterite in meaning]; for which one says also lam~aA AETytnY. (T.) -A2- It is also a particle [or rather a compound of two words] denoting the complement of a condition; originally A_ino laA, which form a compound that does not admit of [the pronunciation termed] imáleh, because A_ino and laA are particles. (T.) [It signifies, lit., If not.] It is followed by a fut., which it renders mejzoom; [and in this case it may be rendered as above, or by unless;] as in the saying in the Kur [viii. 74], A_ilaA tafoEaluwhu takuno fitonapN fiY AlA^aroDi [If ye do it not, or unless ye do it, there will be a weakness of faith and an appearing of unbelief in the earth]. (T.) [In like manner,] in a saying such as the following, [in the Kur ix. 40,] A_il~aA tanoSuruwhu faqado naSarahu A@ll~`hu [If ye do not, or will not, aid him, certainly God aided him], it is only a compound of two words, the conditional A_ino and the negative laA, and is distinct from A_il~aA of which the usages have been mentioned before, though Ibn-Málik has included it therewith. (Mughnee.) [Often in post-classical works, and perhaps in classical also, but seldom except when it is preceded by a condition with its complement, the verb or verbal proposition which should immediately follow it is suppressed; as in the like of the saying, A_ino faEalota ka*aA Eafawotu Eanoka wa A_il~aA qatalotuka If thou do such a thing, I forgive thee, or cancel thine offence; but if thou wilt not do it (i. e., A_il~aA tafoEalohu,) I kill thee: sometimes also it ends a sentence, by an aposiopesis; the whole of what should follow it being suppressed: and sometimes the complement of the condition which precedes, as well as the verb or verbal proposition which should immediately follow it, is suppressed; so that you say, A_ino faEalotu ka*aA wa A_il~aA qatalotuka If thou do such a thing, excellent will it be, or the like, faniEim~aA huwa, or the like, being understood,) but if not, I kill thee. Hence,] it sometimes has the meaning of A_im~aA, [signifying Or, denoting an alternative, corresponding to a preceding A_im~aA, which signifies “either,”] as in the saying, A_im~aA A^ano tukal~imaniY wa A_il~aA faA@sokuto [Either do thou speak to me or else (meaning wa A_il~aA tukal~imaniY or if thou wilt not speak to me) be silent], i. e., wa A_im~aA A^ano tasokuta. (S.) [It is also followed by A^ano, as in A_il~aA A^ano ya$aA='a A@ll~`hu Unless God should please; in the Kur vi. 111, &c. And by w as a denotative of state, as in laA tamuwtun~a A_il~aA wa A^anotumo musolimuwna Do not ye die unless ye be Muslims; in the Kur ii. 126 and iii. 97. And sometimes it is preceded by Aall~hum~a; for the effect of which, in this case, see art. Alh.]

1 A^alaba * , (Th, M, K,) aor.
Aaliba , and
Aaluba , inf. n. A^alobN, (M,) It (a thing, Th, M) was, or became, collected; or compact; syn. AijotamaEa; (Th, K;) or tajam~aEa. (M.) ― -b2- A^alaba A_ilayohi Alqawomu The people came to him from every direction: (M, K:) or A^alaba Alqawomu [signifies the people multiplied themselves, and hastened; for it] denotes AlA_ikovaAru and AlA_isoraAE: (T in art. Dhb:) and A^alaba, (T, K,) aor. as above, (T,) signifies he hastened, or went quickly. (T, K.) ― -b3- A^alabati AlA_ibilu The camels obeyed the driver, and collected themselves together. (M, K.) [See also 5.] ― -b4- A^alaba A_ilayohi He returned to him, or it. (K, * TA.) ― -b5- A^alabati Als~amaA='u, (M, K,) aor.
Aaliba , (M,) The sky rained with long continuance. (M, K.) -A2- A^alaba, (S Msb, K,) aor.
Aaliba , inf. n. A^alobN, (Msb,) He collected (S Msb, K) an army, (S,) or a people; (Msb;) as also ↓ A^l~b, (M,) inf. n. taA^oliybN: (TA:) and camels also: (TA:) or A^alaba AlA_ibila aor.
Aaliba (T, * S, M, K) and
Aaluba , (S, M, K,) inf. n. A^alobN, (T, S,) signifies he collected the camels, and drove them (S, TA) vehemently: (TA:) or he drove them: (T, * K:) or he drove them vehemently. (M.) ― -b2- A^alaba, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (K, TA,) also signifies He drove, pursued, chased, or hunted, with vehemence: (K, TA:) and he drove away a people. (Msb.) You say, A^alaba AlHimaAru Tariydatahu The [wild] ass chased, or pursued, the object of his chase [i. e. his female, as is shown by MF,] with vehemence; (M, K;) as also ↓ A^al~abahaA (K.)

2 Aal~aba see 1, in two places. ― -b2- taA^oliybN also signifies The act of exciting, instigating; or rousing to ardour: (S, K:) and the exciting of discord, or strife, or the making of mischief. (K.) you say, A^l~b bayonahumo He excited discord or strife, or made mischief, between them. (M.)

5 tA^l~bwA *
They collected themselves together. (S, A, Msb.) [See also 1.] You say also, tA^l~bwA Ealayohi They leagued together, or collected themselves. together, and aided one another, against him. (T.)

A^alobN * (T, S, Msb) and ↓ A_ilobN (S, Msb) Persons, or people, collected together; (S;) an assembly; a collected body: (Msb:) or a collection of many people: (T:) and ↓ A^alobN A^aluwbN a great assembly or congregation. (M.) ― -b2- Also A people, or company of men, combining in hostility against a man. (TA, from a trad.)
