You say, humo Ealayohi A^alobN waAHidN, and ↓ A_ilobN, (but the former is the better known, M,) They are [one body of men] assembled against him with injustice and enmity or hostility: (Lth, T, M, K:) like waEolN waAHidN and SadoEN waAHidN and DilaEN waAHidN. (T, TA.)
A_ilobN A^lb Alb lAb lb lbY : see A^alobN, in two places.
A^alabN * a dial. var. of yalabN; (M;) Helmets of camels' shins: or, as some say, it signifies steel: (T:) A^alabapN is [its n. un., being] a dial. var. of yalabapN. (K, * TA.) [See also yalabN.]

A^aluwbN * : see A^alobN. ― -b2- Also One who hastens, or is quick; (T;) and ↓ miy^olabN likewise signifies [the same; or] quick, or swift: (Ibn-Buzurj, T, K:) or the former signifies quick in drawing forth the bucket: (IAar, M, K:) or brisk, lively, sprightly, active, agile, or prompt, and quick; (K, TA;)
applied to a man. (TA.) ― -b3- riyoHN A^aluwbN A cold wind, (M,) that raises and scatters the dust. (M, K.) ― -b4- samaA='N A^aluwbN A sky raining with long continuance. (M.)
miy^olabN * : see A^aluwbN.
HasuwdN muw^al~ibN * [An envious man,] who excites discord or strife, or makes mischief. (S, * TA.)

1 A^alata * ,aor.
Aalita , inf. n.A^alotN, It (a thing) decreased; diminished; lessened; became defective, deficient, incomplete, or imperfect. (Msb.) -A2- A^alatahu Haq~ahu, (S, M, A, K,) aor.
Aalita , (S, M, K,) inf. n. A^alotN (S, M) and A_ilaAtahu; (M;) and A^alitahu, aor.
Aalata ; (Fr;) and ↓ A=lthu (M, K,) inf. n. A_iylaAtN; (K;) as also A^alaAtahu, inf. n. A_ilaAtN, (so in a MS. copy of the K,) or A_ilaAtapN; (so in the L: [agreeably with analogy, and therefore probably the correct reading: see art. lyt, to which it belongs: in SM's copy of the K, and in the CK, the verb is written A^aloA^atahu, and the inf. n. A_iloA=tN: by MF, the verb is written ↓ A=latahu, of the measure faAEala and the inf. n. A_ilaAtN like qitaAlN:]) [and laAtahu, aor. yaliytN; and walatahu; and A^awolatahu;] He diminished to him his right, or due; abridged him, or defrauded him, of a portion of it: (Fr, S, M, A, K:) and in like manner, A^alatahu maAlahu and ↓ A=lthu, &c., he diminished to him his property; or abridged him, or defrauded him, of a portion of it: (M, TA:) and A^alata Al$~aYo'a he diminished the thing. (Msb.) [Hence,] maA A^alotanaAhumo mino Eamalihimo mino $aYo'K [in the Kur lii. 21, We will not diminish to them aught of the reward of their work]: (T, A:) or, accord. to one reading, (that of Ibn-Ketheer, TA,) mA A^alitonaAhumo. (T, TA.) [See also art. lyt.] -A3- A^alatahu, (T, S, K,) or A^alatahu Eano wajohihi, (TA,) aor.
Aalita (T;) as also laAtahu; these being two dial. vars. one of the other, mentioned by Yz, on the authority of AA; (S;) [and A^alaAtahu; (see art. lyt;)] He withheld him, or restrained him, (S, K,) and turned him, or averted him, (T, S, K,) from his course, purpose, or object. (S, TA.) -A4- A^alatahu, (M, K,) or A^alatahu yamiynFA, (As, T, S,) aor.
Aalita inf. n. A^alotN, He made him to swear, or take an oath: (As, T, S, K:) or he desired of him that he should swear, or give his testimony, for him. (M, K.) And A^alatahu biyamiynK, inf. n. as above, He pressed him, or pressed hard upon him, with an oath. (M.) It is related that a man said to 'Omar, "Fear God, O prince of the faithful:" and another, hearing him, said, A^ataA^olitu EalaY A^amiyri Almuw^ominiyna, meaning Dost thou lower the dignity of the prince of the faithful? or dost thou diminish to him [the respect that is due to him]? accord. to IAar.: or rather, dost thou conjure the prince of the faithful? his saying "Fear God" being as though he conjured him by God: for the Arabs say, A^alat~uka biAll~`hi lam~aA faEalota ka*aA, meaning I conjure thee by God but that thou do thus, or such a thing. (T.)
3 AaAolata see 1.
4 A=lata see 1, in two places.

A^alotN *
Deficiency: as in the saying, maA fiY mazaAwidihimo A^alotN [There is not, in their provision-bags, any deficiency]. (A.) -A2- A swearing; syn. HalifN (M, TA.) [Perhaps an inf. n. in this sense.] ― -b2- An oath: as in the saying, when one has not given thee thy right, or due, qay~idohu biAloA^aloti [Bind thou him by oath]. (T.) -A3- Calumny, slander, or false accusation. (Kr, M, K.) [Perhaps an inf. n. in this sense also.]

A^ulotapN *
A small gift. (AA, T, K.) -A2- An oath such as is termed gamuws, q. v. (AA, T, K.)
A_ilaAdapN AlAdh AlAdp &c. for wilaAdapN &c. : see art. wld.

1 A^alifahu * , (T, S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
Aalafa , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_ilufN (S, M, Msb, K) and A^alofN (K) and A_ilaAfN and wilaAfN, which is anomalous, and A^alafaAnN, (M, TA,) He kept, or clave, to it; (A'Obeyd, T, M, Msb, * TA;) namely, a thing, (A'Obeyd, T, M, TA,) or a place; (S, Msb, TA;) as also A^alafahu, aor.
Aalifa ; (TA;) and ↓ A=lfhu, (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, Msb,) aor. yuw^olifu (S, TA,) inf. n. A_iylaAfN; (S, Msb, TA;) and ↓ A=lfhu, aor. yuw^aAlifu, inf. n. muw^aAlafapN and A_ilaAfN: (S, Msb, TA:) [he frequented it, or resorted to it habitually; namely, a place:] he became familiar with it; or accustomed, or habituated, to it; namely, a thing: (AZ, T:) he became familiar, sociable, companionable, friendly, or amicable, with him: (AZ, T, Msb:) he loved, or affected, him; liked, approved, or took pleasure in, him. (Msb.) You say, A^alifati AlT~ayoru AlHarama [The birds kept to the sacred territory], and Albuyuwta [the houses]: and AlZ~ibaA='u Alr~amoli ↓ A=lafati The gazelles kept to the sands. (T.) ― -b2- There are three manners of reading the passage in the Kur [evi. 1 and 2], qurayo$K A_iylaAfihimo riHolapa Al$~itaA='i wa AlS~ayofi ↓ liA_iylaAfi; the second and third being liA_ilaAfi and liA_ilofi; the first and second of which have been adopted; (Aboo-Is-hák, T, TA;) and the third also; this being the reading of the Prophet [himself]: (TA:) [accord. to all these readings, the passage may be rendered, For the keeping of Kureysh, for their keeping to the journey of the winter and of the summer, or spring; the chapter going on to say, for this reason "let them worship the Lord of this House," &c. : or] the second and third readings are from A^alifa, aor. yaA^olafu; [and accord. to these readings, the passage may be rendered as above;] but accord. to the first reading, the meaning is, for the preparing and fitting out [&c.; i. e., preparing and fitting out men and beasts in the journey of the winter &c.]: so says IAmb; and Fr explains in the same manner the third reading: but IAar says that, accord. to this reading, the meaning is, the protecting [&c.]: he says that the persons who protected were four brothers, Háshim and 'Abd-Shems and El-Muttalib and Nowfal, the sons of 'Abd-Menáf: these gave protection to Kureysh in their procuring of corn: (T:) Háshim obtained a grant of security from the king of the Greeks, and Nowfal from Kisrà, and 'Abd-Shems from the Nejáshee, and ElMuttalib from the kings of Himyer; and the merchants of Kureysh used to go to and from the great towns of these kings with the grants of security of these brothers, and none opposed them: Háshim used to give protection (yuw^olifu [in the copies of the K yuw^al~ifu]) [to those journeying] to Syria, and 'Abd-Shems to Abyssinia, and ElMuttalib to El-Yemen, and Nowfal to Persia: (T, K: *) or ↓ A_iylaAf in the Kur signifies a covenant, or an obligation; and what resembles permission, (A_ijaAzap, as in some copies of the K and in the TA,) or protection, (A_ijaArap, as in the CK,) with an obligation involving responsibility for safety; first obtained by Háshim, from the kings of Syria; (K, * TA;) and the explanation is, that Kureysh were dwelling in the sacred territory, (K,) having neither seed-produce nor udders [to yield them milk], (TA,) secure in the procuring of their provisions from other parts, and in their changes of place, in winter and summer, or spring; the people around them having their property seized; whereas, when any cause of mischief occurred to them, they said, "We are people of the sacred territory," and then no one opposed them: (K:) so in the O: (TA:) or the l is to denote wonder; and the meaning is, wonder ye at the AylAf of Kureysh [&c.]: (K:) some say that the meaning is connected with what follows; i. e., let them worship the Lord of this House for the AylAf [&c., agreeably with the first explanation which we have given]: others, that it is connected with what precedes; as J says; (TA;) the meaning being, I have destroyed the masters of the elephant to make Kureysh remain at Mekkeh, and for their uniting the journey of the winter and of the summer, or spring; that when they finished one, they should commence the other; (T, S;) and this is like the saying, Darabotuhu lika*aA Darabotuhu lika*aA a lika*aA, with suppression of the [conjunctive] w: (S:) but Ibn-'Arafeh disapproves of this, for two reasons: first, because the phrase "In the name of God" &c. occurs between the two chapters: [Bd, however, mentions that in Ubeí's copy, the two compose one chapter:] secondly, because AylAf signifies the covenants, or obligations, which they obtained when they went forth on mercantile expeditions, and whereby they became secure. (TA.) ↓ A_ilaAfN [in like manner] signifies A writing of security, written by the king for people, that they may be secure in his territory: and is used by Musáwir Ibn-Hind in the sense of AiytilaAfN [as is also A_ilofN,] when he says, in satirizing Benoo-Asad,
zaEamotumo A^an~a A_ixowatakumo qurayo$N
lahumo A_ilofN wa layosa lakumo A_ilaAfu
meaning Ye asserted [that your brothers are Kureysh; i. e.,] that ye are like Kureysh: but how should ye be like them? for they have [an alliance whereby they are protected in] the trade of El-Yemen and Syria; and ye have not that [alliance]. (Ham p. 636.) [Hence,] A_ilaAfu A@ll~`hi [a phrase used in the manner of an oath,] accord. to some, signifies The safeguard, or protection, of God: or, accord. to others, an honourable station from God. (TA.) -A2- A^alafahu, aor.
Aalifa , He gave him
a thousand; (S, K) of articles of property, and of camels. (TA.)

2 A@l~f bayonahumo * , inf. n. taA^oliyfN, (T, Msb, K,) He united them, or brought them together, (T, Msb, TA,) after separation; (T, TA;) and made them to love one another; (Msb;) he caused union, or companionship, (A^ulofap,) to take place between them. (K.) And A^al~afotu bayona Al$~ayoy^ayoni, inf. n. as above, [I united, or put together, the two things.] (S.) And A^l~f Al$~aYo'a He united, or connected, (T,) or gathered or collected or brought together, (M,) the several parts of the thing. (T, M.) ― -b2- Hence, taA^oliyfu Alkutubi [The composition of books]. (T, TA.) ― -b3- taA^oliyfN is The putting many things into such a state that one name becomes applicable to them, whether there be to some of the parts a relation to others by precedence and sequence, or not: so that it is a more general term than tarotiybN: (KT:) or the collecting together, or putting together, suitable things; from AlAlfp [i. e. AlA^ulofapu]; and is a more particular term than tarokiybN, which is the putting together things, whether suitable or not, or placed in order or not. (Kull p. 118.) -A2- A^al~afuwA A_ilaY ka*aA: see 5. -A3- A^l~f A^alifFA He wrote an alif; (K;) like as one says jay~ama jiymFA. (TA.) -A4- See also 4, in three places.

3 A=lfhu A=lfh A=lfp : see 1, first sentence. -A2- A=lf, (M, TA,) inf. n. muw^aAlafapN, (TA,) [app., He made a covenant with another to be protected during a journey for the purpose of trade, or traffic: (see 1:) and hence,] he (a man) traded, or trafficked. (M, TA.) -A3- $aAarapN muw^aAlafapF He made a condition with him for a thousand: (IAar, M:) like as one says, $aAraTotuhu mumaA A=pF, meaning, for a hundred. (IAar, M, K, in art. mA^Y.)

4 A=lfhu A=lfh A=lfp , inf. n. A_iylaAfN: see 1, in three places. -A2- A=lfhu Al$~aYo'a, (T, M,) or AlmawoDiEa, (S,) or makaAna ka*aA, (K,) inf. n. as above, (T,) He made him to keep, or cleave, to the thing, or to the place, or to such a place. (T, S, * M, K. *) ― -b2- A=lafotu Al$~aYo'a I joined, conjoined or united, the thing. (T.) -A3- A=lafotu Alqawoma, (T, * S, K, *) inf. n. as above, (S,) I made the people, or company of men, to be a thousand complete [by adding to them myself]; (T, S, K, TA;) they being before nine hundred and ninety-nine. (T, TA.) And A=lf AlEadada He made the number to be a thousand; as also ↓ A^al~afahu: (M:) or AlA^alofa ↓ A^l~f he completed the thousand. (K.) And in like manner, (S,) A=lafotu Ald~araAhima I made the dirhems to be a thousand (S, K) complete. (S.) And lahumu AlA^aEomaAra ↓ A^al~afuw They said to them, May you live a thousand years. (A in art. Emr.) -A4- A=lafuwA They became a thousand (T, S, M) complete. (S.) And A=lafati Ald~aArahimu The dirhems became a thousand (S K) complete. (S.)

5 tA^l~f Alqawomu * , (Msb, K,) and ↓ A@y^otalafuwA [written with the disjunctive alif AiyotalafuwA], (T, K,) The people, or party, became united, or came together, (Msb, K,) [after separation, (see 2, of which each is said in the TA to be quasi-pass.,)] and loved one another: (Msb:) or the meaning of ↓ A@y^otilaAfN [and taA^al~ufN also] is the being in a state of union, alliance, agreement, congruity, or congregation: (Msb:) and the being familiar, sociable, companionable, friendly, or amicable, one with another. (TA.) And taA^al~afaA is said of two things; [meaning They became united, or put together; (see 2;)] as also ↓ Ay^tlfA. (S.) And Al$~aYo'u ↓ Ay^tlf signifies The several parts of the thing kept, or clave, together. (M.) And tA^l~f It became put together in order. (M.) ― -b2- tA^l~fwA They sought, desired, or asked, [a covenant to ensure them] protection, (IAar, T, M,) A_ilaY ka*aA [meaning in a journey for the purpose of trade, or traffic, to such a place, as is shown in the T by an explanation of the words of IAar, kaAna haA$imN yuw^olifu A_ilaY Al$~aAmi, in a passage in which the foregoing signification is assigned to tA^l~fwA]; (M;) as also AlY k*A ↓ A^al~afuwA. (M.) -A2- tA^l~fhu He treated him with gentleness or blandishment, coaxed him, or wheedled him; (K;) behaved in a sociable, friendly, or familiar, manner with him; (TA;) attracted him, or allured him; and gave him a gift, or gifts; (T, K; *) in order to incline him to him: (K:) or he affected sociableness, friendliness, or familiarity, with him. (Mgh.) You say, taA^al~afotuhu EalaY AlA_isolaAmi [I attracted him, or allured him; and gave him a gift, or gifts, in order to incline him; to embrace ElIslám]. (S.)
8 A_iAotalafa see 5, in four places.

A^alofN * , meaning A certain number, (S, M, K,) well known, (M,) i. e. a certain round number, (Msb,) [namely a thousand,] is of the masc. gender: (T, S, Msb, K:) you say valaAvapu A=laAfK [Three thousand], not valaAva A=laAfK; (TA;) and h`*aA A^alofN waAHidN [This is one thousand], not waAHidapN; (S;) and A^alofN A^aqoraEu, [A complete thousand], (T, S,) not qaroEaA='u: (S:) it is not allowable to make it fem.: so say IAmb and others: (Msb:) or it is allowable to make it fem. as being a pl.: (T:) or, accord. to ISK, it is allowable to say, h`*ihi A^alofN as meaning h`*ihi Ald~araAhimu A^alofN [These dirhems are a thousand]; (S, K; *) and Fr and Zj say the like: (Msb:) the pl. is A=lufN, applied to three, (M,) and A=laAfN, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) applied to a number from three to ten, inclusively, (TA,) and A^uluwfN, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) used to denote more than ten; (T;) and AlA^aAfu [in the TA AlA^alafu] is used by poetic licence for AlA=laAfu, by suppression of the [radical] l (M.)

A_ilofN A^lf A^lfY A_lf Alf lAf lf |lf [originally an inf. n. of A^alifahu, q. v.,] He with whom one is familiar, sociable, companionable, friendly, or amicable; he to whom one keeps or cleaves; [a constant companion or associate; a mate; a fellow; a yoke-fellow; one who is familiar, &c., with another or others; (see muw^al~afN;)] (M;) i. q. ↓ A^aliyfN; (T, S, M, K;) which is an act. part. n. of A^alifahu; (Msb;) as is also ↓ A=lifN; (Msb, K;) and ↓ A^alifN also is syn. with A^aliyfN: (K:) the female is termed A_ilofapN and A_ilofN; (M;) both of these signifying a woman with whom thou art familiar, &c., and who is familiar, &c., with thee: (K:) and the fem. of ↓ A=lifN is A=lifapN: (K:) the pl. of A_ilofN is A=laAfN; (T, M;) which is also pl. of ↓ A^alifN: (TA:) and that of ↓ A^aliyfN is A^alaAy^ifu (S, K, TA) and A^ulafaA='u: (M, TA:) and that of ↓ A=lifN is A^ul~aAfN (T, S, Msb, K) and A=laAfN, like as A^anoSaArN is pl. of naASirN, (TA,) and so, (M, TA,) in my opinion, [says ISd,] (M,) is A^uluwfN, like as $uhuwdN is pl. of $aAhidN, (M, TA,) though some say that it is pl. of A_ilofN: (M:) and the pl. of ↓ A=lifapN is A^awaAlifu and A=lifaAtN. (K.) You say, fvlaAnN A_ilofiY and ↓ A^aliyfiY [Such a one is my constant companion or associate, &c.] (T.) And Han~ati AlA_ilofu A_ilaY A_ilofi [The female mate yearned towards the mate]. (S.) And nazaEa AlbaEiyru A_ilaY A=laAfihi [The camel yearned towards his mates]. (T.) A^ul~aAfN, (T,) or A=laAfN (TA,) is said by IAar to mean Persons who keep to the large towns, or cities. (T, TA.) A^uluwfN in the Kur ii. 244 is said by some to be pl. of A_ilofN or of ↓ A=lifN: but by others, to signify "thousands." (Bd, L, TA.) AlT~ayori ↓ A^awaAlifu signifies The birds that keep to Mekkeh and the sacred territory: and AlHamaAmi ↓ A^awaAlifu Domestic pigeons. (T.)

A^alifN * : see A_ilofN, in two places. ― -b2- As some say, (O,) it also signifies A man having no wife. (O, K.) -A2- One of the letters of the alphabet; (M;) the first thereof; (K;) as also ↓ A^aliyfN: (M:) Ks says that, accord. to the usage of the Arabs, it is fem., and so are all the other letters of the alphabet; [and hence its pl. is A^alifaAtN;] but it is allowable to make it masc.: Sb says that every one of them is masc. and fem., like as is lisaAnN. (M.) See art. A. ― -b2- (tropical:) A certain vein lying in the interior of the upper arm, [extending] to the fore arm: (K, TA:) so called as being likened to an A: (TA:) the two are called AlA^alifaAni. (K.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) One of any kind of things: (K, TA:) as being likened to the A; for it denotes the number one. (TA.)

A^ulofapN *
A state of keeping or cleaving [to a person or thing]: (M:) a state of union, alliance, agreement, congruity, or congregation; (Msb;) a subst. from AlAiy^otilaAfu: (Msb, K, TA:) and, as such, (TA,) signifying also familiarity, sociableness, socialness, companionableness, friendliness, fellowship, companionship, friendship, and amity. (Msb, TA. *)

A^alofiY~N *
Of, or relating to, or belonging to, the number termed A^alofN [a thousand]. (TA.)

[
qaAmapN A^alifiy~apN *
A stature resembling the letter alif. Often occurring in late works.]
A_ilaAfN A^lAf A^lf A_f A_lf AlA_f AlAf |lAf an inf. n. of A^alifahu: and used as a subst.: see 1. ― -b2- baroqN A_ilaAfN Lightning of which the flashes are consecutive or continuous. (TA.)

A^aluwfN *
Having much A^ulofapN [meaning familiarity, sociableness, &c.]: pl. A^ulufN. (K.)
A^aliyfN * : see A_ilofN, in three places: -A2- and see A^alifN.
A=lifN A=lf and A=lifapN; and A^awaAlifu, the pl. of the latter: see A_ilofN, in seven places.
A_iyolaAfN A_ylAf AylAf an inf. n.: and used as a subst.: see 1.

maA^olafN * [An accustomed place;] a place to which a man keeps or cleaves; [which he frequents, or to which he habitually resorts;] with which he is familiar, or to which he is accustomed; (Msb;) a place with which men or camels [or birds and the like] are familiar, &c. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- And hence, Leafy trees to which animals of the chase draw near. (AZ, K.)
mw^lfwn * , with fet-h, [i. e. muw^olafuwna or ↓ muw^al~afuwna,] Possessors of thousands; or men whose camels have become, to each, a thousand. (TA.)

muw^al~afN * and ↓ maA^oluwfN Kept to, or clove to; applied to a thing [and to a person; and meaning when applied to the latter, with whom one is familiar, sociable, &c.]. (T.) It is said in a trad., Almuw^ominu ↓ A_ilofN maA^oluwfN [The believer is one who is familiar, or sociable, &c., with others, and with whom others are familiar, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- Almuw^al~afapu quluwbuhumo Those whose hearts are made to incline, or are conciliated, by beneficence and love or affection: (S, * Msb:) as used in the Kur [ix. 60], it is applied to certain chief persons of the Arabs, whom the Prophet was commanded to attract, or allure, and to present with gifts, (T, K,) from the poor-rates, (TA,) in order that they might make those after them desirous of becoming Muslims, (T, K,) and lest care for things which they deemed sacred, or inviolable, together with the weakness of their intentions, should induce them to combine in hostility with the unbelievers against the Muslims; for which purpose, he gave them, on the day of Honeyn, eighty [in the TA two hundred] camels: (T:) they were certain men of eminence, of the Arabs, to whom the Prophet used to give gifts from the poor-rates; to some of them, to prevent their acting injuriously; and to some, from a desire of their becoming Muslims, (Mgh, Msb,) and their followers also; (Msb;) and to some, in order that they might remain stedfast as Muslims, because of their having recently become such; but when Aboo-Bekr became appointed to the government, he forbade this practice. (Mgh, Msb.) -A2- A^alofN muw^al~afapN [These are a thousand] made complete. (S.) ― -b2- See also mw^lfwn.

[
muw^al~ifN *
A composer of a book or books; an author.]
maA^oluwfN * : see muw^al~afN, in two places.

1 A^alaqa * , (JK, K, TA,) aor.
Aaliqa ; (K, TA;) or A^aliqa, aor.
Aalaqa ; (CK; [in which it would seem, from what follows in this paragraph and the next, that the pret. is wrong, but that the aor. is right;]) inf. n. A^aloqN and A_ilaAqN; (JK, K;) It (lightning) lied; (AHeyth, K;) [i. e.] it was without rain. (JK.) ― -b2- See also 5. ― -b3- Also, A^alaqa, aor.
Aalaqa , inf. n. A^aloqN, He lied; spoke falsely: whence the reading of Aboo-Jaafar and Zeyd Ibn-Aslam, [in the Kur xxiv. 14,] A_i*o taA^olaquwnahu tA^l~q [When ye spoke it falsely with your tongues]. (TA.)

5 tA^l~q *
It (lightning) shone, gleamed, or glistened; as also ↓ Ay^tlq [written with the disjunctive alif Aiytalaqa]; (JK, S, IJ, K;) and so ↓ A^alaqa, aor.
Aalaqa . (TA.) Ibn-Ahmar has made the second trans., using the phrase AlEuyuwna ↓ taA^otaliqu, either by suppressing a prep., [meaning She shines to the eyes,] or meaning thereby she ravishes the eyes. (TA.) ― -b2- And taA^al~aqatN, said of a woman, She adorned herself: (Sgh, K:) or she became active and quick to engage in contention or altercation, and prepared herself for evil or mischief, and raised her head: (IF, K:) or she became like the A_iloqap [fem. of A_iloqN, q. v.]. (IAar.)
8 A_iAotalaqa see 5, in two places.

A_iloqN A^lq A^lqY Alq lAq lqy
A he-wolf: fem. with p: (IAar, S, K:) and the fem. is also applied to a she-ape or monkey; the male of which is not called A_iloqN, but qirodN, (S, K,) and rub~aAHN. (S.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Evil in disposition, applied to a man; and so with p applied to a woman: and the latter, a [demon of the kind called] siEolaAp; because of its evil, or malignant, nature: (TA:) and a bold woman; (Lth, K;) for the same reason. (TA.)

A_ilaAqN A^lAq AlAq lAqY [an inf. n. (see 1) used as an epithet;] Lying, or fallacious, lightning; (K;) that has no rain; (JK, K;) as also ↓ A^al~aAqN: (K, * TA:) ↓ A=liqN, likewise, is an epithet applied to lightning [in the same sense; or as signifying shining, gleaming, or glistening: see 1 and 5]: and so is ↓ A^ul~aqN, as syn. with xul~abN [that excites hope of rain, but deceives the expectation]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, applied to a man, Lying: (JK:) or lying much, or often, or habitually: (TA:) and very deceitful, and variable in disposition. (TA.)
A^aliyqN * [app. an inf. n. of A^alaqa; (see 5;)] The shining, gleaming, or glistening, of lightning. (TA.)
A^ul~aqN * : see A_ilaAqN.

A_il~aqN A^lq A^lqY Alq lAq lqy , like A_im~aEN, [in a copy of the JK incorrectly written A^aliqN,] i. q. mutaA^al~iqN [Shining, gleaming, or glistening]; (S, K;) applied to lightning. (JK.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) An inconstant man; from Alt~aA^al~uqu as relating to lightning. (JK: there, in this instance, written A_il~aqN.)
A^al~aAqN * : see A_ilaAqN.
A=liqN A=lq : see A_ilaqN.

1 A^alaka Alil~jaAma * , (ISd, K,) [aor.
Aaluka or
Aalika ,] inf. n. A^alokN, (ISd, TA,) He (a horse) chewed, or champed, the bit; syn. Ealakahu. (ISd, K.) One says, of a horse, yA^lku All~ujuma He chews, or champs, the bits: but the verb commonly known is yaluwka, or yaEoluku. (Lth.) ― -b2- [Hence, accord. to some, (see A^aluwkN,)] A^alaka bayona Alqawomi, (Msb, TA,) aor.
Aalika , inf. n. A^alokN and A^uluwkN, (Msb,) He acted as a messenger (taras~ala) between the people. (Msb, TA.) ― -b3- And A^alakahu, aor.
Aalika , inf. n. A^alokN, He conveyed, or communicated, to him a message. (Kr.) ― -b4- And A^alaka He sent. (IB in art. lwk.)

4 A^alikoniY * is from A^alaka signifying “he sent;” and is originally A^aA^olikoniY; the [second] hemzeh being transposed and placed after the l, it becomes A^aloy^ikoniY; then the hemzeh has its vowel transferred to the l and is thrown out; as is done in the case of malakN, which is originally maA^olakN, then maloA^akN, and then malakN: (IB in art. lwk:) it means Be thou my messenger; and bear thou my message; and is often used by the poets. (S in art. lwk.) Accord. to IAmb, one says, A^alikoniY A_ilaY fulaAnK, meaning send thou me to such a one: [but I do not know any instance in which this meaning is applicable:] and the original form is A^aloy^ikoniY; or, if from AlA^aluwku, the original form is A^aA^olikoniY: and he also says that it means be thou my messenger to such a one. (TA.) One says also, A^alikoniY A_ilayohaA birisaAlapK, which should properly mean Send thou me to her with a message: but it is an inverted phrase; since the meaning is, be thou my messenger to her with this message [or rather with a message]: and A^alikoniY A_ilayohaA biAls~alaAmi i. e. convey thou, or communicate thou, to her my salutation; or be thou my messenger to her [with salutation]: and sometimes this [prep.] b is suppressed, so that one says, A^alikoniY A_ilayohaA Als~alaAma: sometimes, also, the person sent is he to whom the message is sent; as in the saying, A^alikoniY A_ilayoka Als~alaAma [virtually meaning receive thou my salutation; but literally] be thou my messenger to thyself with salutation. (TA.) Lh mentions the phrase A^alakotuhu A_ilayohi, with respect to a message, aor. A^uliykuhu, inf. n. A_ilaAkahN; in which case, the hemzeh [in the aor. and inf. n.] is converted into a letter of prolongation. (TA in art. lA^k.)
5 taAal~aka see A^aluwkN.

10 AstA^lk maA^olukatahu *
He bore, or conveyed, his message; (K;) as also AstlA^k. (TA.)

A^aluwkN *
A thing that is eaten [or rather chewed, as will be seen below]: so in the phrases, h*aA A^aluwku SidoqK like Ealuwju SidoqK and Ealuwku SidoqK [This is an excellent thing that is chewed], and maA talaw~akotu biA^aluwkK [or biA^aluwkK ↓ maA taA^al~akotu (K in art.

Elj Elj )] like maA taEal~ajotu biEaluwjK [app. meaning I have not occupied myself in chewing with anything that is chewed]. (TA.) ― -b2- [And hence, accord. to some,] A message, or communication sent from one person or party to another; (Lth, S, M, K, &c.; [in the CK, after Alr~isAlapu, by which AlA^aluwku is explained in the K &c., we find qibala Almaliki mu$otaq~N mnhu, in which the first two words should be qiyla Almalaku, as in other copies of the K and in the TA; and AlAuluwku is erroneously put, in the CK, for AlA^aluwku;]) said by Lth and ISd to be so called because it is [as it were] chewed in the mouth; (TA;) as also ↓ A^aluwkahN (ISd, Sgh, K) and ↓ maA^olukapN (Lth, S, Msb, K, &c.) and ↓ maA^olakapN (Msb, K) and ↓ maA^olukN: (S, M, Msb. K, &c.:) accord. to Kr, (TA,) this last is the only word of the measure mafoEulN: (K, TA:) but accord. to Sb and Akh, there is no word of this measure: (TA:) [i. e. there is none originally
of this measure:] other instances have been mentioned; namely, makorumN and maEuwnN [originally maEowunN] and maqoburN and maholukN and mayosurN, which last occurs in the Kur [ii. 280], accord. to one reading, in the words fanaZirapN A_ilaY mayosurihi; but it is said that each of these, and maA^olukN also, may be regarded as originally with p; or, accord. to AHei, each is [virtually, though not in the language of the grammarians,] a pl. of the same with p; (MF, TA;) and Akh says the same with respect to makorumN and maEuwnN: (TA:) Seer says that each is curtailed of p by poetic licence; but this assertion will not apply to mayosurN, as it occurs in the Kur. (MF, TA.) ― -b3- A^aluwkN also signifies A messenger. (Ibn-'Abbád, K. [In the CK here follows, wAlmA^oluwoku wAlmaA^oluqu: but the right reading is waAlmaA^oluwku AlmaA^oluwqu, as in other copies and in the TA.])
A^aluwkahN * : see A^aluwkN.

maA^olakN * is said to be the original form of malakN [An angel; so called because he conveys, or communicates, the message from God; (K, * TA, in art. lA^k;)] derived from A^aluwkN; (Msb, K, TA; [but in the CK is a mistake here, pointed out above, voce A^aluwkN;]) so that the measure of malakN is maEalN: (Msb:) malakN is both sing. and pl.: Ks says that it is originally maA^olakN, from A^aluwkN signifying “a message;” then, by transposition, maloA^akN, a form also in use; and then, in consequence of frequency of usage, the hemzeh is suppressed, so that it becomes malakN; but in forming the pl., they restore it to maloA^akN, saying malaAy^ikapN, and malaAy^iku also: (S in art. mlk:) or, accord. to some, it is from laA^aka “he sent;” so that the measure of malakN is mafalN: and there are other opinions respecting it: (Msb:) some say that its m is a radical: see art. mlk. (TA in art. lA^k.)
maA^olukN * : see A^aluwkN.
maA^olakapN * : see A^aluwkN.
maA^olakapN * : see A^aluwkN.

1 A^alima * , aor.
Aalama , inf. n. A^alamN, It, (as, for instance, the belly, T, S, or the head, Msb,) or he, (a man, T, S, Msb,) was in pain; had, or suffered, pain; ached. (T, S, M, Msb, K.) A^alima baTonahu [He was in pain, or had pain, in his belly] (M) and A^alimota baTonaka [thou wast in pain, or hadst pain, in thy belly] (T, S) or raA^osaka [in thy head] (Msb) are like safiha raA^oyahu (M) and ra$idota A^amoraka (S, T) and wajiEota raA^osaka; (Msb;) the noun being in the accus. case accord. to Ks as an explicative, though explicatives are [by rule] indeterminate, as in qarirotu bihi EayonFA and Daqotu bihi *aroEFA; (T;) the regular form being [A^alima baTonuhu and] A^alima baTonuka, (T, S,) as the verb is intrans. (T.)
4 A=lamotuhu A=lmth A=lmtp , (S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_iylaAmN, (S, Msb,) I caused him pain or aching. (S, * M, Msb, K.)

5 tA^l~m *
He was, or became, pained: (M, * Msb, K: *) or he expressed pain, grief, or sorrow; lamented; complained; made lamentation or complaint; moaned; syn. tawaj~aEa, (T, S,) and $akaY. (T.) You say, taA^al~ama fulaAnN mino fulaAnK [Such a one expressed pain, &c., on account of the conduct or the like of such a one; complained of such a one]: (T:) and liA^azomapi Alz~amaAni [on account of the hardness of the time]. (TA in art. Azm.)
A^alamN * : see lamo.

A^alamN *
Pain; ache; (T, S, M, K;) as also ↓ A^ayolamapN: (T, M, K:) pl. (of the former, T, M) A=laAmN. (T, M, K.) You say, walaA A^alamFA ↓ maA A^ajidu A^ayolamapF I do not find pain nor ache; i. e. wajaEFA: so says AZ: and IAar says, ↓ A^ayolamapF walaA A^alamapF as meaning the same. (T.) And the Arabs say, laA^ubiytan~aka EalaY ↓ A^ayolamapK, meaning I will assuredly bring upon thee [lit. make thee to pass the night in] distress, or difficulty. (Sh.)

A^alimN *
Being in pain; having, or suffering, pain; aching. (M, K.)
A^alamapN * : see A^alamN.
A_ilaAma A^lAm A^lm A^m AlA^m AlAm |lAm a contraction of A_laY maA: see A_ilaY, last sentence.

A^aliymN *
Causing pain or aching; painful; (S, K;) i. q. ↓ muw^olimN; (T, M, Msb;) like samiyEN as syn. with musomiEN: (S:) so when applied to punishment [or torment or torture]: (T, Msb:) or, thus applied, painful, or causing pain or aching, in the utmost degree. (M, K.)

A^aluwmapN *
Lowness, ignobleness, baseness, vileness, or meanness. (O, K.)

A^ayolamapN * : see A^alamN, in three places. ― -b2- Accord. to IAar, (T,) A sound, or voice. (T, K.) You say, maA samiEotu lahu A^ayolamapN I heard not any sound, or voice, of, or belonging to, him, or it. (IAar, T.) ― -b3- Accord. to AA, (T,) Motion. (T, K.)
muw^olimN * : see A^aliymN.
A^alomaAsN * , or AlomaAsu: see art. mws.

A_ilaAhapN A^lAhh A_lAh A_lAhh A_lAhp A_l`h AlAhh AlAhp Al|hp lAhY |hp (S, Msb, K) and A^uluwhapN and A^uluwhiy~aPN, (K,) He served, worshipped, or adored; syn. Eabada. (S, Msb, K.) Hence the reading of I'Ab, [in the Kur vii. 124,] waya*araka waA_ilaAhataka [And leave thee, and the service, or worship, or adoration, of thee; instead of waA=lihataka and thy gods, which is the common reading]; for he used to say that Pharaoh was worshipped, and did not worship: (S:) so, too, says, Th: and IB says that the opinion of I'Ab is strengthened by the sayings of Pharaoh [mentioned in the Kur lxxix. 24 and xxviii. 38], “I am your lord the most high,” and “I did not know any god of yours beside me.” (TA.) -A2- A^aliha, aor.
Aalaha , (S, K,) inf. n. A^alahN, (S,) He was, or became, confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; (S, K;) originally waliha. (S.) ― -b2- A^aliha Ealay fulaAnK He was, or became, vehemently impatient, or affected with vehement grief, or he manifested vehement grief and agitation, on account of such a one; (S, K;) like waliha. (S.) ― -b3- A^aliha A_ilayohi He betook himself to him by reason of fright or fear, seeking protection; or sought, or asked, aid, or succour, of him: he had recourse, or betook himself, to him for refuge, protection, or preservation. (K.) ― -b4- A^aliha biAlmakaAni He remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, in the place. (MF.) -A3- A^alahahu, (K,) like manaEahu, (TA,) [in the CK Aalihahu,] He protected him; granted him refuge; preserved, saved, rescued, or liberated, him; aided, or succoured, him; or delivered him from evil: he rendered him secure, or safe. (K.)

2 taA^oliyhN * [inf. n. of A^al~ahahu He made him, or took him as, a slave; he enslaved him;] i. q. taEobiydN. (S, K.) ― -b2- [The primary signification of A^al~ahahu seems to be, He made him to serve, worship, or adore. ― -b3- Accord. to Freytag, besides having the former of the two meanings explained above, it signifies He reckoned him among gods; held him to be a god; made him a god: but he does not mention his authority.]

A_ilhN A^lh A^lhY A_l`h Alh Alp lhA lhY lhy wlh wly |l |lh |lp , or A_ilaAhN, [the former of which is the more common mode of writing the word,] is of the measure fEaAlN (S, Msb, K) in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, (S, Msb,) like kitaAbN in the sense of makotuwbN, and bisaATN in the sense of mabosuwTF, (Msb,) meaning ↓ maA^olowpN [An object of worship or adoration; i. e. a god, a deity]; (S, Msb, K) anything that is taken as an object of worship or adoration, accord. to him who takes it as such: (K:) with the article Al, properly, i. q. All~`hu; [sec this word below;] but applied by the believers in a plurality of gods to what is worshipped by them to the exclusion of All~`h: (Msb:) pl. A=lihapN: (Msb, TA:) which signifies idols: (JK, S, TA:) in the K, this meaning is erroneously assigned to A_ilaAhapN: (TA:) [not so in the CK; but there, AlAlihapu is put in a place where we should read AlA_ilaAhapu, or A_ilaAhapu without the article:] ↓ AlA_ilaAhapu [is the fem. of AlA_ilaAhu, and] signifies [the goddess: and particularly] the serpent: [(a meaning erroneously assigned in the CK to AlA=lihapu; as also other meanings here following:) because it was a special object of the worship of some of the ancient Arabs:] (K:) or the great serpent: (Th:) and the [new moon; or the moon when it is termed] hilaAl: (Th, K:) and, (S, K,) as also ↓ A_ilaAhapu, without Al, the former perfectly decl., and the latter imperfectly decl., (S,) and ↓ AlA^ulaAhapu, (IAar, K,) and ↓ A^ulaAhapu, (IAar, TA,) and ↓ AlA^alaAhapu, (K,)
[and app. ↓ A^alaAhapu,] and ↓ AlA^aliyhapu, (K,) the sun; (S, K;) app. so called because of the honour and worship which they paid to it: (S:) or the hot sun. (Th, TA.) [A_ilhN is the same as the Hebrew אֱלוֹהַּ and The Chaldee XXX; and is of uncertain derivaTion: accord. To some,] it is originally wilaAhN, like as A_i$aAHN is originally wi$aAHN; meaning that mankind yearn towards him who is thus called, [seeking protection or aid,] in their wants, and humble themselves to him in their afflictions, like as every infant yearns towards its mother. (TA.) [See also the opinions, cited below, on the derivation of All~`hu.]
A^alahapu * and AlA^alaAhapu: see A_ilhN.
A^ulaAhapu * and AlA^ulaAhapu: see A_ilhN. -A2- A^ulaAhapN: see A_ilaAhapN.

A_ilaAhapN A^lAhh A_lAh A_lAhh A_lAhp A_l`h AlAhh AlAhp Al|hp lAhY |hp inf. n. of 1, q. v. (S, Msb, K.) -A2- Godship; divinity; (K;) as also ↓ A^ulaAhapN (CK [not found by me in any MS. copy of the K) and ↓ A^ulohaAniy~apN. (K.) -A3- A_ilaAhapu and AlA_ilaAhapu: see A_ilhN.
AlA^aliyhapu * : see A_ilhN.

[
A_ilhiY~N A^lhY A^lhy A_l`h A_l`hy A_l`hyy AlhY Alhy lhA lhY lhy , or A_ilaAhiY~N, Of, or relating to, God or a god; divine; theological: Hence, AlEilomu AlA_ilhiY~u or AlA_ilaAhiY~N: see what next follows.]

[
AlA_ilhiy~apu A_l`hy AlA_l`hyp AlAlhyh AlAlhyp , or AlA_ilaAhiy~apu, Theology; the science of the being and attributes of God, and of the articles of religious belief; also termed Eilomu AlA_ilhiy~aAti or AlA_ilaAhiy~aAti, and ↓ AlEilomu AlA_ilhiY~u or AlA_ilaAhiY~u.]

All~`hu All`h All`p , [written with the disjunctive alif Aall~`hu, meaning God, i. e. the only true god,] accord. to the most correct of the opinions respecting it, which are twenty in number, (K,) or more than thirty, (MF,) is a proper name, (Msb, K,) applied to the Being who exists necessarily, by Himself, comprising all the attributes of perfection; (TA;) a proper name denoting the true god, comprising all the excellent divine names; a unity comprising all the essences of existing things; (Ibn-El- 'Arabee, TA;) the Al being inseparable from it: (Msb:) not derived: (Lth, Msb, K:) or it is originally A_ilhN, or A_ilaAhN, (Sb, A Heyth, S, Msb, K,) of the measure fiEaAlN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, meaning maA^oluwhN, (S, K, *) with [the article] Al prefixed to it, (Sb, A Heyth, S, Msb,) so that it becomes AlA_ilaAhu, (Sb, A Heyth, Msb,) then the vowel of the hemzeh is transferred to the l [before it], (Msb,) and the hemzeh is suppressed, (Sb, A Heyth, S, Msb,) so that there remains All~`hu, or AlilaAhu, after which the former l is made quiescent, and incorporated into the other: (Sb, A Heyth, Msb:) the suppression of the hemzeh is for the purpose of rendering the word easy of utterance, on account of the frequency of its occurrence: and the Al is not a substitute for the hemzeh; for were it so, it would not occur therewith in AlA_ilaAhu: (S:) so says J; but IB says that this is not a necessary inference, because AlA_ilaAhu applies to God (All~`hu) and also to the idol that is worshipped; whereas All~`hu applies only to God; and therefore, in using the vocative form of address, one may say, yaA Aall~`hu [O God], with the article Al and with the disjunctive hemzeh; but one may not say, yaA AlA_ilaAhu either with the disjunctive or with the conjunctive hemzeh: (TA:) Sb allows that it may be originally laAhN: see art. lyh: (S:) some say that it is from A^aliha, either because minds are confounded, or perplexed, by the greatness, or majesty, of God, or because He is the object of recourse for protection, or aid, in every case: or from A^alahahu, meaning “he protected him,” &c., as explained above: see 1, last sentence. (TA.) The Al is pronounced with the disjunctive hemzeh in using the vocative form of address [yaA Aall~`hu] because it is inseparably prefixed as an honourable distinction of this name; (S;) or because a pause upon the vocative particle is intended in honour of the name; (S in art. lyh;) and AAF says that it is also thus pronounced in a form of swearing; as in A^afaAall~`hi latafoEalan~a [an elliptical phrase, as will be shown below, meaning Then, by God, wilt thou indeed do such a thing?]; though he denies its being thus pronounced because it is inseparable; regarding it as a substitute for the suppressed hemzeh of AlA_ilaAhu: (S in the present art.:) Sb mentions this pronunciation in yaA Aall~`hu; and Th mentions the pronunciation of yaA All~`hu also, with the conjunctive hemzeh: Ks, moreover, mentions, as used by the Arabs, the phrase yalaho AagofiroliY [O God, forgive me], for yaA All~`hu; but this is disapproved. (ISd, TA.) The word is pronounced in the manner termed tafoxiym, [i. e., with the broad sound of the lengthened fet-h, and with a full sound of the letter l,] for the purpose of showing honour to it; but when it is preceded by a kesreh, [as in biAll~`hi By God, and bisomi All~`hi In the name of God,] it is pronounced in the [contr.] manner termed taroqiyq: AHát says that some of the vulgar say, laAwaAll~`ho [No, by God], suppressing the alif, which should necessarily be uttered, as in Alr~aHomnu, which is in like manner written without alif; and he adds that some person has composed a verse in which the alif [in this word] is suppressed, erroneously. (Msb.) You say, Aall~`ha All~`ha fiY ka*aA, [a verb being understood,] meaning Fear ye God, fear ye God, with respect to such a thing. (Marginal note in a copy of the Jámi' es-Sagheer. [See another ex. voce kar~apN.]) And Aall~`ha laA^afoEalan~a and Aall~`hi laA^afoEalan~a [By God, I will assuredly do such a thing]: in the former is understood a verb significant of swearing; and in the latter, [or in both, for a noun is often put in the accus. case because of a particle understood,] a particle [such as bi or wa] denoting an oath. (Bd in ii. 1.) And lilhi maA faEalotu, meaning waAll~`hi maA faEalotu [By God, I did not, or have not done, such a thing]. (JK.) And lil~hi dar~uka (tropical:) To God be attributed thy deed! (A in art. dr:) or the good that hath proceeded from thee! or thy good deed! or thy gift! and what is received from thee! [and thy flow of eloquence! and the like]: a phrase expressive of admiration of anything: (TA in art. dr:) [when said to an eloquent speaker or poet, it may be rendered divinely art thou gifted!]. And lil~hi dar~uhu (tropical:) To God be attributed his deed! [&c.]. (S and K in art. dr.) And lil~hi AlqaAy^ilu [meaning To God be attributed (the eloquence of) the sayer! or] how good, or beautiful, is the saying of the sayer, or of him who says [such and such words]! or it is like the phrase lil~hi dar~uhu, meaning (assumed tropical:) To God be attributed his goodness! and his pure action! (Har p. 11.) And lil~hi fulaAnN [To God be attributed (the excel-lence, or goodness, or deed, &c., of) such a one!] explained by Az as meaning wonder ye at such a one: how perfect is he! (Har ibid.) [And lil~hi A^abuwka: see art. Abw.] And laAhi A^anota, meaning lil~hi A^anota [lit. To God be thou attributed! i. e. to God be attributed thine excellence! or thy goodness! or thy deed! &c.]. (JK.) [Similar to lil~hi, thus used, is the Hebrew expression לֵאלֹהּים after an epithet signifying “great” or the like.] A_in~aAlil~hi waA_in~aA A_ilayohi raAjiEuwna, in the Kur [ii. 151], said on the occasion of an affliction, means Verily to God we belong, as property and servants, He doing with us what He willeth, and verily unto Him we return in the ultimate state of existence, and He will recompense us. (Jel.) AZ mentions the phrase AlHamodulaAhi [meaning AlHamodulil~hi Praise be to God]: but this is not allowable in the Kur-án: it is only related as heard from the Arabs of the desert, and those not knowing the usage of the Kur-án. (Az, TA.) ― -b2- ↓ Aall~hum~a is an expression used in prayer; as also laAhum~a; (JK, Msb;) meaning yaA Aall~`hu [O God]; the m being a substitute for [the suppressed vocative particle] yA; (S in art. lyh, and Bd in iii. 25;) but one says also, yaA Aall~hum~a, (JK, and S ibid,) by poetic licence: (S ibid:) or the meaning, accord. to some, is yaA Aall~`hu A^um~anaA bixayorK [O God, bring us good]; (JK, and Bd ubi suprà;) and hence the origin of the expression. (Bd.) You say also Aall~hum~a A_il~aA [which may be rendered, inversely, Unless, indeed; or unless, possibly]: the former word being thus used to denote that the exception is something very rare. (Mtr in the commencement of his Expos. of the Makámát of El-Hareeree, and Har pp. 52 and 53.) And Aall~hum~a naEamo [which may be rendered, inversely, Yes, indeed; or yea, verily]: the former word being used in this case as corroborative of the answer to an interrogation, negative and affirmative. (Har p. 563.)
Aall~hum~a All`hm Allhm lhm : see what next precedes.
maA^oluwhN * : see A_ilhN.

1 A^alaA * , (S, M, Mgh, K,) aor. yaA^oluw, (S, Mgh,) inf. n. A^alowN (T, M, Mgh, K) and A^uluw~u (K, TA [in a copy of the M A^aluw~N]) and A^uliY~N; (K, TA; [in a copy of the M A^aliY~N, and in a copy of the Mgh written with fet-h and damm to the A^;]) and ↓ A^al~aY, (S, M, K,) aor. yuw^al~Y, inf. n. taA^oliyapN; (S;) and ↓ Ay^tlY [written with the disjunctive alif AiytalaY]; (S, M, K;) [and ↓ taA^al~Y, as appears from an ex. in a verse cited in art. n$b, q. v.;] He fell short; or he fell short of doing what was requisite, or what he ought to have done; or he
flagged, or was remiss; syn. qaS~ara: (S, M, K; and Fr, IAar, T, Mgh, in explanation of the first of these verbs:) and he was slow, or tardy: (M, K; and AA, T, S, in explanation of the second verb:) or he flagged, or was remiss, or languid, and weak. (A Heyth and T in explanation of all of the above-mentioned verbs except the last.) You say, A^alaA fiY AlA^amori, (Mgh,) and ↓ Ay^tlY fiyhi, (S,) He fell short, &c., (qaS~ara,) in the affair. (S, Mgh.) In the saying, lam yaA^olu A^ano yaEodila fiY *lika, i. e. He did not fall short, &c., (lamo yuqaS~aro,) in acting equitably and equally in that, fiY is suppressed before An: but in the phrase, lamo yaA^oluw mina AlEadoli, as some relate it, [the meaning intended seems to be, They did not hold back, or the like, from acting equitably; for here] the verb is made to imply the meaning of another verb: and such is the case in the saying, laA A=luwka nuSoHFA, meaning I will not refuse to thee, nor partially or wholly deprive thee of, sincere, honest, or faithful, advice: (Mgh:) or this last signifies I will not flag, or be remiss, nor fall short, to thee in giving sincere, honest, or faithful, advice. (T, S. *) It is said in the Kur [iii. 114], laA yaA_oluwnakumo xabaAlFA, meaning They will not fall short, or flag, or be remiss, in corrupting you. (IAar, T.) And the same meaning is assigned to the verb in the saying A^uwluw AlofaDoli minokumo ↓ walaA yaA^otali, in the Kur [xxiv. 22], by A'Obeyd: but the preferable rendering in this case is that of A Heyth, which will be found below: see 4. (T.) Ks mentions the phrase, A^aqobala biDarobapK laA yaA^olu [He came with a blow, not falling short, &c.], for lA yaA^oluw; like laA A^adori [for lA A^adoriY]. (S, M: [but in the copies of the former in my hands, for biDarobapK, I find yaDoribuhu.]) ↓ A^al~aY [with teshdeed] is also said of a dog, and of a hawk, meaning He fell short of attaining the game that he pursued. (TA.) And of a cake of bread, meaning It was slow in becoming thoroughly baked. (IAar, IB.) [See also the phrase laA daryota walaA Ay^otalyota in a later part of this paragraph.] ― -b2- You say also, maA A^alawotu Al$~ayo'a, (K,) or maA A^alawotu A^ano A^afoEalahu, (M,) inf. n A^alwN (M, K) and A^uluw~N, (K, TA, [in a copy of the M A^ulowN,]) meaning I did not leave, quit, cease from, omit, or neglect, (M, K,) the thing, (K,) or doing it. (M.) And fulaAnN laA yaA^oluw xayorFA Such a one does not leave, quit, or cease from, doing good. (M.) And maA A^alawotu jahodFA I did not leave, omit, or neglect, labour, exertion, effort, or endeavour: and the vulgar say, maA A=luwka jahodFA; but this is wrong: so says As. (T. [See, however, similar phrases mentioned above.]) -A2- A^alaA, aor. as above, (TA,) inf. n. A^alowN, (IAar, T, TA,) also signifies He strove, or laboured; he exerted himself, or his power or ability; (IAar, T, TA;) as also ↓ taA^al~aY: (T, TA:) the contr. of a signification before mentioned; i. e. “he flagged;,” or “was remiss, or languid, and weak.” (TA.) You say, A^ataAniY fiY HaAjapK faA^alawotu fiyhaA He came to me respecting a want, and I strove, or laboured, &c., to accomplish it. (T.) ― -b2- And A^alaAhu, aor. as above, (T, S,) inf. n. A^alowN, (IAar, T, S,) He was, or became, able to do it: (IAar, T, S:) and ↓ A^l~Y, inf. n. taA^oliyapN, also signifies he was, or became, able; (TA;) and so ↓ Ay^tlY. (ISk, S, TA.) You say, huwa yaA^oluw h*aA AlA^amora He is able to perform, or accomplish, this affair. (T.) And maA A^alawotuhu I was not able to do it. (T, M, K.) And A^ataAniY fulaAnN fiY HaAjapK famaA A^alawotu rad~ahu Such a one came to me respecting a want, and I was not able to rebuff him. (T.) It is said in a trad., mano SaAma
↓ Ald~ahora falaA SaAma walaA A^al~aY [He who fasts ever, or always, may he neither fast] nor be able to fast: as though it were an imprecation: or it may be enunciative: another reading is walaA A=la, explained as meaning walaA rajaEa: [See art. Awl:] but El-Khattábee says that it is correctly A^al~aY and A^alaA. (TA.) And the Arabs used to say, (S, M,) [and] accord. to a trad. it will be said to the hypocrite [in his grave], on his being asked respecting Mohammad and what he brought, and answering “I know not,” (T in art. tlw,) ↓ laA darayota walaA Ay^talayota, (T, S, M, K,) meaning, accord. to As, (T,) or ISk, (S,) Mayest thou not know, nor be able to know: (T, S: *) or, accord. to Fr, nor fall short, or flag, in seeking to know; that the case may be the more miserable to thee: (T:) or walaA A^alayota, as an imitative sequent [for wlA A^alawota, to which the same explanations are applicable]: (MK:) or laA darayota walaA talayota, the latter verb being assimilated to the former, (ISk, T in art. tlw, S,) said to mean walaA talawota, i. e. nor mayest thou read nor study: (T in art. tlw :) or laA darayota walaA A^atolyota, i. e. [mayest thou not know,] nor mayest thou have camels followed by young ones. (Yoo, ISk, T, S, M, K.) ― -b2- Also, (IAar, T,) inf. n. A^alowN, (IAar, T, K,) He gave him a thing: (IAar, T, K: *) [doubly trans.:] the contr. of a signification before mentioned, (also given by IAar, T and TA,) which is that of “refusing” [a person anything: see, above, laA A=luwka nuSoHFA]. (TA.)

4 A=lY A=lY A=ly , (T, S, M, &c.,) aor. yuw^oliY, inf. n. A_iylaA='N, (T, S, Mgh,) [and in poetry A_ilaA='N, (see a reading of a verse cited voce A^aliy~pN,)] He swore; (T, S, M, Mgh, K;) as also ↓ tA^l~Y, and ↓ Ay^tlY. (T, S, M, K.) You say, A=layotu EalaY Al$~aYo'i and A=layotuhu [I swore to do the thing]. (M.) [And A=layotu laA A^afoEalu ka*aA I swore that I would not do such a thing; and, emphatically, I swear that I will not do such a thing. And A=laY yamiynFA He swore an oath.] It is said in the Kur [xxiv. 22], A^uwluw ↓ walaA yaA^otali A@lofaDoli minokumo, meaning, accord. to A Heyth and Fr, And let not those of you who possess superabundance swear [that they will not give to relations &c.]; for Aboo-Bekr [is particularly alluded to thereby, because he] had sworn that he would not expend upon Mistah and his relations who had made mention of [the scandal respecting] 'Áïsheh: and some of the people of El-Medeeneh read ↓ walaA yataA^al~a, but this disagrees with the written text: A'Obeyd explains it differently: see 1: but the preferable meaning is that here given. (T.) And it is said in a trad., A=lay mino nisaAy^ihi $ahorFA He swore that he would not go in to his wives for a month: the verb being here made trans. by means of mn because it implies the meaning of AimotinaAE, which is thus trans. (TA.) A^alowN * , or A_ilowN: see A_ilFY in art. AlY.

A^uluw * , (so in some copies of the S, and so in the K in the last division of that work, and in the CK in art. Al, [and thus it is always pronounced,] but in some copies of the K in art. Al it is written A^uluwna, [as though to show the original form of its termination,]) or A^uwluw, (so in the M, and in some copies of the S, [and thus it is generally written,]) i. q. *awuw [Possessors of; possessed of; possessing; having]; a pl. which has no sing. (S, M, K) of its own proper letters, (S, K,) its sing. being *uw: (S:) or, as some say, a quasi-pl. n., of which the sing. is *uw: (K:) the fem. is A^ulaAtu, (so in some copies of the S and K, [and thus it is always pronounced,]) or A^uwlaAtu, (so in other copies of the S and K, [and thus it is generally written,]) of which the sing. is *aAtu: (S, K:) it is as though its sing. were A^ulN, (M, K, [in the CK AlN,]) the [final] w [in the masc.] being the sign of the pl., (M,) for it has w [for its termination] in the nom. case, and Y in the accus. and gen. (M, K.) It is never used but as a prefixed noun. (M, K.) The following are exs. of the nom. case: naHonu A^uwluw quw~apK waA^uwluw baA^osK $adiydK [We are possessors of strength, and possessors of vehement courage], in the Kur [xxvii. 23]; and A^uwluw AloA^aroHaAmi baEoDuhumo A^awolaY bibaEoDK [The possessors of relationships, these have the best title to inheritance, one with respect to another], in the same [viii. last verse and xxxiii. 6]; (TA;) and jaA='a niY A^uwluw AlA^alobaAbi [The persons of understandings came to me]; and A^uwlaAtu AlA^aHomaAli [Those who are with child; occurring in the Kur lxv. 4]: (S:) and the following are exs. of the accus. and gen. cases: wa*aroniY waAlomuka*~abiyna A^uwliY Aln~aEomapi [And leave thou me, or let me alone, with the beliers, or discrediters, (i. e., commit their case to me,) the possessors of ease and plenty], in the Kur [lxxiii. 11]; and latanuw'u biAloEuSobapi A^uwliY Alquw~api [Would weigh down the company of men possessing strength], in the same [xxviii. 76]. (TA.) waA^uwliY AloA^amori minokumo, in the Kur [iv. 62], [And those, of you, who are possessors of command], (M, K, *) accord. to Aboo-Is-hák, (M,)
means the companions of the Prophet, and the men of knowledge their followers, (M, K,) and the possessors of command, who are their followers, when also possessors of knowledge and religion: (K:) or, as some say, [simply] the possessors of command; for when these are possessors of knowledge and religion, and take, or adopt and maintain, and follow, what the men of knowledge say, to obey them is of divine obligation: and in general those who are termed A^uwluw AlA^amori, of the Muslims, are those who superintend the affairs of such with respect to religion, and everything conducing to the right disposal of their affairs. (M.)

A_ilaY A^ly A_lY A_ly AlY Aly wly |l |lY |ly , accord. to Sb, is originally with w in the place of the [Y, i. e. the final] alif; and so is EalaY; for the alifs [in these two particles] are not susceptible of imáleh; [i. e., they may not be pronounced ilè and 'alè;] and if either be used as the proper name of a man, the dual [of the former] is A_ilawaAni and [that of the latter] EalawaAni; but when a pronoun is affixed to it, the alif is changed into yé, so that you say A_ilayoka and Ealayoka; though some of the Arabs leave it as it was, saying A_ilaAka and EalaAka. (S.) It is a prep., or particle governing a noun in the gen. case, (S, Mughnee, K,) and denotes the end, as opposed to [mino, which denotes] the beginning, of an extent, or of the space between two points or limits; (S, M;) or the end of an extent (T, Mughnee, K) of place; [signifying To, or as far as;] as in the phrase [in the Kur xvii. 1], mina Almasojidi AlHaraAmi A_ilaY Almasojidi AlA^aqoSaY [From the Sacred Mosque to, or as far as, the Furthest Mosque; meaning from the mosque of Mekkeh to that of Jerusalem]; (Mughnee, K;) or in the saying, xarajotu mina Alkuwfapi A_ilaY mak~apa [I went forth from El-Koofeh to Mekkeh], which may mean that you entered it, [namely, the latter place,] or that you reached it without entering it, for the end includes the beginning of the limit and the furthest part thereof, but does not extend beyond it. (S.) [In some respects it agrees with Hat~aY, q. v. And sometimes it signifies Towards; as in naZara A_ilaY~a He looked towards me; and maAla A_ilayohi He, or it, inclined towards him, or it. ― -b2- It also denotes the end of a space of time; [signifying To, till, or until;] as in the saying [in the Kur ii. 183], vum~a A^atim~uwA AlS~iyaAma A_ilaY All~ayoli [Then complets ye the fasting to, or till, or until, the night]. (Mughnee, K.) [Hence, A_ilaY A^ano (followed by a mansoob aor.) Till, or until: and A_ilaY mataY Till, or until, what time, or when? i. e. how long? and also to, till, or until, the time when. See also the last sentence in this paragraph.] ― -b3- [In like manner it is used in the phrases A_ilaY gayori *lika, and A_ilaY A=xirihi, meaning, (And so on,) to other things, and to the end thereof; equivalent to et cœtera.] ― -b4- Sometimes, (S,) it occurs in the sense of maEa, (T, S, M, Mughnee, K,) when a thing is joined to another thing; (Mughnee, K;) as in the phrase [in the Kur iii. 45 and lxi. 14], mano A^anoSaAriY A_ilaY All~`hi [Who will be my aiders with, or in addition to, God?], (S, Mughnee, K,) accord. to the Koofees and some of the Basrees; (Mughnee;) i. e. who will be joined to God in aiding me? (M, TA;) and as in the saying [in the Kur iv. 2], walaA taA^okuluwA A^amowaAlahumo A_ilaY A^amowaAlikumo [And devour not ye their possessions with, or in addition to, your possessions]; (T, S;) and [in the same, ii. 13,] waA_i*aA xalawoA A_ilaY $ayaA Tiynihimo [And when they are alone with their devils]; (S;) and in the saying, Al*~awodu A_ilaY Al*~awodi A_ibilN [A few she-camels with, or added to, a few she-camels are a herd of camels], (S, Mughnee, K,) a prov., meaning (assumed tropical:) a little with a little makes much; (S and A in art. *wd, q. v.;) though one may not say, A_ilaY zayodK maAlN meaning maEa zayodK maAlN: (Mughnee:) so too in the saying, fulaAnN HaliymN A_ilaY A^adabK wafiqohK [Such a one is clement, or forbearing, with good education, or polite accomplishments, and intelligence, or knowledge of the law]; (M, TA;) and so, accord. to Kh, in the phrase, A^aHomadu All~`ha A_ilayoka [I praise God with thee: but see another rendering of this phrase below]. (ISh.) In the saying in the Kur [v. 8], faAgosiluwA wujuwhakumo waA^ayodiyakumo A_ilaY AlmaraAfiqi, it is disputed whether [the meaning be Then wash ye your faces, and your arms with the elbows, or, and your arms as far as the elbows; i. e., whether] the elbows be meant to be included among the parts to be washed, or excluded therefrom. (T.) A context sometimes shows that what follows it is included in what precedes it; as in qaraA^otu AlquroA=na mino A^aw~alihi A_ilaY A=xirihi [I read, or recited, the Kurán, from the beginning thereof to the end thereof]: or that it is excluded; as in vum~a A^atim~uwA AlS~iyaAma A_ilaY All~ayoli [explained above]: when this is not the case, some say that it is included if it be of the same kind [as that which precedes]; some, that it is included absolutely; and some, that it is excluded absolutely; and this is the right assertion; for with the context it is in most instances excluded. (Mughnee.) ― -b5- It is also used to show the grammatical agency of the noun governed by it, after a verb of wonder; or after a noun of excess importing love or hatred; [as in maA A^aHab~ahu A_ilaY~a How lovely, or pleasing, is he to me! (TA in art. Hb,) and maA A^abogaDahu A_ilaY~a How hateful, or odious, is he to me! (S in art. bgD;) and] as in the saying [in the Kur xii. 33], rab~i Als~ijonu A^aHab~u A_ilaY~a [O my Lord, the prison is more pleasing to me]. (Mughnee, K.) [This usage is similar to that explained in the next sentence.] ― -b6- It is syn. with Einoda; (S, M, Mughnee, Msb, K;) as in the phrase, huwa A^a$ohaY A_ilaY~a mino ka*aA [It is more desirable, or pleasant, in my estimation than such a thing]; (Msb;) and in the saying of the poet,
A^amo laA sabiyla A_ilaY Al$~abaAbi wa*ikoruhu
A^a$ohaY A_ilaY~a mina Alr~aHiyqi Als~alosali
[Is there no way of return to youth, seeing that the remembrance thereof is more pleasant to me, or in my estimation, than mellow wine?] (Mughnee, K:) and accord. to this usage of A_ilaY in the sense of Einoda may be explained the saying, A^anoti TaAliqN A_ilaY sanapK, meaning Thou art divorced at the commencement of a year. (Msb.) ― -b7- It is also syn. with li; as in the phrase, waAlA^amoru A_ilayoka [And command, or to command, belongeth unto Thee, meaning God, as in the Kur xiii. 30, and xxx. 3], (Mughnee, K,) in a trad. respecting supplication: (TA:) or, as some say, it is here used in the manner first explained above, meaning, is ultimately referrible to Thee: and they say, A^aHomadu All~`ha A_ilayoka, meaning, I tell the praise of God unto thee: (Mughnee:) [but see another rendering of this last phrase above:] you say also, *aAka A_ilayoka That is committed to thee, or to thy arbitration. (Har p. 329.) ― -b8- It also occurs as syn. with EalaY; as in the saying in the Kur [xvii. 4], waqaDayonaA A_ilaY baniY A_isoraAy^iyla [And we decreed against the children of Israel]: (Msb:) or this means and we revealed to the children of Israel (Bd, Jel) decisively. (Bd.) ― -b9- It is also syn. with fiY; (M, Mughnee, K;) as in the saying [in the Kur iv. 89 and vi.12], layajomaEan~akumo A_ilaY yawomi AlqiyaAmapi [He will assuredly collect you together on the day of resurrection]: (K:) thus it may be used in this instance accord. to Ibn-Málik: (Mughnee:) and it is said to be so used in the saying [of En-Nábighah, (M, TA,)]
falaA tatorukan~iY biAlwaEiydi kaA^an~aniY
A_ilay Aln~aAsi maToliY~N bihi AlqaAru A^ajorabu
[Then do not thou leave me with threatening, as though I were, among men, smeared with tar, being like a mangy camel]; (M, Mughnee;) or, accord. to some, there is an ellipsis and inversion in this verse; AlY being here in dependence upon a word suppressed, and the meaning being, smeared with pitch, [like a camel,] yet being united to men: or, accord. to Ibn-'Osfoor, mTlY~ is here considered as made to import the meaning of rendered hateful, or odious; for he says that if AlY were correctly used in the sense of fY, it it would be allowable to say, zayodNA_ilaY Alkuwfapi: (Mughnee:) [or the meaning may be, as though I were, compared to men, a mangy camel, smeared with pitch: for] I'Ab said, after mentioning 'Alee, EilomiY A_ilaY Eilomihi kaAlqaraArapi fiY AlmuvuEanojari, meaning My knowledge compared to his knowledge is like the qrArp [or small pool of water left by a torrent] placed by the side of the middle of the sea [or the main deep]. (K in art. vEjr.) It is also [said to be] used in the sense of fY in the saying in the Kur [1xxix. 18], halo laka A_ilaY A^ano tazak~aY [Wilt thou purify thyself from infidelity?] because it imports the meaning of invitation. (TA.) ― -b10- It is also used [in a manner contr. to its primitive application, i. e.,] to denote beginning, [or origination,] being syn. with mino; as in the saying [of a poet],
taquwlu waqado EaAlayotu biAlkuwri fawoqahaA
A^ayusoqay falaA yarowaY A_ilaY~a Abonu A^aHomaraA
[She says, (namely my camel,) when I have raised the saddle upon her, Will Ibn-Ahmar be supplied with drink and not satisfy his thirst from me? i. e., will he never be satisfied with drawing forth my sweat?]. (Mughnee, K.) ― -b11- It is also used as a corroborative, and is thus [syntactically] redundant; as in the saying in the Kur [xiv. 40], faAjoEalo A^afoy^idapF mina Aln~aAsi tahowaY A_ilayohimo, with fet-h to the w [in thwY], (Mughnee, K,) accord.
to one reading, (Mughnee,) meaning tahowaAhumo [i. e. And make Thou hearts of men to love them]: (K:) so says Fr: but some explain it by saying that thwY imports the meaning of tamiylu; or that it is originally tahowiY, with kesr, the kesreh being changed to a fet-hah, and the yé to an alif, as when one says raDaA for raDiYa, and naASaApN for naASiyapN: so says Ibn-Málik; but this requires consideration; for it is a condition in such cases that the Y in the original form must be movent. (Mughnee.) [See art. hwY.] ― -b12- Aall~`hum~a A_ilayoka, occurring in a trad., [is elliptical, and] means O God, I complain unto Thee: or take Thou me unto Thee. (TA.) ― -b13- And A^anaA minoka waA_ilayoka means I am of thee, and related to thee. (TA.) ― -b14- You say also, Ai*ohabo A_ilayoka, meaning Betake, or apply, thyself to, or occupy thyself with, thine own affairs. (T, K. *) And similar to this is the phrase used by El-Aashà, faA*ohabiY maA A_ilayoki. (TA.) And A_ilayokumo [alone is used in a similar manner, elliptically, or as an imperative verbal noun, and] means Betake, or apply, yourselves to, or occupy yourselves with, your own affairs, (Ai*ohabuwA A_ilayokumo,) and retire ye, or withdraw ye, to a distance, or far away, from us. (ISk.) And A_ilayoka Ean~iY means Hold, or refrain, thou from me: (T, K:) or remove, withdraw, or retire, thou to a distance from me: Alyk used in this sense is an imperative verbal noun. (Har p. 508.) Sb says, (M,) or Akh, (Har ubi suprà,) I heard an Arab of the desert, on its being said to him A_ilayoka, reply, A_ilaY~a; as though it were said to him Remove, withdraw, or retire, thou to a distance, and he replied, I will remove, &c. (M.) Aboo-Fir' own says, satirizing a Nabathæan woman of whom he asked for water to drink,
A_i*aA Talabota AlmaA='i qaAlato layokaA
[When thou shalt demand water, she will say, Retire thou to a distance]; meaning, [by lykA, i. e. layoka with an adjunct alif for the sake of the rhyme,] A_ilayoka, in the sense last explained above. (M.) ― -b15- One also says, A_ilayoka ka*aA, meaning, Take thou such a thing. (T, K.) ― -b16- When A_ilaY is immediately followed by the interrogative maA, both together are written A_ilaAma [meaning, To what? whither? and till, or until, what time, or when? i. e. how long?]; and in like manner one writes EalaAma for EalaY maA, (S * and K voce mA,) and Hat~aAma for Hat~aY. (S voce Hat~aY.)
A^alowapN * and A^ulowapN and A_ilowapN: see A^aliy~apN.
A^alY~u * One who swears much; who utters many oaths: (IAar, T, K:) mentioned in the K in art. AlY; but the present is its proper art. (TA.)

A^aliy~apN * [A falling short; or a falling short of what is requisite, or what one ought to do; or a flagging, or remissness; and slowness, or tardiness:] a subst. from A^alaA as signifying qaS~ara and A^aliy~apF. (M.) Hence the prov., (M,) A_il~aA HaDiy~apF falaA A^aliy~apF, i. e. If I be not in favour, and high estimation, I will not cease seeking, and labouring, and wearying myself, to become so: (M, K: *) or if thou fail of good fortune in that which thou seekest, fall not short, or flag not, or be not remiss, in showing love, or affection, to men; may-be thou wilt attain somewhat of that which thou wishest: originally relating to a woman who becomes displeasing to her husband: (S in art. HZw:) it is one of the proverbs of women: one says, if I be not in favour, and high estimation, with my husband, I will not fall short, or flag, or be remiss, in that which may render me so, by betaking myself to that which he loveth: (T and TA in art. HZw:) Meyd says that the two nouns are in the accus. case because the implied meaning is A_il~aA A^akuno HaZiy~apF falaA A^akuno A^aliy~apF; the latter noun being [accord. to him] for ↓ A=liyapN, for which it may be put for the sake of conformity [with the former]; and the former having the signification of the pass. part. n. of A^aHoZaY, or that of the part. n. of HaZiYa [or HaZiyato]. (Har p. 78.) -A2- An oath; (T, S, M, Mgh, K;) as also ↓ A^aliy~aA (M, K) and ↓ A^alowapN (T, S, M, K) and ↓ A^ulowapF and ↓ A_iliywapN: (S, M, K: [in the CK, wAlAuluw~apu muval~avapF is erroneously put for wAliA^alowapu mvl~vpF:]) it is [originally A^aliywapN,] of the measure faEiylapN: (S:) pl. A^alaAyaA. (S, Mgh.) A poet says, (namely, Kutheiyir, TA,)
qaliyluA AlA^alaAyaA HaAfiZN liyamiynihi
waA_ino sabaqato minohu AlA^aliy~apu bar~ati
[A person of few oaths, who keeps his oath from being uttered on ordinary or mean occasions; but if the oath has proceeded from him at any former time, or hastily, it proves true]: (S, TA:) or, as IKh relates it, qaliylu AlA_ilaA='i; meaning, he says, qaliylu AlA_ylaA='i; the Y being suppressed: see 4. (TA.)
A^aliy~aA * : see the latter part of the paragraph next preceding.

A=lK A=l
Falling short; or falling short of what is requisite, or what one ought to do; or flagging, or remiss: [and slow, or tardy: &c.: see 1:] fem. with p: and pl. of this latter A^awaAlK. (S, TA.) See A^aliy~apN, used, accord. to Meyd, for A=liyap. ― -b2- Niggardly, penurious, or avaricious; impotent to fulfil duties or obligations, or to pay debts. (Har p. 78.)

miy^olaApN * The piece of rag which a woman holds in wailing, (S, TA,) and with which she makes signs: (TA:) [it is generally dyed blue, the colour of mourning; and the woman sometimes holds it over her shoulders, and sometimes twirls it with both hands over her head, or before her face:] pl. maA=lK: (S, TA:) which also signifies rags used for the menses. (TA in art. gbr.)

mutaA^al~ * [part. n. of 5]. It is said in a trad., wayolN lilomutaA^al~iyna mino A^um~atiY, explained as meaning Woe to those of my people who pronounce sentence against God, saying, Such a one is in Paradise, and such a one is in the fire [of Hell]: but see the verb. (TA.)
1 A^aliYa * , (S, K,) aor. yaA^olaY, inf. n. A^alFY, (S,) He (a man, S) was, or became, large in the A^uloyap, q. v. (S, K. *) -A2- A^alayota: see 1 in art. Alw.
A^aloYN * : see A_ilFY: -A2- and see also A^alayaAnN.
A^alFY * : see A_ilFY: -A2- and see also A^alayaAnN.
A^uloY~N * : see A_ilFY.

A^ulaY * , (so in some copies of the S and in the M,) accord. to Sb, or A^ulaA, (so likewise in the M, in which it is mentioned in art. AlY, [and thus it is always pronounced,]) or A^uwlaY; (so in several copies of the S and in the K, in the last division of each of those works, [and thus it is generally written;]) and with the lengthened A, [and this is the more common form of the word, i. e. ↓ A^ulaA='i, as it is always pronounced, or A^uwlaA='i, as it is generally written, both of which modes of writing it I find in the M.,] (S, M, K,) of the same measure as guraAb, (M,) indecl., with a kesreh for its termination; (S;) [These and those,] a pl. having no proper sing., (S, K,) or a noun denoting a pl., (M,) or its sing. is *aA for the masc. and *iho for the fem., (S, K,) for it is both masc. and fem., (S,) and is applied to rational beings and to irrational things. (M.) [Thus,] humo A^uwlaA='i EalaY A^avariY, in the Kur xx. 86, means [They are these, following near after me; or] they are near me, coming near after me. (Jel, and Bd says the like.) And in the same, iii. 115, haAA^anotumo A^uwlaA='i tuHib~uwnahumo walaA yuHib~uwnakumo Now ye, O ye these believers, love them, and they love not you. (Jel.) ― -b2- The particle (M) haA (S, K) used as an inceptive to give notice of what is about to be said is prefixed to it, [i. e., to the form with the lengthened A,] (S, M, K,) so that you say, ↓ hw^ulaA='i [meaning These, like as h*aA means “this”]. (S, K.) And AZ says that some of the Arabs say, hw^alaA='i qawomuka [These are thy people], (S, M, *) and ↓ raA^ayotu hw^ulaA='K [I saw these], (M,) with tenween and kesr (S, M) to the hemzeh; (S;) and this, says IJ, is of the dial. of Benoo-'Okeyl. (M.) ― -b3- And the k of allocution is added to it, so that you say, A^uwly^ika, [or A=uwlaA=y^ika, which is the same, and A^uwly^ikumo, or A^uwlaA=y^ikumo, &c.,] and A^uwlaAka, (S, K,) and A^uwlaAlika, (so in some copies of the S and in the K,) or A^ulaAlika, (so in some copies of the S and in the M,) in which the [second] l is augmentative, (M,) and ↓ A^ul~aAka, with teshdeed, (K,) [all meaning Those, like as *aAka and *lika mean “that” and hence] Ks says that when one says A^uwlaA=y^ka, the sing. is *lika; and when one says A^uwlaAka, the sing. is *aAka; (S;) or A^ulaAlika [or A^uwlaAlika, each with an augmentative l, like *lika, (and this, I doubt not, is the correct statement,)] is as though it were pl. of *lika: (M:) but one does not say haAw^ulaAlika, or hA^uwlaAlika, (M,) [nor haw^ulaAy^ika, or the like.] [Thus it is said in the Kur ii. 4, A^uwlaA=y^ika Eala hudFY mino rab~ihimo waA^uwlaA=y^ika humu AlmufoliHuwna Those follow a right direction from their Lord, and those are they who shall prosper.] And sometimes A^uwlaA=y^ika is applied to irrational
things, as in the phrase baEod A^uwlaA=y^ika AlA^ay~aAmi [After those days]; and in the Kur [xvii. 38], where it is said, A_in~a Als~amoEa waAlobaSara waAlofuw^aAda kul~u A^uwlaA=y^ika kaAna Eanohu masow^uwlFA [Verily the ears and the eyes and the heart, all of those shall be inquired of]. (S.) ― -b4- The dims. are ↓ A_ulay~aA and ↓ A^ulay~aA='i (S, M) and ↓ hw^ulay~aA='i: (M:) for the formation of the dim. of a noun of vague application does not alter its commencement, but leaves it in its original state, with fet-h or damm, [as the case may be,] and the Y which is the characteristic of the dim. is inserted in the second place if the word is one of two letters, [as in the instance of *ay~aA, dim. of *aA,] and in the third place if it is a word of three letters. (S.) -A2- AlA^ulaY, (as in some copies of the S and T,) of the same measure as AlEulaY; (S; [wherefore the author of the TA prefers this mode of writing it, which expresses the manner in which it is always pronounced;]) or AlA^ulaA; (ISd, TA;) or AlA^uwlaY; (so in some copies of the S and T;) is likewise a pl. having no proper sing., [meaning They who, those which, and simply who, and which,] its sing. being Al~a*iY; (S;) or is changed from being a noun of indication so as to have the meaning of Al~a*iyna; as also ↓ AlA^ulaA='i; wherefore they have the lengthened as well as the shortened alif, and that with the lengthened alif is made indecl. by terminating with a kesreh. (ISd.) A poet says,
waA_in~a AlA_uwlaY biAlT~af~i mino A=li haA$imK
taA=sawoA fasan~uwA lilokiraAmi Alt~aA=siyaA
[And they who are in Et-Taff, of the family of Háshim, shared their property, one with another, and so set the example, to the generous, of the sharing of property]. (T, and S in art.

Asw A^sw Asw swY swy |sw |sy , where, in one copy, I find AlA^ulaY in the place of AlA^uwlaY.) And another poet says,
waA_an~a AlA_ulaA='i yaEolamuwnaka minohumu
[And verily they who know thee, of them]: which shows what has been said above, respecting the change of meaning. (ISd.) Ziyád El-Aajam uses the former of the two words without Al, saying,
faA^anotumo A^uwlaY jiy^otumo maEa Albaqoli waAld~abaY
faTaAra wah*aA $axoSukumo gayoru TaAy^iri
[For ye are they who came with the herbs, or leguminous plants, and the young locusts, and they have gone away, while these, yourselves, are not going away]: (T:) he means that their nobility is recent. (Ham p. 678; where, instead of fA^ntm and AwlY, we find waA^anotumu and A^ulaA.) ― -b2- In the phrase AlEarabu AlA^uwlaY, (as in the L, and in some copies of the S and K,) or AlA^ulaY, (as also in the L, and in other copies of the S and K, [and thus it is always pronounced,]) AlAwlY or AlAlY may also signify Al~a*iyna, the verb salafuwA being suppressed after it, because understood; [so that the meaning is, The Arabs who have preceded, or passed away;] so says Ibn-EshShejeree: (L:) or it is formed by transposition from AlA^uwalu, being pl. of A^uwlaY [fem. of A^aw~alu], like as A^uxaru is pl. of A=xa: and it is thus in the phrase, *ahabati AlEarabu AlA^uwlaY or AlA^ulaY [The first Arabs have passed away]. (S, K.) 'Obeyd Ibn-ElAbras uses the phrase, naHonu AlA^ulaY [as meaning We are the first]. (TA.)
A_iloYN A^ly A_lY A_ly AlY Aly wly |l |lY |ly : see A_ilFY.
A_ilaY A^ly A_lY A_ly AlY Aly wly |l |lY |ly : see A_ilFY: -A2- and see also art. Alw.

A^aloyapN * The buttock, or buttocks, rump, or posteriors, syn. EajiyzapN, (K,) or [more properly] EajuzN, (M,) of a man &c., (M,) or of a sheep or goat, (Lth, T, S,) and of a man, (Lth, T,) or of a ewe: (ISk, T:) or the flesh and fat thereon: (M, K:) you should not say ↓ A_iloyapN, (T, S, K,) a form mentioned by the expositors of the Fs, but said to be vulgar and low; (TA;) nor liy~apN, (T, S, K,) with kesr to the l, and with teshdeed to the Y, as in the S, [but in a copy of the S, and in one of the T, written without teshdeed,] a form asserted to be correct by some, but it is rarer and lower than A_iloyapN, though it is the form commonly obtaining with the vulgar: (TA:) the dual. is ↓ A^aloyaAni, (AZ, T, S,) without t; (S;) but A^aloyataAni sometimes occurs: (IB:) A^alaS~u AlA^aloyatayoni is an epithet applied to the Zenjee, (K in art. lS,) meaning having the buttocks cleaving together: (TA in that art.:) the pl. is A^aloyaAtN (T, M, K) and A^alaAyaA; (M, K;) the latter anomalous. (M.) Lh mentions the phrase, A_in~ahu la*uw A^aloyaAtK [Verily he has large buttocks]; as though the term A_aloyapN applied to every part of what is thus called. (M.) ― -b2- Fat, as a subst.: (M:) and a piece of fat. (M, K.) ― -b3- The tail, or fat of the tail, (Pers. dunobahN,) of a sheep. (KL.) [Both of these significations (the “tail,” and “fat of the tail,” of a sheep) are now commonly given to liy~ap, a corruption of A^aloyapN mentioned above: and in the K, voce TunobuwrN, it is said that the Pers. dunobaho bar~aho signifies A^aloyapu AlHamali.] ― -b4- A^aloyapu Als~aAqi The muscle of the shank; syn. HamaApu Als~aAqi [which see, in art. Hmw]. (AAF, M, K.) ― -b5- A^aloyapu AlA_ibohaAmi The portion of flesh that is at the root of the thumb; (S, M;) and which is also called its Dar~ap; (M;) or the part to which corresponds the Dar~ap; (S;) and which is also called A^aloyapu Alkaf~i; the Dar~ap being the portion of flesh in fiY, [app. a mistranscription for mino from]) the little finger to the prominent extremity of the ulna next that finger, at the wrist: (TA:) or the portion of flesh in the Dar~ap of the thumb. (K.) ― -b6- A^aloyapu AlxanoSiri The portion of flesh that is beneath the little finger; [app. what is described above, as called the Dar~ap, extending from that finger to the prominent extremity of the ulna, at the wrist;] also called A^aloyapu Alyadi. (Lth, T.) ― -b7- A^aloyataA Alkaf~i The A^aloyap of the thumb [described above as also called by itself A^aloyapu Alkaf~i] and the Dar~ap of the little finger [respecting which see the next preceding sentence]. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b8- Alqadami A^aloyapu The part of the human foot upon which one treads, which is the portion of flesh beneath [or next to] the little toe. (M.) ― -b9- A^aloyapu AlHaAfiri The hinder part of the solid hoof. (S, M.)
