1 A^am~ahu * , (T, S, M, &c.,) aor
Aamu3a , (T, M, Msb,) inf. n. A^am~N, (T, S, M, Msb,) He tended, repaired, betook himself, or directed his course, to, or towards, him, or it; aimed at, sought, endeavoured after, pursued, or endeavoured to reach or attain or obtain, him, or it; intended it, or purposed it; syn. qaSadahu, (Lth, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and tawax~aAhu, (T,) and taEam~adahu, (Mgh,) and tawaj~aha A_ilayohi; (TA;) as also ↓ A^am~amahu, and ↓ tA^m~mhu, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and ↓ Ay^tm~hu, (M, K,) and ↓ yam~am~hu, (T, M, K,) and ↓ tayam~amahu; (T, M, Mgh, K;) the last two being formed by substitution [of Y for A^]. (M.) Hence, yaAAall~`hu A^um~anaA bixayorK [O God, bring us good]. (JK in art. Alh, and Bd in iii. 25.) And laA^am~a maA huwa, occurring in a trad., meaning He has indeed betaken himself to, or pursued, the right way: or it is used in a pass. sense, as meaning he is in the way which ought to be pursued. (TA.) And rasuwla All~`hi ↓ AnoTalaqotu A^ataA^am~amu, in another trad., I went away, betaking myself to the Apostle of God. (TA.) Hence, also, AlS~aEiyda lilS~alaAhi ↓ tayam~ama [He betook himself to dust, or pure dust, to wipe his face and his hands and arms therewith, for prayer]: (T, * M, * Mgh, TA:) as in the Kur iv. 46 and v. 9: (ISk, M, TA:) whence Al~at~ayam~umu as meaning the wiping the face and the hands and arms with dust; (ISk, T, * M, * Mgh, TA;) i. e. the performing the act termed tawaD~uw^N with dust: formed by substitution [of Y for A=]: (M, K:) originally Alt~aA^am~umu. (K.) ― -b2- See also 8. -A2- A^am~ahu, (S, M, Mgh, &c.,) aor.
Aamu3a , (M, Mgh,) inf. n. A^am~N, (M, Mgh, K,) He broke his head, so as to cleave the skin, (S, Msb,) inflicting a wound such as is termed A=m~ap [q. v.]; (S;) [i. e.] he struck, (M, Mgh, K,) or wounded, (M, K,) the A^um~ [q. v.] of his head, (M, Mgh, K,) with a staff, or stick. (Mgh.) -A3- A^am~ahumo (S, M, K) and A^am~a bihimo, (M, K,) [aor.
Aamu3a ,] inf. n. A_imaAmapN, (S, [but in the M and K it seems to be indicated that this is a simple subst.,]) He preceded them; went before them; took precedence of them; or led them, so as to serve as an example, or object of imitation; syn.

taqad~amahumo A^qdm qdm tqdm tqdmhm ; (M, K;) [and particularly] fiY AlS~alaApi [in prayer]. (S.) And A^am~ahu and bihi A^am~a He prayed as A_imaAm [q. v.] with him. (Msb.) And A^am~a AlS~ufuwfa He became [or acted as] A_imaAm to the people composing the ranks [in a mosque &c.]. (Har p. 680.) You say also, laA yaw^um~u Alr~ajulu Alr~ajula fiY suloTaAnihi [A man shall not take precedence of a man in his authority]; meaning, in his house, and where he has predominance, or superior power, or authority; nor shall he sit upon his cushion; for in doing so he would show him contempt. (Mgh in art. slT.) -A2- A^am~atN, (S, M, K,) [first pers. A^amumotu,] aor.
Aamu3a , (M,) inf. n. A^umuwmapN, (M, K,) She (a woman, S) became a mother; (S, M, K;) [as also A^am~atN having for its first pers. A^amimotu, aor.
Aama3a ; for] you say, maA kunoti A^um~aA walaqado A^amimoti [Thou wast not a mother, and thou hast become a mother], (S, M, K, [in the last faA^amimoti,]) with kesr, (K,) inf. n.

A^umuwmapN * . (S, M, K.) ― -b2- A^amamotuhu I was to him a mother. (A in art. rbD.) IAar, speaking of a woman, said, kaAnato lahaA Eam~apN taw^um~uhaA, meaning [She had, lit. there was to her, a paternal aunt] who was to her like the mother. (M.)

It agreed with it, neither exceeding nor falling short. (M.) ― -b2- [See also the part. n. muw^aAm~N, voce A^amamN; whence it seems that there are other senses in which A=m~a may be used, intransitively.]

5 taA^am~ama * and tayam~ama : see 1, former part, in four places. -A2- tA^m~m bihi: see 8. -A3- tam~amotu I took for myself, or adopted, a mother. (S.) And taA^am~amahaA He took her for himself, or adopted her, as a mother; (S, * M, K;) as also ↓ AstA=m~hA, (M, K,) and taA^am~ahahaA. (M.)

8 Ay^tm~hu * [written with the disjunctive alif Aiytam~ahu]: see 1, first sentence. -A2- Ay^tm~ bihi He followed his example; he imitated him; he did as he did, following his example; or taking him as an example, an exemplar, a pattern, or an object of imitation; (S, Mgh, Msb;) as also ↓ A^am~ahu: (Bd in xvi. 121:) the object of the verb is termed A_imaAmN; (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) applied to a learned man, (Msb,) or a head, chief, or leader, or some other person. (M, K.) He made it an A^um~ap or A_im~ap [i. e. a way, course, or rule, of life or conduct; as explained immediately before in the work whence this is taken]; as also bh ↓ tA^m~m. (M.) You say, Ay^tm~ biAl$~ayo'i and Ay^otamaY bh, by substitution [of Y for m], (M, K,) disapproving of the doubling [of the m]. (M.)
10 A_isotaAoma3a see 5.

A^amo * is a conjunction, (S, M, K,) connected with what precedes it (Msb, Mughnee) so that neither what precedes it nor what follows it is independent, the one of the other. (Mughnee.) It denotes interrogation; (M, K;) or is used in a case of interrogation, (S, Msb,) corresponding to the interrogative A^a, and meaning A^aY~, (S,) or, as Z says, A^aY~u AlA^amorayoni kaAy^inN; [for an explanation of which, see what follows;] (Mughnee;) or, [in other words,] corresponding to the interrogative A^a, whereby, and by A^amo, one seeks, or desires, particularization: (Mughnee:) it is as though it were an interrogative after an interrogative. (Lth, T.) Thus you say, A^azayudN fiY Ald~aAri A^amo EamorNw [Is Zeyd in the house, or 'Amr?]; (S, Mughnee;) i. e. which of them two (A^ay~uhumaA) is in the house? (S;) therefore what follows Am and what precedes it compose one sentence; and it is not used in commanding nor in forbidding; and what follows it must correspond to what precedes it in the quality of noun and of verb; so that you say, A^azayodN qaAy^imN A^amE qaAEidN [Is Zeyd standing, or sitting?] and A^aqaAma zayodN A^amo qaEada [Did Zeyd stand, or sit?]. (Msb.) It is not to be coupled with A^a after it: you may not say, A^aEinodaka zayodN A^amo A^aEinodaka EamorNw. (S.) ― -b2- As connected in like manner with what goes before, it is preceded by A^a denoting equality [by occurring after sawaA='N &c.], and corresponds thereto, as in [the Kur lxiii. 6,] sawaA='u Ealayohimo A^asotagofarota lahumN lamN tasotagufiro lahumN [It will be equal to them whether thou beg forgiveness for them or do not beg forgiveness for them]. (Mughnee.) ― -b3- It is also unconnected with what precedes it, (S, Msb, Mughnee,) implying always digression, (Mughnee,) preceded by an enunciative, or an interrogative, (S, Msb, Mughnee,) other than A^a, (Mughnee,) or by A^a not meant [really] as an interrogative but to denote disapproval, (Mughnee,) and signifies balo, (Lth, Zj, T, S, M, Mughnee, K,) or balo and A^a together, (Msb,) and this is its meaning always accord. to all the Basrees, but the Koofees deny this. (Mughnee.) Thus, using it after an enunciative, you say, A_in~ahaA laA_ibilN A^amo $aA='N [Verily they are camels: nay, or nay but, they are sheep, or goats: or nay, are they sheep, or goats?]: (S Msb, Mughnee:) this being said when one looks at a bodily form, and imagines it to be a number of camels, and says what first occurs to him; then the opinion that it is a number of sheep or goats suggests itself to him, and he turns from the first idea, and says, A^amo $aA='N, meaning balo, because it is a digression from what precedes it; though what follows bl is [properly] a thing known certainly, and what follows Am is opined. (S, TA.) And using it after an interrogative in this case, you say, halo zyodN munoTaliqN A^amo EamorNw [Is Zeyd going away? Nay rather, or, or rather, is 'Amr?]: you digress from the question respecting Zeyd's going away, and make the question to relate to 'Amr; so that Am implies indecisive opinion, and interrogation, and digression. (S.) And thus using it, you say, halo zayodN qaAma A^amo EamorNw [Did Zeyd stand? Nay rather, or or rather, did 'Amr?]. (Msb.) And an ex. of the same is the saying [in the Kur xiii. 17], halo yasotawiY AloA^aEomaY waAlobaSiyru A^amo halo tasotawiY AlZ~ulumaAtu waAln~uwru [Are the blind and the seeing equal? Or rather are darkness and light equal?]. (Mughnee.) And an ex. of it preceded by A^a used to denote disapproval is the saying [in the Kur vii. 194], A^alahumo A^arojulN yamo$uwna bihaA A^amo lahumo A^ayodK yaboTi$uwna bihaA [Have they feet, to walk therewith? Or have they hands to assault therewith?]: for A^a is here equivalent to a negation. (Mughnee.) [It has been shown above that] A^amo is sometimes introduced immediately before halo: (S, K:) but IB says that this is when hl occurs in a phrase next before it; [as in the ex. from the Kur xiii. 17, cited above;] and in this case, the interrogative meaning of Am is annulled; it being introduced only to denote a digression. (TA.) ― -b4- It is also used as a simple interrogative; accord. to the assertion of AO; in
the sense of halo; (Mughnee;) or in the sense of the interrogative A^a; (Lth, T, K) as in the saying, A^amo Einodaka gadaA='i HaADirN, meaning Hast thou a morning-meal ready? a good form of speech used by the Arabs; (Lth, T;) and allowable when preceded by another phrase. (T.) ― -b5- And sometimes it is redundant; (AZ, T, S, Mughnee, K) in the dial. of the people of El-Yemen; (T;) as in the saying,
yaA dahona A^amo maA kaAna ma$oyiY rqaSaA
balo qado takuwnu mi$oyatiY tawaq~uSaA
(T, S, * [in the latter, yA hinodu, and only the former hemistich is given,]) meaning O Dahnà, (the curtailed form dahona being used for dahonaA=',) my walking was not, as now in my age, [a feeble movement like] dancing: but in my youth, my manner of walking used to be a bounding: (T:) this is accord. to the opinion of AZ: but accord. to another opinion, Am is here [virtually] conjoined with a preceding clause which is suppressed; as though the speaker had said, yaA dahona A^akaAna ma$oyiY raqaS~aA A^amo maA kaAna ka*lika. (A 'Hát, TA.) -A2- It is also used (T, Mughnee) in the dial. of the people of El-Yemen, (T,) or of Teiyi and Himyer, (Mughnee,) in the sense of Al, (T,) to render a noun determinate. (Mughnee.) So in the trad., layosa mina Amobir~ AmoSiyAmu fiY Amosafari, (T, Mughnee,) i. e. Alayosa mina Albir~i AlS~iyaAmu fiY Als~afari [Fasting in journeying is not an act of obedience to God]. (T, and M in art. br.) So too in the trad., AaloA=na TaAba AmoDarobu Now fighting has become lawful; as related accord. to the dial. of Himyer, for AlD~arobu. (TA in art. Tyb.) It has been said that this form Am is only used in those cases in which the l of the article does not become incorporated into the first letter of the noun to which it is prefixed; as in the phrase, xu*i Alr~umoHa waArokabi Amofarasa [Take thou the spear, and mount the mare, or horse], related as heard in El-Yemen; but this usage may be peculiar to some of the people of that country; not common to all of them; as appears from what we have cited above. (Mughnee.) -A3- A^ama for A^amaA, before an oath: see art. AmA. -A4- And A^ama All~`hi and A^amu All~`hi &c.: see A^ayomunu All~`hi, in art. ymn.

A^um~N *
A mother (T, S, M, Msb, K, &c.) [of a human being and] of any animal; (IAar, T;) as also ↓A_im~N, (Sb, M, Msb, K) and ↓A_um~apN, (T, M, Msb, K,) and ↓A^um~ahapN, (S, M, Msb, K,) which last is the original form (S, Msb) accord. to some, (Msb,) or the h in this is augmentative (M, Msb) accord. to others: (Msb:) the pl. is A^um~ahaAtN (Lth, T, S, M, Msb, K) and A^um~aAtN; (S, M, Msb, K;) or the former is applied to human beings, and the latter to beasts; (T, S;) or the former to rational beings, and the latter to irrational; (M, K;) or the former is much applied to human beings, and the latter to others, for the sake of distinction; (Msb;) but the reverse is sometimes the case: (IB:) IDrst and others hold the latter to be of weak authority: (TA:) the dim. of A^um~N is ↓ A^umayomapN (T, S, K) accord. to some of the Arabs; but correctly, [accord. to those who hold the original form of A^um~N to be A^um~ahapN,] it is ↓ A^umayomihapN. (Lth, T, TA. [In a copy of the T, I find this latter form of the dim. written Amyhp.]) ― -b2- A^um~a laka denotes dispraise; (S;) being used by the Arabs as meaning Thou hast no free, or ingenuous, mother; because the sons of female slaves are objects of dispraise with the Arabs; and is only said in anger and reviling: (A Heyth, T:) or, as some say, it means thou art one who has been picked up as a foundling, having no Known mother: (TA:) [or] it is also sometimes used in praise; (A 'Obeyd, T, S, K;) and is used as an imprecation without the desire of its being fulfilled upon the person addressed, being said in vehemence of love; [lit. meaning mayest thou have no mother!], like vakilatoka A^um~uka, and laA A^abaA laka, [and qaAtalaka All~`hu,] &c. (Har p. 165.) ― -b3- Some elide the A of A^um~; as in the saying of 'Adee Ibn—Zeyd.
A^ay~uhaA AlEaAy^ibu Einodim~a zayodK
[O thou who art blaming in my presence the mother of Zeyd]; meaning, EinodiY A^um~a zayodK; the Y of EndY being also elided on account of the occurrence of two quiescent letters [after the elision of the A of A^um~]: (Lth, T, S:) and as in the phrase wayolum~ihi, (S,) which means wayolN liA^um~ihi. (S, and K in art. wyl, q. v.) ― -b4- humaA A^um~aAk~ means They two are thy two parents: or thy mother and thy maternal aunt. (K.) [But] fad~aAhu biA^um~ayohi is said to mean [He expressed a wish that he (another) might be ransomed with] his mother and his grandmother. (TA.) ― -b5- One says also, laA tafoEaliY ↓ yaA A^um~ati [O my mother, do not thou such a thing], and [in like manner] yaA A^abati AfoEalo; making the sign of the fem. gender a substitute for the [pronominal] affix Y; and in a case of pause, you say yaA A^um~aho. (S.) ― -b6- And one says, maA A^um~iY waA^um~uhu, and maA $akoliY wa$akoluhu, meaning [What relationship have I to him, or it? or what concern have I with him, or it? or] what is my case and [what is] his or its, case? because of his, or its, remoteness from me: whence, (T,)
wamaA A^um~iY waA^um~u AlwaHo$i lam~aA
tafar~aEa fiY mafaAriqiYa Aloma$iybu
[And what concern have I with the wild animals when hoariness hath spread in the places where my hair parts?]; (T, S;) i. e. maA A^anaAwaTalabu AlwaHo$i baEoda maA kabirotu [i. e. maA A^moriy waTalabu AlwaHo$i: in one copy of the S, waTalaba, i. e. with wa as a prep. denoting concomitance, and therefore governing the accus. case: both readings virtually meaning what concern have I with the pursuing of the wild animals after I have grown old?]: he means, the girls: and the mention of A^um~ in the verse is superfluous. (S.) ― -b7- A^um~N also relates to inanimate things that have growth; as in A^um~u Al$~ajarapi [The mother of the tree]; and A^um~u Aln~axolapi [the mother of the palm-tree]; and A^um~u Almawozipa [the mother of the banana-tree; of which see an ex. in art. mwz]; and the like. (M, TA.) ― -b8- And it signifies also The source, origin, foundation, or basis, (S, M, Msb, K,) of a thing, (S, Msb, [in the former of which, this is the first of the meanings assigned to the word,]) or of anything; (M, K) its stay, support, or efficient cause of subsistence. (M, K.) ― -b9- Anything to which other things are collected together, or adjoined: (IDrd, M, K:) anything to which the other things that are next thereto are collected together, or adjoined: (Lth, T:) the main, or chief, part of a thing; the main body thereof: and that which is a compriser, or comprehender, of [other] things: (Ham p. 44:) the place of collection, comprisal, or comprehension, of a thing; the place of combination thereof. (En-Nadr, T.) ― -b10- And hence, (IDrd, M,) The head, or chief, of a people, or company of men; (IDrd, S, M, K;) because others collect themselves together to him: (IDrd, TA:) so in the phrase A^um~u EiyaAlK [lit. the mother of a household], in a poem of Esh-Shenfarà: (IDrd, M:) or in this instance, it has the signification next following, accord. to Esh-Sháfi'ee. (T.) ― -b11- A man who has the charge of the food and service of a people, or company of men; accord. to EshSháfi'ee: (T:) or their servant. (K.) ― -b12- A man's aged wife. (IAar, T, K.) ― -b13- A place of habitation or abode. (K.) So in the Kur [ci. 6], faA^um~uhu haAwiyapN His place of habitation or abode [shall be] the fire [of Hell]: (Bd, Jel, TA:) or, as some say, the meaning is A^um~u raA^osihi haAwiyapN fiyhaA [his brain shall fall into it, namely, the fire of Hell]. (TA.) ― -b14- The ensign, or standard, which an army follows. (S.) [See A^um~u Alr~umoHi, below.] ― -b15- It is said in a trad., respecting the prophets, A^um~ahaA tuhumo $at~aY, meaning that, though their religion is one, their laws, or ordinances, or statutes, are various, or different: or the meaning is, their times are various, or different. (TA in art. $t.) ― -b16- See also A^um~apN, in two places. ― -b17- A^um~ is also prefixed to nouns significant of many things. (M.) [Most of the compounds thus formed will be found explained in the arts. to which belong the nouns that occupy the second place. The following are among the more common, and are therefore here mentioned, with the meanings assigned to them in lexicons in the present art., and arranged in distinct classes.] ― -b18- A^um~u Alr~ajuli The man's wife; and the person who manages the affairs of his house or tent. (TA.) And A^um~u mavowaY Alr~ajuli The man's wife, to whom he betakes himself for lodging, or abode: (T:) the mistress of the man's place of abode. (S, M.) ― -b19- A^um~u EaAmirK The hyena, or female hyena; as also A^um~u EamorKw; (TA;) and A^um~u AlT~ariyqi. (S, TA. [See also other significations of the first and last below.]) A^um~u HilosK [or A^um~u AlHilosi (as in the S and K in art. Hlas)] The she-ass. (TA.) A^um~u AlbayoDi The female ostrich. (S, K.) ― -b20- A^um~u Alr~aA^usi The brain: (T, M, K:) or the thin skin that is upon it: (IDrd, M, K:) or the bag in which is the brain: (T:) or the skin that comprises the brain; [the meninx, or dura mater and pia mater;] (S, Mgh;) which is called
A^um~u Ald~imaAgi (S, Msb) likewise. (S.) ― -b21- A^um~u Aln~ujuwmi The Milky way; (S, M, K) because it is the place where the stars are collected together [in great multitude]: (M:) or, as some say, the sun; which is the greatest of the stars. (Ham pp. 43 and 44.) Because of the multitude of the stars in the Milky way, one says, maA A^a$obaha majolisaka biA^um~i Aln~ujuwmi (assumed tropical:) [How like is thine assembly to the Milky way!]. (TA.) ― -b22- A^um~u AlquraY [The mother of the towns; the metropolis: particularly] Mekkeh; (T, S, M, K) because asserted to be in the middle of the earth; (M, K;) or because it is the Kibleh of all men, and thither they repair; (M, K; *) or because it is the greatest of towns in dignity: (M, K:) and every city is the A^um~ of the towns around it. (T.) A^um~u Alt~anaAy^ifi The most difficult of deserts or of waterless deserts: (T:) or a desert, or waterless desert, (S, K,) far extending. (S.) A^um~u AlT~ariyqi (T, S, M) and ↓ A^um~apN AlT~ariyqi (M, K) The main part [or track] of the road: (T, S, M, K:) when it is a great road or track, with small roads or tracks around it [or on either side], the greatest is so called. (T. [The former has also another signification, mentioned above.]) A^um~u EaAmirK The cemetery, or place of graves. (T. [This, also, has another signification, mentioned before.]) A^um~u Alr~umoHi The ensign, or standard; (M, K;) also called A^um~u AlHarobi; (TA;) [and simply AlA^um~u, as shown above;] and the piece of cloth which is wound upon the spear. (T, M. *) A^um~u jaAbirK Bread: and also the ear of corn. (T.) A^um~u AlxabaAy^ivi [The mother of evil qualities or dispositions; i. e.] wine. (T.) A^um~u AlkitaAbi [in the Kur iii. 5 and xiii. 39] (S, M, &c.) The original of the book or scripture [i. e. of the Kur-án]: (Zj, M, K:) or the Preserved Tablet, All~awoHu AlmaHofuwZu: (M, Msb, K:) or it signifies, (M, K,) or signifies also, (Msb,) the opening chapter of the Kur-án; the faAtiHap; (M, Msb, K;) because every prayer begins therewith; (M;) as also A^um~u AlquroA=ni: (Msb, K:) or the former, the whole of the Kur-án, (I'Ab, K,) from its beginning to its end: (TA:) and the latter, every plain, or explicit, verse of the Kur-án, of those which relate to laws and statutes and obligatory ordinances. (T, K.) A^um~u Al$~ar~i Every evil upon the face of the earth: and A^um~u Alxayori every good upon the face of the earth. (T.)
A_im~u A^m A_m Am |m : see A^um~N, first sentence.
A^am~apN * : see A=m~apN.

A^um~apN *
A way, course, mode, or manner, of acting, or conduct, or the like; (AZ, S;) as also ↓ A_im~apN: (AZ, S, K:) Fr assigns this meaning to the latter, and that next following to the former: (T:) a way, course, or rule, of life, or conduct; (Fr, T, M, K;) as also ↓ A_im~apN. (M, K.) ― -b2- Religion; as also ↓ A_im~apN: (AZ, S, M, K: [one of the words by which this meaning is expressed in the M and K is $iroEap; for which Golius found in the K srEp:]) one course, which people follow, in religion. (T.) You say, fulaAnN laA A^um~apa lahu Such a one has no religion; no religious persuasion. (S.) And a poet says,
wahalo yasotawiY *uw A^um~apK wakafuwru
[And are one who has religion and one who is an infidel equal?]. (S.) ― -b3- Obedience [app. to God]. (T, M, K.) -A2- The people of a [particular] religion: (Akh, S:) a people to whom an apostle is sent, (M, K,) unbelievers and believers; such being called his A^um~ap: (M:) any people called after a prophet are said to be his A^um~ap: (Lth, T:) the followers of the prophet: pl. A^umamN. (T, Msb.) It is said in the Kur [ii. 209], kaAna Aln~aAsu A^um~apK wAHidapF, meaning Mankind was [a people] of one religion. (Zj, T, TA.) ― -b2- A nation; a people; a race; a tribe, distinct body, or family; (Lth, T, M, K;) of mankind; (Lth, T;) or of any living beings; as also ↓ A^um~N: (M, K:) a collective body [of men or other living beings]; (T, S;) a sing. word with a pl. meaning: (Akh, S:) a kind, genus, or generical class, (T, S, M, K,) by itself, (T,) of any animals, or living beings, (T, S, M, TA,) others than the sons of Adam, (T,) as of dogs, (T, S, M,) and of other beasts, and of birds; (T, M, * TA;) as also ↓ A^um~N; (M, K;) pl. of the former A^umamN; (S, M;) which occurs in a trad. as relating to dogs; (S;) and in the Kur vi. 38, as relating to beasts and birds. (T, M, * TA.) ― -b3- A man's people, community, tribe, kinsfolk, or party; (M, K, TA;) his company. (TA.) ― -b4- A generation of men; or people of one time: pl. A^umamN: as in the saying, qado maDato A^umamN Generations of men have passed away. (T.) ― -b5- The creatures of God. (M, K.) You say, maA raA^ayotu mino A^um~api All~`hi A^aHosana minohu [I have not seen, of the creatures of God, one more beautiful than he]. (M.) -A3- I. q. A_imaAmN; (T, M, K;) accord. to A 'Obeyd, applied in this sense to Abraham, in the Kur xvi. 121. (T.) ― -b2- A righteous man who is an object of imitation. (T.) ― -b3- One who follows the true religion, holding, or doing, what is different from, or contrary to, all other religions: (M, K:) [said to be] thus applied to Abraham, ubi suprà. (M.) ― -b4- One who is known for goodness: (Fr, T:) and so explained by Ibn-Mes'ood as applied to Abraham: (TA:) or, so applied, it has the signification next following: (TA:) a man combining all kinds of good qualities: (T, M, K:) or, as some say, repaired to: or imitated. (Bd:) ― -b5- A learned man: (T, M, K:) one who has no equal: (T:) the learned man of his age, or time, who is singular in his learning: (Msb:) and one who is alone in respect of religion. (T.) -A4- See also A_um~N, first sentence. Hence, yaAA^um~ati which see in the same paragraph. -A5- The stature of a man; tallness, and beauty of stature; or justness of stature; syn. qaAmapN; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) and $aTaATF: (M, TA: [in the K, the signification of na$aATN is assigned to it; but this is evidently a mistake for $aTaATK; for the next three significations before the former of these words in the K are the same as the next three before the latter of them in the M; and the next five after the former word in the K are the same as the next five after the latter in the M, with only this difference, that one of these five is the first of them in the M and the third of them in the K:]) pl. A^umamN. (T, S, M. *) You say, A_in~ahu laHasanu AlA^um~api, i. e. Al$~aTaATi [Verily he is beautiful in justness of stature]. (M.) And El-Aashà says,
HisaAnu Alwujuwhi TiwaAlu AlA^umamo
[Beautiful in respect of the faces,] tall in respect of the statures. (T, S, M. * [In the last, byDu Alwujuwhi.]) ― -b2- The face. (T, M, K.) ― -b3- A^um~apu AlA=wajohi The form of the face: (AZ, T:) or the principal part thereof; (M, K;) the part thereof in which beauty is usually known to lie. (M) You say, A_in~ahu laHasanu A^um~api AlA=wajohi Verily he is beautiful in the form of the face: and A_in~ahu lA=aqabiyHu A^um~api AlA=wajohi verily he is ugly in the form of the face. (AZ, T.) ― -b4- A^um~apu AlT~ariyqi: see A^um~N. -A6- A time; a period of time; a while. (T, S, M, K.) So in the Kur [xii. 45], waAd~akara baEoda A^um~apK [And he remembered, or became reminded, after a time]: (S, M:) or, after a long period of time: but some read ↓ A_im~apK, i. e., after favour had been shown him, in his escape: and some read A^amapK, i. e., forgetting. (Bd.) And so in the same [xi. 11], walay^ino A^x~aronaA Eanohumu AlEa*aAba A_ilA=aY A^um~apK maEoduwdap [And verily, if we kept back from them the punishment] until a short period of time. (S * Bd.)

A_im~apN A^m A^mAh A^mh A^mp Amh Amp mAhw : see A^um~apN, in three places; first and second sentences. ― -b2- I. q. ↓ A_imaAmapN (K) [i. e. The office of A_imaAm, q. v. : or] the acting as, or performing the office of, A_imaAm: (T in explanation of A_im~apN, and M and Msb in explanation of A_imaAmapN:) and the mode, or manner, of performing that office. (T.) ― -b3- I. q. hayoy^apN (Lh, M, K) and $aA^onN (M, K) and HaAlN (M) and HaAlapN (M, K) [all as meaning State, condition, or case: or by the first may be here meant external state or condition; form, or appearance; or state with respect to apparel and the like]. ― -b4- An easy and ample state of life; (T;) easiness, or pleasantness of life; ampleness of the conveniences of life, or of the means of subsistence; ease and enjoyment; plenty; prosperity; welfare. (IAar, M, K. *) You say of an old man when he has strength remaining, fulaAnN biA_im~apK, meaning Such a one is returning to a state of well-being and ease and enjoyment. (TA.) ― -b5- Dominion; mastership; authority. (Fr, T, IKtt.) ― -b6- A blessing, or what God bestows upon one; a benefit, benefaction, favour, or boon; a cause of happiness; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) as being that which men aim at, pursue, or endeavour to obtain, (T.) See A^um~apN, last sentence but one. -A2- Accord. to IKtt, it signifies also i. q. A^amamN [but in what sense is not said]. (TA.)

A^amamN *
Nearness. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- [Near; nigh.] You say, A^axa*otu *lika mino A^amamK I took that from near; from nigh. (S, TA.) And daArukumo A^amamN Your house is near, or nigh. (M, TA.) And huwa A^amamN minoka He, or it, is near to thee: and in like manner you say of two: (M, TA:) and of
a pl. number. (S, M, TA.) And daAriY A^amama daArihi My house is opposite to, facing, or in front of, his house. (S.) ― -b3- Easy: (S, M, K:) near at hand; near to be reached, or laid hold of. (T, TA.) ― -b4- Between near and distant. (ISk, T, S.) ― -b5- Conforming, or conformable, to the just mean: (M, K: *) and ↓ muw^aAm~N, (AA, T, S, M, K,) [in form] like muDaAr~N, (S,) originally muw^aAmimN, (TA,) the same; (T;) of a middle, or middling, kind or sort; neither exceeding, nor falling short of, what is right; (AA, T, S, M;) applied to an affair, or a case, (T, S,) and a thing [of any kind]; (S;) as also ↓ muw^am~N; (TA;) and convenient, or suitable: (M, K:) and A^amamN and ↓ muw^aAm~N both signify an affair, or a case, that is manifest, clear, or plain, (M, K,) not exceeding the due bounds or limits. (M.)

AlA^amaAmu *
The location that is before; (M, Msb, * K;) contr. of AlwaraA='u. (M, K.) It is used [absolutely] as a noun, and adverbially, (M, Msb, * K,) necessarily prefixed to another noun: (Mgh:) and is fem., (Ks, M,) and sometimes mase.: (M, K:) or it is mase., and sometimes fem. as meaning the jihap: or, as Zj says, they differ as to making it masc. and making it fem. (Msb.) You say, kunotu A^amaAmahu I was before him, in respect of place. (S.) In the saying of Mohammad, to Usámeh, AlSlaApu A^amaAmaka, the meaning is The time of prayer [is before thee], or the place thereof; and by the prayer is meant the prayer of sunset. (Mgh.) You also say, A^amaAmaka [i. c. Look before thee; meaning beware thou; or take thou note;] when you caution another, (M, K,) or notify him, of a thing. (M.)

A_imaAmN A^mAm A_mAm AmAm
A person, (S, Mgh,) or learned man, (Msb,) whose example is followed, or who is imitated; (S, Mgh, Msb;) any exemplar, or object of imitation, (T, M, K,) to a people, or company of men, (T,) such as a head, chief, or leader, or some other person, (M, K,) whether they be following the right way or be erring therefrom: (T:) applied alike to a male and to a female: (Mgh, Msb:) applied to a female, it occurs in a phrase in which it is written by some with p: (Mgh:) but this is said to be a mistake: (Msb:) it is correctly without p, because it is a subst., not an epithet: (Mgh, Msb:) or it is allowable with p, because it implies the meaning of an epithet: (Msb:) and ↓ A^um~apN signifies the same: (T, M, K:) the pl. of the former is A^ayim~apo, (T, S, M, K, [but omitted in the CK,]) originally A^aA^omimapN, (T, S,) of the measure A^afEilapN, like A^amovilapN, pl. of mivaAlN, (T,) but as two meems come together, the former is incorporated into the latter, and its vowel is transferred to the hemzeh before it, which hemzeh, being thus pronounced with kesr, is changed into Y; (T, S; *) or it is thus changed because difficult to pronounce; (M;) or, as Akh says, because it is with kesr and is preceded by another hemzeh with fet-h: (S:) but some pronounce it A^ay^im~apN, (Akh, T, S, M, K,) namely, those who hold that two hemzehs may occur together; (Akh, S;) the Koofees reading it thus in the Kur ix. 12; (M;) but this is anomalous: (M, K:) it is mentioned as on the authority of Aboo-Is-hák, and [Az says,] I do not say that it is not allowable, but the former is the preferable: (T:) or the pl. is A^ay^im~apN, originally A^aA^omimapN like A^amovilapN: one of the two meems being incorporated into the other after the transfer of its vowel to the hemzeh [next before it]; some of the readers of the Kur pronouncing the [said] hemzeh with its true sound; some softening it, agreeably with analogy, in the manner termed bayona bayona; and some of the grammarians changing it into Y; but some of them reckon this incorrect, saying that there is no analogical reason for it: (Msb:) and accord. to some, (M,) its pl. is also A_imaAmu, (M, K,) like the sing., (K,) occurring in the Kur xxv. 74; (M;) not of the same category as EadolN (M, K) and riD~aY, (M,) because they sometimes said A_imaAmaAni, but a broken pl.: (M, K: *) or, accord. to A 'Obeyd, it is in this instance a sing. denoting a pl.: (M, S: *) or it is pl. of A=m~N, [which is originally A=mimo,] like as SiHaAbN is pl. of SaAHibN: (M:) the dim. of A^ayim~apN is ↓ A^uwayom~apo; or, as El-Mázinee says, ↓ A^uyayom~apN. (S.) ― -b2- AlA_maAmu also signifies The Prophet: (K:) he is called A_imaAmu [the exemplar, object of imitation, leader, or head, of his nation, or people]; (T;) or A_imaAmu AlA^m~api [the exemplar, &c., of the nation, or people]; (M;) it being incumbent on all to imitate his rule of life or conduct. (T.) ― -b3- The Khaleefeh: (Msb, K:) he is called A_maAmu Alr~aEiy~api [the exemplar, &c., of the people, or subjects]. (M.) The title of AlA_maAmu is still applied to the Kings of El-Yemen: Aboo-Bekr says, you say, fulaAnN A_imaAmu Alqawomi, meaning such a one is the first in authority over the people, or company of men: and A_imaAmu Almasolimiyna means the head, chief, or leader, of the Muslims. (TA.) ― -b4- The person whose example is followed, or who is imitated, [i. e. the leader,] in prayer. (Msb.) ― -b5- [The leading authority, or head, of a persuasion, or sect. The four A^yim~ap or A^ay^im~ap are the heads of the four principal persuasions, or sects, of the Sunnees; namely, the Hanafees, Sháfi'ees, Málikees, and Hambelees. And the Hanafees call the two chief doctors of their persuasion, after Aboo- Haneefeh, namely, Aboo-Yoosuf and Mohammad, AlA_imaAmaAni The two Imáms.] ― -b6- The leader of an army. (M, K.) ― -b7- The guide: (K:) he is called A_imaAmu AlA_ibili [the leader of the travellers]. (M.) ― -b8- The conductor, or driver, of camels (M, K) is called A_imaAmu AlA_ibili, though he be behind them, because he guides them. (M.) ― -b9- The manager, or conductor, and right disposer, orderer, or rectifier, of anything. (M, K. *) ― -b10- The Kur-án (M, K) is called A_imaAmu Almusolimyna [the guide of the Muslims]; (M;) because it is an exemplar. (TA.) [The model-copy, or standard-copy, of the Kur-án, namely the copy of the Khaleefeh 'Othmán, is particularly called AlA_imaAmu.] ― -b11- [The scripture of any people: and, without the article, a book, or written record.] It is said in the Kur [xvii. 73], yawoma nadoEuw kul~a A^unaAsK biA_maAmihimo The day when we shall call every one of mankind with their scripture: or, as some say, with their prophet and their law: or, as some say, with their book in which their deeds are recorded. (T.) It is also said in the Kur [xxxvi. 11], kul~a $ayo'K A^aHoSayonaAhu fiY A_imaAmK mubiynK, meaning, says El-Hasan, [And everything have we recorded] in a perspicuous book, or writing; (S, Jel;) i. e., on the Preserved Tablet. (Bd, Jel.) ― -b12- The lesson of a boy, that is learned each day (T, M, K) in the school: (T:) also called Als~abaqu. (TA.) ― -b13- The model, or pattern, of a semblance, or shape. (M, K.) ― -b14- The builder's wooden instrument [or rule] whereby he makes the building even. (S, K. *) ― -b15- The cord which the builder extends to make even, thereby, the row of stones or bricks of the building; also called Alt~ur~u and AlmiToharu; (T;) the string which is extended upon, or against, a building, and according to which one builds. (M, K. *) ― -b16- A_imaAmN signifies also A road, or way: (S, [but omitted in some copies,] M, K:) or a manifest road, or way. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [xv. 79], wa A_in~ahumaA labiA_maAmK mubiynK (S, M) And they were both, indeed, in a way pursued and manifest: (M:) or in a way which they travelled in their journeys. (Fr.) ― -b17- The direction (taloqaA=') of the Kibleh. (M, K. *) ― -b18- A tract, quarter, or region, of land, or of the earth. (S.) ― -b19- A string [of a bow or lute &c.]; syn. watarN. (Sgh, K.)

A^amiymN *
Beautiful in stature; (K;) applied to a man. (TA.) -A2- I. q. ↓ maA^omuwmN; (S, M, Msb, K;) i. e. one who raves, or is delirious, (yaho*iY, [in two copies of the S yahodiY, but the former appears, from a remark made voce A=m~apN, to be the right reading,]) from [a wound in] what is termed A^um~u raA^osihi [see A^um~N]: (S:) or wounded in what is so termed; (M, K;) having a wound such as is termed A=m~ap, q. v. (Msb.) It is also used, metaphorically, in relation to other parts than that named above; as in the saying,
wa Ha$aAYa mino Har~i AlfiraAqi A^amiymu
(tropical:) [And my bowels are wounded by reason of the burning pain of separation]. (M.) -A3- A stone with which the head is broken: (S, O:) but in the M and K ↓ A^mayomapN, [in a copy of the M, however, I find it without any syll. signs, so that it would seem to be ↓ A^amiymapN,] explained as signifying stones with which heads are broken: (TA:) pl. A^amaAy^imu. (S, TA.)

A^umaAy^imu *
Three hundred camels: (M, K:) so explained by Abu-l-'Alà. (M.) A_imaAmapN: see A_im~apN. A^amiymapN: see A^amiymN ― -b2- Also, (Sgh,) or ↓ A^umayomapN, (K,) A blacksmith's hammer. (Sgh, K.)
A^umayomapN * dim. of A^um~N, q. v. (T, S, K.) -A2- See also A^amiymN: ― -b2- and A^maymapN.

AlA_imiAmiy~apu A^mAmy A_mAmy AlA^mAmyp AlA_mAmyp AlAmAmyh AlAmAmyp
One of the exorbitant sects of the Shee'ah, (TA,) who asserted that 'Alee was expressly appointed by Mohammad to be his successor. (Esh-Shahrastánee p. 122, and KT.)
A^umayomihpN * [dim. of A^um~ahpN] : see A^um~N, first sentence.

A^um~iY~N * (T, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and ↓ A^um~aAnN (K) [the former a rel. n. from A^um~apN, and thus properly meaning Gentile: whence, in a secondary, or tropical, sense,(assumed tropical:) a heathen;] (assumed tropical:) one not having a revealed scripture; (Bd in iii. 19 and 69;) so applied by those having a revealed scripture: (Bd in iii.69:) [and particularly] an Arab: (Jel in iii. 69, and Bd and Jel in lxii. 2:) [or] in the proper language [of the Arabs], of, or belonging to, or relating to, the nation (A^um~ap) of the Arabs, who did not write nor read: and therefore metaphorically applied to (tropical:) any one not knowing the art of writing nor that of reading: (Mgh:) or (assumed tropical:) one who does not write; (T, M, K;) because the art of writing is acquired; as though he were thus called in relation to the condition in which his mother (A^um~ahu) brought him forth: (T:) or (assumed tropical:) one who is in the natural condition of the nation (AlA^um~ap) to which he belongs, (Zj, * T, M, * K, *) in respect of not writing, (T,) or not having learned writing; thus remaining in his natural state: (M, K:) or (assumed tropical:) one who does not write well; said to be a rel. n. from A^m~N; because the art of writing is acquired, and such a person is as his mother brought him forth, in respect of ignorance of that art; or, as some say, from A^um~apu AlEarabi; because most of the Arabs were of this description: (Msb:) the art of writing was known among the Arabs [in the time of Mohammad] by the people of Et-Táïf, who learned it from a man of the people of El-Heereh, and these had it from the people of El-Ambár. (T.) A^um~iy~uwn laA yaEolamuwna, AlkitaAba, in the Kur ii. 73, means Vulgar persons, [or heathen,] who know not the Book of the Law revealed to Moses: (Jel:) or ignorant persons, who know not writing, so that they may read that book; or, who know not the Book of the Law revealed to Moses. (Bd.) Mohammad was termed A^um~iY~ [meaning A Gentile, as distinguished from an Israelite: or, accord. to most of his followers, meaning illiterate;] because the nation (A^um~ap) of the Arabs did not write, nor read writing; and [they say that] God sent him as an apostle when he did not write, nor read from a book; and this natural condition of his was one of his miraculous signs, to which reference is made in the Kur [xxix. 47], where it is said, “thou didst not read, before it, from a book, nor didst thou write it with thy right hand:” (T, TA:) but accord. to the more correct opinion, he was not well acquainted with written characters nor with poetry, but he discriminated between good and bad poetry: or, as some assert, he became acquainted with writing after he had been unacquainted therewith, on account of the expression “ before it ” in the verse of the Kur mentioned above: or, as some say, this may mean that he wrote though ignorant of the art of writing, like as some of the kings, being A^um~iy~uwn, write their signs, or marks: (TA:) or, accord. to Jaafar Es-Sádik, he used to read from the book, or scripture, if he did not write. (Kull p. 73.) [Some judicious observations on this word are comprised in Dr. Sprenger's Life of Mohammad (pp. 101-2); a work which, in the portion already published (Part I.), contains much very valuable information.] ― -b2- Also, (K,) or [only] A^um~iY~N, (AZ, T, M,) applied to a man, (AZ, T,) Impotent in speech, (EayiY~, in the K incorrectly written gabiY~, TA,) of few words, and rude, churlish, uncivil, or surly. (AZ, T, M, K.)

A^um~iy~apN * The quality denoted by the epithet A^um~iY~N: (TA:) [gentilism: (assumed tropical:) heathenism: &c.:] (assumed tropical:) the quality of being [in the natural condition of the nation to which one belongs, or] as brought forth by one's mother, in respect of not having learned the art of writing nor the reading thereof. (Kull p. 73.) A^um~aAnN: see A^um~iY~N; and see also art. Amn A^um~ahadN: see A^um~N.

A=m~N A=m [act. part. n. of 1;] i. q. qaASidN: [see 1, first sentence:] (TA:) pl. A_imaAmN, like as SiHaAb~N is pl. of SaAHibN, (M, K,) accord. to some, but others say that this is pl. of A_imaAmN [q. v.; the sing. and pl. being alike]; (M;) and A=m~uwna. (TA.) Hence, in the Kur [v. 2], walaA A=m~iyna Alobayota AloHaraAma [Nor those repairing to the Sacred House]. (TA.)

A=m~apN A=mh A=mp (S, Msb) and ↓ maA^omuwmapN, as some of the Arabs say, (IB, Msb,) because it implies the meaning of a pass. part. n., originally; (Msb;) but 'Alee Ibn-Hamzeh says that this is a mistake; for the latter word is an epithet applied to the part called A^um~u Ald~imaAgi when it is broken; (IB;) or $aj~apN A=m~apN and ↓ maA^omuwmapN; (M, Mgh, K;) A wound by which the head is broken, (S, M, Msb, K,) reaching to the part called A^um~u Ald~imaAgi, (S, Msb,) or, [which means the same,] A^um~u Alr~aA^osi, (M, K,) so that there remains between it and the brain [only] a thin skin: (S:) it is the most severe of $ijaAj [except that which reaches the brain (see $aj~apN)]: ISk says that the person suffering from it roars, or bellows, (yaSoEaqu,) like thunder, and like the braying of camels, and is unable to go forth into the sun: (Msb:) the mulct for it is one third of the whole price of blood: (TA:) IAar assigns the meaning of [this kind of] $aj~ap to ↓ A^am~apN; which seems, therefore, to be either a dial. var. or a contraction of A=m~apN: (Msb:) the pl. of A=m~apN is A^awaAm~u (Mgh, Msb) and ↓ mA=y^imu; or this latter has no proper sing.: (M, TA:) the pl. of ↓ mA^omuwmapN is maA^omuwmaAtN. (Mgh, Msb.)

A^awam~u * and A^ayam~u Better in the performance of the office termed A_imaAmapN; followed by mino: (Zj, T, M, K:) originally A^aA^am~u: the second hemzeh being changed by some into w and by some into Y. (Zj, T, M.)
A^uyayom~apN * , or A^uyayom~apN, dim. of A^ayim~apN, pl. of A_imaAmN, q. v. (S.) muw^m~N: see A^amamN.

miy^am~N * A camel that leads and guides: (M:) or a guide that shows the right way: and a camel that goes before the other camels: (K:) fem. with p; (M, K;) applied to a she-camel (M, TA) that goes before the other she-camels, and is followed by them. (TA.)

mA^omuwmN * : see A^amiymN. ― -b2- Also A camel having his hump bruised internally by his being much ridden, or having his hump swollen in consequence of the galling of the saddle and the cloth beneath it, and bruised, and having his hump corroded: (S:) or whose fur has gone from his back in consequence of beating, or of galls, or sores, produced by the saddle or the like. (M, K.) ― -b3- mA^omuwmapN: see A=m~apN, in three places. muw^aAm~N: see A^amamN, in two places. mw^otam~N act. part. n. of Ay^otam~a bihi; Following as an example; imitating; taking as an example, an exemplar, a pattern, or an object of imitation. (Msb.) ― -b4- muw^otam~N bihi pass. part. n. of the same; Followed as an example; imitated; &c.: thus distinguished from the former by the preposition with the object of its government. (Msb.)
maA=y^imu * : see A=m~apN.

A^amaA * , used to denote an interrogation, is a compound of the interrogative hemzeh and the negative maA: (M:) it is a mere interrogative [respecting a negative, like A^alaA]; as in the saying, A^amaA tasotaHoyiY mina All~`hi [Art not thou ashamed for thyself, or of thyself, with respect to God?]. (Lth, T.) ― -b2- [IHsh says, after explaining two other usages of A^amaA which we have yet to mention,] El-Málakee adds a third meaning of A^amaA, saying that it is a particle denoting EaroDN [or the asking, or requiring, a thing in a gentle manner], like [A^alaA (q. v.) and] lawolaA; and is connected peculiarly with a verb; as in A^amaA taquwmu [Wherefore wilt not thou do stand?], and A^amaA tafoEalu [Wherefore wilt not thou do such a thing?]; which may be explained by saying that the hemzeh is used as an interrogative to make one confess, or acknowledge, a thing, as it is in A^alamo and A^alaA, and that maA is a negative. (Mughnee.) ― -b3- It is also an inceptive word, used in the manner of A^alaA: (M:) followed by A^alaA, it is syn. with A^alaA: (S:) [meaning Now: or now surely: or] both of these meaning verily, or truly; i. c. Haq~FA: and for this reason Sb allows one's saying, A^amaA A_n~ah munoTalqN and A^amaA A^an~ahu munoTalqN [Verily, or truly, he is going away]; with kesr after the manner of A^alaA A_in~ahu, and with fet-h after the manner of Haq~FA A^an~ahu: and hamaA waAll~`hi laqado kaAna ka*aA is mentioned as meaning A^amaA wa All~`hi [&c., i. e. Verily, or truly, by God, such a thing did indeed happen]; the h being a substitute for the hemzeh: (M:) so too HamaY wAll~`h [or HamaA wAll~`h]: (Sgh and K in art. HmY:) it denotes the truth of the words which follow it; as when you say, A^amaA A_in~a zayodFA EaAqilN, meaning Truly, or properly speaking, not tropically, Zeyd is intelligent; and A^am~aA w All~`h qad Daraba zayodN EamorFA [Truly, &c., by God, Zeyd beat, or struck, Amr]: (S in art. Amw:) [in other words,] it corroborates an oath and a sentence; as in
A^amaA wa All~`h lay^ino soharotu laka layolapF laA^a daEan~aka naAdimFA [Verily, or now surely, by God, if I remain awake for thee a night, then will I indeed leave thee repenting]; and A^amaA law Ealimotu makaAnaka laA^azoEajotuka minohu [Verily, or now surely, if I had known thy place of being, then had I unsettled thee, or removed thee, from it]; and A^amaA A_in~ahu larajulN kariymN [Verily, or now surely, he is (emphatically) a generous man]: (T:) or it is an inceptive particle, used in the manner of A^alaA; [meaning now: or now surely:] (Mughnee:) or a particle used to give notice of what is about to be said: only put before a proposition [as in exs. mentioned above]: (TA:) and often occurring before an oath [as in exs. mentioned above]: and sometimes its hemzeh is changed into h or E, before the oath; each with the A remaining; [written hamaA or EamaA;] and with the A elided; [written hama or Eama;] or with the A elided, but without the substitution; [written A^ama;] and when An~a occurs after A^amaA, it is with kesr, as it is after A^alaA: and it also means Haq~FA [verily, or truly]: or A^aHq~FA [verily? or truly?]: accord. to different opinions: and in this case, An~a after it is with fet-h, as it is after Haq~aA: accord. to Ibn-Kharoof, this is a particle: but some say that it is a noun in the sense of Haq~FA: and others, that it consists of two words, namely, the interrogative hemzeh and maA as a noun in the sense of $aYo'N; i. e. A^a*Alika Al$~aYo'u Haq~N [is that thing ture?]; so that the meaning is A^aHaq~FA: [if so, A^amaA A^an~ah munoTalqN means Verily, or truly, is he going away?] and this, which is what Sb says, is the correct opinion: maA is virtually in the accus. case, as an adverbial noun, like as Haq~FA is literally: and A^an~a with its complement is an inchoative, of which the adverbial noun is the enunciative: but Mbr says that Haq~FA is the inf. n. of yaHiq~u, which is suppressed, and that A^n~a with its complement is an agent. (Mughnee.)

A^am~aA * is a conditional and partitive and corroborative particle; and is sometimes written A^ayomaA, by the change of the first m into Y. (Mughnee, K.) ― -b2- It is used as a conditional particle in the words of the Kur [ii.24], fA^am~aA Al~a*iyna A=manuwA fayaEolamuwna A^an~ahu AloHaq~u mino rab~ihimo waA^am~aA Al~a*iyna kafaruwA fayaquwluwna maA *aA A^araAda All~`hu bih*aA mavalAF [For as for those who have believed, they know that it is the truth from their Lord; but as for those who have disbelieved, they say, What is it that God meaneth by this as a parable?]. (Mughnee,* K,* TA.) That it denotes a condition is shown by the necessary occurrence of f after it; for if this f were a conjunction, it would not be prefixed to the enunciative; and if it were redundant, it might be dispensed with; but it may not be dispensed with except in a case of necessity in poetry or in a case of an ellipsis. ― -b3- In most cases, (Mughnee, K,) it is used as a partitive, (S, Mughnee, K,) implying the meaning of a condition; (S; [in which it is mentioned with A^amaA;]) and thus it is used in the passage of the Kur cited above; (Mughnee;) and in the following exs. [in the Kur xviii. 78 and 79 and 81], A^am~aA Als~afiynapu fakaAnato limasaAkiyna yaEomaluwna fiY AlbaHori and waA^amaA AlogulaAmu fakaAna A^abawaAhu muw^ominiyna and wA^am~aA AlojidaAru fakaAna liglaAmayni yataymayoni [As for the ship, it belonged to poor men who worked on the sea . . . and as for the boy, his two parents were believers . . . and as for the wall, it belonged to two orphan boys]. (Mughnee, * K, * TA.) [It is a partitive also in the phrase A^am~aAbaEodu, which see in art. bEd.] ― -b4- Few have mentioned its use as a corroborative: (Mughnee:) it is thus used in the phrase A^am~aA zayodN fa*aAhibN [Whatever be the case, or happen what will or what may, or at all events, Zeyd is going away], when you mean that Zeyd is inevitably going away, and determined, or decided, upon doing so: (Z cited in the Mughnee, and K:) therefore Sb explains it as meaning, in this case, mahomaA yakuno mino $aYo'K [whatever be the case, &c., as above, or, in some instances, happen what would or what might]; thereby showing it to be a corroborative, and to have a conditional meaning: (Z cited in the Mughnee: [and the same explanation of it is given, with a similar ex., in the S, in art. Amw:]) the fa, in this case, is transferred from its proper place before the inchoative, and put before the enunciative. (I 'AK p. 306.) Ks says that A^am~aA is used in commanding and forbidding and announcing: you say, A^am~aA All~`ha faAEobudo [Whatever be the case, or happen what will, &c., God worship thou]: and A^am~aA Alxamora falaA ta$orabohaA [i. e. A^am~aA Alxamora falaA ta$orabohaA (as is shown in the case of a similar ex. in the Mughnee, though you may say A^am~aA Alxamoru falaA ta$orabohaA, without an ellipsis, like as you say A^m~aA vamuwdu fahadayonaAhumo as well as A^am~aA vamuwda, in the Kur xli. 16, accord. to different readers,) Whatever be the case, &c., wine (drink not), drink not thou it]: and A^am~aA zayodN faxaraja [Whatever be the case, &c., with respect to other things, Zeyd has gone forth; or whatever be the case with respect to others, as for Zeyd, he has gone forth]: whereas A_im~aA [which see in the next paragraph] is used in expressing a condition and in expressing doubt and in giving option and in taking option. (T.) ― -b5- [IHsh says that in his opinion,] in the phrase A^am~aA AlEabiyda fa*uw EabiydK, thus heard, with AlEbyd in the accus. case, the meaning is, mahamA *akarota [&c., i. e. Whenever thou mentionest the slaves, he is a possessor of slaves: but I would rather say that the meaning is, A^am~aA *ikoruka AlEabiyda, &c., i. e. as for thy mentioning the slaves, &c.]: and so in similar phrases which have been heard. (Mughnee.) -A2- Distinct from the foregoing is A^am~aA in the saying in the Kur [xxvii. 86], A^am~aA *Akunotumo taEmaluwna [Or rather, what is it that ye were doing?]: for here it is a compound of the unconnected A^amo and the interrogative maA (Mughnee.) -A3- So too in the saying of the poet,
A^abaA xuraA$apa A^am~aA A^anota *aA nasfarK
faA_n~a quwomiYa lamo taA^kulohumu AlD~abuEu
[O Aboo-Khurásheh, because thou wast possessor of a number of men dost thou boast? Verily, my people, the year of dearth, or of sterility, hath not consumed them]: for here it is a compound of the A^ano termed maSudariy~ap [which combines with a verb following it to form an equivalent to an inf. n.] and the redundant maA: A^am~aA A^anota is for liA^ano kunota; the preposition and the verb are suppressed for the sake of abridgment, so that the pronoun [ta in kunota] becomes separate; and maA is substituted for the verb [thus deprived of its affixed pronoun], and the n [of An] is incorporated into the m [of mA]. (Mughnee.) [See another reading of this verse voce A_im~aA; and there also, immediately after, another ex. (accord. to the Mughnee) of A^am~aA used in the manner explained above. See also A^ano as a conditional particle, like A_ino.] -A4- Also i. q. A_im~aA, q. v. (Mughnee, K.)

A_im~aA A^m A^mA A_mA AmA mA |m |mA is sometimes written A^am~aA, and sometimes its first m is changed into Y, [forming A^ayomaA or A_iyomaA or both, as will be shown below,] (Mughnee, [in my copy of which it is written A^ayomaA, and so in some copies of the K,] and K, [in some copies of which it is written A_ymaA,]) and it is held by Sb to be a compound of A_ino and maA, (Mughnee,) or as denoting the complement of a condition it is a compound of A_ino and maA. (M, K.) ― -b2- It denotes doubt; (Ks, T, Mughnee, K;) as in maA A^adoriY mano qaAma A_im~aA zayodNwA_im~aA EamorNw [I know not who stood: either Zeyd or 'Amr]: (Ks, T:) and jaA='aniY A_im~aA zayodN waA_im~aA EamorNw [There came to me either Zeyd or 'Amr], said when one knows not which of them came. (Mughnee, K.) ― -b3- It also denotes vagueness of meaning; as in [the Kur ix. 107,] A_im~aA yuEa*~ibuhum wA^m~aA yatuwbu Ealayohimo [Either He will punish them or He will turn unto them with forgiveness]. (Mughnee, K.) ― -b4- It also denotes giving option; as in [the Kur xviii. 85,] A_im~aA A^an tuEa*~iba wA_im~aA A^ano tat~axi*a fiyihimo HusonAF [Either do thou punish, or do thou what is good to them]. (Mughnee, K.) ― -b5- It also denotes the making a thing allowable; as in taEal~amo A_im~aA fiqohFA wA_im~aA naHowFA [Learn thou either low or syntax; (an ex. given in the T, on the authority of Ks, as an instance of the usage of A_im~aA to denote giving option;)] but its use with this intent is disputed by some, (Mughnee, K,) while they assert it of A^awo. (Mughnee.) ― -b6- It is also used as a partitive; as in [the Kur lxxvi. 3,] A_m~aA $aAkirAF w A_m~aA kafuwrFA [Either, or whether, being thankful or being unthankful]; (Mughnee, K;) the two epithets being here in the accus. case as denotatives of state: or, accord. to the Koofees, A_m~aA may be here [a compound of] the conditional A_ino and the redundant maA; kaAna, accord. to Ibn-EshShejeree, being understood after it: (Mughnee:) and Fr says that the meaning is, A_ino $akara waA_ino kafara [if he be thankful and if he be unthankful]. (T.) ― -b7- It also denotes taking option; as in the saying, liY daArN biAlkuwfapi faA^naA xaArijN A_layohaA faA_m~aA A^ano A^asokunahaA wA_im~aA A^ano A^abiyEahaA [I have a house in El-Koofeh, and I am going forth to it, and either I will inhabit it or I will sell it: but this is similar to the usage first mentioned above]. (Ks, T.) ― -b8- It is a conjunction, (S in art. Amw, and Mughnee,) accord. to most authorities, i. e., the second A_im~aA in the like of the saying, jaA'aniY A_m~aA zayodN wA_im~aA EamorNw [mentioned
above]; (Mughnee;) used in the manner of A^awo in all its cases except this one, that in the use of Aw you begin with assurance, and then doubt comes upon you; whereas you begin with A_im~aA in doubt, and must repeat it; as in the saying last mentioned: (S: [and the like is said in the Mughnee, after the explanations of the meanings:]) but some assert that it is like the first A_im~aA, not a conjunction; because it is generally preceded by the conjunction w: and some assert that A_im~aA conjoins the noun with the noun, and the w conjoins A_im~aA with A_im~aA; but the conjoining of a particle with a particle is strange. (Mughnee.) ― -b9- Sometimes the w is suppressed; as in the following verse, (Mughnee,) of El-Ahwas; (S;)
yaA layotamaA A^um~uniA $aAlato naEaAmatuhaA
A^ayomaA A_ilaY jan~apK A^ayomaA A_ilaY naAri
[O, would that our mother took her departure, either to Paradise or Hell-fire!]; (S,* Mughnee, K;) cited by Ks, with AymA for A_im~aA: (T:) and sometimes it is with kesr [i. e. A_iymaA]: (S:) IB says that it is correctly A_im~aA, with kesr; asserting the original to be A_im~aA, with kesr, only. (TA.) ― -b10- And sometimes the former maA is dispensed with; as in the following verse, (Mughnee,) which shows also that maA is sometimes suppressed;
saqatohu Ar~awaAEidu mino Say~ifK
waA_ino mino xariyfK falano yaEodamaA
[The thundering clouds of summer-rain watered him, or of autumn-rain; so he will not want sufficient drink]: i. e. A_im~aA mino Say~ifK waA_im~aA mino xariyfK. (Mughnee, K.) Mbr and As say that A_ino is here conditional, and that the f is its complement: but this assertion is of no weight; for the object is the description of a mountain-goat as having sufficient drink in every case: AO says that A_ino in this verse is redundant. (Mughnee.) ― -b11- Sometimes, also, one does not require to mention the second A_im~aA, by mentioning what supplies its place; as in the saying, A_im~aA A^ano tatakal~ama bixayorK waA_il~aA fAsokuto [Either do thou speak what is good or else be silent]. (Mughnee.) [See art. AlA, near its end.] -A2- Distinct from the foregoing is A_im~aA in the saying in the Kur [xix. 26], faA_im~aA^itaryin~a mina Aloba$ari A^aHadFAi [And if thou see, of mankind, any one]: for this is [a compound of] the conditional A_in and the redundant maA. (S * in art. Amw, and Mughnee.) [In like manner,] you say, in expressing a condition, A_im~aA ta$otiman~a zoydFA faA_in~ahu yaHolumu Eanoka [If thou revile Zeyd, he will treat thee with forbearance]. (Ks, T.) And A_im~aA taA^otiniy A^ukoirimoka [If thou come to me, I will treat thee with honour]. (S.) ― -b2- In the following saying, A_im~aA A^anota munoTaliqFA AnoTalaqotu [If thou be going away, I go away], the maA is not that which restrains the particle to which it is subjoined from governing, but is a substitute for a verb; (K and TA in art. maA;) as though the speaker said, A_i*aA Sirota munoTaliqFA [or rather A_ino Sirota]. (TA in that art.) And hence the saying of the poet, [of which a reading different from that here following has been given voce A^am~aA,]
A^abaA xuraA$apa A_im~aA A^anota *aA nasfarK
faA_n~a qawomiYa lamo taA_okulohumu AlD~abugu
[O Aboo-Khurásheh, if thou be possessor of a number of men, verily, my people, the year of dearth, or of sterility, hath not consumed them]; as though he said, A_ino kunotu *aA nafarK. (TA in that art.) [But IHsh states the case differently; saying,] An instance of A^am~aA A^anota munTaliqFA AnoTalaqotu not used to restrain from governing, but as a substitute for a verb, occurs in the saying, A^am~aA A^anota munTaliqFA AinoTalaqotu [Because thou wast going away, I went away]; originally, AinoTalaqotu liA^ano kunota munTaliqAF: [for an explanation of which, see what is said of A^am~aA A^anota in a reading of the verse commencing with A^abaA xuraA$ap voce A^am~aA:] but accord. to El-Fárisee and IJ, the government belongs to maA; not to kaAna [or kunota]. (Mughnee in art. maA.) ― -b3- So too in the saying, AifoEalo h*aA A_im~aAlaA, meaning A_ino kunota laAtafoEalu gayorahu [i. e. Do thou this if thou wilt not do another thing; or do thou this at least]; (Mughnee and K, each in art. maA;) indicating a person's refusal to do [fully] that which he is ordered to do: (TA in that art.:) or A_im~aAlaA faAfoEalo ka*aA, meaning if thou wilt not do that, then do thou this; the three particles [A_ino and maA and laA] being made as one word: so says Lth: (T:) [J says,] A_im~aAlaA faAfoEalo ka*aA is pronounced with imáleh, [i. e. “ immá-lè, ”] and is originally A_in laA with maA as a connective; and the meaning is, if that thing will not be, then do thou thus: (S in art. laA:) [but] AHát [disallows this pronunciation, and] says, sometimes the vulgar, in the place of AifoEalo *`lika A_im~aAlaA, say, AifoEalo *`lika baAriY [Do thou that at least]; but this is Persian, and is rejected as wrong: and they say also, A^um~aAlaYo, with damm to the A [and with imáleh in the case of the final vowel, and thus it is vulgarly pronounced in the present day]; but this too is wrong; for it is correctly A_im~aAlaA, [with kesr, and] not pronounced with imáleh, for particles [in general] are not thus pronounced: (T:) and the vulgar also convert the hemzeh into h with damm [saying hum~aAlaYo]. (TA in art. maA.) [Fei says,] laA is a substitute for the verb in the saying, A_im~aAlaA faAfoEalo h`*aA, the meaning being If thou do not that, then [at least] do thou this: the origin thereof is this; that certain things are incumbent on a man to do, and he is required to do them, but refuses; and then one is content with his doing some, or a part, of them, and says to him thus: i. e., if thou wilt not do all, then do thou this: then the verb is suppressed, on account of the frequency of the usage of the phrase, and maA is added to give force to the meaning: and some say that it is for this reason that laA is here pronounced with imáleh; because it serves for the verb; like as balaY is, and the vocative yaA: but it is said that it is correctly pronounced without imáleh; because particles [in general] are not pronounced therewith; as Az says. (Msb in art. laA.) [El-Hareeree says that] A_im~aAlaA is properly [a compound of] three particles, which are A_ino and maA and laA, made as one word, and the A at the end thereof is like the A of HubaAraY [in which it is written Y, agreeably with rule]; wherefore it is pronounced with imáleh, like as is the A of this latter word. (Durrat el-Ghowwás, in De Sacy's Anthol. Gr. Ar. p. 57 of the Arabic text.) In the Lubáb it is said that laA is used as a negative of the future, as in lA tafoEalo; and the verb [in A_im~aAlaA] is suppressed; so it [lA] serves as a substitute in the saying, AifoEalo h`*aA A_im~aAlaA; therefore they pronounce its A with imáleh: and IAth says that the Arabs sometimes pronounced laA with a slight imáleh; and the vulgar make the imáleh thereof full, so that its A becomes Y; but this is wrong. (TA.) You say also, xu*o h`*aA A_im~aAlaA, meaning Take thou this if thou take not that. (T.) It is related that the Prophet saw a runaway camel, and said, “ To whom belongeth this camel? ” when, lo, some young men of the Ansár said, “ We have drawn water upon him during twenty years, and yet he has in him fat; so we desired to slaughter him; but he escaped from us. ” He said, “ Will ye sell him? ” They answered, “ No: but he is thine. ” And he said, A_im~aAlaA fA^aHosinuwA A_ilayohi Hat~aY yA^otiyahu A^ajaluhu, meaning If ye will not sell him, act well to him until his term of life come to him. (T.)

1 A^amatahu * , (T, S, M, K,) aor.
Aamita , (T, M, K,) inf. N. A^amotN, (T, S, M,) He measured it; determined its measure, quantity, or the like; computed, or conjectured, its measure, quantity, &c.; (T, S, * M, K;) as also ↓ Am~thu, (M, K,) inf. n. taA^omiytN. (TA.) You say, Aiymito yaA fulaAnu h`*aA liY kamo huwa Compute thou, O such a one, this, for me, how many it is. (T.) And A^amata Alqawoma He computer, or conjectured, the number of the people, or company of men. (T.) And A^amata AlmaA='a He measured, or computed, the distance between him and the water. (T.) ― -b2- Also, (S, K,) aor. as above, (K,) and so the inf. n., (S,) i. q. qaSadahu [He tended, repaired, betook himself, or directed his course, to it, or towards it; aimed at it; sought after it; or intended, or purposed, it]; (S, K;) namely, a thing. (S.)
2 A^m~thu * : see 1. ― -b2- A^um~ita bil$~ar~i He was suspected of evil. (M, TA.)

A^amotN *
A measure of distance [&c.]; as in the saying, kamo A^amotu bayonaka maA bayona Alkuwfapi What is the measure of the distance between thee and El-Koofeh? (T, TA.) -A2- Doubt: (Th, T, M:) said to be so termed because this word signifies the “ computing, or conjecturing, measure, quantity, and the like, ” in which there is doubt. (T, TA.) [See 1.] So in the following ex.: Alxamoru Harumato laA A^amota fiyhaA Wine is unlawful: there is no doubt respecting the unlawfulness of it: (Sh, Th, T, K:) or the meaning is, there is no indulgence, or lenity, with respect to it; from A^amotN as signifying “feebleness, or weakness,” in a journey, or pace. (T, TA.) And in the saying, layosa fY Alxamori A^amotN
There is no doubt respecting wine, that it is unlawful. (Th, M.) [Or in the like of these two instances it signifies] Disagreement, or diversity of opinion, (AixotilaAfN,) respecting a thing (fiY $aYo'K). (M, K.) -A3- Curvity, crookedness, distortion, or unevenness: (M, K:) ruggedness in one place and smoothness in another; (K;) [inequality of surface;] one part being higher, or more prominent, than another: (TA:) an elevated place: (T, S, K:) small mounds: (Fr, Th, T, S, M, K:) or what is elevated, of ground: or, as some say, water-courses of valleys, such as are low, or depressed: (Fr, T, TA:) small hills; hillocks: (M, TA:) a hollow, or depressed place, between any two elevated portions of ground &c.: (IAar, T, M:) depression and elevation, or lowness and highness, (S, M, A, K,) in the ground; (A;) used in this sense in the Kur xx. 106; (S;) and the same in a water-skin not completely filled: (S, A: *) or laxity in a water-skin when it is not well filled so as to overflow: (T, * TA:) or a [consequence of] pouring [water] into a skin until it doubles, or creases, and not filling it; so that one part of it is higher, or more prominent, than another: (M, TA:) pl. A_imaAtN (M, K, TA, but in some copies of the K A=maAtN, and in the CK AamAtN,) and A^umuwtN. (M, K.) You say, Asotawati AlA^aroDu famaA bahaA A^amotN The earth, or ground, was even, so that there was not in it any depression and elevation. (A, TA.) And AimotalaA^a Als~iqaA='u famaA bihi A^amotN The skin became full, so that there was not in it any depression [of one part of its surface] and elevation [of another part]. (S, A. *) Az says, (TA,) I have heard the Arabs say, qado malaA^a Alqirobapa maloA^F laA A^amota fiyhi He had filled the water-skin so full that there was no laxity in it. (T, TA.) ― -b2- A fault, a defect, an imperfection, a blemish, or the like, (T, M, K,) in the mouth, and in a garment, or piece of cloth, and in a stone. (M, K.) [Hence the saying,] A^amotN fiY AlHajari laA fiyka i. e. [May there be a defect, or the like,] in stones; not in thee: meaning, may God preserve thee when the stones shall have perished: (Sb, M:) Amt is here put in the nom. case, though the phrase is significant of a prayer, because it is not a verbal word: the phrase is like Alt~urAbu laho: and the commencing the sentence with an indeterminate noun is approvable because it is virtually a prayer. (M.) This prov. is mentioned by the expositors of the Tes-heel: not by Meyd. (TA.) ― -b3- Weakness; feebleness; (T, K;) langour; remissness. (TA.) You say, sironaA sayorFA laA A^amota fiyhi We performed a journey, or went a pace, in which was no weakness, or feebleness [&c.]. (T, TA.) -A4- A good way, course, mode, or manner, of acting, or conduct, or the like. (T, K.)

muw^am~atN *
Suspected of evil and the like. (K.) [See 2.] -A2- [A water-skin] filled [so as to be equally distended: see A^amotN]. (K.)

maA=o'N maA^omuwtN *
A water of which the distance is computed, or conjectured. (TA.) ― -b2- huwa A_ilaY A^ajalK maAomuwtK It is until a determined, defined, or definite, period. (S, K. *) ― -b3- $aYo'N maA^omuwtN A thing that is known. (M, TA.) [And so mawomuwtN.]

1 A^amida Ealayohi * , aor.
Aamada , inf. n. A^amadN, He was angry with him: (S, M, Msb, * K:) like A^abida (S) and wamad and wabida and Eabida. (T in art. Abd.)
2 A^m~d * , inf. n. taA^omiydN, He declared the time, considered with regard to its end; or the utmost, or extreme, extent, term, limit, point, or reach; expl. by bay~ana AlA^amada. (K.)

A^amadN *
Time, considered with regard to its end: zamaAnN being time considered with regard to its end and its beginning: (Er-Rághib:) [but sometimes it is interchangeable with zamaAnN, as will be seen in what follows:] or the utmost, or extreme, extent, term, limit, point, or reach. (S, M, A, Msb, K.) You say, balaga A^amadahu He, or it, reached, or attained, his, or its, utmost, or extreme, extent, term, &c. (Msb.) And Daraba lahu A^amadFA [He assigned, or appointed, for him, or it, a term, or limit]. (A.) And huwa baEiydu AlA=maAdi [He is one whose limits are remote: A=maAdN being the pl.]. (A.) ― -b2- The period of life which one has reached; as in the saying, maA A^amaduka What is thy period of life which thou hast reached? (S.) ― -b3- Each of the two terms of the life of a man; i. e. the time of his birth, and the time of his death. (Sh, T.) El-Hasan [El-Basree], being asked by El-Hajjáj, maA A^amaduka, meaning What was the time of thy birth? answered by saying that it was two years before the expiration of 'Omar's reign as Khaleefeh. (T, L, from a trad.) ― -b4- The startingplace, and the goal, of horses in a race. (Sh, T, L.) ― -b5- (tropical:) Any space of time: (Er-Rághib:) a space of time of unknown limit. (Kull pp. 9 and 10.) ― -b6- Sometimes, (assumed tropical:) A particular time; as in the phrase A^amadu ka*aA The time of such a thing; like zamaAnu A^amadN. (Kull p. 10.) ― -b7- [It is also used for *w A^amadN, and (applied to a fem. n.) *aAt A^amadK, Having a term, or limit; limited in duration; as in the saying,] Ald~unoyaA A^amadN wAlA=xirpu A^abadN [The present state of existence is limited in duration, but the final state of existence is everlasting]. (Obeyd Ibn-'Omeyr, L in art. Abd.)

A^umodapN *
A remainder, or what remains, (K,) of anything. (TA)

siqaA='K muw^am~adN *
A skin [exhausted;] in which there remains not a gulp, or as much as is swallowed at once, of water. (K.)

A^amarahu *
An extreme term, limit, or point, reached, or attained. (K.)

1 A^amarahu * , (T, S, M, &c.,) aor.
Aamura , (M, &c.,) inf. n. A^amorN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and A_imaArN, (M, L, K,) which latter, however, is disapproved by MF, (TA,) and A_iymaArN is syn. therewith, (K,) but this also is disapproved by MF, and deemed by him strange, [being by rule the inf. n. of ↓ A=marahu, respecting which see what follows,] (TA,) and A=mirapN, (M, K,) which is one of the inf. ns. [or quasiinf. ns.] of the measure faAEilapN, like EaAfiyapN and EaAqibapN, (M,) He commanded him; ordered him; bade him; enjoined him; the inf. n. signifying the contr. of nahoYN; (T, M, K;) as also ↓ A=mrhu, (Kr, M, K,) mentioned by A'Obeyd also as a dial. var. of A^marahu: (Msb:) but A'Obeyd says that A=marotuhu and A^amrotuhu are syn. [in a sense different from that explained above, i. e.] as meaning kav~arotuhu. (TA.) You say, A^amarahu bihi, (S, M, K,) and A^amarahu A_iy~aAhu, suppressing the prep., (M,) He commanded, ordered, bade, or enjoined, him to do it. (M, K.) And A^marotuka A^ano tafoEala, and litafoEala, and biA^no tafoEala, I commanded, ordered, bade, or enjoined, thee to do [such a thing]. (M.) [And A^amarahu bika*aA as meaning He commanded him, or ordered him, to make use of such a thing; or the like: whence, in a trad.,] A^umirotu biAls~iwaAki [I have been commanded to make use of the tooth-stick]. (El-Jámi' es- Sagheer.) [And He enjoined him such a thing; as, for instance, patience.] The imperative of A^amara is muro; originally Aw^omuro; which also occurs [with wa in the place of w^ when the A is pronounced with damm]: (M:) but [generally] when it is not preceded by a conjunction, (Msb,) i. e., by wa or fa, (T,) you suppress the ', [i. e. the radical ', and with it the conjunctive A preceding it,] contr. to rule, and say, murohu bika*aA [Command, or order, or bid, or enjoin, thou him to do such a thing]; like as you say, kulo and xu*o: when, however, it is preceded by a conjunction, the practice commonly obtaining is, to restore the waA^omuro bika*aA, agreeably with analogy, and thus to say, A^amuro bika*aA. (Msb.) ― -b2- [You say also, A^amara bihi faqutila He gave an order respecting him, and accordingly he was slain. And A^amara lahu bika*aA He ordered that such a thing should be done, or given, to him.] ― -b3- In the Kur [xvii. 17], A^amaronaA mutorafiyhaA fafasaquwA fiyhaA, so accord. to most of the readers, (T, &c.,) means We commanded [its luxurious inhabitants] to obey, but they transgressed therein, or departed from the right way, or disobeyed: (Fr, T, S, &c.:) so says Aboo-Is-hák; adding that, although one says, A^amartu zayodFA faDaraba EamorFA, meaning I commanded Zeyd to beat 'Amr, and he beat him, yet one also says, A^amarotuka faEaSayotaniY [I commanded thee, but thou disobeyedst me]: or, accord. to some, the meaning is, We multiplied its luxurious inhabitants; (T;) and this is agreeable with another reading, namely, ↓ A=maronaA; (TA;) and a reading of El-Hasan, namely, A^amironaA, like EalimonaA, may be a dial. var., of the same signification: (M:) see 4, in two places: or it may be from AlA_imaArapu; (S, TA;) [in which case it seems that we should read ↓ A^am~aronaA; or, perhaps, A^amaronaA: see 2:] Abu-l-'Áliyeh reads ↓ A^am~aronaA, and this is agreeable with the explanation of I'Ab, who says that the meaning is, We made its chiefs to have authority, power, or dominion. (TA.) ― -b4- A^amarahu, aor.
Aamura , also signifies He commanded, ordered, bade, or enjoined, him to do that which it behooved him to do. (A.) [He counselled, or advised, him.] One says, muroniY, meaning Counsel thou me; advise thou me. (A.) ― -b5- A^amara biAqotinaASK, said
of a wild animal, means He rendered the beholder desirous of capturing him. (M.) -A2- A^amara, (As, Fr, Th, T, S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
Aamura ; (Msb, TA;) and A^amura, aor.
Aamura ; (S, M, IKtt, K;) and A^amira, aor.
Aamara ; (M, K, and several other authorities; but by some this is disallowed; TA;) inf. n. A^amorN (K) and A_imorapN (S) and A_imaArapN; (As, T, S;) or the second is a simple subst.; (K;) or perhaps it is meant in the S that this and the third are quasi-inf. ns.; (MF;) He had, or held, command; he presided as a commander, governor, lord, prince, or king; (M, Msb, K;) he became an A^amiyr; (As, T, S;) EalaY Alqawomi over the people. (M, * Msb, K.) [See also 5.] A^amara fulaAnN waA^umira Ealayohi, or Elyh ↓ wA^um~ira, (as in different copies of the S,) [Such a one has held command and been commanded,] is said of one who has been a commander, or governor, after having been a subject of a commander, or governor; meaning such a one is a person of experience; or one who has been tried, or proved and strengthened, by experience. (S.) -A3- A^amarahu as syn. with A=marahu: see 4. -A4- A^amira, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
Aamara , (Msb, K,) inf. n. A^amarN and A^amorap; (M, K, TA; the latter written in the CK Aamorap;) and A^mura, aor.
Aamara ; (IKtt;) (assumed tropical:) It (a thing, M, Msb, or a man's property, or camels or the like, Abu-l-Hasan and S, and a people, T, S) multiplied; or became many, or much, or abundant; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) and became complete. (M, K.) ― -b2- And the former, (assumed tropical:) His beasts multiplied; or became many; (M, K;) [as also ↓ A=mr; for you say,] banuw fulaAnK ↓ A=mr, inf. n. A_iymaArN, (assumed tropical:) The property, or camels or the like, of the sons of such a one multiplied; or became many, or abundant. (M.) -A5- A^amira AlA^amoru, (Akh, S, K,) aor.
Aamara , inf. n. A^amarN, (Akh, S,) (assumed tropical:) The affair, or case, (i. e., a man's affair, or case, Akh, S,) became severe, distressful, grievous, or afflictive. (Akh, S, K.)

2 A^m~rhu * , inf. n. taA^omiyrN, He made him, or appointed him, commander, governor, lord, prince, or king. (S, * Mgh, Msb.) [And it seems to be indicated in the S that ↓ A^amarahu, without teshdeed, signifies the same.] See 1, in three places. You say also, A^um~iraEalayonaA (A, TA) He was made, or appointed, commander, &c., over us. (TA.) ― -b2- Also He appointed him judge, or umpire. (Mgh.) ― -b3- A^m~r AlqanaApa (assumed tropical:) He affixed a spear-head to the cane or spear. (T, M.) [See also the pass. part. n., below.] ― -b4- A^m~rA^amaArapK He made [a thing] a sign, or mark, to show the way. (T.)

3 A=mrhu fiy A^amorihi * , (T, * S, M, Msb,) inf. n. muw^aAmarapN, (S, K,) He consulted him respecting his affair, or case; (T, * S, M, Msb, K, * TA;) as also waAmarahu; (TA;) or this is not a chaste form; (IAth, TA;) or it is vulgar; (S, TA;) and ↓ AstA^mrhu, (M,) inf. n. Asotiy^omaArN; (S, K;) and ↓ Ay^tmrhu, (T,) inf. n. Ay^timaArN. (S, K.) It is said in a trad., A=miruwA Aln~isaA='a fiY A^anofusihin~a Consult ye women respecting themselves, as to marrying them. (TA.) And in another trad., A=marato nafosahaA, meaning She consulted herself, or her mind; as also ↓ AstA^mrt nfshA. (TA.) [See another ex. voce nafosN. And see also 8.]

4 A=mr A=mr , inf. n. A_iymaArN: see 1, last sentence but one, in two places. -A2- A=morN; (S, M, Msb, K;) and ↓ A^amarahu, (S, M, Msb, K,) accord. to some, (M,) aor.
Aamura , (Msb, K,) inf. n. A^amorN; (Msb;) both signifying the same accord. to AO, (S,) or A 'Obeyd, (TA,) but the latter is of weak authority, (K,) or is not allowable; (M;) and, accord. to El-Hasan's reading of xvii. 17 of the Kur, (see 1,) ↓ A^amirahu also; (M;) (assumed tropical:) He (a man) multiplied it; or made it many, or much, or abundant: (S, Msb:) He (God) multiplied, or made many or much or abundant, his progeny, and his beasts: (M, K:) and A=mr maAlahu (assumed tropical:) He (God) multiplied, &c., his property, or camels or the like. (S.) -A3- See also 1, first sentence, in two places.

5 tA^m~r *
He became made, or appointed, commander, governor, lord, prince, or king; (Msb;) he received authority, power, or dominion; Ealayohimo over them. (S, K.) [See also A^amara.] ― -b2- See also 8.
6 taAaAomara see 8, in three places.

8 Ay^tmr * [written with the disjunctive alif Aiytamara] He obeyed, or conformed to, a command; (S, * M, Mgh, K; *) he heard and obeyed. (Msb.) You say, Ay^tmr bixayorK, meaning He was as though his mind commanded him to do good and he obeyed the command. (M.) And [you use it transitively, saying,] Ay^tmr AlA^amora He obeyed, or conformed to, the command. (S.) And laA yaA^otamiru ru$odFA He will not do right of his own accord. (A.) Imra el-Keys says, (S,) or En-Nemir Ibn-Towlab, (T,)
wayaEoduw EalaY Almaro'i maA yaA^otamiro
[And that which man obeys wrongs him, or injures him]; meaning, that which his own soul commands him to do, and which he judges to be right, but in which often is found his destruction: (S:) or, accord. to Kt, that evil which man purposes to do: (T:) or that which man does without consideration, and without looking to its result. (A 'Obeyd, T.) [See what follows.] ― -b2- He undertook a thing without consulting; (Kt, T;) as though his soul, or mind, ordered him to do it and he obeyed it: (TA:) he followed his own opinion only. (Mgh.) One says, A^amarotuhu fA^otamara waA^abaY A^ano yaA^otamira, (A, Mgh,) meaning I commanded him, but he followed his own opinion only, and refused to obey. (Mgh.) ― -b3- He formed an opinion, and consulted his own mind, and determined upon it. (Sh, T.) And Ay^tmr raA^oyahu He consulted his own mind, or judgment, respecting what was right for him to do. (Sh, T.) ― -b4- Ay^tmrwA, (A, Msb,) inf. n. Ay^otimaArN; (S, K;) and ↓ tA=mrwA, (A,) inf. n. taA=murN, of the measure tafaAEulN; (S;) and ↓ tA^m~rwA, (TA,) inf. n. taA^am~urN; (K;) They consulted together: (S, * A, Msb, K: *) or Ay^tmrwA and ↓ tA=mrwA signify they commanded, ordered, bade, or enjoined, one another; like as one says, AqttlwA and tqAtlwA, and AxtSmwA and txASmwA: (T:) or Ay^tmrwA EalaY AlA^amori and Ealayohi ↓ tA=mrwA, they determined, or settled, their opinions respecting the affair, or case: (M:) and Ay^tmrwA bihi, (S, Msb,) inf. n. as above, (K,) signifies they purposed it, (S, Msb, K, *) namely, a thing, (Msb, K,) and consulted one another respecting it. (S.)
