It is said in the Kur [lxv. 6], waA^otamiruwA bayonakumo bimaEoruwfK And command ye, or enjoin ye, one another to do good: [such is app. the meaning,] but God best knoweth: (T:) or, accord. to Kt, purpose ye among yourselves to do good. (TA.) And in the same [xxviii. 19], A_in~a AlomalaA^a yaA^otamiruwna bika liyaqotulwuka, meaning Verily the chiefs command one another respecting thee, to slay thee: (Zj, T:) or consult together against thee, to slay thee: (AO, T:) or purpose against thee, to slay thee: (Kt, T:) but the last but one of these explanations is better than the last. (T.) ― -b5- See also 3. ― -b6- Accord. to El-Bushtee, Ay^tmrhu also signifies He gave him permission: but this has not been heard from an Arab. (Az, TA.)
10 A_isotaAomara see 3, in two places.

A^amorN *
A command; an order; a bidding; an injunction; a decree; an ordinance; a prescript: (S, * Msb, * TA, &c.:) pl. A^awaAmiru: (S, Msb, &c.:) so accord. to common usage; and some writers of authority justify and explain it by saying that A^amorN is [originally] maA^omuwurN bihi; that it is then changed to the measure faAEilN; [i. e., to A=mirN;] like A^amorN EaArifN, which is originally maEoruwfN; and Eiy$apN rADiyapN, originally maroDiy~apN; &c.; [and then, to A^amorN;] and that faAEilN becomes in the pl. fawaAEilu; so that A^awaAmaru is the pl. of maA_omuwrN: others say that it has this form of pl. to distinguish it from A^amorN in the sense of HaAlN [&c.], in which sense it has for its pl. A^umuwrN. (Msb, TA.) [But I think that A^awaAmiru may be properly and originally pl. of A=mirapN, for A=yapN A=mirapN, or the like. MF says that, accord. to the T and M, the pl. of A^amorN in the sense explained in the beginning of this paragraph is A^umuwrN: but he seems to have founded his assertion upon corrupted copies of those works; for in the M, I find nothing on this point; and in the T, not, as he says, AlA^amoruDid~u Aln~ahoYa waAHidu AlA^umuwr, but qaAla All~ayovu AlA^amoru maEoruwfN naqiyDu Aln~ahoYi waAHidu AlA^umuwri, evidently meaning that A^amorN signifies the contr. of nahoYN, and is also, in another sense, the sing. of A^umuwrN.] [Hence,] A^uwluw AlA^amori Those who hold command or rule, and the learned men. (M, K. [See Kur iv. 62.]) And A^amoruAll~`hi The threatened punishment of God: so in the Kur x. 25, and xi. 42, and xvi.1; in which last place occur the words, A^atay A^amoru All~`hi falaA tasotaEojiluwhu, meaning The threatened punishment ordained of God hath, as it were, come: so near is it, that it is as though it had already come: therefore desire not ye to hasten it. (Zj, M, TA.) And The purpose of God. (Bd and Jel in lxv. 3; &c.) And AlA^amoru qariybN The resurrection, or the time thereof, is near. (Mgh, from a trad.) And maA faEalotuhu Eano A^amoriY, in the Kur xviii. 81, I did it not of my own judgment: (Bd:) or, of my own choice. (Jel.) [Hence also AlA^amoru, in grammar, signifies The imperative form of a verb.] ― -b2- Also A thing; an affair; a business; a matter; a concern: a state, of a person or thing, or of persons or things
or affairs or circumstances; a condition; a case: an accident; an event: an action: syn. $aA^onN: (M, F, TA:) and HaAlN, (Msb, TA,) and HaAlapN: (Msb:) and HaAdivapN: (K:) and fiEolN: (MF, TA:) and a thing that is said; a saying: (TA voce A^uwluw, at the end of art. Al:) pl. A^umuwrN; (S, M, K, &c.;) its only pl. in the senses here explained. (TA.) You say, A^amoru fulaAnK musotaqiymN [The affair, or the like, of such a one is in a right state]: and Amuwruhu musotaqiymapN [His affairs are in a right state]. (S, A.) And $at~ata A^amorahu He dissipated, disorganized, disordered, unsettled, or broke up, his state of things, or affairs. (As, TA in art. $Eb.) [Amr seems to be here used, as in many other instances, rather in the sense of the pl. than in that of the sing.] ― -b3- A^amorN kul~iY~N [A universal, or general, prescript, rule, or canon]. (Msb voce qaAEidapN, KT voce qaAnuwnN, &c.)

A_imorN A^mAr A^mr Amr mAr mr |mr a subst. from A^amiraAliA^amoru in the sense of Ai$otad~a; (S;) or a subst. from A^amira as signifying kavura and tam~a; (M;) (assumed tropical:) [A severe, a distressful, a grievous, or an afflictive, thing: or] a terrible, and foul, or very foul, thing: or a wonderful thing. (TA,) Hence, [used as an epithet, like A^amirN, q. v.,] in the Kur [xviii. 70], laqado jiy^ota $ayoy^FA A_imorFA (assumed tropical:) Verily thou hast done a severe, a distressful, a grievous, or an afflictive, thing: (S:) or a terrible, and foul, or very foul, thing: (TA:) or a wonderful thing: (S:) or an abominable, a foul, or an evil, and a wonderful, thing: (Ks, M, K: *) or a terrible and an abominable thing; signifying more than nakorFA, [which occurs after, in verse 73,] inasmuch as the [presumed] drowning of the persons in the ship was more abominable than the slaying of one person: (Zj, T:) or a crafty, and an abominable, or a foul, or an evil, and a wonderful, thing; and derived from A^amira Alqawomu as meaning kavuruwA. (Ks.)
A^amarN * a coll. gen. n. of which A^amarapN (q. v.) is the n. un. -A2- See also taA^omuwrN.

A^amirN * : see A_im~arN. -A2- (assumed tropical:) Multiplied; or become many, or much, or abundant. (M, K.) [See A^amira.] You say zaroEN A^amirN (assumed tropical:) Abundant seed-produce. (Lh, M.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A man whose beasts have multiplied, or become many or abundant. (M.) (assumed tropical:) A man blessed, or prospered, (Ibn-Buzurj, M, K, *) in his property: (M:) fem. with p. (Ibn-Buzurj.) And with p, (assumed tropical:) A woman blessed to her husband [by her being prolific]: from the signification of kavorapN. (M.) -A3- (assumed tropical:) Severe; distressful; afflictive. (TA.) [See also A_imorN.]

A^amorapN *
A single command, order, bidding, or injunction: as in the saying, laka EalaY~a A^amorapN muTaAEapN Thou hast authority to give me one command, order, bidding, or injunction, which shall be obeyed by me. (S, M, * A, Msb, K.) You should not say, [in this sense,] A_imorapN, with kesr. (T, S.) -A2- See also A_imorapN.

A_imorapN A^mAr A^mr A^mrh A_mrp Amrh Amrp mAr mr |mr |mrh |mrp a subst. from A^amara [q. v.]; Possession of command; the office, and authority, of a commander, governor, lord, prince, or king; (M, * Msb, K;) as also ↓ A_imaArapN (Mgh, Msb, K) and ↓ A^amaArapN; (L, K;) but this last is by some disallowed, and is said in the Fs and its Expositions to be unknown. (MF.) It is said in a trad., laEal~aka sA='a toka A_imorapu Aboni Eam~ika Perhaps thy paternal uncle's son's possession of command hath displeased thee. (TA.) ― -b2- [And hence, (assumed tropical:) Increase, or abundance, or the like; as also other forms mentioned in what follows.] You say, fiY wajohi maAlika taEorifu A_imoratahu (assumed tropical:) In the face of thy property, [meaning such as consists in camels or the like, and also money,] thou knowest its increase and abundance, and its expense: (S:) or ↓ A_im~aratahu, and ↓ A_im~ratahu, which latter is a dial. var. of weak authority, and ↓ A^am~aratahu, i. e., its increase and abundance: (M:) or ↓ A_im~aratahu as meaning its prosperous state; as also ↓ A^amaAratahu, and ↓ A^amoratahu: (Ibn-Buzurj:) accord. to AHeyth, who reads ↓ tuEorafu A_im~aratuhu, the meaning is, its decrease; but the correct meaning is, its increase, as Fr explains it. (T, TA.) It is said respecting anything of which one knows what is good in it at first sight: (Lh, M:) and means, on a thing's presenting itself, thou knowest its goodness. (T.) One says also, ↓ mA^aHosana A^amaAratahumo (assumed tropical:) How good is their multiplying, and the multiplying of their offspring and of their number! (M.) And ↓ laA jaEala All~`hu fiyhi A_im~arapF (assumed tropical:) May God not make an increase to be therein. (T.)

A^amarapN *
Stones: (K:) [or a heap of stones:] or it is the n. un. of A^amarN, which signifies stones: (M:) or the latter signifies stones set up in order that one may be directed thereby to the right way: (Ham p. 409:) and the former also signifies a hill; (M, K;) and A^amarN is [used as] its pl.: (M:) and a sign, or mark, by which anything is known; (M, K;) as also ↓ A^amaArN and ↓ A^amaArapN; (As, S;) and A^amarN is [used as] its pl. in this sense also: (M:) or a sign, or mark, set up to show the way; (AA, Fr;) as also ↓ A^amaArN and ↓ A^amaArahN: (K:) or a small sign, or mark, of stones, to show the way, in a waterless desert; (S;) as also ↓ A^amaArN [and ↓ A^amaArapN]; and any sign, or mark, that is prepared: (TA:) or a structure like a manaArap [here app. meaning a tower of a mosque], upon a mountain, wide like a house or tent, and larger, of the height of forty times the stature of a man, made in the time of 'Ád and Irem; in some instances its foundation being like a house, though it consists only of stones piled up, one upon another, cemented together with mud, appearing as though it were of natural formation: (ISh, T:) the pl. (in all the senses above, K) [or rather the coll. gen. n.,] is A^amarN. (S, K.) -A2- See also A_imorapN.

A^amaArN * and ↓ A^amaArapN A sign, mark, or token. (As, S Mgh.) See also each voce A^amarapN, in three places. You say, hiY A^amaArapu maA bayoniY wabayonaka It is a sign, or token, of what is between me and thee. (T, * TA.) And a poet says,
A_i*aA TalaEato $amosu Aln~ahaAri faA_in~ahaA
A^amaArapu tasoliymiY Ealayoki fasal~imiY
[When the sun of day rises, it is a sign of my saluting thee, therefore do thou salute]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A time: (As, S, K:) so IAar explains the latter word, not particularizing the time as definite or otherwise: (M:) or a definite time: (TA:) or a time, or place, of promise or appointment; an appointed time or place; syn. mawoEidN: (M, Mgh, K:) or, accord. to some, the former word is pl. [or rather col. gen. n.] of the latter. (TA.) El- 'Ajjáj says,
A_i*o rad~ahaA bikayodihi faArotad~ati
A_ilay A^amaArK waA^amaAri mud~atiY
When He (meaning God) brings it, (namely my soul,) by his skilful ordering, and his power, [and it is thus brought, or it thus comes, to a set time, and] to the time of the end of my appointed period: AmArmd~tY being as above; the former word being prefixed to the latter, governing it in the gen. case. (IB. [In the S we find waA^amaArN mud~atiY.])

A^amuwrN * [an intensive epithet from A^amarahu]. You say, A_in~ahu laA^amuwrN biAlomaEorwfi wanahuw~N Eani Alomunokari Verily he is one who strongly commands, or enjoins, good conduct, and who strongly forbids evil conduct. (S in art. nhY, and A. *)

A^amiyrN *
One having, holding, or possessing, command; (S;) a commander; a governor; a lord; (M, * Msb;) a prince, or king: (M, K:) fem. with p: (S, K:) pl. A_umaraA='u. (M, Msb, K.) ― -b2- A leader of the blind. (M, K.) So in the saying of El-Aashà:
A_i*aAkaAna haAdiY AlfataY fiY AlbilaA
diSadora AlqanaApi A^aTaAEa AlA^amiyraA
[When the young man's guide in the countries, or lands, or the like, is the top of the cane, he obeys the leader of the blind]. (M.) ― -b3- A woman's husband. (A.) ― -b4- A neighbour. (K.) ― -b5- A person with whom one consults: (A, K:) any one of whom one begs counsel, or advice, in a case of fear. (TA.) You say, huwa A^amiyriY He is the person with whom I consult. (A.)
A^amaArapN * : see A_imorapN, in three places: ― -b2- and see also A^amarapN, in three places; and A^amaArN.
A_imaArapi A^mAr A^mArh A^mArp A_mArp AmArh AmArp mArY : see A_imorapN. ― -b2- AlA_imaArapu is also used for SaAHibu AlA_maArapi, i. e. AlA^amiyru. (Mgh.)
A^am~arN * : see the next paragraph, in two places.

A_im~arN A^mAr A^mr Amr mAr mr |mr A man who consults every one respecting his case; as also ↓ A^amirN and ↓ A^am~aArapN: (M:) or a man resembling [in stupidity] a kid: [see the latter part of this paragraph:] (Th, M:) or, as also ↓ A_im~arapN (S, M, K, &c.) and ↓ A^am~arN and ↓ A^am~arapN, (K,) a man having weak judgment, (S, K,) stupid, (T, M,) or weak, without judgment, (M, L,) or without intellect, or intelligence, (T,) who obeys the command of every one, (T, S,) who complies with what every one desires to do in all his affairs; (K;) a stupid man, of weak judgment, who says to another, Command me to execute thine affair. (IAth.) It is said in a trad., mano yuTiEo A_im~arapF laA yaA^okulo vamarapF [He who obeys a stupid man, &c., shall not eat fruit: or the meaning is]
he who obeys a stupid woman shall be debarred from good. (IAth.) ↓ A_im~arapN is applied to a woman and to a man: when it is applied to a man, the p is added to give intensiveness to the signification. (ISh.) The following saying, A_i*aA TalaEati Al$~iEoraY walaA A_im~arFA, ↓ safarFA falaA turosilo fiyhaA A_im~arapF, in rhyming prose, means [When Sirius rises in the clear twilight,] send not thou among them (meaning the camels) a man without intelligence [in a great degree, nor one who is so in a less degree; or a woman without intelligence, nor a man without intelligence;] to manage them. (Sh.) ― -b2- Also, (M, K,) and ↓ A_im~arapN and ↓ A^am~ara and ↓ A^um~arN, (K,) A young lamb: (M, K:) or the first (A_imarN) and the second, a young kid: (M, TA:) or the former of these two, a male lamb: (M, TA:) or a young male lamb: (S:) and the latter of them, a female lamb: (M, TA:) or a young female lamb. (S, M.) One says, ↓ maA lahu A_im~arN walaA A_im~arapN, meaning He has not a male lamb nor a female lamb: (M, TA:) or he has not anything. (T, S, M.)
A^am~arapN * : see A_im~arN, in two places.
A_im~arapN A^mAr A^mr A^mrh A_mrp Amrh Amrp mAr mr |mr |mrh |mrp : see A_im~arN, in six places: -A2- and see A_imorapN, in four places.
A_im~rapN A^mAr A^mr A^mrh A_mrp Amrh Amrp mAr mr |mr |mrh |mrp : see A_imorapN.

A^am~aArN * [Wont to command]. [Hence,] Aln~afosu AlA^am~aArapu [The soul that is wont to command]; (A;) the soul that inclines to the nature of the body, that commands to the indulgence of pleasures and sensual appetites, drawing the heart downwards, so that it is the abode of evils, and the source of culpable dispositions. (KT.) [See nafosN.]
A^am~aArapN * fem. of A^am~aArN [q. v.]. ― -b2- See also A_im~arN.

A=mirN A=mr [act. part. n. of A^amarahu.] ― -b2- A=mirN and ↓ muw^otamirN Two days, (S,) the last, (K,) the former being the sixth, and the latter the seventh, (M,) of the days called A^ay~aAmu Alajuwzi: (S, M, K: [but see EajuwzN:]) as though the former commanded men to be cautious, and the latter consulted them as to whether they should set forth on a journey or stay at home: (S:) accord. to Az, the latter is applied as an epithet to the day as meaning yuw^otamarufiyhi. (TA.)
taA^omuriY~u * : see taA^omuwrN, in two places.
tuw^omuriY~N * , and without ': see taA^omuwrN, in six places.

taA^omuwrN * and ↓ taA^omuwrapN are properly mentioned in this art.; the measure of the former being tafoEuwlN; (K;) and that of the latter, tafoEolwlapN: (TA:) not as J has imagined; [who writes them without ', and mentions them in art. tmr;] (K;) their measures accord. to him being faAEuwlN and faAEuwlapN. (TA.) [But in all the senses here explained, they appear to be with and without '.] ― -b2- The former signifies The soul: (S in art. tmr, where it is written without '; and M, A, K:) because it is that which is wont to command. (A.) One says, qado Ealima taA^omuwruka *lika Thy soul, or self, hath known that. (AZ, and T in art. tmr.) ― -b3- The intellect: (M:) as in the saying, Earafotuhu bitaA^omuwriy I knew it by my intellect. (M in art. tmr, without '; and TA.) You say also, huwa Abonu taA^omuwrihaA, meaning He is the knowing with respect to it. (TA in art. bny.) ― -b4- The heart, (T in art. tmr without ', and M, A, K,) itself. (M, TA.) Hence the saying, HarofN fiY taA^omuwriY xayorN mino Ea$arapK fY wi EaAy^ika [One word in my heart is better than ten in thy receptacle]. (T in art. tmr, and TA.) ― -b5- The pericardium. (M in art. tmr, without '.) ― -b6- The core, or black or inner part, or clot of blood, (Hab~ap, M, K, or Ealaqap, TA,) and life, and blood, of the heart: (M, K:) or blood, (As, S, M, in art. tmr, and K,) absolutely: (TA:) and taA^omuwru Aln~afosi signifies the life-blood: (As, S:) or the blood of the body: (S in art. nfs:) and the life of the soul. (M, K.) ― -b7- Also, as being likened to blood, (TA,) (tropical:) Wine; and so ↓ taA^omuwrapN: (M, K:) and ― -b8- (tropical:) A dye: (M, TA:) and ― -b9- (tropical:) Saffron. (As, K.) ― -b10- [Hence also,] (tropical:) Water. (M, K.) You say, maA fYi Alr~akiy~api taAmuwrN, (T, S in art. tmr, and M,) or taA^omuwrN, (A,) (tropical:) There is not in the well any water. (T, S, M, A.) -A2- The wezeer (waziyr) of a king: (M, K:) because his command is effectual. (TA.) -A3- Any one: as in the saying, maAbihaA taA^omuwrN, (T in art. tmr, A, K,) as also ↓ tuw^omuwrN, (T in art. tmr, and K,) each with an augmentative t, and without ' as well as with it, accord. to Er-Radee and others, (TA,) and ↓ taA^omuriY~u, and ↓ taA^omuwriY~u, (M,) and ↓ tuw^omuriY~u, (T in art. tmr, M, TA,) or without ', (S, M, K, in art. tmr,) and ↓ A^amarN, (M, K,) There is not in it (i. e. in the house, AldAr, M, A, TA) any one. (M, A, K, and T and S in art. tmr.) You say also, bilaAdN xalaA='N
↓ layosa fiyhaA tuwmuriY~N Vacant regions wherein is not any one. (S in art. tmr.) ↓ tuw^omuriY~N (M, K) and ↓ tuwmuriY~N (S in art. tmr) and ↓ taA^omuwriY~N and ↓ taA^omuriy~N (M, K) also signify A man, or human being. (S, * M, K.) You say, speaking of a beautiful woman, A^aHosana minohaA ↓ maA raA^ayotu tuwmuriy~aA I have not seen a human being, or creature, more beautiful than she: (S and M in art. tmr:) and maA raA^ayotu A^aHosana minohu ↓ tuwmuriy~aA [I have not seen a man more beautiful than he]. (T and S in art. tmr.) Accord. to some, they are used only in negative phrases; but accord. to others, they are also used in such as are affirmative. (MF.) ― -b2- Also Anything: as in the saying A^akala Al*~iy^obu Al$~aApa famaA taraka minohaA taAmuwrFA [The wolf ate the sheep, or goat, and left not of it anything]. (T and S in art. tmr.) -A4- A child, young one, or fœtus syn. waladN. (M, K.) -A5- The receptacle (wiEaA=') of the child, young one, or fœtus. (M in art. tmr, without '; and K.) ― -b2- A wiEaA=' [in the ordinary sense; i. e. a bag, or receptacle, for travelling-provisions and for goods or utensils &c.]. (M, K.) Hence the saying, A^anota A^aEolamu bitaA^omuwrika Thou art best acquainted with what thou hast with thee; and with thine own mind. (M.) ― -b3- Also, (K,) and ↓ taA^omuwrapN, (M, [in which the former is not given in the following senses,] and K,) or ↓ taAmuwrapN, (S in art. tmr,) A ewer, syn. A_iboriyqN, (S, M, K,) for wine: (S:) and, (M, K,) or, as some say, (TA,) a Huq~ap (M, K, TA) in which wine is put. (TA.) ― -b4- Also the first, (M, K,) or ↓ third, (T and S in art. tmr,) The chamber, or cell, (SawomaEap, T and M in art. tmr, without ', and S and K, and nAmuwY, M, K,) of a monk. (M, K.) ― -b5- And hence, (TA,) the first, (K,) and ↓ second, (M, K,) or ↓ third, of these three words, (T and S, in art. tmr,) (tropical:) The covert, or retreat, of a lion. (T, S, M, K.) Whence, ↓ fulaAnN A^asadN fiY taAmuwratihi (tropical:) Such a one is a lion in his covert: (T and S in art. tmr:) a saying borrowed from 'Amr Ibn-Maadee-Kerib: (T and S ibid:) or, accord. to some, it means, a lion in the greatness of his courage, and in his heart. (TA.) -A6- Also (i. e. the first only) Play, or sport, of girls or of boys. (Th, M in art. tmr without ', and K.) -A7- See also yaA^omuwrN.

tuw^omuwrN *
A sign, or mark, set up to show the way in a waterless desert; (K, TA;) consisting of stones piled up, one upon another: (TA:) pl. taA=miyru. (K.) [See A^amarapN.] -A2- See also taA^omuwrN.
taA^omuwrapN * , and without ': see taA^omuwrN, in eight places. ― -b2- Also The pericardium; the integument (gilaAf) of the heart. (S in art. tmr: there written without '.)
taA^omuwriY~N * : see taA^omuwrN, in two places.

miy^omarN *
Counsel; advice: as in the saying, fulaAnN baEiydN mina Almiy^omari qariybN mina Almiy^obari Such a one is far from counsel, or advice: near to calumny, or slander. (A.)

muw^am~arN *
Made, or appointed, commander, governor, lord, prince, or king: (S, M, K: *) made to have authority, power, or dominion: (T, M, K:) in which latter sense it is explained by Khálid, as applied by Ibn-Mukbil to a spear. (T.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A cane, or spear-shaft, having a spearhead affixed to it. (K.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A spear-head (T, TA) sharpened; syn. muHad~adN. (T, M, K, TA.) ― -b4- Distinguished, or defined, (muHad~adN,) by signs, or marks: (TA:) or, as some say, (TA,) marked with a hot iron; syn. muwosuwmN. (K, TA.)

maA^omuwrN * [pass. part. n. of A^amarahu, q. v.]. ― -b2- It is said in a trad., (S, &c.,) xayoru AlmaAli muhorapN maA^omuwrapN wasik~apN maA^obuwrapN (tropical:) The best of property are a prolific filly [and a row of palm-trees, or perhaps a tall palmtree, fecundated]; (AZ, A 'Obeyd, T, S, A, K;) as though the filly were commanded [by God] to be so: (A, in which the epithet mA^mwrp thus used is said to be tropical:) [or] mA^mwrp is thus for the sake of conformity to mA^bwrp, and is originally muw^omarapN, (S, M, * K,) from A=marahaA All~`hu: (TA:) or it is a dial. var. of weak authority; (K;) though, accord. to AZ, it signifies made to have abundant offspring, from A^amara All~`hu Almuhorapa, meaning “God made the filly to have abundant offspring,” a dial. var. of A=marahaA, as A 'Obeyd also asserts it to be. (TA.)
maA=miru mA=mr and maA=miyru: see what next follows.

muw^otamirN * [Obeying, or conforming to, a command; &c.: see 8. ― -b2- ] One who acts according to his own opinion; (T;) who follows his own opinion
only: or who hastes to speak. (M.) -A2- See also A=mirN. ― -b2- Also, and Almuw^otamiru, [The month which is now commonly called] AlmuHar~amu: (M, K:) the former appellation (mw^tmr) is that by which the tribe of 'Ád called it: (Ibn-El-Kelbee:) pl. ↓ maA=miru and maA=miyru [both anomalous]. (M, K.) [See $ahorN.]

yaA^omuwrN * ; (M, K;) so in all the copies of the K but in the L and other lexicons, ↓ taA^omuwrN; (TA;) A certain beast of the sea: or, as some say, a small beast: (M:) and a kind of mountain-goat: (M, K:) or a certain wild beast, (K, TA,) or a beast resembling the mountain-goat, (M,) having a single branching horn in the middle of his head. (M, TA.) [See yaHomuwrN, the oryx.]

A_amos A^ms A^msY Ams mAs ms msY wms , meaning Yesterday, or the day before the present day (Msb, K) by one night, (K,) and tropically applied to (tropical:) what is before that, (Msb,) or a short time before, (Bd in x. 25,) [used as a subst. and as an adv.,] is indecl., with any of the three vowels for its termination: (K:) [written A^amosi and A^mosa and A^mosu:] or it is an adv. n., indecl., with kesr for its termination, unless made indeterminate, or made determinate [be the article Al]; and sometimes indecl. with fet-h: (EzZejjájee, M, TA:) or, accord. to I Hsh, the termination with fet-h is a rejected form; and that with damm is not mentioned by any of the grammarians: (TA:) but mu*o A^amosa [Since yesterday] occurs, used by poetic licence: (Sb, S:) A^amos is a noun of which the last letter is made movent to avoid the concurrence of two quiescent letters: and the Arabs differ respecting it: (S:) most of them make it indecl., with kesr for its termination, when it is determinate [without the article Al]: but some of them make it [imperfectly] decl. when it is determinate [in the same manner]: (S, K: *) [accord. to the most approved usage,] you say, [raA^ayotuhu A^amosi, and biAlA^amosi, which is more common, and AlA^amosa, I saw him yesterday; and] maA raA^ayotuhu mu*oA^amosi [I have not seen him since yesterday]; and if you have not seen him [since the day next] before that, you say, maA raA^ayotuhu mu*o A^aw~alu mino A^amosi [I have not seen him since the day before yesterday]; and if you have not seen him [since] two days before that, you say, maA raA^ayotuhu mu*o A^aw~alu mino A^aw~ala mino A^amosi [I have not seen him since the day before the day before yesterday]. (ISk, TA.) The phrase raA^ayotuhu A^amosK [I saw him yesterday] has also been heard, but it is extr. (K.) The people of El-Hijáz make A^amos indecl., with kesr for its termination; and the Benoo-Temeem do the same when it is in the accus. or gen. case; but these latter make it [imperfectly] decl. when it is in the nom. case, saying, *ahaba A^amosu bimaA fiyhi [Yesterday has gone with what happened during it]; whereas the people of El-Hijáz say, *ahaba A^amosi bimaA fiyhi, because it is [held by them to be] indecl. on account of its implying that it has the determinative article Al [understood as prefixed to it], the kesreh being added to avoid the concurrence of two quiescent letters; while the Benoo-Temeem hold it to be, in the nom. case, a deviation from AlA_amosu, and therefore imperfectly decl., because of its being determinate, [and so resembling a proper name,] and its deviation from the original form, like saHaru in the like case: (IB, TA:) all of the Arabs, however, make it decl. when the article Al is prefixed to it, (S, K, *) and when it is made indeterminate, or is prefixed to another noun: (S:) they say, using it indeterminately, kul~u gadK SaAy^irN A^amosKA [Every morrow becomes a yesterday]; (S, * IB;) and making it determinate by the article Al, they say, kaAna AlA^amosu Tay~ibFA [The yesterday was good], (IB,) and maDay AlA^amosu AlmubaAraku [The blessed yesterday has past]; (S;) and prefixing it to another noun, kul~u A^amosinaA kaAna Tay~ibFA [All of our yesterday was good], (IB,) and maDaY A^amosunaA [Our yesterday has past]: (S:) [therefore,] in the following verse,
waA_in~iY waqafotu Alyawoma waAlA^amosi qabolahu
bibaAbika Hat~aY kaAdati Al$~amosu tagorubu
[And verily I stood to-day, and yesterday before it, at thy door until the sun was almost setting], (thus related by IAar in two different ways, AlA^amosi and AlA^amosa,) if we read AlA^amosi, the Al is redundant, because it is implied in the word A^amosi; but if we read AlA^amosa, the Al is not implied in A^amosa, and therefore is prefixed to make it determinate. (IJ, M.) The pl. is A=musN and A=maAsN, (Zj, K,) both pls. of pauc., (Zj, TA,) and A^muwsN, (Zj, K, TA, [in the CK, incorrectly, AmuwosN,]) which is a pl. of mult. (Zj, TA.) There is no dim. form of A^amos; like as there is none of gadN and AlbaAriHapu and kayofa and A^ayona and mataY and A^aY~u and maA and Einda and the names of the months and those of the days of the week, except AljumoEapu. (Sb, S.)

A_imosiY~N A^ms A^msY A^msy A^msyy AmsY Amsy msY , contr. to analogy, (M, TA,) and A^amosiY~N [which is agreeable with analogy] is allowable, as related by Sgh on the authority of Fr, but the former is the more chaste, (TA,) Of, or relating to, or belonging to, yesterday. (M, TA.)

1 A^amalahu * , (T, S, M, &c.,) aor.
Aamula , (T, S, M, Msb,) and
Aamila , (so in the M accord. to the TT,) inf. n. A^amalN, (T, S, M, &c.,) this being the inf. n. accord. to IJ, [as distinguished from A^amolN and A_imolN,] (M,) He hoped it; or hoped for it; syn. rajaAhu; (S, * M, * [see A^amalN below,] K;) meaning, what was good for him; (S;) as also ↓ A^malhu, (T, * M, K,) inf. n. taA^mylN: (S, T:) or he expected it; [or had a distant, or remote, expectation of it; for] it is mostly used in relation to that of which the occurrence, or coming to pass, is deemed remote; as in the saying of Zuheyr,
A^arojuw waA=mulu A^ano tadonuw mawad~atuhaA
[I hope, and have a distant expectation, that her love may approach]: he who has determined upon a journey to a distant town or country says, A^amalotu AlwuSuwla [I have formed an expectation, or a distant expectation, of arriving]; but he does not say, TamiEotu until he has become near thereto; for TamaEN relates only to that of which the occurrence, or coming to pass, is [deemed] near: and Alr~ajaA='u is between AlA^amalu and AlT~amaEu; for it is sometimes attended with fear that the thing expected may not come to pass, wherefore it is used in the sense of fear; and when the fear is strong, [lest the thing expected should not come to pass, it denotes distant expectation, and thus] it is used in the sense of AlA^amalu; whence the usage in the verse of Zuheyr; but otherwise it is used in the sense of AlT~amaEu: (Msb:) or AlrjA' signifies the expectation of benefit, or advantage, from some preceding cause or means: so says El-Harállee: or it is properly syn. with AlA^amalu; and in common conventional language, means the clinging of the heart to the coming to pass of a future desired event: so says Ibn-El-Kemál: or, accord. to Er-Rághib, an opinion requiring the coming to pass of an event in which will be a cause of happiness: (TA:) and ↓ A^m~lhu, inf. n. taA^omiylN, signifies he expected it much; and is more commonly used than the form without teshdeed. (Msb.)
2 Aam~ala see 1, in two places. -A2- taA^omiylN also signifies The inducing [one] to hope or expect. (KL.)

5 tA^mlAl$~aY'i * [He considered the thing, or studied it, or contemplated it, carefully, or attentively, with investigation;] he looked at the thing endeavouring to obtain a clear knowledge of it: (S:) or i. q. tadab~arahu; (Msb, TA;) i. e., (Msb,) he looked into the thing, considered it, examined it, or studied it, repeatedly, (Msb, TA,) in order to know it, or until he knew it, (Msb,) or in order to ascertain its real case: (TA:) or he looked intently, or hardly, at, or towards, the thing: (TA:) or tA^m~l signifies he acted, or proceeded, deliberately, not hastily, syn. tavab~ata, (T, M,) or he paused, or waited, syn. talab~iva, (K,) in an affair, and in consideration; (M, K, TA;) he paused, and acted with deliberation. (TA.) fiyhi taA^am~ulN [meaning It requires careful, or attentive, consideration, or simply it requires consideration,] is a phrase [of frequent occurrence in the larger lexicons &c., used to imply doubt, and also to insinuate politely that the words to which it relates are false, or wrong,] like fiyhi naZarN [q. v.]. (MF in art. SfH.)
A^amolN * : see A^amalN.
A_imolN A^mAl A^ml A^mlY Aml mAl ml mlA mlY |ml : see A^amalN.

A^amalN * (T, S, M, Msb, K) and ↓ A_KimolN (IJ, M, K) and ↓ A^amolN, (K,) the first of which is an inf. n., accord. to IJ, (M,) and is the form commonly known, (TA,) Hope; syn. rajaA='N: (S, M, K:) or expectation; [or distant, or remote, expectation; being] mostly used in relation to that of which the occurrence, or coming to pass, is deemed remote: applied also to an affection of the heart from some good to be attained: (Msb, TA: [in both of which are further explanations, for which see 1:]) ↓ A_imolapN, also, signifies the same as A^amalN,
(S, M, K,) or taA_omiylN; (Lh, M, K;) [or a manner of hoping or expecting; for J adds,] and it is like jilosapN and rikobapN: (S:) and ↓ muw^am~alN, likewise, signifies the same as A_amalN: (TA:) the pl. of A^malN and A_amolN and A^amolN is A=malN. (M, * K, TA.) You say, xaAba saEoyuhu waA^amaluhu [His labour, and his hope, or expectation, were disappointed, frustrated, or balked]. (A and TA in art. xyb.) And ↓ maA A^aTowala A_amolatahu How far-reaching is his hope, or expectation! (T, * S, M, K:) [or his manner of hoping or expecting!] from AlA^amalu. (T.) ― -b2- Also, the first, An object of hope. (Jel in xviii. 44.)
A_imolapN A^ml A^mlY A^mlh Amlh Amlp mlA mlY |ml |mlh |mlp : see A^amalN, in two places.
A=milN A=ml act. part. n. of 1; [Hoping: or] expecting. (Msb.) [See 1.]

muw^am~alN * One whose beneficence may be hoped for. (Har p. 183.) ― -b2- Almuw^am~alu The eighth of the horses that are started together in a race; (K;) these being ten: (TA:) or the ninth thereof: (TA in explanation of Als~ukayotu:) or the seventh thereof. (Ham p. 46.) -A2- See also A^amalN.
maA^omuwlN * pass. part. n. of 1; [Hoped: or] expected. (Msb.)

1 A^amina * , (T, S, M, &c.,) aor.
Aamana , (T, Msb, K,) inf. n. A^amonN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and A_imonN (Zj, M, K) and A^amanN (M, K) and A^amanapN (T, S, M, K) and A_imonapN (T) and A^amaAnN (M, K) [and app. A^amaAnapN, for it is said in the S that this is syn. with A^amaAnN,] and A=mnN, an instance of an inf. n. of the measure faAEilN, which is strange, (MF,) or this is a subst. like faAlijN, (M,) He was, or became, or felt, secure, safe, or in a state of security or safety; originally, he was, or became, quiet, or tranquil, in heart, or mind; (Msb;) he was, or became, secure, or free from fear; A^amonN signifying the contr. of xawofN, (S, M, K,) and so A^amanapN (S) and A=minN [&c.]: (M, K:) he was, or became, or felt, free from expectation of evil, or of an object of dislike or hatred, in the coming time; originally, he was, or became, easy in mind, and free from fear. (El-Munáwee, TA.) [See A^amonN, below.] You say also, yaA_omanu EalaY nafosihi [He is secure, or safe, or free from fear, for himself]. (M.) And A^amina Albaladu, meaning The inhabitants of the country or district, or town, were in a state of security, or confidence, therein. (Msb.) The verb is trans. by itself, and by means of the particle mino; as in A^amana zayodN AlA^asada and A^amina mina AlA^asadi, meaning Zeyd was, or became, or felt, secure from, safe from, [or free from fear of,] the lion. (Msb.) You say also, A^amina ka*iba mano A^axobarahu [He was secure from, or free from fear of, the lying of him who informed him]. (M.) And laA A=nanu A^ano yakuwna ka*lika [I am not free from fear of its being so; I am not sure but that it may be so]. (Mgh in art. nb*; and other lexicons passim.) And, of a strong-made she camel, A^aminato A^ano takuwna DaEayfapF [She was secure from, or free from fear of, being weak]: (M: [in a copy of the S A^uminato:]) and A^aminati AlEivaAra waAlA_aEoyaA='K [She was secure from, or free from fear of, stumbling, and becoming jaded]: (M:) and A^umina EivaAruhaA [Her stumbling was not feared]. (So in a copy of the S.) And, of a highly-prized camel, A^umina A^ano yunoHara [It was not feared that he would be slaughtered; or his being slaughtered was not feared]. (M.) [A^amnahu sometimes means He was, or became, free from fear, though having cause for fear, of him, or it. i. e. he thought himself secure, or safe, from him or it. (See Kur vii. 97.)] ― -b2- A^minahu (inf. n. A^amonN TK) [and accord. to some copies of the K ↓ A=manahu] and ↓ A^m~nhu (inf. n. taA^omiynN K) and ↓ Ay^tmnhu ([written with the disjunctive alif Aiytamanahu, and] also written Ait~amanahu, on the authority of Th, which is extr., like Ait~ahala [&c.], M) and ↓ AstA^mnhu all signify the same (M, K, TA) [He trusted, or confided, in him; (as also A=mn bihi, q. v.;) he intrusted him with, or confided to him, power, authority, control, or a charge; he gave him charge over a thing or person: these meanings are vaguely indicated in the M and K and TA.]. You say, yaA^omanuhu Aln~aAsu walaA yaxaAfuwna gaAy^ilatahu [Men, or people, trust, or confide, in him, and do not fear his malevolence, or mischievousness]. (T, M.) And A^aminahu EalaY ka*aA (S, Mgh, * Msb *) and ↓ Ay^tmnhu Ealayohi, (S, Msb, K,) [He trusted, or confided, in him with respect to such a thing; he intrusted him with, or confided to him, power, authority, control, or a charge, over it; he gave him charge over it;] he made him, or took him as, A^amiyn over such a thing. (Mgh.) Hence, in a trad., the muw^a*~in is said to be muw^otamanN; i. e. Aln~aAsu Eala AlA^awoqaAti Al~atiY yuw^a*~anu fiyhaA ↓ yaA^otaminuhu [Men trust, or confide, in him with respect to the times in which he calls to prayer], and know, by his calling to prayer, what they are commanded to do, as to praying and fasting and breaking fast. (Mgh.) It is said in the Kur [xii. 11], maA laka laA taA^omanunaA EalaY yuwsufa and [taA^oman~aA] with idghám [i. e. What aileth thee that thou dost not trust, or confide, in us with respect to Joseph? or, that thou dost not give us charge over Joseph?]; (S;) meaning, why dost thou fear us for him? (Bd;) some pronouncing the verb in a manner between those of the former and the latter modes of writing it; but Akh says that the latter is better: (S:) some read tiyman~aA. (Bd.) You say also, ↓ Auwtumina fulaAnN [Such a one was trusted, or confided, in &c.;] when it begins a sentence, changing the second ' into w; in like manner as you change it into Y when the first is with kesr, as in Aiytamanahu; and into A when the first is with fet-h, as in A=mana. (S.) The phrase A^amaAnapF ↓ Auwtumina, in a saying of Mohammad, if it be not correctly EalaY A^amaAnapK, may be explained as implying the meaning of AusotuHofiZa A^amaAnapF [He was asked to take care of a deposite; or he was intrusted with it]. (Mgh.) [You also say, A^aminahu bika*aA, meaning He intrusted him with such a thing; as, for instance, money or other property: see two exs. in the Kur iii. 68.] -A2- A^amuna, (M, Mgh, K,) or A^amina, (Msb,) inf. n. A^amaAnapN, (M, Mgh, Msb,) He was, or became, trusted in, or confided in: (M, K:) or he was, or became, trusty, trustworthy, trustful, confidential, or faithful: said of a man. (Mgh.)

2 A^m~nhu * , inf. n. taA^omiynN: see 4: ― -b2- and see also A^aminahu. -A2- A^m~n, inf. n. as above, also signifies He said A=miyna or A^amiyna, (T, S, Msb,) after finishing the Fátihah, (T,) or Ealay Ald~uEaA='i on the occasion of the prayer, or supplication. (Msb.)

4 A=mana A=mn is originally A^aA^omana; the second ' being softened. (S.) You say, A=mnhu, [inf. n. A_iymaAnN;] (S, M, Msb;) and ↓ A^m~nhu, [inf. n. taA^omiynN;] (M, TA;) meaning He rendered him secure, or safe; (Msb;) he rendered him secure, or free from fear; (S, M, TA;) contr. of A^axaAfhu: (TA:) so in A=manotuhu minohu I rendered him secure, or safe, from him, or it. (Msb.) And of God you say, A=mana EibAdahu mino A^ano yaZolimahumo [He hath rendered his servants secure from his wronging them]. (S.) And yuw^ominu EibaAdahu mino Ea*aAbihi [He rendereth his servants secure from his punishment]. (M.) You say also, A=manotu AlA^asiyra, meaning I gave, or granted, AlA^amaAn [i. e. security or safety, or protection or safeguard, or the promise or assurance of security or safety, or indemnity, or quarter,] to the captive. (Msb.) And A=mana fulaAnN AlaEaduw~a [Such a one granted security, &c., to the enemy], inf. n. as above. (T.) It is said in the Kur ch. ix. [verse 12], accord. to one reading, laA A_iymaAna lahumo They have not the attribute of granting protection; meaning that when they grant protection, they do not fulfil their engagement to protect. (T.) -A2- A_iymaAnN also signifies The believing [a thing, or in a thing, and particularly in God]; syn. taSodiyqN; (T, S, &c.;) by common consent of the lexicologists and other men of science: (T:) its primary meaning is the becoming true to the trust with respect to which God has confided in one, by a firm believing with the heart; not by profession of belief with the tongue only, without the assent of the heart; for he who does not firmly believe with his heart is either a hypocrite or an ignorant person. (T, TA.) Its verb is intrans. and trans. (TA, from a Commentary on the Mutowwal.) You say, A=mana, meaning He believed. (T.) And it is said to be trans. by itself, like Sad~aqa; and by means of bi, considered as meaning AiEotiraAfN [or acknowledgment]; and by means of li, considered as meaning A_i*oEaAnN [or submission]. (TA.) [Thus] you say, [A=mnhu and] A=mn bihi, (inf. n. A_iymaAnN, T, K,) namely, a thing. (T, M.) And A=mn biAll~`hi He believed in God. (T.) It seems to be meant by what is said in the Ksh [in ii. 2], that A=mn bihi [or A=manahu] properly signifies A=manahu Alt~ako*iyba [He rendered him secure from being charged with lying, or falsehood]; and that the meaning he believed him or in him, is tropical; but this is at variance with what its author says in the A; and Es-Saad says that this latter meaning is proper. (TA.)
The phrase in the Kur [ix. 61], wayuw^ominu lilomw^ominiyna, accord. to Th, means And he believeth the believers; giveth credit to them. (M.) ― -b2- Sometimes it is employed to signify The acknowledging with the tongue only; and hence, in the Kur [lxiii. 3], *lika bA^an~ahumo A=manuwA vum~a kafaruwA That is because they acknowledged with the tongue, then disacknowledged with the heart. (TA.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) The trusting, or confiding, or having trust or confidence. (M, K.) [You say, A=mn bihi, meaning He trusted, or confided, in him, or it: for] the verb of AymAn in this sense is trans. by means of bi without implication; as Bd says. (TA.) [And it is also trans. by itself: for] you say, maA A=mana A^ano yajida SaHaAbapF, meaning (tropical:) He trusted not that he would find companions; (M, * K, * TA;) said of one who has formed the intention of journeying: or the meaning is maA kaAda [i. e. he hardly, or scarcely, found &c.; or he was not near to finding &c.]. (M, K.) See also A^aminahu. ― -b4- Also The manifesting humility or submission, and the accepting the Law, (Zj, T, * K,) and that which the Prophet has said or done, and the firm believing thereof with the heart; (Zj, T, M;) without which firm belief, the manifesting of humility or submission, and the accepting that which the Prophet has said or done, is termed A_isolaAmN, for which one's blood is to be spared. (T.) [In this sense, it is trans. by means of li, accord. to some, as shown above; or by means of bi, for, accord. to Fei,] you say, A=manotu biAll~`hi, inf. n. as above, meaning I submitted, or resigned, myself to God. (Msb.) [There are numerous other explanations which it is needless to give, differing according to different persuasions. ― -b5- See also A_iymaAn below.]
8 A_iAotamana see 1, in five places.

10 AstA^mnhu *
He asked, or demanded, of him AlA^amaAn [i. e. security or safety, or protection or safeguard, or the promise or assurance of security or safety, or indemnity, or quarter]. (T, * Msb, TA.) ― -b2- See also A^aminahu. ― -b3- AstA^mn A_ilayohi He entered within the pale of his A^maAn [or protection, or safeguard]. (S, Msb.)

A^amonN * [an inf. n. of A^amini: as a simple subst. it signifies Security, or safety: (see A^amina:) or] security as meaning freedom from fear; contr. of xawofN; (S, M, K;) as also ↓ A_imonN (Zj, M, K) and ↓ A^aminN (M, K) and ↓ A^amanahu (S, M, K) [and ↓ A_imonapN (see A^amina)] and ↓ A^amaAnN and ↓ A=minN, (M, K,) which last is an inf. n. of A^amina [like the rest], (MF,) or a subst. like faAlijN; (M;) and ↓ A^amaAnapN is syn. with A^amaAnN, (S,) both of these signifying security, or safety, and freedom from fear: (PS:) or A^amonN signifies freedom from expectation of evil, or of an object of dislike or hatred, in the coming time; originally, ease of mind, and freedom from fear. (El-Munáwee, TA.) You say, A^anota fiY A^amonK [Thou art in a state of security], (T, M,) mino *aAka [from that]; and ↓ fY A^amaAnK signifies the same; (T;) and so ↓ fY A=minK. (M.) And nuEaAsFA ↓ A^amanapF, in the Kur [iii. 148], means Security (A^amonFA) [and slumber]. (S.) ↓ A^amaAnN also signifies Protection, or safeguard: and [very frequently] a promise, or an assurance, of security or safety; indemnity; or quarter: in Pers. PanaAho and zinohaArN: (KL:) syn. A_il~u. (K in art. Al.) You say, ↓ daxala fiY A^amaAnihi [He entered within the pale of his protection, or safeguard]. (S, Msb.) [And All~`hi ↓ kunN fiY A^amaAni Be thou in the protection, or safeguard, of God.] And ↓ A^aEoTayotuhu AlA^amaAna [I gave, or granted, to him security or safety, or protection or safeguard, or the promise or assurance of security or safety, or indemnity, or quarter]; namely, a captive. (Msb.) And Talaba ↓ minohu AlA^amaAna [He asked, or demanded, of him security or safety, or protection or safeguard, &c., as in the next preceding ex.]. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- A^amonFA in the Kur ii. 119 means *aA A^amon [Possessed of security or safety]: (Aboo-Is-hák, M:) or mawoDiEa A^amonK [a place of security or safety; like maA^omanFA]. (Bd.) ― -b3- See also A=minN. ― -b4- You say also, maA A^aHosana A^amonaka, and ↓ A^amanaka, meaning How good is thy religion! and thy natural disposition! (M, K.)
A_imonN A^mn A^mnn Amn mn mnA mnY |mn |mnn : see A^amonN.
A^amanN * : see A^amonN, first and last sentences.

A^aminN * : see A=minN. ― -b2- Also, (K, [there said to be like katifN,]) or ↓ A=minN, (M, [so written in a copy of that work,)] Asking, or demanding, or seeking, protection, in order to be secure, or safe, or free from fear, for himself: (M, K:) so says IAar. (M.)
A_imonapN A^mn A^mnh A^mnnh Amnh Amnp mn mnA mnY |mn |mnh |mnnh |mnp : see A^amonN.

A^manapN * : see A^amonN, in two places: ― -b2- and see also A^amaAnapN. -A2- Also A man who trusts, or confides, in every one; (T, S, M;) and so ↓ A^umanapN: (S:) and who believes in everything that he hears; who disbelieves in nothing: (Lh, T:) or in whom men, or people, trust, or confide, and whose malevolence, or mischievousness, they do not fear: (T, M:) and ↓ A^umanapN signifies trusted in, or confided in; [like A^amiynN;] and by rule should be A^umonapN, because it has the meaning of a pass. part. n. [like luEonapN and DuHokapN and luqoTalpN &c. (see laqaTN)]: (M:) or both signify one in whom every one trusts, or confides, in, or with respect to, everything. (K.) ― -b2- See also A^amiynN.
A^umanapN * : see A^amanapN, in two places.
A^amaAnN * : see A^amonN, in seven places.

A^amuwnN * , applied to a she camel, of the measure faEuwlN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN, like EaSuwbN and HaluwbN, (tropical:) Trusted, or confided, in; (T;) firmly, compactly, or strongly, made; (T, S, M, K;) secure from, or free from fear of, being weak: (S, M:) also, that is secure from, or free from fear of, stumbling, and becoming jaded: (M:) or strong, so that her becoming languid is not feared: (A, TA:) pl. A^umunN. (M, K.) [See also what next follows.]

A^amynN *
Trusted; trusted in; confided in; (T, * S, * M, Msb, * K;) as also ↓ A^um~aAnN; (S, M, K;) i. q. ↓ maA^omuwnN (S, M, K) and ↓ muw^otamanN: (ISk, T, K:) [a person in whom one trusts or confides; a confidant; a person intrusted with, or to whom is confided, power, authority, control, or a charge, EalaY $aYo'K over a thing; a person intrusted with an affair, or with affairs, i. e., with the management, or disposal, thereof; a confidential agent, or superintendent; a commissioner; a commissary; a trustee; a depositary;] a guardian: (TA:) trusty; trustworthy; trustful; confidential; faithful: (Mgh, Msb: *) pl. A^umanaA='u, and, accord. to some, ↓ A^amanapN, as in a trad. in which it is said, A^aSoHaAbiY A^amanapN liA^um~atiY, meaning My companions are guardians to my people: or, accord. to others, this is pl. of ↓ A=minN [app. in a sense mentioned below in this paragraph, so that the meaning in this trad. is my companions are persons who accord trust, or confidence, to my people]. (TA.) Hence,
A^alamo taEolamiY yaA A^asoma wayoHaki A^an~aniY
Halafotu yamiynFA laA A^axuwnu A^amiyniY
[Knowest thou not, O Asmà (A^asomaA=', curtailed for the sake of the metre), mercy on thee! or woe to thee! that I have sworn an oath that I will not act treacherously to him in whom I trust?] i. e. ↓ maA^omuwniY: (S:) or the meaning here is, him who trusts, or confides, in me; (ISk, T;) [i. e.] it is here syn. with ↓ A=miniY. (M.) [Hence also,] AlA^amiynu fiY AlqimaAri, (K voce mujumidN, &c.,) or A^amiynu, AlqimaAri, [The person who is intrusted, as deputy, with the disposal of the arrows in the game called Almayosir; or] he who shuffles the arrows; Al~a*iY. yaDoribu biAlqidaAHi. (EM p. 105.) [Hence also,] Alr~uwHu AlA^amiynu [The Trusted, or Trusty, Spirit]; (Kur xxvi. 193;) applied to Gabriel, because he is intrusted with the revelation of God. (Bd.) ↓ A^um~aAnN, mentioned above, and occurring in a verse of El-Aashà, applied to a merchant, is said by some to mean Possessed of religion and excellence. (M.) ↓ muw^otamanN is applied, in a trad., to the muw^a*~in, as meaning that men trust, or confide, in him with respect to the times in which he calls to prayer, and know by his call what they are commanded to do as to praying and fasting and breaking fast. (Mgh.) AlmuEaAmalapi ↓ huwa maA^omuwnu means He is [trusty, or trustworthy, in dealing with others; or] free from exorbitance and deceit or artifice or craft to be feared. (Msb.) ― -b2- An aid, or assistant; syn. EawonN [here app. meaning, as it often does, an armed attendant, or a guard]; because one trusts in his strength, and is without fear of his being weak. (M.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) The strong; syn. qawiY~N. (K, TA: [in the latter of which is given the same reason for this signification as is given in the M for that of Ewn; for which qwY may be a mistranscription; but see A^amuwnN.]) ― -b4- One who trusts, or confides, in another; (ISk, T, K;) [as also ↓ A=minN, of which see an ex. voce Ha*irN;] so accord. to ISk in the verse cited above in this paragraph: (T:) thus it bears two contr. significations. (K.) ― -b5- See also A=minN, in five places. -A2- And see A=miyna.

A^amaAnapN * : see A^amonN, first sentence. ― -b2- Trustiness; trustworthiness; trustfulness; faithfulness; fidelity; (M, Mgh, K;) as also ↓ A^amanapN. (M, K.) A^amaAnapu All~`hi [for A^amaAnapu All~`hi qasamiy or maA A^uqosimu The faithfulness of God is my oath or that by which I swear] is composed of an inf. n. prefixed to the agent, and the former is in the nom. case as an inchoative; the phrase being like laEamoru All~`hi, as meaning an oath; and the enunciative being suppressed, and meant to be understood: accord. to some, you say, A^amaAnapa All~`hi [app. for na$adotuka A^amaAnapa All~`hi I adjure thee, or conjure thee, by the faithfulness of God, or the like], making it to be governed in the accus. case by the verb which is to be understood: and some correctly say, waA^amaAnapi All~`hi [By the faithfulness of God], with the w which denotes an oath: (Mgh:) or this last is an oath accord. to Aboo-Haneefeh; but Esh-Sháfi'ee does not reckon it as such: and it is forbidden in a trad. to swear by AlA^amaAnap; app. because it is not one of the names of God. (TA.) [Or these phrases may have been used, in the manner of an oath, agreeably with explanations here following.] -A2- A thing committed to the trust and care of a person; a trust; a deposite; (Mgh, Msb;) and the like: (Msb:) property committed to trust and care: (TA:) pl. A^amaAnaAtN. (Mgh, Msb.) It is said in the Kur [viii. 27], wataxuwnuwA A^amaAnaAtikumo [Nor be ye unfaithful to the trusts committed to you]. (Mgh.) And in the same [xxxiii. 72], A_in~aA EaraDonaAAlA^amaAnapa EalaY Als~mwaAti waAloA^aroDiwaAlojibaAli faA^abayona A^ano yaHomilonahaA waA^a$ofaqona minohaA waHamalahaA AloA_inosaAnu [Verily we proposed, or offered, the trust which we have committed to man to the heavens and the earth and the mountains, and (accord. to explanations of Bd and others) they refused to take it upon themselves, or to accept it, and they feared it, but man took it upon himself, or accepted it: or, (accord. to another explanation of Bd, also given in the T, and in the K in art. Hml, &c.,) they refused to be unfaithful to it, and they feared it, but man was unfaithful to it: but in explaining what this trust was, authors greatly differ: accord. to some,] AlAmAnp here means obedience; so called because the rendering thereof is incumbent: or the obedience which includes that which is natural and that which depends upon the will: [for] it is said that when God created these [celestial and terrestrial] bodies, He created in them understanding: or it may here [and in some other instances] mean reason, or intellect: [and the faculty of volition: and app. conscience: these being trusts committed to us by God, to be faithfully employed: (see an ex. voce ja*orN:)] and the imposition of a task or duty or of tasks or duties [app. combined with reason or intellect, which is necessary for the performance thereof]: (Bd:) or it here means prayers and other duties for the performance of which there is recompense and for the neglect of which there is punishment: (Jel:) or, accord. to I'Ab and Sa'eed Ibn-Jubeyr, (T,) the obligatory statutes which God has imposed upon his servants: (T, K: *) or, (T, K,) accord. to Ibn-'Omar, [the choice between] obedience and disobedience was offered to Adam, and he was informed of the recompense of obedience and the punishment of disobedience: but, in my opinion, he says, (T,) it here means the intention which one holds in the heart, (T, K,) with respect to the belief which he professes with the tongue, and with respect to all the obligatory statutes which he externally fulfils; (K;) because God has confided to him power over it, and not manifested it to any [other] of his creatures, so that he who conceives in his mind, with respect to the acknowledgment of the unity of God, (T, K,) and with respect to belief [in general], (T,) the like of that which he professes, he fulfils the AmAnp [or trust], (T, K,) and he who conceives in his mind disbelief while he professes belief with the tongue is unfaithful thereto, and every one who is unfaithful to that which is confided to him is [termed] HaAmilN, (T,) or HaAmilu AlA^amaAnapi, and muHotamiluhaA: (Bd:) and by AlA_inosaAnu is here meant the doubting disbeliever. (T.) ― -b2- Also, [as being a trust committed to him by God, A man's] family, or household; syn. A^aholN. (TA.)

A^um~aAnN * : see A^amynN, in two places. -A2- Also One who does not write; as though he were (kaA^an~ahu [in the CK lAan~ahu because he is]) an A^um~iY. (K, TA.) [But this belongs to art. Am; being of the measure fuEolaAnN, like EuroyaAnN.] ― -b2- And A sower, or cultivator of land; [perhaps meaning a clown, or boor;] syn. zar~aAEN: (CK:) or sowers, or cultivators of land; syn. zur~aAEN: (K, TA:) in one copy of the K ziraAE. (TA.)

A=minN A=mn
Secure, safe, or free from fear; as also ↓ A^amiynN (Lh, T, * S, * M, Msb, K) and ↓ A^aminN. (M, K.) Hence, in the Kur [xcv. 3], ↓ wah*aA Alobaladi AloA^amiyni [And this secure town]; (Akh, Lh, T, S, M;) meaning Mekkeh. (M.) baladN A=minN and ↓ A^amiynN means A town, or country, or district, of which the inhabitants are in a state of security, or confidence, therein. (Msb.) It is also said in the Kur [xliv. 51], ↓ A_in~a Alomut~aqiyna fiy maqaAmK A^amiynK, meaning [Verily the pious shall be in an abode] wherein they shall be secure from the accidents, or casualties, of fortune. (M.) [And hence,] ↓ AlA^amiynu is one of the epithets applied to God, (Mgh, K,) on the authority of El-Hasan; (Mgh;) an assertion requiring consideration: it may mean He who is secure with respect to the accidents, or casualties, of fortune: but see Almuw^ominu, which is [well known as] an epithet applied to God. (TA.) A=minu AlmaAli means What is secure from being slaughtered, of the camels, because of its being highly prized; by AlmAl being meant AlA_ibil: or, as some say, (tropical:) what is highly esteemed, of property of any kind; as though, if it had intellect, it would feel secure from being exchanged. (M.) You say, A^aEoTayotuhu mino A=mini maAliy, (K, TA, [in the CK A=mani,]) meaning (tropical:) I gave him of the choice, or best, of my property; of what was highly esteemed thereof; (K, TA;) and maAliY ↓ mino A^amoni which Az explains as meaning of the choice, or best, of my property. (TA: [in which is given a verse cited by ISk showing that A^amon, thus used, is not a mistranscription for A=min.]) And A=minu AlHilomi means Steadfast in forbearance or clemency; of whose becoming disordered in temper, and free from self-restraint, there is no fear. (M.) ― -b2- See also A^amiynN, in three places: ― -b3- and see AaminN. -A2- See also A^amiynN, in two places.

A=miyna A=myn [in the CK, erroneously, A=miynu] and ↓ A^amiyna; (Th, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) both chaste and well known, (TA,) the latter of the dial. of El-Hijáz, (Msb, TA,) as some say, (TA,) [and this, though the less common, is the original form, for] the medd in the former is only to give fulness of sound to the fet-hah of the A^, (Th, M, Msb, TA,) as is shown by the fact that there is no word in the Arabic language of the measure faAEiylN; (Msb, TA;) and some pronounce the former A=m~iyna, (K,) which is said by some of the learned to be a dial. var., (Msb,) but this is a mistake, (S, Msb,) accord. to authorities of good repute, and is one of old date, originating from an assertion of Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà, [i. e. Th,] that A=miyna is like EaASiyna, by which he was falsely supposed to mean its having the form of a pl., [and being consequently A=m~iyna,] (Msb, [and part of this is said in the M,]) whereas he thereby only meant that the m is without teshdeed, like the S in EaASiyna; (M;) beside that the sense of qaASidiyna [which is that of A=m~iyna, from A^am~a,] would be inconsistent after the last phrase of the first chapter of the Kur [where A=myna is usually added]; (Msb;) and sometimes it is pronounced with imáleh, [i. e. “émeena,”] as is said by ElWáhidee in the Beseet; (K;) but this is unknown in works on lexicology, and is said to be a mispronunciation of some of the Arabs of the desert of El-Yemen: (MF:) each form is indecl., (S,) with fet-h for its termination, like A^ayona and kayofa, to prevent the occurrence of two quiescent letters together: (T, S, TA:) it is a word used immediately after a prayer, or supplication: (S, * M:) [it is best expressed, when occurring in a translation, by the familiar Hebrew equivalent Amen:] El-Fárisee says that it is a compound of a verb and a noun; (M;) meaning answer Thou me; [i. e. answer Thou my prayer;] (M, Mgh;*) or O God, answer Thou: (Zj, T, Msb, K:) or so be it: (AHát, S, Msb, K:) or so do Thou, (K, TA,) O Lord: (TA:) it is strangely asserted by some of the learned, that, after the Fátihah, [or Opening Chapter of the Kur-án,] it is a prayer which implies all that is prayed for in detail in the Fátihah: so in the Towsheeh: (MF:) or it is one of the names of God: (M, Msb, K:) so says El-Hasan (M, Msb) El-Basree: (Msb:) but the assertion that it is for yaA Aall~`hu [O God], and that AsotajibN [answer Thou] is meant to be understood, is not correct accord. to the lexicologists; for, were it so, it would be with refa, not nasb. (T.)

A_iymaAnN A^ym A^ymAn A_ymAn AymAn ymyn [inf. n. of 4, q. v. ― -b2- Used as a simple subst., Belief; particularly in God, and in his word and apostles &c.: faith: trust, or confidence: &c.] ― -b3- Sometimes it means Prayer; syn. SalaApN: as in the Kur [ii. 138], where it is said, wamaA kaAna All~`hu liyuDiyEa A_iyamAnakumo, (Bd, Jel, TA,) i. e. [God will not make to be lost] your prayer
towards Jerusalem, (Bd, * Jel,) as some explain it. (Bd.) ― -b4- Sometimes, also, it is used as meaning The law brought by the Prophet. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

maA^omanN *
A place of security or safety or freedom from fear; or where one feels secure. (M, TA.)

muw^omanN * pass. part. n. of A=manahu. (T.) It is said in the Kur [iv. 96], accord. to one reading, (T, M,) that of Aboo-Jaafar El-Medenee, (T,) lasota muw^omanFA [Thou art not granted security, or safety, &c.; or] we will not grant thee security, &c. (T, M.)

muw^ominN * [act. part. n. of 4; Rendering secure, &c.]. Almuw^ominu is an epithet applied to God; meaning He who rendereth mankind secure from his wronging them: (T, S:) or He who rendereth his servants secure from his punishment: (M, IAth:) i. q. Almuhayominu, (M,) which is originally Almuw^aA^ominu; [for the form mufoEilN is originally muw^afoEilN;] the second ' being softened, and changed into Y, and the first being changed into h: (S:) or the Believer of his servants (Th, M, TA) the Muslims, on the day of resurrection, when the nations shall be interrogated respecting the messages of their apostles: (TA:) or He who will faithfully perform to his servants what He hath promised them: (T, TA:) or He who hath declared in his word the truth of his unity. (T.) ― -b2- [Also Believing, or a believer; particularly in God, and in his word and apostles &c.: faithful: trusting, or confiding: &c.: see 4.]
maA^omuwnN * : see A^amiynN, in three places. ― -b2- maA^omuwnapN A woman whose like is sought after and eagerly retained because of her valuable qualities. (M.)

maA^omuwniy~apN *
A certain kind of food; so called in relation to El-Ma-moon. (TA.)
muw^otamanN * : see A^amiynN, in two places.

1 A^amiha * , aor.
Aamaha , inf. n. A^amahN, He forgot. (S, K.) Hence the reading of I'Ab, [in the Kur xii. 45,] waAd~akara baEoda A^amahK [And he remembered, or became reminded, after forgetting]. (S.) AHeyth is said to have read baEoda A^amohK; and accord. to AO, A^amohN signifies nisoyaAnN [like A^amahN]; but this is not correct. (Az, TA.) ― -b2- He confessed, or acknowledged: (S, K:) occurring in this sense in a trad. of Ez-Zuhree; but not well known. (S.) The reading of I'Ab, mentioned above, baEoda A^amahK, is explained by A'Obeyd as meaning after confessing, or acknowledging. (TA.)

5 tA^m~h A^um~aA *
He adopted a mother; (M, K;) as also taA^am~amahaA. (M in art. Am.)

A^um~ahapN *
i. q. A^um~N [A mother of a human being and of any animal]: (M, K:) the former is [said by some to be] the original of the latter: (S:) Aboo-Bekr says that the h in the former is a radical letter: (TA:) or the former applies to a rational creature; and the latter, to [a rational and] an irrational: (K:) or, accord. to Az, the pl. of the former applies to the rational; and that of the latter, to the irrational: (TA:) the former sing. sometimes applies to an irrational creature: (IJ, TA:) [for some further remarks on both of these words and their pls., see the latter of them:] the pl. [of the former] is A^um~ahaAtN and [that of the latter is] A^um~aAtN: (T, S:) Az says that the Amw is added in the former for the purpose of distinguishing between the daughters of Adam [to whom it is generally applied] and other animate beings. (TA.)

1 A=mato A=mt , (S, * M, K, [in the CK, erroneously, A=mato,]) second pers. A^amawoti; (S;) and A^amiyato, (M, K,) like samiEato; (K;) and A^amuwato, (Lh, M, K,) like karumatN; (K;) inf. n. A^umuw~apN; (S, M, K;) She (a woman) became a slave; (S, * M, K;) as also ↓ taA^am~ato. (Msb.) -A2- A^amati Als~in~aworu, aor. taA^omuw, inf. n. A^umaA='N, The cat [mewed, or] uttered a cry; (S, K;) like maA='a to, aor. tamuwo'u, inf. n. muwaA='N. (S.)
2 A^am~aAhaA * , (M, K,) inf. n. taA^omiyapN, (K,) He made her a slave. (M, K.)
5 taA^am~atu * : see 1. -A2- tA^m~Y A^amapF He took for himself a female slave; (S, M, Msb, K;) as also ↓ AisotaA^omaAhaA. (S, K.)

8 huwayaA^otamiY bihi *
He follows his (another person's) example; imitates him; i. q. yaA^otam~u bihi (TA in the present art.) And Ay^tmY biAl$~aYo'i [written with the disjunctive alif AiytamaY] is used for Ay^tam~a bihi [He made the thing to be a rule of life or conduct], by substitution [of Y for m], (M and K in art. Am,) the doubling [of the m] being disapproved. (M in that art.)
10 A_isotaAo^aaa see 5.

A^amapN * , originally Amwp, (Msb,) [but whether A^amawapN or A^amowapN is disputed, as will be seen in what follows,] A female slave; (M, K;) a woman whose condition is that of slavery; (T;) contr. of Hur~apN: (S:) [in relation to God, best rendered a handmaid:] dual A^amataAni: (Msb:) pl. A=mK, (Lth, T, S, M, Msb, K, &c.,) like qiADK, (Msb,) a pl. of pauc. [respecting which see what follows after the other pls.], (Lth, T,) and A_imaA='N [the most common form] (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and A_imowaAnN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and A^umowaAnN (K, and so in some copies of the M) and A^amowaAnN (K, and so in some copies of the M) [the last, or last but one, accord. to different copies of the M, on the authority of Lh,] and A^amawaAtN, (M, Msb, K,) for which one may say A^amaAtN. (Ibn-Keysán, TA.) Accord. to Sb (M) and Mbr (TA) it is originally A^amawapN, (S, M, K,) because it has for a pl. A=mK, (S, M,) which is [originally A^aA^omuwN,] of the measure A^afoEulN, (Lth, T, S,) like A=kumN, pl. of A^akamapN, (Sb, M,) and like A^ayonuqN, [pl. of naAqpN, which is originally nawaqpN,] for a sing. of the measure faEolapN has not a pl. of this form; (S;) and Mbr says that there is no noun of two letters but a letter has been dropped from it, which it indicates by its pl. or dual, or by a verb if it is derived therefrom: (TA:) or it is originally faEolapN: (AHeyth, T, K:) AHeyth says that they suppressed its final radical letter, and, forming a pl. from it after the manner of naxolapN and naxolN, instead of saying A^amN, which they disliked as being of only two letters, they transposed the suppressed w, changing it into A, and placing it between the A and m. (T: [in which this opinion, though it does not account for the termination of the pl. A=mK, is said to be preferable.]) One says, jaA='a toniYF A^amapu All~`hi [The handmaid of God came to me]: and in the dual, jaA='a toniY A^mataA All~`hi: and in the pl., jaA='a niY A_imaA='u All~`hi and A_imowaAnu All~`hi and A^amawaAtu All~`hi; and one may also say, A^amaAtu All~`h. (Ibn-Keysán, TA.) [ISd says,] wamaAhu All~`hu mino kul~i A^amapK bHajarK is mentioned by IAar as said in imprecating evil on a man; but I think it is mn kl~ A^amoti [May God cast a stone at him from every elevated place, or the like]. (M.)

A^amawiY~u *
Of, or relating or belonging to, a female slave. (S.)
A^umay~apN * dim. of A^amapN; (S, Msb;) originally A^umayowapN. (Msb.)

1 A^an~a * , aor. yay^in~u, inf. n. A^aniynN and A^unaAnN (S, M, Msb, K) and taA^onaAnN (S, K) and A^an~N, (M, K,) He moaned; or uttered a moan, or moaning, or prolonged voice of complaint; or said, Ah! syn.

taA^aw~aha * ; (M, K;) by reason of pain: (S, TA:) he complained by reason of disease or pain: (TA:) he uttered a cry or cries: (Msb:) said of a man. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- A^an~iti Alqawosu, aor. tay^in~u, inf. n. A^aniynN, The bow made a gentle and prolonged sound. (AHn, M.) -A2- laA A^afoEaluhu maA A^an~a fiY Als~amaA='i najomN means I will not do it as long as there is a star in the heaven: (S, M, K:) A^an~a being here a dial. var. of Ean~a. (S.) You say also, maA A^an~a fiy AlfuraAti qaTorapN As long as there is a drop in the Euphrates. (T, S.) And laA A^afoEaluhu maA A^an~a fiY Als~amaA='N [I will not do it as long as there is rain in the heaven]. (S.) [It is said in the M that Lh mentions the last two sayings; but it is there indicated that he read qaTorapF and samaA='F: and] ISk mentions the saying, laA A^afoEaluhu maA A^an~a fiY Als~amaA='i najomFA, (T, M,) and maA Ean~a fiY Als~amaA='i najomN; (T;) [in the former of which, A^an~ must be a particle (which see below); but it seems that it should rather be A_in~a, in this case, as ISd thinks; for he says,] I know not for what reason An~ is here with fet-h, unless a verb be understood before it, as vabata or wujida: [and he adds,] Lh mentions maA A^an~a *lika Aljabala makaAnahu [as long as that mountain is in its place]: and maA A^an~a HiraA='F makaAnahu [as long as Mount Hirà is in its place]: but he does not explain these sayings. (M.)

A^anN * is a pronoun, denoting the speaker, [I, masc. and fem.,] in the language of some of the Arabs: they say, A^ano faEalotu [I did], with the n quiescent: but most of them pronounce it [↓ A^ana] with fet-h when conjoined with a following word; (Mughnee, K;) saying, A^ana faEalotu: (TA:) and [↓ A^anaA] with A in a case of pause: (Mughnee, K:) and
some pronounce it with A also when it is conjoined with a following word; saying, A^anaA faEalotu; [as we generally find it written in books;] but this is of a bad dialect: (TA:) [this last assertion, however, requires consideration; for the dial. here said to be bad is that of Temeem, accord. to what here follows:] the Basrees hold that the pronoun consists of the ' and the n, and that the [final] A is redundant, because it is suppressed in a case of conjunction with a following word; but the Koofees hold that the pronoun is composed of all the three letters, because the A is preserved in a case of conjunction with a following word in the dial. of Temeem. (Marginal note in a copy of the Mughnee.) [Accord. to Az,] it is best to say ↓ A^anaA in a case of pause; and ↓ A^ana in a case of conjunction with a following word, as in A^ana faEalotu *aAka [I did that]; but some of the Arabs say, faEalotu *aAka ↓ A^anaA; and some make the n quiescent in a case of this kind, though this is rare, saying, A^ano qulotu *aAka [I said that]; and Kudá'ah prolong the former A, saying, qulotuhu ↓ A=na. (T.) [Accord. to J,] ↓ A^anaA is a pronoun denoting the speaker alone, and is made to end invariably with fet-h to distinguish it from the particle A^ano which renders the aor. mansoob; the final A being for the purpose of showing what is the vowel in a case of pause; but when it occurs in the middle [or beginning] of a sentence, it is dropped, except in a bad dialect. (S.) [Accord. to ISd,] ↓ A^ana is a noun denoting the speaker; and in a case of pause, you add A at the end, [saying ↓ A^anaA,] to denote quiescence; (M;) [or] it is better to do this, though it is not always done: (TA:) but it is said, on the authority of Ktr, that there are five dial. vars. of this word; namely, faEalotu ↓ A^ana, and ↓ A^anaA, and ↓ A=na, and A^anN, and ↓ A^anahN, all mentioned by IJ; but there is some weakness in this: IJ says that the h in ↓ A^anahN may be a substitute for the A in A^anaA, because the latter is the more usual, and the former is rare; or it may be added to show what is the vowel, like the h, and be like the h in kitaAbiyaho and HisaAbiyahN. (M.) For the dual, as well as the pl., only naHonu is used. (Az, TA.) ― -b2- It is also a pronoun denoting the person addressed, or spoken to, by assuming the form ↓ A^anota [Thou, masc.]; t being added to it as the sign of the person addressed, (S, M, Mughnee, K,) and A^ano being the pronoun, (M, Mughnee, K,) accord. to the general opinion; (Mughnee, K;) the two becoming as one; not that one is prefixed to the other as governing it in the gen. case: (S:) and so ↓ A^anoti, (S, M, Mughnee, K,) addressed to the female: (S, M:) and ↓ A^anotumaA, (M, Mughnee, K,) addressed to two; not a regular dual, for were it so it would be A^anotaAn; but like kumaA in DarabotukumaA: (M:) and ↓ A^anotumN and ↓ A^anotun~a, (S, Mughnee, K,) which are [respectively] the masc. and fem. pls. (TA.) ― -b3- To each of these the k of comparison is sometimes prefixed; so that you say, ↓ A^anota kaA^anaA [Thou art like me, or as I], and ↓ A^anaA kaA^anota [or A^ana kaA^anota I am like thee, or as thou]; as is related on the authority of the Arabs; for though the k of comparison is not prefixed to the [affixed] pronoun, and you say, A^anota kazayodK but not A^anota kiy, yet the separate pronoun is regarded by them as being in the same predicament as the noun; and therefore the prefixing it to the latter kind of pronoun is approved. (S.) It is said in the Book of layosa, by IKh, that there is no such phrase, in the language of the Arabs, as A^anota kiY, nor as A^anaA kaka, except in two forged verses; wherefore Sb says that the Arabs, by saying A^anota mivoliY and A^anaA mvoluka, have no need of saying A^anota kiY and A^anaA kaka: and the two verses are these:
walawolaA AlbalaA='u lakaAnuwA kanaA
falawolaA AlHayaA=A_u lakun~aA kahumN
[And but for the sense of shame, we had been like them, or as they: and but for trial, or affliction, they had been like us, or as we]: and
A_ino takuno kiY fiA_in~aniy kaka fiyhaA
A_in~anaA fiY AlmalaAmi muSoTaHibaAni
[If thou art like me, or as I, verily I am like thee, or as thou, in respect of her, or it, or them: verily we, in respect of blame, are companions]. (TA.) Az mentions his having heard some of the Benoo-Suleym say, kamaA A^anotaniy, [the latter word being a compound of the pronoun A^anota, regularly written separately, and the affixed pronoun niY,] meaning Wait thou for me in thy place. (TA.) -A2- It is also a particle: and as such, it is—First, a particle of the kind called maSodariY~N, rendering the aor. mansoob: (Mughnee, K:) i. e., (TA,) it combines with a verb [in this case] in the future [or aor.] tense, following it, to form an equivalent to an inf. n., and renders it mansoob: (S, TA:) you say, A^uriydu A^ano taquwma [I desire that thou stand, or that thou wouldst stand, or that thou mayest stand]; meaning A^uriydu qiyaAmaka [I desire thy standing]. (S.) It occurs in two places: first, in that of the inchoative, or in the beginning of a phrase, so that it is in the place of a nom. case; as in the saying [in the Kur ii. 180], waA^ano taSuwmuwA xayorN lakumo [And that ye fast is better for you]; (Mughnee, K;) i. e. SiyaAmukumo [your fasting]. (TA.) And, secondly, after a word denoting a meaning which is not that of certainty: and thus it is the place of a nom. case; as in the saying [in the Kur lvii. 15], A^alamo yaA^ani lil~a*iyna A=manuwA A^anN taxo$aEa quluwbuhumo [Hath not the time that their hearts should become submissive, i. e. the time of their hearts' becoming submissive, yet come unto those who have believed?]: and in the place of an accus. case; as in the saying [in the Kur x. 38], wamaA kaAna h*aA AlqoroA=nu A^ano yufotara' [And this Kur-án is not such that it might be forged; i. e., AfutiriA='N; so in Bd and Jel; and so in a marginal note to a copy of the Mughnee, where is added, meaning mufotarFY forged]: and in the place of a gen. case; as in the saying [in the Kur lxiii. 10], mino qaboli A^ano yaA^otiYa A^aHadakumu Alomawotu [Before that death come unto any one of you; i. e. before death's coming unto any one of you]. (Mughnee, K.) Sometimes it makes the aor. to be of the mejzoom form, (Mughnee, K,) as some of the Koofees and AO have mentioned, and as Lh has stated on the authority of certain of the Benoo-Sabbáh of Dabbeh; (Mughnee;) as in this verse:
A_i*aA maA gadawonaA qaAla wilodaAnu A^aholinaA
taEaAlwogA A_ilaY A^ano yaA^otinaA AlS~ayodu naHoTibi
[When we went away in the morning, the youths of our family, or people, said, Come ye, until that the chase come to us, (i. e. until the coming of the chase to us,) let us collect firewood]. (Mughnee, K.) And sometimes it is followed by an aor. of the marfooa form; as in the saying [in the Kur ii. 233], accord. to the reading of Ibn-Moheysin, limano A^araAda A^ano yutim~u Alr~aDaAEapa [For him who desireth that he may complete the time of sucking; i. e. the completing thereof]; (Mughnee, K;) but this is anomalous, (I 'Ak p. 101, and TA,) or A^ano is here a contraction of A^an~a [for A^an~ahu]: (I 'Ak:) and in the saying of the poet,
A^ano taqaraA=ni Ealay A^asomaA='i wayoHakumaA
min~iY Als~alaAma waA^ano laA tuxobiraA A^aHadaA
[That ye two convey, or communicate, to Asmà, (mercy on you! or woe to you!) from me, salutation, and that ye inform not any one]; but the Koofees assert that A^anN is here [in the beginning of the verse] a contraction of A^an~a, and anomalously conjoined with the verb; whereas the Basrees correctly say that it is A^anN which renders the aor. mansoob, but is deprived of government by its being made to accord with its co-ordinate maA, termed maSodariy~ap; (Mughnee;) or, as IJ says, on the authority of Aboo-'Alee, A^anN is here used by poetic licence for A^an~akumaA; and the opinion of the Baghdádees [and Basrees], that it is likened to maA, and therefore without government, is improbable, because A^ano is not conjoined with a verb in the present tense, but only with the preterite and the future. (M.) When it is suppressed, the aor. may be either mansoob or marfooa; but the latter is the better; as in the saying in the Kur [xxxix. 64], A^afagayora All~`hi taA^omuruwn~iY A^aEobudu [Other than God do ye bid me worship?]. (S.) If it occurs immediately before a preterite, it combines with it to form an equivalent to an inf. n. relating to past time; being in this case without government: you say, A^aEojayaniyA^ano qumota [It pleased me that thou stoodest]; meaning thy standing that is past pleased me: (S:) and thus it is used in the saying [in the Kur xxviii. 82], lawolaA A^anN man~a All~`hu EalayonaA [Were it not for that God conferred favour upon us; i. e., for God's having conferred favour upon us]. (Mughnee.) It is also conjoined with an imperative; as in the phrase mentioned by Sb, katabotu A_ilayhi biA^anp qumN [I wrote to him, Stand; i. e. I wrote to him the command to stand]; which shows that AHei is wrong in asserting that whenever it is conjoined with an imperative it is an explicative [in the sense of A^ayN], and that in this particular instance the b may be redundant, which it cannot here be, because, whether redundant or not, it is not put immediately before anything but a noun or what may be rendered by a noun. (Mughnee.) ― -b2- Secondly, it is a con-
traction of A^an~a; (Mughnee, K;) and occurs after a verb denoting certainty, or one used in a manner similar to that of such a verb: (Mughnee:) so in the saying [in the Kur lxxiii. 20], Ealima A^anN sayakuwnu minokumN maroDay [He knoweth that (the case will be this:) there will be among you some diseased; the affixed pronoun hu, meaning A$~aA^ona, being understood after A^ano, which therefore stands for A^an~ahu, i. e.

A^an~a Al$~aA^ona * ]: (Mughnee, K: *) and in the phrase, balaganiY A^ano qado kaAna ka*aA wka*aA [It has come to my knowledge, or been related to me, or been told to me, or it came to my knowledge, &c., that (the case is this:) such and such things have been]; a phrase of this kind, in which A^ano occurs with a verb, not being approved without qado, unless you say, balaganiY A^an~ahu kaAna ka*aA waka*aA: (Lth, T:) [for] when the contracted A^ano has for its predicate a verbal proposition, of which the verb is neither imperfectly inflected, like layosa and EasaY, nor expressive of a prayer or an imprecation, it is separated from the verb, according to the more approved usage, by qado, or the prefix sa, or sawofa, or a negative, as laA &c., or lawo: (I 'Ak pp. 100 and 101:) but when its predicate is a nominal proposition, it requires not a separation; so that you say, Ealimotu A^ano ziayodN qaAy^imN [I knew that (the case was this:) Zeyd was standing]; (I 'Ak p. 100;) and balaganiY A^ano zaydN xaArijN [It has come to my knowledge, or been related to me, or been told to me, &c., that (the case is this:) Zeyd is going, or coming, out, or forth]; (TA;) except in the case of a negation, as in the saying in the Kur [xi. 17], wA^ano laA A_ilha A_il~aA huwa [And that (the case is this:) there is no deity but He]. (I 'Ak p. 100.) Thus used, it is originally triliteral, and is also what is termed maSodariy~ap; [Ealima A^ano, in the first of the exs. above, for instance, meaning Ealima A^an~ahu, i. e. Ealima A^an~a Al$~aA^ona, which is equivalent to Ealima kawona Al$~aA^oni;] and governs the subject in the accus. case, and the predicate in the nom. case: and its subject must be a pronoun, suppressed, [as in the exs. given above, where it means Al$~aA^oni, and in a verse cited before, commencing A^ano taqoraA=ni, accord. to A'boo-'Alee,] or expressed; the latter, accord. to the more correct opinion, being allowable only by poetic license: and its predicate must be a proposition, unless the subject is expressed, in which case it may be either a single word or a proposition; both of which kinds occur in the following saying [of a poet]:
biA^anoka rabiyEN wgayovN mariyEN
waA^anoka hunaAka takuwna Alv~imaAlaA
[he is speaking of persons coming as guests to him whom he addresses, when their provisions are exhausted, and the horizon is dust-coloured, and the north wind is blowing, (as is shown by the citation of the verse immediately preceding, in the T,) and he says, They know that thou art like rain that produces spring-herbage, and like plenteous rain, and that thou, there, art the aider and the manager of the affairs of people]. (Mughnee.
