[In the T, for rabiyEN, I find Al~arbiyEu; and for waA^anoka, I there find waqidomFA: but the reading in the Mughnee is that which is the more known.]) [J says,] A^ano is sometimes a contraction of A^an~a and does not govern [anything]: you say, balaganiY A^anN zayodN xaArijN [explained above]; and it is said in the Kur [vii. 41], wanuwduwA A^ano tilokumu Aljan~apu [And it shall be proclaimed to them that (the case is this:) that is Paradise]: (S:) [here, however, A^anp is regarded by some as an explicative, as will be seen below:] but in saying this, J means that it does not govern as to the letter; for virtually it does govern; its subject being meant to be understood; the virtual meaning being A^an~ahu tilokumu Aljan~apu. (IB.) [In another place, J says,] You may make the contracted A^ano to govern or not, as you please. (S.) Aboo-Tálib the Grammarian mentions an assertion that the Arabs make it to govern; as in the saying [of a poet, describing a beautiful bosom],
kaA^ano va*oyayohi Huq~aAni
[As though its two breasts were two small round boxes]: but [the reading commonly known is
kaA^ano vadoyaAhu Huq~aAni
(this latter reading is given in De Sacy's Anthol. Gram. Ar. p. 104 of the Ar. text; and both are given in the S;) kaA^ano here meaning kaA^an~ahu; and] Fr says, We have not heard the Arabs use the contracted form and make it to govern except with a pronoun, in which case the desinential syntax is not apparent. (T.) The author of the K says in the B that you say, Ealimotu A^ano zyodFA lamunoTaliqN [I knew that Zeyd was indeed going away], with l when it is made to govern; and Ealimotu A^ano zayodN munoTaliqN [I knew that (the case was this:) Zeyd was going away], without l when it is made to have no government. (TA. [But in the latter ex. it governs the subject, which is understood, as in other exs. before given.]) [See an ex. in a verse ending with the phrase wakaA^ano qadi cited voce qad, where kaA^ano is for kaA^an~ahu, meaning kaA^an~a Al$~A^na, and a verb is understood after qd. And see also A^an~a, below.]― -b2- Thirdly, it is an explicative, (Mughnee, K,) meaning A^ayo (S, M, and so in some copies of the K,) or [rather] used in the manner of A^ayo; (Mughnee, and so in some copies of the K;) [meaning qaAy^ilFA, or qaAy^iliyna; or yaquwlu, or yaquwluwna; or some other form of the verb qaAla; i. e. Saying ; &c.;] as in the saying [in the Kur xxiii. 27], faA^awoHayonaA A_ilayohi A^ani ASonaEi Aloquloka [And we revealed, or spake by revelation, unto him, saying, Make thou the ark]; (Mughnee, K) and [in the Kur vii. 41,]wanuwduwA A^ano tilokumu Alojan~apu [And it shall be proclaimed to them, being said, That is Paradise]; or in these two instances it may be regarded as what is termed maSodariy~ap, by supposing the preposition [bi] understood before it, so that in the former instance it is the biliteral, because it is put before the imperative, and in the second it is the contraction of A^an~a because it is put before a nominal proposition; (Mughnee;) and [in the Kur xxxviii. 5,] waAnoTalaqa AlomalaA^u minohumo A^ani Amo$uwA(S, M, Mughnee) i. e. [And the chief persons of them] broke forth, or launched forth, with their tongues, or in speech, [saying,] Go ye on, or continue ye, in your course of action &c. (Mughnee.) For this usage of A^ano certain conditions are requisite : first, that it be preceded by a proposition : secondly, that it be followed by a proposition; so that you may not say, *akarotu EasojadFA A^ano *ahabFA, but you must say A^aYN in this case, or must omit the explicative : thirdly, that the preceding proposition convey the meaning of Alqawolu, as in the exs. above; in the last of which, AnTlq has the meaning assigned to it above; not that of walking or going away : fourthly, that there be not in the preceding proposition the letters of Alqawolu; so that one may not say, qulotu lahu A^ani AfoEalo; or, if there be in it those letters, that the word which they compose shall be interpreted by another word; as in the saying, in the Kur [v, 117], maA qulotu lahumo A_il~aA maA A^amarotaniY bihi A^ani AEobuduwA All~`ha which may mean, as Z says, I have not commanded them [aught save that which Thou commandedst me, saying, Worship ye God]; (Mughnee;) in which instance Fr says that it is an explicative : (T :) fifthly, that there be not a preposition immediately before it; for if you say, katabotu A_ilayohi biA^ani AfoEalo ka*aA, it is what is termed maSodariy~ap [as we have before shown]. (Mughnee.) When it may be regarded as an explicative and is followed by an aor. with lA as in A^a$arotu A_ilayohi A^ano laA tafoEal ka*aA, it may be marfooa, [namely, the aor.,] on the supposition that lA is a negative ; or mejzoom, on the supposition that it is a prohibitive; and in both cases An is an explicative ; [so that the meaning is, I made a sign to him, as though saying, Thou wilt not do such a thing, in the former case ; or, in the latter, Do not thou such a thing ;] or mansoob, on the supposition that lA is a negative and that An is what is termed maSodariy~ap: but if lA is wanting, it may not be mejzoom, but may be marfooa [if we use An as an explicative] or mansoob [if An be what is termed maSodariy~ap]. (Mughnee.)― -b3- Fourthly, it is redundant, as a corroborative, (Mughnee, K,) like whatever else is redundant : and thus it is in four cases : one of these, which is the most common, being when it occurs after lam~aA denoting time; [and this is mentioned in the M ; ] as in the saying [in the Kur xxix. 32], walm~aA A^ano jaA='a to rusulunaA luwTFA [And when our apostles came to Lot]: (Mughnee:) [or,] accord. to J, (TA,) it is sometimes a connective to lam~aA; as in the saying in the Kur [xii. 96], falam~aA A^ano jaA='a Aloba$iyru [And when that (like as we say, " now that,") the announcer of good tidings came] : and sometimes it is redundant ; as in the saying in the Kur [viii. 34], wamaA lahumo A^ano laA yuEa*ibahumu All~`hu [as though it might be rendered But what reason have they, God should not punish them?] : (S, TA:) but IB says that the connective is redundant ; and [that An is not redundant in the latter instance, for] if it were redundant in this verse of the Kur it would not render the [aor.] verb mansoob. (TA. [The author of the Mughnee, like IB, disallows that An is redundant in a case of this kind, which Kh asserts it to be ; and says that fiY is under-
stood before it.]) The second case is when it occurs between lawN and a verb signifying swearing, the latter being expressed; as in this verse:
faA^uqosimu A^ano lawi A@lotaqayonaA waA^anotumu
lakaAna lanaA yawomN mina Al$~ar~i muZolimu
[And I swear, had we and you met, there had been to us a dark day of evil]: and when that verb is omitted; as in the following ex.:
A^amaA waA@ll~`hi A^ano lawo kunota Hur~iA
wamaA biA@loHuiriA^anota walaA AlEatiyqi
[Verily, or now surely, by God, if thou wert freeborn; but thou art not the freeborn nor the emancipated]: so say Sb and others: Ibn-'Os- foor holds it to be a particle employed to connect the complement of the oath with the oath; but this is rendered improbable by the fact that it is in most cases omitted, and such particles are not. (Mughnee.) The third case, which is extr., is when it occurs between the k [of comparison] and the noun governed by it in the genitive case; as in the saying,
wayawomFA tuwaAfiynaA biwajohK muqas~amK
kaA^anN ZaboyapK taEoTuw A_ilaY waAriqi Als~alamo
[And on a day thou comest to us with a beautiful face, like a doe-gazelle raising her head towards the goodly green-leaved tree of the selem kind], accord. to the reading of him who makes Tbypo to be governed in the genitive case [instead of the accus. or the nom.; for if we read it in the accus. or the nom., A^ano is a contraction of A^an~a; in the former case, Zbyp being its subject, and its predicate being suppressed; and in the latter case, the meaning being kaA^an~ahaA ZaboyapN, so that the subject of An is suppressed]. (Mughnee.) The fourth case is when it occurs after A_i*aA; as in the following ex.:
faA^umohluhu Hat~aY A_*aA A^ano kaA^an~ahu
muEaATiY yadK fiy luj~api AlmaA='i gaAmiru
[And I leave him alone until when he is as though he were a giver of a hand to be laid hold upon, in the fathomless deep of the water immerged]. (Mughnee.) ― -b4- [Fifthly,] among other meanings which have been assigned to it, (Mughnee,) it has a conditional meaning, like A_inN: (Mughnee, K:) so the Koofees hold; and it seems to be most probably correct, for several reasons: first, because both these forms occur, accord. to different readings, in several instances, in one passage of the Kur; as in [ii. 282,] A^ano taDil~N A_iHodaAhumaA [If one of them twain (namely, women,) err]; &c.: secondly, because [the prefix] fa often occurs after it; as in a verse commencing with A^abaA xuraA$apa [as cited voce A^am~aA, accord. to some who hold that A^m~aA in that verse is a compound of the conditional A^ano and the redundant maA; and as in the Kur ii. 282, where the words quoted above are immediately followed by fatu*ak~ira A_iHodaAhumaA A@loA^uxoraY]: thirdly, because it is conjoined with A_inN [which forms a part of the compound A_ik~aA] in this ex.:
A_im~aA A^aqamota waA^am~aA A^anota murotaHilFA
faA@ll~`hu yakolaA^u maA taA^otiY wamaA ta*aru
[If thou remain, and if thou be going away (A^am~aA meaning A^ano kunota, as syn. with A_ino kunota), may God guard thee (yakolaA^u being marfooa because of the f) as long as thou doest and as long as thou leavest undone]: thus related, with kesr to the former An [in A_in~aA] and with fet-h to the latter [in A^am~aA]. (Mughnee.) ― -b5- [Sixthly,] it is a negative, like A_ino: (Mughnee, K:) so, as some say, in [the Kur iii. 66,] A^anE yuw^otaY A^aHadN mivola maA A^uwtiytumo [meaning accord. to them Not any one is given the like of that scripture which ye have been given]: but it is said [by others] that the meaning is, [taken with what precedes it,] And believe not ye that (biA^ano) any one is given the like of that scripture which ye have been given, except it be given to him who followeth your religion; and that the phrase “ say thou, Verily the direction is the direction of God, ” is parenthetic. (Mughnee.) ― -b6- [Seventhly,] it is syn. with A_i*o, (AZ, T, Mughnee, K, [in Freytag's Lex., from the K, A_i*o qiyla, but qyl in the K relates to what there follows,]) as some say, in [the Kur l. 2,] balo EajibuwA A^anN jaA='ahumo muno*irNminohumo [Verily they wonder because a warner from among themselves hath come unto them]; (Mughnee, K;) and in other instances; but correctly, in all these instances, An is what is termed maSodariy~ap, and li denoting cause is understood before it. (Mughnee.) [See also A^am~aA and A_im~aA.] ― -b7- [Eighthly,] it is syn. with liy^al~A, accord. to some, in [the Kur iv. last verse,] yubay~inu A@ll~`huA^ano taDil~uwA [God explaineth to you (the ordinances of your religion, Jel), lest ye should err, or in order that ye may not err]; (Mughnee, K;) and in the saying,
nazalotumo manozila AlA^aDoyaAfi min~aA
faEaj~alonaA AlqiraY A^ano ta$otimuwnaA
[Ye became, or have become, in the condition of our guests; so we hastened, or have hastened, the entertainment, lest ye should revile us, or in order that ye should not revile us]: (Mughnee:) but correctly, in such a case [likewise], An is what is termed maSodariy~ap, and the original wording is karaAhapa A^ano taDil~uwA [from a motive of dislike that ye should err], (Mughnee, K,) and maxaAfapa A^ano ta$otimuwnaA [from a motive of fear that ye should revile us]: so say the Basrees: some say, extravagantly, that l is meant to be understood before it, and Al~a*iY after it. (Mughnee.) ― -b8- [Ninthly,] it occurs in the sense of Al~a*iY; as in the saying, zayodN A^aEoqalu minN A^ano yako*ib [Zeyd is more reasonable than he who lies; which is equivalent to saying, Zeyd is too reasonable to lie: but respecting its usage in a phrase of this kind, and respecting the form of the aor. after it in such a case, see mino]. (Kull p. 78.) ― -b9- By a peculiarity of pronunciation termed EanoEatapN, the tribe of Temeem say Eano instead of A^anN. (M.)

A_inN A^n A_n An wnY |n is used in various ways: first, as a conditional particle, (S, M, Msb, Mughnee, K,) denoting the happening of the second of two events in consequence of the happening of the first, (S, Msb, *) whether the second be immediate or deferred, and whether the condition be affirmative or negative; (Msb;) [and as such it is followed by a mejzoom aor., or by a pret. having the signification of an aor.;] as in the saying, [A_ino tafoEalN A^foEalN If thou do such a thing, I will do it; and] A_ino taA^otiniY A=tika [If thou come to me, I will come to thee]; and A_inN jiy^otaniY A^akoramotuka [If thou come to me, I will treat thee with honour]; (S;) and A_ino faEalota faEalotu [If thou do, I will do] for which the tribe of Teiyi say, as IJ relates on the authority of Ktr, hino faEalota faEalotu; (M;) and A_ino daxalot Ald~aAra A^awN [If thou stand, I will stand]; and A_ino daxaloti Ald~aAra A^awo lamo tadoxuliY Ald~aArD faA^anoti TaAlqN [If thou enter the house, or if thou enter not the house, thou shalt be divorced]; (Msb;) and [in the Kur viii. 39,] A_ino yanotahuwA yugofarN lahumo maA qad salafa [If they desist, what hath already past shall be forgiven them]; and [in verse 19 of the same ch.,] waA_ino taEuwduwA naEudo [But if ye return to attacking the Apostle, we will return to assisting him]. (Mughnee, K.) [On the difference between it and A_i*A, see the latter.] When either it or A_i*aA is immediately followed by a noun in the nom. case, the said noun is governed in that case by a verb necessarily suppressed, of which it is the agent; as in the saying, in the Kur [ix. 6], waA_ino A^aHadN mina A@lomu$orikiyna A@stajaAraka; the complete phrase being waA_ini AsotajaAraka A^aHadN mina A@lomu$orikiyna A@sotajaAraka [And if any one of the believers in a plurality of gods demand protection of thee, (if) he demand protection of thee]: so accord. to the generality of the grammarians. (I 'Ak p. 123.) Sometimes it is conjoined with the negative laA, and the ignorant may imagine it to be the exceptive A_il~aA; as in [the saying in the Kur ix. 40,] A_il~aA tanoSuruwhu faqad naSarahu A@ll~`hu [If ye will not aid him, certainly God did aid him]; and [in the next preceding verse,] A_il~aA tanofiruwA yuEa*~ibokumo [If ye will not go forth to war, He will punish you]. (Mughnee, K. *) It is sometimes used to denote one's feigning himself ignorant; as when you say to one who asks, “ Is thy child in the house? ” and thou hast knowledge thereof, A_ino kaAna fiY Ald~aAri A^aEolamotuka bihi [If he be in the house, I will inform thee thereof]. (Msb.) And to denote one's putting the knowing in the predicament of the ignorant, in order to incite to the doing or continuing an action; as when you say, A_inN kunota A@buniY faA^aTiEoniY [If thou be my son, obey me]; as though you said, “ Thou knowest that thou art my son, and it is incumbent on the son to obey the father, and thou art not obedient; therefore do what thou art commanded to do. ” (Msb.) And sometimes it is divested of the conditional meaning, and becomes syn. with law; as in the saying, Sal~i waA_inN Eajazota Eani AlqiyaAm [Pray thou though thou be unable to stand;] i. e. pray
thou whether thou be able to stand or unable to do so; and in the saying, A^akorimN ziyodFA waA_ino qaEada i. e. [Treat thou Zeyd with honour] though he be sitting; or, whether he sit or not. (Msb.) [A_im~aA as a compound of the conditional A_inN and the redundant maA, see in an art. of which AmA is the heading.] ― -b2- [Secondly,] it is a negative, (S, Mughnee, K,) syn. with maA; (S;) and is put before a nominal proposition; (Mughnee, K;) as in the saying [in the Kur lxvii. 20], A_ini A@lokaAfiruwna A_il~aA fiY guruwrK [The unbelievers are not in aught save in a deception]; (S, Mughnee, K;) and before a verbal proposition; as in [the Kur ix. 108,] A_ino A^aradonaA A_il~aA A@loHusonaY [We desired not, or meant not, aught save that which is best]. (Mughnee, K.) The assertion of some, that the negative A_inN does not occur except where it is followed by A_il~aA, as in the instances cited above, or by lam~aA, with tesh-deed, which is syn. therewith, as, accord. to a reading of some of the Seven [Readers], in the saying [in the Kur lxxxvi. 4], A_ino kul~u nafosK lam~aA EalayohaA HaAfiZN, i. e., maA kul~u nafosK A_il~aA EalayohaA HaAfiZN [There is not any soul but over it is a guardian], is refuted by the sayings in the Kur [x. 69 and lxxii. 26], A_ino Eindakumo mino suloTaAnK bih`*aA [meaning, accord. to the Jel., Ye have no proof of this that ye say], and A_ino A^adoriyA^aqariybN maA tuwEaduwna [I know not whether that with which ye are threatened be nigh]. (Mughnee, K. *) The conditional and the negative both occur in the saying in the Kur [xxxv. 39], walay^ino zaAlataA A_ino A^amosakahumaA mino A^aHadK mino baEodihi [And I swear that, if they should quit their place, not any one should withhold them after Him]: the former is conditional; and the latter is negative, and is [part of] the complement of the oath which is denoted by the l prefixed to the former; the complement of the condition being necessarily suppressed. (Mughnee.) When it is put before a nominal proposition, it has no government, accord. to Sb and Fr; but Ks and Mbr allow its governing in the manner of layosa; and Sa'eed Ibn-Jubeyr reads, [in the Kur vii. 193,] A_ini A@l~a*iyna tadoEuwna mino duwni A@ll~`hi EibaAdFA A^amovaAlakumN [Those whom ye invoke beside God, or others than God, are not men like you]: also, the people of El-'Áliyeh have been heard to say, A_inN A^aHadN xayorFAmino A^aHdK A_il~aA biAlEaAfiyapi [Any one is not better than any other one, except by means of health, or soundness]; and A_ino *`lika naAfiEaka walaA DaAr~aka [That is not profitable to thee nor injurious to thee]: as an ex. of its occurrence without government, which is mostly the case, the saying of some, qaAy^mN ↓ A_in~a may be explained as originally A_inN A^anaA qaAy^imN [I am not standing]; the A^ of A^anaA being elided for no reason in itself, and the n of A_inN being incorporated into the n of A^anaA, and the A of this latter being elided in its conjunction with the following word; but A_in~a qaAy^imFA has also been heard. (Mughnee.) Sometimes it occurs [as a negative] in the complement of an oath: you say, waA@ll~`hi A_inN faEalotu, meaning maA faEalotu [By God, I did not]. (S.) ― -b3- [Thirdly,] it is a contraction of A_in~a, and is put before a nominal and before a verbal proposition. (Mughnee, K.) In the former case, it is made to govern and is made to have no government: (S, * K:) [i. e.] in this case, it is allowable to make it govern; contr. to the opinion of the Koofees: (Mughnee:) Lth says that he who uses the contracted form of A_in~a uses the nom. case with it, except that some of the people of El-Hijáz use the accus. case with it: (T:) thus it is said, accord. to one reading, [in the Kur xi. 113,] A_ino kul~aA lamaA layuwaf~iyan~ahumN rab~uka A^aEomaAlahumN [Verily all of them, thy Lord will indeed fully render them the recompense of their works]: (T, Mughnee:) Fr says, We have not heard the Arabs use the contracted form and make it to govern, unless with a pronoun, in which case the desinential syntax is not apparent; and he adds that in the instance cited above, they make kul~A to be governed in the accus. case by lywf~yn~hm; as though the phrase were layuwaf~iyan~ahumo kul~aA; and that kul~u would be proper; for you say, A_ino zayodN laqaAy^imN [Verily Zeyd is standing]: (T:) the ex. given by Sb is, A_ino EamorFA lamunTaliqN [Verily 'Amr is going away]. (Mughnee.) But it is [most] frequently made to have no government; as in the saying [in the Kur xliii. 34 accord. to one reading], waA_ino kul~u *`lika lamaA mataAEu A@loHayaApi A@ld~unoyaA [And verily all that is the furniture of the present life]; and, accord. to the reading of Hafs, [and of 'Ásim and Kh, in the Kur xx. 66, respecting which see A_in~a,] A_ino h`*aAni lasaAHiraAni [Verily these two are enchanters]; &c. (Mughnee.) When it is put before a verbal proposition, it is necessarily made to have no government: (Mughnee, K:) and in most cases the verb is a preterite and of the kind called naAsix [which effects a change of the grammatical form or of the meaning in a nominal proposition before which it is placed]; as in the saying [in the Kur ii. 138], waA_ino kaAnatN lakabiyrapF [And verily it was a great matter]; and [in the Kur xvii. 75,] waA_ino kaAduwA layafotinuwnaka [And verily they were near to seducing thee]; (Mughnee;) in which last ex. AZ says, it means laqado, i. e. without doubt; and so in the same ch. vv. 78 and 108: (T:) less frequently it is an aor. of a verb of this kind; as in the saying [in the Kur xxvi. 186], waA_ino naZun~uka lamina A@lokaA*ibyna [And verily we think thee to be of the number of the liars]: and both these kinds of expression may be taken as exs. to be imitated: less frequently than this it is a preterite of a verb not of the kind termed nasx; as in the saying [of a poet],
$al~atN yamiynuka A_inN qatalota lamusolimFA
[May thy right arm, or hand, dry up, or become unsound! verily thou hast slain a Muslim]; but this may not be taken as an ex. to be imitated; contr. to the opinion of Akh; for he allows the phrase, A_ino qiAma laA^anaA [Verily I stood], and A_inN qaEada lA^anota [Verily thou sattest]: and less frequently than this it is an aor. of a verb not of the kind termed nAsx; as in the saying, A_ino yaziynuka lanafosuka waA_inN ya$iynuka lahiyahN [Verily thy soul is that which beautifies thee, and it is that which deforms thee]; and this, by common consent, may not be taken as an ex. to be imitated. (Mughnee.) Wherever you find A_inN with la after it, decide that it is originally A_in~a; (Mughnee, K;) as in the exs. above: but respecting this l there is a difference of opinion: see this letter. (Mughnee.) J says, (TA,) A_inN is sometimes a contraction of A_in~a, and this must have l put before its predicate, to compensate for what is elided, of the doubled letter; as in the saying in the Kur [lxxxvi. 4, accord. to him who reads lamaA instead of lam~aA], A_ino kul~u nafosK lamaA EalayohaA HaAfiZN [Verily every soul hath over it a guardian]; and in the saying, A_inN zaydN laA^axuwka [Verily Zeyd is thy brother]; in order that it may not be confounded with A_inN which is syn. with the negative maA: (S, TA:) but IB says, l is here introduced to distinguish between negation and affirmation, and this A_ino has neither subject nor predicate; so J's saying that the l is put before its predicate is without meaning: and this l is sometimes introduced with the objective complement of a verb; as in A_ino Darabotu lazayodFA [Verily I struck, or beat, Zeyd]; and with the agent; as in A_ino qaAma lazayodN [Verily Zeyd stood]. (TA.) When the contracted A_ino governs, this l is not necessary; so you may say, A_ino zayodFA qaAy^imN [Verily Zeyd is standing]; because in this case it cannot be confounded with the negative; for the negative does not render the subject mansoob and the predicate marfooa: and when it does not govern, if the meaning is apparent, the l is not needed; as in
wanaHonu A^ubaApu AlD~ayomi mino A=li maAlikK
waA_ino maAlikN kaAnato kiraAma AlmaEaAdini
[And we are persons who refuse to submit to injury, of the family of Málik: and verily the family of Málik are generous in respect of their origins]; kaAnato being here for lakaAnatN. (I 'Ak p. 99.) ― -b4- [Fourthly,] it is redundant, (S, Mughnee, K,) occurring with maA; as in the saying, maA A_ino yaquwmu zayodN [Zeyd does not stand]; (S;) and in the saying [of a poet],
kaA A_ino A^atayota bi$oY'K A^anota takorahuhu
[Thou didst not a thing which thou dislikest]. (Mughnee, K: in the CK Aatotu.) It is mostly thus used after the negative mA, when put before a verbal proposition; as above; or before a nominal proposition; as in the saying,
manaAyaAnaA wadawolapu A=xariynaA
wamaA A_ino Tib~unaA jbunN wl`kinN
[And our habit is not cowardice; but our destinies and the good fortune of others caused our being defeated]: and in this case it prevents the government of mA, as in this verse: but in the saying,
baniY gudaAnapa maA A_ino A^anotumu *ahabFA
walaA SariyfFA wal`kinN A^anotumu Alxazafu
[Sons of Ghudáneh, ye are not indeed gold, nor silver, or pure silver, but ye are pottery], accord. to him who relates it thus, saying *hbFA and SryfFA, in the accus. case, it is explained as a negative, corroborative of mA: (Mughnee:) and accord. to J,
(TA,) the negatives maA and A_inN are sometimes thus combined for corroboration; as in the saying of the rájiz, (El-Aghlab El-'Ijlee, TA,)
A^akovara minohu qirapF waqaAraA
maA A_inN raA^ayonaA malik~aA A^agaAraA
[We have not indeed seen a king who has made a hostile incursion possessing more numerous sheep, or goats, and camels, than he]; (S, TA;) but IB says that An is here redundant, not a negative. (TA.) Sometimes it is redundant after the conjunct noun maA; as in the saying,
yurajiY~ AlmaroA_u maA A_inN laA yaraAhu
wataEoriDu duwna A^adonaAhu AlxuTuwbu
[Man hopes for that which he will not see; for calamities intervene as obstacles in the way to what is nearest thereof]. (Mughnee.) And after the maA termed maSodariy~ap, (Mughnee,) [i. e.,] after the adverbial maA [which is of the kind termed mSdry~p]; (TA;) as in the saying (of Maaloot El-Kurey'ee, cited by Sb, TA),
waraj~i AlfataY liloxayori maA A_ino raA^ayotahu
Ealay Als~in~i xayorFA laAyazaAlu yaziydu
[And hope thou that the youth is destined for good as long as thou hast seen him not ceasing to increase in good with age]. (Mughnee.) And after the inceptive A^alaA; as in the saying,
A^alaA A_ino saraY layoliY fbit~u kay^iybaA
A^uHaA*iru A^ano tanoA^aY Aln~awaY bigaDuwbaA
[Now he journeyed on, or during, that my night, and I passed the night in an evil state, broken in spirit by grief, being fearful that the distance to which he was going with Ghadoob (a woman so named) would become far]. (Mughnee.) And before the meddeh denoting disapproval: [for] Sb heard a man, on its being said to him, “ Wilt thou go forth if the desert become plentiful in herbage? ” reply, A^aA^anaA A_iniyhN [What, I, indeed?] disapproving that he should think otherwise than that. (Mughnee. [See also art. AnY.]) ― -b5- [Fifthly,] it is syn. with qado: so it is said to be in the saying [in the Kur lxxxvii. 9], A_ino nafaEati A@l*~ikoraY [Admonition hath profited], (T, Mughnee, K,) by IAar (T) and by Ktr: (Mughnee:) and Abu-l-' Abbás relates that the Arabs say, A_inN nafaEati A@l*~ikoraY meaning qadoqaAma zayodN [Zeyd has stood]; and he adds, that Ks states his having heard them say so, and having thought that it expressed a condition, but that he asked them, and they answered that they meant qadoqaAma zayodN, and not maA qaAma zayodN. (T.) [So too, accord. to the K, in all the exs. cited in the next sentence as from the Mughnee; but this is evidently a mistake, occasioned by an accidental omission.] ― -b6- [Sixthly,] it is asserted also by the Koofees, that it is syn. with A_i*o, in the following exs.: in the Kur [v. 62], waA@t~aquwA A@ll~`ha A_inN kunotumo muw^ominiyna [And fear ye God, because ye are believers: and so, accord. to AZ, as is said in the T, in a similar instance in the Kur ii. 278: and in the same, iv. 62]: and [in the Kur xlviii. 27,] latado xulun~a A@lmasojida A@loHaraAma A_ino $aA='a A=miniyna [Ye shall assuredly enter the sacred mosque, because God hath willed, in security]: and in like instances, when the verb therein expresses what is held sure to happen or to have happened: and in the saying,
A^atagoDabu A_inN A^udonaA qutayobapa Huz~ataA
jihaArFA walamo tagoDabo liqatoli A@boni HaAzimi
[Art thou angry because the ears of Kuteybeh have been cut, openly, or publicly, and wast not angry for the slaughter of Ibn-Házim?]: (Mughnee:) but in all these instances [it is sufficiently obvious that] An may be otherwise explained. (Mughnee, K.) ― -b7- [Seventhly,] it is sometimes syn. with A_i*aA; as in the Kur [ix. 23], laA tat~axi*uwA A=baA='akumo waA_ixowaAnakumo A^awoliyaA='a A_ini A@sotaHab~uwA A@lokuforaEalaY A@loA_iymaAni [Take not ye your fathers and your brethren as friends when they love unbelief above belief]; and in the same [xxxiii. 49], waA@moraA^apF muw^ominapF A_ino wahabato nafosahaA liln~abiY~ [And a believing woman when she giveth herself to the Prophet]: so says AZ. (T.) ― -b8- [Eighthly,] it is used for A_im~aA, (Mughnee and K, voce A_im~aA,) distinct from A_im~aA which is a compound of the conditional A_inN and the redundant maA. (Mughnee ibid.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce A_im~aA in the present work, commencing with the words saqatohu Alr~awaAEidu.]
A^ana * : see A^ano, in four places.

A^an~a * is one of the particles which annul the quality of the inchoative; and is originally A_in~a; therefore Sb has not mentioned it among those particles [as distinct from A_in~a, from which, however, it is distinguished in meaning]: (I 'Ak p. 90:) it is a corroborative particle; (I 'Ak, Mughnee;) a particle governing the subject in the accus. case and the predicate in the nom. case, (S, I 'Ak, Mughnee, K,) combining with what follows it to form an equivalent to an inf. n., (S,) [for,] accord. to the most correct opinion, it is a conjunct particle, which, together with its two objects of government, is explained by means of an inf. n. (Mughnee.) If the predicate is derived, the inf. n. by means of which it is explained is of the same radical letters; so that the implied meaning of balaganiy A^an~aka tanoTaliqu [It has come to my knowledge, or been related to me, or been told to me, or it came to my knowledge, &c., that thou goest away], or A^an~aka munoTaliqN [that thou art going away], is balaganiy AlAinoTilaAqu [or rather A@noTilaAquka thy going away has come to my knowledge, &c.]; and hence, the implied meaning of balaganiY A^an~aka fiy Ald~aAri [It has come to my knowledge, &c., that thou art in the house] is balaganiY A@sotiqoraAruka fiy Ald~aAri [thy remaining in the house has come to my knowledge, &c.], because thea predicate is properly a word suppressed from Aistaqar~a or musotaqir~N: and if the predicate is underived, the implied meaning is explained by the word kawoni; so that the implied meaning of balaganiY A^an~a h`*A zayodN [It has come to my knowledge, &c., that this is Zeyd] is balaganiY kawonuhu zayodFA [his being Zeyd has come to my knowledge, &c.]; for the relation of every predicate expressed by an underived word to its subject may be denoted by a word signifying “ being; ” so that you say, h`*aA zayodN and, if you will, h`*aA kaAy^inN zayodFA; both signifying the same. (Mughnee.) There are cases in which either A^an~a or A_in~a may be used: [see the latter, in twelve places:] other cases in which only the former may be used: and others in which only the latter. (I 'Ak p. 91.) The former only may be used when the implied meaning is to be explained by an inf. n. (I 'Ak, K.) Such is the case when it occurs in the place of a noun governed by a verb in the nom. case; as in yuEojibuniY A^an~aka qaAy^imN [It pleases me that thou art standing], i. e. qiyaAmuka [thy standing pleases me]: or in the place of a noun governed by a verb in the accus. case; as in Earafotu A^at~aka qaAy^imN [I knew that thou wast standing], i. e. qiyaAmaka [thy standing]: or in the place of a noun governed in the gen. case by a particle; as in Eajibotu mino A^an~aka qaAy^imN [I wondered that thou wast standing], i. e. mino qiyaAmka [at, or by reason of, thy standing]: (I 'Ak p. 91:) [and sometimes a preposition is understood; as in laA $ak~a A^an~ahu ka*aA, for laA $ak~a fiY A^an~ahu ka*aA There is no doubt that it is thus, i. e. laA $~k~a fiY kawonihi ka*aA There is no doubt of its being thus:] and A^an~a must be used after lawo; as in lawo A^an~aka qaAy^imN laqumotu [If that thou wert standing, I had stood, or would have stood, i. e. lawo vabata qiyaAmuka, or lawo qiyaAmuka vaAbitN, accord. to different opinions, both meaning if thy standing were a fact: see I 'Ak pp. 305 and 306]. (K.) Sometimes its A^ is changed into E; so that you say, Ealimotu Ean~aka munoTaliqN [meaning I knew that thou wast going away]. (M.) ― -b2- With k prefixed to it, it is a particle of comparison, (S, * M, TA,) [still] governing the subject in the accus. case and the predicate in the nom. case: (TA:) you say, kaA^an~a zayodFA EamorNw [It is as though Zeyd were 'Amr], meaning that Zeyd is like 'Amr; as though you said, A_in~a zayodFA kaAy^inN kaEamorKw [verily, Zeyd is like 'Amr]: [it is to be accounted for by an ellipsis: or] the k is taken away from the middle of this proposition, and put at its commencement, and then the kesreh of A_in~a necessarily becomes changed to a fet-hah, because A_in~a cannot be preceded by a preposition, for it never occurs but at the commencement [of a proposition]. (IJ, M.) Sometimes, kaA^an~a denotes denial; as in the saying, kaA^an~aka A^amiyrunaA fataA^omuranaA [As though thou wert our commander so that thou shouldst command us], meaning thou art not our commander [that thou shouldst command us]. (TA.) It also denotes wishing; as in the saying, kaA^on~aka biy qado qulotu Al$~iEora faA^ujiydahu, meaning Would that I had poetized, or versified, so that I might do it well: (TA:) [an elliptical form of speech, of which the implied meaning seems to be, would that I were as though thou sawest me that I had poetized, &c.; or the like: for] you say [also], kaA^an~iY bika meaning kaA^an~iY A^aboSuru bika [It is as though I saw thee]; i. e. I know from what I witness of thy condition to-day how thy condition will be tomorrow; so that it is as though I saw thee in that condition: (Har p. 126: [see also bi; near
the end of the paragraph:]) [thus,] kaA^an~a also denotes knowing; and also thinking; [the former as in the saying immediately preceding, and] as when you say, kaA^an~a A@ll~`ha yafoEalu maA ya$aA='u [I know, or rather it appears, as though seen, that God does what He wills]; and [the latter as when you say,] kaA^an~aka xaArijN [I think, or rather it seems, that Thou art going forth]. (TA.) ― -b3- [When it has The affixed pronoun of the first person, sing. Or Pl., you say, A^an~iY and A^an~aniY, and A^an~aA and A^an~anaA: and When it has also the k of comparison prefixed to It,] you say, kaA^an~iY and kaA^an~aniY, [and kaA^an~aA and kaA^an~anaA,] like as you say, l`kin~iY and l`kin~aniY [&c.]. (S.) ― -b4- As A^an~a is a derivative from A_in~a, it is correctly asserted by Z that A^an~amaA imports restriction, like ↓ A_in~amaA; both of which occur in the saying in the Kur [xxi. 108], yuwHaY A_ilaY~a A^an~amaA ↓ qulo A_in~amaA
A_il`hukumo A_il`hF waAHidN [Say thou, It is only revealed to me that your God is only one God]: the former is for the restricting of the quality to the qualified; and the latter, for the reverse: (Mughnee, K:) i. e. the former is for the restricting of the revelation to the declaration of the unity; and the latter, for the restricting of “ your God ” to unity: (Marginal note in a copy of the Mughnee:) but these words of the Kur do not imply that nothing save the unity was revealed to the Prophet; for the restriction is limited to the case of the discourse with the believers in a plurality of gods; so that the meaning is, there has not been revealed to me [aught], respecting the godhead, except the unity; not the attribution of any associate to God. (Mughnee.) [A^an~amaA, however, does not always import restriction; nor does always even ↓ A_in~amaA: in each of these, mA is what is termed kaAf~apN; i. e., it restricts the particle to which it is affixed from exercising any government; and sometimes has no effect upon the signification of that particle: (see art. maA; and see A_in~amaA, below, voce A_in~a:) thus, for instance, in the Kur viii. 28, waA@EolamuwA A^an~amaA A^amowaAlukumo fitonapF means And know ye that your possessions and your children are a trial; not that they are only a trial. When it has the k of comparison prefixed to it, it is sometimes contracted; as in the following ex.:] a poet says,
kaA^am~aA yaxotaTiyna Ea$laY qataAdK
wayasotaDoHikona Eano Hab~i AlgamaAmi
[As though, by reason of their mincing gait, they were walking upon tragacanthas; and they were laughing so as to discover teeth like hailstones: kaA^am~aA being for kaA^an~amaA. (IAar.) ― -b5- A^an~a is someTimes contracted into A^ano; (S, Mughnee;) and in This case, it governs in the manner already exPlained, voce A^ano. (Mughnee.) ― -b6- It is also syn. with laEal~a; (Sb, S, M, Mughnee, K;) as in the saying, Aiyti Als~uwqa A^an~aka ta$otariY lanaA $ayoy^FA [Come thou to the market; may-be thou wilt buy for us something; Aiyti being originally Aiy^oti]; i. e. laEal~aka: (Sb, M, Mughnee, K: *) and, accord. to some, (M, Mughnee, K,) so in the Kur [vi. 109], where it is said, wamaA yu$oEirukumo A^an~ahaA A_i*aA jaA='ato laA yuw^ominuwna [And what maketh you to know? (meaning, maketh you to know that they will believe when it cometh? i. e. ye do not know that: Jel:) Maybe, when it cometh, they will not believe]: (S, M, Mughnee, K:) thus accord. to this reading: (Mughnee, K:) and Ubeí here reads laEal~ahaA. (S.) A^an~a and laA^an~a and lawo A^an~a are all syn. with Eal~a and laEal~a; and A^an~iY and A^an~aniY, and laA^an~iY and lA^an~aniY, and luwo A^an~iY and lawo A^an~iniY, with Eal~iY and laEal~iY. (K voce laEal~a.) ― -b7- It is also syn. with A^ajalo [Yes, or yea; or it is as thou sayest]. (M, TA.) [See also A_in~a as exemplified by a verse commencing with wayaqulona and by a saying of Ibn-Ez-Zubeyr.]

A_in~a A^n A_n An wnY |n is one of the particles which annul the quality of the inchoative, like A^an~a, of which it is the original: (I 'Ak p. 90:) it is a corroborative particle, (I 'Ak, Mughnee,) corroborating the predicate; (S, K;) governing the subject in the accus. case and the predicate in the nom. case; (S, I 'Ak, Mughnee, K;) [and may generally be rendered by Verily, or certainly, or the like; exactly agreeing with the Greek ὃτι, as used in Luke vii. 16 and in many other passages in the New Testament; though it often seems to be nothing more than a sign of inception, which can hardly be rendered at all in English; unless in pronunciation, by laying a stress upon the predicate, or upon the copula;] as in the saying, A_in~a zayodFA qaAy^imN [Verily, or certainly, Zeyd is standing; or simply, Zeyd is standing, if we lay a stress upon standing, or upon is]. (I 'Ak p. 90.) But sometimes it governs both the subject and the predicate in the accus. case; as in the saying,
A_i*aA A@$otad~a junoHu All~ayoli falotaA^oti walotakunN
xuTaAka xifaAfFA A_in~a Hur~aAsanaA A^usodaA
[When the darkness of night becomes, or shall become, intense, then do thou come, and let thy steps be light: verily our guardians are lions]; (Mughnee, K; [but in the latter, for A@$otad~a, we find A@sowad~a, so that the meaning is, when the first portion of the night becomes, or shall become, black, &c.;]) and as in a trad. in which it is said, An~a qaEora jahan~ama saboEiyna xariyfFA [Verily the bottom of Hell is a distance of seventy years of journeying]: (Mughnee, K:) the verse, however, is explained by the supposition that it presents a denotative of state [in the last word, which is equivalent to $ijoEaAnFA or the like], and that the predicate is suppressed, the meaning being, taloqaAhumo A^usodFA [thou wilt find them lions]; and the trad. by the supposition that qaEora is an inf. n., and saboEiyna is an adverbial noun, so that the meaning is, the reaching the bottom of hell is [to be accomplished in no less time than] in seventy years. (Mughnee.) And sometimes the inchoative [of a proposition] after it is in the nom. case, and its subject is what is termed Damiyru $aA^onK, suppressed; as in the saying of Mohammad, A_in~a mino A^a$ad~i Aln~aAsi Ea*aAbFA yawoma Alqiy`mapi AlmuSaw~iruwna [Verily, (the case is this:) of the men most severely to be punished, on the day of resurrection, are the makers of images], originally A_in~ahu, i. e. A_in~a Al$~aA^ona; (Mughnee, K; *) and as in the saying in the Kur [xx. 66], A_in~a h`*aAni lasaAHiraAni, [accord. to some,] as will be seen in what follows. (TA.) ― -b2- Of the two particles A_in~a and ↓ A^an~a, in certain cases only the former may be used; and in certain other cases either of them may be used. (I' Ak p. 91.) The former must be used when it occurs inceptively, (Kh, T, I' Ak p. 92, Mughnee, K,) having nothing before it upon which it is syntactically dependent, (Kh, T,) with respect to the wording or the meaning; (K;) as in A_in~a zayodFA qaAy^imN [Verily Zeyd is standing]. (I' Ak, K.) It is used after A^alaA, (I' Ak, K,) the inceptive particle, (I' Ak,) or the particle which is employed to give notice [of something about to be said]; (K;) as in A^alaA A_in~a zayodFA qaAy^imN [Now surely Zeyd is standing]. (I' Ak K.) And when it occurs at the commencement of the complement of a conjunct noun; (I' Ak, K; *) as in jaA='a Al~a*iY A_in~ahu qaAy^imN [He who is standing came]; (I' Ak;) and in the Kur [xxviii. 76], waA=tayonaAhu mina A@lokunuwri maA A_in~a mafaAtiHahu latanuwo'u biA@loEuSobapi A^uwliY Alquw~api [And we gave him, of treasures, that whereof the keys would weigh down the company of men possessed of strength]. (I' Ak, * K, * TA.) And in the complement of an oath, (I' Ak, K,) when its predicate has la, (I' Ak,) or whether its subject or its predicate has la or has it not; (K;) as in waA@ll~`hi A_in~a zayodFA laqaAy^imN [By Allah, verily Zeyd is standing], (I' Ak,) and A_in~ahu qaAy^imN: or, as some say, when you do not employ the l, the particle is with fet-h; as in qaAy^imN ↓ waA@ll~`hi A^an~aka [I swear by Allah that thou art standing]; mentioned by Ks as thus heard by him from the Arabs: (TA:) but respecting this case we shall have to speak hereafter. (I' Ak.) And when it occurs after the word qawolN or a derivative thereof, in repeating the saying to which that word relates; (Fr, T, I' Ak, * K; *) as in the saying [in the Kur iv. 156], waqawolihimo A_in~aA qatalonaA A@lomasiyHa [And their saying, Verily we have slain the Messiah]; (Fr, T;) and qulotu A_in~a zayodFA qaAy^imN [I said, Verily Zeyd is standing]; (I' Ak;) and [in the Kur v. 115,] qaAla A@ll~`hu A_in~Y mun~z~iluhaA Ealayokumo [God said, Verily I will cause it to descend unto you]; accord. to the dial. of him who does not pronounce it with fet-h: (K:) but when it occurs in explaining what is said, you use ↓ A^an~a; as in the saying, qado qulotu laka kalaAmFA HasanFA A^an~a A^abaAka $ariyfN waA^an~aka EaAqilN [I have said to thee a good saying; that thy father is noble and that thou art intelligent]; (Fr, T;) or when the word signifying “ saying ” is used as meaning “ thinking; ” as in A^ataquwlu A^an~a zayodFA qaAy^imN [Dost thou say that Zeyd is standing?], meaning A^ataZun~u [Dost thou think?]. (I' Ak.) Also, when it occurs in a phrase denotative of state; (I' Ak;) [i. e.,] after the w denotative of state; (K;) as in zurotuhu waA_in~iY *uwA^amalK [I visited him, I verily having hope, or expectation]; (I' Ak;) and in jaA='a ziyodN wa A_in~a yadahu EalaY raA^osihi [Zeyd came, he verily having his hand upon his head]. (K.) And when it occurs in a phrase which is the predicate of a proper (as
opposed to an ideal) substantive; (I' Ak, K; *) as in zayodN A_in~ahu qaAy^imN [Zeyd, verily he is standing], (I' Ak,) or *aAhibN [going away]; contr. to the assertion of Fr. (K.) And when it occurs before the l which suspends the grammatical government of a verb of the mind, preceding it, with respect to its objective complements; (I' Ak, K; *) as in Ealimotu A_in~a zayodFA laqaAy^imN [I knew Zeyd verily was standing]; (I' Ak;) and in [the Kur lxiii. 1,] waA@ll~`hu yaEolamu A_in~aka larasuwluhu [And God knoweth thou verily art his apostle]: (K:) but if the l is not in its predicate, you say, ↓ A^an~a; as in Ealimotu A^an~a zayodFA qaAy^imN [I knew that Zeyd was standing]. (I' Ak.) And in the like of the saying in the Kur [ii. 171], waA_in~a A@l~a*iyna A@xotalafuwA fiY A@lokitaAbi lafiY $aqaAqK baEiydK [And verily they who differ among themselves respecting the book are in an opposition remote from the truth]; because of the l [of inception] which occurs after it, in lafiY: (Ks, A 'Obeyd:) the l of inception which occurs before the predicate of A_in~a should properly commence the sentence; so that A_in~a zayodFA laqaAy^imN [Verily Zeyd is standing] should properly be laA_in~a zayodFA qaAy^imN; but as the l is a corroborative and A_in~a is a corroborative, they dislike putting two particles of the same meaning together, and therefore they put the l later, transferring it to the predicate: Mbr allows its being put before the predicate of ↓ A^an~a; and thus it occurs in an unusual reading of the saying [in the Kur xxv. 22], A_il~aA A^an~ahumo layaA^okuluwna A@lT~aEaAma [But they ate food]; but this is explained by the supposition that the l is here redundant: (I' Ak p. 95:) this is the reading of Sa'eed Ibn-Jubeyr: others read, A_il~aA A_in~ahumo layaA^okuluna AlT~aEaAma [but verily they ate food]: and A_in~a [as well as ↓ A^an~a] is used after the exceptive A_il~aA when it is not followed by the l [of inception]. (TA.) Also, When it occurs after Hayovu; as in Aijoliso Hayovu A_in~a zayodFA jaAlisN [Sit thou where Zeyd is sitting]. (I' Ak p. 92, and k) And after Hat~aY; as in mariDa zayodN Hat~aY A_in~ahumo laA yarojuwnahu [Zeyd has fallen sick, so that verily they have no hope for him: whereas after a particle governing the gen. case, [i. e. a preposition,] you say, ↓ A^an~a. (IHsh in De Sacy's Anthol. Gr. Ar. P. 76.) ― -b3- Either of these two forms may be used after A_i*aA denoting a thing's happening suddenly, or unexpectedly; as in xarajotu faA_i*aA A_in~a zayodFAqaAy^imN [I went forth, and lo, verily Zeyd was standing], and zayodFA qaAy^imN ↓ faA_i*aA A^an~a [and lo, or at that present time, Zeyd's standing]; in which latter case, A^an~a with its complement is [properly] an inchoative, and its enunciative is A_i*aA; the implied meaning being, and at that present time was the standing of Zeyd: or it may be that the enunciative is suppressed, and that the implied meaning is, [and lo, or at that present time,] the standing of Zeyd was an event come to pass. (I' Ak p. 93.) Also, when occurring in the complement of an oath, if its enunciative is without l: (I' Ak:) [see exs. given above:] or, as some say, only ↓ A^an~a is used in this case. (TA.) Also, when occurring after fa denoting the complement of a condition; as in mano yaA^otiniY faA_in~ahu mukoramN [He who cometh to me, verily he shall be treated with honour], and mukoramN ↓ A^an~ahu; in which latter case, A^an~a with its complement is an inchoative, and the enunciative is suppressed; the implied meaning being, honourable treatment of him shall be an event come to pass: or it may be an enunciative to an inchoative suppressed; the implied meaning being, his recompense shall be honourable treatment. (I' Ak p. 94.) Also, when occurring after an inchoative having the meaning of a saying, its enunciative being a saying, and the sayer being one; as in xayoru Alqawoli A_in~Y A^aHomadu [The best saying is, Verily I praise God], and A^aHomadu ↓ A^an~iY; in which latter case, A^an~a with its complement is an enunciative of xayoru; the implied meaning being, the best saying is the praising of God [or my praising of God]. (I' Ak ubi suprà.) You also say, lab~ayoka A_in~a AlHamodalaka [At thy service ! Verily praise belongeth to Thee! O God]; commencing [with A_in~a] a new proposition: and sometimes one says, ↓ A^an~a; meaning biA^an~a AlHamoda laka [because praise belongeth to Thee]. (Msb.) ― -b4- The cases in which A_in may not be used in the place of A^an~a have been mentioned above, voce A^an~a. ― -b5- [When it has the affixed pronoun of the first person, sing. or pl.,] you say, A_in~iY and A_in~aniY, (S,) and A_in~aA and A_in~anaA, (TA,) like as you say l`kin~iY and l`kin~iniY [&c.]. (S.) A_in~a as a contraction of A_in~a A^anaA has been mentioned above, as occurring in the phrase A_in~a qaAy^imN, voce A_ino, q. v. ― -b6- Accord. to the grammarians, (T,) A_in~amaA is a compound of A_in~a and maA, (T, S,) which latter prevents the former's having any government: (T:) it imports restriction; like A^an~amaA, which see above, voce A^an~a, in three places: (Mughnee, K:) [i. e.] it imports the restriction of that which it precedes to that which follows it; as in A_in~amaA zayodN munoTaliqN [Zeyd is only going away], and A_in~amaA yanoTaliqu zayodN [Only Zeyd goes away]: (Bd in ii. 10:) [in other words,] it is used to particularize, or specify, or distinguish a thing from other things: (S:) it affirms a thing in relation to that which is mentioned after it, and denies it in relation to other things; (T, S;) as in the saying in the Kur [ix. 60], A_in~amaA A@lS~adaqaAtu lilofuqaraA='i [The contributions levied for pious uses are only, or but, for the poor]: (S:) but El- Ámidee and AHei say that it does not import restriction, but only corroboration of an affirmation, because it is a compound of the corroborative A_in~a and the redundant maA which restrains the former from exercising government, and that it has no application to denote negation implied in restriction, as is shown by the trad., A_in~amaA Al~iribaA fiY Aln~asiyoy^api [which must mean, Verily usury is in the delay of payment], for usury is in other things beside that here mentioned, as ribaA AlfDoli [or profit obtained by the superior value of a thing received over that of a thing given], by common consent: (Kull p. 76:) some say that it necessarily imports restriction: J says what has been cited above from the S: some say that it has an overt signification in denoting restriction, and is susceptible of the meaning of corroboration: some say the reverse of this: El-Ámidee says that if it were [properly] restrictive, its occurrence in another sense would be at variance with the original import; but to this it may be replied, that if it were [properly] corroborative, its occurrence in another sense would be at variance with the original import: it [therefore] seems that it is susceptible of both these meanings, bearing one or the other according as this or that suits the place. (Msb.) A_in~amaA is to be distinguished from A_in~a with the conjunct [noun] maA, which does not restrain it from governing [though its government with this is not apparent, and which is written separately]; as in A_in~a maA Einoka HasanN meaning Verily what is with thee is good, and in A_in~a maA faEalota HasanN meaning Verily thy deed is good. (I' Ak pp. 97 and 98.) ― -b7- A_in~a is sometimes contracted into A_inN; (S, Mughnee, K;) and in this case, it is made to govern and is made to have no government: (S:) it is seldom made to govern in this case; often made to have no government: the Koofees say that it is not contracted; (Mughnee, K;) and that when one says, A_ino zayodN lamunoTaliqN [the meaning is virtually Verily Zeyd is going away, but] A_inN is a negative and the l is syn. with A_il~A; but this assertion is refuted by the fact that some make it to govern when contracted, as in exs. cited above, voce A_ino, q. v. (Mughnee.) ― -b8- It is also syn. with naEamN [Even so; yes; yea]; (Mughnee, K;) contr. to the opinion of AO. (Mughnee.) [See also A^an~a, last sentence.] Those who affirm it to have this meaning cite as an ex. the following verse (Mughnee, K *) of 'Obeyd-Allah Ibn-Keys-er-Rukeiyát: (S, * TA:)
ka waqado kabirota faqulotu A_in~aho
wayaqulona $ayobN qado EalaA
[And they say, (namely, the women,) Hoariness hath come upon thee, and thou hast become old: and I say, Even so, or yes, or yea]: (Mughnee, K:) but this has been rebutted by the saying, We do not concede that the h is here added to denote the pause, but assert that it is a pronoun, governed by A_in~a in the accus. case, and the predicate is suppressed; the meaning being, A_in~ahu ka*`lika [Verily it, i. e. the case, is thus]. (Mughnee.) [J says,] The meaning is, A_n~ahu qado kaAna kamaA taqulona [Verily it, i. e. the case, hath been as ye say]: A 'Obeyd says, This is a curtailment of the speech of the Arabs; the pronoun being deemed sufficient because the meaning is known: and as to the saying of Akh, that it signifies naEamo, he only means thereby that it may be so rendered, not that it is originally applied to that signification: he says that the h is here added to denote the pause. (S.) There is, however, a good ex. of A_in~a in the sense of naEamo in the saying of Ibn-Ez-Zubeyr, to him who said to him, “May God curse a she camel which carried me to thee,” A_in~a waraAkibahaA, i. e. Even so, or yes, or yea; and may God curse her rider: for the suppression of both the subject and the predicate is not allowable. (Mughnee.) And hence, accord. to Mbr, the saying in the Kur [xx. 66], as thus read, A_in~a h`*Ani lasaAHiraAni [meaning, if so, Yes, these two are
enchanters]. (Mughnee.) [But this phrase has given rise to much discussion, related in the Mughnee and other works. The following is a brief abstract of what has been said respecting it by several of the leading authorities.] A booIs-hák says that the people of El-Medeeneh and El-Koofeh read as above, except 'Ásim, who is reported to have read, A_inN h`*aAni, without tesh-deed, and so is Kh; [so too is Hafs, as is said above, voce A_ino;] and that AA read A_in~a h`*yoni, the former word with teshdeed, and the latter in the accus. case: that the argument for A_in~a h`*aAni, with teshdeed and the nom. case, [or rather what is identical in form with the nom. case,] is, that it is of the dial. of Kináneh, in which the dual is formed by the termination An in the nom. and accus. and gen. cases alike, as also in the dial. of Benu-l-Hárith Ibn-Kaab: but that the old grammarians say that h is here suppressed; the meaning being, A_in~ahu h`*aAni: (T:) this last assertion, however, is weak; for what is applied to the purpose of corroboration should not be suppressed, and the instances of its suppression which have been heard are deviations from general usage, except in the case of A^an~a, with fet-h, contracted into A^ano: (Mughnee:) Aboo-Is-hák then adds, that some say, A_in~a is here syn. with naEamo: this last opinion he holds to be the best; the meaning being, naEamo h`*aAni lahumaA saAHiraAni [Yes, these two, verily they are two enchanters: for this is not a case in which the l (which is the l of inception) can be regarded as transferred from its proper place, at the commencement of the sentence or proposition, as it is in some instances mentioned in the former half of this paragraph: but it is said in the Mughnee that this explanation is invalidated by the fact that the combining of the corroborative l and the suppression of the inchoative is like the combining of two things inconsistent, or incompatible; as is also the opinion that the l is redundant, because the redundant l prefixed to the enunciative is peculiar to poetry]: next in point of goodness, in the opinion of A booIs-hák, is, that it is of the dial. of Kináneh and Benu-l-Hárith Ibn-Kaab: the reading of AA he does not allow, because it is at variance with the written text: but he approves the reading of 'Ásim and Kh. (T.) -A2- A_in~a also occurs as a verb: it is the third person pl. fem. of the pret. from AlA^ayonu, syn. with Alt~aEabu; or from A=na syn. with qaruba: or the third person sing. masc. of the pret. passive from AlA^anyinu, in the dial. of those who, for rud~a and Hub~a, say rid~a and Hib~a, likening these verbs to qiyla and biyEa: or the sing. masc. of the imperative from the same: or the pl. fem. of the imperative from AlA^ayonu; or from A=na syn. with qaruba: or the sing. fem. of the corroborated form of the imperative from waA^aY, syn. with waEada. (Mughnee.) A^anaA, signifying I: see A^ano, in seven places.
A^anahN * , signifying I: see A^ano, in two places.

A^an~apN *
i. q. A^aniynN [inf. n. of A^an~a, but app. a simple subst., signifying A moan, moaning, or prolonged voice of complaint; or a saying Ah: or a complaint: or a cry]. (TA.)
A^anota * , signifying Thou: fem. A^anoti; dual A^anotumaA; pl. masc. A^anotumo, and pl. fem. A^anotun~a: see A^ano, in six places.
A^unanapN * see A^an~aAnN
A^unaAnN * see A^an~aAnN

A^an~aAnN * One who moans; who utters a moaning, or prolonged voice of complaint; or who says Ah; much, or frequently; as also ↓ A^unaAnN and ↓ A^unanapN: (M, K:) or this last signifies one who publishes complaint, or makes it public, much, or frequently: (M:) or one who talks and grieves and complains much, or frequently; and it has no verb derived from it: (T:) and you say, rajulN A^unanapN qunanapN, [in which the latter epithet is app. an imitative sequent to the former,] meaning an eloquent man. (TA.) The fem. of A^an~aAnN is with p: (M, K:) and is said to be applied to a woman who moans, or says Ah, and is affected with compassion, for a dead husband, on seeing another whom she has married after the former. (MF.) [See also Han~aAnapN, voce Han~aAnN.]
A=na A=n , signifying I: see A^ano, in two places.

A=n~N A=n part. n. of A^an~a, [Moaning; or uttering a moan or moaning or a prolonged voice of complaint; or saying Ah; by reason of pain: complaining by reason of disease or pain: or] uttering a cry or cries: fem. with p. (Msb.) [Hence,] you say, maA lahu HaAn~apN walaA A=n~apN He has not a she camel nor a sheep, or goat: (S, M, A, K:) or he has not a she camel nor a female slave (M, K) that moans by reason of fatigue. (M.)

may^in~apN * , occurring in a trad., (S, Mgh, K, &c., in the first and last in art. mA^n, and in the second in the present art.,) where it is said, A_in~a Tuwla AlS~alaApi waqiSara AlxuTobapi may^in~apN mino fiqohi Alr~ajuli, (S, Mgh, TA, &c.,) is of the measure mafEilapN waqiSara AlxuTobapi may^in~apN mino fiqohi Alr~ajuli, [originally maA^oninapN,] from A_in~a, (S, Z in the Fáïk, IAth, Mgh, K,) the corroborative particle; (Z, IAth, Mgh;) like maEosaApN from EasaY; (S, K;) but not regularly derived from A_in~a, because a word may not be so derived from a particle; or it may be said that this is so derived after the particle has been made a noun; (Z, IAth;) or neither of these modes of derivation is regular: (MF:) the meaning is, [Verily the longness of the prayer and the shortness of the oration from the pulpit are (together)] a proper ground for one's saying, Verily the man is a person of knowledge or intelligence: (Z, * Mgh, K in art. mA^n:) this is the proper signification: accord. to AO, the meaning is, a thing whereby one learns the knowledge, or intelligence, of the man: (Mgh:) or it means a thing suitable to, (S, Mgh,) and whereby one knows, (S,) the knowledge, or intelligence, of the man: (S, Mgh:) or a sign (As, S, K) of the knowledge, or intelligence, of the man; and suitable thereto: (As, S:) or an evidence thereof: (M:) or an indication, or a symptom, thereof; everything that indicates a thing being said to be may^in~apN lahu: [so that may^in~apN lika*aA may be well rendered a thing that occasions one's knowing, or inferring, or suspecting, such a thing; and in like manner, a person that occasions one's doing so: or, more properly, a thing, &c., in which such a thing is usually known to take place, or have place, or be, or exist, like maZin~apN:] one of the strangest of the things said of it is, that the ' is a substitute for the Z of maZin~apN: (IAth:) this seems to have been the opinion of Lh: (Az, L:) accord. to AA, it is syn. with A=yapN [a sign, &c.]. (TA.) As says (S, * K, TA, all in art. mA^n) that the word is thus, with teshdeed to the n, in the trad. and in a verse of poetry, as these are related; (S, TA;) but correctly, in his opinion, it should be may^iynapN of the measure faEiylapN, (S, K, * TA,) unless it be from A_in~a, as first stated above: (S, TA:) AZ used to say that it is may^it~apN, with t, (S, K, * TA,) meaning a thing (lit. a place) meet, fit, or proper, or worthy or deserving, and the like; of the measure mafoEilapN, [originally maA^otitapN,] from A^at~ahu meaning “he overcame him with an argument or the like:” (S, K, TA:) but some say that it is of the measure faEil~apN, from maA^ana meaning AiHotamala: see art. mA^n. (K in that art.) You say also, huwa may^in~apN liloxayori, from A_in~a, He is a person fit, or proper, for one's saying of him, Verily he is good; and in like manner, maEosaApN, from EasaY, as meaning “a person fit, or proper, for one's saying of him, May-be he will do good.” (A, TA.) And A_in~ahu lamay^in~apN A^ano yakuwna ka*aA Verily it is meet, fit, or proper, for one's saying of it, Verily it is thus; or is worthy, or deserving, of one's saying &c.: or verily it is a thing meet, fit, or proper, for one's saying &c.; or is a thing worthy, or deserving, of one's saying &c.: of the measure mafoEilapN, from A_in~a. (K in the present art.) And A_in~ahu lamay^in~apN A^ano yafoEala *aAka Verily he is meet, fit, or proper, for doing that; or is worthy, or deserving, of doing that: or verily he is a person meet, fit, or proper, for doing that; or is a person worthy, or deserving, of doing that: and in like manner you say of two, and of more, and of a female: but may^in~apN may be of the measure faEil~apN [from mA^n], i. e. a triliteral-radical word. (M.) ― -b2- You also say, A^ataAhu Ealay may^n~ap *aAka, meaning He came to him at the time, or season, [or fit or proper time,] of that; and at the first thereof. (M.)
A^anaA * (pronoun of the first person sing.): see art. An.

2 A^n~bhu * , inf. n. taA^oniybN, He blamed, reproved, reprehended, chid, or reproached, him: (S, M, A, K:) or he did so severely, or angrily: (ISk, T, S, M, A, K:) or, with the utmost severity or harshness: (T, M, TA:) or he repulsed him, meaning a person who asked something of him, in the most abominable manner. (M, * K, * TA.)

A^unobuwbN *
An internodal portion, or the portion between any two joints, or knots, of a cane, or reed, and of a spear-shaft: (T:) [and] a spear,
or lance: pl. A^anaAbiybu: mentioned in this art. [in the T, and] by Ibn-El-Mukarram [in the L]. (TA.) [See also art. nb.]
A^anota * ,A^anoti,A^anotumaA,A^anotumo, and A^anotun~a: see A^ano, in art. An.

1 AanVva [A^anuva, aor.
Aanuva , inf. n. A^anaAvapN and A^unuwvapN, (see the former of these two ns. below,) It was, or became, female, feminine, or of the feminine gender. ― -b2- And hence, A^anuvato, said of land (A^aroD), (tropical:) It was, or became, such as is termed A^aniyvap. ― -b3- Hence also,] A^anuva, said of iron, (tropical:) It was, or became, soft. (Golius, from the larger of two editions of the lexicon entitled mrqAp Allgp.) Accord. to IAar, softness is the primary signification. (M.) [But accord. to the A, the second and third of the meanings given above are tropical: (see A^aniyvN:) and the verb in the first of the senses here assigned to it, if not proper, is certainly what is termed Haqiyqap Eurofiy~ap, i. e., conventionally regarded as proper.]

2 A^n~vhu * , inf. n. taA^oniyvN, He made it (namely, a noun [&c.], S and Msb) feminine; (S, M, L, Msb;) he attached to it, or to that which was syntactically dependent upon it, the sign of the feminine gender. (Msb.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) He, or it, rendered him effeminate. (KL.) [See the pass. part. n., below.] -A2- A^n~v lahu, inf. n. as above, (tropical:) He acted gently, [or effeminately] towards him; as also lh ↓ tA^n~v. (K, TA.) And A^n~v fiY A^amorihi, inf. n. as above, (T, A,) (tropical:) He acted gently in his affair: (A:) or he applied himself gently to his affair: (T:) and some say, fY Amrh ↓ tA^n~v, meaning he acted effeminately in his affair. (T, TA.)

4 A=navato A=nvt , (S, M, A, K,) inf. n. A_iynaAvN, (K,) She (a woman) brought forth a female, (S, A, K,) or females. (M.) ― -b2- [And hence,] (assumed tropical:) It (land, A^aroD,) was, or became, such as is termed miy^onaAv. (A.)

5 tA^nv *
It (a noun [&c.]) was, or became, or was made, feminine. (S, L.) ― -b2- See also 2, in two places.

A^unovay *
Female; feminine; of the female, or feminine, sex, or gender; contr. of *akarN: (T, S, M:) an epithet applied to anything of that sex or gender: (T:) IAar asserts, that a woman is termed Anvy from the phrase baladN A^aniyvN, q. v, because of her softness; she being more soft than a man: (M, L:) [but see the observation at the end of the first paragraph of this art.:] the pl. is A_inaAvN; (T, S, M, A, Msb, K;) and sometimes one says A^unuvN, as though it were pl. of A_inaAvN; (S;) or it is [truly] pl. of A_inaAvN, like as numurN is of nimaArN; (T;) and A^anaAvaY, (T, A, Msb, K,) which last occurs in poetry. (T.) You say, h`*aA TaAy^irN wa A^unovaAhu [This is a (male) bird and his female]: not A^unovaAtuhu. (ISk, T.) In the Kur iv. 117, I'Ab reads A^uvunFA [in the place of A^unuvFA or A_inaAvFA]; and Fr says that it is pl. of wavanN, the w in wuvunN being changed into A^ as in A^uq~itatN [for wuq~itatN]. (T, L.) ― -b2- AimoraA^apN A^anovaY (tropical:) [A feminine woman,] means a perfect woman; (T, A, K;) a woman being thus termed in praise; like as a man is termed rajulN *akarN. (T, A.) ― -b3- [The pl.]

A_inaAvN A^nvY A_nAv AnAv also signifies (assumed tropical:) Inanimate things; (Lh, T, M, K;) as trees and stones (T, K) and wood. (T.) In the passage of the Kur mentioned above, A_inaAvFA is said to have this meaning: (T, M:) [or it there means females; for] Fr says that El-Lát and El-'Ozzà and the like were said by the Arabs to be feminine divinities. (T, TA.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Small stars. (K.) ― -b3- And [the dual] AlA^unovayaAni (tropical:) The two testicles; syn. AlxuSoyataAni; (S, K;) or AlxuSoyaAni [which is said by some to mean the scrotum; but the former is generally, though app. not always, meant by AlAnvyAn]. (M, Mgh, Msb.) ― -b4- And The two ears: (As, T, S, M, A, Mgh, K:) because they are of the fem. gender. (TA.) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) The two tribes of Bejeeleh and Kudá'ah. (K) ― -b6- And A^unovayaA Alfarasi (assumed tropical:) The inner parts (Alr~abalataAni) of the thighs of the horse. (M, L.) ― -b7- And AlA^unovay is also used to signify (assumed tropical:) The [engine of war called] manojaniyq; because the latter word is [generally] of the feminine gender. (M.)

A^aniyvN * : see muw^an~avN. ― -b2- A^aroDN A^aniyvapN, (AA, * IAar, T, S, M, K,) and ↓ miy^onaAvN, (ISh, T, M, K,) (tropical:) Plain, even, or soft, land, or ground, (ISh, IAar, T, M, K,) that produces many plants, or much herbage; (AA, T, M, K;) or that produces herbs, or leguminous plants, and is plain, even, or soft; (El-Kilábee, S;) or fitted for producing plants, or herbage; not rugged. (ISh, T, L.) And makaAnN A^aniyvN A place in which the herbage grows quickly, and becomes abundant. (T, L.) And baladN A^aniyvN (assumed tropical:) A country, or district, of which the soil is soft, and plain, or even. (IAar, M, L.) ― -b3- HadiydN A^aniyvN (tropical:) Female iron; that which is not what is termed *akarN: (S, M, L, K:) soft iron. (T and K in art. Anf.) And sayofN A^aniyvN (tropical:) A sword of female iron: (M, L:) or a sword that is not sharp, or cutting; a blunt sword: (T, M, * L:) and ↓ sayofN miy^onaAvN, and ↓ miy^onaAvapN, (T, M, L, K,) mentioned by Lh, (T, L,) a blunt sword; (K;) as also ↓ muw^an~avN: (TA:) or a sword of soft iron. (T, L.)

A^anaAvapN * [inf. n. of A^anuva, q. v.:] The female, or feminine, nature, or quality, or gender; (M;) as also ↓ A^unuwvapN. (A.) ― -b2- (tropical:) The quality of land which is termed A^aniyvapN. (A.) ― -b3- [(tropical:) Softness of iron: see A^anyvN.]
A^unuwvapN * : see the paragraph next preceding.
muw^onivN * A woman bringing forth, or who brings forth, a female, (S, K,) or females. (M.)

miy^onaAvN * A woman who usually brings forth females: (S, M, K:) and a man who usually begets female children; for the measure mifoEaAlN applies equally to both sexes: (S:) the contr. epithet is mi*okaArN. (TA.) ― -b2- See also muw^an~avN, in two places. ― -b3- A^aroDN miy^onaAvN: see A^aniyvN. ― -b4- sayofN miy^onaAvN, and miy^onaAvapN: see A^aniyvN.

muw^an~avN * [A feminine word; a word made feminine. ― -b2- Also,] (T, A, K,) and ↓ A^aniyvN, (AA, T,) and ↓ miy^onaAvN, (K,) and ↓ miy^onaAvapN, (TA,) (tropical:) i. q. muxan~avN, (AA, T, A, K,) i. e. An effeminate man; one who resembles a woman (AA, T, TA) in gentleness, and in softness of speech, and in an affectation of languor of the limbs: (TA:) or a man in the form, or make, of a female. (T.) ― -b3- sayofN muw^an~avN: see A^aniyvN. ― -b4- TiybN muw^an~avN (tropical:) Perfume that is used by women; such as xaluwq and zaEofarAn, (Sh, T, L,) and what colours the clothes: (L:) *ukuwrapu AlT~iybi being such perfumes as have no colour; such as gaAliyap and kaAfuwr and misok and Euwd and Eanobar and the like, which leave no mark. (T, L.)

1 A^anaHa * , aor.
AaniHa , inf. n. A^anoHN and A^aniyHN and A^anuwHN, He (a man, S) breathed hard, or violently, in consequence of heaviness, or oppression, experienced by him as an effect of disease, or of being out of breath, (S, K, TA,) as though he made a reiterated hemming in his throat, (kaA^an~ahu yatanaHonaHu,) and did not speak clearly, or plainly: (S, TA:) or he made a reiterated hemming in his throat (tanaHonaHa), when asked for a thing, by reason of niggardliness: (L:) or he uttered a long, or vehement, sigh, or a kind of groaning sound, (zafara,) when asked for a thing. (A.) You say, yaA^oniHu EalaY maAlihi He utters a long, or vehement, sigh, or a kind of groaning sound, over his property [from unwillingness to part with it]. (A.) ― -b2- It is said in a trad. of Ibn-'Omar, raA^aY rajulFA yaA^oniHu bibaTonihi, meaning, [it is asserted, though this seems doubtful, He saw a man] raising, or lifting, his belly with an effort, oppressed by its weight: from A^unuwHN in the last of the senses assigned to it below. (TA.)
A^un~aHN * : see A=niHN, with which it is syn., and of which it is also pl.
A^anuwHN * : see A=niHN, in two places.

A^unuwHN * : [see 1:] it is also explained as signifying A sound like that which is termed zafiyrN, arising from grief, or anger, or repletion of the belly, or jealousy: (L:) a sound accompanied by a reiterated hemming in the throat (SawotN maEa tanaHonuHK): (As:) and a sound that is heard from a man's inside, with breathing, and a shortness of breath, or panting for breath, which affects fat men; as also ↓ A^aniyHN. (L.)
A^aniyHN * : see A^unuwHN. [See also 1.]
A^an~aAHN * : see A=niHN.

A=niHN A=nH act. part. n. of 1; A man breathing hard, or violently, &c.: and a man who, when he is asked for a thing, makes a reiterated hemming in his throat (yatanaHonHu), by reason of niggardliness; as
also ↓ A^anuwHN, and ↓ A^un~aHN, (S, K,) and ↓ A^an~aAHN: (Lh:) or ↓ A^anuwHN signifies a man who hangs back from, or falls short of, doing generous deeds; as also A^azuwHN: (El-Ghanawee and S in art. AzH, and TA in the present art.:) and is also applied to a horse, meaning that runs, and makes a kind of groaning noise; A_i*aA jaraY fazafara: this is the right reading in the K: in some copies A*A jrY qaroqara [that makes a rumbling sound in his belly when he runs]: (TA:) the pl. of A=niHN is A^un~aHN. (S, K.) ― -b2- A=niHapN, applied to a female, signifies Short. (K.)

1 A^anisa bihi * , (AZ, S, M, A, Msb, K,) and A_ilayohi, (A,) aor.
Aanasa ; (Msb, TA;) and A^anasa, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) aor.
Aanisa (M, Msb, TA) and
Aanusa ; (M;) and A^anusa, aor.
Aanusa ; (M, Sgh, K;) inf. n. A^anasN and A^anasapN, (S, K,) both of A^anisa, (S,) or A_inasN, (AZ, AHát, T, M, Msb,) also of A^anisa, (AZ, AHát, Msb, TA,) but this is rare, (T, TA,) and A^unosN, (T, S, M, A, K,) which is the more common, (T, TA,) and is of A^anasa, (S,) or A^unosN has a different signification from A_inosN the inf. n. of A^anisa, [see A^unosN below,] (AZ, AHát,) or it is a subst. from A^anisa bihi, (Msb,) and A^unosapN; (M;) [but this also is probably a subst.;] one says A^unosN and A^unosapN, like as one says buEodN and buEodap; (Ham p. 768;) He was, or became, sociable, companionable, conversable, inclined to company or converse, friendly, amicable, or familiar, with him, or by means of him, and to him: and [Ans bh] he was, or became, cheered, or gladdened, by his company or converse, or by his, or its, presence; or cheerful, gay, or gladsome: the inf. n. signifying the contr. of waHo$apN: (T, S, A, K:) or he was, or became, at ease, or tranquil, with him: (M:) or his heart was, or became, at ease, or tranquil, with him; without shrinking, or aversion: (Msb:) and bihi ↓ AstA^ns, (S, M, A, Msb,) and A_ilayohi, (A,) and bihi ↓ tA^n~s, signify the same, (S, M, Msb,) i. e., the same as A^anisa (M, A, Msb, TA) and A^anasa (M, Msb) and A^unusa: (M:) A^anisa bifulaAnK is likewise explained as signifying he delighted, or rejoiced, in such a one; he was happy, or pleased, with him: (IAar, TA:) [and ↓ A=nshu, a form of frequent occurrence, inf. n. muw^aAnasapN, which occurs in this art. in the TA, also signifies he was, or became, sociable, &c., with him; like A^anisa bihi &c.: it is also said in the TA that A^anisa bihi and bihi ↓ A=nasa are syn., meaning, app., like AstA^ns and tA^n~s bh, and that A=ns in this case is therefore of the measure faAEala; but this admits of some doubt, as it is said immediately after A=nshu as meaning the contr. of A^awoHa$ahu:] and ↓ AstA^ns, (K, TA,) said of a wild animal, (TA,) signifies [he became familiar, or tame, or domesticated; or] his wildness (tawaH~u$uhu) departed: (K, TA:) you say A_i*aA jaA='a All~ayolu A@sotaA^onasa kul~u waHo$iY~K waA@sotawoHa$a kul~u A_inosiYN [When the night comes, every wild animal becomes familiar with his kind, and every human being becomes shy of his kind, i. e., of such thereof as he does not know, when meeting them in the dark]. (A, TA, Msb in art. wH$.)

2 Aan~asa
A^n~shu, inf. n. taA^oniysN, He rendered him familiar; or tame. (KL.) -A2- See also 4, in three places.
3 AaAonasa see 1, in two places.

4 A=nshu A=nsh A=nsp , (M, K,) inf. n. A_iynaAsN, (S,) He behaved in a sociable, friendly, or familiar, manner with him; [see 1, in two places;] he, or it, cheered him, or gladdened him, by his company or converse, or by his, or its, presence; he, or it, solaced, or consoled, him; contr. of A^awoHa$ahu; (S, * K;) as also ↓ A^n~shu, (K,) inf. n. taA^oniysN: (S, K:) or he, or it, rendered him easy, at ease, or tranquil; as also ↓ the latter verb, occurring in the following ex.: sam~aAhaA biA@lomuw^onisaAti liA^an~ahun~a yuw^an~isonahu biA^aqoraAnihi fayuw^am~in~ahu A^awoyuHas~in~a Zan~ihu [He has called them (referring to weapons) Almw^nsAt because they render him at ease with his adversaries, and secure, or cause him to have a good opinion of his safety, and thus, cheer him, or solace him, by their presence]. (M: [and the like is said in the A.]) -A2- He perceived it; syn. of the inf. n. A_idoraAkN. (TA.) ― -b2- He saw him, or it, (S, M, A, * Msb, K,) and looked at him, or it; (M, TA;) as also ↓ A^n~shu, inf. n.

taA^oniysN * ; (K;) and ↓ AstA^nshu: (M:) or he saw it so that there was no doubt or uncertainty in it: or he saw it, meaning a thing by the sight or presence of which he was cheered, gladdened, solaced, or consoled; A_iynaAsN signifying A_iboSaAru maA yuw^onasu bihi: (Bd in xx. 9:) or he saw it, not having before known it, or been acquainted with it. (TA.) ― -b2- He heard it; namely, a sound or voice. (S, K.) ― -b3- He felt it; was sensible of it; (M, K, TA;) experienced it in himself; (TA;) namely, [for instance,] fright, or fear. (A, TA.) ― -b4- He knew it: (S, M, Msb, K:) he was acquainted with it: (TA:) he had certain knowledge of it; was certain of it. (M, TA.) You say, A=nasotu minohu ru$odFA (S, A, TA) I knew him to be characterized by ru$od, (S, TA,) i. e., maturity of intel-lect, and rectitude of actions, and good management of affairs. (TA.) [See Kur iv. 5.] And it is said in a prov., baEoda A@T~ilaAEK A_iynaAsN, i. e. After appearance [is knowledge, or certain knowledge]. (Fr, TA.)
5 tA^n~s bihi * : see 1. -A2- tA^n~s AlbaAzy The falcon looked, raising his head (M, A, K) and his eyes. (A.) ― -b2- tA^n~s lahu: see 10.

10 AstA^ns * , and AstA^ns bihi and A_ilayohi: see 1. -A2- AstA^ns signifies also He (a wild animal) became sensible of the presence or nearness of a human being. (S, K.) -A3- He looked; as in the phrase Ai*ohabo faA@sotaA^oniso halo taraY A^aHadFA [Go thou and look if thou see any one]: (Fr, TA:) he considered, or examined, endeavouring to obtain a clear knowledge of a thing; (K, TA;) and looked aside, or about, to ascertain if he could see any one: (TA:) he sought, or asked for, knowledge, or information; he inquired: (M, TA:) and hence, (Bd in xxiv. 27,) he asked permission. (Fr, Zj, K, TA, and Bd ubi suprà.) It is said in the Kur [xxiv. 27], laA tadoxuluwA buyuwtFA gayora buyuwtikumo Hat~ay tasotaA^onisuwA watusal~imuwA [Enter ye not houses other than your own houses] until ye inquire whether its inhabitants desire that ye should enter or not; [and salute:] (M:) or (which is essentially the same, M) until ye ask permission: (Fr, Zj, M, TA:) but Fr says that the sentence presents an inversion, and that the meaning is, until ye salute, and ask if ye shall enter or not: (TA:) I'Ab says that tastA^nswA is a mistranscription; and he and Ubeí and Ibn-Mes'ood read tasotaA^o*inuwA, which signifies the same: (Az, TA:) [it is said that] AstA^ns also signifies he made a reiterated hemming, like a slight coughing; [as a man does to notify his nearness;] syn. tanaHonaHa: and so some explain it in the text of the Kur quoted above. (TA.) ― -b2- AstA^ns lahu He listened to, or endeavoured or sought to hear, him, or it; as also ↓ tA^n~s. (A.) [See the Kur xxxiii. 53.] -A4- AstA^nshu: see 4.

A^unosN *
Sociableness; companionableness; conversableness; inclination to company or converse; friendliness; amicableness; socialness; familiarity: cheerfulness; gayness; gladsomeness: contr. of waHo$apN: (T, S, A, K:) joy; gladness; happiness: (Har p. 652:) or ease, or tranquillity: (M:) or ease, or tranquillity, of heart, and freedom from shrinking, or from aversion: (Msb:) an inf. n. of 1, (S, M,) as are also ↓ A^anasN and ↓ A^anasapN (S, K) and ↓ A_inosN, (M,) but this is rare as signifying the contr. of waHo$apN: (T, TA:) or ↓ A_inosN is the inf. n. of A^anisa bihi; but A^unusN is not: (AZ, AHát, Msb, TA:) this latter is a subst. from that verb [signifying as explained above]: (Msb:) or only signifying converse, and companionship, or familiarity, with women; (AZ, AHát, TA;) or amatory conversation and conduct; or the talk of young men and young women: (Fr, TA:) [but of all the forms above, A^unosN is that which is most commonly used, at least in post-classical works, as signifying the contr. of waHo$apN.] ― -b2- [Also (assumed tropical:) Delight, as meaning a cause of delight, or thing that gives delight.] A poet says,
yaA saAkiniY mak~apa laA zilotumu
A^unosFA lanaA A_in~iYa lamo A^anosakumo
maA fiykumu EayobN siwaY qawolikumo
Einoda All~iqaA A^awoHa$anaA A^unosukumo
[O inhabitants of Mekkeh, may ye not cease to be a delight to us: verily I have not forgotten you: there is in you no fault beside your saying, at meeting, Your sociableness, or companiableness, &c., has made us feel lonely and sad; meaning, in your absence]. (TA in art. wH$.) [See A^awoHa$a. But this signification, though allowable as tropical, is perhaps post-classical.] ― -b3- Aibonu A^unos: and fulaAnN A@bonu A^unosi fulaAnK: and kayofa A@bonu A^unosika: and kayofa taraY A@bona A^unosika: see A_inosN.

A_inosN A^ns A^nsY A_ns Ans nAs nsy |ns : see A^unosN, in two places. -A2- (tropical:) A chosen, select, particular, or special, friend or companion; (S, K;) as also Aibonu A_inosK (S, K,) or ↓ Aibonu A^unosK.
