(So in a copy of the A.) You say, h`*aA A_inosiY; (S;) and A_inosuka, and A@bonu A_inosika; (K;) (tropical:) This is my chosen, or particular, friend; (S;) and thy chosen, or particular, friend. (K.) And fulaAnN A@bonu A_inosi fulaAnK (S,) or flAn ↓ Abn A^unosi (A,)
(tropical:) Such a one is the chosen, or particular, friend of such a one. (S, A.) One also says, kayofa A@bonu A_inosika and ↓ A^unosika, (S, M,) or kayofa taray A@bona A_inosika (AZ, Fr, A) and ↓ A^unosika, (A,) meaning himself, (AZ, Fr, S, S TA,) i. e., (assumed tropical:) How dost thou regard me in my companionship with thee? (S:) or the meaning is, (tropical:) how dost thou find thyself? (A:) or how is thyself? (M, TA.) -A3- Mankind; (S, M, A, K;) the opposite of jin~N; (Msb;) as also ↓ A^anasN, (Akh, S, TA,) and ↓ A_inosaAnN; (A, K;) the last being a gen. n., (Msb,) but applied to the male (S, * Msb) and female, (S, Msb, K,) and sing. and pl.: (Msb:) one is [also] termed ↓ A_inosiY~N and ↓ A^anasiY~N; (S, K;) the former of which is a rel. n. from A_inosN; (M;) [and the latter, from A^anasN: the fem. of each is with p:] the vulgar apply to a woman, instead of ↓ A_inosaAnN, [which is the more approved,] ↓ A_inosaAnapN: (S, K:) this latter [accord. to some] should not be used: (S:) but it is correct, though rare: it is said in the K to occur in poetry, but supposed to be post-classical: it occurs, however, in classical poetry, and has been transmitted by several authors: (MF:) the pl. (of A_inosN, M, TA) is A=naAsN; (M, K, TA;) and (of the same, K in art. nws, or of ↓ A_inosaAnN, M) A^unaAsN, (M, K ubi suprà,) with which naAsN is syn., (S, M, Msb, K,) being a contraction thereof; (Sb, S, M, Msb;) and (of ↓ A_inosiY~N, S, M, or ↓ A^anasiY~N, S, or of ↓ A_inosaAnN, Lh, S, M, Msb) A^anaAsiY~N, (Lh, S, M, Msb, K,) like as karaAsiY~u is pl. of kurosiY~N, or like as saraAHynu is pl. of sirHaAnN, but Y being substituted for n, (M, TA,) after the same manner as they say A^araAnK for A^araAnibu; (Fr, TA;) and A^anaAsK, (Lh, M,) in the accus. case A^anaAsiYa, as the word is read in the Kur xxv. 51, by Ks, (TA,) and by Yahyà Ibn-El-Hárith, (K, TA,) dropping the Y between the second and last radical letters, [for, with some others, it seems, they held the word to be derived from the root nsY,] (TA,) and A^anaAsiyapN, (S, M, K,) in which the p is a substitute for one of the two yás in A^anaAsiY~u, a pl. of A_inosaAnN; or, accord. to Mbr, A^anaAsiyapN is pl. of A_inosiY~N, [in the TA, of A_inosiy~apN, which I regard as a mistranscription,] and is like zanaAdaqapN for zanaAdiyqu, and faraAzitapN for faraAziynu; (M, TA;) and you say also A_inosay~uwna. (TA.) naAsN is masc., as in the Kur ii. 19, &c.; and sometimes fem., as meaning A tribe, or a body of men, qabiylapN, or TaAy^ifapN; as in the phrase, mentioned by Th, jaA='atoaka Aln~aAsu, meaning, The tribe, or portion of people (qiToEap), came to thee. (M, TA.) ↓ banuwAlA_inosaAni means The sons of Adam. (M.) And Aln~aAsu Aln~aAsu, an expression mentioned by Sb, means, Men in every place and in every state are men: a poet says,
bilaAdN bahaA kun~aA wakun~aA nuHib~uhaA
A_i*i Aln~aAsu naAsN waAlbilaAdu bilaAdu
meaning [A country in which we were, and which we used to love,] since the men were ingenuous men, and the country was a fruitful country. (M.) The following trad., lawo A^aTaAEa A@ll~`hu Aln~aAsa fiY Aln~aAsi lamo yakuno naAsN If God complied with the prayer of men with respect to men there would be no men, is said to mean, that men love to have male children born to them, and not females, and if there were no females, or if the females were not, men would cease to be. (TA.) It is related that a party of the jinn, or genii, came to a company of men, and asked permission to go in to them, whereupon the latter said to them, Who are ye? and they answered, naAsN mina Aljn~i [A people of the jinn], making their answer to accord. with common usage; for it is customary for men, when it is said to them, Who are ye? to answer, naAsN mino baniY fulaAnK [Men of the sons of such a one]. (IJ, M, L: but in the L, for nAs, in both instances, we find A^unaAsN.) [See also naAsN in art. nws.] Respecting the derivation of ↓ A_inosaAnN, authors differ, though they agree that the final n is augmentative: the Basrees say that it is from AlA_inosu; (Msb;) and its measure is fiEolaAnN; (S, Msb;) but an addition, of Y, is made in its dim., [which is A^unayosiyaAnN,] like as an addition is made in ruwayojilN, the dim. of rajulN: (S:) [but it should be observed that ruwayojilN is more probably the dim. of raAjilN:] some say that it is from A_iynaAsN, signifying “perception,” or “sight,” and “knowledge,” and “sensation;” because man uses these faculties: (TA:) and Mohammad Ibn-'Arafeh El-Wásitee says that men are called A_insiy~uwni because they are seen (yuw^onasuwna, i. e.

yurawona rA^Y wrY yrwn ), and that the jinn are called jin~ because they are [ordinarily] concealed (mujotan~uwna, i. e. mutawaAruwna,) from the sight of men: (TA:) [it is said in the B, as cited in the TA, that the form A^anisaAn is also used for A_inosaAnN; as though it were a dual, meaning “a double associate,” i. e., an associate with the jinn and with his own kind; for it is added, A^anisa biA@lA=ojin~i waA^anisa biA@lA=oxaloqi:] some derive the word from Aln~awosu, signifying “motion:” (TA:) some (namely, the Koofees, Msb) say that it is originally A_insiyaAnN, (S, Msb, TA,) of the measure A_ifoEilaAnN, (S, Msb,) from Aln~isoyaAnu [“forgetfulness”], (Msb,) and contracted to make it more easy of pronunciation, because of its being so often used; (S;) but it is restored to its original in forming the dim., (S, Msb,) which is A^unayosiyaAnN: (Msb, TA:) this form of the dim., they say, shows the original form of the word which is its source; (TA;) and they adduce as an indication of its derivation the saying of I'Ab, A_in~amaA sum~iya A_inosaAnFA liA^an~ahu Euhida A_ilayohi fanasiYa [He (meaning the first man) was only named AnsAn because he was commanded and he forgot]: (S, TA:) [in like manner,] it is said that Aln~aAsu is originally Aln~aAsiY; the former of these, accord. to one reading, and the latter accord. to another, occurs in the Kur ii. 195; the latter referring to Adam, and to the words of the Kur in xx. 114: (TA:) but Az holds that A_inosiyaAnN is of the measure fiEoliyaAnN, from AlA_inosu, and similar to xiroSiyaAnN. (L, TA. *)

A^anasN *
i. q. A^unosN, q. v. (S, K.) -A2- Also i. q. A_inosN, q. v. (Akh, S, TA.) ― -b2- Also A numerous company of men; (K, * TA;) many men. (TA.) ― -b3- A tribe (HaY~u) staying, residing, dwelling, or abiding: (S, K:) the people of a place of alighting or abode: (M, TA: [but in the latter, in one place, said to be A_inosN, with kesr; though a verse cited in both, as an ex., shows it to be A^anasN:]) the inhabitants of a house: (AA, TA:) pl. (of the word in the first sense, of these three, TA, and in the second, M, TA) A=naAsN. (M, TA.) ― -b4- One with whom a person is sociable. (Ham p. 136.) You say also, humo A^anasu fulaAnK They are they with whom such a one is sociable (Aal~a*iyna yasotaA^onisu A_ilayohimo). (Lh, M.) And huwa A^anasu fulaAnK He is much accustomed to the serving of him. (Har p. 472.)

A^anasapN *
i. q. A^unosN, q. v. (S, K.)

A_inosiY~u A^ns A^nsY A^nsy A_ns A_nsy AnsY Ansy nsy
Of, or belonging to, mankind; human; [as also ↓ A^anasiY~N, and ↓ A_inosaAniY~u;] a rel. n. from A_inosN. (M.) ― -b2- A human being; a man; as also ↓ A^anasiY~N, (S, K,) and ↓ A_inosaAnN. (S, A, Msb, K.) See A_inosN, in two places. ― -b3- [Domestic, as opposed to wild. Ex.] HumurN A_inosiy~apN Domestic asses; asses that are accustomed to the houses: commonly known as written with kesr to the A^unosiy~apN: but in the book of Aboo-Moosà is an indication of its being with damm to the ' [A^anasiy~apN]: and as some relate a trad. in which it occurs, A^anasiy~apN, which is said to be of no account. (TA.) ― -b4- The left side (AZ, S, M, Msb, K) of an animal, (Msb,) or of a beast and of a man, (M,) or of anything: (AZ, S, K:) or the right side: (As, S:) [but the latter seems to be a mistake:] Az says that Lth has well explained this term and its contrary waHo$iY~N, saying that the latter is the right side of every beast; and the former, the left side; agreeably with those of the first authority in sound learning; and [that] it is related of El-Mufaddal and As and AO, that all of them asserted the latter to be, of every animal except man, [the “far” side, or “off” side,] the side on which it is not milked nor mounted; and the former, [the near side,] the side on which the rider mounts and the milker milks: (TA in art.

wH$ * :) [and the like is said, as a citation from Az, in the Msb in art. wH$: but after this, in my copy of the Msb, there seems to be an omission; for it is immediately added, “But Az says, This is not correct in my opinion:”] it is said that everything that is frightened declines to its right side; for the beast is approached to be mounted and milked on the left side, and, fearing thereat, runs away from the place of fear, which is the left side, to the place of safety, which is the right side: (S, * IAmb in Msb; both in art. wH$:) [accordingly,] Er-Rá'ee describes a beast as declining to the side termed AlwH$Y because frightened on the left side: (S and Msb in art. wH$:) and 'Antarah alludes to one's shrinking with the side so termed from the whip, [which he likens to a cat,] because the whip of the rider is in his right hand: (S in art. wH$:) but Abu-l-'Abbás says that people differ respecting these two terms when relating to a man: that, accord. to some, they mean the same in this case as in the cases of horses
and other beasts of carriage, and of camels: but some say, that in the case of a man, the latter term means the part next the shoulder-blade; and the former, the part next the arm-pit. (TA in art.

wH$ * .) Of every double member of a man, as the upper half of each arm, and the two fore arms, and the two feet, it means That [side] which is towards the man; and wH$Y~, that which turns away from him: (As, S:) or, of the foot, the former means that [side] which is towards the other foot; [i. e., the inner side;] and the latter, the contrary of the former. (TA in art. wH$.) Of a bow, (S, M, K,) or of a Persian bow, (TA in art. wH$,) That [side] which is towards thee; (S, K;) and wH$Y~, the back: (S and K in art.

wH$ * :) or the former, that [side] which is next to the archer; and the latter, that which is next to the animal shot at: (M, TA:) or of a bow, whether Persian or not is not said, [the former means the side against which the arrow lies; and] the latter, the side against which the arrow does not lie. (TA in art. wH$.) A^anasiY~N: see A_inosN and A_inosiY~N, each in two places.

A_inosaAnN A_nsAn AnsAn and A_nosaAnapN: see A_inosN, passim; and A_inosiY~N. ― -b2- A_inosaAnu AlEayoni (tropical:) The image that is seen [reflected] in the black of the eye; (S, K;) what is seen in the eye, like as is seen in a mirror, when a thing faces it: (Zj in his “Khalk el-Insán:”) or the pupil, or apple, (naAZir,) of the eye: (M:) or the black (Hadaqap) of the eye: (Msb:) pl. A^anaAsiY~u, (S, Msb, K,) but not A^unaAsN. (S.)
A_inosaAniY~N A^ns A^nsAny A^nsY A_nsAn A_nsAny A_nsAnyy AnsAnY AnsAny nsy |ns |nsAny : see A_inosiY~N, first signification.

[
A_inosaAniy~apN A_nsAn A_nsAny A_nsAnyh A_nsAnyp AnsAnyh AnsAnyp
Human nature; humanity; as also naAsuwtN, which is probably post-classical, opposed to laAhuwtN, q. v., in art. lyh.]
A^anuwsN * A tame, or gentle, dog; contr. of EaquwrN: pl. A^unusN. (M, A, K.) ― -b2- See also A=nisapN.

A^aniysN *
i. q. ↓ muw^aAnisN [generally used as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant, meaning, A sociable, companionable, conversable, friendly, or familiar, person; a cheerful companion]: (S, K:) one with whom one is sociable, companionable, conversable, friendly, familiar, or cheerful: (K:) a person, (A,) or anything, (S,) by whose company, or converse, or presence, one is cheered, gladdened, solaced, or consoled. (S, A.) You say, maA biAld~aAri A^niyso (or, as in some copies of the K, mino A^aniysK,) There is not in the house any one by whose company, or converse, or presence, one is cheered, gladdened, solaced, or consoled: (A:) or there is not in the house any one. (S, M, K.) [See also A=nisapN.] ― -b2- AlA^aniysu (assumed tropical:) The domestic cock; (AA, K;) also called Al$~uqaru. (TA.) ― -b3- AlA^aniysapu (tropical:) The fire; (IAar, A, K;) as also ↓ maA^onuwsapu, [imperfectly decl., being a proper name and of the fem. gender,] (M,) and ↓ AlmaA^onuwsapu, (M, K,) of which [says ISd] I know no verb: (M:) because, when a man sees it in the night, he becomes cheerful and tranquil thereat, even if it be in a desert land. (TA.) You say, baAtati AlA^aniysapu A^aniysatahu (tropical:) [The fire was during night his cheerful companion, or his cheerer by its presence]. (A, TA.)

A=nasu A=ns [More, and most, sociable, &c.]. Hence, A=nasu mina AlHum~aY (assumed tropical:) [A closer companion than fever]: a saying of the Arabs, meaning, that fever scarcely ever quits the patient; as though it were sociable with him. (M, TA.)

jaAriyapN A=nisapN jAryp A=nsh jAryp A=nsp
A girl of cheerful mind, (Lth, A, K, TA,) whose nearness, and conversation, or discourse, thou lovest, (Lth, TA,) or whose conversation, or discourse, and nearness, are loved: (A:) or a girl of pleasant conversation or discourse; as also ↓ A^anuwsN: (M:) and A=nisapu AlHadiyvi who becomes sociable, companionable, conversable, friendly, familiar, or cheerful, by means of thy conversation or discourse: it does not mean who cheers thee [by conversation or discourse]: (S:) pl. A^awaAnisu (Lth, A, TA) and A=nisaAtN: (Lth, TA:) and the pl. of A^anuwsN is A^unusN. (M, TA.) [See also A^aniysN.]
maA^onasN * [app. i. q. makaAnN maA^onuwsN, q. v.] (A.)

muw^onis * (assumed tropical:) A name which the Arabs, (S, M,) and the ancients, (M,) used to give to Thursday; (S, M;) because on that day they used to incline to places of pleasure; and 'Alee is related to have said that God created Paradise on Thursday, and named it thus. (M, TA.) ― -b2- Almuw^onisaAtu (tropical:) Weapons: (M, A:) or all weapons: (K:) or the spear and the migofar and the tijogaAf and the tasobigap and the turos (Fr, K) and the sword and the helmet: (IKtt, TA:) so called because they render their possessor at ease with his adversaries, and secure, or cause him to have a good opinion [of his safety, and thus, cheer him, or solace him, by their presence: see 4]. (M, A. *) ― -b3- See also baAbuwnajN.

makaAnN maA^onuwsN * , (M,) and maHal~N maA^onuwsN, (A,) [A place, and] a place of alighting or abode, in which is A^unos [i. e. sociableness, &c.]: (A:) mA^nws is a kind of possessive noun, because they did not say A^anasotu AlmakaAna, nor A^anisotuhu. (M, L.) ― -b2- maA^onuwsapu and AlmaA^onuwsapu: see A^aniysN.
muw^aAnisN * : see A^aniysN.
AlmutaA^an~isu * (assumed tropical:) The lion; (TS, K;) as also ↓ AlmusotaA^onisu: (TS, TA:) or he that is sensible of the prey from afar, (K, TA,) and examines and looks about for it. (TA.)
AlmusotaA^onisu * : see what next precedes.

1 A^anafahu * , (T, S, M, K,) aor.
Aanifa (M, K) and
Aanufa , (K,) inf. n. A^anofN, (M,) He struck, (T, S, K,) or hit, or hurt, (M,) his nose; (T, S, M, K;) namely, a man's. (S.) ― -b2- It (the water) reached his nose, (T, S, K,) on the occasion of his descending into a river; (S;) as also ↓ A=nfhu, (K, [but in some copies written again A^anafahu,]) inf. n. A_iynaAfN. (TK.) -A2- A^anafati AlA_ibilu, (inf. n. as above, TA,) The camels trod herbage, or pasture, such as is termed A^unuf, (ISk, S, K,) i. e., which had not been pastured upon. (S.) [But in the TT, as from the M, I find ↓ A=Anafa, (which should rather be written A^aAnafa, or, accord. to the more usual mode, A=nafa,) He trod such herbage, or pasture.] -A3- A^anifa, aor.
Aanafa , (S, M, K,) inf. n. A^anafN, (M,) He (a camel) had a complaint of, or suffered pain in, his nose, from the burap [or nose-ring]: (S, M, K:) from ISk. (S.) ― -b2- A^anifati AlA_ibilu, accord. to certain of the Kilábees, means The flies alighted upon the noses of the camels, and they sought places which they did not seek before. (T.) ― -b3- A^anifa minohu, aor.
Aanafa , inf. n. A^anafN (S, M, Msb, K) and A^anafapN, (S, M, K,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Msb,) [He turned up his nose at it;] he disdained it; scorned it; abstained from it, or refused to do it, by reason of disdain and pride; (S, M, Msb, K;) he disliked it, or hated it, and his soul was above it; (L;) namely, a thing: (S, M, L, Msb:) and he shunned it, avoided it, or kept himself far from it: (Msb:) and he disliked it, or hated it; namely, a saying. (AZ, T, Msb.) You say, maAraA^ayotu A^aHomaY A^anafFA mino fulaAnK [I have not seen any one more vehemently disdainful, or scornful, than such a one]. (S.) And Hamala mino *`lika A^anafFA He conceived, in consequence of that, disdain, or scorn, arising from indignation and anger. (TA, from a trad.) [The verb is also trans. without mn: you say,] yaA^onafu A^ano yuDAma [He disdains, or scorns, or refuses to bear, or to submit to, being injured]. (K.) [When immediately trans.,] A^anifa also signifies He loathed, disliked, or regarded with disgust. (IAar, T.) You say, A^anifa AlbaEiyru AlkalaA^a The camel loathed, disliked, or regarded with disgust, the herbage, or pasture. (T.) And A^anfa AlT~aEaAma wagayorahu He disliked the food &c. (M.) And A^anifato farasiY h`*ihi h`*aA Albalada This my mare disliked this region. (T, as heard from an Arab of the desert.) And taA^onafu faHolahaA She (a woman, and a mare, and a camel, being pregnant,) dislikes her male, or stallion. (T.) And A^anifato, said of a woman, signifies She, being pregnant, had no appetite for anything. (Ibn-Abbád, K.)

2 Aan~afa see 4. -A2- taA^oniyfN also signifies (assumed tropical:) The sharpening, or making pointed, the extremity of a thing. (S.) You say of a spear-head, or an arrow-head, or a blade, A^un~if~, inf. n. taA^oniyfN, (K,) (assumed tropical:) It was sharpened or pointed [at its extremity]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Used as a subst.,] (assumed tropical:) Sharpness of the extremity of the hock; which, in a horse, is approved. (TA.) ― -b3- A^un~ifa taA^oniyfa Als~ayori, said by an Arab of the desert in describing a horse, means (assumed tropical:) He was made even, like as is made even the cut thong or strap. (M.) -A3- (assumed tropical:) The seeking after herbage, or pasture, (K, TA,) such as is termed A^unuf. (TA.) ― -b2- A^n~f maAlahu, (T,) or AlA_ibila, (K,) inf. n. as above; and ↓ A=nafahaA, (T, S, K,) inf. n. A_iynaAfN; (T;) (assumed tropical:) He pastured his beasts upon the first of the herbage: (T:) or he pursued, with the camels, repeatedly, or gradually, or step by step, (S, K, TA,) after the first of the herbage, (S,) or after the herbage
which had not been pastured upon: (K, * TA:) or he went with them thereto. (L.)

4 A=nfhu A=nfh A=nfp , (S, M, K,) inf. n. A_iynaAfN, (S,) He, (S,) or it, (M,) made him to have a complaint of, or to suffer pain in, his nose. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- See also A^anafahu. ― -b3- He, or it, induced him to feel disdain, scorn, indignation, and anger; (IF, M, K, TA;) as also ↓ An~fhu, inf. n. taA^oniyfN: (K:) or caused him to dislike, or hate, or to loath, or feel disgust. (T.) -A2- (assumed tropical:) He hastened it; namely, his affair. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) -A3- See also 2. -A4- A=nf as an intrans. verb: see 1.

5 tataA^an~afu Al$~ahawaAti * (assumed tropical:) She desires of her husband, with eagerness, one thing after another, by reason of intense longing in pregnancy. (T, the Moheet, L, K. *) ― -b2- yataA^an~afu AlA_ixowaAna (assumed tropical:) He seeks the brethren, they disdaining, or scorning, or disliking; not holding social intercourse with any one. (TA.)
8 A_iAotanafa see 10.

10 AstA^nfhu * and ↓ Ay^tnfhu [written with the disjunctive alif Aiytanafahu] (assumed tropical:) He took [its A^anof, i. e.,] the first of it: (M:) he began it, or commenced it: (S, ↓ M, Msb, K: *) or i. q. Aisotaqobalahu [which has also the latter of the two significations mentioned above, (Mgh in art. qbl,) and moreover signifies he anticipated it; and from what follows here, it seems to be probable that this last signification, as well as the other, may be meant by it in this instance]: (T, M:) namely, a thing, (M, Msb,) or an affair. (T.) You say, AstA^nfhu biwaEodK (assumed tropical:) He made him a promise in anticipation; without his asking it of him. (M.) And, of a woman, Ausotuw^onifato biAln~ikaAHi A^aw~alFA (assumed tropical:) [She was just married, or bedded, for the first time]. (M.) See also A^unufN, last sentence. ― -b2- [Hence, Harofu A@sotiy^onaAfK, in grammar, An inceptive particle, placed at the commencement of a new proposition grammatically independent of that which precedes it.]

A^anofN * a word of well-known meaning; (Lth, T, K;) The nose; syn. maEoTisN; (Msb;) the aggregate composed of the two nostrils and the septum and the [bone called] qaSabap, which is the hard part of the Anf; (MF;) i. q. manoxirN [which is evidently an explanation by a synecdoche, as this word properly signifies nostril]: (M:) it pertains to man and to others: (S:) ↓ A^unofN is a dial. var. of the same; (MF, TA;) and so is ↓ A_inofN, which is a form used by the vulgar peculiarly: (TA:) the pl. [of pauc.] is A=nufN and A=naAfN (S, M, Msb, K) and [of mult.] A^unuwfN. (T, S, M, Msb, K.) The dual is applied to The two nostrils; as in the saying of Muzáhim El-'Okeylee, yasuwfu biA^anofiyohi Aln~iqaAEa [He scents with his two nostrils the dust]. (TA.) You say also, huwa yatatab~aEu A^anofahu (tropical:) He scents, or sniffs, the odour, and follows it. (T, [in which, however, I find yatobaEu in the place of yttb~E] O, L, K, TA.) And, of a she-camel, taroA^amu biA^anofihiA (assumed tropical:) [She makes a show of affection with her nose, by smelling her young one; not having true love]. (S, M, K, voce mu*aAy^irN; &c.: see also muEaAriDN.) And maAta Hatofa A^anofihi (S, K, &c., in art. Htf,) and Htf A^anofiyohi, (K ibid.,) (assumed tropical:) He died [a natural death,] on his bed, (K,) without being slain or beaten (S, K) or drowned or burned. (K. [See art. Htf]) And HamiYa A^anofuhu (tropical:) He became vehemently angry, or enraged; as also warima A^anofuhu. (IAth. [See also art. Hmy]) And rajulN HamiY~u AlA^anofi (tropical:) A disdainful, or scornful, man; who disdains, or scorns, being injured. (T, K, TA. [See, again, art. Hmy.]) And samiY~u AlA^anofi (assumed tropical:) [lit. Highnosed, signifies the same;] i. q. A^anofaAnu. (T, K.) And A^anofN fiy Als~amaA='i waA@sotN fiY AlmaA='i (assumed tropical:) [A nose in the sky and a rump in the water]; a prov., applied to him who magnifies himself in words and is little in actions. (Har p. 641.) And HaEala A^anofahu fiY qafaAhu (tropical:) [lit. He put his nose in the back of his neck]; meaning he turned away from the truth, or what was right, and betook himself to what was false, or vain: (K, TA:) expressing the utmost degree of turning away, or turning the head, from a thing. (TA.) And A^aDaAEa maTolaba A^anofihi, (M, K,) and muwoDiEa A^anofihi, (M,) (assumed tropical:) [He neglected, or left unprotected,] the womb from which he had come forth: (Th, M:) or the faroj of his mother. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) And huwa AlfaHolu laA yuqoraEu A^anofuhu, and laA yuqodaEu, He is the speaker, or orator, who is not to be rebutted. (TA.) AlA^asdi A^anofu (assumed tropical:) [The nose of the lion] is the asterism called Aln~avorapu, q. v. (Kzw in his Description of the Mansions of the Moon.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) [A prominent part of anything, as being likened to a nose;] the extremity of anything. (M.) [Thus,] A^anofu jabalK (tropical:) A prominence, or projecting part, of a mountain. (T, S, M, Msb, TA.) A^anofu Aln~aAbi, (S, M. K, TA,) in [some of] the copies of the K erroneously, AlbaAbi, (TA,) (tropical:) The extremity, (S, M, K, TA,) or edge, (M, TA,) of the canine tooth, or tush, when it comes forth. (S, M, K, TA.) A^anofu xuf~i AlbaEiyri (assumed tropical:) The extremity of the manosim [i. e. toe, or each of the two nails of the foot,] of the camel. (T, K.) A^anofu All~iHoyapi (tropical:) The fore part, (M, TA,) or side, (K,) of the beard. (M, K, TA.) A^anofu Aln~aEoli (assumed tropical:) The toe, or foremost extremity, of the sandal [also called its A^asalap and its *unaAbap]. (M.) A^anofaA Alqawosi (assumed tropical:) The two extremities which are in the inner sides of the two curved ends of the bow. (M.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) The first, or first part, of anything; (S, M, K;) relating also to times; (M;) as also ↓ musotaA^onafN (M, TA.) Thus, A^anofu AlmaroEaY (assumed tropical:) The first of the herbage, or pasture. (S, * M.) A^anofu AlmaTari (assumed tropical:) The first vegetation produced by the rain. (T, K.) jaA='a fiY A^anofi Alxayoli (tropical:) [He came among the first of the horses, or horsemen]. (TA.) saAra fiY A^anofi Aln~ahaAri (tropical:) [He journeyed in the first part of the day]. (TA.) h`*aA A^anofu Eamali fulaAnK (tropical:) This is the first of the things which such a one has begun to do. (T, TA.) A^anofu Al$~ad~i, (T, S, M,) and AlEadowi, (M,) (assumed tropical:) The first of the run, or running: (T:) the most vehement thereof. (T, S, M, K. *) A^anofu Albarodi (assumed tropical:) The first of the cold: (T:) the most vehement thereof; (T, S, M;) so says Yaákoob. (S.) ― -b4- (tropical:) A lord, or chief. (IAar, T, K.) You say, huwa A^anofu qawomihi (tropical:) He is the lord, or chief, of his people. (TA.) ― -b5- (tropical:) A piece broken off of a cake of bread. (K, TA.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) A part of ground, or land, that is hard, and lying open, exposed to the sun. (IF, K.)
A^unofN * : see A^anofN, first sentence: -A2- and see A^unufN.
A_inofN A^nAf A^nf A^nwf Anf nAf nf nfA nfY |nf : see A^anofN, first sentence.

A^anifN * A camel having a complaint of, or suffering pain in, his nose, from the burap [or nose-ring]: (ISk, S, M, K:) or wounded by the nose-rein, whether it be with a xi$aA$ or burap (A 'Obeyd, T, M) or xizaAmap [all of which are different kinds of nose-rings]. (A' Obeyd, T.) And consequently, Submissive, and tractable: (S, TA:) or submissive and obedient, that dislikes chiding and beating, and goes as he is able to do spontaneously and easily: (Aboo-Sa'eed, TA:) and ↓ A=nifN signifies the same; (A 'Obeyd, M, K;) but the former is the more correct and the more chaste: (Sgh, K:) by rule, it should be maA^onuwfN, like maSoduwrN, (T, S, M,) and maboTuwnN. (T, S.) To such a camel, the believer is likened in a trad.; (T, S, M;) because he ceases not to complain, or suffer pain; (M;) or because he does not require to be chidden nor to be punished, but endures and performs what is incumbent on him. (Aboo-Sa'eed, TA.) ― -b2- Disdaining, or disdainful; scorning, or scornful; i. q. HamiY~u AlA^anofi: and ↓ A^anofaAnu [signifies the same;] i. q. samiY~u AlA^anofi. (T, K.) -A2- See also A=nifN.

rawoDapN A^unufN * (tropical:) A meadow of new herbage, (Msb,) not pastured upon (S, Msb, K) by any one; (S;) as also ↓ muw^onifN: (Ibn-'Abbád, K:) or untrodden: contracted, by poetic licence, into ↓ A^unofN, in a verse of Abu-n-Nejm. (M.) And kalaA^N A^unufN (assumed tropical:) Herbage not pastured upon (S, M) by any one. (M.) ― -b2- kaA^osN A^onufN (assumed tropical:) A cup of wine not drunk: (K:) or from which one has not drunk before; as though the drinking thereof were [but just] begun; like rawoDapN A^unufN: (S) or (assumed tropical:) full: and in like manner, manohalN A^unufN (assumed tropical:) [a full watering-place]; (M;) or (tropical:) not before drunk from. (TA.) And xamorN A^unufN (tropical:) Wine of which none has before been taken from its jar. (M, TA. *) ― -b3- A^aroDN A^unufN i. q. A^aniygapN, q. v. (M, TA.) ― -b4- naqiy*apN A^unofN (assumed tropical:) A long [as though new and undiminished] coat of mail. (L in art.

nq* * , from El-Mufaddal.) ― -b2- A^amorN A^unufN (assumed tropical:) An event brought to pass at the first, not being before decreed: (K, TA:) accord. to those who assert that there is no decreeing [by God]. (TA.) ― -b3- mi$oyapN A^unufN (assumed tropical:) A goodly [as though novel] gait, or manner of walking. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b4- A=tiyka mino *iY A^unufK is like the phrase mino *iY qabalK; i. e., fiymaA yusotaqobalN [I will come to thee in what is (now) to be begun (of time); meaning, immediately; nearly the same as A=nifFA, but relating to the nearest future time, whereas this latter relates to the nearest past time]. (S, K.) And A^afoEalu *aAka mino *iY A^unufK:
i. e., ↓ fiymaA yusotaA^onafu [I will do that in what is (now) to begun &c.]; like mino *iY EawoDK. (K in art. EwD.)

A^anofapu AlS~alaApi * (assumed tropical:) The beginning, or commencement, of prayer; (K;) i. e. the first saying of Aall~`hu A^akobaru: (TA:) accord. to a relation of a trad., in which it occurs, with damm, [A^unofap,] (IAth, K,) but correctly with fet-h. (Hr, IAth, K.) The p seems to be here added to A^anof as it is in *anabapN for *anabN. (Sgh.)

A^anafapN *
Disdain; scorn; disdainful and proud incompliance or refusal; (Msb;) indignation; and anger: (TA:) a subst. [or, accord. to the S and M and K, an inf. n.] from A^anifa minohu. (Msb.)
A^anofaAnu * : see A^anifN.

A^anofiy~apN *
Snuff, for the nose: but this is postclassical. (TA.)

A^anuwfN * A man very disdainful, scornful, or indignant; very disdainfully and proudly incompliant or refusing; (M;) who disdains, or scorns, exceedingly, to do ignoble deeds: (Har p. 312:) pl. A^unufN. (M.) ― -b2- A woman whose nose has a pleasant odour: (S, M, K:) or whom one likes to smell: (IAar, M:) or who disdains, scorns, abstains from, shuns, or dislikes, that in which is no good. (Ibn-'Abbád, Sgh, K.)

A^aniyfN * (assumed tropical:) A mountain which produces vegetation before other regions. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) And A^aroDN A^aniyfapN, (T, M,) or A^aniyfapu Aln~aboti, (S, K,) (assumed tropical:) Land that produces its vegetation early: (T:) or that produces vegetation quickly: (Et-Táee, ISk, S, K:) or that produces vegetation; as also ↓ A^unufN. (M.) -A2- Applied to iron, i. q. A^aniyvu; i. e. Soft. (Aboo-Turáb, T, K.)
A^unaAfiY~N * (with damm, K) Having a large nose; (Yaakoob, S, M, K;) applied to a man: (M, K:) similar to EuDaAd~iYN and A^u*aAniY~N. (TA.)

A=nafu A=nf [More, and most, disdainful, &c.]. You say, maA raA^ayotu A=nafa mino fulaAn I have not seen any one more disdainful, or scornful, or indignant, than such a one. (S, TA.) -A2- h`*ihi A=nafu bilaAdi A@ll~`hi This is the speediest, in producing vegetation, of the countries of God. (T, S, * M, * K. *)

A=nifN A=nf : see A^anifN. -A2- A=nifFA means (assumed tropical:) In the beginning, or first part, of this present time in which we are; from A^anofN as meaning the “ first, ” or “ first part, ” of a thing: and hence what here immediately follows. (Ham p. 348.) maA *aA qaAla A=nifFA, (T, S, * M, K, * &c.,) and ↓ A^anifFA, (IAar, Bd, K, Jel,) in the Kur [xlvii. 18], (M, &c.,) means (tropical:) What was this that he said just now? (Zj, T, M, Bd, Jel:) or, a little while ago? (IAar, T, K:) i. e., in the first time near to us? (Zj, T, M:) from AisotaA^onafotu Al$~aYo'a “ I began the thing. ” (Zj, T, M.) You say also, A^atayotu fulaAnFA A=nifFA (tropical:) [I came to such a one a little while ago]; like as you say, mino *iY qibalK. (Lth, T.) And jaA='a A=nifFA (tropical:) He came a little while ago; syn. qubayola. (M.) And ↓ faEalahu biA=nifapK, mentioned by IAar, but not explained by him; in my opinion, [says ISd,] like faEalahu A=nifFA (tropical:) [He did it a little while ago: or just now]. (M.) And it is said in a trad., A^unozilato Ealay~a suwrapN A=nifFA A chapter of the Kur-án has been sent down to me now. (TA.)
A=nifapN A=nfh A=nfp (tropical:) The first part of life (mayoEap and A^aw~aliy~ap) of a boy. (Ks, K, TA.) ― -b2- See also A=nifN.
muw^onafN * : its fem., with p, see voce muw^an~afN.
muw^onifN * : see A^unufN.

muw^an~afN * (assumed tropical:) Sharpened at its extremity; or pointed; (M, K;) applied to a spear-head, or an arrowhead, or a blade, (K,) or anything. (M.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Made even: a thong, or strap, made of a certain measure, and evenly. (M.) -A2- A_ibilN muw^an~afapN (assumed tropical:) Camels with which one pursues repeatedly, or gradually, or step by step, after the first of the herbage; and so ↓ muw^onafapN: (M:) and the former epithet is applied to sheep or goats. (K.) ― -b2- The former of these two epithets, applied to a woman, signifies (assumed tropical:) Just married or bedded, (Al~atiY A@sotuw^onifato biAln~ikaAHi,) for the first time. (M.)
maA_onuwfN A^wfY mAnwf wfY A camel that is urged on by [means of the rein attached to] his nose. (M.)

miy^onaAfN * (assumed tropical:) A man who begins to make use of the places of pasturing and alighting; (M;) who pastures his beasts upon the first of the herbage. (As, T, K. * [In the CK, Aunufu AlkalaA^i is put for A^anofa AlkalaA^i.]) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A man (TA) journeying in the beginning, or first part, of the night: (K:) so in all the copies of the K; but correctly, as in the Moheet and the O, in the beginning, or first part, of the day. (TA.)

muw^otanafN * (assumed tropical:) [A place] from which nothing has been eaten; as also ↓ mutaA^an~ifN; (K;) which latter is explained by Ibn-'Abbád as signifying a place not eaten [from] before. (TA.) ― -b2- jaAriyapN muw^otanafapu Al$~abaAbi (assumed tropical:) A girl [in the prime of youth;] in whom no trace of agedness appears. (Sgh, K.)
mutaA^an~ifN * : see muw^otanafN.
musotaA^onafN * : see A^anofN, in the latter part of the paragraph.

1 A^aniqa * , aor.
Aanaqa , inf. n. A^anaqN, It excited admiration and approval by its beauty or goodliness; it pleased, or rejoiced. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also, aor. and inf. n. as above, He rejoiced; was joyful, happy, or pleased. (S, K.) You say, A^aniqotu bihi, (Lth, JK, Msb, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Lth, JK,) I was pleased with it, or by it; or was rejoiced by it. (Lth, JK, Msb, K. [In the CK AaEojaba is erroneously put for A^uEojiba] It is said in a trad., maA mino EaA$iyapK A^a$ad~u A^anaqFA walaA A^aboEadu $ibaEFA mino TaAlibi EilomK There is not any eater by night [i. e. any man] who hath more pleasure and approval and desire and love [in his pursuit, nor any who is further from satiation therein, than the student, or pursuer, of science]; meaning that the man of learning is excessively greedy and insatiable, persevering in vehement desire. (L.) ― -b3- And A^anaqa Al$~aYo'a, (AZ, K,) inf. n. as above, (AZ,) He loved the thing. (AZ, K.)
2 A^n~q * , inf. n. taA^oniyqN, He made, or caused, to wonder. (K, TA.)

4 A=naqaniY A=nqnY A=nqny , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_iyonaAqN and niyqN, (K,) [but the latter is properly a quasi-inf. n.,] It excited my admiration and approval; pleased me; or rejoiced me. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- maA A=naqahu fiY ka*aA How vehemently does he seek, or pursue, or desire, such a thing! or how vehement is he in seeking, pursuit, or desire, with respect to such a thing! (JK, K.)

5 tA^n~q *
He sought, pursued, or desired, the most pleasing of things; (TA;) [he affected nicety, or refinement; he was dainty, nice, exquisite, refined, or scrupulously nice and exact; or chose what was excellent, or best; and he exceeded the usual bounds; as also tanaw~aqa and tanay~aqa, in all these senses;] fiY AlmaToEami, in respect of food, never eating anything but what was clean [and choice]; and fiY Almalobasi, in respect of apparel, never dressing otherwise than well; and fiY AlkalaAmi, in respect of speech, never speaking otherwise than chastely; and fiY jamiyEi AlA^umuwri, in respect of all affairs. (TA in art. nTs.) tA^n~q fiyhi is like tanaw~aqa; (JK, S, K;) i. e. He did it, or performed it (namely, a thing, or an affair,) with niyqap [i. e. daintiness, nicety, exquisiteness, refinement, neatness, or scrupulous nicety and exactness; or in a manner exceeding what is usual]: (S:) or he chose what was excellent, or best, to be done in it, and did it admirably: (TA:) or he did it (namely, his work, Msb) firmly, solidly, soundly, or thoroughly, (Msb, K,) and skilfully. (K: [but in this last sense, 'Alee Ibn-Hamzeh allows only the latter of these two verbs. TA in art. nwq.]) You say also, tA^n~q fulaAnN fiY Al~ar~awoDapi Such a one found himself in the meadow, or garden, (waqaEa fiyhaA,) pleased, or rejoiced, therewith: (S:) or he found it pleasant or delightful, delighted in it, or took pleasure or delight in it, and enjoyed its beauties: and he sought after its beauties, step by step, and was pleased, or rejoiced, therewith, and enjoyed it. (TA.) And tA^n~q AlmakaAna He was pleased, or rejoiced, with the place, and attached to it, not quitting it: (L:) he loved the place. (Fr, K.) It is said in a trad. of Ibn-Mes'ood, A_i*aA waqaEotu fiY A=li H=m= waqaEotu fiy rawoDaAtK A^ataA^an~aquhun~a, or, as in the T, A^ataA^an~aqu fiyhin~a, meaning [When I find myself in the chapters of the Kur-án commencing with Há Meem,] I find myself in meadows, or gardens, the beauties of which I seek after step by step, and with which I am pleased, or rejoiced, and which I enjoy: i. e., I find pleasure, or delight, in reading them, or reciting them, and enjoy their beauties. (TA.)

A^anaqN * inf. n. of 1 [q. v.] (Lth, JK, &c.) ― -b2- [Hence, A pleasing, or rejoicing, state, or condition.] You say, huwa fiY A^anaqK mino Eayo$ihi waxiSobK [He is in a pleasing, or rejoicing, state, or condition, in respect of his life, and in a state of plenty]. (JK.) ― -b3- Goodliness, or beauty, and
pleasingness, of aspect, or outward appearance: or, as some say, a uniform and uninterrupted state of verdure before the eye; because it pleases, or rejoices, its beholder. (TA.) ― -b4- Herbage, or pasturage, (K, TA,) that is goodly, or beautiful, and pleasing, or rejoicing: an inf. n. used as a subst. (TA.)
A^aniqN * : see A^aniyqN.

maA lahu fiY Al$~aYo'i A^aniqapN *
He has no pleasure, or pride, in the thing. (JK.)

A^anuwqN *
A certain bird; (S;) i. e. the raxamap [or female of the vultur percnopterus]; (IAar, S;) called by Kumeyt *aAtu A@somayoni [possessor of two names] because having these two appellations: (S:) or the eagle: and also the former bird: (K:) ISk cites 'Omárah as saying that it is in his opinion the eagle; but that people say it is the rxmp; and he adds, [alluding to a prov., which see below,] that the eggs of the rxmp are found in ruins, and in plain country: (TA:) or the male of the raxam: (JK, TA:) or a certain black bird, having what resembles the Eurof [or comb of the cock], (AA, K,) that deposits its eggs in remote places: (AA:) or a certain black bird, (AA, K,) like a great hen, (AA,) bald in the fore part of the head, (AA, K,) having a yellow bill, (K,) or having a long bill: (AA:) she guards her eggs, and defends her young one, and keeps with her offspring, and submits not herself to any but her mate, and migrates among the first of the migrating birds, and returns among the first of the returning birds, and will not fly while moulting, and will not be deceived by her small feathers but waits until they become quills and then flies, and will not remain constantly in the nests, and will not alight upon the quiver (K) knowing it to contain arrows: (TA:) the word is sing. and pl.: (TA:) or its pl. is A^unuqN. (JK.) Hence the prov., (JK, S,) A^aEaz~u mino bayoDi AlA^anuwqi [More rare than the eggs of the anook]: (JK, S, K:) because this bird guards its eggs, so that they are hardly ever, or never, found; for its nests are on the tops of mountains, and in difficult and distant places; (S, K;) notwithstanding which, it is said to be stupid: (S:) ISd says that the female bird called rxmp may be meant thereby; or the male, because the eggs of the male exist not; or the eggs of the latter may be meant because he often guards them, like as does the male ostrich. (TA.)

A^aniyqN *
Goodly, or beautiful; (S, K;) pleasing, or rejoicing; (JK, S, Msb, K;) as also ↓ A^anaqN: (JK, TA:) and loved. (TA.) You say, rawoDapN A^aniyqN A meadow, or garden, that is loved: and rawoDapN A^aniyqapN a meadow, or garden, that is pleasing, or rejoicing. (TA.)

lahu A_inaAqapN lh AnAqh lh AnAqp and A^anaAqapN (K, and so in some copies of the S,) He has goodliness, or beauty, and pleasingness: but in the L, [and in some copies of the S,] lahu A_inaAqapN walabaAqpN; and what precedes it indicates that the meaning is he has a faculty of doing well or excellently [and of nice or refined skilfulness]. (TA.)
A=naqu A=nq [originally A^A^onaqu] More, or most, pleasing or rejoicing. (TA.)

mutaA^an~iqN * [part. n. of 5; Seeking, pursuing, or desiring, the most pleasing of things; affecting nicety, or refinement; dainty, nice, exquisite, refined, &c.; in respect of food, apparel, speech, &c.:] one who is in a pleasing condition (fiY A^anaqK) in respect of his life, and in a state of plenty. (JK.) It is said in a prov., layosa AlmutaEal~iqu kaAlmutaA^an~iqi, (JK, TA,) i. e. He who is content with what is little, (S, K, in art. Elq,) or what is barely sufficient, of sustenance, (TA in the present art.,) is not like him who seeks, pursues, or desires, the most pleasing of things, or who is dainty, &c., (mano yataA^an~aqu,) and eats what he pleases, (S, K, in art. Elq,) or him who is not content save with the most pleasing of things. (TA in the present art.)

A=nukN A=nk
pure raSaAS [or lead]: or black riSiAS: (Msb:) i. q. A^usorub~u; (S, K;) i. e. raSaASN qaloEiY~N; so says Kt; and Az says, I think it is an arabicized word: (TA:) or white Asrb~: or black Asrb~: or pure Asrb~: (K:) or i. q. qazodiyrN [which is applied in the present day to tin, and pewter]: (Kr:) El-Kásim Ibn-Maan says, I heard an Arab of the desert say, h`*aA raSaASN A=nukN, i. e. [this is] pure [lead]: (TA:) it is of the measure A^afoEulN, [originally A^aA^onukN,] (S, K,) which is one of the forms of pls., (S,) like A^afolusN; (Msb;) and there is no other word of this measure, (Az, S, K,) among sing. nouns, (Az, S,) except A^a$ud~N [originally A^a$odudN], (S, Sgh, K,) and A=jurN in the dial. of those who pronounce it without teshdeed: (Sgh:) it is disputed, however, whether A^a$ud~N be a sing. or a pl.: (Az, TA:) [and as to A=jurN, see what follows:] or, accord. to some, (Msb,) A=nukN is of the measure faAEulN, (Kr, Msb,) and is the only word of that measure in Arabic: (Kr:) or it is a foreign word; and so are A=jurN and [the proper names] A=mulu and kaAbulu. (Msb.) It is said, in a trad., that he who listens to a singing female slave, A=nuk shall be poured into his ears (S, TA) on the day of resurrection. (TA.)

AlA^anaAmu * (T, M, Msb, K) and ↓ AlA=naAmu (K) and ↓ AlA^aniymu, (M, K,) the last allowable in poetry, (M,) i. q. Alxaloqu; (M, K, and Bd and Jel in lv. 9;) i. e. [Mankind; for such is the general meaning of Alxaloqu, or] mankind and the jinn (or genii) and others: (Jel ubi suprà:) or the jinn and mankind: (T, Msb, K:) or what are on the face of the earth of all that are termed Alxaloq [or created beings]: (Lth, T, Msb:) or all that is on the face of the earth: (K:) or everything having a ruwH [i. e. soul, or spirit]: (Bd ubi suprà:) or every one who is subject to sleep. (TA [as though it were derived from Aln~awomu.]) AlAnAm is not mentioned by J, though occurring in the Kur-án. (TA.)
AlA^aniymu * : see above.
AlA=naAmu AlA=nAm : see above.
A_in~amaA A_nmA AnmA : see A_in~a, in art. An
A_inowN A^nw Anw nwY : see A_inoYN, in two places.

1 A^anaY * , (S, M, K,) aor. yaA^oniY, (S,) inf. n. A_inNY (S, M, K) and A^anoYN and A^anaA='N, (M, K,) or, accord. to [some of the copies of] the M, A^anFY, (TA, [in which this is said to be the right form,]) or A^anFA, (as written in the CK,) said of a thing, Its time came; or it was, or became, or drew, near; syn. A^ataY waqotuhu, and jaA='a A^anaAhu; (Bd lvii. 15 [in explanation of a passage cited voce A^ano];) or HaAna: (S, M, K:) or A^anaY, aor. yaA^oniY, inf. n. A^anoYN, signifies it was, or became, or drew, near; and it was, or became, present. (Msb.) You say, A^anaY laka A^ano tafoEala, aor. yaA^oniY; and A=na, aor. yay^iynu; and naAla lk, aor. yaniylu; and A^anaAla; all meaning HaAna laka [The time has come, or has drawn near, for thee that thou shouldst do such a thing: or the time of thy doing such a thing has come to thee: or thy doing such a thing has drawn near]: so says Zj; and Fr says the like: but the best of these is A^anaY laka. (T.) And A^anaY Alr~aHiylu The time of departure came, or drew near; syn. HaAna waqotuhu. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b2- It came, or attained, to its time; to its full, or final, time or state; to maturity, or ripeness; it became mature, or ripe; (T, S, M, IAmb, * Msb, * K;) or, accord. to some, only when said of a plant; (M, K;) [or it signifies also] it became thoroughly cooked. (T, Msb. *) Hence, in the Kur [xxxiii. 53], gayoranaAZiriyna A_inaAhu Not waiting, or watching, for its becoming thoroughly cooked; or for its cooking becoming finished. (T, S, * M.) [See also A_inFY, below.] You say also, A^anaY AlHamiymu, (inf. n. A^anoYN, TA,) The hot water became heated to the utmost degree. (S, K.) And A^anaY AlmaA='u The water became hot to the utmost degree. (M.) -A2- A^anaY, aor. A^uniY~N, inf. n. A^anoYN, It (a thing) was, or became, behind, or after, its time: (Lth, T:) or A^anaY, inf. n. A^uniY~N, it, or he, (a man, TA,) was, or became, behind, backward, or late; it, or he, delayed, or held back; (M, K;) as also A^aniYa, aor. yaA^onaY, inf. n.
A_inFY A^n A^nY A^ny A_n A_ny AnY Any wnY |n |ny ; and ↓ A^an~aY, inf. n. taA^oniyapN. (K.) ― -b2- See also 5, in two places.

2 Aan~aYa see 4, in two places: -A2- and see 1. ― -b2- You say also, A^an~ayotu fiY Al$~aYo'i I fell short, or fell short of what was requisite or what I ought to have done, or flagged, or was remiss, in, or in respect of, the thing. (TA. [The verb is there written without any syll. signs; but the context seems to indicate that it is as above.])

4 A=nY A=nY A=ny and ↓ A^n~Y signify the same. (IAar, T, M.) You say, A=naAhu, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) with medd, (Msb,) aor. yuw^oniyhi, (S,) inf. n. A_iynaA='N, (S, K,) [in the CK, Aanayotuhu AinoyFA is erroneously put for A=nayotuhu A_iynaA='N,] He postponed it, put it off, deferred it, delayed it, retarded it; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) retrained
it, withheld it, impeded it; (S, TA;) whatever the thing be. (T.) And AlT~aEaAma fiY Aln~aAri ↓ A^an~ayotu I kept the food long upon the fire. (TA.) And laA tuw^oni furoSataka Postpone not thou, or defer not, thine opportunity, or the time when thou art able to do a thing. (T.) And it is said in a trad., respecting the prayer of Friday, raA^ayotuka A=nayota waA=*ayota (M, * Mgh, * TA) I see thee to have delayed coming, and to have done what is annoying to others by stepping over the necks [of those already in their places in the mosque]: (As, Mgh, * TA:) a saying of 'Omar. (Mgh.) -A2- A=naAhu also signifies He made him, or it, to be distant, remote, or far off; removed far away, alienated, or estranged, him, or it; like A^anoA=hu [from which it is formed by transposition]. (TA.) [Hence,] yuw^oniyka occurs in a verse of Es-Sulameeyeh; (M, TA;) meaning yunoy^iyka; the ' being put before the n (M.)

5 tA^n~Y *
He acted deliberately, or leisurely, not hastily; as also ↓ AstA^nY; and ↓ A^aniYa, (M, K,) aor. yaA^onaY, (K,) inf. n. A^noYN: (TA:) he acted with moderation, gently, deliberately, or leisurely; without haste; and with gravity, staidness, sedateness, or calmness; fiY AlA^amori in the affair; as also ↓ AstA^nY: (Mgh:) or he acted gently; (IAar, T, TA;) as also ↓ A^aniYa, aor. and inf. n. as above: (TA:) or he acted gently, and waited; fiY AlA^amori in the affair: (S:) or he waited, or was patient, or waited with patience, (T, Msb,) and did not hasten, in an affair. (Msb.) Alt~aA^at~iY and Alt~aA^an~iY are nearly syn.: you say, tA^n~Y lahu He acted gently with him, [or to him,] and did not hasten in his affair. (Mgh.) You say also, bihi ↓ AstA^nY He waited patiently with him; or waited, and had patience, with him; (S, TA;) he did not hasten him; (Lth, T;) as also ↓ AstA^nAhu. ('Eyn, Har p. 67.) And bihi HawolFA ↓ Ausotuw^oniYa [He was waited patiently with for a year]. (S.) And fiY A^amorika ↓ AisotaA^oni Hasten not in thine affair. (Lth, T.) And fiY AlT~aEaAmi ↓ AisotaA^onayotu I waited for the food to become perfectly prepared or cooked. (Har p. 67.) And taA^an~ayotu Alr~ajula (and Ealayohi, M and K in art. nZr, [see AinotaZarahu,]) I waited for the man; as also bihi ↓ AisotaA^onayotu: whence, biAlojiraAHaAti ↓ yusotaA^naY One should wait for the issues, or consequences, or results, of wounds. (Mgh.) And taA^n~ayotuka Hat~aY laA A^anaApa biY [I have waited patiently for thee until there is no disposition to wait patiently in me]. (S.)
10 A_isotaAonaYa see 5, passim.
A^anoYN * : see what next follows.

A_inoYN A^n A^nY A^ny A_n A_ny AnY Any wnY |n |ny (AO, T, S, M, Msb, K) and ↓ A_inFY, (Akh, T, S, Msb,) the latter in [some of] the copies of the K erroneously written A^anaA='N, (TA,) [and in other copies of the same omitted,] and ↓ A_inowN, (Akh, Th, T, S, M, K,) with w substituted for Y, (AAF, M,) and ↓ A^anoYN (K) and ↓ A^anFY, (M, I Amb,) An hour, or a short portion, or a time, or an indefinite time, (saAEapN,) of the night: (Zj, T, S, M, K:) or a time or season (waqotN) of the night: (M in art. Anw:) or i. q. wahonN [the period about midnight; or the time after an hour, or a short period, of the night; or when the night is departing]: (M, K:) or any saAEap [i. e. hour, or short portion, or time,] (M, K) of the night: (M:) [and any period of time; as will be seen below:] or, accord. to some, (M,) ↓ A_inFY signifies the whole day; (M, K;) as also ↓ A^anFY: (K:) the pl. is A=naA='N (T, S, M, Msb, K) and A^unY~N and A_iniY~N. (M, K.) You say, maDaY A_inoYN mina Al~ayoli and ↓ A_inowN [&c.] A time, or season, [&c.,] (waqotN, [&c.,]) of the night passed: (M in art. Anw:) dual A_inoyaAni and A_inowaAni. (S.) And a poet says,
A^atam~ato HamolahaA fiY baEoDi $ahorK
waHamolu AlHaAmalaAti A_nFY Tawiylu
[She completed her gestation in a portion of a month; but the gestation of the pregnant in general is a long period of time]. (IAar, T.) Another uses the phrase DaH~aAku AlA^uniYo, occurring at the end of a verse, [for DH~Ak AlA^uniY~i,] meaning Found to be laughing whenever one comes to him. (M.)

A^anFY * : see A_inoYN, in two places. ― -b2- The utmost point, reach, or degree, (M, K,) of a thing; (M;) as also ↓ A_inFY: so in the phrase, balaga A^anaAhu and A_inaAhu It (a thing, M) attained its utmost point, reach, or degree: (M, K:) or this means, [or, accord. to the CK, “and” it means,] its state of being thoroughly cooked; its state of maturity; or its full, or final, time or state. (K.) [See 1, where an ex. from the Kur xxxiii. 53 is cited. Both words are said to be inf. ns.] -A2- See also A^anaApN.
A_inFY A^n A^nY A^ny A_n A_ny AnY Any wnY |n |ny : see A_iniYN, in two places: ― -b2- and see A^anFY.

A^anaA='N * [Postponement; a putting off; a deferring; a delaying; a retarding: restraint; a withholding; an impeding:] a subst. from A=naAhu, aor. yuw^oniyhi, inf. n. A_iynaA='N, meaning “he postponed it,” &c.: (S, Msb, * TA:) the context of the K erroneously requires it to be understood as a subst. from A^anaY, aor. yaA^onY. (TA.)

A_inaA='N AnA='
A certain thing of which one makes use, (M,) well known; (S, K;) namely, a vessel, or receptacle, (Mgh, Msb,) for water [&c.]: (Mgh:) pl. A=niyapN, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) originally A^aA^oniyapN; (M;) and A^awaAnK; (T, S, M, Mgh, K;) the former a pl. of pauc.; and the latter a pl. of mult., (Mgh,) pl. of A=niyapN. (T, S, M.)

A^anaApN *
Moderation; gentleness; deliberateness; a leisurely manner of proceeding, or of deportment, &c.; patience, as meaning contr. of hastiness: and gravity; staidness; sedateness; calmness: a subst. from taA^an~aY; (S, Msb;) syn. tuw^adapN; (T;) and rifoqN; (Ham p. 317;) and HilomN and waqaArN; (M, Mgh, K;) as also ↓ A^nFY. (M, K, TA. [In the CK, kAlAanoYi is erroneously put for kaAlA^anaY.]) ― -b2- Also Hope: [in this sense, accord. to the TA, written with kesr; but this is doubtless a mistake, probably occasioned by a mistranscription:] so in the charge of 'Orweh to his sons; yaA baniY~a A_i*aA raA^ayotumo xal~apF raAy^iEapF mino rajulK falaA taqoTaEuwA A^anaAtakumo mitohu waA_ino kaAna Einoda Aln~aAsi rajula saw^o'K [O my sons, when ye see a quality exciting admiration and approval, in a man, cut not ye off your hope of him, though he be in the estimation of the people a bad man]. (M.) -A2- A woman in whom is a languor on the occasion of rising, or standing up; (T, S, K;) and a gentle, or grave, deportment: (S:) or in whom is a languor impeding from rising, or standing up: (As:) and wahonaAnapN signifies the like: (T:) Sb says that it is originally wanaApN, like as A^aHadN is originally waHadN; from AlwanaY: (S:) the people of El-Koofeh say that it is only wanaApN: so says Lth: and he says that A^anaApN signifies, as applied to a woman, blessed, prospered, or abounding in good, as it is explained also by ADk, and forbearing, gentle, grave, staid, sedate, or calm, and compliant, or agreeing with another in mind or opinion: and the pl. is A^anawAtN: or, as some say, it signifies a grave, staid, sedate, or calm, woman, who does not clamour, nor utter foul language. (T.)

A^aniY~N * , as part. n. of 1, A thing of which the time has come, or drawn near: and which has come, or attained, to its time; to its full, or final, time or state; to maturity, or ripeness: but accord. to some, only applied to a plant. (M, K.) [Compare A=nK.] -A2- Behind, or after, the time; backward, or late; delayed, or held back; (K, TA; [but wanting in a MS. copy of the former in my possession, and in the CK;]) as also ↓ A=nK. (TA.)

A_Kniyho A^nyh A_nA' Anyh Anyp wnY |ny |nyh |nyp a word expressive of disapproval, and of deeming a thing remote or improbable: Sb relates that it was said to an Arab of the desert, who had taken up his abode in a town, or place, “Wilt thou go forth when the desert shall have become plentiful in herbage?” and he said, A^aA^anaA A_iniyho [What, I, indeed?], meaning “Do ye say this to me when I am know to do thus?” as though he disapproved of their questioning him: but there is much diversity of opinion respecting this word: (TA:) [accord. to some,] it is composed of the redundant A_ino and the meddeh denoting disapproval [followed by the h of silence]. (Mughnee voce A_inN.) [See what is said of the redundant Ano in the present work.]

A^an~aY * signifies Whence? syn. mino A^ayona; (T, S, M;) being an interrogative respecting the direction, or quarter, from which a thing is: (Msb:) and whence [used to denote a condition]: (TA:) and where? and where [used to denote a condition]; syn. A^ayona: (T, K: [in which latter the first signification is not mentioned:]) and as one of the adverbial nouns used to denote a condition, whencesoever; from whatever direction or quarter: (S:) and wherever; wheresoever: (Lth, T:) and when? and when [used to den a condition]; syn. mataY: (T, K: [but in the latter of these, in art. An, in the place of mataY we find Hayovu, which I regard as a mistake:]) and how? syn. kayofa: (Lth, T, S, M, K:) and however. (Lth, TA.) [I mention all these significations together because
one of them is assigned by some authorities and another by others to An~Y in one and the same instance.] You say, A^an~aY yakuwnu h`*aA Whence, from what direction or quarter, from what way, will, or should, be this? (Msb.) And A^an~aY laka h`*aA Whence [came, or cometh,] to thee this? (S.) It is said in the Kur [iii. 32], yaA maroyamu A^an~aY laki h`*aA O Mary, whence [came] to thee this? (T.) And in the same [xxxiv. 51], waA^an~aY lahumu A@lt~anaAwu$u mino makaAnK baEiydK, meaning [But] whence [shall the attaining of belief be possible to them from a distant place, i. e., (as explained in the S in art.

nw$ * ,) in the world to come, when they have disbelieved in the present world? or but how &c.?]. (T.) And in the same [1xxx. 25], accord. to one reading, A^an~aY SababonaA AlmaA='a Sab~aA, meaning Where have we poured forth the water, pouring? but in this is an allusion to the direction [whence the rain comes]; and it may be rendered whence? &c.; and accord. to this reading, the pause upon TaEaAmihN [immediately preceding] is complete. (IAmb, T.) And you say, A^an~aY taA^otiniY A=tika, (S, K,) meaning Whencesoever, or from whatever direction or quarter, thou shalt come to me, I will come to thee. (S.) In the saying of 'Alkameh,
wamuToEamu Algunomi yuwoma Algunomi muToEamuhu
A^an~aY tawaj~aha waAlmaHoruwmu maHoruwmu
the meaning is, [And he who is given spoil to enjoy, (lit., who is fed therewith,) on the day of spoil, is given it to enjoy] wherever he repairs, or however he repairs, [and the prohibited is prohibited.] (Lth, T, TA.) The saying in the Kur [iii. 159], qulotumN A^an~aY h`*aA means Ye say, When is this? or How is this? (T,) or Whence is this? (T, Bd, Jel.) And A^an~aY $y^otumo, in the same, [ii. 223,] may mean Whence, or when, or how, ye will. (TA.) You say also, A^an~aY laka A^ano tafotaHa AlHiSona, meaning How [is it, or will it be, possible for thee to open, or conquer, the fortress]? (S.)

A=nK A=n
Hot, or heated, to the utmost degree: applied to hot water, (S, M, K,) in the Kur lv. 44: (S, M:) fem. A=niyapN; occurring in the Kur lxxxviii. 5. M.) -A2- See also A^aniY~N. -A3- Also A man much characterized by moderation, gentleness, or deliberateness; by a leisurely manner of proceeding, or of deportment, &c.; by patience, as meaning contr. of hastiness; by gravity, staidness, sedateness, or calmness. (S, K. *)

A^atayotuhu A=niyapF baEoda A=niyapK * is a phrase mentioned by AAF, meaning I came to him time after time: in which, [says ISd,] I am of opinion that A=nyp is of the measure faAEilapN from AlA_naY: but the word commonly known is A=winap [pl. of A^awaAnN; or A=yinap, which is syn. with A=winap: see A^awaAnN]. (M.)
A_iniyho A^nyh A_nA' Anyh Anyp wnY |ny |nyh |nyp : see art. AnY.

1 A^ah~a * , (S in art. Awh, and K,) inf. n. A^ap~N (K) and A^ah~apN (S, * K) and the same without teshdeed; (K, * TA; [app. meaning A=hapN, which, however, belongs to art. Awh, q. v.;]) or A_ih~apN; (so in the CK; [but in some copies of the K, and ↓ A^ah~aha, as in the TK, where it is said that the inf. n. of this form of the verb is taA^ohiyhN;]) and ↓ tA^h~h; (K;) [i. q. A=ha and A^aw~aha and taA^ahiyhN; or] He expressed pain or grief or sorrow, or he lamented or complained or moaned, (S, K,) as one in an evil state, and broken in spirit by grief or mourning, and said A=hi, or haAho. (K.) [See a verse cited in art. Awh, voce A=hapN.]
2 Aah~a3a and 5: see above.
A_iho A^h Ah Ap whY |h , i. e. A_i with the h of pausation; imperative of waA^ay, q. v. (Mughnee in art. Alf)
A=hi A=h A=p and A=hK and A=hFA &c.: see art. Awh.

2 A^h~bhu liloA^amori * , [inf. n. taA^ohiybN,] He furnished, prepared, equipped, or accoutred, him, for the thing, or affair; he furnished him, or provided him, with the apparatus, gear, tackling, implements, instruments, tools, or the like, proper, or necessary, for it. (MF.) ― -b2- A^h~b AlA^amora He prepared the thing, or affair. (MF.) ― -b3- See also 5.

5 tA^h~b *
He furnished, prepared, equipped, or accoutred, himself; furnished, or provided, himself with proper, or necessary, apparatus, gear, tackling, implements, instruments, tools, or the like; (S, A, Msb, K;) lils~afari for journeying; (Msb;) or liloA^amori for the thing, or affair; as also ↓ A^h~b. (K.)
A^ahabN * : see A_ihaAbN.

A^uhobapN *
Apparatus, equipments, equipage, accoutrements, furniture, gear, tackling, implements, instruments, tools, or the like; (S, A, Msb, K;) as in A^uhobapu AlHarobi [the apparatus, arms, weapons, equipage, or accoutrements, of war]; (S;) as also hubapN: (K:) pl. of the former, A^uhabN. (S, Msb.) You say, A^axa*a li*`lika AlA^amori A^uhobathu [He took his apparatus, &c., for that thing, or affair; also meaning, he made his preparation, or he prepared himself, for it]. (TA.)

A_ihaAbN A^hAb A_hAb AhAb hAb
A skin, or hide, (A, Msb, K,) in an absolute sense, (A,) of a bull or cow, sheep or goat, or wild animal: (TA:) or a skin, or hide, not yet tanned: (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) and sometimes applied to the skin of a man: (Msb:) pl. (of pauc., TA) A=hibapN (IAar, K) and (of mult., TA) A^uhubN, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, Msb, K,) with two dammehs, (Mgh, Msb,) and ↓ A^habN, (S, Msb, K,) contr. to rule, (S, Msb,) or, accord. to Sb, (L,) this last is a quasi-pl. n.: (Mgh, L:) in one copy of the K, it is written A=hub. (TA.) You say, jaAEuwA Hat~aY A^akaluwA AlA^uhuba [They hungered so that they ate the skins, or hides]. (A.) And kaAda yaxoruju mino A_ihaAbihi fiY Eadowihi (assumed tropical:) [He almost issued from his skin in his running]. (A.) And Haqana Ald~imaA='a fiY A^uhubihaA (assumed tropical:) [He spared the people's blood in their bodies]. (TA, from a trad.)

1 A^ahala * , aor.
Aahula , inf. n. A^uhuwlN; (Msb;) or A^uhila, like EuniYa; (K, TA;) It (a place, Msb, TA) was, or became, peopled, or inhabited. (Msb, K, TA.) ― -b2- A^ahala, aor.
Aahula and
Aahila , inf. n. as above, He married, or took a wife; (Yoo, S, Msb, K;) as also ↓ tA^h~l; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) and ↓ A@t~ahala, [written with the disjunctive alif Ait~ahala, like A@t~axa*a and A@t~azara and A@tamana &c.], (K,) of the measure AftEl. (TA.) ― -b3- A^ahala; (Ks, S, Msb;) or A^ahila, aor.
Aahala ; (K;) or both; (JK;) bihi, (JK,) i. e. biAlr~ajuli, (Ks, S,) or biAl$~aY'i; (Msb;) i. q. A^anisa [He was, or became, sociable, companionable, friendly, amicable, or familiar, with him, i. e. the man; or he was, or became, cheered, or gladdened, by his company or converse, or by his, or its (the thing's) presence]. (JK, S, Msb, K.)
2 A^h~l bihi * , (K,) or A^h~lhu, (Ham p. 184,) inf. n.

taA^ohiylN * , (Ham, K,) He said to him A^aholFA: (Ham:) or he said to him maroHabFA waA^aholFA: (K:) like raH~aba bihi: (TA:) [see A^aholN:] IB says that [the first pers. of] the aor. of this verb is with fet-h to the h [contr. to rule: a strange assertion]. (TA.) ― -b2- A^h~lhu li*`lika, inf. n. as above; and ↓ A=hlhu; He saw him, judged him, thought him, or held him, to be worthy, or deserving, of that; to merit it; to have a right, or just title or claim, to it: (K, * TA:) or he made him to be worthy, or deserving, of that; &c. (TA.) You say, A^ah~alaka A@ll~`hu liloxayori [May God make thee worthy, or deserving, of good, good fortune, prosperity, or the like]. (S.)

4 A=halaka A@ll~`hu fiY Aljan~api * , inf. n. A_iyhaAlN, May God make thee to enter with thy wife into Paradise: (AZ, S, TA:) or may God make thee to have a family in Paradise, and unite thee with them [therein]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 2.
5 taAah~ala see 1.
8 A_iAotahala see 1.

10 AstA^hlhu * as signifying He was, or became, worthy, or deserving, of it, or he merited it, or he had a right, or just title or claim, to it, is not allowable: (Msb, * MF:) not only does J disallow it, but the generality of those before him do so; saying that it is not chaste: in the Fs it is said to be of weak authority; and the expositors thereof confirm this assertion, saying that it occurs, but is inferior to other words in chasteness; and El-Hareeree asserts it to be erroneous: (MF:) or it is good in this sense; and J's disallowance of it is of no account: (K:) Az and Z and Sgh and others assert it to be good: and Az says, in the T, some have asserted the saying fulaAnN yasotaA^ohilu A^ano yukorama A^awo yuhaAna, as meaning [Such a one] is worthy, or deserving, [of being treated with honour, or of being held in light estimation,] to be erroneous; and AlAisotiy^ohaAlu to be only from AlA_ihaAlapu; but I do not disallow it, nor charge with error him who says thus; for I have heard the verb thus used by a chaste Arab of the desert, of the BenooAsad, and there was present a number of Arabs of the desert who did not disapprove his saying: and this is confirmed by the saying in the Kur
[lxxiv. 55], huwa A^aholu Alt~aqoway wa A^aholu Almagofirapi [explained below: see A^aholu]. (T.) -A2- AstA^hl, (JK, K,) or AstA^hl AlA^ahaAlapa, (Msb,) He took the A_ihaAlapa: (JK, K:) or he ate the AhAlp: see this word below. (Msb, TA.)

A^aholN * [The people of a house or dwelling, and of a town or village, and of a country: and the family of a man:] a man's cohabitants of one dwelling or place of abode, (Er-Rághib, Kull p. 84,) and of one town or country: (Er-Rághib:) afterwards applied to a man's fellow-members of one family or race, and of one religion, and of one craft or art or the like: (Er-Rághib, Kull:) or, as some say, relations, whether they have followers or dependents, or not; whereas A=lN signifies relations with their followers or dependents: (Kull:) or it originally signifies relations: and sometimes is applied to followers or dependents: and signifies also the A^ahol [i. e. people, or inhabitants, or family,] of a house or tent: (Msb:) or a man's nearer, or nearest, relations by descent from the same father or ancestor; or his kinsfolk; his relations: (K:) or, accord. to [the Imám] Mohammad, a man's wife [or wives] and his children and household who are the objects of his expenditure; and thus, any brother and sister, or paternal uncle and son of a paternal uncle, or strange or distantly-related child, whom a man feeds or sustains in his abode: the most particular, or most special, dependents, or the like, of a man: on the authority of El-Ghooree: (Mgh:) [J indicates some of these meanings merely by saying that it signifies] the A^ahol of a man, and the A^ahol of a house; as also ↓ A^aholapN: (S:) [see also A=lN; in the explanations of which, certain distinctions between it and A^aholN will be found mentioned:] the pl. is A^aholuwna, [like A^aroDuwna, a form sometimes used for A^araDuwna] (Mgh, Msb, K,) and A^ahaAlK, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) with an additional Y [implied by the tenween, and expressed in the accus. case, and when the word is determinate, as in AlA^ahaAliY,] (S,) contr. to rule, (S, Mgh,) like layaAlK, pl. of layolN, (S,) [and like A^araAD, respecting which and lyaAlK and A^ahaAlK, see A^aroDN,] and A=haAlN, (S, K,) a pl. [of pauc.] sometimes occurring in poetry, (S,) [like A=raADN,] and A^aholaAtN and A^ahalaAtN [as though pls. of A^aholapN]. (S, K.) ― -b2- A^aholu Albayoti The [people or] inhabitants [or family] of the house or tent. (Mgh, K.) But A^awoSaY lA^aholi bayotihi means the same as AwSY lijinosihi, i. e. He left by will, of his property, to the children of his father, [or his kindred by the father's side,] exclusively of all relations of the mother. (Mgh in art. jns.) [See also A^aholu Alr~ajuli, below.] ― -b3- A^ahola AlquraY The [people or] inhabitants of the towns or villages. (TA.) And A^aholu Albaladi The settled, or constant, inhabitants of the country or town. (Msb.) And A^aholu AlHaDari The people of the region, or regions, of cities, towns, or villages, and of cultivated land. (A in art. HDr.) And A^aholu Almadari wa Alwabari (S in art. mdr, &c.) [The people of the towns or villages, or] the inhabitants of the buildings, and of the tents, (Kull,) or deserts. (TA in art. wbr) ― -b4- [A^aholu Alqubuwri, and AlmaqaAbiri, The people of the graces, and of the places of graves; i. e., those buried therein.] ― -b5- [A^aholu Aljan~api The people of Paradise.] ― -b6- [A^aholu Aln~aAri The people of the fire, i. e., of Hell.] ― -b7- See also A^ahilapN. ― -b8- The following is an ex. of Ahl as explained above in the first sentence on the authority of the K: AlA^aholu A_ilaY AlA^aholi A^asoraEu mina Als~iyli A_ilaY Als~aholi a prov. [meaning Kinsfolk are quicker of tendency to kinsfolk than the torrent to the plain]. (TA.) So, too, a saying of a poet cited voce xafoDN. (TA.) [And] A^aholaka waAll~ayola a prov. meaning baAdir A^aholaka waA@Ho*ari All~ayola wa Zulomatahu [Betake thyself early to thy family, and beware of the night and its darkness]. (Har p. 175.) [And] maroHabFA waA^aholFA (S, K) a saying meaning Thou hast come to an ample, or a spacious, or roomy, place, and to [people like thine own] kinsfolk; therefore be cheerful, or sociable, not sad, or shy: (S:) or thou hast found, or met with, [an ample, or a spacious, or roomy, place, and] kinsfolk, not strangers. (K.) [And] A^aholFA wa saholFA wamaroHabFA Thou hast come to a people who are [like] kinsfolk, and to a place that is plain, even, not rugged, and that is ample, spacious, or roomy; therefore rejoice thyself, and be not sad, or shy. (Msb.) ― -b9- A^aholu Aln~abiY~i The [family or] wives and daughters of the Prophet, and his son-in-law 'Alee: or his women; and (as some say, TA) the men who are his A=l; (K, TA;) comprising the grandchildren (A^aHofaAd) and [other] progeny: and so A^aholu Albayoti as used in the Kur xxxiii. 33, occurring also [in a like sense] in xi. 76: (TA:) and AlA^aholu is conventionally applied to the nearer, or nearest, kinsfolk of the Prophet. (Er-Rághib.) ― -b10- A^aholu kul~i nabiY~K also means The people to whom any prophet is sent; (K, TA;) and those who are of his religion. (TA.) ― -b11- In the phrase A=lN A@ll~`hi warasuwlihi, meaning The friends, or the like, (A^awoliyaA=' K, TA,) and the assistants, (TA,) of God and of his apostle, the first word is originally A^ahol. (K, TA.) ― -b12- A^aholu A@ll~`hi is also an appellation which used to be applied to The readers or reciters [of the Kur-án]. (TA.) ― -b13- A^aholu Alr~ajuli also signifies (tropical:) The man's wife; (Mgh, * Msb, * K;) as well as his wife and children; (TA;) [so, too, in the present day, A^aholu bayoti Alr~ajuli;] and so, too, ↓ A^aholatuhu. (K.) Hence the phrase banaY Ealay A^aholihi [see art. bnYi]: (Kull:) and daxala biA^aholihi and daxala EalaY A^aholihi [see art. dxl]. (Har p. 502; &c.) ― -b14- A^aholu ma*ohabK [The people of, or] those who follow, (K, TA,) and believe, (TA,) a certain persuasion, or body of tenets. (K, TA.) [Hence,] A^aholu Als~unapi [Those who conform to the institutes of Mohammad]. (TA.) [And] A^aholu AlA^ahowaA='i [The people of erroneous opinions;] those whose belief is not that of the class termed A^aholu Als~un~api, but who hare the same qibolap. (TA.) [And] A^aholu AlA_isolaAmi Those who follow the religion of El-Islám. (Mgh.) [And] A^aholu AlquroA=ni Those who read, or recite, the Kur-án, and perform the duties enjoined thereby. (Mgh.) [And] A^aholu AlkitaAbi [The people of the Scripture, or Bible: and] the readers, or reciters, of the Mosaic Law, and of the Gospel. (TA.) ― -b15- A^aholu AlEilomi [The people of knowledge, or science;] those who are characterized by knowledge, or science. (Msb.) ― -b16- A^aholu AlA^amori [The possessors of command: or] those who superintend the affairs [of others]; (K, TA;) like A^uluwAlA^amri, q. v. (TA.) ― -b17- A^aholu AlmaraAtibi [The people of exalted stations, posts of honour, or dignities]. (TA in art. rtb.) ― -b18- A^aholu Al*~im~api (Mgh in art. *m) and A^aholu AlEahodi (TA in art. Ehd) Those persons, (Mgh, TA,) of the unbelievers, (Mgh,) [namely, Christians, Jews, and Sabians, but no others,] who have a compact, or covenant, with the Muslims, (Mgh, TA,) paying a poll-tax, whereby they are secure of their property and blood, (Mgh,) or whereby the Muslims are responsible for their security [and freedom and toleration] as long as they act agreeably to the compact. (TA.) ― -b19- A^aholN also signifies The possessors, or owners, of property: as in the Kur iv. 61. (TA.) ― -b20- A^aholN lika*aA A person, (S, K,) and persons, for it is used as a sing. and as a pl., (K,) having a right, or just title, to such a thing; entitled thereto; worthy, or deserving, thereof; meet, or fit, for it: (S, K:) the vulgar say ↓ musotaA^ohilN, which is not allowable: (S:) or this assertion of J's is of no account. (K: see 10.) You say, huw A^aholN liA_ikoraAmi He is entitled to be, or worthy of being, treated with honour. (Msb.) And lik~uli ↓ huwa A^aholapN xayor [He is entitled to, or worthy of, all that is good]. (Ibn- 'Abbád.) And wud~K ↓ A^ahlapN He who is, or they who are, entitled to, or worthy of, love, or affection. (S, Sgh.) And hence, in the Kur [lxxiv. last verse], huwa A^aholu Alt~aqowaY waA^aholu Almagofirapi (TA) He is the Being entitled to be regarded with pious fear, and the Being entitled to forgive those who so regard Him. (Jel.) In the phrase A^hola AlvanaA='i waAlmajodi [0 Thou who art the Being entitled to praise and glory], occurring in a form of prayer, the first word is mansoob as a vocative: and it may be marfooa, as the enunciative of an inchoative suppressed; i. e. A^anota A^aholu [Thou art the Being entitled &c.]. (Msb.) ― -b21- [Frequently, also, A^aholN signifies The author, or, more commonly, authors, of a thing; like SaAHibN and A^aSoHaAbN; as in A^aholu AlbidaEi The author, or authors, of innovations; and A^aholu AlZ~ulomi The author, or authors, of wrong.]
A^ahilN * : see A^aholiyYN.
A^aholapN * : see A^aholN, in four places: -A2- and see A^ahlapN.

A^ahilapN *
i. q. maAlN [Property; or cattle]: so in the saying A_in~ahumo laA^aholu A^ahilapK (JK, K) [app. meaning Verily they are sojourners, or settlers, possessed of property, or cattle]: ↓ A^aholN here signifying HuluwlN [pl. of HaAl~N]. (JK, TA.) [But] Yoo says that ↓ humo A^aholu A^aholapi and A^ahilapK means They are people of the distinguished sort. (TA.)

A^aholiY~N * A domestic beast [or bird]; a beast [or bird] that keeps to the dwelling [of its owner];
(JK, Msb, K, TA;) contr. of waHo$iY~N; (TA;) as also ↓ A^ahilN. (K.) You say HumurN A^aholiy~apN [Domestic asses]: (JK, TA:) occurring in a trad., in which their flesh is forbidden to be eaten. (TA.)

A^aholiy~apN * The quality of having a right, or just title, to a thing; worthiness, or desert; meetness, or fitness; in Pers. sazawaAriY: (Golius, app. from a gloss. in a copy of the KL:) the state, or quality, of meetness, or fitness, [of a person,] for the bindingness of the rights which the law imposes for one or upon him. (TA.)

A_ihaAlapN A^hAl A^hAlh AhAlh AhAlp
Grease: (S:) or melted grease: (Msb:) or fat: or melted fat: or olive-oil: and anything that is used as a seasoning or condiment: (K:) such as fresh butter, and fat, and oil of sesame: (TA:) or melted fat of a sheep's tail and the like. (JK.) Hence, saroEaAna *aA A_ihaAlapN, a prov., mentioned in art. srE; (K, * TA;) or, as some say, wa$okaAna. (TA.)

A=hilN A=hl , (JK, S, Msb, K,) [said by those unacquainted with the verb A^ahala in the first of the senses explained in this art. to be] a kind of rel. n., (TA,) and ↓ maA^ohuwlN, (JK, K,) A place peopled, or inhabited: (Msb:) or a place having people: (JK:) or the former has this signification; and the latter signifies having its people in it: (ISk, K:) or the former has this last signification: (Yoo, S:) pl. of the latter maA=hilu, occurring in a poem of Ru-beh [app. by poetic licence for maA=hiylu]. (TA.) You say qaroyapN A=hilapN A peopled, or inhabited, town or village. (Msb.) And A^amosato niyraAnuhumo A=hilapN Their fires became in the evening attended by many people. (TA.)
maA^huwlN * : see A=hilN. -A2- variydapN maA^ohuwlapN [A mess of crumbled bread] having much A_ihaAlap, q. v. (A, TA.)

mutaA^ah~ilN *
Having a wife. (Har p. 571.)
musotaA^ohilN * : see A^aholN; latter part of the paragraph. -A2- Also Taking, or eating, A_ihaAlap, q. v. (S.)

A^awo * a conjunction, (M, Mughnee, K,) to which the later authors have ascribed meanings amounting to twelve: (Mughnee:) a particle which, when occurring in an enunciative phrase, [generally] denotes doubt, and vagueness of meaning; and when occurring in an imperative or a prohibitive phrase, [generally] denotes the giving of option, or choice, and the allowing a thing, or making it allowable. (S.) ― -b2- First, (Mughnee,) it denotes doubt. (T, S, M, Msb, Mughnee, K.) So in the saying, raA^ayotu zayodFA A^awo EamorFA [I saw Zeyd or 'Amr]. (T, * S, Msb.) And jaA=niY rajulN A^awi A@moraA^apN [A man or a woman came to me]. (Mbr, T.) And labiy^onaA yawomFA A^awo baEoDa yawomK [in the Kur xviii. 18 and xxiii. 115, We have remained a day or part of a day]. (Mughnee.) ― -b3- Secondly, (Mughnee,) it denotes vagueness of meaning. (S, Msb, Mughnee, K.) S [it may be used] in the first of the .exs. given above. (Msb.) And so in the saying, waA^an~aA A^awo A_iy~aAkumo laEalaY hudFy A^awo fiY DalaAlK mubiynK [And verily we or ye are following a right direction or in manifest error], (S, Mughnee,) in the Kur [xxxiv. 23]; (S;) the ex. being in the former Aw. (Mughnee.) ― -b4- Thirdly, (Mughnee,) it denotes the giving of option, or choice. (T, S, M, Mughnee, K.) So in the saying, kuli Als~amaka A^awi A@$orabi All~abana [Eat thou the fish, or drink thou the milk]; i. e. do not thou both of these actions; (Mbr, T, S;) but choose which of them thou wilt. (Mbr, T.) And tazaw~ajo hinodFA A^awo A^uxotahaA [Take thou as wife Hind or her sister]. (Mughnee.) And [in like manner] it denotes the making choice. (T.) [So when you say, saA^atazaw~aju hinodFA A^awo A^uxotahaA, meaning I will take as wife Hind or her sister; whichever of them I choose.] ― -b5- Fourthly, (Mughnee,) it denotes the allowing a thing, or making it allowable. (T, S, Msb, Mughnee, K.) So in the saying, jaAlisi Hasana A^awi A@bona siyriyna [Sit thou with El- Hasan or Ibn-Seereen]. (Mbr, T, S.) And qumo A^awi A@qoEudo [Stand thou or sit]: and the person to whom this is said may do [one or] both of the se actions. (Msb.) [And similar exs. are given in the Mughnee.]) But walaA tuTiEo minohumo A=vimFA A^aw kafuwrFA [in the Kur lxxvi. 24, And obey not thou, of them, a sinner or a person very ungrateful to God,] means that thou shalt not obey either of such persons: (Mbr, T, Mughnee:) in which case Aw is more forcible than wa; for when you say to a person, laA tuTiEo zayodFA waEamorFA [Obey not thou Zeyd and 'Amr], he may obey one of them, since the command is that he shall not obey the two. (Zj, T.) ― -b6- Fifthly, (Mughnee,) it denotes unrestricted conjunction. (Mughnee, K.) So in the saying, in the Kur [iv. 46 and v. 9], A^awo jaA='a A^aHadN minokumo mina AlgaAy^iTi [And if any one of you cometh from the privy]; (TA;) [where, however, it may also be rendered or, though] meaning wajaA='a; (T, TA;) the w in this explanation being what is termed a denotative of state. (T.) So, too, accord. to AZ, in the expression A^awo yaziyduwna [And they exceeded that number], in the Kur [xxxvii. 147]: but see below. (TA.) And so in the words, A^awo A^ano nafoEala fiY A^amowaAlinaA maA na$aA='u [And our doing, in respect of our possessions, what we will], in the Kur [xi. 89]. (T, TA.) ― -b7- Sixthly, it denotes transition, (Mughnee,) used in the sense of [the adversative particle] balo, (T, S, M, Mughnee, K,) in a case of amplification of speech; (S;) accord. to Sb, on two conditions; that it shall be preceded by a negation or a prohibition, and that the agent shall be mentioned a second time; as in maA qaAma zayodN A^awo maA qaAma EamorNw [Zeyd did not stand: nay, rather 'Amr did not stand]; and laA yaqomN zaydN A^awo laA yaqumo Eamoruw [Let not Zeyd stand: nay, rather let not 'Amr stand]. (Mughnee.)
