Accord. to Fr, (Th, M, Mughnee,) it has this meaning in A^awo yaziyduwna [Nay, rather they exceeded that number], (Th, S, M, Mughnee,) in the Kur [xxxvii. 147, cited above]: (S:) or the meaning is, or they would exceed [that number] in your estimation: or these words with those preceding them in the same verse mean, we sent him to a multitude of whom, if ye saw them, ye would say, They are a hundred thousand, or they exceed [that number]; (M, Mughnee; *) so that it denotes doubt on the part of men, not of God, for He is not subject to doubt: (M:) or we sent him to a hundred thousand in the estimation of men, or they exceeded [that number] in the estimation of men; for God does not doubt: (S:) or Aw is here used to denote vagueness of meaning: (IB, Mughnee:) or, it is said, to denote that a person might choose between saying, “they are a hundred thousand,“ and saying, “they are more;“ but this may not be when one of the two things is the fact: or, accord. to some of the Koofees, it has the meaning of wa: and each of these meanings, except the last, has been assigned to Aw as occurring in the Kur ii. 69 and xvi. 79. (Mughnee.) ― -b8- Seventhly, it denotes division; (Mughnee, K; *) as in the saying, Alkalimapu A@somN A^awo fiEolN A^awo HarofN [The word is a noun or a verb or a particle]: so said Ibn-Málik: or, as he afterwards said, in preference, it denotes separation (Alt~afriyq) divested of the attribute of denoting doubt and vagueness of meaning and the giving of option or choice; adducing as one of his exs. of this meaning the saying, waqaAluwA kuwnuwA huwdFA A^awo naSaAraY [in the Kur ii. 129, And they said, “Be ye Jews” or “Christians”]; because the use of w in division is better; as when you say, Alkalimapu A@somN wafiEolN waHarofN: or it denotes, accord. to some, distinction (Alt~afoSiyl); and the meaning of the ex. last cited, say they, is, and the Jews said, “Be ye Jews,” and the Christians said, “Be ye Christians.” (Mughnee.) It is [said to be] used in this last sense (that of AltfDyl) in the saying, kunotu A=kulu All~aHoma A^awi AlEasala [I used to eat flesh-meat or honey]; i. e. I used to eat flesh-meat one time and honey another time: and so in the Kur vii. 3 and x. 13. ― -b9- Eighthly, (Mughnee,) it is used in the sense of the exceptive A_il~aA, (Mughnee, K,) or A_il~aA A^ano (M;) and in this case the aor. after it is mansoob, because of A^ano suppressed. (Mughnee, K.) So in the saying, laA^aqotulan~ahu A^awo yusolima [I will assuredly slay him or he shall become a Muslim; i. e., unless he become a Muslim]. (Mughnee. [And a similar ex. is given in the M.]) So, too, in the saying,
wakunotu A_i*aA gamazotu qanaApa qawomK
kasarotu kuEuwbahaA A^awo tasotaqiymaA
[And I used, when I pinched and pressed the spear of a people, to break its knots, or joints, or its internodal portions, (the shaft being a cane,) or, i. e. unless, it became straight]: (Mughnee, K: *) a prov., of which the author is Ziyád ElAajam; meaning, when a people behaved with hardness to me, I endeavoured to soften them: (TA in art. gmz:) thus related by Sb, the verb ending it being rendered mansoob by Aw; and thus he heard it from some one or more of the Arabs; but in the original verses, which are but three, it is tasotaqiymu, with refa. (IB and TA in art. gmz.) [And similar to these above are the sayings,] A_n~ahu lifulaAnK A^awomaA binajodK qarZahu [Verily it belongs to such a one or there is not, i. e. unless there be not, in Nejd, a qaraZap (see art. qrZ)]: and laA=tiyan~aka A^awo maA binajodK qaraZapN [I will assuredly come to thee or there
is not, i. e. unless there be not, in Nejd, a qaraZap]; meaning I will assuredly come to thee, in truth. (T.) ― -b10- Ninthly, (Mughnee,) it is used in the sense of A_ilaY, (Mughnee, K,) or A_ilaY A^ano; (S;) in which case also the aor. after it is mansoob, because of A^ano suppressed: (Mughnee:) and in the sense of Hat~aY [which is also syn. with A_itaY]. (Fr, T, M, K.) So in the saying, laA^aDoriban~ahu A^awo yatuwba [I will assuredly beat him until he repent]. (S. [And similar exs. of Aw as explained by Hat~ay are given in the T (from Fr) and in the M and in the Mughnee.]) And so in the saying of the poet,
laA^asotasohilan~a AlS~aEoba A^awo A^udorika AlmunaY
famaA A@noqaAdati AlA=maAlu A_il~aA liSaAbiri
[I will assuredly deem easy what is difficult until I attain the objects of wish; for hopes become not easy of accomplishment save to one who is patient]. (Mughnee.) ― -b11- Tenthly, some say, (Mughnee,) it denotes nearness [of one event or thing to another]; as in the saying, maA A^adoriY A^asal~ama A^awo wad~aEa [I know not whether he saluted or bade farewell]: (Mughnee, K: [but in the CK this ex. is misplaced:]) this, however, is manifestly wrong; Aw being here used to denote doubt, and the denoting of nearness being only inferred from the fact of the saluting being confounded in the mind with the bidding farewell, since this is impossible or improbable when the two times are far apart. (Mughnee.) ― -b12- Eleventhly, (Mughnee,) it occurs as a conditional, (T, Mughnee, K,) accord. to Ks alone; (T;) or rather as a conjunctive and conditional; waA_ino being meant to be understood in its place; though in truth the verb that precedes it indicates that the conditional particle [A_ino] is meant to be understood [before that verb], and Aw retains its proper character, but forms part of that which has a conditional meaning because conjoined with a preceding conditional phrase. (Mughnee.) So in the saying, laA^aDoriban~ahu EaA$a A^awo maAta, (Mughnee, K,) i. e., A_ino EaAiD baEoda AlD~arobi wa A_ino maAta [I will assuredly beat him if he live (after the beating) or if he die]: so says Ibn-Esh-Shejeree. (Mughnee.) ― -b13- Twelfthly, accord. to Ibn-Esh-Shejeree, on the authority of some one or more of the Koofees, (Mughnee,) it denotes division into parts, or portions; as in the saying [in the Kur ii. 129, before cited,] waqaAluwA kuwnuwA huwdFA A^aw naSaAraY, (Mughnee, K,) i. e. And they said, “Be ye, some of you, Jews, and, some of you, Christians:” (TA:) but [IHsh says,] it appears to me that the meaning here is that of Alt~afoSiyl mentioned before. (Mughnee.) ― -b14- [In the K it is said to occur also in the sense of A^ano: but this is evidently a mistake, app. originating in one of the two principal sources of the K, namely, the M, in which the same is said, but is exemplified by a phrase in which it is explained by A_il~aA A^ano, the eighth of the meanings of A^awo mentioned above.] ― -b15- See also A^aw~N below.
A^awa * in A^awa lamo yarawoA &c. is [the conjunction] wa with the interrogative A prefixed to it. (Fr, T.)

A^aw~i mino ka*aA * (T, M) and A^aw~a (M) [Alas, on account of, or for, such a thing!] an expression denoting complaint of distress, or of anxiety, or of grief or sorrow; (T;) or an expression of grief or sorrow; (M;) like ↓ A=wi and ↓ A=wK and ↓ A^awataAh (K and TA in art. Awh,) or ↓ A^awataAhu (CK in that art.,) or ↓ A^aw~ataAh, or ↓ A=w~ataAh, (S in that art., [the h in one copy of which is marked as quiescent,]) and like A=hi and A^awohi &c. (S and Msb and K in art. Awh: see A=hi in that art.) AZ says, one says, A^awohi EalaY zayodK [meaning Alas, for Zeyd!] with kesr to the h, and Ealayoka ↓ A^aw~ataA [thus without h, meaning Alas, for thee!] with t; an expression of regret for a thing, whether of great or mean account. (T.)

A^aw~N * The word ↓ A^awo when made a noun. (T, K.) So say the grammarians. (T.) You say, h`*hi A^aw~NHasanapN [This is a good A^awo]. (T.) And to one who uses the phrase A^afoEalu ka*aA A^awo ka*aA, (T,) you say, daEi AlA^aw~ajaAnibFA [Let thou, or leave thou, the word A^awo alone]. (T, K.)

A^aw~apN * [A moaning (see its syn. A=hapN in art. Awh)] is said by some to be of the measure faEolapN, in which the p is the sign of the fem. gender; for they say, samiEotu A^aw~ataka [I heard thy moaning], making it t: and so says Lth; A^aw~apN is after the manner of faEolapN: (T:) you say, A^aw~apF laka [May God cause moaning to thee!], (Lth, T, and S in art. Awh,) and A=hapF laka: [but accord. to J, the former of these is cognate with the latter; for he says that] the former is with the h suppressed, and with teshdeed to the w. (S in art. Awh, where see A=hapN.) ― -b2- A^aw~ataA Ealayka; and A^aw~ataAh, or A=w~ataAh, or A^awataAh, or A^awataAhu: see A^aw~i mino ka*aA.

A^uw~apN *
i. q. daAhiyapN [A calamity, a misfortune, &c.: or, perhaps, very cunning, applied to a man]: pl.

A^uwawo * ; (AA, T, K, TA; [but in copies of the K, written A^uwawN;]) which is one of the strangest of the things transmitted from the Arabs; the regular form being A^uw~aY, like quw~ay, pl. of quwapN; but the word occurring as above in the saying of the Arabs, maA huwa A_il~aA A^uw~apN mina AlA^uwawo [It is no other thing than a calamity of the calamities: or, perhaps, he is no other than a very cunning man of the very cunning]. (AA, T, TA.)
A=wi A=w and A=wK: see A^aw~i: and see A=hi in art. Awh.
A^awawiY~N * and A=wiY~N: see A=yapN, in art. AY.
A=w~ataAh A=wtAh A=wtAp : see A^aw~i.

1 A=ba A=b , aor. yaw^uwbu, (T, S, &c.,) inf. n. A^awobN (S, M, Msb, K) and A_iyaAbN and A^awobapN (T, S, M, K) and A^ayobapN, (M, K,) Y taking the place of w, (M,) and A_iybapN (Lh, M, K) and maA=bN [like maA=lN], (Msb, TA,) He (an absent person, T) returned (T, S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K) to his place, (Sh,) or to a thing, (M,) or from his journey; (Msb;) as also ↓ A^w~b, (M,) inf. n. taA^owiybN and taA^oyiybN; (K;) and ↓ tA^w~b; (M, K;) and ↓ Ay^tAb [written with the disjunctive alif AiytaAba]; (S;) and ↓ A^ay~aba, [a quasi-quadriliteralradical verb, originally A^ayowaba,] of the measure fayoEala, (M,) inf. n. A_y~aAbN, (M, K,) originally A_ywaAbN, of the measure fiyEaAlN, (M, TA,) or, accord. to Fr, A_iy~aAbN is incorrect, and the right word is A_iyaAbN: (TA:) [and if so, A^ay~aba is perhaps changed from A^aw~aba, like as A^ayobapN is from A^awobapN; and taA^oyiybN is perhaps its inf. n., changed from taA^owiybN:] or, as some say, A_iyaAbN signifies only the returning to one's family at night: (M, TA:) and A^aholahu ↓ tA^w~b and Ahlh ↓ Ay^tAb [as well as A=ba A_ilaY A^aholihi] signify he returned to his family at, or in, the night: (T, TA:) or A=ba A_ilayohimo, (S,) [or A=bahumo, accord. to a copy of the A, where we find A^ubotu baniy fulaAnK,] aor. as above; (TA;) and ↓ taA^aw~abahumo (S, A, K) and ↓, taA^ay~abahumo, (K,) Y taking the place of w, (TA,) inf. n. mutaA^aw~abN and mutaA^ay~abN, (M, * [in which the two forms of the verb are also given, but with the sing. pronoun of the third pers. instead of the pl.,] and K,) each in the form of a pass. part. n.; (TA;) he came to them at night: (S, M, * A, K:) and A=ba AlmaA='a, (M,) inf. n. A^awobN, (K,) signifies he came to the water, to drink, at night; as also ↓ Ay^tAbhu; (M, K;) and ↓ tA^w~bhu: (M:) or, accord. to AZ, taA^aw~abtu signifies I came in the beginning of the night. (S.) You say also, A=bati Al$~amosu, (T, S, &c.,) aor. taw^uwbu, (M,) inf. n. maA=bN, (T,) or A_iyaAbN [in the CK AayAb] and A^uyuwbN, (M, K,) The sun returned from its place of rising, and set: (Msb:) or the sun set; (T, S, M, A, K;) as though it returned to the place whence it commenced its course; (M;) [or] it is a dial. var. of gaAbat. (S.) And A=ba A_ilayohi People came to him from every direction, or quarter. (TA, from a trad.) The poet Sáideh Ibn-El-'Ajlán uses the expression, laA=baka murohafN, meaning A thin sword would have come to thee; in which the verb may be trans. by itself, or the prep. A_ilaY may be understood. (M, TA.) ― -b2- He returned from disobedience to obedience; he repented. (TA.) And A=ba A_ilaY A@ll~`hi He returned unto God from his sin, or offence, and repented. (Msb.) ― -b3- A=ba bihi A_ilayohi He made him to return to him, or it; as also A_layohi ↓ Aw~bhu. (M.) And A=ba yadahu A_ilaY sayofihi, (as in a copy of the T,) or biyadihi, (as in a copy of the A, [which is probably here the more correct],) He put back his hand to his sword to draw it: (Lth, T, A:) and AlY qawosihi [to his bow] to draw it: and AlY sahomihi [to his arrow] to shoot it. (A.) ― -b4- See also 2.

2 A^w~b * : see 1, first sentence: ― -b2- and the same again, near the end. ― -b3- He repeated, or echoed, the praises of God: thus in the saying [in the Kur xxxiv. 10], yaA jibaAlu A^aw~ibiY maEahu 0 mountains, repeat ye, or echo ye, the praises of God with him; [i. e., with David;] (S, * M, TA;) but some read mEh ↓ AuwbiY, meaning return ye with him in praising as often as he returneth therein: (M, TA:) or, accord. to the former reading, the meaning is, 0 mountains, labour ye with him in praising God all the day, until the night: (T:)
for ― -b4- A^w~b, (T, A,) inf. n. taA^owiybN, (T, A, K) also signifies It (a company of men) journeyed by day: (Aboo-Málik, T:) or all the day, (T, A, K,) to the night, (T,) without alighting to rest: (TA:) tA^wyb being the same kind of day-journeying as A_isoA=dN is of night-journeying: (T, M:) or he journeyed all the day, and alighted at night: (T, S:) or he journeyed by night: (Msb:) or tA^wyb (M, L, K) and ↓ muw^aAwabapN (Lth, T, L, K) signify the vying, one with another, of travellingcamels, in pace, or going. (Lth, T, M, L, K.) A poet says,
↓ tajidohu miy^owabaA ↓ waA_ino tuw^aAwibohu
[And if thou, or they, (meaning camels,) vie with him in pace, or going, thou wilt, or they will, find him to be one that overcomes therein]: so as related by Lth: but as related by others, tuw^aw~ibohu. (T.)
3 A=wb 5 , inf. n. muw^aAwabapN: see 2, in two places.
5 tA^w~b * and tA^y~b : see 1, in five places.
8 Ay^tAb * : see 1, in three places.
Q. Q. 1 A^ay~aba * , originally A^ayowaba: see 1, first sentence.

A=bu A=b
The name of a [Syrian] month [corresponding to August, O. S.]: an arabicized word. (IAar, M, K.)

A^awobN * an inf. n. of 1. (S, M, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Also The returning of the fore and hind legs of a beast in going along: (T, M, A, * K:) or quickness in the changing, or shifting, of the fore and hind legs in going along: (S:) and simply quickness, or swiftness. (M, K.) One says, maA A^aEojaba A^awoba yadayohaA How wonderful is the returning [or quick shifting] of her fore legs! (A.) And to one going at a quick pace, one says, AlA^awoba AlA^awoba [meaning Keep to the quick changing, or shifting, of the legs; a verb being understood: or Trot on! Trot on!]. (A.) ― -b3- A right, or direct, way, course, or tendency; syn. qaSodN and AisotiqaAmapN. (M [in which these two syns. are mentioned together] and K [in which another explanation intervenes between them, namely EAdp, as though they were meant to be understood in different senses, which I do not think to be the case].) ― -b4- A direction: as in the saying, ramaY A^awbFA A^awo A^awobayoni [He shot, or cast, in one direction, or in two directions]. (M, A.) ― -b5- A course, way, mode, or manner, of acting, or conduct, or the like: (A:) custom. (Lh, M, A, K.) You say, kunotu EalaY Sawobi fulaAnK waA^awobihi I was [proceeding] in the course, way, mode, or manner, of acting, &c., of such a one. (A.) And maA zaAla h`*aA A^awobahu This ceased not to be his course, way, mode, or manner, &c.: (A:) or his custom. (Lh, M, A.) ― -b6- A way, or road: (M, Msb, K:) a quarter: ('Eyn, M, A, K:) a tract, or side: ('Eyn, S:) a place: (S:) a place to which one returns [like maA=bN]. (A, Msb.) You say, jaAw^uwA mino kul~i A^awobK They came from every way, or road, (M, Msb,) or quarter, ('Eyn, M, A,) or tract, or side, ('Eyn, S,) and place, (S,) or place to which one returns. (A, Msb.) And A^awobaA AlwaAdiY signifies The two sides of the valley. (A.) -A2- Bees: (M, K:) a quasi-pl. n.: as though the sing. were A=y^ibN: AHn says that they are so called because of their returning to the mabaA='ap, i. e. the place where they hive for the night. (M, TA.) See A=y^ibN. ― -b2- The clouds. (K.) ― -b3- The wind. (K.)

A^awobapN * and ↓ A^ayobapN Return; (T, A, K;) as also ↓ A_iyaAbapN, a subst. from A=ba. (Msb.) You say, liyahoniy^oka A^awobapu AlgaAy^ibi [May the return of the absent give thee joy]. (TA.) And fulAnN sariyEu AlA^awobapi and ↓ AlA^ayobapi Such a one is quick in return. (A 'Obeyd, T, S. *) ― -b2- Return from disobedience to obedience; repentance. (TA in art. Ayb.) ― -b3- kalaAmN laA A^awobapa lahu Speech, or language, without profit. (A.) -A2- A^awobapN is also the sing. of A^awobaAtN, which signifies The legs of a beast. (K, TA.)
A^ayobapN * : see A^awobapN, in two places. -A2- Also, (as in some copies of the K,) or ↓ A_iybapN, (accord. to the CK,) or ↓ A=y^ibapN, (accord. to the TK,) A noon-day draught or drink. (K.)
A_iybapN Aybh Aybp |yb |ybh |ybp : see what next precedes.
A^awuwbN * A she-camel quick in the changing, or shifting, of her fore and kind legs in going along. (S.)
A_iyaAbapN A_yAb A_yAbh AyAbh AyAbp : see A^awobapN.

A^aw~aAbN *
Frequent in returning. (T.) ― -b2- Frequent in returning unto God, from one's sins; (M, TA;) wont to repent, or frequent in repenting: (Zj, T, A, Mgh, Msb:) or turning from disobedience to obedience: or (S, L:) or a praiser of God; (Sa'eed Ibn-Jubeyr, TA;) by which is here meant, in the prayer of the period of the forenoon called AlD~uHaY, when the sun is high, and the heat violent; hence termed SalaApu AlA^aw~aAbiyna; which is performed when the young camels feel the heat of the sun from the parched ground: (TA:) or obedient: (Katádeh, TA:) or one who reflects upon his sins in solitude, and prays God to forgive them: (TA:) or one who keeps, or is mindful of, the ordinances prescribed by God, (HafiyZN, [which is thus explained by Bd and Jel as occurring in the Kur l. 31,]) and does not rise from his sitting-place until he begs forgiveness of God: ('Obeyd Ibn-'Omeyr, T, TA: * [but this is evidently meant as an explanation of A^aw~aAbN together with HafiyZN: see the Kur ubi suprà:]) or one who sins, and then returns to obedience, and then sins, and then returns to obedience. (TA.)
A=y^ibN * act. part. n. of A=ba; Returning: [&c.:] (M, Msb:) pl. A^uw~aAbN and A^uy~aAbN and ↓ A^awobN [q. v.]: (M, K:) or, accord. to some, the last is a quasipl. n. (M, TA.)

A=y^ibapN * The coming of camels to water, to drink, every night: whence the saying,
laA taridan~a AlmaA='a A_il~aA A=y^ibaho
[Do not thou come to the water, to drink, unless coming to it every night]. (IAar, M.) ― -b2- See also A^ayobapN.

maA=bN mA=b
A place to which one returns: (T, S, K:) a settled, or fixed, abode, or dwelling-place: (TA:) the place to which one is translated, or removed, by death: (K, TA:) the goal to which the course of life ultimately leads one; or place to which one returns in the ultimate state, or world to come. (T, TA.) ― -b2- The place where the sun sets. (TA.) ― -b3- [A day-journey: pl. maA=wibu; as in the saying,] bayonahuma valaAvu maA=wiba Between them two are three day-journeys. (K.)
miy^owabN * [A camel that overcomes in vying with another, or others, in pace, or going]: see an ex. voce A^aw~aba. (T.)

maA=bapu Albiy^ori * [The place where the water flows again into the well to supply the deficiency occasioned by drawing;] the mabaA='ap of the well; i. e. the place where the water collects in the well. (TA.)
riyHN muw^awibapN * , (IB, CK,) or muw^aw~abapN, (as in a copy of the M, and in some copies of the K,) A wind blowing throughout the whole day: (M, K:) or a wind that comes at night. (IB.)
muw^otaAbN * : see mutaA^aw~ibN, in two places.
mutaA^aw~abN * an inf. n. of 5, q. v.; as also ↓ mutaA^ay~abN. (M, * K.)

mutaA^aw~ibN *
Returning to one's family at, or in, the night; as also ↓ muw^otaAbN: (TA:) or, as also ↓ mutaA^ayibN, coming at night: or coming in the beginning of the night: (S:) [and so ↓ muw^otaAbN, as in the following ex.:]
wamano yat~aqo faA_in~a A@ll~`ha maEohu warizoqu A@ll~`hi muw^otaAbN wagaAdi
[And whoso feareth God, verily God is with him; and the supply of God cometh to him at night, or in the beginning of the night, and cometh early in the morning: yat~aqo being here put for yat~aqi, by a necessary poetical licence: see art. wqY]. (S.)
mutaA^ay~abN * : see mutaA^aw~abN.
mutaA^ayibN * : see mutaA^aw~ibN.

1 A^awida * , aor. yaA^owadu, inf. n. A^awadN, It (a thing, T, S, M, or an arrow, AHn, M) was, or became, of itself, crooked, curved, or bent. (T, S, M, A, * K.) [See also 5.] -A2- A=da, aor. yaw^uwdu, inf. n. A^awodN, It (the day) receded, in the evening. (T, L.) ― -b2- It (the evening, T, S) declined. (T, S, K.) ― -b3- It (a thing, L) returned. (M, L, K.) ― -b4- A=dati AlZ~ilaAli The shadows returned, and inclined towards the east. (L.) ― -b5- A=da Ealayohi He inclined towards him; or pitied him. (M.) -A3- A=dahu, (T, S, Msb,) first pers. A^udotuhu, (M,) or A^udt~uhu, (K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, Aidt~uhu,]) aor. yaw^uwdu, inf. n. A^awodN, (As, T, M, Msb,) He crooked, curved, or bent, it; (As, T, S, L, Msb, K;) i. e., a stick, (As, T, L,) or other thing; (L;) as also ↓ A^w~dhu. (L, K.) ― -b2- A=dahu, aor. yaw^uwdu, (T, S, M, &c.,) inf. n. A^awodN (S, M, K) and A^uwuwdN, (M, K,) It (a load) oppressed him by its weight; pressed heavily upon him; burdened him. (AZ, T, S, A, Msb.) And It (a thing, or an affair,) oppressed, distressed, or afflicted, him: (M, L, K:) and [in like manner] ↓ tA^w~dhu, (L, K,)
or ↓ tA=wdhu, (T,) as also tA=dAhu, (L, K,) the last formed by transposition (T, L) from the second, (T,) or first, (L,) said of an affair, it pressed heavily upon him; oppressed him. (T, L, K.) You say, ↓ maA A=daka fahowa liY A=y^idN What hath burdened [or distressed] thee, it (that thing) is burdening [or distressing] to me. (S.)
2 Aaw~ada see 1.

5 tA^w~d *
It (a stick, T, L, or some other thing, L) became, by an extraneous operation, crooked, curved, or bent; (T, S, M, A, L, K;) as also ↓ AnA=d. (T, S, M, L, K: [in the CK faA^otAda is erroneously put for faA@noA=da.]) El-'Ajjáj says,
lamo yaku yanoA=du faA^amosaY A@noA=daA
[He used not to become bent, and he has become bent], making the pret. to be a denotative of state because qado is meant to be understood, as in the saying in the Kur [iv. 92], A^awo jaAw^uwkumo HaSirato Suduwruhumo. (S.) You say also, taA^aw~adato fiY qiyaAmihaA She (a woman) bent in her rising, by reason of her heaviness. (T and L in art. wA^d.) -A2- : see A=dahu.
6 tA=wdhu tA=wdh tA=wdp : see A=dahu.
7 AnA=d AnA=d : see 5, in two places. ― -b2- Also He became oppressed, or burdened [by a load]. (Msb.)
A^awidN * ; (T, M;) or ↓ A=wadu; fem. A^awodaA='u; (K;) Crooked, curved, or bent. (T, M, K.)
A=wadu A=wd ; fem. A^awodaA='u: see what next precedes.

A=y^idN *
Burdening [or distressing]. (S.) See 1, last sentence.

maw^uwdN *
Oppressed, pressed heavily upon, or burdened, by a load. (S.)

maA=widu mA=wd
Calamities: (IAar, M, L, K:) as also mawaAy^idu, which is app. formed by transposition. (M, L.) Some say that mA=wd is pl. of muw^oyidN, and derive this word [which see in art. Ayd] from A=dahu, aor. yaw^uwdN, meaning “ it oppressed him by its weight: ” (T, L:) or it has no sing. (IAar, M.)

A_iwaz~N A^wz A_wz A_wzp Awz wz (S, Msb, K) and A_iwaz~apN, (S,) or the latter is the n. un. of the former, [which is a coll. gen. n.,] (Msb,) i. q. baT~N [The goose, or geese; and the duck, or ducks; but Awz~ is generally applied to the former of these birds; and bT~, to the latter; agreeably with a statement in the Jm, that baT~N is applied by the Arabs to the small, and A_iwaz~N to the large]; (S, K;) as also waz~N, of which the n. un. is waz~apN: (Msb:) A_iwaz~N is of the measure fiEal~N: (Msb:) [but see what follows:] the pl. is A_iwaz~uwna, (S, Msb, K,) a form which is sometimes used, (S, Msb,) and which is anomalous. (Msb.) [See also kurokiY~N.] ― -b2- [Hence,] A_iwaz~N also signifies (assumed tropical:) Short and thick: (K:) fleshy without being tall: (Lth, TA:) fem. with p. (TA.) El-'Okberee asserts that the A^ is augmentative, because it is followed by three radical letters: (MF, TA:) but ISd says that it is of the measure fiEal~N, and may not be of the measure A_ifoEalN, [i. e., originally A_iwozazN,] because this does not occur as the measure of an epithet. (TA.) [It seems, however, that Awz~ is in this case a subst. used tropically as an epithet, after the manner of many nicknames.] ― -b3- Also, applied to a man, and to a horse, and to a camel, Firm in make: (AHei in the Expos. of the Tes-heel, and TA:) or, applied to a horse, compact and strong in make. (TA.)

A_iwaz~ay A_wzp A_wzy AwzY Awzy
A manner of walking in which is a moving up and down: or leaning on one side; (K;) [the latter omitted in the CK;] at one time on the right and at another on the left [like a goose or duck]: (TA:) and the walk of a sprightly horse. (TA.) Az says that it may be of the measure A_ifoEalaY, [i. e., originally A_iwozaz~aY,] or fiEal~aY; but Abu-l-Hasan holds the latter to be the more correct, because it is the measure of many words relating to walking; as jiyaD~aY, and difaq~aY. (TA.)

A^aDN maA^owazapN *
A land abounding with the birds called A_iwaz~. (Sgh, K.)

A=sN A=s [The myrtle;] a certain kind of tree, (S, Msb, K,) well known, (S, K,) fragrant, (IDrd, M, Msb,) and evergreen, abundant in the land of the Arabs, growing in the plains and mountains, and increasing so as to become a great tree: (AHn, M, TA:) n. un. with p: (AHn, M, Msb, K:) IDrd says, I think it an adventitious word, although used by the Arabs, and occurring in chaste poetry. (M, TA.)

1 A=fati AlbilaAdu A=ft AlblAd , aor. taw^uwfu, inf. n. A^awofN and A=fapN (M, TA) and A^uwuwfN, (M,) or A^uw^uwfN, (TA,) The country, or countries, had therein what is termed A=fap [i. e. a blight or blast or the like, or a pest or plague or the like]. (M, TA.) And A_iyfa AlT~aEaAmu, (Ibn Buzurj, T,) or Alz~aroEu, (K,) or Alb~a$oY'u, with the verb in the pass. form, (Msb,) like qiyla, (K,) The wheat, or seed-produce, or thing, became affected, or smitten, with what is termed A=fap [i. e. a blight, blast, taint, canker, or the like]. (T, K, Msb.) And A=fa Alqawomu, (M, TA,) and A^uwfuwA, (K,) thus in a correct copy of the 'Eyn, (TA,) and A_iyfuwA, (Lth, T, K,) and A^ufuwA, (K, TA,) [in the CK Auf~ifuwA,]) and A_ifuwA, (Lth, T, K, [in the CK AufuwA,]) the last, namely, A_ifuwA, with the A termed mumaAlap, having a quiescent letter [i. e. Y] rendered apparent by utterance but not by writing, between it and the f, (T, K, * [in which is a strange omission, of the words saAkinN bay~anahu All~afoZu laA AlxaT~u as in the T, or saAkinapN yubay~inuhaA Alx as in the TA,] TA,) The people became affected, or smitten, with what is termed A=fap [i. e. a pest or plague or the like]. (Lth, T, M, K.) Lth says, in this case one says A_ifuwA, and in one dial. A_iyfuwA: (T:) in several copies of his book, in one dial. A^uf~ifuwA, with two distinct f s, of which the former is with teshdeed: but in some copies as mentioned just before. (Sgh, TA.)

A=fapN A=fh A=fp [A blight, blast, taint, canker, disease, bane, pest, plague, or the like; any evil affection; an evil; a cause of mischief or harm or injury; anything that is noxious or destructive; a calamity;] i. q. EaAhapN; (S, Msb, K;) i. e. (Msb, [in the K “ or, ”]) an accident that mars, or corrupts, that which it affects, or befalls, or smites: (T, M, O, Msb, K:) pl. A=faAtN. (Msb, K.) [See 1.] One says, A=fahu AlZ~arofi AlS~alafu wa A=fapu AlEilomi Aln~isEyaAnu [The bane of elegance in manners, or the like, is the overpassing the due limits therein, and arrogating to oneself superiority therein, through pride; and the bane of science is forgetfulness]. (T.) And it is said in a trad., A=fapu AlHadiyvi Alka*ibu wa A=fapu AlEilomi Aln~isoyaAnu [The bane of discourse is lying; and the bane of science is forgetfulness]. (TA.) And hence the saying, likul~i $aYo'K A=fapN wa liloEilom A=faAtN [To everything there is a bane; and to science there are banes]. (TA.)

maw^uwfN * , (Ks, T, S, M, Msb, K,) originally maA^owuwfN, (Msb,) and ↓ may^iyfN, (Ibn-Buzurj, T, K,) Affected, or smitten, with what is termed A=fap; (T, S, M, &c.;) applied to wheat, (Ks, Ibn-Buzurj, T, M,) or seed-produce, (S, K,) &c. (Msb.)
may^iyfN * : see maw^uwfN.
A^uwqiy~apN * : see art. wqY.

1 A=la A=l , aor. yaw^uwlu, (T, S, M, &c.,) inf. n. A^awolN (T, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and maA=lN (M, K) and A_iyaAlN, which last is used as a subst. in relation to objects of the mind, (Msb,) and A^ayoluwlapN [like dayomuwmapN], (TA,) He, or it, returned; syn. rajaEa; (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) and EaAda; (T;) [and he resorted; (see an instance voce A_iy~alN;)] A_ilayohi to it; (M, K;) namely a thing [of any kind; the thing, or place, whence he, or it, originated, or came; his, or its, origin, or source; his, or its, original state, condition, quantity, weight, &c.; any place; and a former action, or saying, or the like: see rajaEa, by which, as the explanation of A=la, may be meant to be implied some other significations, here following, which these two verbs have in common]: (M:) and A=la Eanohu he (a man, M) returned, or reverted, from it. (M, K.) ― -b2- From A=la as syn. with rajaEa is the phrase, fulaAnN yaw^uwlu A_ilaY karamK [meaning either Such a one returns to generosity, or, as karamN is used in the sense of kiraAmN, is referable to generous, or noble, ancestors]. (TA.) [And hence the phrase,] A=la A_ilayohi binasabK [He bore a relation to him, as a member to a head, by kindred], and bidiynK [by religion]. (Ibn-'Arafeh.) And the saying, in a trad., mano SaAma Ald~ahora falaA SaAma wa laA A=la, i. e. (tropical:) [He who fasts ever, or always, may he neither fast] nor return to what is good. (TA.) [In the Mgh, art. dhr, for A=l I find A^afoTara; and it is there said that this is an imprecation uttered by the Prophet, lest a man should believe
this kind of fasting to be ordained by God; or, through impotence, should become insincere; or because, by fasting all the days of the year, he would do so on the days on which fasting is forbidden. See other readings voce A^alaA in art. Alw.]) ― -b3- Hence also the saying, A=lti AlD~arobahu A_ilaY Aln~afosi, meaning (assumed tropical:) The blow, or stroke, resulted in destroying life; in slaying, or killing. (Mgh.) ― -b4- Hence also, A=la AlA^amoru A_ilaY ka*aA [The affair, or case, became ultimately reduced to such a state, or condition; came to such a result; came to be thus]. (Msb.) ― -b5- Hence also, Tabaxotu Al$~araAba faA=la A_ilaY qadori ka*aA I cooked the wine, or beverage, and it became reduced (rajaEa) to such a quantity. (S.) And Tabaxahu Hat~aY A=la A_ilaY Alv~uluvi A^awiAlr~ubEi He cooked it (namely nabiy* [i. e. must, or mead, or wort,]) until it became reduced (rajaEa) to the third, or to the fourth: (T:) or, said of the same, (Mgh,) or of medicine, (TA,) Hat~aY A=la Alman~aAni man~aA waAHidFA, (Mgh,) or A_ilaY man~K waAHidK, (TA,) until twice the quantity, or weight, of a man~ became [reduced to] (SaAra) one man~. (Mgh.) ― -b6- [Hence also, majaAzu AlA^awoli The proleptic, or anticipative, trope; as faSiylN applied to “a young camel” before it is weaned, because it is to be weaned.] ― -b7- [And hence also, app.,] A=la Al$~aYo'u, inf. n. maA=lN, The thing [became reduced in quantity or size;] decreased; diminished; or became defective, or deficient. (M, K.) And A=la laHomu Aln~aAqapi The flesh of the she-camel went away, so that she became lean, or slender and lean, or lean and lank in the belly. (T, K.) ― -b8- A=la, (T, S, M, K,) inf. n. A^awolN (T, M, K) and A_iyaAlN, (M, K,) is also said of tar, (T, S, M,) and of honey, (S,) and of milk, (M,) and of wine, or beverage, (TA,) and of urine, (M,) or of the urine of camels that have been contented with green pasture instead of water, at the end of their being in that state, (T,) and of oil, (M, K,) and other things, (K,) as meaning It became thick: (T, S, M, K:) said of milk, it thickened and coagulated: (M:) said of wine, or beverage, it thickened, and became intoxicating in its utmost degree: (Az, TA:) and said of oil, it attained its full perfume, or sweetness of odour, by being well prepared or compounded. (T.) ― -b9- maA laka taw^uwlu A_ilaY katifayoka [written in the TA without any vowel-signs, app. meaning (tropical:) What aileth thee that thou shruggest thy shoulders? lit., drawest thyself together to thy two shoulder-blades?] is said [to a man] A_i*aA A@noDam~a A_ilayohimaA waA@jotamaEa [when he draws himself together to them, and contracts himself]; and is a tropical phrase: so says Z. (TA.) ― -b10- A=la mino fulaAnK He escaped, or became safe or secure, from such a one: a dial. var. of waA^ala: (T, K:) of the dial. of the Ansár. (TA.) ― -b11- You say also, A=la, aor. yaw^uwlu; (T, Msb;) or A^awila, aor. yaA^owalu; (K;) meaning He, or it, preceded; went before; was, or became, before, beforehand, first, or foremost; (T, Msb, K;) and came: (Msb:) with this, also, waA^ala is syn.; and from it [says Az] is most probably derived A^aw~alu, so that its original form is A^aA^owalu: [or, as Fei says,] hence is derived the phrase, used by the vulgar, AlEa$oru AlA^aw~alu with fet-h to the hemzeh [as meaning “the first, or preceding, ten (nights of the month),” for AlA^uwalu, pl. of AlA^uwlaY, fem. of AlA^aw~alu; but this is generally regarded as being originally AlA^awoA^alu, from waA^ala]. (Msb.) -A2- A=lahu: see 2. ― -b2- Accord. to Lth, (TA,) A^ulotuhu, (M, K,) aor. A^aw^uwluhu, inf. n. A^awolN, (TA,) signifies I made it (namely, milk, M, or oil &c., K) to thicken, (M, K,) and to coagulate; (M;) the verb being both intrans. and trans.: (K:) but Az says that it is not known as trans., in this sense, in the language of the Arabs [of the classical ages]. (TA.) -A3- A=la raEiy~tahu, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor. yuw^uwlu, inf. n. A^awolN (S) and A_iyaAlN, (S, M, K,) of which the simple subst. is A_iyaAlapN, (S, * Msb,) He (a prince or commander, S, or a king, M, K) ruled, or governed, his subjects; presided over their affairs, as commander or governor; (S, M, Msb, K;) and did so well: (S:) and A=la Ealayohimo, inf. n. A^awolN and A_iyaAlN and A_iyaAlapN, [or this last, as said above, is a simple subst.,] he presided over them; held command, or authority, over them; (M, K;) namely, a people, or company of men; (K;) or, over their affairs. (TA.) It is said in a prov., (M,) qado A^ulonaA waA_iyla EalayonaA (T, S, M) We have ruled and been ruled; (T;) we have presided and been presided over. (M.) ― -b2- A=la maAlhu, (T, S, M, * Msb, K,) inf. n. A_iyaAlapN, (T, Msb,) He put into a good, or right, state, or condition, and managed, or tended, his mAl [meaning cattle]; (T, S, M, * K;) as also ↓ Ay^tAlhu [written with the disjunctive alif AiytaAlahu], (K,) inf. n. AiytiyaAlN: (S:) or he managed his camels, and his sheep or goats, in such a manner that they throve, or became in a good state or condition, by his management. (Msb.) Lebeed describes a female singer
A_ibohaAmuhaA ↓ bimuwat~arKtaA^otaAluhu
(T, S,) meaning with a stringed lute, (EM p. 169,) which her thumb adjusts; (S, EM;) from A^ulotu, (T, S,) signifying I put into a good, right, or proper, state, or condition. (T. [But see another reading in the first paragraph of art. Awy.]) You say also, A^ulotu Al$~aYo'a meaning I composed, or collected together, the thing, and put it into a good, right, or proper, state, or condition: and some of the Arabs say, A@ll~`hu Ealayoka ↓ A^aw~ala A^amoraka, i. e. May God compose for thee thine affair: and, by way of imprecation, A@ll~`hu ↓ laA A^aw~ala Ealayohi $amolahu [May God not compose for him his discomposed, disorganized, deranged, or unsettled, affair, or affairs]. (T.) ― -b3- A^ulotu AlA_ibla, inf. n. A^awolN and A_iyaAlN, also signifies I drove the camels: (M:) or, accord. to the T, I bound the camels' udders with the A^aSir~ap (SararotuhaA) until the time of milking, when I loosed them. (TA.)

2 A^w~lhu A_ilayohi * , (M, K,) inf. n. taA^owiylN, (TA,) He returned it (namely, a thing, M) to him, or it; he made it, or caused it, to return to him, or it; syn. rajaEahu: (M, K: in the CK raj~aEahu:) and ↓ A=lahu also signifies the same; syn. rad~ahu. (TA.) You say, A^aw~ala A@ll~`hu Ealayoka DaAl~ataka May God restore to thee thy stray; (T, * TA;) cause it to return to thee; (TA;) bring together thee and it. (T.) And A^aw~alotuhu A_ilaY ka*aA I caused him, or it, to come to such a state or condition; brought, or reduced, him, or it, thereto; syn. Say~arotuhu A_ilayohi. (T.) ― -b2- See also 1, near the end of the paragraph, in two places. ― -b3- taA^owiylN also signifies The discovering, detecting, revealing, developing, or disclosing, or the explaining, expounding, or interpreting, that to which a thing is, or may be, reduced, or that which it comes, or may come, to be: (S, O, TA:) you say, A^aw~alotuhu, inf. n. taA^owiylN; and ↓ taA^aw~alotuhu, inf. n. taA^aw~ulN; in one and the same sense: and hence the saying of El-Aashà:
Hub~ihaA ↓ EalaY A^an~ahaA kaAnato taA^aw~ulu
riboEiY~i Als~iqaAbi faA^aSoHabaA ↓ taA^aw~ula
(S:) or Hub~ahA ↓ tAw~al: (so in a copy of the T: [the former word being, accord. to this reading, a contraction of tataA^aw~alu; but this does not altogether agree with what here follows:]) AO says, taA^aw~ulu Hub~ihaA means tafosiyruhu wamarojiEuhu: [i. e., the explanation of her love, or of the (poet's) love of her, and the state, or condition, to which it eventually came, is this:] (S:) it was small in his heart, and ceased not to grow until it became great; like as the little young camel [born in the season called rbyE, or in the beginning of the breeding-time,] ceases not to grow until he becomes great like his mother, (T, * S,) and has a son accompanying him: (S:) [or] A^w~lhu and ↓ tA^w~lhu, (M, K,) inf. n. of the former as above, (K,) when said of language, signify dab~arahu waqad~arahu wafas~arahu [he considered its end, or what it might be to which it led or pointed, and compared one part of it with another, and then explained, or expounded, or interpreted, it]: (M, K:) hence, [if the explanation in the M and K be meant to denote three distinct meanings, which I do not think to be the case,] it would seem as though taA^owiylN and tafosiyrN were syn.; but accord. to other authorities, they differ: (TA:) [Az says,] accord. to Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà, these two words and maEonFY are all one: but tA^wyl seems to me to signify the collecting the meanings of dubious expressions by such expression as is clear, or plain, without dubiousness: or, accord. to Lth, it is the interpreting of language that has different meanings; and this cannot be rightly done but by an explanation which changes the expression; as also ↓ tA^aw~ulN: (T:) or the turning a verse of the Kur-án from its apparent meaning to a meaning which it bears, or admits, when the latter is agreeable with the Scripture and the Sunneh: for instance, in the words of the Kur [vi. 95, &c.], yuxoriju A@loHaY~a mina Almay~iti, if the meaning be [thus explained] “He produceth the bird from the egg,” this is tfsyr: and if [it be explained as meaning] “He produceth the believer from the unbeliever,” or “the knowing from the ignorant,” this is tA^wyl: so says Ibn-El-Kemál: (TA:) [hence, although it may often be rendered by interpretation, like tfsyr, it more properly signifies the rendering in a manner not according to the letter, or overt sense; explaining the covert, or virtual,
meaning; interpreting in a manner not according to the obvious meaning:] or the reducing a thing to its ultimate intent, whether it be a saying or an action: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or tfsyr signifies the “discovering, detecting, revealing, or disclosing, what is meant by a dubious expression;” and tA^wyl, the reducing one of two senses, or interpretations, which an expression bears, or admits, to that which suits the apparent meaning: (L and K in art. fsr, and TA in that and in the present art.:) or the former signifies the “expounding, explaining, or interpreting, the narratives which occur collected without discrimination in the Kur-án, and making known the significations of the strange words or expressions, and explaining the occasions on which the verses were revealed;” and the latter, the explaining the meaning of that which is muta$aAbihi, [or what is equivocal, or ambiguous,] i. e., what is not understood without repeated consideration. (TA: [in which are some further explanations; but these add nothing of importance.]) ― -b4- [Hence, A^w~l lafoZFA, in grammar, He rendered a word, or an expression, or a phrase, in grammatical analysis, by another word, or expression, or phrase.] ― -b5- And [hence likewise,] taA^owiylN signifies also The interpretation, or explanation, of a dream; the telling the final sequel, or result, thereof: (M, K:) as in the Kur xii. 101. (M.) ― -b6- It is also used [as a simple subst.] to signify The end, issue, result, or final sequel, of a thing; syn. EaAqibapN; (Bd in iv. 62 and xvii. 37;) or ↓ maA=lN; (Jel in the same places;) or marojiEN, and maSiyrN; as in the Kur [iii. 5], wamaA yEolamu taA^owiylahu A_il~aA A@ll~`hu [But none knoweth the end, &c., thereof, except God]: (A'Obeyd, T:) or this phrase means, but none knoweth when will be the resurrection, and to what the case will eventually come, (T, M,) when the hour shall arrive, (TA,) except God: (T, M:) so says Aboo-Is-hák: (T:) and in like manner, [in the Kur vii. 51,] halo yanoZuruwna A_il~aA taA^owiylahu means Do they wait for aught save the result to which their case will come by the resurrection? (Aboo-Is-hák, T, M:) or, the result to which it will come (Bd, Jel) in the manifestation of its truth by the appearance of the promises and threats of which it has told? (Bd:) in like manner, also, the saying, taqowy A@ll~`hi A^aHosanu taA^owiylFA means The fear of God is best in respect of result; syn. EaAqibapF. (TA.)

5 taAaw~ala see 2, in the former half of the paragraph, in six places. ― -b2- tA^w~l fiyhi Alxayora He discovered in him the existence of good, or goodness, from its outward signs: and he sought, or looked for, good, or goodness, in him. (TA.) You say also, taA^aw~alotu fiY fulaAnK AlA^ajora I sought, or looked for, recompense in (or of or from) such a one. (T.)
8 A_iAotawala see 1, near the end of the paragraph, in two places.

10 AstA=l Alr~uw^oyaA *
He sought the interpretation of the dream, by consideration. (TA in art. swA^.)

A=lN A=l A man's A^ahol [or family]; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) i. e. his relations: (Msb:) his Ea$iyrap [or kinsfolk; or nearer, or nearest, relations by descent from the same father or ancestor; &c.]; from A^awolN as signifying rujuwEN, because recourse is had to them in all affairs: (Har p. 578:) and his household; (S, TA;) the people of his house: (Msb:) and his followers; (S, Msb, K;) including soldiers: (S, TA:) and his A^awoliyaA=' [i. e. friends, and the like]: (K:) those who bear a relation to him, as members to a head, (mano A=la A_ilayohi,) by religion or persuasion or kindred; as in the Kur iii. 9 and viii. 54 and 56 &c.: (Ibn-'Arafeh:) [or in these and many other instances, it may be rendered people:] but in general it is not used save in relation to that in which is eminence, or nobility; so that one does not say, A=lu AlA_isokaAfi, like as one says A^aholuhu: (K:) and it is peculiarly used as a prefix to the proper names of rational beings; not to indeterminate nouns, nor to nouns of places or of times; so that one says, A=lu fulaAnK; but not A=lu rajulK, nor A=lu zamaAni ka*aA, nor A=lu mawoDaEi ka*aA, like as one says, [A^aholu rajulK, and A^aholu zamaAni ka*aA, and] A^aholu baladi ka*aA and mawoDiEi ka*aA: (TA:) Ks disallows its being prefixed to a pronoun; so that one should not say, A=luhu, but A^aholuhu; but his opinion in this matter is not correct: it is originally A^awalN; the w being changed into A, (M, * Msb,) as in qaAla [which is originally qawala]: so say some: (Msb:) or it is originally A^aholN, (T, M, Msb, K,) then A^aA^olN, and then A=lN: (K:) so say some, arguing thus from its having A^uhayolN for its dim.: (T, Msb:) but accord. to Ks, it assumes the form ↓ A^uwayolN as a dim.: (T:) or each of these is its dim. (M, K.) By the A=l of the Prophet are meant, accord. to some persons, His followers, whether relations or others: and his relations, whether followers or not: (Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà, T:) or, as some say, his family (A^aholuhu [q. v.]) and his wives: [but it seems to be indicated that what I have rendered “and his wives” is meant as an explicative adjunct to Ahlh:] or, as some say, the people of his religion: (Esh-Sháfi'ee, T:) being himself asked who were his A=l, he answered all pious persons: (Anas, TA:) but in a trad. in which it is said that the poor-rates are prohibited to him and to his A=l, by this is meant those to whom was appropriated the fifth [of the spoils] instead of the poor-rates; and these were the genuine descendants of Háshim and El-Muttalib. (Esh-Sháfi'ee, T.) ― -b2- yaA lazayodK and yaAla zayodK, accord. to the Koofees, are contractions of yaA A=la zayodK [O family of Zeyd]. (Mughnee, on the letter l; and El-Ashmoonee on the Alfeeyeh of Ibn-Málik, section AlAstgAvp. [See the letter l.]) ― -b3- [See also A_iylapN.] -A2- (tropical:) I. q. $axoSN [meaning The body, or corporeal form or figure or substance, (of anything, as is said in the T,) which one sees from a distance; or, in this case, often, though not always, the person, or self]; (AA, T, S, M, K;) of a man: a metaphorical application, from A=lN as signifying A^aholN and Ea$iyrapN; because comprising the members and the senses. (Har p. 578.) ― -b2- Sometimes, it is redundant, or pleonastic; [being only used for the sake of metre in verse, or to give more force to an expression;] as in the following instance:
A^ulaAqiY mino ta*ak~uri A=li layolaY
kamaA yaloqaY Als~aliymu mina AlEidaAdi
[I experience, from remembrance of Leylà, or of Leylà's person or self, the like of what the person bitten or stung by a venomous reptile experiences from the paroxysm of pain occasioned by the bits or sting]. (TA.) [See also another ex., voce jaA^obN; and another, voce mizomaArN.] ― -b3- [Like $axoSN, it seems to be sometimes applied to Any material thing that is somewhat high, and conspicuous: and hence, perhaps, the signification next following.] ― -b4- maA A^a$orafa mina AlbaEiyri [app. meaning The overtopping, or higher, part, or parts, of the camel]. (M, K.) ― -b5- A [tent of the kind called] xayomap. (M.) ― -b6- The poles of the xayomap; (M, K;) as also ↓ A=lapN; of which the pl. is A=lAtN: (K:) or ↓ A=lapN is the sing. of A=lN and A=laAtN, [or n. un. of the former and pl. of the latter,] which signify the pieces of wood (xa$abaAt) upon which the xymp is raised, or constructed: and hence Kutheiyir likens the legs of his she-camel to four A=lAt of the [wood of the tree called] TaloH. (S.) ― -b7- The pieces of wood (xa$ab, T, M, K) of xayom [or tents], (M,) stripped [of the tent-cloths]. (T, TA.) ― -b8- Also, [app. because rising from the general surface of the ground,] The extremities and sides of a mountain. (M, K. *) -A3- The saraAb [or mirage]: (As, T, M, K:) or peculiarly applied to that which is in the first part of the day, (K,) as though raising figures seen from a distance ($uxuwS), and making them to quiver: (TA:) or that which one sees in the first part of the day, and in the last part thereof, as though raising figures seen from a distance ($xwS); not the same as the srAb: (S:) or what resembles the srAb: (Msb:) or, as some say, that which is in the DuHaY [or early part of the day when the sun is yet low], like water between the sky and the earth, [in appearance] raising figures seen from a distance ($xwS), and making them to quiver; whereas the srAb is that which is at mid-day, [apparently] cleaving to the ground, as though it were running water: Th says, the A=l is in the first part of the day: (M:) As says that the A=l and the srAb are one: but others say that the former is from the DuHaY [see above] to the declining of the sun from the meridian; whereas the srAb is after the declining of the sun from the meridian to the prayer of the EaSor; and in favour of their assertion they urge, that the former [in appearance] raises everything so that it becomes what is termed A=l, i. e. $axoS; for the A=l of everything is its $xS; and that the srAb [in appearance] lowers every $xS in it so that it becomes [as though it were] cleaving to the ground, having no $xS: Yoo says, the Arabs say that the A=l is from the gudowap [or period between the prayer of daybreak and sunrise] to the time when the sun is very high, or near the meridian; then it is called srAb for the rest of the day: ISk says, the A=l is that which [in appearance] raises figures seen from a distance ($xwS),
and is in the DuHaY [explained above]; and the srAb is that which is upon the surface of the ground, as though it were water, and is at midday: and this, I [namely Az] say, is what I have found the Arabs in the desert to say: (T:) El- Hareeree speaks of the glistening of the A=l; app. using this word in the sense of srAb; for it is the latter that glistens; not the former: (Har p. 363:) the word is masc. and fem. (Msb, K.) The phrase yarfaEu A@loA=laA, ending a verse (S, M) of En-Nábighah, (M, TA,) i. e. Edh-Dhubyánee, (TA,) or El-Jaadee, (S,) [variously cited in the S and M and TA,] is an instance of inversion; the meaning being yarofaEuhu A@loA=lu [The A=l raising it]: (S, TA:) or the meaning is, making the A=l conspicuous more than it would otherwise be; the agent of the verb being a prominent portion of a mountain, which, being itself raised [in appearance] by the A=l, has the effect of doing this. (M.) -A4- See also the next paragraph. -A5- And see A^alayaAnN, in art. Aly.

A=lapN A=lh A=lp
i. q. A^adaApN [i. e. An instrument; a tool; an implement; a utensil: and instruments; tools; implements; utensils; apparatus; equipments; equipage; accoutrements; furniture; gear; tackling;] (S, M, K) with which one works, for himself or for another: it is both sing. and pl.: (M, K:) or, (K,) as some say, (M,) it is a pl. having no sing. (M, K) as to the letter: (M:) [but it is very often used as a sing.:] and the pl. is A=laAtN. (S, K.) In the saying of 'Alee, yasotaEomilu A=lapa Ald~iyni fiY Talabi Ald~unyaA [lit. He makes use of the instrument of religion in seeking the goods of the present world], (assumed tropical:) science, or knowledge, is meant; because thereby only is religion. (M.) ― -b2- [A musical instrument;] a lute; a musical reed, or pipe; the [kind of mandoline called] Tunobuwr. (TA.) ― -b3- The male organ of generation. (TA.) ― -b4- The bier of a corpse. (Abu-l-'Omeythil, S, M, K.) Thus, accord. to some, in the following verse, (S, * M,) of Kaab Ibn-Zuheyr:
kul~u A@boni A^unovaY waA_ino TaAlto salaAmatuhu
yawomFA EalaY A=lapK HadobaA='a maHomuwlu
[Every son of a female, though his health, or safety, long continue, is one day borne upon a gibbous bier: for the bier of the Arabs of the desert was generally composed of two poles connected by a net-work of cords upon which the corpse lay depressed]: (S, M:) or, as some say, [in a distressing state, or condition; for, they say,] A=lap here signifies Halap. (TA.) ― -b5- See also A=lN, in two places, near the middle of the paragraph. -A2- A state, or condition; i. q. HaAlapN [as mentioned above]: (T, S, M, K:) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] ↓ A=lN. (T, S.) You say, huwabiA=lpi sawo'K [He is in an evil state or condition]. (S.) ― -b2- I. q. $i*~apN [Straitness; difficulty; distress; &c.]. (M, K.)

A_iylapN A^yl A^ylh A^ylp Aylh Aylp |yl |ylh |ylp sometimes signifies The relations to whom one goes [or is traced] back in genealogy. (Ibn- 'Abbád.) [See also A=lN.] ― -b2- You say also, radadotuhu A_ilaY A_iylatihi I made him to go back, or revert, to his natural disposition: or, to his [original] state or condition. (Ibn-'Abbád.)
A^uwluw * , in the gen. and accus. A^uwliY: see A^uluw, in art. A^uwlaY.
A^uwlaY * fem. of A^aw~alu: see the latter in art. wA^l. -A2- A^uwlaY as a pl., and its var. A^uwlaA='i; and A^uwl`y^ika, or A^uwlaA=y^ika; &c.: see A^ulaY, in art. AlY.

A^awaAlN *
A certain idol of [the tribes of] Bekr and Teghlib, (K, TA,) the two sons of Wáïl. (TA.)
A^wayolN * dim. of A=lN, q. v. (Ks, T, M, K.)

A_iyaAlN AyAl The vessel, or receptacle, of thickening, or thick, milk: (M:) [or, accord. to the K, this seems to be termed ↓ A^uy~alN: see A=y^ilN:] or, in which wine ($araAb), or expressed juice, or what is pressed, or squeezed, so that its juice is forced out, or the like thereof, is made to thicken. (TA.) -A2- [Also an inf. n. of 1, which see throughout.]

A_iyaAlapN A_yAlp AyAlh AyAlp
Rule, or government: (S, Msb:) [accord. to some, an inf. n. of A=la as a trans. verb: accord. to others,] a simple subst. (Msb.)
A^aw~alu * and its variations &c., see art. wA^l: some, on account of difference of opinion from others respecting its radical letters, have mentioned this word in the present art. (TA.)
A^ay~ilN * : see A_iy~alN: -A2- and see also A=y^ilN, last sentence.
A^uy~alN * : see A_iy~alN: -A2- and see also A=y^lNi, in four places; and A_iyaAlN.

A_iy~alN A^yl A_yl Ayl |yl and ↓ A^uy~alN (T, S, Mgh, Msb, K, the first and third and fourth in art. Ayl) and ↓ A^y~ilN, (T, K,) the last on the authority of IAar, (TA,) but A'Obeyd says that it is A_iy~alN, with kesr, (T,) and this is the approved form, (TA,) The [animal called] waEol: (K:) or the male waEol; (ISh, T, S, Mgh, Msb;) i. e. the mountain-goat: (Msb:) accord. to some, (S,) what is called in Persian kawazon; (S, Mgh;) by which word Sh explains the word A_iy~alN: ISh says, it is the animal that is very wide between the horns, and bulky, like the domestic bull: (T:) [see baqaru AlwaHo$i in art. bqr:] and Lth says, it is called thus because it resorts (yaw^uwlu) to the mountains: sometimes the Y is changed into j: the fem. is of the same three forms with p: (TA:) and the pl. is A^ayaAy^ilu [like sayaAy^idu pl. of say~idN]. (Lth, T, Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- See also A=y^ilN, in two places.

A=y^ilN * [act. part. n. of 1 in all its senses: and thus, particularly,] Thickening, or thick; (T, S, M, TA;) applied to the urine of camels that have been contented with green pasture instead of water, at the end of their being in that state; (T;) or to milk, (S, M, TA,) and to oil, and other things, such as tar, and honey, and wine, or beverage: (TA:) pl. ↓ A^uy~alN: (S, M:) which last word [in one copy of the M written A_iylN, but this I think a mistranscription,] signifies also the remains of thickening, or thick, milk; or, as some say, the [seminal] water in the womb: (M:) or this same word (A^uy~alN) has the last of these significations; and also, [as a sing. epithet,] the first of the meanings explained in this paragraph; as also A=y^ilN, applied to milk; (K;) or to milk thickening, or thick, and mixed; not excessively thick, but in a somewhat good degree, and changed in its flavour: (AHát, TA:) or it [app. A^uy~alN, as in the TK,] signifies the vessel, or receptacle, thereof; (K;) [a meaning assigned in the M to A_iyaAlN;] in which milk thickens: (TA:) Sh says that ↓ A_iy~alN signifies the milk of the A^ayaAy^il [pl. of A_iy~alN]; and so says AA: but AHeyth says that this is absurd; and that the right word is ↓ A^uy~alN, having the signification first explained in this paragraph, i. e. thickening, or thick, milk: En-Nadr says that ↓ A_iy~alN signifies thick urine of she-goats of the mountain; which, when drunk by a woman, excites her venereal faculty: (T:) or this last word is used to signify milk of an A_iy~al, which is said to strengthen in the venereal faculty, and to fatten, as Ibn-Habeeb asserts; and ↓ A^uy~alN, which he affirms to be wrong, is a dial. var. thereof; and it may also be a quasi-pl. n. thereof: (M:) as a pl. [of A=y^ilN], applied to milk, ↓ A=uy~alN is extr. in two respects; as a pl., of this form, of an epithet not applied to an animal; and as being regularly A^uw~alN. (IJ, M.) -A2- A_in~ahu laA=y^ilu maAlK and maAlK ↓ A^ay~ilu Verily he is a good manager, or tender, of cattle, or camels, or the like. (M, TA.)
taA^owiylN * used as a simple subst. in the sense of EaAqibapN &c.: see 2, last sentence.

maA=lN mA=l inf. n. of A=la, in two senses pointed out above. (M, K, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, maA=luhu A_ilaY ka*aA His, or its, return, or course, or transition, is to such a state or condition.] -A2- Also, [as a noun of place &c.,] i. q. marojiEN [as signifying A place, and a state, or condition, to which a person, or thing, returns; and, to which he, or it, ultimately, or eventually, comes]. (TA, [where this is given as a signification not mentioned in the K; so that mrjE is not here used as an inf. n.: it is, moreover, a signification well known.]) See also 2, last sentence. ― -b2- A refuge: applied in this sense to God. (Har p. 361.)

huwa muw^otaAlN liqawomihi muqotaAlN Ealayohimo *
He is ruler, or governor, of his people; a possessor of dictatorship over them, or of authority over them to judge or give judgment or pass sentence or decide judicially. (A, TA.)
h`*aA mutaA^aw~alN HasanN * [app. This is a good discovery made from outward signs]. (TA, where it immediately follows taA^aw~ala fiyhi Alxayora with its explanations given above.)
mutaA^aw~ilN * : see its verb. ― -b2- [Sometimes it signifies] Veracious: opposed to mutaqaw~ilN. (Har p. 256.)
A^uwluw * , in the gen. and accus. A^uwliY: see A^uluw in art. Alw.

A^uwlaY * fem. of A^aw~alu: see the latter in art. wA^l. -A2-
A^uwlaY as a pl., and its var. A^uwlaA='a; and A^uwl`y^ika, or A^uwlaA=y^ika; &c.: see A^ulaY, in art. AlY.
A^awam~u * for A^aA^am~u: see art. Am.

1 A=na A=n , aor. yaw^uwnu, inf. n. A^awonN, He was, or became, at rest, or at ease; he rested in a journey. (IAar, T.) ― -b2- A^unotu, aor. and inf. n. as above, I enjoyed a life of ease and plenty; a state of freedom from trouble or inconvenience, and toil or fatigue; a state of ease, repose, or tranquillity. (AZ, T, S, M, K.) ― -b3- I was, or became, grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm. (S, K.) ― -b4- I was, or became, gentle; or I acted gently: (T, S, M, Msb, K:) and I acted, or proceeded, with moderation, without haste or hurry, in pace or journeying: (M:) I went gently, softly, or in a leisurely manner: (S, K:) A^awonN [the inf. n.] is formed by substitution [of A^ for h] from hawonN. (S.) You say, A^unotu biAl$~aYo'i, and EalaY Al$~aYo'i, I was gentle, or I acted gently, with the thing; (M;) and fiY AlA^amori in the affair. (Msb.) And A^uno EalaY nafosika Act thou gently with thyself, or be thou gentle, in pace or journeying: and proceed thou with moderation, without haste or hurry: (T, S:) said in the latter sense to one who has become unsteady, or irresolute. (T.) [In like manner,] you say, EalaY qadorika ↓ A^aw~ino, meaning Ait~ay^ido EalaY naHowika [app. Act thou with moderation, gentleness, deliberation, or in a leisurely manner, according to thine ability, or to the measure of thine ability; for qadorN and naHowN are both syn. with miqodaArN]. (T, K.) And fiY sayorikumo ↓ A^aw~inuwA Proceed ye with moderation in your course or pace or journeying. (ISk, T.) And fiY ↓ taA^aw~ana AlA^amori He paused, or was patient, in the affair. (M.) -A2- A^awonN also signifies The being weary, or fatigued; like A^ayonN. (M.) [Whether, in this sense, it have a verb, is doubtful: see its syn. here mentioned.] ― -b2- Also The putting oneself to trouble, or inconvenience, for the sake of what one may expend upon himself and his family. (M.) And hence, accord. to one [whose name is imperfectly written in the TA], the word ↓ maw^uwnapN, [as being originally maA^owunapN,] of the measure mafoEulapN: but others say that it is of the measure faEuwlapN, from maA^anotu. (TA.) -A3- ↓ A=na A^awonuka and A^awaAnuka [and A^ayonuka] signify the same. (M.) [See art. Ayn.]
2 Aaw~ana see 1, in two places.
5 taAaw~ana see 1.
AlA=na AlA=n and its vars.: see art. Ayn. [Accord. to some, it belongs to the present art., in which it is mentioned in the Msb.]
A^awonN * : see 1 [of which it is the inf. n.]: and see also what next follows.

A^awaAnN * (T, S, M, Msb, K) and ↓ A_iwaAnN, (T, M, Msb, K,) the latter mentioned by Ks on the authority of Aboo-Jámi', but the former is the usual mode of pronouncing it, (T,) and ↓ A^awonN, (M,) A time; a season: pl. A=winapN; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) but Sb says A=wnAtN; (M; [so in a copy of that work; app. A=winaAtN, as though pl. of A=winapN;]) and A=yinapN is syn. with A=winapN. (AA, T, K.) You say, jaA='a A^awaAnu Albarodi [The time, or season, of cold came]. (T.) And fulaAnN yaSonaEu *`lika AlA^amora A=winapF, (S, K, *) and A=yinapF, (K, [in the CK A=y^inapF,]) Such a one does that thing sometimes, leaving it undone sometimes. (S, K. *) And A^atayotuhu A=ynapF baEoda A=yinapK I came to him times after times. (AA, T.) And A=winapF signifies Time after time. (TA, from a trad.) In the saying (of Aboo-Zubeyd, L),
TalabuwA SuloHanaA walaAta A^awaAnK
(M,) or A_iwaAnK, (L,) [They sought our reconciliation with them, but it was not the time that reconciliation should be sought], accord. to Abu-l- 'Abbás, the tenween of the last word is not a sign of the genitive case, but is, as in the instance of A_i*K, because of the suppression of a proposition to which the word should be prefixed, as when you say, jiy^otu A^awaAna qaAma zayodN I came at the time that Zeyd stood. (M, L.) ― -b2- [Hence, A^awaAnay^i*K At that time or season; then; like Hiynay^i*K.]
A_iwaAnN A^wAn A_nA' AwAn : see A^awaAnN: -A2- and see also A_iyawaAnN.

A=y^inN * [part. n. of 1:] A man enjoying a life of ease and plenty; a state of freedom from trouble or inconvenience, and toil or fatigue; a state of ease, repose, or tranquillity. (AZ, T, S, K.) ― -b2- [Hence the saying,] riboEN A=y^in xayorN mino gib~K HaSoHaASK [An easy, or a gentle, journey in which the camels are watered only on the first and fourth days is better than a laborious, or quick, journey in which they are watered only on the first and third days]. (TA.) [The fem. is A=y^inapN: the pl. of which is A^awaAy^inu and A=y^inaAtN.] You say, bayonanaA wabayona mak~Fpa valaAvu layaAlK A^awaAy^inu Between us and Mekkeh are three nights of easy, or gentle, journeying: (S, K: *) and Ea$orulayaAl A=y^inaAtN ten nights of easy journeying. (S, M, K.)

A_iywaAnN A_ywAn AywAn and ↓ A_iwaAnN (T, S, M, Msb, K) [each] a foreign word, [i. e. Persian,] (M,) A chamber, or an apartment, (T, Msb,) or a large Suf~ap [i. e. porch, or roofed vestibule, or the like], (S, K,) similar to an A^azaj [or oblong arched or vaulted structure, or a portico], (T, S, M, K,) or built in the form of an A^azaj, (Msb,) not closed in the front, or face: (T, M, Msb: *) [and a palace; often used in this sense in Arabic as well as in Persian: and in the present day, the former, and more commonly liywaAn, which is Persian, is also applied to an estrade; a slightly-raised portion of the floor, generally extending nearly from the door to the end, or to each end, of a room:] pl. of the former, A^awaAwiynu, (T, S, K,) because the sing. is originally A_iwowaAnN, (S,) and A_iywaAnaAtN; and pl. of the latter, A^uwnN. (T, S, K.) Hence, A_iywaAnu kisoraY [The great porch, or the palace, of Kisrà, or Chosroes, who is called SaAHibu AlA_iywaAni]. (T, S, Msb.) ― -b2- Also the latter, [and app., accord. to the Msb, the former also,] Any prop, or support, of a thing: (T, Msb:) particularly, a pole of a [tent of the kind called] xibaA='. (T.) ― -b3- The A_iywaAn of the lijaAm [is The headstall of the bridle; and] has for its pl. A_iywaAnaAtN. (T, K.)
maw^uwnapN * : see 1, and see art. mA^n.
1 AawVha and 2: see 5.

5 tA^w~h * ; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) and ↓ A^w~h, (S, Mgh, K,) inf. n. taA^owiypN; (S, K;) and ↓ A=ha, inf. n. A^awohN; (K;) He said A=hi or A^awohi &c. [i. e. Ah! or alas!]; (S, Mgh, K;) he moaned; or uttered a moan, or moaning, or prolonged voice of complaint; (S, TA;) i. q. tawaj~aEa. (Msb.)

A=hi A=h A=p , (Az, S, Msb, K, &c.,) as also A=hK, (IAmb, K,) and A=hFA, and ↓ A=hapF, (TA,) and ↓ A^awohi, (S, Msb, K,) and ↓ A^awoha, (ISd, K,) and ↓ A^awohu, (K,) and ↓ A^aw~iho, (S,) or ↓ A^aw~ihi, (K,) and ↓ A^aw~aho, (Hr, Mgh, Msb, K,) so in some copies of the S, but in a copy in the author's handwriting ↓ A=w~aho, there said to be with medd, and with teshdeed and fet-h to the w, and with the h quiescent, (TA,) [or,] accord. to Aboo- Tálib, A=w~aho, with medd, thus pronounced by the vulgar, is wrong, (T in art. Aw,) and ↓ A^aw~aAh, and ↓ A^aw~uwh, [in both of which, and in some other forms which follow, it is doubtful whether the h be quiescent or movent, and if movent, with what vowel,] (TA,) and ↓ A=wuwhu, (K, TA,) or ↓ A^awuwhu, but said by ISd to be with medd, and mentioned by AHát as heard from the Arabs, (TA,) and ↓ A^awataAh, (K, TA,) or ↓ A^awataAhu, (CK,) or ↓ A^aw~ataAh, and ↓ A=w~ataAh, (S, [in one copy of which the h is marked as quiescent,]) and ↓ A=way~aAh, (K, TA,) with medd, (TA,) or ↓ A^awiy~aAhu, (CK,) and A^aw~i (S, Msb, K,) and A=wi, and A=wK, (K, TA,) and waAhFA, and haAhN or haAhu, (TA,) [Ah! or alas!] a word imitative of the voice, cry, or exclamation, of the mutaA^ah~ih; (Az and TA in explanation of A=hi;) [i. e.] a word expressive of pain, grief, sorrow, lamentation, complaint, or moaning; (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA;) denoting the prolongation of the voice with complaint: (S, TA, after A^aw~aho or A=w~aho:) sometimes, also, a man says A=hi from a motive of affection, or pity, or compassion, and of impatience: (Az, TA:) [and it is also said that] A=hFA is a word expressive of grief or lamentation, or of most intense grief or lamentation or regret; [that] it is put in the accus. case as being used in the manner of inf. ns.; and [that] the hemzeh is originally w: but IAth says, A=hFA is a word expressive of pain, grief, sorrow, lamentation, complaint, or moaning, used in relation to evil, like as waAhFA is used in relation to good: (TA in art. Ah:) and A=w~aho and A=wi and A=wK are cries uttered to horses, to make them return. (ISh and TA in art. AwY. See 2 in that art. in the present work.) You say, A=hi mino ka*aA [Ah, or alas, on account of, or for, such a thing!]; (S, Msb;) and in like manner, A^awohi [&c.], followed by mino, and by li, (S, TA,) and by EalaY. (TA.) [See also A^aw~i in art. Aw.]

A=hapN A=hh A=hp a subst. from taA^aw~aha; occurring in the saying of El-Muthakkib El-'Abdee,
A_i*aA maAqumotu A^aroHaluhaA bilayolK
taA^aw~ahu A=hapa Alr~ajuli AlHaziyni
[When I arise to saddle her, by night, she moans with the moaning of the sorrowful man]: (S, ISd:) ISd says that, in his opinion, the subst. is here put in the place of the inf. n., i. e. taA^aw~uh: (TA:) but some recite the verse differently, saying, A^ah~apa, from A^ah~a meaning tawaj~aEa: (S:) and some say, tahaw~ahu haAhapa. (TA.) And hence the saying, in imprecating evil on a man, A=hapF laka [May God cause moaning to thee!], and A^aw~apF laka, with the h suppressed, and with teshdeed to the w. (S.) [See also A^aw~apN in art. Aw.] And see A=hi above. -A2- [Also] Measles: thus in the phrase, used in imprecating evil on a man, A=hapF wamaAhapF [May God cause] measles and small-pox [to befall thee]! (K, * TA,) mentioned by Lh on the authority of Aboo-Khálid. (TA.)
A^awohi * and `A^awoha and A^awohu and A^aw~ih &c.: see A=hi.

A^aw~aAhN * A man often saying Ah! or alas! or often moaning: (Mgh:) or one who says Ah! or alas! from a motive of affection, or pity, or compassion, and fear: or mourning, or sorrowing, much, or often: (TA:) or compassionate; tender-hearted: or often praying, or frequent in prayer: (K, * TA:) or one who celebrates the praises of God, or praises Him greatly, or glorifies Him: or who praises much, or often: or who abases himself, or addresses himself with earnest supplication, [to God], confident of his prayer's being answered: (TA:) or one having certain knowledge (K, TA) of his prayer's being answered: (TA:) or inviting much, or often, to what is good: (TA:) or skilled in the law: or a believer; so in the Abyssinian language: (K:) occurring in the Kur [ix. 115 and xi. 77]. (TA.) -A2- See also A=hi.
A^awuwhu * , or A=wuwhu, and A^aw~uwh: see A=hi.
A^awataAh * , or A^awataAhu, or A^aw~ataAh, and A=w~ataAh: see A=hi.
A^awiy~aAhu * , or A=way~aAh: see A=hi.
mutaA^aw~ihN * [Saying Ah! &c.: (see the verb:) and] abasing himself; or addressing himself with earnest supplication [to God]. (TA.) [See also A^aw~aAhN.]

1 A^awaY A_ilayohi * , (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and A^awaAhu, (M, Msb, K,) aor. yaA^owiY, (T, S, Msb,) imperative Aiywi (T,) inf. n. A^uwiY~u, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) with damm, (K,) of the measure fuEuwlN, [originally A^uwuwYN,] (S,) and A_iwiY~N, (Fr, M, K,) with kesr, (K,) and A_iwaA='N; (S;) and Alyh ↓ A^w~Y, (M, K,) inf. n. taA^owiyapN; (K;) and ↓ tA^w~Y; (M, K;) and ↓ A@A^otawaY, (thus [more commonly Ay^twY] accord. to a copy of the M,) or ↓ A@t~awaY, (K,) like A@t~axa*a, (TK,) and ↓ AiytawaY, (M, K,) both of the measure AftEl; (TA;) and ↓ A=waY is used by some in the same sense, but rejected, in this sense, by several; (Msb;) the pronoun relating to a place of abode; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) He betook himself to it, or repaired to it, for lodging, covert, or refuge; (Mgh;) and [simply] he got him or got himself, betook himself, repaired, or resorted, to it; (T, Mgh;) he returned to it; (M;) he took up his abode in it; he lodged, or abode, or dwelt, in it. (Msb, K.) Hence, in the Kur [xi. 45], saA=wiY A_ilaY jabalK yaEoSimuniY mina AlmaA='i [I will betake myself for refuge to a mountain that shall preserve me from the water]. (S.) AlA^uwiY~u properly relates to living beings; but is used otherwise, metaphorically. (M.) In the saying of Lebeed,
biSabuwHi SaAfiyapK waja*obi kariynapK
lahu A_ibohaAmuhaA ↓ bimuwatrK taA^otaY
[With a morning-potation of clear wine (xamorK being understood), and a female singer's straining of her chords, with a stringed instrument to which her thumb returns after the straining], he means taA^otawiY lahu, of the measure tafotaEilu, from A^awayotu A_ilayohi signifying Eudotu; the w being changed into A [written Y], and the Y, which is the final radical, being elided. (M. [But see another reading near the end of the first paragraph of art. Awl.]) A^awaY, aor. as above, inf. n. A^uwiYN, also signifies He turned away: and hence, [it is said,] A_i*o A^awaY Alfitoyapu A_ilaY Alkahofi [When the young men turned away to the cave: though the verb may be here well rendered betook themselves for refuge]. (Har p. 246.) You say also, A^awayotu A_ilaY fulaAnK, (A'Obeyd, T,) or lahu, (as afterwards written in a copy of the T,) [I betook myself to such a one, or repaired to him, for lodging, covert, or refuge; or] I joined myself, got myself, betook myself, repaired, or resorted, to such a one: and accord. to AHeyth, A^awayotu fulaAnFA signifies the same; but he did not know A^awayotu to be syn. with A=wayotu as explained below. (T.) And A^awaY A_ilaY A@ll~`hi He returned unto God. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b2- A^awaY said of a wound: see 5. -A2- See also 4, in seven places. -A3- A^awaY lahu, (T, S, M, Mgh, K,) like rawaY, (K, TA,) but it would have been more explicit if the author of the K had said like ramaY, (TA,) [as is shown by the false reading in the CK, A^wiYa lahu karawiY~,] aor. yaA^wiY, (T, S, Mgh,) inf. n. A^awoyapN (S, K) and A_iy~apN, (S, Mgh, K,) with kesr, (TA,) [originally A_iwoyapN,] the w being changed into Y because of the kesreh before it, (S,) or because combined with Y and preceded by sukoon [a mistake for “kesreh”], (IB as cited in the TA,) [in a copy of the T written Ay~ap, and in a copy of the M and in the CK Aay~ap,] and maA^owiyapN, (S, M, K,) without teshdeed, (S, TA,) [in my copy of the Mgh written with tesh-deed,] and maA^owaAhN, (S, M, K,) He compassionated him; felt compassion, or pity, for him; (T, S, M, Mgh, K;) as also ↓ Ay^twY, (T, K,) of the measure AftEl. (TA.) In using the imperative form, you say, Aiwi lahu, [unless this be a mistranscription for Aiywi lahu,] meaning Be thou compassionate to him. (T, TA.)

2 Aaw~aYa see 1, first sentence: -A2- and see 4. -A3- A^aw~ayotu biAlxayoli (ISh, T) [I drew together the horses: this meaning seems to be indicated in the T, by the context: or] I called out to the horses A=w~aho, in order that they should return at hearing my voice: (ISh:) and in like manner one says to them ↓ A=wi or A=wK; (ISh, T, TA;) a well-known call of the Arabs to horses; and sometimes A=Y, with a long meddeh, is said to them from afar. (T, TA.) [See also 5.]

4 A=wAhu A=wAh A=wAp , (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_ywaA='N; (T, S, Mgh;) and ↓ A^w~Ahu; (K;) and ↓ A^awaAhu; (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) the first of which is the [most] approved; (T;) the last used by some; (T, Msb;) both given on the authority of AZ, (S,) and of A'Obeyd, accord. to whom you say, A^awayotu A_ilayohi, with the short A only; (T, M;) He, or it, gave him, or afforded him, lodging, covert, or refuge; harboured him; sheltered him; protected him; (Mgh;) he lodged him, or lodged him with himself; made him his guest; or gave him refuge or asylum, absolutely, or with himself; syn. A^anozalahu; (K;) or A^anozalahu. (T, S, TA.) You say also, Alr~ajula A_ilaY~a ↓ A^awayotu and A=wayotuhu [I took the man to me to lodge, to be my guest, or to give him refuge or asylum]. (M.) And A=waAhu saqofN [A roof shel-tered him]. (Mgh.) And AlA_ibila ↓ A^awayotu and A=wayotuhaA [I lodged the camels in their nightly resting-place]; both meaning the same. (T.) And it is said in a trad., AlHamodu lil~hi Al~a*iY kafaAnaA waA=waAnaA i. e. [Praise be to God who hath sufficed us and] hath brought us to a place of abode for us, and not made us to be scattered like the beasts. (TA.) AHeyth disallowed ↓ A^awayotu as syn. with A=wayotu; but it is correct. (T.) It is said in a form of divorce, ↓ laA yaA^owiyniY waA_iy~aAki bayotN [A house, or tent, shall not lodge, or comprise, me with thee]. (Mgh.) And among other instances, is the saying of the Prophet, (T,) AlD~aAl~apN A_l~aA DaAl~N ↓ laA yaA^owiY [No one will harbour the stray beast but a person straying from the right course of conduct]. (T, Mgh.) And his saying, Aljariynu ↓ laA qaToEa fiY vamarK Hat~aY yaA^owiyih i. e. [There shall be no cutting off of the hand in the case of stealing fruit] unless the place where the fruit is dried contain it [at the time of the stealing thereof]. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, A_iywaA='u xa$abi AlfaHomi The throwing of dust, or earth, upon the wood of which charcoal is made, and covering it therewith. (Mgh.) -A2- See also 1, first sentence.

5 taAaw~aYa see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- taA^aw~ati AlT~ayoru The birds collected, or flocked, together; (Lth, T, S, M, K;) as also ↓ taA=wat: (K:) the latter is allowable. (T.) And in like manner one says of other things. (M.) [Thus,] one says, taA^aw~ati Alxayolu The horses drew, or gathered, themselves together: and tA^w~Y Aln~aAsu The men did so. (T.) You say also, of a wound, ↓ tA=wY, and ↓ A^awaY, meaning It drew together, for healing; and so tA=zY, and A^azaY: so in the Nawádir el-Aaráb. (T.) -A2- One may also say, yataA^aw~aY, without saying it with h, [i. e. yataA^aw~ahu,] meaning He says A^awohi. (Fr and T in art. Aw.) [See also 2; and see art. Awh.]
6 taAaAowaYa see 5, in two places.
8 A@A^otawY * , or Ay^twY, or A@t~awaY, and AiytawaY, and taA^otaY for taA^otawiY: see 1, first part of the paragraph, in four places. -A2- See also the last sentence but one of the same paragraph.

10 A@sotaA^owayotuhu *
I asked him, or desired him, to compassionate me, or have mercy on me; syn. A@sotaroHamotuhu. (T.) A poet (namely, Dhu-r-Rummeh, TA) says,
walawo A^an~anY A@sotaA^owayotuhu maA A^awaY liyaA
[And if I had asked him, or desired him, to compassionate me, he would not have compassionated me]. (T, S.)
A^uway~apN * dim. of A='N: see the letter A.

A=wi A=w or A=wK: see 2. -A2- A=wK [the part. n. of 1] has for its pl. A^uwiY~N [like one of the inf. ns. of 1]. (T, S.) The latter is applied to birds, signifying Collecting, or flocking, together; (T, S, M, * K; *) syn. ↓ mutaA^aw~iyapN (Lth, T) and mutaA^aw~iyaAtN. (Lth, T, S, M, K.)

Aibonu A=waY Abn A=wY Abn A=wy , a determinate noun, (S, M,) [The jackal; vulgarly called in the present day waAwiY;] a certain small beast, (M, K,) called in Persian $agaAlo, (S,) or in that language [or in Turkish] JaqaAlo: (TA:) it has been said to be the offspring of the wolf; but is well known to be not of the wolf-kind: (Msb;) A=waY is inseparable from Abn: (M:) it is imperfectly decl., (T, S, Msb,) being of the measure A^afoEalu, (S,) or regarded as such; (Lth, T;) or because it has the quality of a proper name and the measure of a verb : (Msb :) the pl. is banaAtu A=waY, (T, S, Msb, K,) though applying to males [as well as females], like banaAtu A^aEowaja and banaAtu labuwn. (AHeyth, T.)
A=wiYN A=wY A=wy and A^awawiY~N, said to be rel. ns. of A=yapN; which see, in, art. AY.
A=yapN A=yh A=yp , said by some to be originally A^awayapN:see art. A Y.

maA^owFY * (S, M, Msb, K) and ↓ maA^owK and ↓ maA^owaAhN (M, K [but respecting these two forms see what follows]) nouns of place from the first of the verbs in this art.; (M, K;) [A place to which one betakes himself, or repairs, for lodging, covert, or refuge; a refuge; an asylum; a place of resort; (see 1;)] any place to which a thing betakes itself, &c., (yaA^owiY A_ilayohi,) by night or. by day; (S;) the lodging-place, or abode, of any animal; the nightly resting-place of sheep or goats; (Msb;) and of camels: (Idem in art. rwH:) ↓ maA^owK is used peculiarly in relation to camels: (S;) maA^owiY AlA_ibili being a dial. var. of maA^owaY AlA_ibili, but anomalous, (Fr, T, S, Msb,) and the only instance of the kind except maA^oqiY AlEayoni: (Fr, T, M: [but see art. mA^q:]) maA^owaY and muw^oq and maA^oq are the forms preferred: (Fr, T:) [Az also says,] I have heard the chaste in speech of the Benoo-Kiláb use, for maA^owaY AlA_ibili, the word ↓ maA^owaAp. (T.) jan~apu AlmaA^owaY, in the Kur [liii. 15], is said to mean The paradise to which repair the souls of the martyrs, (M, Bd, Jel, TA,) or the pious, (Bd, Jel,) or the angels: (Jel:) or that in which the night is passed. (TA.)
maA^owK * : see maA^owFY, in four places.
maA^owaApN * : see maA^owFY, in four places.
maAwiy~apN mAwyh mAwyp mAy^y mAy^yp : see art. mwh.
mutaA^aw~iyapN * : see A=wK.

2 A^ay~aA A=yapF * , [inf. n., by rule, as below,] He put, or set, a sign, token, or mark, by which a person or thing might be known. (M.) -A2- A^ay~aA bilA_ibili, (inf. n. taA^oyyapN, Lth, T,) He chid the camels, saying to them A^ayaAyaA, (Lth, T, M, and K in art. A^ayaA,) or A^ayaAyaho, (M,) or yaAyaA, (K,) or yaAyaho. (M, K.)

5 tA^y~A * , as a trans. verb: see 6. -A2- He paused, stopped, stayed, remained, or tarried, (T, S, M, K, *) biA lmakaAni in the place; (M, K; * [in the latter explained by talab~ava Ealayohi; but this seems to be a mistake, arising from the omission of part of a passage in the M, (one of the chief sources of the K,) running thus; taA^ay~aA biA lmakaAni talab~ava watamak~ava wataA^ay~aA Ealayohi A@noSarafa fiY tuw^adapK;]) and confined, restricted, limited, restrained, or withheld, himself. (T.) In the sense of its inf. n., [by rule taA^aY~, originally taA^ay~uYN,] they said ↓ taA^ay~apN, or taA_iy~apN or tay^iy~apN; [thus differently written in different places in copies of the T and S;] as in the ex. layosa manozilukumo bidaAri taA^ay~apK or taA_iy~apK, (IAar, T,) or layosa manozilukumo h`*aA bimanozili taA^ay~apK or taA_iy~apK, (S,) i. e. Your abode, or this your abode, is not an abode of tarriance and confinement. (IAar, T, S.) ― -b2- He expected, or waited for, a thing: (Lth, T:) and he acted with moderation, gently, deliberately, or leisurely; without haste; or with gravity, staidness, sedateness, or calmness; (Lth, T, K;) fiY AlA^amori in the affair; inf. n. taA^YK.
