(Lth, T.) taA^ay~ayotu Ealayohi, in a verse of Lebeed, means I acted with moderation, &c., as above, and paused, stopped, stayed, remained, or tarried, upon him, i. e., upon my horse: (T:) or I remained firm upon him: (TA, as on the authority of Az:) but it is explained by Lth as meaning I turned away, or back, deliberately, or leisurely, upon him. (T: and the like is said in the M.)

6 taA=yayotuhu tA=yyth tA=yytp , (T, S, M, * K,) and ↓ taA^ay~ayotuhu, (S, K,) I directed my course, or aim, to, or towards, (T, S, M, * K,) his A=yap, (S, M,) i. e., (M,) his $axoS [or body, or corporeal form or figure or substance, seen from a distance; or person]. (T, M, K.) The following is an ex., as some relate it, of the former verb; and as others relate it, of the latter:
AaloHuSonu A^awolaY lawo taA=yuyotihi
mino Havoyiki Alt~uroba EalaY Alr~aAkibi
[Modest behaviour were more proper, if thou directedst thy course towards his person, than thy throwing dust upon the rider]: (S, TA: [in two copies of the former of which, for A^awolaY, I find A^adonaY:]) said by a woman to her daughter, on the latter's relating, in a couplet, that a rider, passing along, had seen her, and she had thrown dust in his face, purposely. (IB.)

A^aYo * a vocative particle, (S, M, Mughnee, K,) addressed to the near, (S, K,) not to the distant: (S:) or to the near, or the distant, or the intermediate; accord. to different authorities. (Mughnee.) You say, A^aYo zayodu A^aqobilo [O Zeyd, advance: or, if it may be used in addressing one who is distant, ho there, soho, or holla: and if used in addressing one who is between near and distant, ho, or what ho]: (S:) and A^aYo rab~i [O my Lord]; occurring in a trad.: and sometimes it is pronounced ↓ A=Yo. (Mughnee.) -A2- Also an explicative particle. (S, M, Mughnee, K.) You say, A^aYo ka*aA in the sense of yuriydu ka*aA [He means such a thing, or yaEoniY ka*aA, which has the same signification; or A^uriydu, or A^aEoniY, I mean; or the like; for all of which, we may say, meaning; or that is]; (S;) as in EinodiY EasojidN A^aYo *ahabN [I have Easojad, that is, (I have) *ahaba, or gold]. (Mughnee.) What follows it is an adjunct explicative of what precedes it, or a substitute. (Mughnee.) AA says that he asked Mbr respecting what follows it, and he answered that it may be a substitute for what precedes, and may be a word independent of what precedes it, and may be a noun in the accus. case: and that he asked Th, and he answered that it may be an explicative, or a word independent of what precedes it, or a noun governed in the accus. case by a verb suppressed: you say, jaA='aniY A^axuwka A^aYo zayodN [Thy brother came to me; that is, Zeyd]; and you may say, A^aYo zayodFA [I mean Zeyd]: and raA^ayotu A^axaAka A^aYo zayodFA [I saw thy brother; I mean, or that is, Zeyd]; and you may say, A^aYo zayodN [that is, Zeyd]: and mararotu biA^axiyka A^aYo zayodK [I passed by thy brother; that is, by Zeyd]; and you may say, A^aYo zaydFA [I mean, Zeyd]; and A^aYo zayodN [that is, Zeyd]. (T, TA.) When it occurs after taquwlu, in a case like the following, [i. e., when a verb following it explains a verb preceding it,] one says, taquwlu Aisotakotamotuhu AlHadiyva A^aYo saA^alotuhu kitomaAnahu [Thou sayest, Astktmth AlHdyv, meaning sA^lth ktmAnh I asked of him the concealment of it, namely, the discourse, or story; and so when taquwlu is understood, as is often, or generally, the case in lexicons]; with damm to the t: but if you put A_i*aA in the place of A^aYo, you say, A_i*aA saA^alotahu, with fet-h, because A^a*A is an adverbial noun relating to taquwlu. (Mughnee.) -A3- See also A^aY~N, near the beginning of the paragraph, in three places.

A_iYo AY A^y A_y Ay |y is a particle denoting a reply, meaning naEamo [Yes, or yea]; importing acknowledgment of the truth of an enunciation; and the making a thing known, to him who asks information; and a promise, to him who seeks or demands; therefore it occurs after such sayings as “Zeyd stood” and “Did Zeyd stand.?” and “Beat thou Zeyd,” and the like; as does naEamo: Ibn-El-Hájib asserts that it occurs only after an interrogation; as in the
saying [in the Kur x. 54], wayasotanobiw^unaka A^aHaq~N huwa qulN A_i Yo warabiY~ [And they will ask thee to inform them, saying, Is it true? Say, Yea, by my Lord!]: but accord. to all, it does not occur otherwise than before an oath: and when one says, A_i Yo waA@ll~`hi [Yea, by God!], and then drops the w the Y may be quiescent, and with fet-h, and elided; [so that you say, A_i Yo A@ll~`hi, and A_i Ya A@ll~`hi, and A_i A@ll~`hi;] in the first of which cases, two quiescent letters occur together, irregularly. (Mughnee.) Lth says, A_i Yo is an oath, as in A_ iYo warab~iY meaning, says Zj, naEamo warab~iY: IAar is also related to have said the like; and this is the correct explanation. (T.) [J says,] It is a word preceding an oath, meaning balaY [q. v.]; as in A_i Yo warab~iY and A_i Yo waA@ll~`h. (S.) [ISd and F say,] It is syn. with naEamo, and is conjoined with an oath: and one says also hiYo. (M, K.)

A^aY~N * is a noun, used in five different manners. (Mughnee.) One of its meanings is that of an interrogative, (T, S, M, Mughnee, K,) relating to intellectual beings and to non-intellectual things; [meaning Who? which? and what?] (S, M, K;) and as such, it is a decl. noun: (S:) it is said in the K to be a particle; (MF;) and so in the M; (TA;) but this is wrong: (MF:) and it is added in the K that it is indecl.; (MF;) and it is said to be so in the M, accord. to Sb, in an instance to be explained below; (TA;) but this is only when it is a conjunct noun [like Al~a*iY], or denotes the object of a vocative: (MF:) or, accord. to some, it is decl. as a conjunct noun also. (Mughnee.) You say, A^ay~uhumo A^axuwka [Who, or which, of them, is thy brother?]. (S.) Another ex. is the saying [in the Kur vii. 184, and last verse of lxxvii.], fabiA^aY~i HadiyvK baEodahu yuw^ominuwna [And in what announcement, after it, will they believe?]. (Mughnee.) Sometimes it is without teshdeed; as in the saying (of El-Farezdak, M),
↓ tanaZ~arotu naSorFA waAls~imaAkayoni A^ayohumaA
EalaY~a mina Algayovi A@sotahal~ato mawaATiruho
[I looked for rain, or aid from the clouds, and the two Simáks (stars so called). Of which of them two did the rains pour vehemently upon me from the clouds?]: (M, Mughnee, K: * [in the last of which, only the former hemistich is given, with nasorFA (meaning the star or asterism so called) instead of naSorFA:]) so by poetic licence: (M:) IJ says that for this reason the poet has elided the second Y, but should have restored the first Y to w, because it is originally w. (TA. [But this assertion, respecting the first Y, I regard as improbable.]) ↓ A^ayoma, also, is a contraction of A^aY~u maA, meaning A^aY~u $aYo'K: so in the saying, A^ayoma huwa yaA fulaAnu [What thing is it, O such a one?]: and A^ayoma taquwlu [What thing sayest thou?]. (TA in art. Aym.) In like manner, also, ↓ A^ayo$a is used as a contraction of A^aY~u $aYo'K. (Ks, TA in art. jrm.) A poet speaks of his companions as being biA^aYa waA^ayonamaA; making A^aY~ the name of the quarter (jihap); so that, being determinate and of the feminine gender, it is imperfectly declinable. (M. [See A^aynN; under which head two other readings are given; and where it is said that the verse in which this occurs is by Homeyd Ibn-Thowr.]) A^aY~ is never without a noun or pronoun to which it is prefixed, except in a vocative expression and when it is made to conform with a word to which it refers, as in cases to be exemplified hereafter. (Mughnee.) Being so prefixed, it is determinate; but sometimes, [as in the latter of the cases just mentioned,] it is not so prefixed, yet has the meaning of a prefixed noun. (S.) When used as an interrogative, it is not governed, as to the letter, though it is as to the meaning, by the verb that precedes it, but by what follows it; as in the saying in the Kur [xviii. 11], linaEolama A^aY~u AlHizobayoni A^aHoSaY [That we might know which of the two parties was able to compute]; and in the same [xxvi. last verse], wasayaEolamu A@l~a*ayna ZalamuwA A^aYa munoqalabK yanoqalibuwna [And they who have acted wrongly shall know with what a translating they shall be translated]: (Fr, * Th, Mbr, T, S: *) when it is governed by the verb before it, it has not the interrogative meaning, as will be shown hereafter. (Fr, T.) In the saying of the poet,
taSiyHu binaA Haniyfapu A_*o raA^atonaA
waA^aY~a AlA^aroDi ta*ohabu lilS~iyaAHi
[Haneefeh (the tribe so named) shout to us when they see us. And to what place of the earth, or land, will they go for the shouting?], A^aY~ is in the accus. case because the prep. A_ilaY is suppressed before it. (S.) When they separate it [from what follows it, not prefixing it to another noun], the Arabs say A^aYN, and in the dual A^ay~aAni, and in the pl. A^ay~uwna; and they make it fem., saying A^ay~apN, and [in the dual] A^ay~ataAni, and [in the pl.] A^ay~aAtN: but when they prefix it to a noun, properly so called, not a pronoun, they make it sing. and masc., saying A^aYu Alr~ajulayoni [Who, or which, of the two men?], and A^aYu AlmaroA^atayoni [Who, or which, of the two women?], and A^aY~u Al~rijaAli [Who, or which, of the men?], and A^aY~u Aln~isaA='i [Who, or which, of the women?]: and when they prefix it to a fem. pronoun, they make it masc. [as when they prefix it to a masc. pronoun] and fem., saying A^ay~uhumaA and A^ay~atuhumaA [Who, or which, of them two?], meaning women; (Fr, T;) [the latter of which seems to be the more common; for ISd says,] sometimes they said A^ay~uhun~a [Who, or which, of them? referring to women], meaning A^ay~atuhun~a. (M.) It is said in the Kur [xxxi. last verse], wamaA tadoriY nafosN biA^aY~i A^arDK tamuwtu [And a person knoweth not in what land he will die]: (S:) but some read biA^ay~api A^aroDK; and Sb compares this fem. form to kul~atuhun~a. (Bd.) When it is used as an interrogative relating to an indeterminate noun in a preceding phrase, A^aY~ is made to conform with that indeterminate noun in case-ending and in gender and in number; and this is done [alike, accord. to some,] in the case of its connexion with a following word and in the case of a pause; so that, [in the case of a pause,] to him who says, jaA='aniY rajulN [A man came to me], you say, [accord. to the authorities alluded to above,] A^aY~N [Who?]; and to him who says, raA^ayotu rajulFA [I saw a man], A^ay~aA [Whom?]; and to him who says, mararotu birajlK [I passed by a man], A^aY~K [Whom?]: and in like manner, [accord. to all authorities,] in the case of its connexion with a following word; as A^aY~u yaA fataY [Who, O young man?], and A^ay~aA yaA fataY [Whom, O young man?], and A^aYK yaA fataY [Whom, O young man?]: and in the case of the fem. you say, A^ay~apN and A^ay~apF and A^ay~apK [in the nom. and accus. and gen. respectively]; and in the dual, A^ay~aAni and A^ay~ataAni in the nom. case [masc. and fem. respectively], and A^ay~ayoni and A^ay~atayoni in the accus. and gen. cases [masc. and fem. respectively]; and in the pl., [with the like distinction of genders,] A^ay~uwna and A^ay~aAtN in the nom. case, and A^ay~iyna and A^ay~aAtK in the accus. and gen. cases. (I' Ak p. 319.) [Exs. in cases of pause, agreeing with the foregoing rules, are given in the T; and exs. in cases of connexion with following words, agreeing with the foregoing, are given in the Mughnee: but J gives rules differing from the foregoing in some respects; and IB gives rules differing in some points both from the foregoing and from those of J.] It is said in the S, A^aY~ is made to conform with indeterminate nouns significant of intellectual beings and of nonintellectual things, and is used as an interrogative; and when it is thus used in reference to an indeterminate noun, you make it to have a caseending like that of the noun respecting which it demands positive information; so that when it is said to you, mar~abiY rajulN [A man passed by me], you say, A^aY~N yaA fataY [Who, O young man?], thus giving it a case-ending [like that of rajulN] when it is in connexion with a following word; and you indicate the case-ending [by the pronunciation termed Alr~awomu, saying A^aY~u, with a somewhat obscure utterance of the final vowel,] in pausing; and if one says, raA^ayotu rajulFA [I saw a man], you say, A^ay~aA yaAfataY [Whom, O young man?], giving it a case-ending [like that of rajulFA], with tenween, when it is [thus] in connexion with a following word; and you pause upon the A, saying A^ay~aA; and when one says, mararotu birajulK [I passed by a man], you say, A^aY~K yaAfataY [Whom, O young man? in a case of connexion with a following word; and A^aY~i in a case of pausing]: you conform with what the other has said, in the nom. and accus. and gen. cases, in the case of connexion with a following word and in that of pausing: but IB says that this is correct only in the case of connexion with a following word; for in the case of a pause, you say only A^aY~o, in the nom. and gen., with sukoon; and you imitate in both of these cases only when you use the dual form or the pl.: it is added in the S, you say in the cases of the dual and pl. and fem. like as we have said respecting mano: when one says, jaA='aniY rijaAlN [Men came to me], you say, A^ay~uwno [Who?], with the n quiescent; and A^ayiyno in the accus. and gen.: but IB says, the correct
mode is to say, A^ay~uwna and A^ay~ina, with fet-h to the n in both; [meaning that this is the only allowable mode in the case of connexion with a following word, and app. that it is the preferable mode in the case of a pause;] the quiescent n being allowable only in the case of a pause, and with respect to mano, for you say manuwno and maniyno with the quiescent n only: it is then added in the S, you say, also, A^ay~aho [Who? and whom?] in using the fem. [in a case of pause]; but in a case of connexion with a following word, [when referring to a noun in the accus.,] you say, A^ay~apF yaA h`*aA [Whom, O thou? in the sing.], and A^ay~aAtK [in the pl.; and in like manner, A^ay~apN in the nom. sing., and A^ay~apK in the gen. sing.; and A^ay~aAtN in the nom. pl., and A^ay~aAtK in the gen. pl.]: but when the interrogation refers to a determinate noun, A^aY~ is in the nom. case (with refa) only. (TA.) [See also A^ay~aAna, below.] ― -b2- [In other cases, now to be mentioned, it is used alike as sing., dual, and pl.] ― -b3- It also denotes a condition; (T, S, M, Mughnee;) in which case, also, it is a decl. noun, applied to an intellectual being and to a non-intellectual thing. (S.) So in the saying, A^ay~uhumo yukorimoniY A^ukorimohu [Whichever of them treats me with honour, I will treat him with honour]. (S.) So, too, in the saying [in the Kur xvii. 110], A^ay~FA maA tadoEuwA falahu AlA^asomaA='u AlHusonaY [Whichever ye call Him, He hath the best names]. (T, * Mughnee.) And in the saying [in the same, xxviii. 28], A^ay~amaA A@loA^ajalayoni qaDayotu falaA EudowaAna EalaY~a [Whichever of the two terms I fulfil, there shall be no wrongdoing to me]. (Mughnee.) One says also, SaHibahu A@ll~`hu A^ay~aA maA tawaj~aha, meaning A^ayonamaAtawaj~aha [May God accompany him wherever he goeth]. (AZ, T.) And Zuheyr uses the expression A^ay~apF salakuwA for A^ay~apa wijohapK salakuwA [Whatever tract they travelled, or travel]. (T.) The saying, A^ay~iY waA^ay~uka kaAna $ar~aA faA^axozaAhu A@ll~`hu [Whichever of me and thee be evil, may God abase him !] was explained by Kh to Sb as meaning A^ay~unaA kaAna $ar~FA [whichever of us two be evil]; and as being like the saying, A^axozaY A@ll~`hu AlkaA*iba miniY~ waminoka, meaning min~aA. (M. [And in a similar manner, the former clause of that saying, occurring in a verse, with maA after A^ay~iY, is said in the T to have been explained by Kh to Sb.]) ― -b4- It is also a conjunct noun; (Mughnee;) [i. e.] it is sometimes used in the manner of Al~a*iY, and therefore requires a complement; as in the saying, A^ay~uhumo fiY Ald~aAri A^axuwka [He, of them, who is in the house is thy brother]: (S:) [i. e.] it is syn. with Al~a*iY. (M, Mughnee.) So in the saying [in the Kur xix. 70], vum~a lananoziEan~a mino kul~i $iyEapK A^ay~uhumo A^a$ad~u EalaY Alr~aHom`ni Eutiy~aA [Then we will assuredly draw forth, from every sect, him, of them, who is most exorbitantly rebellious against the Compassionate]: so says Sb: but the Koofees and a number of the Basrees disagree with him, holding that the conjunct noun A^aY~ is always decl., like the conditional and the interrogative: Zj says, “It has not appeared to me that Sb has erred except in two instances, whereof this is one; for he has conceded that it is decl. when separate, and how can he say that it is indecl. when it is a prefixed noun?” and El-Jarmee says, “I have gone forth from El-Basrah, and have not heard, from my leaving the Khandak to Mekkeh, any one say, laA^aDoriban~a A^ay~uhumo qaAy^imN [as meaning I will assuredly beat him, of them, who is standing], with damm:” these assert, that it is, in the verse above, an interrogative, and that it is an inchoative, and A$d is an enunciative: but they differ as to the objective complement of the verb: Kh says that this is suppressed, and that the implied meaning is, we will assuredly draw forth those of whom it will be said, Which of them is most &c.? and Yoo says that it is the proposition [Ayh~m &c.], and that the verb is suspended from governing, as in the instance in the Kur xviii. 11, cited above: and Ks and Akh say that it is kl~ $yEp, that mn is redundant, and that the interrogative proposition is independent of what precedes it; this being grounded on their saying that the redundance of mino is allowable in an affirmative proposition: but these [following] facts refute their sayings; viz. that the suspension of government is peculiar to verbs significant of operations of the mind; and that it is not allowable to say, laA^aDoriban~a AlfaAsiqu, with refa, as meaning by implication “I will assuredly beat him of whom it is said, He is the transgressor;” and that the redundance of mino in an affirmative proposition is not correct. (Mughnee. [Some further remarks on the same subject, in that work, mentioning other opinions as erroneous, I omit. Another reading of the passage in the Kur cited above (xix. 70) will be found in what here follows.]) [ISd states that] they said, laA^aDorban~a A^ay~uhumo A^afoDalu [I will assuredly beat him, of them, who is most excellent], and A^aY~N A^afoDalu [him who is most excel-lent]; AY~ being indecl., accord. to Sb, and therefore the verb does not govern it [save as to the meaning]. (M.) And [that] you say, AiDoribo A^ay~uhumo A^afoDalu [Beat thou him, of them, who is most excellent], and A^ay~ahumo A^afoDalu [meaning the same, or whichever of them, &c.]; suppressing the relative huwa after Ay~hm. (M in a later part of the same art.) Fr says that when A^aY~ is governed by the verb before it, it has not the interrogative meaning; and you may say, laA^aDoriban~a A^ay~ahumo yaquwlu *`lika [I will assuredly beat him, of them, or whichever of them, says that]: and he says that he who reads A^ay~ahumo, in the accus. case, in the passage of the Kur cited above (xix. 70) makes it to be governed by lananoriEan~a. (T.) Ks says, you say, laA^aDoriban~a A^ay~ahumo fiY Ald~aAri [I will assuredly beat him, of them, or whichever of them, is in the house]; but you may not say, Darabotu A^ay~ahumo fiY Ald~aAri: thus he distinguishes between the actual occurrence and that which is expected. (S.) Akh says, also, that it may be indeterminate and qualified by an epithet; as when one says, mararotu biA^aY~K muEojibK laka, like as one says, bimano muEojibK laka [I passed by one pleasing to thee]: but this has not been heard [from the Arabs]. (Mughnee.) ― -b5- It also denotes perfection, or consummateness: and in this case it is an epithet applying to an indeterminate noun; as in zayodN rajulN A^aY~u rajulK (tropical:) [Zeyd is a man; what a man!], meaning that he is complete, or consummate, in the qualities of men: and it is a denotative of state relating to a determinate noun; as in mararotu biEabodi A@ll~`hi A^aY~a rajulK (tropical:) [I passed by 'Abd-Allah; what a man was he!]: (Mughnee:) and used in this sense, it is tropical. (Har p. 534.) [J says,] it is sometimes an epithet applying to an indeterminate noun: you say, mararotu birajulK A^aY~i rajulK and A^ay~imaArajulK (assumed tropical:) [I passed by a man; what a man!]; and mararotu biA@moraA^apK A^ay~api A@moraA^apK (assumed tropical:) [I passed by a woman; what a woman!], and biA@moraA^atayoni A^ay~atimaA A@moraA^atayoni [by two women; what two women!]; and h`*ihi A@moraA^apN A^ay~apu A@moraA^apK (assumed tropical:) [This is a woman; what a woman!]: and A^ay~atumaA A@moraA^a A^ay~apu A@moraA^apK (assumed tropical:) [What two women!]; mA being redundant: and in the case of a determinate noun, you say, h`*aA zayodN A^ay~amaA rajulK (assumed tropical:) [This is Zeyd; what a man is he!]; putting it in the accus. case as a denotative of state; and h`*ihi A^amapu A@ll~`hi A^ay~atamaA jaAriy~pK (assumed tropical:) [This is the handmaid of God; what a girl, or young woman, is she!]: you say, also, [in using an indeterminate noun,] A^aY~u A@moraA^apK jaA='atoka and jaA='aka, and A^ay~apu A@moraA^apK jaA='atoka (assumed tropical:) [What a woman came to thee!]; and mararotu bijaAriyapK A^aY~i jaAriyapK (assumed tropical:) [I passed by a girl, or young woman; what a girl, or young woman!]; and jiy^otuka bimulaA='apK A^aY~i mulaA='apK and A^ay~api mulaA='ipK (assumed tropical:) [I brought thee a body-wrapper; what a body-wrapper!]: all are allowable. (S.) [In all these it evidently denotes admiration, or wonder, at some good or extraordinary quality in the person or thing to which it relates; notwithstanding that J says afterwards,] and sometimes it is used to denote wonder; as in the saying of Jemeel,
buvayona A@lozamiY laA A_an~a laA A_ino lazimotihi
EalaY kavorapi AlwaA$iyna A^aY~u maEuwni
(assumed tropical:) [O Butheyneh, (buvayona being a curtailed form of buvayonap, a woman's name,) adhere thou to “No:” verily “No,” if thou adhere to it, notwithstanding the numbers of the slanderers, what a help will it be!]: (S:) i. e., an excellent help will be thy saying “No” in repelling, or rebutting, the slanderers, though they be many. (TA in art. Ewn.) Fr gives as exs. of its use to denote wonder the sayings, A^aY~u rajulK zayodN [What a man is Zeyd!], and A^aY~u jaAriyahK zayonabu [What a girl, or young woman, is Zeyneb!]. (T.) It denotes wonder at the sufficiency, and great degree of competence, of the person [or thing] to whom [or to which] it relates. (M.) El-Kattál El-Kilábee says,
walam~aA raA^ayotu A^an~aniY qado qatalotuhu
nadimotu Ealayohi A^aY~a saAEapi manodami
[And when I saw that I had slain him, I repented of it; in what an hour, or time, of repentance!]: i. e., when I slew him, I repented of it, in a time when repentance did not profit: AY~ being here in
the accus. case as an adv. n.; for, as it denotes the part of a whole, its predicament is made to be the same as that of the affixed noun, of whatever kind this may be. (Ham p. 95.) ― -b6- It also has k prefixed to it; and thus it becomes changed in signification so as to denote numerousness, being syn. with the enunciative kamo [How many!]; (S, K;) or syn. with rub~a [as meaning many]: (Sb, M:) [and sometimes it is syn. with the interrogative kamo, meaning how many? or how much? as will be shown below:] thus it is written kaA^aY~K, (M,) or kaA^ay~ino, (S, M, K,) its tenween being written n; (S, K;) and kaA='K, (M,) or [more commonly] kaAy^ino, (S, M, K, [in some copies of the S and K kaAyino,]) like kaAEino, (S,) said by IJ, on the authority of Aboo-'Alee, to be formed from kaA^ay~ino, by putting the double Y before the ', after the manner of the transposition in qisiY~N and a number of other words, so that it becomes kay~aA^K [or kay~ay^ino], then suppressing the second Y, as is done in may~itN and hay~inN and lay~inN, so that it becomes kaYo'K [or kaYo'ino], and then changing the [remaining] Y into A, as in [Tayoy^iY~N, which becomes] TaAdiY~N, and in [HiyriY~N, which becomes] HaAriY~N, so that it becomes kaA='K [or kaAy^ino]; (M;) and it has other dial. vars.; namely kayoy^inN [one of the intermediate forms between kaA^ay~ino and kaAy^ino mentioned above]; (K; [in one copy of the K written kayay~ino, and so accord. to the TK;]) and kaA^oYK, (M, K,) of the measure of ramoYK, and most probably formed by transposition from kaYo'K, mentioned above; (M;) and kaA^, of the measure of EamK, (M, TA,) incorrectly written in the copies of the K kaA'K, i. e. like kaAEK, (TA,) formed by the suppression of Y in kaYo'K; a change not greater than that from A^ayomunu A@ll~`hi to mu A@ll~`hi and mi A@ll~`hi. (M.) You say, kaA^ay~ino rajulFA laqiytu [How many a man have I met! or many a man &c.], (S, K, *) putting the noun following kA^y~n in the accus. case as a specificative; (S;) and kaA^ay~ino mino rajulK laqiytu; (S, K; *) and the introduction of mino after kaA^y~n is more common, and better. (S. [And Sb, as cited in the M, says the like.]) You say also, kaA^ay~ino qado A^ataAniY rajulFA [How many a man has come to me! or many a man &c.]. (Sb, M.) And bikaA^ay~ino tabiyEu h`*aA Alv~awoba, i. e. bikamo tbyE [For how much wilt thou sell this garment, or piece of cloth?]. (S.) Kh says that if any one of the Arabs made it to govern the gen. case, perhaps he did so by making mino to be implied, as is allowable with kamo: (M:) [so that you may say, bikaA^ay~ino dirohamK A@$otarayota h`*aA For how many a dirhem didst thou buy this? for] it is allowable to make the noun that follows kamo to be governed in the gen. case by mno implied, when km immediately follows a preposition; as in bikDmo dirohamK A@$otarayota h`*aA; but when it is not thus preceded by a preposition, the noun after it must be in the accus. case. (I 'Ak p. 317.) It always holds the first place in a proposition, like kamo. (Idem, next p.) ― -b7- It is also a connective of the vocative yaA with the noun signifying the person or persons or thing called, when this noun has the article Al prefixed to it; (S, M, Mughnee, K;) and with a noun of indication, as *aA; and with a conjunct noun having Al prefixed to it, as Al*~iY: (I 'Ak p. 268:) it is a noun formed for serving as such a connective; (M, K;) and has haA affixed to it. (S, M, &c.) You say, yaA A^ay~uhaA Alr~ajulu [which seems to be best rendered O thou man; more agreeably with the original, O thou, the man; or, accord. to Akh, O thou who art the man; lit., O he who is the man; often written yaA^ay~uhaA]; (T, S, M, Mughnee, K;) and yaAA^ay~uhaA Alr~ajulaAni [O ye two men]; and yaAA^ay~uhaA Alr~ijaAlu [O ye men]; (M;) and yaAA^ay~atuhaAAlmaroA^apu [O thou woman]; (S, M;) and yaA A^ay~atuhaA AlmaroA^ataAni [O ye two women]; and A^ay~atuhaA Aln~sowapu [O ye women]; and yaAA^ay~uhaA AlmaroA^apu, and AlmaroA^ataAni, and Aln~isowapu; (M;) and yaAA^ay~uhaA *aA [O thou, this person or thing]; and yaA A^ay~uhaA Al~a*iY faEala ka*aA [O thou who didst, or hast done, thus]. (I 'Ak p. 267.) In the first of the exs. here given, A^aY~ is a noun of vague signification, (Zj, T, S,) denoting the person called, (Zj, T,) of the sing. number, (Zj, T, S,) rendered determinate by the vocative [yA], (S,) indecl., with damm for its termination; (Zj, T, S;) and haA is a particle employed to rouse attention, or to give notice, a substitute for the noun to which A^aY~ is in other cases prefixed; and Alr~ajulu is a qualificative to A^aY~, (Zj, T, S,) wherefore it is in the nom. case. (S.) Akh asserts, [as we have indicated above,] that A^aY~ is here the conjunct noun, and that the first member of its complement, namely the relative huwa, is suppressed; the meaning being, yaA mano huwa Alr~ajulu: but this assertion is refuted by the fact that there is no relative pronoun that must be suppressed, nor any conjunct noun that necessarily requires that its complement should be a nominal proposition: though he might reply to these two objections by arguing that mA in the saying laA siy~amaA zayodN is in like manner [virtually] in the nom. case [as a conjunct noun syn. with Al~a*iY, and that the first member of its complement, namely huwa, an inchoative of which zayodN is the enunciative, is suppressed]. (Mughnee.) The putting of the qualificative of A^aY~ in the accus. case, as in the saying yaA A^ay~uhaA Alr~ajula A^aqobilo [O thou man, advance], is allowed (M, K) by El-Mázinee; but it is not known [as heard from the Arabs]. (M.) A^ay~uhaA and A^ay~atuhaA are also used for the purpose of particularizing; [in which case they are not preceded by yA;] as when one says, A^am~aA A^anaA faA^afoEalu ka*aA A^ay~uhaA Alr~ajulu [As for me, I will do thus, or such a thing, thou man], meaning himself; and as in the saying of Kaab Ibn-Málik, related in a trad., fataxal~afonaA A^ay~atuhaA Alv~alaAvahu [And we remained behind, or held back, ye three], meaning, by the three, those particularized as remaining behind [with him], or holding back. (TA.)
A^ayaA * : see art. AyA. -A2- A^ayFA: see the next paragraph.

A_iyaA Al$~amosi * , [the former word, when alone and indeterminate, perhaps (as when determinate) without tenween, for it is-explained (with its dial. vars.) in the S and K in bAb AlAlf Ally~np, though it is also explained in some copies of the S in the present art.,] and Al$ms ↓ A^ayaApu, (T, S, M, Mgh, K,) and Al$ms ↓ A^ayaApu, (S, M, K,) and ↓ A^ayaA='u Al$ms, (T, M, Mgh, K, and in a copy of the S,) with fet-h and medd, (T, Mgh, K, and so in a copy of the S,) The light of the sun, (S, M, Mgh, K,) and its beauty: (M, K:) or its rays, and its light: (T:) or, as some say, Al$ms ↓ AyAp signifies the halo of the sun; that, with respect to the sun, which is like the haAlap with respect to the moon; i. e. the daArap around the sun: (S:) the pl. [of A^ayaApN] is ↓ A^ayFA and A_iyaA='N; [or rather the former is a coll. gen. n.;] like A^akamN and A_ikaAmN in relation to A^akamapN. (M.) Tarafeh says, (T, S, Mgh,) describing the fore teeth (vagor) of his beloved, (EM p. 62,)
Al$~amosi A_il~aA livaAtihi ↓ saqatohu A_iyaApu
[The light of the sun has shed its lustre upon them, except their gums]. (T, S, Mgh.) ― -b2- And hence, by way of comparison, (M,) A_iyaA Aln~abaAti, and ↓ A^ayaAw^uhu, (M, K,) and ↓ A_iyaAtuhu, and ↓ A^ayaAtuhu, (K,) (tropical:) The beauty of herbage, (M, K,) and its blossoms, (M,) and brightness, (K, TA,) in its verdure and growth. (TA.) -A2- A^ayaA A_iyaAhu A^aqobilo: see A^ayaA, in art. AyA.
A^ayaA=' * : see the next preceding paragraph, throughout.
A^ayaApN * : se the next preceding paragraph, throughout.
A_iyaApN A_yA A_yAh AyAh AyAp : see the next preceding paragraph, throughout.
A^uyay~apN * dim. of A='N: see the letter A.
A_iyay~apN Ayyh Ayyp dim. of A=yapN, q. v. (T.)
A^ay~aA * : see A_iy~aA, in art. AyA.

A_iy~aA A^y A^yA AyA |yA : see art. AyA. [Az says,] I have not heard any derivation of A_iy~aA; but I think, without being certain, that it is from taA=yayotuhu as explained above; as though it were a noun from that verb, of the measure fiEolaY, like *ikoraY from *akarotu; so that the meaning of A_iy~aAka is I direct myself, or my aim, to, or towards, thee, and thy person. (T.)

A^ay~iY~N * [a rel. n. of A^aY~N]. When you ask a man respecting his kuwrap [i. e. district, or city, or town], you say, AaloA^ay~iY~u [The person of what district, &c., art thou?]; like as you say, in asking him respecting his qabiylap [or tribe], AalomaniY~u [from mano]: and you say also, A^ay~iY~N A^anota [A person of what district, &c., art thou?]; and manY~N (T.) [See also maniY~N, in art. mn.]

A^ay~aAna * : see art. Ayn. Lth says that it is used in the manner of mataY; [signifying When?]; and that some say its n is radical; others, that it is augmentative: (T:) IJ says, it must be from A^aY~N, not from A^ayona, for two reasons: first, because A^ayona denotes place; and A^ay~aAna, time: and secondly, because nouns of the measure faE~aAl are few; and those of the measure faEolaAn, many: so that if you
name a man A^ay~aAn, it is imperfectly decl.: and he adds, that A^aY~N means a part of a whole; so that it applies as properly to times as it does to other things: (TA:) Fr says that it is originally A^aY~a A^awaAnK [at what time?]. (T.) One says, of a stupid, or foolish, person, laA yaEorafu A^ay~aAna [He knows not when]. (IB.)
A=Yo A=Y A=y : see A^aYo: -A2- and see also 2 in art. AwY. -A3- YN: see what next follows, in two places.

A=yapN A=yh A=yp
A sign, token, or mark, by which a person or thing is known; syn. EalaAmapN (IAar, T, S, M, Msb, K) and A^amaArapN: (M, K:) it properly signifies any apparent thing inseparable from a thing not equally apparent, so that when one perceives the former, he knows that he perceives the other, which he cannot perceive by itself, when the two things are of one predicament; and this is apparent in the object of sense and in that of the intellect: (Er-Rághib, TA:) it is of the measure faEolapN, (M, K,) originally A^ay~apN; the [former] Y being changed to A because the letter before it is with fet-h, though this is an extraordinary change: (M:) this is related as on the authority of Sb: (TA:) or it is of the measure faEalapN, (M, K,) accord. to Kh; (M;) originally A^awayapN; (S;) [for, accord. to J and Fei,] Sb said that its medial radical letter is w, and that the final is Y, because words of this class are more common than those of which the medial and final radical letters are both Y; (S, Msb;) and the rel. n. is A^awawiY~u: (S:) but IB says, Sb did not state that the medial radical letter of A=yapN is w, as J states; but he said that it is originally A^ayapN, and that the quiescent w is changed into A; and he relates of Kh, that he allowed the rel. n. of A=yapN to be ↓ A=y^iY~N and ↓ A=yiY~N and A=wiY~N; but as to A^awawiY~N, he says, I know not any one who has said it except J: (TA:) or it is of the measure faAEilapN, (S, Msb, K,) originally A=yayapN, contracted by the suppression of its final radical letter [with the preceding kesreh]: so accord. to Fr: [but see what follows (after the pls.), where this is said to be the opinion of Ks, and disallowed by Fr:] (S, Msb:) the pl. is A=yaAtN and ↓ A=YN, (S, M, Msb, K,) [or the latter is rather a coll. gen. n.,] and pl. pl. A=yaA='N: (M, K:) J says that one of its pls. is A=yaAYN; [and we find the same also in some copies of the K;] but this is a mistake for A=yaA='N, which is pl. of A=YN, not of A=yapN: (IB, TA:) and this pl., being of the measure A^afoEaAlN, has been adduced as evidence that the medial radical letter is Y, not w: (TA:) the dim. is ↓ A_iyay~apN, [of the measure fuEaylapN changed to fEayolapN because of the medial radical Y,] which, accord. to Fr, shows the opinion of Ks, that A=yapN is of the measure faAEilapN rendered defective by the suppression of its final radical letter, to be incorrect, because [Fr holds, in opposition to some others, that] a noun of this measure has not its dim. formed on the measure fuEayolapN unless it is a proper name. (T.) They said, AifoEalohu biA=yapi ka*aA [Do thou it at the sign of such a thing]; like as you say, biEalaAmapi ka*aA and biA^amaArapi. (M.) And [in this sense, as is indicated by the context in the M,] it is one of the nouns that are prefixed to verbs [as virtually governing the gen. case], (M, K, *) because of the nearness of its meaning to the meaning of time: (K:) as in the saying [of a poet],
biA=yapi tuqodimuwna Alxayola $uEovFA
[At the sign of your urging forward the horses, unsmoothed in their coats, or not curried; which means nearly the same as “at the time of your urging” &c.]. (M.) ― -b2- A sign as meaning an indication, an evidence, or a proof. (TA.) ― -b3- A sign as meaning a miracle; [and a wonder; for] A=yaAtu A@ll~`hi means the wonders of God. (TA.) ― -b4- An example, or a warning; (Fr, T, M, Msb, K;) as, for instance, the case of Joseph and his brethren, related in the Kur: (Fr, T:) pl. ↓ A=YN (M, K) and A=yaAtN. (Fr, T.) ― -b5- A message, or communication sent from one person or party to another; syn. risaAlapN. (TA.) ― -b6- The body, or corporeal form or figure or substance, (S, M, K,) of a man, (S,) which one sees from a distance; [as being a kind of sign;] or a person, or an individual; syn. $axoSN. (S, M, K.) ― -b7- A whole company of people: as in the saying, xaraja Alqawomu biA=yatihimo The people, or party, went forth with their whole company, not leaving behind them anything. (AA, S, M.) ― -b8- [Hence, accord. to some, A verse of the Kur-án; as being] a collection of words of the Book of God: (S:) or a connected form of words of the Kur-án continued to its breaking off; (K, TA;) accord. to Aboo-Bekr, so called because it is a sign of the breaking off: (TA:) or a portion of the Kur-án after which a suspension of speech is approvable: (Msb:) or a portion of the Kur-án denoting any statute, or ordinance, of God, whether it be [what is generally termed] an A=yap, [i. e. a verse,] or a chapter (suwrap), or an aggregate [and distinct] portion of the latter. (Er-Rághib, Kull, TA. *) [AlA=yapa, written after a quotation of a part of a verse of the Kur-án, means AiqoraA^i AlA=yapD Read thou the verse.]
A=yaA A=yA : see A^ayaA, in art. AyA.
A=y^iY~N * and A=yiY~N, accord. to Kh, rel. ns. of A=yapN, q. v. (IB.)
taA^ay~apN * , or taA_iy~apN or tay^iy~apN: see 5.

A^ayaA * a vocative particle, (S, M, K,) used in calling him who is near and him who is distant: [in the former case, like O: in the latter, like ho there, or soho, or holla:] you say, A^ayaA zayodu A^aqobilo [O Zeyd, advance: or ho there, or soho, or holla, &c.]: (S:) or J is in error in saying this: it is used in calling to him who is distant: (Mughnee, K:) so say Ibn-El-Hájib, in the Káfiyeh, and ElFakhr El-Járabardee; and the latter adds, or to him who is in a predicament like that of him who is distant, being sleeping or inadvertent; the person who calls thereby being eager for the person called to advance to him: (TA:) or not used in calling to him who is near: (K:) and h is substituted for its hemzeh; (M, K;) so that one says, hayaA. (M.) AZ says, I have heard them say, A^ayaA A_iyaAhu A^aqobilo. (T in baAbu AlA^alifaAti.) [Accord. to the TA, (art. A,) one says also A=yaA.]
A_iyaA Al$~amosi * , and Aln~abaAti; and A_iyaAp, and A^ayaAp, and A^ay~aA: see art. AY.

A_iy~aA A^y A^yA AyA |yA (S, M, K, &c.) and A^ay~aA, (M, K,) the latter form used by some, as related on the authority of Ktr; (M;) accord. to some, (M,) a noun of vague signification, (S, M, K,) used metonymically for a noun in the accus. case, (M,) with which are connected all the affixed pronouns that denote the accus. case: you say A_iy~aAnA [Thee] and A_iy~aAhu [him] and A_iy~aAYa [me] (S, K) and A_iy~aAnaA [us, &c.]: (S:) and the hemzeh is changed into w, so that you say wiy~aAka (S, M, K *) and way~aAka; (Ktr, IJ, M, K; *) and sometimes into w, so that you say wiy~aAka [and app. way~aAka also; both of which are used by some of the Arabs in the present day, very commonly in Egypt, for waA_iy~aAka as meaning maEaka; like as one says wazayodFA, meaning maEa zayodK]: (K:) the k and h and Y [&c.] are put to show the object meant, in order that the person addressed may be known from the absent [&c.]; and have no place in the analysis of a sentence, like the k in *`lika and A^araA^ayotaka: (S, M: in the former of which is added, and like the A and n in A^anota:) and this is identical with the opinion of Akh: (M, TA:) thus Ay~A is the noun, and what follows it is to denote allocution, [&c.,] and the two become as one thing; for nouns of vague signification are not prefixed to other nouns to govern them in the gen. case, nor are any of the pronouns, being themselves determinate. (S.) Ibn-Keysán says, (S, M,) some of the grammarians say that A_iy~aAka, altogether, is a noun; and he adds, but some say (M) that the k and h &c. are the nouns, and that Ay~A is a support thereto, because they cannot stand by themselves, (S, M,) like the k &c. which occupy the latter place in yaDoribuka &c.; so when the k &c. are put first, [as in A_iy~aAka Darabotu Thee I beat, or struck,] they are supported by AyA, and the whole becomes as one thing: (S:) and you may also say, Darabotu A_iy~aAYa [I beat, or struck, me]; because it is not allowable to say, DarabotuniY: (S as corrected by IB:) but you may not say, Darabotu A_iy~aAka [I beat, or struck, thee]; because you only require Ay~Ak when you cannot use the k [alone]; though you may say, Darabotuka A_iy~Aka [I beat, or struck, thee, thee]; because the k is made to be syntactically dependent upon the verb, so when you repeat it you require Ay~A. (S.) In the saying of the poet, (S,) Dhu-l-Isba' El-'Adwánee, (TA,)
kaA^an~aAyawoma qur~aY A_in~amaA naqotulu A_iy~aAnaA
[As though we, on the day of Kurrà, only killed ourselves], he has separated it from the verb only because the Arabs do not make the action of the agent to fall upon the agent itself by the adjunction of the pronoun: they do not say, qatalotuniY, but only qatalotu nafosiY: so the poet has used Ay~AnA in the same manner as A^anofusanaA. (S, TA.) Some of the grammarians say that A_iy~aA is prefixed to what follows it, governing it in the gen. case; and adduce as an evidence thereof a saying which see below, commencing with A_i*aA balaga Alr~ajulu. (S.)
Zj says that it is an explicit noun, [not a pronoun,] which is prefixed to all the pronouns, governing them in the gen. case; but only to pronouns; so that if one said, A_iy~aA zayodK Had~avotu, it would be bad. (M.) Kh holds that it is a pronoun prefixed to the k [&c.], governing it in the gen. case; (M, K;) and the like is related to have been the opinion of El-Mázinee: and Sb relates of Kh that he said, if any one were to say A_iy~aAka nafosaka [Thee, thyself], I would not severely blame him, for this k is [virtually] governed in the gen. case. (M.) But accord. to Akh, it is a simple, or uncompounded, pronoun, the ending of which becomes altered, as the endings of pronouns are wont to become, because of the varying of the numbers of the persons using them; (M, K; [in both of which the last of the word thus rendered is AlmDmryn; accord. to a copy of the M, AlmDmryn, i. e. AlmuDomiryna; in a copy of the K, without any syll. signs; and in the CK, AlmuDomarayoni; of which readings, I have followed that found in the M; supposing the meaning to be, that Ay~A has different endings according as it is used by one speaking to another, or by one speaking of another, or by one speaking of himself, or to, or of, two or more, and the like;]) and the k of Ay~aAk is like the k of *`lika, inasmuch as it is an indication of allocution only, divested of the idea of its being a sign of the pronoun. (M.) Of all these varying opinions, IJ says that he has found none to be correct when investigated, except that of Akh; with whose opinion, that stated in the begining of this art. is identical [except as to the affix, which is there said to be a pronoun, not merely a particle of allocution]. (M, TA.) Zj, being asked to explain the meaning of the phrase A_iy~aAka naEobudu, [in the Kur i. 4,] answered, Haqiytataka naEobudu [Thine essence we worship]; and said that it is derived from A=yapN, meaning “a sign by which a thing is known:” but IJ does not approve of this. (M.) [Respecting the phrase, faA_i*aA huwa A_iy~aAhaA, in which Ay~AhA is used in the place of a noun in the nom. case, and which is therefore disallowed by Sb, see A_i*aA.] ― -b2- It is also used for the purpose of cautioning, or putting one on his guard. (T, S.) You say, A_iy~aAka waAlA^asada [Beware thou of, or avoid thou, or remove thyself far from, the lion]: it is a substitute for a verb; as thou you said, baAEido: and you say also, hiy~aAka; like as you say A^araAqa and haraAqa: (S:) [or Ay~Ak in this case is governed by a verb understood: for] Ibn-Keysán says, when you say, A_iy~aAka wazayodFA [Beware thou of, or avoid thou, or remove thyself far from, Zeyd], you caution him whom you address against Zeyd, and the verb governing the accus. case is not apparent: the meaning is, A^uHa*~iruka zayodFA [I caution thee against Zeyd]; as though you said, A^uHa*~iruka A_iy~aAka wazayodFA [I caution thee, thee with Zeyd]; or as though you said, baAEido nafosaka Eano zayodK wabaAEid zayodFA Eanoka [Remove thyself far from Zeyd, and remove Zeyd far from thee]; so that the verb governs the word signifying the person cautioned and that signifying him against whom that person is cautioned: (TA:) [and Az says,] when you say, A_iy~aAka warukuwba AlfaAHi$api, the verb is suppressed: it is as though you said, A^uHa*~iruka rukuwba AlfaAHi$api [I caution thee against the committing of that which exceeds the bounds of rectitude]. (T.) Kh is related to have heard an Arab of the desert say, (T, * M, the latter on the authority of Sb.,) A_i*aAbalaga Alr~ajulu Als~it~iyna faA_y~aAhu waA_iy~aA Al$~awAb~ [When the man attains to sixty years, I caution him against, or let him avoid, the young women]; (T, S, M;) prefixing Ay~A to Al$wAb~, and putting the latter in the gen. case: (S:) but accord. to Akh, it is not allowable to say [thus, or] A_iy~aAka waA_iy~aA zayodK. (M.) Sometimes the w is suppressed, as in the saying of the poet,
faA_iy~aAka A_iy~aAka AlmiraA='a faA_in~ahu
A_ilaY Al$~ar~i daE~aA='N walil$~ar~i jaAlibu
[Then avoid thou, avoid thou obstinate disputation, for it is wont to invite to evil, and an attracter of evil]; meaning, A_iy~aAka waAlmiraA='a: i. e., A_iy~aAka waA^ano tumaAriya. (TA.) You say [properly], A_iy~aAka waA^ano tafoEala ka*aA [Beware thou of, or avoid thou, doing such a thing]: but [in strict propriety] you should not say, A_iy~aAka A^ano tafoEala ka*aA, without w. (S.) See also art. Ay.
A^ayaAyaA * (Lth, T, S, M, K) and A^ayaAyaho, (M,) or yaAyaA, (K,) and yaAyaho, (M, K,) A cry by which camels are chidden. (Lth, T, S, M, K.) [See 2 in art. Ay.]

div1.div2: Ayb For words which might be supposed to be properly mentioned under this head, see art. Aw~b.

div2.entryFree: 1 A=da A=d , aor. yay^iydu, inf. n. A^ayodN, He, (a man, AZ, T, &c.,) or it, (a thing, L,) was, or became, strong: (AZ, T, S, M, K, &c.:) and ↓ A=yd, inf. n. A_iyaAdN, he became possessed of strength. (AHeyth, T, L.) ― -b2- A=datN DiyaAfatuhu (tropical:) His coming as a guest was, or became, frequent. (A.) [See A^ay~idN.]

2 A^y~d * , inf. n. taA^oyiydN; (T, S, M, &c.;) and ↓ A=yd, (T, S, K,) of the measure faAEala, (S,) inf. n. muw^aAyadapN; (K;) or He strengthened: (S, M, L, Msb, K:) he aided, or rendered victorious. (L.) You say, A^y~dhu EalaY AlA^amori He strengthened him to accomplish the affair. (M, L.)
3 AaAoyada see 2.
4 A=yada see 1.

5 tA^y~d *
He, or it, (a thing, S,) became strengthened. (T, S, K.)

A=dN A=d
Strength; syn. SulobN, (M, L, K,) and quw~apN [which is one of the significations of SulobN, and that which is here meant]; as also ↓ A^ayodN [which is an inf. n.: see 1]. (S, M, K.)
A^ayodN * : see A=dN.

A^ay~idN *
Strong: (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) an epithet applied [to God, and] to a man. (S.) A poet says,
ramaY faA^aSaAba AlkulaY waAl*~uraY
A_i*aA Alqawosu wat~arahaA A^ay~idN
[lit. When a strong one strings the bow, he shoots, and hits the kidneys, and the tops of the humps of the camels]; meaning, when God strings [or stretches] the bow that is in the clouds, He casts fat into the kidneys and humps of the camels, by means of the herbage that is produced by the rain. (S.) ― -b2- A_in~ahu laA^ay~idu AlgadaA='i waAlEa$aA='i means (tropical:) Verily he is often present at the morning and evening meals. (A.)

A_iyaAdN A^yAd A_yAd AyAd yd
Anything by which a person or thing is strengthened, (M, L, K,) or guarded, defended, or protected: (T, L:) a thing by which one is protected, or veiled, or concealed: the side; shade, or shadow; or protection: a place of refuge: (M, L, K:) either side of anything, that strengthens it: (Lth, T:) anything that is in the vicinity of a thing: (T:) each wing of an army: (S, M, L, K:) earth that is put round a watering-trough or tank, or round a tent, (S, M, L, K,) to strengthen it, or to keep away from it the rain-water: (S, L:) any fortification: a fortified mountain: (M, L, K:) a mountain that is inaccessible, or difficult of access. (IAar, T.) [In the place of one signification, Golius gives “ cortex; ” having found lHAh in the place of lajaA^.] ― -b2- An elevated tract, or a heap, of sand. (M, K.) ― -b3- Abundance of camels [because they strengthen their owner]. (K.) ― -b4- The air; syn. hawaA='. (K.)
muw^oyadN * : see muw^ay~adN: -A2- and see what next follows.

muw^oyidN * , of the same measure as muw^ominN, A great, mighty, or severe, thing; (S, L, K;) a calamity: (T, S, M, L, K:) or, accord. to As, it is ↓ muw^oyadN, with fet-h to the Y, and signifies anything rendered strong, or hard, or severe. (L.) [See maA=widu, in art. Awd.)
muw^ay~adN * and ↓ muw^oyadN (the latter irreg., by rule being muw^aAyadN, TK,) Strengthened: (S, L, K:) aided; or rendered victorious: (L:) and the former, strong, applied to a building. (M.)

muw^ay~idN *
Strengthening: (S, L:) aiding; or rendering victorious. (L.) The dim. also has this form. (S.)
1 A=rahaA A=rhA , aor. yay^iyru, (T, S, and K in art. Awr,) inf. n. A^ayorN; (T, TA;) or A=rahaA, aor. yaw^uwru; (ISk, T;) or both; (K ubi suprà;) Inivit eam; he compressed her. (ISk, T, S, K.)

A^ayorN * The membrum virile; penis; veretrum: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A=yurN and A=yaArN (S, M, K) and [of mult.] A^uyuwrN (S, K) and A^uyurN. (L.) ― -b2- kaAna A^ayoruhu TawylFA is a phrase meaning (tropical:) He had many male children. (T, TA.)

A^uyaAriY~N *
Having a large membrum virile, or penis; (T, S, M, K;) like A^unaAfiY~N signifying “ having a large nose. ” (T.)

A^ay~aAru *
The [Syrian] month [corresponding to May, O. S.;] preceding HaziyraAnu, or (as written by Saadee Efendee, TA) HuzayoraAnu. (So in different copies of the K.)

A=y^irN *
Iniens. (T, S, TA.)
may^iyrN * pass. part. n. of 1, (T, S, TA,) of the same measure as maSiyrN; i. q. manoyuwkN. (TA.)
miy^oyarN * (K, TA, [in the CK may^iyr, and in Gol. Lex. miy^oyarN,]) Qui multum coit. (K.)

1 A^ayisa minohu * , (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. yaA^oyasu (S, Msb, K) and yaA^oyisu, (Msb,) inf. n. A^ayasN, (Msb,) or A_iyaAsN, (K,) or it has the same inf. n. as yay^isa, namely yaA^osN, (S,) with which ↓ A_iyaAsN is syn., (Mgh,) but this last is a contraction of A_iyA=sN, of the measure A_iyEaAsN, as determined by Az, and is not an inf. n. of A^ayisa as some think it to be, (Mgh, art. yy^is,) He despaired of it; syn. qniT: (K:) a dial. var. of yay^isa: (ISk, S, TA:) or it is not so, but is formed by transposition from yay^isa, because it has no [proper] inf. n.; and A_iyaAsN, the proper name of a man, is not to be adduced in evidence, for it is of the measure fiEaAlN from AlA^awosu, “ the act of giving: ” (Preface to the M, quoted in the TA:) if it were a dial. var. of yay^isa, they would say A_isotu for A^ayisotu: (M, TA:) and A^uyisa, incorrectly written A^uwysa, also signifies the same. (Mgh.) -A2- A^ayosa: see layosa.
2 Aay~asa see 4.

4 A=yasahu A=ysh A=ysp
He made him to despair; (K;) like A^ayoA^asahu; (S, Mgh;) and so ↓ A^y~shu, (S * K,) inf. n. taA^oyiysN. (S.)

A^ayisN * and ↓ A=yisN [Despairing]; part. ns. of A^ayisa. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A=yisapN [and accord. to Golius ↓ A^ayosaA='u, both properly meaning Despairing of the recurrence of the menstrual flux;] who has not menstruated in a period of five and fifty years. (KT.)
A^ayosaA=w^u * : see A^ayisN.
A_iyaAsN A_yAs AyAs : see 1.
A=yisN A=ys : see A^ayisN.
A^ayo$a * , for A^aY~u $aYo'K: see A^aY~N, in art. AY.

1 A=Da A=D , aor. yay^iyDu, inf. n. A^ayoDN, i. q. EaAda; (ISk, S, M, Msb, * K;) as in the phrase A=Da A_ilaY Al$~aYo'i [He returned to the thing, i. e. to the doing of the thing; he did the thing again, or a second time]. (K.) ― -b2- And i. q. rajaEa; (S, M, Msb, K;) as in the phrase A=Da A_ilaY A^aholihi [He returned to his family]. (S, M.) ― -b3- In the phrase faEalotu ka*aA ↓ A^ayoDFA, the last word is the inf. n. of A=Da in the sense of EaAda, (ISK, IDrd, S, M, Msb, *) and in the sense of rajaEa: (IDrd, M:) and the meaning is, [I did such a thing again, or a second time;] I returned to the doing of such a thing: (IDrd, M:) or I did such a thing returning to what had preceded. (Msb, K. *) [It also, and more commonly, signifies I did such a thing also.] When one says, ↓ faEalotu *`lika A^ayoDFA [I did that again, &c.], you say, ↓ qado A^akoyarota mino A^ayoDK [Thou hast made much use of the expression A^ayoDFA], and ↓ daEoniY mino A^ayoDK [Let me alone and cease from using the expression A^ayoDFA]. (ISk, S.) ― -b4- A^ayoDN also signifies (tropical:) A thing's becoming another, or a different, thing; and being changed from its state or condition [to another and a different state or condition]: (Lth, K: *) so says Kh. (Ham p. 356.) And A=Da ka*aA (tropical:) He, or it, became such a thing. (Lth, S, M, * K.) You say, A=Da sawaAdu $aEarihi bayaADFA (A, TA) (tropical:) The blackness of his hair became whiteness. (TA.) And Zuheyr says, speaking of a land which he traversed,
qaTaEotu A_i*aAmaAAlA=lu A=Da kaA^an~ahu
suyuwfN tunaH~aY saAEapF vum~a talotaqiY
[I traversed, when the mirage, or the mirage of the morning, became as though it were swords which were removed a while, then met]. (S.)
A^ayoDN * and A^ayoDFA: see above, in four places.

1 A^ayika AlA^araAku * , aor.
Aayaka , The [trees called] ArAk became what is termed A^ayokap [n. un. of A^ayokN, q. v.]; as also ↓ AstA^yk. (K.) The former occurs in poetry contracted into A^ayoka. (ISd, Sgh.)
10 A_isotaAoyaka see 1.

A^ayokN *
Numerous, luxuriant or tangled or dense, trees: (S, K:) or a place where water collects and sinks into the ground (gayoDapN) producing [trees of the kinds called] sidor and A^araAk (Lth, K) and similar soft trees: (Lth:) or a collection of any trees; even, of palm-trees: (K:) or, as some say, a place where [trees of the kind called] A^avol grow, and where is a collection of them: or, accord. to AHn, an abundant collection of A^araAk in one place: (TA:) or trees; said to be of the [kind called] A^araAk: (Msb:) n. un. with p: (S, Msb, K, &c.:) IAar says, [you say,] A^ayokapN A^avolK and rahoTN, and qaSiymapN. (Sh.) A^aSoHaAbu A@loA^ayokapi occurs in the Kur in four chapters: [xv. 78 and xxvi. 176 and xxxviii. 12 and 1.13:] (Sgh:) he who reads thus means, by the latter word, AlgayoDap [explained above, and also signifying the thicket, or collection of tangled trees, &c.]; (S, K;) or the tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, trees: (TA:) another reading is layokapa; accord. to which, this is the name of the town [in which the people here mentioned dwelt]: (S, K:) or, as some say, the two words are [applied to the same place,] like bak~apu and mak~apu: (S:) but Zj says that another reading is allowable, and very good; i. e. A^aSoHaAbu layokapi, as being originally AlA^yokapi; for the Arabs say, AalaHomaru qado jaA='aniY and laHomaru jaA=A_aniY for AlA^aHomaru; so that layokap is like laHomar. (TA.)

A^ayokN A^ayikN * , (K, TA,) like katifo, (TA, [agreeably with the verb, but in the CK A`yikN,]) is a phrase in which the latter word signifies muvomirN [Putting forth fruit; &c.]: (K, TA:) or, as some say, it is an intensive epithet [signifying very abundant or luxuriant or tangled &c.]. (M, TA.)

A_iylu A^yl A_yl Ayl |yl a name of God; (Lth, T, S, M, K;) a Hebrew word; (Lth, S;) or Syriac: (S:) it is a dial. var. of A_il~u [q. v.]: or the latter may be an arabicized form of the former: (Az, TA:) Ibn-El-Kelbee says that jaboray^iylu and miykaAy^iylu and the like are similar to Eabodu A@ll~`hi and Eaboda Alr~aHomaAni; (M;) [and J says,] they are like Eabodu A@ll~`hi and tayomu A@ll~`hi: (S:) so that jabor signifies “ servant, ” and is prefixed to Ayl, governing it in the gen. case: (M:) but this is not a valid assertion; for were it so, such names would be perfectly decl.: (M in art. Al:) Suh says, in the R, that jibry^yl is Syriac, and means Eabodu Alr~aHomaAni, or Eabodu AlEziyzi, as is related on the anthority of I'Ab: that most persons hold Ayl in this case to be a name of God: but that some hold names of this kind to be constructed inversely, after the manner of the language of the 'Ajam; Ayl meaning servant. (TA. [See what is said of A_il~u.])
A_iylapN A^yl A^ylh A^ylp Aylh Aylp |yl |ylh |ylp : see art. Awl.
A^ayoluwlu * [written by some A_iyluwlu] One of the Greek [or Syrian] months; (T, * M, Kzw;) the last thereof [corresponding with September, O. S.]. (Kzw.)
A_iyaAlN AyAl : see art. A_iyaAlapN.

1 A=mato A=mt , (T, M, Mgh, K,) aor. tay^iymu, (T, K,) inf. n. A^ayomapN, (T, M, Mgh, K,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb,) and A_iymapN and A^ayomN and A^uyuwmN, (M, K,) She had no husband; said of a virgin and of one who is not a virgin; (IAar, T, M, Mgh, K;) as also ↓ tA^y~mt (Lth, T, M) and ↓ Ay^tAmt: (M:) or, as some say, ↓ tA^y~mt signifies she lost her husband by his death, she being still fit for husbands, having in her a remaining force of youth: (T:) and you say, A=mato mino zawojihaA, aor. tay^iymu, inf. n. A^ayomapN and A^ayomN and A^uyuwmN, (S, TA, [accord. to the former app. signifying the same as A=mato alone as explained above: or]) meaning she became bereft of her husband by his death, or by his being slain, and remained without marrying. (TA.) And A=ma, (T, S, Msb,) aor. yay^iymu, (T, Msb,) inf. n. A^ayomapN, (T,) He had no wife: (T, Msb:) or he lost his wife by her death: (S, * K, * and Ham p. 650:) and he did not marry; as also ↓ tA^y~m. (Ham ubi suprà.) It is said of the Prophet, in a trad., kaAna yataEaw~a*u mina AlA^ayomapi (T, S) He used to pray for preservation from remaining long without a wife. (T.) And Yezeed Ibn-El-Hakam Eth-Thakafee says,
kul~u A@moriY'K satay^iymu minohu AlEirosu A^awominohaA yay^iymu
(S) i. e. Every man, the wife will be bereft of him by his death, or he will be bereft of her by her death. (Ham p. 531.) One says also,
maA lahu A=ma waEaAma, meaning [What aileth him?] May his wife and his cattle die, or perish, so that he shall have no wife (Hat~aY yay^yima) and be vehemently desirous of milk (yaEiyma). (S, K: [in the CK, erroneously, AmN w EAmN; and in a MS. copy of the K A=mN wlAEAmN.])

2 A^ay~amahu A@ll~`hu * inf. n. taA^oyiymN, God made him to have no wife. (K, * TK.) And A^ay~amotu AlmaroA^apa, inf. n. as above; (Ham p. 11, and TA; *) or ↓ A^aA^a motuhaA, like A^aEamotuhaA; (T, S;) I made the woman to be a widow, by slaying her husband. (T, * S, and Ham ubi suprà.) Taäbata-sharrà says,
faA^ay~amotu nisowaAnFA waA^ayotamotu A_ilodapF
[And I have made women widows, by slaying their husbands; and children fatherless]. (TA.)
4 A^aA^amotu AlmaroA^apa * : see 2.

5 taA^ay~amato * and tA^y~m : see 1, in three places. The former is also explained as signifying She became forlorn (taHaw~a$ato) of her husband. (K in art. Hw$.) And also, (TA,) or taA^ay~amato zamaAnFA, (ISk, T, S,) She remained some time without marrying. (ISk, T, S, TA.) And tA^y~m, (Msb, K,) or tA^y~m zamaAnFA, (ISk, T, S,) He remained some time without marrying. (ISk, T, S Msb, K.)

8 A@y^otaAmato * , written with the disjunctive alif AiytaAmato: see 1. -A2- A@y^otamotuhaA, (M, K,) like A@EotamotuhaA, (TA,) I took her as my wife, she being what is termed A^ay~im [without a husband]. (M, K.)

A^ayoma * is a contraction of A^aY~u maA, meaning A^aY~u $aYo'K: it is thus in the saying, A^ayoma huwayaA fulaAnu [What thing is it, O such a one?]: and A^ayoma taquwlu [What thing sayest thou?]. (TA.) -A2- Aayomu A@ll~`hi [for Aayomunu A@ll~`hi]: see in art. ymn. (K.)
A^ayam~u * , for A^aA^am~u: see art. Am.
A^ayomaA * : see A^am~aA: -A2- and A_im~aA.
A_ymaA A^ym A^ymA AymA : see A_im~aA.

A^ayomaAnu * A man whose wife has died: and A^ayomaY A woman whose husband has died: pl. A^ayaAmaY, of both; like as sakaAray is pl. of sakoraAnu: accord. to ISk, A^ayaAmaY is originally A^ayaAy^imu. (Msb.) [See also A^ay~imN.] A^ayomaAnu EayomaAnu are epithets applied to a man, (M, K, TA,) meaning Whose wife [and cattle] have died or perished [so that he has no wife and is vehemently desirous of milk; as shown above; see 1, last signification]: (TA:) the former relates to wives; and the latter, to milk: (S, K, TA:) fem. A^ayomaY EayomaY, applied to a woman. (M, K.)

A^ay~imN * A woman having no husband; (Lth, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) whether she be a virgin or not; (IAar, T, S, M, Mgh, K;) or whether she have married before or not; (Sgh, Msb;) as also A^ay~imapN; (Msb;) [said to be] applied to one who has not married: (IAar, T:) or if not a virgin; accord. to [the Imám] Mohammad; agreeably with a reading of a trad. by which the A^ay~im is distinguished from the virgin: (Mgh:) also, the former, a man having no wife; (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) whether he have married before or not: (S, Sgh, K:) or who has not married: (IAar, T:) pl. A^ayaAmaY (S, M, K) and A^ayaAy^imu; (M, K;) the latter of which is the original form: (S, M:) [or both, accord. to the Msb, are pls. of A^ayomaAnu, q. v.:] and A^ay~imuwna is a pl. applied to men, and A^ay~imaAtN applied to women: and A=mapN, also, signifying men having no wives, is pl. of ↓ A=y^imN for A^ay~imN. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A free woman: (K:) pl., in this sense also, A^ayaAmaY, used in this sense in the Kur xxiv. 32, (T, TA,) accord. to some. (TA.) ― -b3- And A female relation; (K;) in which sense also A^ayaAmaY is pl.; (T, TA;) meaning such as the daughter and the sister and the maternal aunt. (T, K.)
A=y^imN * : see A^ay~imN.
AlHarobu maA^oyamapN * (T, S, M, Msb, K) liln~isA='a (M, K) War is a cause of widowing to women; it slays the men, and leaves the wives without husbands. (T, S, M, Msb.)
muw^oyamapN * A rich, or wealthy, woman, or one possessing competence or sufficiency, having no husband. (Sgh, K.)
maA=y^imu * : see A=m~apN, in art. Am.

1 A=na A=n , [aor. yay^iynu,] inf. n. A^ayonN, [in a copy of the Msb, A^ayina, aor. yaA'anu, inf. n. A^ayanN, but as this is at variance with all other authorities known to me, I regard it as a mistranscription,] He was, or became, fatigued, or tired: (T, M:) so says IAar: (T:) and As says the like: (TA, from a marginal note in a copy of the S:) [see also what I have cited from the Mughnee voce A_in~a, last sentence:] in proof of this, IAar cites the following ex., from a poet:
A_in~aA warab~i AlquluSi AlD~awaAmiri
[We were, or have become, fatigued, by the Lord of the lean and lank-bellied youthful she-camels]: but Lth says that there is no verb derived from A^ayonN, in this sense, except in poetry: (T:) Aboo-Mohammad says that the only instance is that cited above: (TA:) [it is not disputed that] A^ayonN signifies fatigue, or the being fatigued or tired: (S, K:) AZ says that it has no verb formed from it; but on this point he has been contradicted: (S:) A 'Obeyd also says that it has no verb. (M.) -A2- A=na, aor. yay^iynu, inf. n. A^ayonN, (S, M, Msb, K, &c., [but see what follows,]) also signifies Its time came; (A^ataY waqotuhu;) as also A^anaY: (Bd lvii. 15:) it was, or became, present: it came, or attained, to its time; to its full, or final, time, or state; to maturity: it was, or became, or drew, near: syn. A^anaY: (M:) and A^adoraka; like A^anaY: (Ham p. 455:) and HaAna: (S, M, Msb, K:) and qaruba. (Mughnee voce A_in~a.) You say, A=na laka A^ano tafoEala ka*aA, aor. and inf. n. as above, (AZ, S,) i. e. HaAna [The time has come, or has drawn near, for thee to do, or that thou shouldst do, such a thing]; like A^anaY: and it is formed from it by transposition: (S:) [i. e.] A^anaY is formed by transposition from A=na: (Msb:) or A=na is a dial. var. of A^anaY; not formed from it by transposition, [nor is the reverse the case,] because of the existence of the inf. n. [of each]: (M:) or A=na is formed by transposition from A^anaY, because the latter has an inf. n. and the former has not: so says As: for A^ayonN does not belong to this; its meaning being only A_iEoyaA='N and taEabN: or, accord. to AZ, A=na has an inf. n., namely A^ayonN; and if the case be so, the two [verbs] are equal; neither being the original of the other: (IJ in the Khasáïs:) Suh, in the R, asserts that A=na is formed by transposition from A^anaY: (TA:) the assertion of El-Bekree, that A=na is originally with w [for its medial radical letter], and that it is of the class of waliYa, aor. yaliY, requires consideration, and involves what is contrary to rule. (MF.) You say also, A=na A^ayonuka, (S, M, K,) and A_iynuka, (M, K,) and A=nuka, (S, K,) i. e. HaAna Hiynuka [Thy time, or season, came, or hath come: or drew near, or hath drawn near]. (S, M, K.)

A=nN A=n : see A^ayonN. ― -b2- A@loA=na is a noun denoting the present time; (S, M, Msb, K;) [signifying At the present time; now; for] it is an adverbial noun; (S, Msb, K;) one which, in a place where it is fitting to be used as such, may not be used otherwise; occurring in a determinate sense; (S, K;) the Al being inseparable from it; (IJ, M, Msb;) not prefixed to it for the purpose of rendering it determinate, because it has not that which participates in its meaning: (S, Msb, K:) as Ibn-Es-Sarráj says, there is not one A=n and another A=n: (Msb:) [accord. to ISd, who quotes a long disquisition by IJ on this word,] the Al which is expressed in this case is redundant, because the noun is determinate without it, but it is rendered so by another Al, which is understood, as in the case of A^amosi: so says IJ, following Aboo-'Alee; and his is the correct opinion: (M:) Fr says that it is a particle, compounded with Al, which is inseparable from it; and that it is originally A^awaAna [or A@loA^awaAna]: or that it may have originated from the phrase A=na laka A^ano tafoEala [explained above], and is therefore mansoob, like qiyla and qaAla when used as nouns: but Zj disallows its originating from A=na; and says that the right opinion is that of Kh, that A@loA=na is indecl. with fet-h for its termination, and that the Al is prefixed because the meaning is h`*aA Alwaqot; and this is the opinion of Sb. (T.) You say, A^anaA A@loA=na A^afoEalu ka*aA [I, at the present time, or now, do, or will do, thus, or such a thing]. (M.) And kunotu A@loA=na Einodahu, meaning I was, in this time, of which part is present and some portions have passed, with him, or in his presence. (IJ, M.) And when you mean the kind of expression which is used in this saying, you say, AaloA=nu Had~u Alz~amaAnayoni [The term “ now ” is the limit of the two times; namely the past and the future]; thus pronounced, marfooa: so says IJ: but in the Book of Sb we read, AlA=na Had~u Alz~amaAnayoni, with nasb: and in like manner, in the same, AlA=na A=nuka [Now is thy time]; the former with nasb and the
latter with refa. (M.) You say also, h`*aA A^awaAnu A@loA=na [This is the present time]: and maA jiy^otu A_il~aA A^awaAna A@loA=na, meaning I came not save at the present time, or now: with the last word mansoob in both instances. (ISh, T.) [And A_ilaY A@loA=na and Hat~aY A@loA=na To the present time and until the present time; i. e. hitherto. And mina A@loA=na From the present time; henceforward.] Sometimes the hemzeh [after the l] is suppressed, and its vowel is transferred to the l; so that you say AlaAna. (Bd ii. 66.) And sometimes also the l is pronounced with fet-h and both the hemzehs are suppressed; so that you say laAna. (S, K.) And sometimes ta is prefixed to it, like as it is to Hiyna; so that you say talaAna, like as you say taHiyna. (El-Umawee, A 'Obeyd. [See art. tln.])

A^ayonN *
Fatigue. (S, K, &c.) [Whether it be a simple subst., or an inf. n., and, if the latter, whether it be an inf. n. of A=na only in the former of the two senses assigned to that verb above, or in both these senses, is doubted: see 1, throughout.] -A2- A time; a season; syn. HiynN; (S, M, K;) as also ↓ A_iynN (M, K) and ↓ A=nN. (S, K.) [See 1, last sentence.]

A^ayona * is an adverbial noun, (Msb,) an interrogative respecting a place: (S, M, Msb, K:) [signifying Where? in what place?]: Zj says that it is an interrogative particle, like kayofa: (T:) [ISd says,] it is a noun, because you say, mino A^ayona [meaning From what place? whence?]: (M:) [and you say also, A_ilaY A^ayona To what place? whither?]: it is always mansoob, unless you prefix the article to it, saying AlA^ayonu [which means The place where]: (Lth, T:) it is fem.; but may be made masc. (Lh, M.) You say, A^ayona zayodN Where, or in what place, is Zeyd? (S, Msb.) And A^ayona bayotuka [Where is thy house, or tent?]. (M.) And A^ayona yu*ohabu bika, which may mean Where, or whither, wilt thou be taken away, and what will be done with thee and made to come to pass with thee, if this be thine intellect? or, accord. to Mtr, it is a saying of the people of Baghdád, addressed to him whom they charge with foolish judgment or opinion, as meaning A^ayona yu*ohabu biEaqolika [Where, or whither, is thine intellect taken away?]. (Har p. 574.) [And A^ayona h`*aA mino *aAka and Eano *aAka and wa *aAka What place does this hold in relation to that, or in comparison with that? what is this in relation to that, or in comparison with that? what has this to do with that? what has this in common with that?] ― -b2- It also denotes a condition: when you say, A^ayona tajoliso A^ajoliso [Where thou sittest, I will sit], the sitting must be in one place: and maA is added to it; so that you say, A^ayonamaA taqumo A^aqumo [Wherever thou standest, I will stand]. (Msb.) ― -b3- It also occurs used as a proper name of a particular place: thus the poet Homeyd Ibn-Thowr speaks of his companions as being biA^ayona wa A^ayonamaA [app. meaning In certain places: where and wherever those places were, there were my companions]: in which case it is divested of the meaning of an interrogative, and is imperfectly decl. because determinate and of the fem. gender. (M, L. [In one copy of the former, biA^an~aY wa A^ayonamaA, which may mean the same; and voce A^aY~N, q. v., biA^aY~a wa A^ayonamaA.])
A_iynN A^yn A^ynn Ayn : see A^ayonN.

A^ay~aAna * , (T, S, M, &c.,) of the measure faE~aAl, or it may be of the measure faEolaAn, (Msb,) also pronounced ↓ A_iy~aAna, (T, S, M, K,) the latter of the dial. of Suleym, mentioned by Fr, (T, S,) and by Zj, (M,) is an interrogative respecting a time, (T, S, Msb,) but only respecting a time not come: (T:) signifying When? (S, M, Msb;) at what time? (Msb, K:) it is fem.; but may be made masc.: (Lh, M:) and it may be pronounced with imáleh, though not belonging to a class of words regularly subject to imáleh. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [xvi. 22 and xxvii. 67], accord. to different readings, A^ay~aAna yuboEavuwna or ↓ A_iy~aAni [When they shall be raised to life]; (T, S, M;) i. e. when shall be the resurrection. (Aboo-Is-hák, T.) But you may not say, A^ay~aAna faEalota *aAka as meaning When didst thou that? (T.) ― -b2- IJ says that, were it syn. with mataY, it would be conditional; whereas it was not mentioned by his colleagues among the adverbs used conditionally, as mataY and A^ayona &c.: but sometimes it has a conditional meaning, though that meaning be not explicit. (M.) A poet says,
A^ay~aAna nuw^ominoka taA^omano gayoranaA wa A_i*aA
lamo tudoriki AlA^amona min~aA lamo tazalo Ha*iraA
[When we grant thee security, thou wilt be secure from others than us; and when thou obtainest not security from us, thou wilt not cease to be in a state of fear]. (I 'Ak p. 300.)
A_iy~aAna A^yAn A_yAn AyAn : see A^ay~aAna, in two places.
A=y^inN * part. n. of A=na in both its senses. A=yinapN: see A^awaAnN.

2 Ay~h bihaA Ayh bhA , (S, TA,) and, accord. to some, bihimo (TA,) and bihi, (K, * TA,) inf. n. taA^oyiyhN, (S, K,) He cried out to, or shouted to, and called, (S, K, TA,) them, namely, camels, (S, TA,) and, accord. to some, horses, and men, (TA,) and him, (K, TA,) namely, a camel: (TA:) or Ay~h bh signifies he said to him, namely, a man, and a horse, yaA wayohaAho [Ho! On!]: (A 'Obeyd:) and he said to him, namely, a man, yaA A^ay~uhaA Alr~ajulu [O thou man]: (K:) or he called him, yA Ay~hA Alrjl: (IAth:) and he cried out to him, or at him; or drove him away with crying or a cry; namely, an object of the chase. (TA.)

[
A^ayoha * would seem to be a dial. var. of wayoha; for it is said that] A^ayohaka is syn. with wayohaka. (K: [but see wayoha.]) -A2- A^ayohFA: see A^ayohaAta.

A_iyho A^y A^yh A^yp A_yh Ayh Ayp |yp , with the h quiescent, is a word used in chiding, or checking; meaning Hasobuka [Sufficient for thee is such a thing; &c.]. (ISd, K.) ― -b2- A_iyhFA signifies, (S, K,) as also Ayha, (K,) a command to be silent, (S, K,) and to abstain; (S, TA;) i. e. Be silent; and abstain, or desist: (TA:) both are used in chiding, or checking: and hiyha is used in the place of A_iyha. (Lth, TA.) You say [also,] A_iyhFA Ean~aA Be silent, and abstain from [troubling] us. (S, TA.) And A_iyhaA Ean~iY A@loA=na Abstain thou from [Troubling] me now. (AZ, TA.) ― -b3- A_iyhFA also occurs as meaning I hold that to be true, and approve it. (IAth, TA.) -A2- A_iyhi, as also A_iyha and A_iyhK, is a word denoting a desire, or demand, for one to add, or to give, or do, more; (Lth, K;) and a desire for one to speak: (K:) it (i. e. A_iyhi) is an imperative verbal noun, (S,) indecl., with kesr for its termination: (K:) you say to a man, when you desire, or demand, his telling or saying more of a [certain] story or subject of discourse, or his doing more of a [certain] deed, A_iyhi, with kesr. to the h; (S;) [i. e. Tell me, or say, more of this; say on; go on, or proceed, with this; or do more of this;] and A@foEalo A_iyhi [Go on, or proceed, with this; do it]; (AZ;) and for A_iyhi, you say, hiyhi: (Lth:) but when you make no interruption after it, you pronounce it with tenween, (ISk, S, K,) and say A_iyhK, (ISk, S,) which means Had~ivonaA [i. e. Tell us, or relate to us, something]; (Ks, Lh, (ISk, * S; *) and for this one says hiyhK, by substitution of one letter for another: (Ks, Lh:) or it means zido [i. e. tell, or say, or do, something more]; and haAti [i. e. give, or relate, something]; (Har p. 592;) and takal~ama [i. e. speak]. (Idem p. 419.) In the following saying of Dhu-r-Rummeh,
waqafonaA wa qulonaA A_iyhi Eano A^um~i saAlimK
wa maA baAlu takoliymi Ald~iyaAri AlbalaAqiEi
[We stopped, and we said, Tell us some tidings: inform us (A^axobiriynaA being app. understood) respecting Umm-Sálim: but what is the case (meaning what is the use) of speaking to the vacant dwellings?], he has used the word without tenween, though making no interruption after it, because he intended a pause. (ISk, S.) Ibn-Es-Seree says, When you say, A_iyhi yaA rajulu, you only command him to tell you more of the subject of discourse known to you and him, as though you said, haAti AlHadiyva [Give, or relate, the story, or narrative, O man]: but if you say, A_iyhK, with tenween, it is as though you said, haAti HadiyvFA m~aA [Give, or relate, some story or narrative], because the tenween renders indeterminate: and Dhu-rRummeh meant the tenween, but omitted it through necessity. (S.) As says that Dhu-rRummeh has committed a mistake; the expression of the Arabs being only A_iyhK [in a case of this kind]: ISd says, the truth is, that it is without tenween when determinate, and with tenween when indeterminate; and that Dhu-r-Rummeh asks the ruins to tell him more of a known story, as though he said, Relate to us the story, or tell us the tidings: (TA:) Aboo-Bekr Ibn-Es-Sarráj says, citing this verse, that Ayh is not known in a case of this kind without tenween in any of the dialects; meaning that it is never conjoined with a following word unless it be with tenween. (IB, TA.)
A^ayohaA * : see what next follows.

A^ayohaAta *
i. q. hayohaAta [Far, or far from being believed or from the truth, is such a thing: or remoteness, or remoteness from being believed or from the truth, is to be attributed to such a thing.]: as also ↓ A^ayohaAni, (S, K,) and ↓ A^ayohaAna, (K, TA, in the CK AayohaAnu,) [and several other dial. vars., for which see hayohaAta,] and ↓ A^ayohaA, (TA; and so in some copies of the S and K; in other copies of these, ↓ A^ayohFA; [but the former is app. the right;]) with the n [or the t] suppressed, (TA,) which is said in pronouncing [a thing] to be remote [whether in a proper or a tropical sense]: (S, TA:) Th explains ↓ A^ayohaAni as meaning baEiydN *`lika AA explains it as meaning baEuda *`lika, making it a verbal noun; and this is the correct explanation: (TA:) or the meaning is AlbuEodu, [as I have indicated above,] (K in art. hyh,) but this is only when li is prefixed to what follows it, as Sb says. (TA. [See hayohaAta.])
A^ayohaAna * and A^ayohaAni: see A^ayohaAta, in three places.

A^ay~ihN *
Having a strong, or loud, voice; and vigilant, or wary. (Ham p. 675.)
A^ay~uhaA * : see A^aY~N; last portion of the paragraph.
